title: DUKE'S BODY FLOWN TO ENGLAND BY R.A.F.
description: OXFORD, England, May 31 (Reuters)  The body of the Duke of Windsor came home today to be buried in the land where he stepped down from the throne 36 years ago.

title: Ulster Bombing Goes On
description: BELFAST, Northern May 29The Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army showed its disregard of the ceasefire called by the rival Official wing by continuing its bombing campaign, which is nesses as possible out of ac tion.

title: Foe Said to Offer to Defect
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 31 (Reuters)John Paul Vann, the senior United States ad viser to Military Region II, told newsmen here that a group of 100 North Vietnamese made contact by radio today with Government positions in Kon turn and said they wanted to defect.

title: Farm Unit Scores Chavez
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, May 31 (UPI)  William Kuhfuss, the president of the American Farm Bureau, accused Cesar Chavez today of diverting public atten tion from key issues in pending farm labor legislation by picket ing bureau offices. Mr. Chavez is the leader of the United Farm Workers.

title: Heart Group Names Hogan
description: Thomas B. Hogan, a senior partner of the accounting firm of Haskins & Sells, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the New York Heart Association to succeed Ross Reid, who has become chairman of the board of the American Heart Association. Henry M. Hubshman Jr., a sen ior vice president of First Na tional City Bank, has replaced Mr. Hogan as vice chairman.

title: Berlin Accords Facing a Possible Delay
description: BONN, May 31A last minute problem developed to day on the signing of the four power Berlin agreement this weekend because of differences between West Germany and the Soviet Union over final ratifica tion of their 1970 friendship treaty.

title: Mrs. Straub Increases Lead In L.I. Golf to Four Strokes
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., May 31  Mrs. Austin Straub of Huntington Country Club shot 39, 3675 the best round to day, to increase her lead to four shots With a 155 total in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54hole Medal Play Championship at the Piping Rock Club. Par for the 5,539 yard course is 35, 3671

title: CASALS ILL, MISSES FESTIVAL'S OPENING
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 31  Pablo Casals canceled his open ing appearance at the 16th San Juan Music Festival tonight and sources said the 95yearold musician was suffering from a mild case of bronchitis:

title: ARGENTINA SETS PETROLEUM CURB
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 31 The Argentine military Govern ment reportedly plans to is sue a decree on Saturday curb ing the operations of private petroleum companies in the country.

title: Yanks and Lyle Hold On To Defeat Brewers, 54
description: MILWAUKEE, May 31  Sparky Lyle, the relief pitcher who has nearly as many saves this year as the entire Yankee relief corps compiled last year, came close to needing saving himself tonight, but he and the Yankees held on and struggled to a 54 victory over the Mil waukee Brewers.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, May 31A chal lenge by insurgent Democrats against 59 Illinois delegates to the National Convention finally got under way today as the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a passionate political foe of Mayor Richard J., Daley, testi fied at a party factfinding hearing.

title: Moe Berg, a Catcher in Majors Who Spoke 10 Languages, Dead
description: Morris (Moe) Berg, a former major league ballplayer who was also a linguist and scholar, died Monday in a Belleville, N.J., hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: The City Borrows $377Million, $100Million With Budget Notes
description: With the longanticipated Federal revenuesharing meas ure still not passed in the Con gress, the city was forced yes terday to sell $100million in budget notes as a part of a $377million assortment of shortterm notes.

title: Air Force Planning A Robot Bomber Guided by TV Eyes
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)The Air Force disclosed, today plans for its dream plane of the future, a robot bomber with television eyes flown from miles away like a model air plane by a pilot using radio controls.

title: The 13th District: Drugs and Murder
description: A siren sounded, and then another, and Detective Edwin Bailey Jr. smiled a woeful smile.

title: Man in the News
description: William Lucy, a relaxed and gregarious 38yearold black man who was elected Tuesday night as secretary treasurer of the 550,000mem ber American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, takes his achieve ment modestly.

title: Retroactive Pay Approved For Penn Central Unions
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (UPI)A Federal judge in Phil adelphia granted the Penn Cen tral Railroad approval today to pay members of 21 unions about $5.6million in retroac tive wage increases that were frozen under the President's economic stabilization program last year.

title: Advertising:
description: Well, yesterday the Inter public Group of Companies and the CampbellEwald Company were doing a lot more than talking merger their chiefs were signing an agreement under which In terpublic, the international communications complex, could, acquire Detroit's No. agency in the biggest deal of its kind in agency history.

title: MORE SOVIET SUBS IN MEDITERRANEAN
description: NAPLES, May 31The out going Commander in Chief of Allied Forces, South, warned to day that the Soviet Navy was deploying 22 submarines, a rec ord number, in the Mediter ranean Sea.

title: Marriage: Anachronism
description: Marriage is the hell of false expecta tions, where both partners, expecting to be loved, defined and supported, abdicate responsibility for themselves and accuse the other of taking away freedom.

title: Bombs on Bronx Roof
description: About 70 Molotov cocktails were found yesterday morning on the roof of a Bronx building at 433 East 147th Street, the police reported. No arrests were made.

title: Witnesses Reconstruct Account Of a ThreeMinute Nightmare
description: TEL AVIV; May 31At about 10 o'clock last night, Daisuke Namba and two companions stepped off Air France's flight 132 at the Tel Aviv airport. The three Japanese were among 116 passengers from Paris and Rome who lined up to have their passports checked.

title: Credit Markets
description: Yields on highgrade utility bonds dipped yesterday to their lowest level since midJanuary, and investors were not enthusi astic.

title: Foster to Defend Title
description: LONDON May 31 (Reuters) A London boxing promoter, Mike Barrett, said today that Bob Foster, American holder of the world lightheavyweight title, had agreed to meet Chris Finnegan of Britain for the championship in London Oct. 10.

title: Lottery Deadline Changed
description: NEWTON, Mass., May 31(AP) The Massachusetts State Lot tery announced a policy change today that will allow patrons to buy the 50cent tickets up to the day before the weekly Thursday drawing. Previously most ticket sales ended eight days before the drawing.

title: Detector Was Passed
description: ROME, May 31The Italian police said today that the three, Japanese gunmen who shot up the Tel Aviv terminal last night had boarded the Israel bound French airliner in Rome.

title: INVENTORY DROP LISTED FOR APRIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The prolonged sluggishness in manufacturing inventories con tinued in April but new orders rose even more than originally estimated, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: Dancers Give Preview of Museum Summergarden
description: The Egyptian belly dancer was an ArmenianAmerican who had never been to Egypt and the Indian Hindu dancer was a Barnard graduate from Manhattan, but still the crowd that gathered yester day for a preview of summer offerings seemed to enjoy the wigglings and the shimmy ings.

title: CHUMBO SCORES AT DEVON'S SHOW
description: DEVON, Pa., May 31Chum bo, a 9yearold brown stallion, ridden by Barney Ward, made his comeback official tonight by winning the Gambler's Choice stake at the Devon horse show.

title: Seaver Joiled Again, This Time by the Rain
description: Tom Seaver, unable to fin ish a starting assignment since April 26, didn't finish another for the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night, but it wasn't the Phila delphia Phillies who inter rupted his work; it was rain.

title: Reserve Rates Up In West Germany
description: WEST BERLIN, May 31 (Reu ters)  West Germany is in creasing its minimum reserve requirements on domestic lia bilities by 8 per cent effective July 1, Bundesbank President Karl Klasen said today.

title: Pilgrimage to Holy Land Began in joy in San Juan
description: On Monday, most of the Protestants of a tiny Puerto Rican barrio 20 miles outside San Juan gathered for a gay sendoff for their pastor and seven friends who left for an 18day pilgrimage to the Holy Land, and, later, some sight seeing in Switzerland and Italy.

title: Mecom Is Linked to a Gambler
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The director of the New Or leans Crime Commission told a Congressional committee to day that the owner of New Orleans Saints football team, John Mecom Jr., was associated in a business deal with a con victed ganibler and with a developer who had ties with an alleged organized crime kingpin, Carlos Marcello.

title: Pamela Bellwood and Backus Win Derwent Acting Awards
description: Two young Broadway per formers were chosen yester day as winners of the 28th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given to an actor and actress for best individu al supporting roles in plays presented here during the last season.

title: R. T. Heacock, Black Minister Sent to AllWhite Parish, Dies
description: STAFFORD, Conn., May 31 The Rev. Dr. Roland T. Hea cock, a black minister whose appointment in 1950 to the all white Staffordville Congrega tional Church drew national at tention, died here yesterday. He was 79 years old and had lived here since his retirement at the end of 1958.

title: Ajax Wins, 20, Retains, European Soccer Cup
description: ROTTERDAM, the Nether lands, May 31 (Reuters) Ajax of Amsterdam retained the European Cup in soccer when it beat Inter of Milan, 20, in the final before 65,000 here tonight.

title: SIDEROWF GAINS; SCOT, 14, OUSTED
description: SANDWICH, England, May 31 (UPI)  Dick Siderowf, the top American challenger, and Mike Bonallack of Britain, fa vored to win for the sixth time, made it to the round of 32 today in the British Ama teur golf championship, but it was the end of the road for the boy wonder, Davey Robertson, the 14yearold Scottish school boy champion.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Last week, Elizabeth Drew of the public television network opened an interview with Senator George Mc Govern by asking him if it were not true that his program seems to add up to quite a substantial and impor tant change in the way this country works, economically and socially.

title: Fitzsimmons Is Named Atlanta Hawks' Coach
description: ATLANTA, May 31 (AP) Coach Lowell (Cotton) Fitz simmons, who took the Phoe nix Suns to consecutive third place finishes in the National Basketball Association, was named coach of the Atlanta Hawks today.

title: Jersey Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of men killed in action in Indo china. Among the Army dead was Specialist 4 David A. Bausch, of Towaco, N. J.

title: Lithograph of Bernhardt Disappears From Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 31 (UPI) The late Sarah Bernhardt is starring in a modern mystery the disappearance last weekend from Cornell University's art museum of a 19thcentury lithograph announcing a per formance by the actress.

title: A Suspense Melodrama of 'Fright':British Import Proves a Tale of Cruelties Ian Bannen Has Part of Homicidal Maniac
description: Peter Collinson's "Fright" is a describably dreadful English suspense melodrama, set in an old but not quite empty mansion, about a homicidal maniac, who sneaks in, and the terrorized babysitter who can't sneak out.The arbitrary cruelties in the screenplay by Tudor Gates, one of the eight writers who collaborated on "Barbarella," include a rape, a baby held hostage with a piece of broken glass at its throat, some slashings and the splitting of a skull, as well as lots of cross-cutting between scenes in the house and scenes of the would-be rescuers having the kind of car trouble that only a desperate writer would borrow from a Keystone comedy.Collinson, who has made some bad movies in his short career ("The Penthouse" and "The Italian Job," among others), bottoms himself with the dreary affectations in "Fright." Leaky faucets sound like footsteps, TV sets suddenly scream in the night, faces are seen reflected on pendulums, fractured through frosted windows, and so on. It's like being drunk without joy. Most of the movie seems to have been photographed with the camera about three feet, nine inches off the floor, a technique sometimes employed to create the feeling of menace instead of, as here, the suspicion that everything is being audited by a midget.Susan George plays the baby-sitter, Ian Bannen the maniac and Honor Blackman the baby's mother. Though good actors, they're hopeless in these frankly fake, sadomasochist circumstances. Perhaps because the film has been rated PG (parental guidance suggested), the camera usually looks away just before the blood begins to spurt. I suspect that's the sort of discretion that only the mother of a film censor can fully appreciate.

description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN

title: Bomb Rocks Site in Iran Just Before Visit by Nixon
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 31 Terrorists exploded three bombs here today, one of them near the tomb of the Shah's father, Riza Shah, an hour before President Nixon was sched uled to lay a wreath there. A second went off under a car carrying an American adviser to the Iranian Air Force.

title: Miss Claudel Bride of Edward Gilly
description: Miss MarieHelene Claudel, daughter of Henri Claudel, French consul general here, and Mrs. Claudel, was mar ried yesterday afternoon to Edward Gilly, who is attend ing the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. The ceremony at St, Jean Baptiste's Roman Catholic Church was performed in Latin and French by Abbe Harold Tiercelin of St. Vin cent de Paul's Church.

title: N.Y.U. Commencement: Some Fiscal Overtones
description: Threads of New York Uni versity's troubled financial con dition wove themselves into the fabric of the institution's 140th commencement yesterday morn ing in Madison Square Garden.

title: Coast Banker Confirmed As a Member of Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of a California banker, Jeffrey M. Bucher, to a 14year term on the Federal Reserve Board over the opposi tion of Senator William Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin who called him an inexperi ericed amateur.

title: ABRAMS IS CHOICE AS CHIEF OF STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, will be nominated as the Army's new Chief of Staff within a few days of President Nixon's re turn from his European summit trip tomorrow night, well placed Army sources said to day.

title: Vanatta Gets Coaching Job
description: CLEVELAND, Miss., May 31 (AP)Bob Vanatta, general manager of the American Bas ketball Association's Memphis Pros, was named head basket ball coach at Delta State Col lege today.

title: Annuals at Whitney Museum To Be Biennials, but Larger
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art's annual sur veys of the contemporary scene will be doubled in size and halved in frequency be ginning in January, 1973, it was announced yesterday by John I. H. Baur, the museum's director. The annual will be come a biennial, but the en tire exhibition space of the museum will be turned over to itwhich means four full floors and a small subterran ean gallery instead of the two floors that have been allotted to the annuals.

title: Chess: Renewed Study of Openings Is Leading to New Lines
description: The systematic study of the openings has recently ex perienced a real boom, and such analysis has become more and more a part of the routine of every serious chess player. No longer can even a strong player ignorant of the latest developments in the openings expect to do well against weaker opponents more booked up than he.

title: Dublin Holds 2 Leaders of I.R.A. Militant Wing
description: DUBLIN, May 31The Irish Republic intensified its cam paign tonight against the out lawed Irish Republican Army with the arrest of two leaders of the militant Provisional wing.

title: Ford to Build Rapid Transit Systems Based on Its PeopleMover
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Henry Ford 2d announced yes terday that the Ford Motor Company would build rapid transit systems based on its driverless, rubbertired people mover system being demon strated at the Transpo 72 ex hibition here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your May 8 report of a daylong discussion by a group of Kremlinolo gists on the origins of the cold war is interesting but disappointing. It seems to indicate that the question as to when the cold war began was not seriously discussed. Indeed, it is not clear that those present were agreed as to what the term really means.

title: Pravda Terms Pacts Of Great Significance
description: MOSCOW, May 31 ((Reu ters)  Pravda forecast to day that President Nixon's talks with Soviet leaders and the agreements they signed would have great significance for improvements in the world political situation.

title: At 86, Carolyn Wyeth Interrupts  Briefly  the Quiet, Rural Life She Loves
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa.  Mrs. N. C. Wyeth blinked at the cameras. She paused in answering questions. At the age of 86 a news con ference, her first, was not her idea of a good time.

title: Screen: 'Final Comedown' Arrives:Story of a Black Revolt Is at the Victoria Leader's Role Is Taken by Billy Dee Williams
description: Normally you should allow at least two years between the time something happensan assassination, a trend, a major shift in the national consciousnessand the time you begin seeing movies about it. That leaves one year for the thing, whatever it is, to penetrate the collective consciousness of the movie industry (a phenomenon known as cultural lag), and another year for production, post-production, distribution and everything else it takes to bring the never-before-revealed to your silver screen.Thus, youth-rebellion films, the spirit of '67-'68, appeared with some regularity in 1969-70. But black-rebellion films, dealing with an altogether scarier and less popular subject, have been more erratic in coming, and they have come mostly under the protection of a certain academicismthe nostalgic 1930's dramaturgy of Jules Dassin's "Up Tight," or the cinematic pyrotechnics of Melvin van Peebles's "Sweet Sweetback's Baadasss Song."Oscar Williams's "The Final Comedown," which opened yesterday at the Victoria and Apollo theaters, has less exalted models, but it seems as slavishly rooted to convention as any of its predecessors. Essentially it is the story of how a gentle, handsome young black man (Billy Dee Williams) is radicalized by social injustice and finally drivenby a process never quite made clearto lead a kind of violent revolt in which young people all over share.The revolt is a pretty bloody affair, in fact, a shootout in which everybody loses, and black heroes and white cops fall like files. Its sources lie very much in the tradition of the Western, especially the Italian Western, and it is the climax to a plot full of personal relations that never avoid the clichs of urban soap opera.If it had become, from these elements, a good genre film, "The Final Comedown" could have represented an interesting adaption. But it is a bad genre filmwholly exploitative of both its dramatic forms and its social situation.It is of course a very angry movie, in the sense that everybody is almost always very angry. But it takes time out for some young-love exploitation, and a brief glamour tour of soul food and black fashions, and even a glimpse at the problem of air pollution and the plight of the American Indianand I think that any movie with so many concerns must have too little really on its mind.Its technique is slick, but ineffective. I think I might like virtually al the cast under different circumstances. But for a film in which nobody converses, and people even in their most private moments, only make speeches at one, another, it seems useless to discuss performance.

title: Range of Fanny May Bids Narrows as Volume Slips
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reu ters)The range of bids at the latest auction of Government backed fourmonth mortgage commitments narrowed, while the volume declined by about 150 per cent, the Federal Na tional Mortgage Association re ported today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today

title: Player, Umpire Penalized
description: EL PASO, Tex., May 31 (UPI)Bobby Bragan, president of the Texas League, suspended Paul Womble, Memphis Blues' infielder, for three days today and also handed a $25 fine to the umpire, Ernie Gallagher, for their roles in a fight Monday night at Midland, Texas.

title: The Ultimate Betrayal
description: WASHINGTON  There seems no room now for sympathy on either side of the partisan debate over the block ade of North Vietnam. But at some point, this decision should also be seen as personal tragedy for the men who made itHenry Kissinger and Richard Nixon.

title: Hurricane Season Starts
description: MIAMI, May 31 (Reuters) Robert Simpson, head of the National Hurricane Center, says that the 1972 hurricane season starts today.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill Putting Environmental Bond Issue on Ballot
description: Governor Rockefeller signed a bill yesterday placing on the November ballot a $1.15billion environmental bond issue de signed to pay for air, water and land conservation and an tipollution projects in the state for the next five years.

title: Two Services Offer a Combat Enlistment Bonus
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) To attract more volunteers, the Army and Marine Corps will begin tomorrow to offer a cash enlistment bonus of $1,500 to men who sign up for combat arms unitsinfantry, artillery and armor.

title: ARMY DRUG TESTS HELD INADEQUATE Aspin Charges Thousands of Men Slip by Screen
description: WASHINGTON, May 31A Wisconsin Representative charged today that thousands of drug experimenters and ad dicts were slipping through the Army's drugtesting screen be cause of inaccurate laboratory testing.

title: Keppel, Addressing Baruch Graduates, Praises Curriculum
description: Francis Keppel, former United States Commissioner of Education, told the 1,460 stu dents in the graduating class of Bernard M. Baruch College yes terday that they were far bet ter qualified than those of us who wandered innocent  as I did  into both business and government in the course of our lives.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: EAST LOS ANGELES, May 31  The McGovern Presiden tial campaign has taken the television news release, an old idea that never worked very well before, and perfected it into a major political weapon here in California.

title: ONE SLAIN AS GROCER FOILS HOLDUP BY 3
description: A Brooklyn man shot and killed one of three armed men who, the police said, tried to hold up his grocery store yes terday.

title: Jazz Salute to Hampton Off
description: The Jazz Adventures salute to Lionel Hampton, scheduled for tomorrow at the Playboy. Club, has been postponed until June 16. Instead, the Charles McPherson Quartet will per form at the noon program this week.

title: Music: Finesse at Piano
description: John Browning and the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto in B flat minor have been go ing together for years, and that familiarity showed in his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Tues day night's Promenades concert. Mr. Browning took the famous hazards of the work in his stridethe dou ble octave passages came off cleanly and brilliantly, though without the accelerating thun deration that every virtuoso and wouldbe virtuoso used to attempt in the wake of Horowitz.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J. May 31  There are two political main events next Tuesday California's primary, in which 271, Democratic convention del egates will be elected, and New Jersey's, in which 109 delegates will be elected.

title: News Analysis
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 28There are two demons in North Korean life, United States imperialists and Ja panese militarists, and it is hard to tell which is worse.

title: Mundine Registers Knockout in 7th Over Denny Moyer
description: SYDNEY, Australia May 31 (AP)Tony Mundine, the Brit ish, Commonwealth and Aus tralian middleweight champion, scored a knockout at the end of seven rounds tonight over Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore.

title: Swedish Countess Bride Of Duke of Marlborough
description: Countess Rosita Douglas of Stockholm, a 26yearold fashion designer, and the 11th Duke of Marlborough were married in a civil cere mony, at Caxton Hall, the registry office in Westminster, London, on May 20.

title: Japan Vows Compensation for Disgrace
description: TOKYO, May 31Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda today called the shootings yesterday at the Tel Aviv airport by three Japanese terrorists, a disgrace for Japan and sent Hideho Tanaka, counselor of the For eign Ministry's Middle Eastern and African Affairs Bureau, to Tel Aviv to investigate the incident.

title: Bridge: Princeton Reunion May Hear Of How Tiger Held an Expert
description: Most players have trouble remembering a bridge hand a day after the event, or even an hour later. Therefore it is unlikely that any player would remember a hand 50 years after the event. So when the class of '22 at Princeton discusses auction bridge games as well as track meets and the Yale football game at its 50th reunion this weekend, the recollections will be general rather than specific.

title: Hartford Gets Franchise
description: CAMP HILL, Pa., May 31 (AP)The twoyearold Sea board professional football league awarded a franchise to day to the Hartford Knights. The new Connecticut team is owned by Peter and Herbert Savin.

title: Executive Changes
description: Howard C. Miller has been elected president and chief operating officer of the ITT Canteen Corporation, Chicago. He succeeds Patrick L. O'Malley, who has been elected chairman of the board and continues as chief executive officer. Mr. Miller formerly was a vice president of Inter national Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, parent company of ITT Canteen.

title: 4 Top Crews Clash Today in I.R.A. Trials
description: SYRACUSE, May 31  At 4:45 tomorrow afternoon, be fore a few hundred spectators here on the shoreline of Onon daga Lake, the best crew race of the season is likely to be rowed.

title: Thieu Spends Day at Hue
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 31 (AP)  President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam, who flew into Kontum yesterday, spent the day today in Hue to bolster the morale of troops holding the defense line on the southern edge of enemyoccu pied Quangtri Province.

title: LAWYER MAY SEEK CITY SCHOOL POST
description: Acting under a twoyearold state law that has never been used before, a local Brooklyn school board is seeking to have the State Education Department declare the board's chairman a noneducatoreligible to be the district school superintend ent.

title: Woman in Queens is Raped On Apartment House Roof
description: A 40yearold Queens woman was raped early yesterday on the roof of her Forest Hills apartment house by a man who pretended he had a gun, the police said.

title: Many Nonfarmers Live On Farms, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)American farms are increasingly becoming places where people either live or work, but not both, a new report from the Census Bu reau shows.

title: RELIEF FRAUDS UP, BERLINGER FINDS
description: State Welfare inspector Gen eral George F. Berlinger, re porting that a sampling indi cated 37 per cent of January's new relief cases in one center were ineligible, called yesterday for revision of the acceptance process.

title: EASED ANNULMENT APPROVED BY POPE
description: ROME, May 31The Vatican said today that Pope Paul had approved new guidelines for annulling marriages between Roman Catholics that had not been consummated.

title: TOP SOVIET DANCER SERVING JAIL TERM
description: MOSCOW, May 31 (AP) One of the Soviet Union's leading male ballet dancers has been sentenced to jail on charge of petty hooliganism which, his friends say, was brought against him because he asked for papers to go to Israel.

title: C.A.B. Backs Subsidy Rise To Local Service Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board has approved an increase in annual subsidies for the local service airlines.

title: Fuel Leak Linked to Blast
description: VALDESE, N. C., May 31 (AP)A Federal agent said to day that leaking gasoline fumes, probably set off by a spark from a light switch, caused an explosion that killed five chit dren here last night. Jack Wil liams, an Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agent, said the gaso line line led from a fuel tank to the generator in the private bomb shelter that James E. Garrou, a textile executive, had built on a hillside near his home.

title: Israeli Scientist Is Among Victims Of Tel Aviv Attack
description: Among those killed in the Tel Aviv airport shooting yes terday was Dr. Aharon Katzir Katchalsky, one of Israel's leading scientists, who had served since 1948 as head of the department of polymer re search at the Weizmann Insti tute of Science in Rehovoth.

title: News of Dogs
description: A visit to her sister in New Mexico stepped off a new career for Mrs. Richard Dysart, for the Swiss blonde now is playing a leading role in Southwest dog show circles.

title: Boxer Died of Hemorrhage
description: BRISBANE, Australia, May 31 (AP)The inquest on the death of a Filipino boxer, Al berto Jangalay, disclosed today that Jangalay's death was caused by a subdural hemor rhage. Jangalay died after a bout with a South African boxer, Anthony Sithole (Kid Snowball) in Brisbane Oct. 1.

title: TV: Basic Strategies of the Presidential Debates
description: The third is yet to come, this Sunday on the American Broadcasting Company net work, but the George McGov ernHubert Humphrey de bates have already under lined several points con cerning the wobbly marriage between politics and televi sion.

title: Upgrading of MentalHealth Effort Urged Here
description: A public hearing yesterday on a plan for mental health services in Manhattan brought pleas for better followup care for discharged mental patients, better psychiatric care for the elderly, improved care for chil dren and a change in the state program of matching local funds.

title: New S.E.C.Rule Proposes Tighter Securities Safety
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a comprehensive new rule de signed to safeguard customers' cash and securities that are in the hands of stockbrokers.

title: Electoral Shell Game
description: Now you see it; now you don't. The right to vote recently extended to young Americans between the ages of 18 and 21 by Federal court decree, and by amendment to the Federal Constitution is a right which youths resid ing in New York State will not be able to exercise in this month's primary elections. The Supreme Court that giveth has now become the Supreme Court that taketh away.

title: Roundup: Aaron's 648th Ties Mays on Homer List
description: It took Hank Aaron 18plus seasons to catch Willie Mays in home runs. His next target is Babe Ruth's record.

title: U.S. Dismisses Kim's Terms For Easing Korean Relations
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The State Department asserted today that Premier Kim 11 Sung of North Korea had set conditions for the normaliza tion of relations with South Korea that were manifestly unacceptable to Washington and Seoul.

title: Senate Panel Moves to Cut Off Relief Funds for Some Addicts
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Senate Finance Committee voted today to cut off Federal welfare payments to drug ad dicts and alcoholics who are not undergoing treatment.

title: Amex and Counter Prices Close Lower
description: It was a down day on the American Stock Exchange yes terday, with one major excep tion. The index closed at 27.75, off 0.12, but one stock, Binney & Smith, jumped 19 to close at 56, in what may rank as one of the best kept corporate merger secrets in a long time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am a registered nurse. My license has lost meaning since July of 1970. I cared too much for people. I cared too much for life. I have even fought to save persons who attempted suicide. What a disservice I did helping them to life after they made a valid decision to die. Suicide is a personal matter.

title: Travel Industry Doubts Shooting Will Reduce Tourism in Israel
description: Travel industry spokesmen said yesterday that they knew of no cancellations of trips to Israel that they could attribute to apprehension following the shootings at the Tel Aviv air port.

title: GLAMOURS LEAD TUMBLE IN STOCKS
description: Stock prices broke sharply yesterday as glamour issues notably weak on Tuesdayled the general market downward..

title: Now the Provisionals
description: The decision of the Official wing of the Irish Republi can Army to call off terrorist activities in Northern Ire land is as welcome as it is overdue. Though its opera tions were always on a lesser scale than those of the I.R.A. Provisionals, its withdrawal from violence will increase Roman Catholic pressures on its ultramilitant rivals to do likewise.

title: Maryland Hospital Is Doubted as Site Of Wallace Surgery
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 31 (AP)  An aide to Gov. George C. Wallace said today that he did not expect that the operation to remove a bullet from Mr. Wallace's spinal col umn would be performed at Holy Cross Hospital here.

title: PRESSMEN DELAY EDITION OF TIMES
description: Pressmen at The New York Times delayed the start of the firstedition press run of yes terday's issue for nearly 15 minutes to protest the contents of a paid advertisement seek ing the impeachment of Presi dent Nixon.

title: General Tire to Expand
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 31 (UPI) The General Tire & Rubber Company plans a $12.6million expansion at its Bryan, Ohio, plant. The company said the addition will increase its man ufacturing and warehouse space by 400,000 square feet.

title: Massacre at Lydda
description: The extremist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, which specializes in indiscriminate slaughter under a false banner of Palestinian justice, has descended to new depths of infamy with the massacre of 25 air travelersincluding fourteen Christian pilgrims from Puerto Rico and a leading Israeli scientistat Israel's International Airport.

title: TAP SHOW PROPELS FANS AND DANCERS
description: If you can remember back to before current No, No, Nan ette days, you will recall that in 1969, a marvelous group of tap dancers, who were dubbed The Hoofers, appeared al most timidly on the Off Broad way stages with great success, and showed what their almost forgotten art was all about.

title: Rockefeller Warmtoldea Of a Fusion Mayor Here
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that Democratic and Republican leaders should con sider uniting behind a oneterm fusion candidate for Mayor of New York City next year.

title: ORANTES TOPPLES SOLOMON IN 4 SETS, GAINS SEMIFINALS Spaniard Is Too Strong for U.S. Foe at French Open Miss Goolagong Wins
description: PARIS, May 31  Harold Solomon doesn't have a big service and can't hit overheads too well. His volleys are weak, he has a twofisted backhand and his ground strokes can get lost in the sun. But the little man made his presence felt again today in the $100,000 French open tennis tournament.

title: Union Theological Votes a Rise In Blacks and Women in School
description: The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary voted yesterday to require that blacks and representatives of other minority groups make up onethird and that won??n com prise onehalf of all students, faculty, staff and directors.

title: AIDE SAYS AIRLINE TOOK PRECAUTIONS
description: PARIS, May 31The French Government today formally condemned the massacre at the Tel Aviv airport and sharply denied Israeli allegations that Air France was partly at fault for the incident.

title: NIXON IN WARSAW, GREETS THE PUBLIC AND MEETS GIEREK
description: WARSAW, May 31  Presi dent Nixon arrived in Warsaw today and succeeded in reach ing the Polish people despite official attempts to avoid a repetition of the emotional wel come he received here in 1959, when he was Vice President.

title: The Culinary Legacy Of a Turin Childhood
description: CLOSTER, N. J.  Grow ing up in an elegant restau rant in northern Italy is no way to prepare the palate for the southern Italian food served in most New York and New. Jersey restaurants. And after 18 years away from her family's restaurant, Teresa Candler has turned into a missionary for, the food of her native Turin.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: The New York Times Com pany announced yesterday that its board of directors had de clared the usual quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on the Class A and Class B common stock, payable June 27 to holders of record June 12. The board also declared a reg ular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 per cent cumulative prior prefer ence stock. It is payable July 1 to holders of record June. 12.

title: Women to Ring the Capitol June 22 to Protest the War
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Joan Baez, the folk singer, and more than 30 other women gathered on the east steps of the Capitol this afternoon to announce plans for a ring around the Congress antiwar demonstration June 22.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Prefontaine: Pre for PreEminent or Precocious?
description: EUGENE, Ore., May 31To West Coast sports fans who have enjoyed the firstname intimacy of such easily identi fiable heroes as Wilt and O. J., Steve Prefontaine is Pre, as in Hey, wasn't Pre something out there today?

title: GrowingUp Time Called Too Long for Class of 1972
description: Prof. Oscar Handlin, the Harvard historian, skipped the traditional praise and congratulations for the grad uating seniors at Brooklyn College yesterday, telling them instead that they and the rest of the classes of '72 across the country were tak ing too much time to grow up.

title: Market Place: Halt Is Examined In Levitz Trades
description: Why hasn't the New York Stock Exchange permitted the shares of Levitz Furniture to trade for a week?

title: JAMES J. DOWNEY, 65, RESTAURATEUR, DIES
description: James J. Downey, a restaura teur best known for Downey's Steak House catering to the theater crowd on the West Side, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital following surgery. He was 65 years old and had lived in retirement since 1968 at 5425 Pine Tree Drive, Miami Beach.

title: Pentagon Aide Says McGovern Errs on cuts in Military Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, made a $10billion Mistake in calculating his proposed reduc tion in Pentagon spending, the Controller of the Defense De partment told Congress today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRY D. M. GRIER OF FRICK MUSEUM
description: Harry D. M. Grier, director since 1964 of the Frick Col lection, died Tuesday follow ing a traffic accident. He was 58 years old and lived at 16 East 84th Street and at Brook side Farm Cottage in Oxford, Pa.

title: Death for Sale
description: On Memorial Day Harvey Glenn McLeod walked into Thorne's Hardware and Sporting Goods Store in Raleigh, N. C., selected a 22caliber automatic rifle and the nec essary ammunition, and paid $54. From there he went straight away to a crowded shopping center where he used the weapon to kill three persons, wound eight others and put a last fatal bullet through his own head.

title: Treasury Changes Rule To Close a Tax Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) In a ruling affecting state and local governments, the Treas ury Department issued new regulations today to plug a tax loophole used by governments when they reinvest borrowed money.

title: Mission to Rescue Jewish Scholars In Soviet Is Urged
description: A massive rescue mission to get Jewish scholars out of the Soviet Union was called for last night by Dr. Alfred Gott schalk, president of the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion.

title: Chavez Is Hospitalized By His 20Day Fast
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 31 (AP)Cesar Chavez, United Farm Workers leader, his face drawn from the effects of a 20day fast, was taken by ambulance today from his headquarters to a hospital.

title: Raiders Get Black Player, Only Second in Hockey
description: The New York Raiders of the World Hockey Associa tion yesterday signed a small ish minorleaguer named Al ton White, who probably will bring the club as much recog nition as all its previous signing combined.

title: KEY TO THE MINT FIRST IN WITHERS
description: Key to the Mint opened the way to preeminent considera tion for the reniainder of the 3yearold campaign by the manner in which he won the Withers at Belmont Park yes terday.

title: GOLD AT NEW HIGH; DOLLAR WEAKENS
description: GENEVA, May 31Gold hit a new high of just under $60 an ounce and the dollar weak ened against most major cur rencies today as nervousness continued over the state of United States balanceofpay ments recovery.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For three weeks in June the United States has a rare opportunity to dem onstrate a real concern for a common problem we share with the rest of the worldhow to prevent the virtual ex tinction of human life on earth.

title: Ted Bates, Ad Agency Founder, Dies
description: Ted Bates, founder of the worldwide advertising agency that bears his name and a piv otal figure in modern advertis ing, died Tuesday while playing bridge with friends. He was 70 years old.

title: 3 U.S. Sailboats Chosen For Onion Patch Defense
description: Charisma, owned by Jesse Philips of Dayton, Ohio; The Aura, owned by Wallace James Stenhouse Jr. of Chicago, and Yankee Girl, owned by David D. Steere of Dallas, were chosen yesterday to represent the United States in the sixth bien nial Onion Patch Trophy sail boat series.

title: Agriculture Aide to Resign
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) Assistant Agriculture Secre tary Clarence D. Palmby plans to resign soon to join an inter national grain trade firm, in formed sources said today. Mr. Palmby has been Assistant Sec retary of Agriculture for inter national affairs and commodity programs since early 1969.

title: 3 Newsmen to Receive Columbia Alumni Awards
description: A newspaper editor in Chi cago, a New York television reporter and a Washington cor respondent are the winners of the 1972 Columbia journalism alumni awards.

title: The Man Who Shot Serpico Is Convicted in Brooklyn
description: The man who shot Patrolman Frank Serpico during a police raid on a Brooklyn apartment on Feb. 3, 1971, was convicted yesterday of attempted mur der, possession of dangerous weapons and grand larceny.

title: Well, Anything Can Happen (And in This Town It Does)
description: This is a collection of stories currently being told around town. Unlike many events described in stories New Yorkers hear and tell, these actually happened. In each case they were traced to either a participant or first hand observer. Names have been omitted in some cases because they were not known, in others to protect the inno cent, the guilty and the em barrassed. What do these stories prove? Nothing.

title: 'One Brief Summer'
description: Don't be fooled by those juicy palpitating ads for "One Brief Summer," a British study of sexual tensions that turns into a rambling, tedious bore. It opened yesterday quietly  that much to its creditat a cluster of showcases, padding out a double bill.The film had plot possibilities. We have a beautiful country estate, where a middle-aged financier becomes obsessed with a houseguest, a wide-eyed Lolita type. Watching, in agony, is the man's older daughter, with an acute father complex.Watching all three, with a wise sneer, is a young farmer, biding his time.Up to about midpoint, it works pretty well, the British way  clipped dialogue, restrained expressions over coffee and tea and a civilized atmosphere. The music is pretty and soothing, likewise the rustic color photography, taking a few peaks into mod London.The set-up is serenely arranged by the director, John Mackenzie. The acting of Clifford Evans, Felicity Gibson, Jennifer Hilary and Peter Egan is quite good. Trouble is, once the friction surfaces, the film goes nowhere, leaving the cast to mill around and stare at one another in disillusion, lust or both. That civilized facade becomes a thin cover-up for some infantile behavior.It's too bad someone like Franoise Sagan, of the sardonic swizzle-stick, or Iris Murdoch, with her grotesque irony, didn't stir up a more interesting sexual brew. Anyway, the four principals finally pair off as they deserve, father and daughter, visitor and farmer.

title: DR. BAYARD DODGE, UNIVERSITY HEAD
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 31 Dr. Bayard Dodge, president emeritus of the American Uni versity in Beirut, Lebanon, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Tenants Buy and Rehabilitate Slum Building
description: A group of determined slum dwellers in the South Bronx has put into effect a plan to save housing that is the model for Federal legislation that will be introduced today in the House of Representatives.

title: Saigon Reports Slight Gain at Kontum
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 1 (AP)South Vietnamese troops, heavily sup ported by helicopter gunship and fighterbomber attacks, re portedly reoccupied some lost ground in the Central Highlands city of Kontum yesterday.

title: G.E. Discloses Transmission Gain
description: The General Electric Com pany announced yesterday what is believed to be a major breakthrough in underground transmission of electricity at cryogenic  extremely low  temperatures. The work was part of a $1.05million experi mental project financed by the Edison Electric Institute, the Tennessee Valley Authority and the American Public Power As sociation under operation of the Electric Research Council.

title: Draft Violator Convicted
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 31 (AP)A Federal court jury today convicted John Russell Karnap, 21 years old, of violat ing the Selective Service Act. Karnap, a former draft coun selor at Marshall University, was found guilty of failing to submit to an armed forces phys ical examination and failing to report for induction.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 Black Republicans have in vited 2,000 Negroes from across the country to a two day strategy meeting on the reelection of President Nixon.

title: F.B.I.Investigating Sabotage Of Three Air Force Planes
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The Federal Bureau of Investi gation is investigating damage to three Air Force Reserve cargo planes at the Willow Grove Naval Air Station near Philadelphia.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Richard H. Poff of Virginia, one of the Southern conservatives Pres ident Nixon considered nom inating for the United States Supreme Court, was nom inated to the Supreme Court of his home state by Republi can Gov. Linwood Holton. If approved by the General As sembly, Mr. Poff would be come the first Republican on the Virginia Supreme Court in this century. The Con gressman, who withdrew himself from United States Supreme Court consideration in the face of hostility from liberal Senators, said he would accept the Virginia post with a curious mixture of joy, gratitude and deep humility.

title: TRUCK DRIVER SEIZED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn truck driver was arraigned yes terday in Federal Court on charges of attempting to extort $350,000 by threatening to blow up an airliner and the Pan American Airways passen ger terminal.

title: 3% RISE SHOWN BY FARM PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI)A recovery in prices for beef cattle and hogs helped produce a 3 per cent increase in the average price of raw farm products in midMay, the agriculture department report ed today.

title: Rabbis Get Suspended Term
description: BOSTON, May 31 (UPI) Five rabbis who joined in an antiwar demonstration May 17 at the JFK Federal Building were given suspended sentences today by a judge who told them that a condition of their sixmonth probation was to avoid any similar activities. Each also was fined $50 for at tempting to block the entrance to the downtown building.

title: Senators Hear an Expert On TV Ads for Children
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) A Florida schoolgirl, in plaid, bangs and green knee socks, told Congress today that she thought Saturday morning tele vision commercials for children were deceptive and dangerous.

title: JASPER DEETER, 78, PRODUCER, IS DEAD
description: Jasper Deeter, producer, di rector, actor, teacher and found er of the nationally known Hedgerow Theater in Moylan Rose Valley, Pa, one of the country's early repertory groups, died yesterday in Rid del Memorial Hospital in Media, Pa. He was 77 years old.

title: Trevino in Kemper Today With an Eye on U.S. Open
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 31  Lee Trevino disclosed his recipe today in preparation for the forthcoming United States Open golf championship.

title: Personal Finance
description: Property owners in the city should have received notice by now telling them officially that the tax office is no longer sending out re ceipts automatically to show that taxes have been paid.

title: MILLS GIVES PLAN TO FORCE REVIEW OF TAX BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, intro duced today legislation that would gradually repeal 54 spe cial provisions of the tax law, including most, of those that opponents consider to be major loopholes.

title: Equity Financing: Offer by Long Island Lighting
description: A rights offering of common shares of the Long Island Light ing Company became effective yesterday whereby holders of record at the close of business yesterday may subscribe for 2,021,806 shares at the rate of one share for each ten shares held as of May 31, 1972. The offer, according to the under writers headed by Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc., expires at the close of business June 16. According to the un derwrtiers proceeds of the sale will be used largely to repay all of the utility's Series E 3 per cent, First Mortgage Bonds due July 1, 1972. The company stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yester day at 21 down . The sub scription price on the rights offering is $19.50 per share.

title: C. T. Bayley Weds Cynthia G. Conroy
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31 Miss Cynthia Gayle Conroy was married here this morn ing to Christopher Tappan Bayley, District Attorney for King County, Wash., which includes Seattle. Msgr. John J. Devlin performed the cere mony in St. Victor's Roman Catholic Church.

title: JAMES MADDEN, 79, N.Y.U. CHANCELLOR
description: James L. Madden, a retired lawyer, insurance executive, manpower expert and former acting chancellor of New York University, died Tuesday in St. Barnabas Hospital, Livingston, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: U.S. Backs 11 State Plans To Reduce Pollution of Air
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The administrator of the En vironmental Protection Agency announced today that he had given complete approval to the plans of 11 states and three other jurisdictions for meeting the Federal standards on six air pollutants.

title: Football Coach Named
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31 (AP) Tom Richards, who has been an assistant five years, was named head football coach at Loyola University of Los An geles today. Richards succeeds Jim Brownfield.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, three months after it was ousted from the Lever Brothers stable of agencies, has trotted into the one run by Procter & Gamble. And a very stable stable it is, since, in its history, the Cincinnati giant has only dismissed one agency.

title: New Yorker Is Appointed Tariff Commission Member
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) President Nixon has named Italo H. Ablondi of New York to be a member of the Tariff commission, the White House announced today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 31This is the final examination in American studies. Each correct answer is worth ten points. Grade your own paper. Stu dents scoring less than seventy points should leave the country immediately.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 31 Senator John L. McClellan faces an uphill fight to retain his seat in a Democratic runoff contest June 13 after what he called a disappointing show ing in yesterday's preliminary primary.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER ADVANCE
description: Traders in grain futures were extremely cautious again yes terday but those in the soybean futures pit were slightly more optimistic than they had been the day before.

title: Rap Brown Flown to Louisiana for Sentencing on U.S. Charge
description: Shortly before dawn yester day, H. Rap Brown was re moved from the Federal House of Detention on West Street despite a court order barring his removal  and flown to Louisiana to face sentencing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Hotel and motel employes are scheduled to leave their jobs at about 2 RM. today to attend a strike authorization meeting in Madison Square Garden. Skeleton crews will remain on duty at the 140 New York hostelries involved in the deadlocked contract talks.

title: Wood, Field and, Stream
description: A measure of the everin creasing pressure to which our public and private hunt ing lands are subjected is in dicated by the halfmillion increase in hunting license sales in 1971. Total sales in that year were 15,977,588, and perhaps a million or more individuals who do not require licenses because of age or military status were also afield.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Party Leaders Shun Frills But Take Over in Substantive Talks With Nixon
description: WARSAW, May 31Presi dents and emperors don't seem to mind going to the airport to greet the Nixons, but secretaries general of Communist parties do, it seems.

title: Her North Italian Recipes
description: VITELLO TONNATO 5 tablespoons oil 1 large onion, sliced I rib celery 2 carrots, cut in pieces 5 bay leaves 3 whole cloves 5 sage leaves or I teaspoon dried 2 teaspoons salt 3 cups dry white wine 3 pounds leg of veal without bone or 3 pounds of beef eye round 1 6ounce can tuna fish, drained 6 fillets of anchovies 3 cups mayonnaise sauce (see recipe below).

title: SHOP TALK
description: From the garbage heap at the Plaza Hotel has grown something of a new art form. Not many people would look through kitchen leavings in search of art materials, but Joe Leone, who worked for the Plaza Hotel Florist doing the decor for charity balls and wedding receptions, did, with gratifying results.

title: Hartford Suing State on Districting Laws That It Says Are Destroying Schools
description: HARTFORD, May 31  Con necticut is being taken to Fed eral Court by its capital city in a suit that charges that its constitutional rights are being violated by school districting laws that give Hartford increas ingly segregated and deterio rating schools.

title: PANARCTIC DECLINES TO DISCUSS GAS FIND
description: Charles Hetherington, presi dent of Panarctic Oils Ltd., de clined to comment yesterday on reports that the company had discovered considerable quantities of gas at its stepout well near Drake Point on Mel ville Island in the Canadian Arctic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For more than two years the Senate has debated various amendments to end the war in Vietnam, to cut off funds for it, withdraw troops, etc. None of these amendments has had any effect, except to prevent the Sen ate from acting on other bills before it.

title: Soviet Ratifies Treaty
description: MOSCOW, May 31 (AP)  The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet unanimously ratified to day the friendship treaty be tween West Germany and the Soviet Union, Tass announced.

title: $19.7Billion Approved For Federal Activities
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $19.7billion bill to finance the Government's housing, space and veterans' activities$864 million more than the House voted.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Mayor's Bid to Void Mandated Welfare Costs
description: A move by Mayor Lindsay to rid the city of the growing burden of welfare costs was rejected yesterday in Federal Court here.

title: NATO ARMS TALKS WITH EAST BACKED
description: BONN, May 31Fourteen members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization  all the member but France  agreed today to explore with the Soviet Union and its allies reductions of air and ground forces in Central Europe.

title: Court and Compassion
description: The changing attitudes of the Supreme Court are glaringly reflected in its 6to3 decision upholding Texas welfare provisions which allocate lower benefits to dependent children than to the needy aged and disabled.

title: Merger News
description: ChesebroughPond's, Inc., producer of cosmetics, toilet ries, proprietary drugs and specialty foods, is planning to go into the artmaterials field through a proposed acquisition of Binney & Smith, Inc.

title: DR. EDWARD P. EGLEE OF TB ASSOCIATION
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 31 Dr. Edward P. Eglee, a re tired chest physician and for mer director of the National Tuberculosis Association, died today in Lawrence Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 10 Courseview Road.

title: HILL JUMPS TO LEAD IN N.A.I.A. DECATHLON
description: BILLINGS, Mont., May 31 Gary Hill of Oklahoma Christ ian withstood a 95degree tem perature to take the firstday lead in the decathlon at the 21st annual N.A.I.A. track and field championships that opened here today.

title: SCRAMBLE BETS ENDED AT TROTS
description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 31 To the surprise of few, Roose velt Raceway will drop the scramble tomorrow night and reinstate the individual $2 place and $2 show wagering.

title: Hanes Names President
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., May 31 (AP)Robert E. Elberson, 43, today was named president and chief executive officer of the Hanes Corporation, suc ceeding Gordon Hanes who will continue as chairman of the board. Mr. Elberson, who also was elected as a director of the company, had been presi dent of Hanes' hosiery division since 1968 and a corporate vice president since 1965.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, May 31  The platform committee of the Dem ocratic National Convention was asked by three diverse in terest groups today to avoid taking a strong position on bus ing to achieve school desegre gation.

title: Columbia Pictures Wins, Right to Try Subscription Plan
description: A Federal judge approved yesterday a oneyear experi mental venture by Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., fea turing a movieofthe month subscription repertory of films.

title: Bloomingdale's Plans Store In a Suburb of Washington
description: Bloomingdale's said yesterday that it plans to open a 250,000 squarefoot store in the Wash ington, D.C., area if a rezoning application that it has filed is approved.

title: I.C.C. DELAYS MOVE ON RAIL STOCK PLAN
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday it would hold up its earlier ap proval of a Florida East Coast Railway Company plan for an exchange of securities until the I.C.C. can rule on a stock holder's request.

title: Anloc Pins Its Hopes on Relief Column
description: LAIKHE, South Vietnam, May 31Sgt. 1st. Cl. Jesse Yearta and a dozen other American advisers living in bunkers under the surround ed town of Anloc formed a betting pool weeks ago on when a Government relief column would push through to break the siege, now 55 days old, and enable the thousands of wounded Viet namese soldiers there to get out. No one has won.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, May 31 The California Presidential pri mary moved today into the sharpest dispute of 1972 over excessive campaign spending for television and radio.

title: F.D.A. Files First Complaint Over a Cattle Feed Additive
description: WASHINGTON, May, 31 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration announced today the first criminal action against a livestock producer for allegedly marketing cattle with residues of DES, the cancercausing feed additive.

title: William F. Butler, Chief Economist Of Chase, 54, Dead
description: William F. Butter, chief econ onust and a vice president of the Chase Manhattan and chair man of the New York State Council of Economic Advisers, died of a heart attack yesterday in Amsterdam, where he was attending the International Con ference of Commercial Bank Economists. He was 54 years Ord and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Miami Acts on Pollution
description: MIAMI, May 31 (AP)Dade County officials, angry after five days of a choking blanket of industrial smog from Ohio, Pennsylvania and Tennessee, demanded today immediate ac tion by the Federal Government and the states to shut down the polluters. The National Weather Service said it tracked clouds of smokestack emissions last week as they rode air currents into Florida from the three states.

title: Study Assails Work of Agricultural Colleges
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 The big agriculture and tech nical universities of the United States have strayed so far from their original research mis sion of aiding consumers and rural communities that they in jure the people they were in tended to serve, a study by publicinterest research organ ization has found.

title: Last Dowah Played By Smokey Robinson
description: William (Smokey) Robin son, whose soft, highpitched oooooohs and dowahs with strings created a new sound and set a special mood in soul music for young, pri marily black audiences throughout the sixties, has oohed his last dowah with, his group, The Miracles at the Apollo.

title: Congress Promised Full Arms Briefing
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The Nixon Administration said to day that it would inform Con gress fully of all private under standings reached with the Soviet Union about the arms limitation agreements signed in Moscow last Friday by Presi dent Nixon and Leonid I. Brezh nev, the Communist party leader.

title: Output Rise Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund forecast United States industrial production in creases will accelerate from the current quarter forward.

title: Pepitone to Return to Cubs to Help Win the Pennant
description: CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI)Joe Pepitone said today he would end his brief retire ment from baseball and return to the Chi cago Cubs as soon as possible because the club has a chance to win the pennant and he'd like to help them do it.

title: Books of The Times
description: Symbolic Images. By E. H. Gombrich. 247 pages. 170 illustrations. Phaidon, $15. The 19th century regarded the Renais sance as a movement of liberation from the monkish dogmatism of the Middle Ages, expressing its newfound enjoyment of sensuous pleasure in the artistic celebration of physical beauty. Some of the greatest historians of Renaissance painting such as Berenson and Wolflin still stood under the spell of this inter pretation, which dismissed all concerned with symbolism as irrelevant pedantry. In Symbolic Images, Professor Gom brich has set himself the task of correct ing this enthusiastic oversimplification and reinterpreting Renaissance art as a far more complex iconological affair.

title: Senate Reaffirms Its Support Of Rhodesian Chrome Imports
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  The Senate reaffirmed its sup port today for the continued importation into the United States of chrome ore from Rho desia in defiance of a United Nations trade embargo against the former British colony.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Moe Berg had such manifold talents that he had to be as unusual and remarkable a character as the world of baseball ever produced. It's a sadder world today because Moe died suddenly on Monday at the age of 70, and those who knew him best will grieve deeply. He was such a delightful companion and just to be with him was not only a pleasure but often an educational experience.

title: ISRAELIS SUGGEST BOYCOTT OF BEIRUT BY WORD AIRLINES
description: JERUSALEM, May 31Israe li leaders called today for a boycott of Beirut by interna tional airlines, charging that terrorist attacks on air travel ers such as the shooting at the Tel Aviv airport last night are planned by Arab guerrillas on Lebanese soil.

title: U.S. OPPOSES LIFTING O.A.S. CURBS ON CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, May 31The United States strongly opposed a plea by Peru today for nor malization of relations with Cuba, including a lifting of sanctions imposed by the Or ganization of American States in 1964.

title: Italy's Recovery Slowing, Central Bank Chief Says
description: ROME, May 31The governor of the Bank of Italy, Guido Carli, said today that the recovery of the Italian economy was slowing. He also suggested that gold and Special Drawing Rights would be essential in correcting ex change rate fluctuations. Special Drawing Rights would be essential in correcting ex change rate fluctuations.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The Bronx Democratic leader, Patrick J. Cunningham, will join his Brooklyn counterpart, Meade H. Esposito, in endorsing Senator George McGovern's Presidential candidacy, sources close to Mr. Cunningham re ported last night.

title: Curb on Primaries Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Senator Thomas F. Eagle ton, Democrat of Missouri, proposed legislation today to require that all states hay ing Presidential primaries hold them in July. His measure also would prohibit any campaign advertising more than three weeks before a primary elec tion.

title: Beirut Apprehensive of Israeli Move
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 President Suleiman Franjieh called an emergency meeting of civilian and military leaders today to consider precautionary measures against possible Israeli retaliation against Leba non.

title: Friends and Foes of OTB Disagree on Televised Races
description: Roosevelt Raceway's pro posed television agreement with the Offtrack Betting Corpora tion came under heavy attack yesterday during a 3hour hearing at the Manhattan head quarters of the State Harness Racing Commission.

title: Prosecutor Asks Davis Jurors For a FirstDegree Conviction
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 31 The jurors in the trial of Angela Davis were asked today to convict the 28yearold black activist of murder in the first degree.

title: PLAN UNIT BACKS SOUTH ST. SEAPORT
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterdey approved the creation of a Special South Street Seaport District within the Manhattan Landing devel opment along the East River.

title: Con Ed Asks P.S.C. For 17.2 % Increase In Area Gas Rates
description: The Consolidated Edison Company asked the State Pub lic Health Service Commission yesterday to approve a pro posed increase in gas rates averaging 17.2 per cent for about 1.2 million customers in the metropolitan area.

title: Development Stressed
description: The chairman of the Rank Organisation, Ltd., came to Wall Street yesterday to discuss the I biggest takeover bid ever made in Britain. At a late afternoon meeting of security analysts, Sir John Davis described Rank's efforts to acquire Watney Mann, Ltd., the big British brewery with interests in pubs, distilleries, hotels, restaurants and other businesses in Britain and elsewhere.

title: CASALS MISSES OPENING OF FETE
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 1Pablo Casals, the 95yearold master cellist, was recovering today from a bronchial ailment that forced him to cancel his appearance last night as conductor of the opening concert of the annual Casals Festival of Puerto Rico the first he has missed in 15 years.

title: 2,000 Skilled Jobs Are Offered To Aid SpanishSpeaking Here
description: The first job fair designed to place skilled persons of Spanishspeaking background in jobs paying as high as $12,000 a year was held last night in the offices of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, 322 West 45th Street.

title: Advertising:
description: On the desk of W. Page Thompson, recently installed publisher of American Home magazine, is a little sign that says, Think Bold. And just because he, can only see the back of it from where he sits doesn't mean he hasn't been affected.

title: LYALL L. STUART
description: Lyall L. Stuart, a retired en gineer for. James Stuart & Co., contractors died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 76 years old ,and lived in Garrison, N. Y., and Anna Maria, Fla.

title: WALLACE'S DOCTOR SAYS TOES MOVED
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 1 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has had some slight voluntary movement in his left toes, a doctor at Holy Cross Hospital reported today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A $5million claim was filed with. the city yesterday on behalf of the family of a detective killed by a traffic policeman who mistook him for a criminal suspect.

title: PENN'S OARSMEN TOP WASHINGTON
description: SYRACUSE, June 1Varsity eights from Pennsylvania, Cornell and Northeastern won their heats today on rough Onondaga Lake and qualified for Saturday's final at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championships.

title: Dublin Is Intensifying Its Campaign to Halt Ulster Terrorism by the I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, June 1Beside the gray concrete walls outside a Dublin pOlice station last night, 40 members of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army marched to protest the arrest of two of their leaders by the Governmint of Prime Minister John Lynch.

title: Boston Police Post Filled
description: BOSTON, June 1 (AP)William J. Taylor, superintendentinchief of the Boston Police Department, was appointed today as acting Police Commissioner to fill the job vacated by Edmund L. McNamara. Mayor Kevin H. White, who declined to appoint Mr. McNamara to a, third fiveyear term this year, said that Mr. Taylor would serve until a permanent com missioner was named.

title: Roundup: Indians Victors And Snap Losing Streak
description: Nine days and seven Cleveland defeats separated Gaylord Perry's victories.

title: UpFront, Saigon Officer Blames U.S.
description: CHINHAN, South Vietnam, May 27  Lieutenant Minh, the commander of a company of 100 men posted on the lonely front lines of South Vietnam's Orthern defenses, says: The war will never end because the Americans need it for the support of their industries.

title: Most Members Missed The Speech to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The galleries were packed but there was less than a quorum on the House floor tonight as President Nixon reported to a joint session of Congress on his trip to the Soviet Union.

title: Europe's Airports Tighten Security in Wake of Raid
description: LONDON, June 1Security at European airports has been tightened in the last two days in the aftermath of the attack by three terrorists that. left 26 persons dead at the Tel Aviv international airport.

title: Quiet Please, ExRace Horse, Takes Devon Green Hunter Title
description: DEVON, Pa., June 1  Dr. and Mrs. Harry Hemphill's Quiet Please never made it on the race track, but in the span bf three years he has found his niche in life.

title: Waterfowl With Disease To Be Killed on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 (AP)A flock of about 100 swans, geese and ducks in the lagoon at the Palace of Fine Arts will be captured and killed to prevent spread of a rare and deadly duck disease.

title: Federal Court in Hartford Voids 6Month Voter Residency Rule
description: HARTFORD, June 1Taking a lead from the United States Supreme Court, a threejudge Federal court here today declared unconstitutional a Connecticut requirement that a person live in a community for six months before being eligible to vote there.

title: Linda Stein, Writer, Wed to John Small
description: The marriage of Miss Linda Stein, a freelance press agent and writer, to John.Small, a marketing analyst with the Jello Division of the General Foods COrporation, took place in Forest Hills, Queens, last night. Justice of the peace Sidney Sterling performed the cereMony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Scherl.

title: Market Place: Mutual Funds Market Effect
description: For more than a year Wall Street has been haunted by the specter of forced selling of common stocks by mutual funds because of net redemptions of fund shares by investors.

title: CLINT HOLMES SINGS IN FORCEFUL STYLE
description: During the three shows that Clint Holmes does each night at Shepheard's in the Drake Hotel he expends an exhausting amount of energy. Mr. Holmes is a young singer with a very forceful deliveryboth physically and emotionally forcefulwho seems determined to bowl over his listeners with every song he sings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Battery Park City Authority has announced the proposed issuance of $200 million of debt. This authority contemplates the construction of five million square feet of commercial office space on landfill in the East River. The pattern of the World Trade Center is therefore to be repeated; a governmental authority will undertake the construction of a private office; building.

title: Julius J. Richman IS Dead; Finance Officer for City,
description: Julius, J. Richman, assistant finance administrator for audits and inspections for the City of NeW York died Wednesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx. His age was 57. He aved at 2312 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx.

title: CANADA CONFIRMS GAS WELL REPORT
description: The Canadian Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development confirmed yesterday in Montreal that Panarctic Oils, Ltd., has encountered additional natural gas at its Drake Point well on Northeast Melville Island in the Canadian Arctic.

title: JUDGE MAY SELECT ELECTIONS BOARD
description: A Federal judge declared yesterday that he would appoint a new Board of Elections unless. the city acted. promptly under his decision of last September in which he declared the present board unconstitutional.

title: Tel Aviv, Alerted for New Raid Applies Strict Curbs
BOEING'S CHAIRMAN WILL RETIRE AT 72
description: William M. Allen, chairman of the Boeing Company, said yesterday that, in accordance with company policy, he would retire in September at the age of 72. He will remain a consultant to the company. Boeing said that T. A. Wilson, president and chief executive officer, would assume the additional duties of chairman.

title: Bullet Hits Car of Mayor Hart, A Black in Essex House Contest
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 1 Al bullet hit the car of Mayor William S. Hart, a black candidate for the Democratic nomination for. Representative in New Jersey's 10th Congressional District, as he emerged from the car at the rear of City Hall tonight.

title: Hanol Claims 3 U.S. Planes
description: HONG KONG, Friday, June 2 (Reuters)The North Vietnamese press agency reported today that three American planes were shot down yesterday over the North Vietnamese provinces of Langson, Vinhphu and Yenbai. The fate of the fliers was not disclosed.

title: Books of The Times
description: Dissenting in the subtitle doesn't quite cover the case. The essays are a broadfront attack on the situation in English studies in the colleges, as well as on departmental structures, outlook, curriculums, philosophy and practice. They are concerned with what the editors, Louis Kampf and Paul Lauter, term the social function of literature, the institutional role of that discipline in the world of scholarship. And these concerns are in turn an expression of the frustration that the contributors to this volumeand those they speak forfeel in their work as teachers.

title: TAX AIDE FAVORS TOP RATE OF 35%
description: WASHINGTON, June 1A high Treasury, official has suggested that the Nixon Administration at least consider a reform in the tax laws that would cut the top tax rate to 35 per cent from 70 per cent and eliminate all favored tax treatment of capital ,gains,

title: Signs of a New South
description: I want to change the political climate of Arkansas, an unknown named Dale Bumpers told voters in his 1970 campaign for Governor. Mr. Bumpers went far toward his objective by swamping the demagogic former Governor, Orval E. Faubus, for the Democratic nomination, then beating Republican Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller handily. Now it is probable that Governor Bumpers will get major help in transforming. the Arkansas political climate from Representative David H. Pryor, 37.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The doves have long been unhappy about the work of the Central Intelligence Agency in fomenting and directing secret wars in Laos and other countries. Now it becomes clear that. our military was caught by surprise in finding that North Vietnam brought a large number of tanks down the Ho Chi Minh Trail and prepared for largescale attacks across the DMZ and at Anloc.

title: Amex Net Shows Drop
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its firstquarter net income had declined, to $245,000 from $306,000 in the comparable period of last year. Total revenues rose to $6.5Million from the yearearlier $6.2million, but exinnses also rose, from $5.9million to $6.2million.

title: The Screen: Suggested by Thurber:'War Between Men and Women' at Music Hall Lemmon Has Role of a Man Going Blind
description: Watching "The War Between Men and Women" is like being in a haunted house in broad daylight. The movie is described as having been "suggested by the writings and drawings of James Thurber and including 'The Last Flower'" (a construction that I'm sure would have amused the late humorist and grammarian for at least 14 minutes).However sunny it looks, it is really eerie, something all wrong and out of joint, a comedy about a man going blind, and about a child with a traumatic stammer. It's the sort of movie in which Dr. Joyce Brothers, apparently playing herself at a literary tea, is heard saying "There's nothing wrong with paranoia if you don't take it seriously."What, you might wonder, Is up? Who's making fun of who? These are legitimate questions if you've ever had the pleasure of hearing Dr. Brothers make Sweeping Statements about masturbation on N.B.C. Radio.Confusion, as they say, reigns (or is it rains?) in "The War Between Men and Women," which pretends to be about Thurber, but isn't (it's about a fictional character named Peter Wilson who writes Thurber's books and draws Thurber's cartoons), and which utilizes Thurber's work but whose comic pole is located somewhere south of "Make Room for Daddy."Gag: At a cocktail party Peter Wilson (Jack Lemmon) drops his glasses into a pitcher of martinis. Since he can't see to fish them out, he must drink the contents of the pitcher.
