J., a sec ondyear premedical student at the University of Michi gan, and Scott Usher, a pack aging engineer for the Lehn & Fink Products Company, Montvale, N. J. Mr. Williams is now 19 and Mr. Usher 29.

title: Blasts in Argentina Mark Date of 56 Coup Attempt
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 9 (AP) Bombs exploded here and in three other major cities today on the 16th anniversary of a Peronist military attempt to take over the Government.

title: MRS. ESTILL I. GREEN
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., June 9 Mrs. Sara V. Green,.wife of Estill I. Green, executive vice president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories until his retire ment in 1960, died yesterday at her home, 95 Farley, Road. She was 76 years old.

title: Levitz's Chairman Ties Woes to Lack Of Communication
description: The top management of the Levitz Furniture Corporation took the unusual step yester day of telling its shareholders that a lack of communication among top management was responsible for some of its re cent troubles.

title: Saturday's Children
description: Saturday morning is children's time on most television channels. Millions of youngsters spend hours at the start of each weekend watching their favorite cartoons and other shows of varying quality. Along with these goes a steady stream of commercial messagesat a rate of well over twenty an hour. The inevitable consequence of this concentrated hardsell practiced on an exceed ingly impressionable audience is a massive appeal to mothers and fathers everywhere to buy, buy, buy.

title: 3 Weight Records Are Set in Trials For Paralympics
description: Because this is an Olympic year, there was special interest in the 16th annual National Wheelchair Games that began three days of competition in six sports yesterday in Queens.

title: Holders of U.S. Smelting Approve Change in Name
description: Stockholders of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company approved change in the corporate name to UV Industries, Inc., at a spe cial meeting here yesterday. The company's trading symbol has been UV since 1916 and the new name was said to be more representative of present operations. Directors also named J. George Gange, for merly senior vice president, as chairman to succeed Jack Wil der, who will remain a direc tor.

title: 4 Challenge McGovern's Right To All 271 California Delegates
Patricia H. Hamlin Married to Ensign
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9The garden of the Alumni House on King George Street here was the setting for the marriage today of Miss Pa tricia Hill Hamlin to Ens Del man Brown Hall 3d a 1972 graduate of the United States Naval Academy. Capt. Henry Duncan, Chaplain Corps U.S.N., performed the Episco pal ceremony.

title: Appeals Court Race Lacks Politicking
description: With three of the seven seats on the state's highest court on the ballot and a woman in the running for the first time, the Democratic primary race for the Court of Appeals has all the makings of bigtime politicking.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW SLIM DROP
description: Talk of the Wankel engine, which sparked a sharp rise dur ing the week in American Is raeli Paper Mills shares, had an impact on another American Stock Exchange issue yesterday.

title: Illegal Guns
description: Federal guncontrol legislation is an essential part of any effective response to the growing abuse of firearms that has reached epidemic proportions. But there is no reason to stand passively by and await Federal action which, if the past influence of the gun lobby on Congress is any indication, may not be taken until the bloodletting becomes even more appalling. There can be no excuse whatsoever for the continuing laxity in the enforcement of existing local and state statutes.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CORP. AWARDED CONTRACT
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day it has been selected by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and the United Il luminating Company, New Ha ven, Conn., to supply two nu, clear reactors and fuel for an electric generating station to be built in Seabrook, N. H. West inghouse declined to estimate the value of the proposed con tract.

title: Humphrey Plans to Push Intensive Delegate Hunt
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In response to Rose Shapiro's letter of May 20, in my judgment she mis represents both Dr. Kenneth Clark's assessment of school decentralization and what decentralization is under the current law.

title: Jersey Unemployment Rate Reported at 7.3% for May
description: TRENTON, June 9 (AP)The State Department of Labor and Industry reported today that the New Jersey unemployment rate in May stood at 7.3 per cent after seasonal adjustment, a rise of threetenths of a point over April.

title: Ryun Wins 3:57.3 Mile On Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP) Jim Ryun added luster to a curious comeback tonight by defeating an excellent field of milers in the Vons track meet at the Coliseum, running under 4 minutes for the third time this season.

title: U.S. Air Power Surges As Bombing Is Increased
description: WASHINGTON, June 9President Nixon has nearly doubled Air Force fighter bomber strength in Southeast Asia and tripled the number of aircraft carriers, and he is, quadrupling the force of 352 Stratofortresses there.

title: Vietnamization: Is It Working or Isn't It?
description: Mr. Proxmire. Mr. President, on Monday, May 15, Secretary of State William Rogers appeared before the Foreign Operations Subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee. I have the honor to chair that sub committee.

title: Bomb Parcel Sent to Kaunda
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, June (Reuter)  The explosion of bomb in a parcel at President Kenneth B. Kaunda's official residence is under investigation by the Zambia police. Accord ing to unofficial reports, parcel addressed to President Kaunda exploded on May 26. A secretary who opened it was said to have been blinded and had an arm blown off.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 9(UPI)Robert G. Dillenbeck, 36, waived a preliminary hear ing today on charges that he threatened to blow up an American Airlines jetliner un less he was given $300,000.

title: Rita Mitchell Bride Of Richard Crone
description: HUNTINGTON, June 9 Miss Rita Mitchell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William A Mitchell, was married here this noon to Richard Allan Crone, son of Brig. Gen Richard I. Crone, Army Medi cal Corps, retired, and Mrs. Crone of Santa Rosa, Calif The Rev. Peter Kaczmarek performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Hugh's Roman Catholic Church.

title: PATRICIA COLE
description: WESTON, Mass., June 9Patricia Cole, an abstract artist who had paintings ex hibited in galleries in New Eng land and New York City, died here Wednesday after a long illness. Her age was 48.

title: Kennedy Guard Lifted At Request of Senator
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The Secret Service agents who have guarded Senator Edward M. Kennedy since the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace were re moved at the Senator's re quest this week with his thanks for their cooperation and understanding.

title: Westinghouse Shifts Merger Terms
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day it had completed negotia tions to acquire Host Enter prises, Inc., an operator of motels and resort properties, for stock valued at about $19 million.

title: Legal Age Cut to 18
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June (UP1)A law lowering the legal age of majority to 18 went into effect today in West Virginia. The law gives persons 18 to 20 years old legal independence from their parents, the right to purchase liquor, bet at race tracks, enter contracts and sue or be sued.

title: New Ukrainian Premier Named In a Shuffle of Top Soviet Posts
description: MOSCOW, June 9A 57yearold former engineer was appointed today as Premier of the Ukrainian Republic, the Soviet Union's second most im portant state. The job has often been a stepping stone to the nation's Politburo, the inner circle of Soviet power.

title: Couple in Soviet Balked After Jewish Marriage
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI)Risking arrest, a Soviet Jew and his American bride came out of hiding today and tried to legalize their clandestine marriage. Bureaucratic red tape blocked the way.

title: Mrs. King Reaches Tennis Final; Graebner, Wife Ill, Quits Match
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June, 9 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., gained the final of the John Player roundrobin tennis tournament today, but Clark Graebner of New York was forced to de fault in the middle of his final round match when his wife became ill.

title: 2 Anthropological Films Are Beauties
description: The Film Forum that small but enterprising uptown showcase, is ending its cur rent season with colors fly ing. Two of the three filmsthe two long onesof batch labeled anthropological are real beauties.

title: Japan Sets Up a Fund For Tel Aviv Victims
description: TOKYO, June 9 (AP)Japan announced today a $1.5million fund for victims of the Tel Aviv airport mas sacre on May 30, in which 27 were killed and nearly 80 wounded by proArab Japan ese terrorists.

title: RANEY, GUITARIST, KEEPS HIS STYLE
description: When Jimmy Raney was playing with Stan Getz and Red Norvo in the early nine teenfifties he was one of the very few jazz guitarists of that period who managed to project any individuality of expression amid the tinny clatter of bop bred, guitarists who were then running through endless suc cessions of uniform phrases. Mr. Raney was relaxed and lyrical and, simply by subtle uses of shading, he made his performances swing much more convincingly than the agitated efforts of his peers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Serious questions involving diplo matic protocol and international com munication have arisen as a result of the signatures appended by the Gen eral Secretary of the Communist party of the U.S.S.R. and the First Secretary of the Polish Communist party to the accords concluded between these coun tries and the United States of America.

title: Drexel Firestone Names New Chief
description: Drexel Firestone., Inc. the investment banking and broker1 age concern, announced yester day that Archie E. Albright had been named chairman, president and chief executive in what ap peared to be a major manage ment restructuring.

title: Thomas E. Groehn, 57, Directed G.M. Press Office
description: GROSSE POINTE WOODS, Mich., June 9  Thomas E. Groehn, director of news rela tions for the General Motors Corporation, died here today at his home after a brief ill ness. His age was 57.

title: Aussies Make Shaky Reply To English in Cricket Test
description: MANCHESTER, England, June 9 (Reuters)Australia scored only 103 runs for four wickets today in reply to England's moderate firstinnings total of 249 on the second day of the first cricket test.

title: BAJA 500 IS TAKEN BY FERRO'S BUGGY
description: ENSENADA, Mexico, June 9 (AP)Bob Ferro of Sherman Oaks, Calif., driving a single seat dune buggy, won the Baja 500 offroad race in record breaking time today.

title: Slaying of Militiaman in Ulster Brings Death Toll to 5 in 2 Days
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 9A Protestant militia man was slain today in a new surge of violence that has taken five lives in Northern Ireland in the last two days.

title: Negotiating Season
description: Presidential adviser Henry Kissinger has repeatedly predicted that serious negotiations with Hanoi will re sume when the current Communist offensive in South Vietnam comes to an end. The offensive, after some spectacular gains, now appears to be slowing down with the beginning of heavy monsoon rains. The season for negotiations appears to be approaching again.

title: Deportation Inquiry Told Guard Beat NaziDeathCamp Inmates
description: A woman who was an in mate of the Nazi concentra tion camp at Maidanek, Poland, during World War II testified yesterday that she had seen Mrs. Russell Ryan help to load children into trucks that were to take them to gas chambers.

title: 24 Foundations Are Asked By Patman to Produce Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Representative Wright Pat map, Democrat of Texas, chair man of the House Banking Committee, asked 24 privately controlled foundations today for infortnation on their com pliance With provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1969.

title: Eleven New Issues Made Their Debut During the Week
description: Eleven new issues made their appearance in public trading on the overthecounter market this week and, with two ex ceptions, wound up their initial trading experience with rela tively minor price fluctuations.

title: Study for House Unit Finds Laxity in F.D.A. Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) House investigators accused the Food and Drug Adminis tration today of risking Amer icans health by letting most imported foods enter the coun try without any kind of exam ination.

title: Executive Changes
description: Samuel Z. Arkoff, chairman of the American International Pictures, Inc., has been named to the additional post of president.

title: Castro Visits Gdansk
description: WARSAW, June 9 (Reuter)Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba today visited the Baltic port of Gdansk on the last leg of his fourday tour of Poland's in dustrial provinces.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Professor William Quirk, writing from South Carolina, makes four fac tual errors, one twicerepeated, in the first four sentences of his letter of May 5 referring to the Battery Park City Authority's recent $200 million bond sale.

title: ROLLSROYCE AUTOS TO GO PUBLIC IN FALL
description: LONDON, June 9 (AP)RollsRoyce Motors, Ltd., the automotive section of the once mighty auto and aerospace en terprise, is to be turned into a public corporation, it was an nounced today.

title: Federal Drug Traffic Figures Contested
description: Representative Lester L. Wolff, chairman of a House foreign affairs subcommittee in vestigating international drug traffic, challenged yesterday an Administration assertion that it had made real progress in suppressing the flow of narcot ics out of South Vietnam, Laos, and Thailand.

title: RISE OF 10% VOTED IN SOCIAL SECURITY BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security benefits by 10 per cent for 27 million Americans.

title: Screen: Routine Western
description: Filmed on location In and around Madrid directed by Terence Young and starring Charles Bronson, Alain Delon Toshiro Mifune and Ursula Andress, Red Sun, which opened yesterday at several local theaters, may very well qualify as the first Spanish BritishAmerican FrenchJap aneseSwiss Western. But for all its international exoticism, it remains a very convention al Western, a little above routine, in which the best sequence happens to be the shootemup Indian attack in the finale.

title: Antitrust Division Chief Quits; Professor Is Named Successor
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Walker B. Comegys, acting head of the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department, re signed today  one day after Richard G. Kleindienst was con firmed as Attorney General.

title: Gilbert T. Stephenson Dead; Banker Specialized in Trusts
description: PENDLETON, N. C., June 9Gilbert T. Stephenson, a banker specializing in trust work who also had been an educator, died today at Warren Place, the family home near here, where he was born. He was 87 years old.

title: RUSKIN CAUTIONS STATE ON INQUIRY
description: The city's Commissioner off Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin, served notice on the state com mission investigating the New York City government yester day that its inquiry would not be allowed to run roughshod over the rights of individuals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Representative William F. Ryan's progressive record in the area of health care deserves and has gotten continued support from those of us who are health workers. He has successfully pioneered the development, enactment and implementation of programs for childhood lead poisoning, Medicaid and Medicare, neighborhood health and mentalhealth centers, child health pro grams, school breakfasts, dental health, sicklecell anemia, insecticide and noise pollution, etc.

title: New Orleans Warned
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 9 (Reuters)  The United States Environmental Protection Agen cy warned New Orleans today that the city might lose some Federal sewage treatment funds if it continued dumping huge amounts of raw sewage into the Mississippi River.

title: 60 YACHTS BEGIN SERIES OF RACES
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 9Sixty yachts took off in a mid Sound spinnaker start today on the first leg of a racing series that includes the Astor, Onion Patch and duPont Trophies and the Bermuda Race. For some skippers, the fun won't be over until they reach Bayona, Spain, a month from now.

title: MARKET DECLINES FIFTH DAY IN ROW
description: The stock market, somber in tone and saddled with worries, sank for the fifth day in a row yesterday.

title: J. E. Hartman Weds Ann O'Donnell
description: MANHASSET L.I, June 9 Miss Ann Moira O'Donnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Emmet O'Donnell of Munsey Park was married here this afternoon to John Ellsworth Hartman son of Mr. and Mrs. Coy Schaeffer Hartman of Wolfeboro N.H. The Rev. Neil Doherty per formed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: PHILIPPINES INTENDS TO REOPEN U.S. PACTS
description: MANILA, June 9 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos said yesterday that the Philip pines intends to renegotiate all existing treaties with the Unit ed States because of changing American policies in Asia.

title: Rachel K.Rice Has Nuptials
description: RED BANK, N. J., June 9Miss Rachel Kirk Rice, daugh ter of Brig Gen. Harold Windsor Rice, U.S.A., retired and Mrs. Rice of Sea Girt was married here this eve ning to Robert Alden Jocelyn son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Law Jocelyn of Honolulu. The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Webster performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: MUSKIE REFUSES TO BACK ROVER REMAINS IN RACE
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine prolonged the competi tion for the Democratic Presi dential nominationand added a bit of suspense about the out comeby refusing today to en dorse Senator George McGovern of South Dakota.

title: Dave Anderson
description: From the asphalt runway, Norman Tate waved at a husky man beyond the landing pit.

title: City Bank Raises Rate
description: The First National City Bank, as expected, increased its floating prime, or base lend ing rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, effective next week.

title: School Board, 3 to 2, Approves A Black for Examiners Board
description: The Board of Education ap proved 3 to 2 yesterday the provisional appointment of a black educator, who was once accused of harassing union teachers, to membership on the school system's Board of Exam iners.

title: Mrs. Lawrence Married to E. F. Locke
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 9Mrs. Lael Markel Law rence of Old Chatham and Edward F. Locke were mar ried here this evening in the Berkshire Garden Center by Justice of the Peace Clement Moore.

title: Price of A7 Light Bomber Up $900,000 for Each Plane
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (Reu ters) The cost of advanced models of the A7 light bomber, the main attack aircraft of the Air Force and Navy, has risen by $900,000 a plane, according to Congressional testimony re leased today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two gunmen burst into a basement construction shanty in an uncompleted building at 41st Street and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday and stole $17,533.46 in 71 pay envelopes minutes before the money was to be distributed to sheetmetal workers on the site.

title: Art: Venice Biennale as a Barometer
description: VENICE, Italy, June 9As a cultural event, the Venice Biennale claims a double interest. It is, first of all, a mammoth international survey of contemporary art, reflecting what official spokesmen in the advanced. industrial nations regard as their most prestigious ac complishments of the mo ment. But the Biennale is also, in addition to being an exhibition, a barometer of the social climate in which art is conceived, created, promoted and appreciated. Thus, whatever the exhibition may lack in esthetic quality, it is never without interest as a sign of what is happen Mg to the art world itself.

title: STAMFORD PASSES SCHOOLBUS BILL Program Will Mainly Affect City's Minority Pupils
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 9  Stamford's Board of Edu cation has approved a far reaching redistricting plan to desegregate the city's public. elementary schools.

title: U.S. and China Clash
description: STOCKHOLM, June 9 (AP)The United States and China clashed tonight over the Viet nam war in a meeting held to discuss a draft declaration on environmental principles.

title: New Window Opens on Atom as Giant Accelerator Passes FullPower Test
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M., June 9A new accelerator capable of generating proton beams thousands of times more in tense than can be produced by any other comparable machine was tested successfully at full power early this morning. The test opened a new window on the atomic nucleus and the mysterious forces that hold it together.

title: Winter Wheat Crop Is Estimated at 2% Above Level for '71
description: WASHINGTON,. June 9 (AP) The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1972 crop of winter wheat at 1,192,478, 000 bushels, 2 per cent more than last year and 4 per cent more than predicted in May.

title: The Pilots'
description: The threat of the international organization representing airline pilots to shut down global service for 24 hours on June 19 unless the United Nations acts to stop hijacking reflects their exasperation at an unconscionable situation.

title: SAMUEL M. VINCENT
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 9Samuel Mitchell Vincent, presi dent of the Vincent Brothers (Company, a home and indus trial heating concern here, died today in Bridgeport Hos pital. He was 47 years old and lived at 2173 Redding Road.

title: Policeman Kills Himself After Wounding 2 Others
description: READING, Pa., June 9 (AP) An offduty policeman shot and wounded two fellow po licemen and then killed him self today as the three were working as guards at the Read ing Air Show, the police reported.

title: RAINY DAY BESETS SOYBEAN FUTURES
description: Rain in cropgrowing areas sent prices of soybean and most grain futures lower yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Business Bureau Elects
description: William G. Sharwell, execu tive vice presidentoperations of the New York Telephone Company has been elected chairman of the board of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, Inc. The bureau is the largest of the nation's 140 local units.

title: Books of The Times
description: Margaret Drabble has a teasing way about her. She is, in this novel, always promising the unexpected and delivering the expected. What is not supposed to happen in fiction occurs here with disarm ing regularity. Illicit lovers don't consum mate their affairs, wayward husbands re turn to their wives, sundered marriages are made whole, children after es trangement, are re conciled to their parents, family quarrels lose their sting. Real estate is not excepted. Run down neigh borhoods rehabili tate themselves. And the one bizarre character in the book man ages, after a fash ion, to reconcile herself to wealth and marital peace. I guess The Needle's Eye is a domestic comedy are made whole, children after es trangement, are re conciled to their parents, family quarrels lose their sting. Real estate is not excepted. Run down neigh borhoods rehabili tate themselves. And the one bizarre character in the book man ages, after a fash ion, to reconcile herself to wealth and marital peace. I guess The Needle's Eye is a domestic comedy of sorts, although the humor doesn't stand much chance in the portentous atmos phere of the fiction. Like her mentors; Henry James and very, likely Virginia Woolf, Miss Drabble IS concerned with interior states: of mind, feeling, perception. Essentially colorless, her people turn in wards, conscious of the intensity of their feelings, of pendulumlike swings of love and hate, one following hard on the other, of powerful impulses never given outlet, of thoughts never expressed. They weigh, balance, measure. Most of the novel takes place indoors and over dinner or cups of tea. If the atmosphere is suffocating, blame the author.

title: GINEVRA, AT 81, WINS EPSONIOAKS
description: EPSOM, England, June 10 (AP)Ginevra rallied from last place to win the Epsom Oaks today, upsetting hopes of double for the United States.

title: New York Junior Girls Rebuild Golf Squad for Title Defense
description: The junior schedule of the Women's Metropolitan. Golf Association has just been completed and it calls for an intercity team match as well as a championship.

title: Schoolboy Hurdles Mark Set
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 10 (UPI)Bruce Scully of Audubon High School in Audubon, N. J., set a national record of 36.6 seconds in the allAmerican High School track and field meet 330yard high hurdles tonight. Scully's speed broke the old record of :36.7 set by Bob Bornkessel of North High in 1968.

title: Some Weeks It's Just Bah! Humbug!
description: WHAT would I think if I were alive today! On Broadway and onSeventh Avenue, between 45th and 48th Streets, there were five films designed almost exclusively for black audiences in first runs last week. The Astor Theater, on Broadway at 45th Street, which showed its first film (the Italian Quo Vadis) in 1913, has just closed, probably permanently. It's now easier to buy a shishkabob than a hot dog on most Times Square street corners. The proliferating little porn houses on Eighth Avenue, Seventh Avenue and the side streets grind away with titles like School Girls and Bob & Daryl & Ted & Alex. Early on a Thursday afternoon, on a 49th Street crosstown bus, three elderly ladies, who looked to be from the suburbs, were giggling in anticipation of seeing

title: The Fire This Time
description: The children were at play last Thursday beside large pink pagoda on the edge of the town of Trangbang, 40 miles from Saigon. Some 150 yards away, North Vietnamese soldiers were entrenched in the town's marketplace. Two singleengine, propellerdriven Skyraiders of the South Vietnamese air force began dropping bombs on the enemy, and some the bombs fell near the pagoda. The children ran down a. road.

title: Kodak Goal: Beat Polaroid
description: ROCHESTEROne subject is a virtual nono when corporate officials at the Eastman Kodak company talk to outsiders. And it doesn't take a visitor long to discover what it is.

title: She's a Pied Piper for Modern Art
description: EAST ORANGEAn active ardent woman who has introduced hundreds of suburbanites to modern art has just been elected for a second time to the graphics jury of the National Association of Women Artists.

title: Music
description: THERE is, to quote a prophetic American folk song of the fifties, a whole lotto shakin goin on. Last week we saw the New York Stock Exchange electing the first black director in its 180year historywhich sounds earthshaking even to one who is quite vague about what, exactly, the New York Stock Exchange does. In the same week, another pillar of the Establishment, the New York Philharmonic, agreed on a fairemployment program with the city's Human Rights Commission after three years of debate. Such seismic rumblings can only lift the hopes of those of us who have listened in growing consternation while spokesmen both black and white have advised us that the country's only future lies in some homegrown variety of apartheid.

title: Impervious is the word for Noah
description: There is a note so eerie, so daunting, in the story of Josh Greenfeld's small son, Noah, that it transcends even the dreadful sadness. I remembered the Gadarene swine. Two thousand years ago Noah Greenfeld would have been a child possessed of demons. Through months of excruciating repetition, his father, his mother, his therapists, manage to teach Noah one sound, Aaaah. Then the child sees his favorite food and shrieks, Bagels! He is autistic, maybe. The diagnoses, if not the demons, are legion. And the agony of Josh and Foumi Greenfield  mean, draining, undignified agony  has no end. I wanted to do what they cannot do, close the book. Yet didn't, for A Child Called Noah is at least as fascinating as it is terrible.

title: Medicine
description: In American hospitals, when word spreads that a typhoid case has arrived on the premises, medical students flock to the patient's bedside. The disease is now that rare in this country. But in lands were sanitation and water supplies are primitive, typhoid cases are all too common. And public health officials there know that at any time the disease can suddenly, unpredictably become epidemic.

title: ALL AGESCan anyone look at a panda and not smile?
description: WASHINGTONTwo 18monthold Chinese immigrants, a svelte, 136pound giant panda named LingLing and her sleepy 74pound mate, HsingHsing, have already become this town's number one tourist attraction, outdrawing the Capitol, the Washington Monument and even the White House.

title: New Novel
description: Do You Remember England?

title: CanAm Pole to Donohue; 4Man Race Is Seen Today
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, June 10 With a contented smile, Mark Donohue sat out today's time trials at Mosport Park and watched his competitors futilely chase the qualifying record he set yesterday.

title: Burnessa, Ridden By Chapot, Victor In Far Hills Show
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., June 10Mrs. Screven Lorillard's Burnessa switched from the field to the ring in successful fashion today at the 20th renewal of the Far Hills Horse Show.

title: FOLKLORE CENTER SWITCHES TO JAll
description: The Folklore Center, Avenue of the Americas at Third Street, which is usually a setting for folk singers and folk musicians, made one of its very rare ventures into jazz on Friday night. Unlike the relatively traditional nature of the folk music that is usually heard there, this switch to jazz went out toward the exploratory, avantgarde end of the spectrum.

title: Music in Lomdon
description: MY baptism of fire was a voluble voice at the end of a telephone at an hour when most critics are still sleeping the sleep of the unjust. At that time I only knew of Lina Lalandi as a Greek harpsichordist. But her early morning call of nine years ago  it was a summons to a party to launch what was originally called the Oxford Bach Festivalwar; my first experience of the powers of persuasion that induced Stravinsky to serve as her festival's patron and to conduct at its inaugural concert, and have since landed Leonard Bernstein as his successor.

title: Open Heart
description: For novelists it matters very much whether the Messiah has come or is yet to come. The human difference is this: If the Messiah has not yet appeared, then the world is still profane, and our task is to wrest him forth, to go and fetch him, so to speakto do what is necessary to bring him on. But if the Messiah has already cleft the skin of human history, then the world is at this moment transfigured into a holy site, and we need only stand still; already redeemed, we do God's work unawares, and even the most unlikely vessels inherit the divine redemption. It is the difference between meriting and being found, between ethics and grace, between covenant and disclosurethe difference, in short, between man searching for God and God searching for man.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The statements and actions of the Imperial Japanese Government regarding the horrifying massacre of innocent travelers at Lod Airport have earned the admiration and gratitude of all who seek peace, justice, decency and authentically human relations among men.

title: Recordings

These are of Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 and Schubert's Symphony No. 8 (Unfinished), which were originally made for Victor with the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1927. They are paired On No. 5 in the Parnassus catalogue (Parnassus Records, P.O. Box 281, Phoenicia, N.Y. 12464).

It is again with deep regret that we report that the Commission appointed by the President with authority and funds from Congress has not yet appeared to move off dead center, and with the calendar moving inexorably toward July 4, 1976, the Commission might even be said to be sliding backward.

title: Foreign policypeace through war, truth through lies
description: For the past three decades one President after another has been telling us that we must make the world safe for America. F.D.R. preached the Four Freedoms, Harry Truman dropped the atomic bomb, Ike and Dulles set up a global system of bases, J.F.K. told us we were the watchmen on the walls of freedom, L.B.J. warned us that others wanted what we have, and Nixon seeks respect for his office by B52 raids on small Asian states. Security through terror, peace through war, truth through lies: this has been the model for United States foreign policy for nearly two generations.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Alternative LifeStyle Of Playboys and Playmates
description: THE Big Black Bunny soared high above the frozen stubble land of northern Kansas. Snug in his orange shag compartment, Hugh Hefner confidently surveyed his holdings and plumped down $280 for Marvin Gardens. His secretary, Bobbie Arnstein, rolled next, won second prize in a beauty contest and collected $10. Then it was my turn, and with monopolies coalescing all around me, I needed to deal. Hefner and his girl friend, Barbi Benton, sitting side by side on the facing banquette, had most of the attractive properties, but I was wary of dealing with either of them. Early in the game Barbi had lured me into a bad bargain, giving her the pale blue Oriental Vermont Connecticut monopoly on which she was already building a Levittown of little green houses. Then Hefner had persuaded me to take his Water Works (which along with my Electric Company would give me 10 times the roll of the dice if anybody ever landed on one, which they never did) in exchange for my Short Line Railroad (which along with the three other railroads he soon assembled gave him $200 every time somebody landed on one, which they always did). But now Hefner had Tennessee Avenue, which I needed to go with my New York and St. James. For five minutes we haggled over our chicken bones until finally he induced me to part with Virginia Avenue and $700. Only as the Big Black Bunny made its final approach to Chicago's O'Hare Field did I realize that I'd made my third mistake. Hefner's properties now sported not green row houses but phalanxes of big red hotels which marched the board like the coastline of Miami Beach. And I was rounding Go, heading right for them. As the plane came to a halt in front of its hangar, the issue was still in doubtthere were those who felt that Hefner's resources were overextended and his cash supply dangerously lowbut from the sunshine yellow of Ventnor Avenue to the deep purple of St. Charles Place, the Hefner Empire looked well entrenched.

title: Bill Is Introduced to Forbid Use of ABomb in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)  Representative Lester L. Wolff, Democrat of Nassau, has introduced a bill designed to prohibit President Nixon from using a nuclear bomb in Southeast Asia without specific approval of Congress.

title: How a Big Wheel Like Ferris Got His Start
description: It's Children's Day again in Forest Hills, an event that's been taking place there every June for the last 19 years. And in Flagpole Park, just behind the Forest Hills Inn, multicolored plastic flags are waving over all sorts of little booths that haven't opened as yet. Hot dogs are heating in bubbling cauldrons, and lastminute checks are being made on the free flow of Coke.

title: Plan to Preserve Surplus Water For Droughts Studied in Florida
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 10 (UPI)Engineers are studying the possibility of pumping surplus rain and recycled waste water into halfmiledeep storage wells that could be tapped during south Florida's periodic droughts.

title: 54,636 AT TRACK
description: Rive Ridge ascended to the heights at Belmont Park yeterday, recording a smashing Victory in the $155,900 Belmont Stakes. The Meadow Stable's star raced in front all the Way in the 1mile test of the champion to score by seven lengths over the long shot Ruritania of the Greentree Stable, In third place among the 10 contestants came Cloudy Dawn, who had five lengths over the fourthplace colt, Key to the Mint.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article, Scholars Ponder Right to Shelter, [May 7] leads me to believe that the New York State law relating to forming cooperative apartments is unconstitutional when applied to rentstabilized tenant who votes against a cooperative plan.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to Amherst to see Emily Dickinson's home, you'll have to go on a Tuesday. The house is open only on Tuesdays, from 3 to 5 P.M., and only to visitors who have made reservations through the secretary of Amherst College (Phone: 4135422321).

title: Plants of the Little Frogs
description: Buttercups sparkle in the meadows and wild columbines glow, red and gold, on rocky slopes. In the damp places the marsh marigolds have finished their blooming and spread a thick shade of rounded, deep green leaves. Hepatica and the dainty little wood anemone are almost through flowering, overwhelmed by shade and the flow of the season.

title: CHINA DENOUNCES U.S. ON POLLUTION
description: STOCKHOLM, June 10China today denounced the United States and other imperialistic superpowers as being primarily responsible for global environmental problems, and demanded compensation for the underdeveloped countries.

title: WHEELCHAIR GAMES GET JAVELIN RECORD
description: John Jerome of the Cleveland Comets set a record in the javelin with a toss of 110 feet 5 inches yesterday as the 16th annual National Wheelchair Games continued at Bulova Park in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Miss Shanahan Engaged to Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 10Miss Alice Mary Shanahan and Yeoman 3/c Robert Alan Cross, U.S.N., 1970 graduates of Niagara University, plan to be married next May.

title: Stunt Pilot Tells Of 42d St. Flight
description: NORTH BERGEN  Anyone seeing mildmannered William Diehl sitting in Schuetzen Park in North Bergen probably would not identify him as one of the most daring pilots of the 1910's and 20's.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The harried Long Island Rail Road commuter may soon see a new era of improved rail passenger service.

title: Indvidualized Teaching Aiding Poor Readers
description: Emphasizing individualized instruction and utilizing any and all educational materials, a remedial reading program for 1,000 belowaverage students of Community School District 29 in southeastern Queens has produced substantial gains in their reading scores.

title: The Case of the Albuquerque Eights Is Closed
description: A 57yearold former vice president of the Meadow Brook National Bank, a man with three grown daughters and high blood pressure, stood before Judge Irving Ben Cooper in Federal Court here earlier this month and heard the sentence:

title: 94BILLION BUDGET ADOPTED FOR CITY; LAYOFFS FORESEEN
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday Adopted a S9.407billion city operating budget, abandoning his request for new taxes, but warning of impending layoffs of an undisclosed number of city employes and the continued loss in Police, Fire and Sanitation Department strength.

title: Rodeo School: 30 Students Take Great Pains to Learn the Ropes
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 10Last week. Larry Mahan held his seventh annual rodeo school on the Tommy Steiner Ranch near Austin. It was comparable to golfers taking lessons from Arnold Palmer: the students hung on Mahan's every word.

title: Mail:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The Times obituary of John Montague, the golfer who died May 29 in California, told a great deal about him, but certainly not all. Surprisingly, it did not even mention the name under which La Verne Moore became famous, Mysterious Montague.

title: The Nation
description: Angela Davis walked out of the court in San Jose, Calif., a free woman last Sunday afternoon. After 13 weeks of testimony, the allwhite jury delib. erated for 13 hours over three days before finding the 28yearold black militant Communist not guilty on all charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy growing out of a Marin County courthouse shooting in which four persons, including a judge, died in August, 1970.

title: Civil Liberties Hails 4 in Legislature for Vote Record
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union has given perfect marks to one Assemblyman and three State Senators for their voting records on civilliberties issues in the recent legislative session.

title: Anthony Quinn Answers Ellen Holly; Can I Not Play a Black?
description: DEAR MISS HOLLY: IDETEST the vulgarity of the headline in Variety. If I pay heed to the people who are trying to keep me from playing Henry Christophe, its next headline will be:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I joined Fidelity Mortgage Investors about a year ago, and they had office landscaping ["New Ideas Change Office Landscapes, May 14] when I arrived. After one year of observation, I have to believe that it is virtually a complete failure. Perhaps the only thing I can say in its favor is that if a company is growing rapidly office landscaping can be used to rearrange the setup more easily and cheaply.

title: Loyal Opposition Concept Is Urged by New Bar Head
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., June 10 Chesterfield Smith, presidentelect of the American Bar Association, said today that the United States lacked the concept of a loyal opposition and must develop one to preserve the rule of law.

title: JEWISH UNIT HERE RAISES ISRAEL AID
description: The Joint Distribution Committee, for nearly six decades a principal conduit through which American Jewry has given help to Jews in Aber lands, has lately increased the proportion of its aid to Israel because of greater needs in that country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I must take strong exception to your use of the phrase take credit when writing of terrorist activities. It would be far more accurate and responsible to say that the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (or the I.R.A. or the Jewish Defense League or the Weathermen) accepted the blame for a bombing.

title: Gay Brown Richardson Is Bride Of Archibald Alexander Smith 3d
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 10Miss Gay Brown Richardson was married here this afternoon to Archibald Alexander Smith 3d in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev, Francis X. Cheney.

title: Miss Muscio Fiancee Of Donald B. Mowat
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 10Mr. and Mrs. U. V. Muscio have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Muscio, to Donald B. Mowat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Mowat of McLean, Va.

title: Peter M. Rooney Will Marry Miss Wynne Bilby on Aug. 19
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Helen Owen Bilby of Greenwich, Conn., and Kenneth W. Bilby of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Windsor Bilby, to Peter Michael Rooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Folk:
description: NRBQ: Scraps (Kama Sutra, KSBS 2045). Friends, are you tired of nostalgia? Have you had enough of digging back for the golden plays of yesterday? Do you sit there counting the tentacles on your pet octopus waiting for someone to come along singing good old rock and roll that makes sense in the 70's? Well, friends, just mosey on down to your local phonograph record salesman and ask for a copy of NRBQ's latest album. NRBQ? he'll say. Are they still around? And with a big smile on your face, tell him yes, you want NRBQ's Scraps!

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his article Scholars Pondering Right to Shelter  Israel Shenker asks if the socalled ethical ideal of a right to shelter can be converted into a constitutional guarantee for all.

title: Beginners Find Sewing a Snap
description: Their dinner dishes put away, they arrived early. carrying their work in shoe boxes, canvas totes or plastic bags. By the 7 P.M. starting time, the dozen members of Bernice Wilson's sewing class for beginners had gathered in the room behind her Now Boutique at 12219 New York Boulevard in Jamaica and were spreading out their equipment.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: On Sunday nights at the Rib and Rump, a spacious Italianstyle restaurant in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, a musical bouillabaise is cooked up that is not likely to be reproduced anywhere elseeither in Brooklyn or in the great world beyond the Gowanus.

title: 2 Sierra Club Units Merge to Add Clout
description: PENNINGTON  The Sibrra Club, the national conservation group, is estaalishing a new statewide chapter in New Jersey in order to work more effectively to save the natural environment of the most urban American state.

title: Aid for Brooklyn Alcoholics
description: A new treatment program for alcoholics, including a 25bed detoxification unit, will be established at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn under a contract with the Health Services Administration, William K. Klein, the hospital's executive director, announced yesterday.. He said the program would also include a 35bed halfwayhouse and two outpatient clinics.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Tarport Adios and Surprise Win Split New York Sire Stakes Pace
Problems of Mail Order Health Insurer
description: FRAZER, Pa.Art Linkletter, the radio and television personality, has been endqrsing products of one kind or another for nearly 40 years.

title: Green Grow Greenlawn's Organic Crops
description: GREENLAWN, L. I.The environmentalresearch scientist strode across the muddy fields toward a lone figure, a man who stood hunched against the gray sky and oblivious to the damp wind and driving rain as he pummeled the earth with a longhandled rake. He raised a sweatlined face as the scientist stared down at crowded row of seedlings in obvious dismay.

title: War Heim, 81, Triumphs in Inglewood Handicap
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 10 (AP)War Heim, an 8.1 outsider, beat favored Kennedy Road in a photo finish today in the $80,300 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park.Victor Tejada piloted the 5yearold War Heim out of a bunched field in the stretch to capture the 1mile race on fast track in 1:47 25.

title: Television
description: IS it too much to say that all of the killing contradictions of this country of ours can nowhere be better seen than late at night, in the intimate dreamy privacy of one's bedroom, on the TV talk shows? Picture itThe struggle of the day is over, the lights are low or off, and then suddenly, coming right out of the darkness, are these glittering wellknown people talking with each other and letting you share everything they say.

title: Miss James Wed To Lon Munsey
description: CHRISTMAS COVE, Me., June 10Miss Victoria Ten Eyck James, daughter of George F. James, dean of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, and Mrs. James of Cos Cob and Christmas Cove, was married here this afternoon to Lon Munsey, son of Wylie Munsey of Lisbond and the late Mrs. Villa Reed Munsey.

title: A Weekend in the Yoga Positions
description: WHEN my town added a 12week yoga course to its roster of adult education offerings, I signed up right away. I was curious. Besides, I needed the exercise and yoga sounded more exciting than women's volleyball. After attending several classes I decided that the best part of them was at the end, when Doris, our teacher, would shut off the lights and switch on her tape recorder. Now we will relax, said a deep, resonant, massaging male voice. Toes of the right foot... relax.... I never lasted longer than, Right elbow... relax...

title: Search for Space Rocket Fuel, as Told by One of the Hunters
description: NEWFOUNDLAND  Dr. Isaac Asimov, the science writer, gives an affectionately unflattering description of anyone working with rocket fuels. He thinks they are all batty.

title: Khrushchev's Vote in the U.S. Elections
description: During our conversations, 10 years ago, Nikita Khrushchev exhibited sharp insights into U.S. politics, and strong feelings about the U.S. leaders he dealt with. He showed a deep respect for President Eisenhower. He liked John F. Kennedy and he had. a strong dislike for Richard M. Nixon. From our conversations, I gathered he felt Nixon was insincere in their mantoman relationships, and he resented what he considered Nixon's exaggerated hostility toward the Soviet Union and its achievements.

title: Satellite to Film Ecological Data on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 10The Earth Resources Technolv ogy Satellite, to be launched early next month, will provide, a broad range of information on pollution sources and the entire vegetable and marine environment of the New York metropolitan area, officials of the United States Geological Survey said last week.

title: Miss Isham Fiancee Of Harold Field Jr.
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., June 10Mr. and Mrs. George S. Isham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet M. Isham, to Harold J. Field Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Field of Providence, R. I. The wedding is planned for Nov. 25 in Lake Forest.

title: Napoles Knocks Out Pruitt, Keeps Title
description: MONTEREY, Mexico, June 10  Jose Angel Napoles retained his world welterweight crown tonight with a secondround knockout over Adolph Pruitt of St. Louis.

title: Plays and Playing
description: The dramatic triumph of my juniorhigh years was that I played both Benjamin Franklin and a wicked Tory in a single afternoon of oneaot historical plays. The dramatic triumph of my highschool years was that, as the cheeky younger son in a RyersonClements patriotic. comedy, Lease on Liberty, I got one more laugh than a friend of mine who was playing the sharptongued maid. I beat her out unfairly, I confess, for my extra laugh came from the inevitable paintedon black eye.

title: A COP'S VIEW
description: To THE EDITOR: I've been following with interest the articles about The French Connection, but haven't seen any written by policemana cop's view of a cop, if you will.

title: Television
description: FOR years, the content of television was judged primarily on its most explicit level. An hour entertainment was either enjoyable or miserable. A news special was either effective or ineffective. The medium was simply a mechanism for distribution. Success was verified in the audience ratings.

title: NEW FACILITY AIDS SOVIET ATOM STUDY
description: MOSCOW, June 10The Soviet Union has inaugurated a nuclear energy research facility that is expected to enhance the versatility of its big atom smasher at Serpukhov, south of Moscow.

title: The World
description: At New York's Kennedy Airport, no flights; at London Airport, no flights; at Paris's Orly Airport, no flights.... That is what it could be like at all the world's great international airports a week from tomorrow if the world's pilots go through with their threat to stage a 24hour global shutdown to protest the lack of effective action to stop skyjacking.

title: News of Dogs
description: Brahms will strike a high note again today as the LongshoreSouthport Kennel Club celebrates its 40th anniversary. Not Johannes Brahms, but Meriking's Brahms, a canine performer on the exhibition team of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Northern New Jersey. At a demonstration on the grounds of the Wilton Junior High School on Route 9, Wilton, Conn., Bra hms will leap through a flaming hoop in a pyrotechnic finale to the team's performance. The shepherd is owned by Mrs. John S. Miraglia of River Vale, N.J.

title: Hometown of W.C.T.U. Gets Liquor Licenses
description: EVANSTON, Ill , June 10 (UPI)Last call, drink up, it's closing time.

title: Violence Among Extremists Stirs Fears in Italy
description: ROME, June 10 A rash of political street fights, attacks and bombings this week deepened fears in Italy that the nation might drift into a state of running warfare between extremists on the right and left.

title: Corporation Move Causes an Exodus
description: MARTINSVILLE  Along with the move of the JohnsManville Corporation from New York City, a major exodus is taking place in this once sleepy little village, a geographical section of Bridgewater Township.

title: BONN AND WARSAW EXPANDING TIES
description: WARSAW, June 10  West Germany and Poland are expected to exchange ambassadors next week after more than three decades of hostility and separation. They have been represented in each other's capitals by trade missions for two years.

title: Folk:
description: ELLEN MeILWAINE: Honky Tonk Angel (Polydor, PD 5021). Certain performers are best seen in person; others are shown to their best advantage on record. On the basis of having seen her several times in person, and having now listened to her debut recording, I would place Ellen Mcllwaine in the latter category. Or at least make the stipulation that she sounds best with more than her own guitar as accompaniment. The first side of the album was recorded live with a backup band, though there does seem to have been some later overdubbing (the liner notes list all guitars as being played by Ms. Mcllwaine and there is more than one guitar on several cuts). The second

title: Extra Physicians on Duty To Examine Sick Firemen
description: The Fire Department yesterday made extra doctors available to cope with the recent sharp upturn in the number of firemen reporting sick after fires.

title: Western Eyes Fail to See the Real Japan
description: THE Japanese people share one trait with Americans: They take a childish delight in hearing what visitors think about themselves and their country. If the opinions are complimentary, fine; if not, for every indignant flag waver there are likely to be two or three murmurs of Hear, hear.

title: Movies
description: THERE Is nothing intelligent to say about a massacre, Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. writes at the opening of his novel SlaughterhouseFive. One might disagree, but It is true that the novel, and the film that screenwriter Stephen Geller and director George Roy Hill have fashioned from It, fail to deal meaningfully or intelligently with the reallife massacre that overwhelms the surrounding fictionthe firebombing of Dresden, an undefended city with no strategic importance, near the end of World War II, a raid that killed 135,000 people, mainly civilians  twice the number killed at Hiroshimain of several hours.

title: Presto chango!
description: Now you see it, now you don't. The bathing suit that takes cover under matching dress or skirt or shirt is the latest thing under the sun. Your old white terry robe might keep you warmer, but you wouldn't wear it to lunch by the hotel pool or when friends drop by the beach house for drinks sunset. Some of the new coverups look enough like dresses to go dancing. (And don't forget to slip your feet into clogs; they've come a long way.)

title: The original of a prototype
description: In his essays about Algeria, the sunbeaten country he loved, Camus praises a pitiless sky. And speaking of his compatriots there, he praises them for living with heedless intensity, without any spiritual values beyond a simple and virile code: I have seen two of them die. They were full of horror, but silent.

title: Blast at Bonn's Embassy
description: DUBLIN, June 10An explosion extensively damaged the West Germany Embassy here tonight. Windows in nearby private houses were shattered. The Ambassador and his staff

title: Lawyers Group Fears an Overreliance on Educational Studies
description: A group of lawyers and educators have charged that too, much credence is being given to inconclusive or flawed", studies that minimize the influence of schools on student achievement or the value of racial integration in the schools.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MONTCLAIR  Like most of Essex County, Montclair is no longer in a period of rapid growth; its integrated population has stabilized at 44,000.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Now that striped bass, bluefish, mackerel and weakfish are ranging as far north as New England, the Eastern Seaboard anglers wives must once again deal with them in the kitchen.

title: Folk:
description: J. F. MURPHY and SALT: J. F. Murphy and Salt (Elektra, 75024). One of the more positive cultural achievements of the last decade has been that ethnicity in music has broken away from the stronghold of the folk tradition. Rock and jazz were permitted to take influences from anywhere. Thus we had Latin beats, ragalike guitarists, countryrock, etc. Jazz, due to the nature of its origins, was always ahead of its time in this respect. Rock took a little longer, but now the road lies open for groups such as J. F. Murphy and Saltprobably the first Irishrock band. They've been together for about three years, and have one earlier recording. It is this one, though, which captures the spirit of

title: Wheelchair Athletes Find New Life
description: Adjusting to life in a wheelchair was easier for Robert Hawkes Orrington, Me., than it was for most persons who found themselves paralyze from the waist down.

title: You Can't Tell a Millionaire Without a Scorecard
description: IT was Damon Runyon whose father advised him to rub against money in the hope that some might rub off on him, but anyone trying to follow that advice today could easily go to unnecessarily expensive places. The fact is that you no longer have to gamble at a highstakes table in a fashionable casino or stay in a Grand Hotel to meet a millionaire. Pick your spot carefully and you can meet one on a cheap package tour.

title: Estuary Inventory Focuses on Birds
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I.Bird watching has become official business in the Township of Hempstead. The reason for this unusual municipal activity is that the township's Department of Conservation and Waterways is conducting an inventory of the 16,000 acres of the Hempstead Estuary.

title: Nassau Residents Help Police Spot Criminals
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  After a recent holdup of a bank in Freeport, a'sresident enrolled in the 40,000 Pairs of Eyes program in the village called the police and said he saw a man flashing a lot of bills.

title: HUTTON ART AUCTION TOTALS $1MILLION
description: In a series of auctions called Hutton Week, Sotheby, ParkeBernet dispersed the art collection of Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, widow of the financier, for a total of $1,057,890.

title: Letters:
description: The potential for righteous outrage, sometimes thought to be sadly diminished in recent years, is apparently alive and well fed. Stephanie Harrington's article on flying with very young children, which appeared in the Travel section May 28, produced a large volume of correspondence, practically none of it fit for a scholarly journal: some who wrote were outraged at Mrs. Harrington, others at specific airlines, still others at airlines in general. One correspondent was even outraged at Mrs. Harrington's children.. The letters that follow are a sampling, in order, of those attacking the article and those supporting it. (A comment by Mrs. Harrington appears at the end.)

title: L.I. Planner Doubles as Stony Brook Professor
description: STONY BROOK, L. I.  Every Tuesday afternoon Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Nassau Suffolk Regional Planning Board, leaves his office in nearby Hauppauge for the State University campus here, where he is an adjunct professor of political science.

title: About Pro Football
description: In spite of a lot of talk. much of it from Kansas City's Hank Stram. there is no chance that pro football will adopt college football's exciting wishbone offense. It is not so much that the pro coaches are conservative and their game increasingly static; it is instead a matter of practicality, which Tommy Prothro of the Rams recently articulated quite well. In the first place, he said, the pros have advanced to the point where it usually takes several years for a quarterback to become a regular and by the time he does he is not the nifty, quick runner necessary to make it [the wishbone] go.

title: Art
description: MOST people's Idea of what the conservation of paintings should be, confirmed by the practical of most conservators (restorers, they used to be called), begins with the removal of dirt and old varnish kind of face washing  followed by bit of touching up where damage has occurredsomething like face liftingto bring the painting back to its original appearance.

title: The AllPurpose Cure for Bloody Disputes
description: PARISAs it happens, my neighborhood pub in this city is the bright and brandnew Bosquet Pub, two blocks down the Avenue Bosquet from the Place de l'Ecole Militaire, a comfortable block and a half from my garden gate, no strain. So I dropped around the other evening and said to M'sieur Henri, behind the bar, Where's the guvnor? I wanted to ask him JeanClaude, the guvnorwhat he was going to do about the Guinness Book of World Records. I mean, he wasn't planning to run a facsimile London pub on a Paris streetcorner without a copy of the uptodate Guinness was he? A copy or two under the bar for knocking knotty arguments on the head.

title: DEEP CUT SCORES BY TWO LENGTHS
ELLen Fishwick Plans Fall Nuptials
description: ROANOKE, Va., June 10Miis Ellen Blair Fishwick, who is with the commodity division of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., in Boston, will be married here in September to Isaiah Guyman Martin 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaiah Guyman Martin of Washington.

title: Votes Change Hudson Politics
description: JERSEY CITY  Whether you call it reform, meaning makeover, or reform, meaning simply to regroup, Hudson County politics went through a reformation last Tuesday.

title: U.S. LIFTING RECORD BROKEN BY CANTORE
description: DETROIT, June 10 (AP)Dan Cantore of San Francisco broke the American record today in winning the 148pound class at the 45th annual Amateur Athletic Union senior national weightlifting championships.

title: $25 TRISTATE TAX URGED ON TRANSIT
description: A $25aperson masstransportation tax on everyone who lives or works in the New York metropolitan area and a massive increase in Federal grants are being urged by the Governors Special Commission on Financing of Mass Transportation.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The human side of politics is a terrible and tragic thing, and it has never been more apparent than in the pictures in the newspapers over the last few days.

title: Miss Bailey Bride Of John F. Haney
description: MANTOLOKING, N. J., June 10Miss Carol Ferris Bailey was married here this afternoon to John Franklin Haney, whose father, Jack Alexander Haney of Toronto, is senior news editor of The Canadian Press. The Rev. Richard Anderson performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Simon bytheSea.

title: DEVELOPER IS TOLD TO RENT TO BLACKS
description: The State Division of Human Rights yesterday ordered Hillside Homes, a 1,415unit lowand middleincome development in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, to make special efforts to rent to blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: Music
description: WAGER: You are known for your broad variety of talentscomposer, conductor, author, distinguished pianist but you're also a teacher. Your daughter has said that you are a joyous and almost compulsive teacher. Do you think you might be doing some teaching again?

title: 43 Food Establishments Listed For Violating City Health Code
U.S. Awards $406Million To Help College Students
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The United States Office of Education has awarded more than $406million to colleges and universities to help needy students next academic year.

title: For Italy's First Lady, the Limelight Has No Appeal
description: ROMEAfter seven years Italy once again has a first lady to reside amidst the Renaissance splendor of Rome's Quirinal Palace. Six months ago Italy's sixth President, Giovanni Leone, and his wife, Vittoria, moved into the Presidential residence formerly occupied by Giuseppe Saragat, a widower.

title: New Perjury Trial Ordered
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 10 (AP) The state Supreme Court has ordered a new trial for Dean A. Andrews Jr., a lawyer who was convicted in 1967 on three counts of perjury in the Clay Shaw conspiracy trial. The court, yesterday reversed the Aug. 1:3, 1967, judgment of Judge Frank J. Shea and sent the case hack to him. The action came on a petition filed by District Attornety Jim Garrison and Andrews, attorney.

title: Mansfield Praises the President's Efforts Toward World Peace
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader, commended President Nixon today for leading the nation out of the murky detours of the cold war in the direction of world peace.

title: ARTHUR BOGARDUS, INSURANCE LEADER
description: J. Arthur Bogardus, who retired in 1953 as chairman of the board of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 8 Stonehouse Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Cornmission reported yesterday a significant rise in taxi ridership, with 810,000 people riding taxis here every day. The taxi industry has reported to us that ridership has gone up 21 per cent since the last fare hike in March, 1971, said Michael J. Lazar, the chairman.

title: Eligibility for School Breakfasts Is Argued
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 10What's for breakfast, Mrs. Hatfield, wnat's for breakfast? the children shout outside Kathleen Hatfield's window each school morning.

title: The World
description: PRETORIA  The confrontation had been a long time coming.

title: Anti Americanism
description: europeanization gone to America and returned to, Europe as Americanization is now complete. The English are more in need of warning against. America than Americans of warning against England, but beyond this there are evils common to both. cultures add the tion for today is whether the last problem to be solved by Americans will not be that of Americanization.

title: City Is Beginning Programs to Help Defendants as Alternative to Money Baill
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 10 In an effort to forestall spending on additional jails, the Lindsay, administration is beginning work on a new system to provide alternatives to money bail.

title: Chess: Being No. 2 Good Enough For Players in Zonal Test
Kathryn Steele a Bride
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., June 10  Miss Kathryn Steele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Steele of Palm Beach, Fla., was married at the White Elephant Inn here today to John Edward Kehoe, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Kehoe of Davenport, Iowa. The Rev. Robert Dean Sweet of the First Baptist Church here performed the nonsectarian ceremony.

title: The role of the media defended and defined
description: One of the problems with criticism of the news media is that none of us, including this writer, knows exactly what he's talking about. There is a wild conglomeration of organisms (1,750 daily papers, over 8,000 weeklies, 22,000 periodicals, 850 television and 6,400 radio stations), and they range in quality from noble to idiotic. No one has ever monitored them all and there have been few careful samplings. Most press criticism consists of an angry man reading one news item that crosses his desk and firing off a jeremiad about The American Press.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: New Novel
description: 417 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Doctors Expect Wallace To Attend the Convention.
The World
description: WASHINGTONThe disclosures of the past year of the dealings between the Nixon Administration and the Pakistani Government in the course of the IndiaPakistan crisis of 1971 have produced a diplomatic Dance of the Seven Veils. One veil of obfuscation after another has been stripped away by journalistic enterprise or Government leaks, leaving high Administration officials discomfited. Last week another veil came off.

title: State Shifting Some of Retarded From Its Schools to Hospitals
description: To relieve the overcrowding at state institutions for the mentally, retarded, some of their adult residents are being transferred to underpopulated state mental hospitals.

title: CLEVELAND SPLIT ON SUMMER JOBS
description: CLEVELAND, June 10Summer jobs for more than 10,000 persons between the ages of 14 and 21 hinge on the outcome of a fight between the city of Cleveland and the Cleveland Board of Education for control of $4.4million in Federal funds.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW To a man once vilified by Moscow as a counterrevolutionary and an agent of American imperialism and of whom Stalin once angrily declared, I shall shake my little finger and there will be no more Tito, the tributes of the current masters of the Kremlin must have seemed sweet indeed, especially since he was able to keep firmly to his own political line.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The man in charge of freeofcharge
description: It is both a bewitching and a saddening experience to be a revolutionary in America. You are lionized by the media; intellectuals lend you their ears with the same abandon drunken sailors dispense cash; and you're courted by the beautiful people. Bewitching. The sad thing is that the bulk of the populace seems to pay you no heed.

title: Bridge
description: VIOLENT partnership disagree ments are not uncommon at the bridge table, especially among New York experts, who are more volatile than most. A legendary story concerns Tobias Stone, who had apparently provoked his wife and partner to the point at which she was ready to let fly at him with a heavy ashtray. At which moment a third party emitted an anguished scream: Don't duck, Stoney, I'm right behind you.

title: Folk:
description: McKENDREE SPRING: McKendree Spring III (Decca, DL 75332). This is yet another group which has been largely ignored and/or overlooked by the larger segment of the rock audience. Despite a very imaginative and original sound, built primarily around an electric violin played by Michael Dreyfuss, a sound capable of hardrocking with the best as well as of presenting a simple and melodic ballad, McKendree seems to have gotten lost somewhere in the music industry shuffle.

title: Stamps
description: COMMEMORATING the centenary of selling merchandise by mail, ascribed to Aaron Montgomery Ward of Chatham, N. J., who established his mail order business in Chicago in 1872, the Postal Service has unveiled its design for an 8c stamp that will be issued in Chicago on Sept. 27 (shown below).

title: A Time to Choose
description: The Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern which has had such remarkable success in the Democratic primaries is based on the conviction that amajority of the :American people want an opportunity to vote for fundamental change.

title: MRS. ARTHUR WATTS
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 10 Mrs. Helen Allen Watts, who was Queens director of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers Association in the late 1930's and 1940's, died Thursday at the age of 74. She lived at 284 Stewart Avenue, here.

title: Lora Moore Is Bride of Attilio Vezzosi
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 10Miss Lora Tucker Moore, whose grandfather, the late Hoyt A. Moore, was a senior partner in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, was married here this noon to Attilio Vezzosi, son of Ettore Vezzosi of Florence, Italy, and the late Mrs. Vezzosi. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward Parsons Moore.

title: TRIUMPH BY 8 TO 4
description: KANSAS CITY, June 10Maybe it was the overnight 23degree drop in temperature, to a comfortable 71 above, or perhaps it was the sudden appearance of General Manager Lee MacPhail, but the Yankees looked like a different team tonight as they defeated the Royals, 84.

title: Adult Education Helps Retarded to Help Themselves
description: NEW MILFORDA pilot program in adult education for retarded adults, the first in the state, has been dubbed a success and will be repeated in the fall.

title: Moonlighting by Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON  Four of the 15 members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation have law practices in addition to their jobs as Representatives, and another has banking and oil interests. according to a study of House financial disclosure reports by the National Committee for an Effective Congress.

title: The Senior Prom: Some Still Find It's a Night to Remember
description: It all began to, happen around 6 P.M. Friday: He fastened a tiny corsage of red roses around her right wrist. She pinned a white carnation on the lapel of his rented dinner jacket. They toasted each other with Cold Duck. They kissed.

title: Miss Nularid Bride on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 10Miss Patricia Stewart Nuland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Greenberry Nuland of Locust Valley and Quogue, and Richard Merrick Chandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Alton Chandler of North Andover, Mass., were married here today at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Bomb Scare and Clashes Mark Le Mans Car Race
description: LE MANS, France, June 10 The sun shines on one part of the course while it rains on another. Early this morning there was a minor riot in the main square, and less than an hour after the start there was a bomb scare.

title: Sandler and Obert Gain Final in OneWall Handball
description: Steve Sandler of the host club, the defending champion, advanced with Ruby Obert of the New York Athletic Club to the final of the Amateur Athletic Union national onewall handball singles championship yesterday with semifinalround triumphs at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

title: Pebble Beach: Tough Course Tougher
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. June 10 (UPI)  Discounting luck, unusual circumstances and the weather the man who wins the United States Open at Pebble Beach this week almost surely will be one who has beaten the seaside course in the past.

title: HART SWEEPS 100, 220 ON THE COAST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 10 (AP)The former University of California sprinter, Eddie Hart, rounding into shape just in time for the Olympic track trials later this month, swept the dash events today in the Kennedy Games.

title: Black Politicians Found to Disregard Plea for Unity
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Unity without uniform it y might sound good as a slogan, but so far it has not proved good politics among blacks running for Congressional seats.

title: RODRIGUEZ AHEAD BY SHOT WITH 209
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 10 Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, who now disdains the comic antics once associated with his game, assumed the 54hole lead by one stroke today in the $150,000 Philadelphia Classic.

title: Social Announcements
description: Belskin Jeanne Elias Joyfully announces the Golden Wadding Anniversary of her dear parents and Eric's grandparents, Estelle and Bernard Belskin on June 10th.

title: The New Movies
description: A DAY IN THE DEATH OF JOE EGG, directed by Peter Medak from Peter Nichols's play, and starring Allan Bates and Janet Suzman, got seven favorable reviews (Arm Guarino, News; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; Judith Crist, New York; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; William Wolf, Cue, Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service), seven mixed (Vincent Canby, Times; Frances Herridge, Post; Gail Rock, Women's Wear; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; John Simon, New Leader; Richard Schickel, Life; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers) and two negative (Jay Cocks, Time; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek). Vincent Canby: 'A Day in the Death of Joe Egg is a difficult movie to describe properly. It is beautifully acted, funny, moving, but infinitely depressing. The story concerns Bri and Sheila, the parents of a 10yearold spastic daughter, Joe, whose brain is so damaged that she is completely helpless, a lump of life whose eyes float in their sockets like the twin bubbles in a carpenter's level. A Day in the Death of Joe Egg is worrisome indeed, difficult to recommend, since it isn't grand enough to go much beyond its special experience, but easy to admire in isolated instances. At the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: Environment
description: STOCKHOLMIn the corridors of the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment, among the tents of the youth encampment on an unused airfield near this city and through the concurrent meetings here of various political colorations, the same debate swirled last week: How should man control his growth to save his planet?

title: Stewart of Britain Wins Mile In 3:55.3, Fastest This Year
description: LONDON, June 10 (UPI)Peter Stewart, 25yearold Birmingham engineer, ran the fastest mile in the world this year at Crystal Palace and then disclosed that a spine injury almost ruled him out of athletics.

title: Giant Zipper Eases Work on L.I.R.R.
description: GREENLAWN, L. I.  Once you're a railroad man, you're always a railroad man, said Wansa Williams of Brooklyn.

title: General Bombed in North Before President's Order
description: WASHINGTON, June 10Gen. John D. Lavelle was relieved as commander of United States Air Force units in Southeast Asia in March and demoted after ordering repeated and unauthorized bombing attacks of military targets in North Vietnam.

title: 47 Seized in Coast Raid
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (UPI)A gambling casino where patrons were offered drugs and liquor was raided by the police today after it had been infiltrated by undercover agents. The casino was in a twostory house near the HaightAshbury District. The police arrested 47 persons.

title: The Confession of A Child of the Century
description: Thomas Rogers is in his midforties; The Confession of a Child of the Century is his second novel. At a time when good young writers are popping forth all over the place, bringing new life and excitement to American fiction, one who comes as late to the novelist's craft as Rogers is something of an anomaly  all the more so since in both of his novels his subject has been the generation gap. But his fiction is a powerful argument for the virtues of maturity and experience, for it possesses a depth, compassion and complexity that only the rarest of youngwriters commands.

title: Music
description: ON two occasions when the New York Pro Musics was in residence at Stanford University, a particularly interested faculty member was George Houle. He was director of earlymusic studies at the California school. Like Pro Musica's members, he played such old instruments as the shawm, krummhorn, recorder, baroque oboe and cornett. He was in charge of several Stanford ensembles performing medieval, renaissance and baroque music. Houle's And Pro Musica's paths are now joined, rather than intersecting. He has, at the age 44, become the new music director of the ensemble.

title: Photography,
description: JUDGING by two current gallery exhibitions, few contemporary photographers have learned how to cope with nudity and sex.
