The onceforbidden subjects still seem to make them nervous, and leads them to take pictures that are too arty to have much connection with the feelings that nudity and sex arouse in the rest of us.

title: U.S. Agrees to Aid 2d Avenue Subway
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Federal Government has agreed to help finance New York City's Second Avenue subway, according to officials here.

title: New Hockey Teams
description: Attempting to assess the kinds of amateurs the New York Islanders drafted during the recent National Hockey League meetings is about as fruitful as predicting which yearlings will run in the Kentucky Derby.

title: HOPE FOR GIRLS
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Navy's R.O.T.C. Program Is Completed at Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N. H., June 10 (AP)The formal academic program of the Navy R.O.T.C. program at Dartmouth College ended today with the commissioning of 16 graduating seniors as Navy ensigns.

title: $1.8Million Is Bet On Belmont at OTB
description: A tiny strip of magnetic tape loaded with $1.8million worth of offtrack bets on the Belnlont Stakes touched off the largest single display of parimutluel fireworks in racing history yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: CLERMONT FERRAND, France  Albert Pissis has worked for the Michelin Tire Company since he was 19. At 44 he earns $260 a month; rents a comfortable fourroom house, which Michelin built, for $55 a month; has four children, one of whom, Norbert, now works for Michelin; never joined a trade union because Michelin frowns on such activities, and sums up his life as follows: Telly, bistro, dodo [the French vernacular for sleep] and Michelin.

title: MAYORS IN STATE WEIGH PROBLEMS
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y. June 10John P. Manzi is stocky figure with a pepperandsalt mustache who draws a $1,500ayear stipend as Mayor of Millbrook, N. Y., sells mutual funds and insurance for a living, likes to reminisce about his days in the 100th Division during World War II, and cheerfully characterizes the village of 17,000 he has headed for the last three years as a very, very pleasant wide spot in the road.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10Ten Arab oilproducing countries accepted today the principle of giving financial support to Iraq and other countries adversely affected by Iraq's nationization of the Iraq's Petroleum Company and agreed on a meeting of their finance ministers to set the amount of assistance.

title: Trevino in Hospital With Pneumonia
description: EL PASO, June 10Lee Trevino, the 1971 United States Open champion, was in a hospital with pneumonia today and may lose a chance to defend his golf title at Pebble Beach, Calif., next week.

title: Stickeys and Provos
description: The Official Irish Republican Army is committed to a political victory through a socialist workers revolution. Stickeys (as they are disparagingly tagged by the Provisional wing because of the sticky backs of their Easter seals) maintain close ties with the minorleague Irish Communist party. But their socialism is a combination of idealism and textbook Marxism, and a far cry from Russian Communism.

title: Law
description: In enforcing the law, the police and the prosecution authorities often engage in some selectivity. A motorcycle officer may stop only one out of three speeding cars. The police may not issue summonses on every store violating the Sunday closing laws. If a new criminal law is passed, a prosecutor may ignore many cases until he finds the. best one to test the law in the courts.

title: Gallup Poll Gives the President Widest Lead Over 2 Democrats
Texas Gets Kankakee Star
description: KANKAKEE, Ill., June 10 (AP)Jeff Scott, a pitcher for Kankakee Eastridge, a unanimous alltournament choice in the recent Illinois state high (school baseball championships, said today he had signed a con;tract with the Texas Rangers. The 6foot2inch Scott is righthander,

title: New Role Looms for Old Police Building
description: The building that served as the headquarters for what was believed to be the city's oldest police precinct is no longer under police jurisdiction, nor is it a historical site. Situated at 263 Bedford Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, it is now an abandoned, vandalized, uninhabitable structure and, until recently, was a haven for drug addicts and derelicts.

title: New York Races
description: Both Representative Herman Badillo and his challenger in the Democratic primary on June 20, Assemblyman Manuel Ramos, spent yesterday on walking tours of the Bronx district they both want to represent. But they had different messages and, evidently, different routes, since their paths never converged during the day.

title: Miss Jean Middendorf Wed To Gregory C. Banus on
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 10Miss Jean Reynolds Middendorf and Gregory C. Banus were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. He Was assisted by the Rev. Phillip R. Newell of Washington, an uncle of the bride.

title: A sanctified world speckled with dying and laughter
description: This credofrom a 1969 volume of Buechner's Christian meditations accounts for Leo Bebb, the lustily flawed hero of Open Heart, selfcontained sequel to Lion Country. Both are Godhungry comic novels speckled with dying and laughter. In the earlier book, Bebb runs a diploma millfor an offering by mail you can become a Reverend overnight, instantly endowed with theological authority. Bebb has a ginswigging wife who drowned her baby long ago, a welldomesticated exhomosexual assistant who believes Bebb raised him from the dead, a tough adopted daughter who sleeps with strangers. And his great feat is standing surrounded by lions in an open fieldin Florida! the state where everyone goes to get rebornun

title: The ra Made Us Listen, and Our Hopes Rose
description: IONCE had an acquaintance, a young actor, who began to get film jobs, and, as I watched him from thousands of miles away, I was puzzled. knew him, you see, and knew that he had a light, perverse wit, a quicklyarched eyebrow, a dark and offcenter handsomeness that wound up seeming more skeptical than heroic. A but of an original. And here was, in films, striving all too successfully to become nobody. That is to say, he was working hard to the mold, the role, the rut; he was trying to become the stock figure all screen juveniles were. I suppose, now, he was playing it the company way.

title: Syosset's Hochuli Vaults 15 To Set State Schoolboy Record
TO THE POINT
description: To THE EDITOR: May I compliment you on reprinting from the Harvard Crimson the astute movie criticism of Garrett Epps? This is the kind of pointed social criticism that has been missing. It is a change from the verbose hollow talk of drawingroom critics who don't realize that the problem is that the film is over their eyes.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It needs an interior decorator and landscape gardener, but it has its comforts. And for Tug McGraw, the New York Mets bull pen at Shea Stadium is a second home. He sleeps there occasionally. Dines there, too.

title: Philadelphia Area To Get Competition In Postal Services
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP)An alternative to the United States Postal Service will become available here in September, officials have announced.

title: New Novel
description: 168 pp. New York: Saturday Review Press. $5.95.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Pay Board insisted it was simply trimming some fat from an excessively high wage settlement. For many wage earners throughout the country, however, the board's latest ruling was ominous. It had acted for the first time on deferred wage increase  one that had been agreed upon before the Administration's wageprice program went into effect last summer.

title: Police Crews Dig for Body Under Basement in Village
description: Two police emergency crews with jackhammers and shovels were diggingyesterday beneath a concrete basement floor in Greenwich Village in search of a body believed to have been left there in a mob rubout more than a year ago.

title: PARIS SHAKING UP ITS RADIO AND TV
description: PARIS, June 10  The staterun television and radio organization, one of France's favorite whipping boys, is undergoing another reorganization following the revelation of widespread corruption.

title: FLOOD KILLS 155 IN NM DAKOTA; 5,000 HOMELESS
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 10More than 155 persons were reported dead today and 5,000 were homeless in a flash flood that swept through this city and several smaller towns on the eastern edge of the Black Hills last night.

title: Press
description: It was a year ago, on a Sunday, that The New York Times began printing a series it called, with an agonizingly demure attempt to avoid sensationalism, Vietnam Archive. Nobody paid any attention.

title: The McGuigans:
description: THIS is a tale of bravery and savagery in one Irish Republican family, the McGuigans of Belfast. They are a family of ninesix sons, one daughter, a tough battling mother and a bricklayer father who has spent more years than he cares to remember in Ulster prison camps. For being Roman Catholics and lifelong Republicans, the McGuigans have borne the brunt of Unionist repression for the past 30 years. The McGuigans have seen the inside of every civil jail and internment camp from Long Kesh to Armagh Women's Prison. They have been accused of every crime from the illegal sale of Easter lilies to attempted murder of a British soldier. Even now the family is split between allegiance to the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army and the Official I.R.A., which has strong links with the tiny Communist party of Ireland. The mother, Mary McGuigan, is a redhot Provo, while the father, John, is a conservative member of the Officials. At the moment the six Provos

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt was the Saturday night before the California primary. On a dark Los Angeles County freeway, a car bearing a McGovern bumper sticker whizzed past.

title: Voters Hold the Key In Battle of Corona
description: Just across the Long Island Expressway from Forest Hillsthe proposed home of 840 units of controversial lowincome public housinglies the community of Corona, a section of Queens whose homeowners were making headlines long before the Forest Hills Residents Association came into being.

title: David Brinkley Marries Mrs. Susan Benfer Adolph
description: JAMES CITY COUNTY, Va., June 10Mrs. Susan Banter Adolph of Washington and David Brinkley, the National Broadcasting Company news correspondent, were married here tonight at Carter's Grove Plantation.

title: Vikings Sign Stanford Ace
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 10 (AP)The Minnesota Vikings announced the signing today of an allAmerica linebacker, Jeff Siemon of Stanford. their No. 1 National Football League draft choice. Siemon is a 6foot2 inch, 235pounder.

title: Folk:
description: FAT CITY: Welcome to Fat City (Paramount, PAS 6028). Fat City, which is comprised of Bill Danoff and Taffy Nivert, first came to prominence as the authors of a number of tunes recorded by John Denver, the most successful of which was Take Me Home (Country Roads). This album, which is their first under their own name (they have done backup vocals for Denver), proves them well able to hold their own.

title: AsianPacific Conference To Appraise Council's Role
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 10Delegates from 12 Asian and Oceanian nations will gather here next week to seek a new plan for regional cooperation in keeping with the current mood of relaxation of tension in the area.

title: Paterson Schools Use U.S. Aid to Broaden Horizons
description: PATERSON  Man, you can't chop it into little pieces, the whole thing works well, snapped the sixthgrade teacher, Charley Fuchs.

title: Presley, Talents Richly Intact, Shifts Emphasis to Rock/Gospel
description: Elvis Presley finally made it to New York Friday night, in the opener of four soldout concerts at Madison Square Garden that represented his first live appearance in Gotham.

title: UConn Coach Honored
description: BOSTON, June 10 (AP) Larry Panciera, the University of Connecticut baseball coach, who piloted his club to the Yankee Conference title and the District 1 championship today, was named District coach of the year.

title: Miss Walker Has Nuptials
description: SALISBURY, Conn., June 10  Miss Carolyn Place Walker and Ebard F. Evans were married here this afternoon, The Rev. Edwin M. Ward, headmaster, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Salisbury School Chapel.

title: NASCAR Sticks to Limiting CarburetorBase Openings
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 10The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing (NASCAR) announced this week it would continue its system of limiting carburetorbase openings in Grand National races for latemodel sedans. The decision was made on the basis of an evaluation of the program, which started last September.

title: WALL STREET
description: Ten representatives of the public have been nominated to sit on the new board of directors at the New York Stock Exchange in a shift of power away from the men who traditionally have called the shots in Wall Street.

title: Nixon Asks Senate to Ban Arms Aid Cut
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon told Senate leaders today that the cuts proposed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the military aid program would have a destablizing effect on the nation's allies and on world peace efforts.

title: Mary Candler, Vassar Alumna, Bride of Edward A. Powell Jr.
description: GROSSE POINTE, Mich, June 10The Grosse Pointe Memorial Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Edith Candler, a Vassar College alumna, class of 71, to Edward Angus Powell Jr., who is with the Defense Intelligence Agency of the Navy in Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ray H. Kiely.

title: Miss Anne Hobler Bride in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 10Miss Anne Davis Hobler, a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Van Arden Dukehart Jr.

title: Gibson to Issue a Newspaper
description: NEWARK  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's administration has announced it will begin publication of a twicemonthly newspaper some time in August.

title: A New Twist on Early PhysicalEd
description: TEANECK  Twentytwo 5yearolds grip the edges of an orange and green parachute.

title: Wildflowers of L.I.: A Fragile Beauty
Sussex, Now for Commuters
description: Would you believe that remote, sylvan, lakedotted Sussex County at the top of New Jersey is a bedroom community for commuters to the New York City area?

title: Hamptons to Unreel Film Fete
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. How many months does it take to arrange a fiveday film festival? At least three, but more likely four, according to Mrs. Herbert Golden, who has just completed her labors on Film Makers of the Hamptons, an unusual cinematic fiesta opening July 1 at the John Drew Theater here.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors are being cautioned to be on the alert for a planned multistamp issue from Haiti that proposes to commemorate the 262 Popes who have served the Roman Catholic Church. It is, in essence, a getrichquick promotional venture, allegedly aimed at building a road in Haiti via the purses of stamp collectorsand nonphilatelists who would be subjected to a manyfaceted sales promotion campaign.

title: Three in 727 Crew Injured In OxygenFlask Explosion
description: Two stewardesses were seriously injured and a captain was hurt yesterday when an oxygen flask exploded on board an American Airlines jet at LaGuardia Airport as the crew was preparing to treat two elderly passengers for nausea, the airline reported.

title: George Beebe, Nicole Wilson Plan Nuptials
description: Miss Nicole Wilson and George Taylor Beebe, professor of political history at Simon's Rock College in Great Barrington, Mass., plan to be married here July 8.

title: Coins
description: TWO cast silver medals will be features of the exhibit being planned by the Collectors of Art Medals, Inc., for their meeting the evening of June 22d at the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. The society members will convene in the Biarritz Suite on the fourth floor of the hotel. Doors will be open at 7:30 and the meeting will begin at 8.

title: Fords Triumph ht Soling Race
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 10  Hamilton G. and Jonathan Ford's Star Fire won the 6.8mile Soling race by 2 minutes and 44 seconds and nearly 250 yards off Belle Haven Club today in the seventh championship regatta of the season for Yacht Racing Association fleets based eastofRye on Long Island Sound.

title: Ann J. Croke Married
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 10  Miss Ann Jule Croke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Croke, was married here this afternoon in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church to Donald Leigh Doorly 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doorly of Westport, Conn. The Rev. John K. Daly performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The bride's father is a retired captain in the New York City Police Department. Mr. Doorly's father is with the advertising department of The New Yorker magazine.

title: Kathy Daley Wed To T. G. Bohnen Jr.
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 10  St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Kathy Lew Daley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Grant Daley of Bronxville, to Theodore G. Bohnen Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Bohnen of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Bohnen. Msgr. William J. Kenealy performed the ceremony.

title: BILL ON LAND USE GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A bill to set policy on landuse throughout the country has been favorably reported out of the Senate Interior Committee. The bill, approved 14 to 2 by the committee on Monday and soon to be reviewed by other Senate committees, would authorize more then $800million by 1980 to provide for the creation and implementation of plans for land use in every state

title: The World
description: Foreigners have no rights on our territories or to our natural resources, which are an exclusive ownership of our peoples, Sheik Abdulla Tariki, the firebrand former Saudi Arabian Oil Minister, told cheering delegates at the Eighth Arab Petroleum Congress in Algeria.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WILLIAM J. CASEY, S.E.C. chairman, warned corporations against omitting information on breakdowns sales and earnings for all product groups that account for 10 per cent or more of their business... Longawaited legislative proposal from the S.E.C. sought Congressional enactment of a bill that would give the commission greater authority over the N.A.S.D.... Former Secretary TreaSury Connally started his roundtheworld tour champion the President's policies. lie will discuss economic development as well as industry, trade and monetary matters.

title: Grave Theft Sentences
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10 (UPI)Judge Bruce Jenkins has reduced the jail terms of five Ohio State University fraternity brothers sentenced to 90 days for stealing grave decorations at a cemetery. I think the shock of that first week behind bars was enough for them, Judge Jenkins said yesterday. It made believers out of them if anything can. The sentences were reduced to the time already served and $200 fines.

title: Mrs. Wagnon Wed to A. W. Perry
description: Mrs. Mary Stuyvesant Pierrepont Wagnon of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont of Locust Valley, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Anthony Winter Perry. He is the son of Mrs. Kathleen D. Perry of of Maidstone, Kent, England.

title: Gardens
description: SEDUM, also called stonecrop,is an excellent plant for places in the garden or rock garden where soil is light and dry and the location is sunny. It will grow in spots where only a little soil is available.

title: A Deserted Village, Allaire, Nears Age 150
description: ALLAIREHere along the bucolic boundaries of historic Monmouth County, preparations are under way to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the deserted village of Allaire, once a thriving 15th Century industrial complex sponsored by one of labor's pioneer patron saints.

title: Gardens
description: Lacebugs and aphids are appearing now on andro. meda and roses; control them with malathion... Do not cut down foliage of daffodils, tulips or hyacinths because the leaves are required to nourish bulbs while 1973 flower buds are forming.... Keep up with lawn mowing; 2,4D will get rid of any broadleaved weeds.... Keep up with vegetable planting; sow lettuce and radishes again.

title: Mail:
description: TO THE EDITOR: I agree with your May 31 story that the running of the Indianapolis 500 was not all it should have been, starting with the swerve of the pace car across the traffic. I also agree that there was sloppy organization. I know a fair amount about this because I was at Indianapolis first in 1933, and was there a good deal after the war.

title: In Princeton, It's Tennis Everyone
description: PRINCETON  For a successful community tennis program, you need to find a way to teach an individual sport to a whole lot of people at once, Eve Kraft said. And fortunately, we have been able to work out how to do it.

title: PRISONERS FORM N.A.A.C.P: BRANCH
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., June 10The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has been forming branches since 1910, a year after it was founded, but until now it had not chartered one in a prison.

title: Deepwater Port Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)  Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, said today that a proposed deepwater port off the Atlantic Coast might be internationally illegal as well as ecologically offensive. He cited Army Corps of Engineers studies being made of sites along the East Coast.

title: DANCES AT STAGE 73 FOCUS ON LARGE MAN
description: Alonso Castro's Dance Theater embraces a mixed group of dancers, including those with a technically professional polish and others of less sure technique. Presenting the company to best advantage poses choreographic problems, which were only partly solved at its concert Friday evening at Stage 73.

title: W. F. Heyne Marries Miss Mary Robinson
description: CHATHAM, N. J., June 10 In the Stanley CongregationalUnited Church of Christ here this afternoon, Miss Mary Rainer Robinson, who is completing her senior year at Vassar College, was married to William Frederick Heyne by the Rev. Walter Heyne, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: ... and miles to go before l sleep Robert Frost's Last Adventure
description: IT is now 10 years since the curtains began to open on a nuclear showdown and the two great powers of the East and West confronted each other in the Cuban missile crisis. It was in late spring or early summer of 1962 that the Soviet Union began preparing to install about 60 offensive intermediaterange ballistic missiles in Cuba, well within range of the United States. The peoples of the world then watched, waited and were brought to the very edge of great danger before the crisis was ultimately met and the feared Armageddon averted.

title: Miss Ahern Cards a 76 for 224 to Lead in $50,000 Sutton Golf by a Stroke
Anne M. Ryan Wed To James Beha 2d
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., June 10 In the Manhattanville College Chapel here this afternoon Miss Anne Marie Ryan, a senior at the college, was married to James Alexius Beha 2d, a student at the Harvard Law School. The Rev. Vincent Butler performed the ceremony.

title: BURNS URGES BOND FOR A TAX REFUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 10AT thur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. has suggested to Congress that taxpayers now experiencing significant overwithholding of their Federal income tax, voluntarily or otherwise, be offered next spring a special Treasury bond with a high interest rate that they could choose instead of a tax refund.

title: Art
description: THE career of the German sculptor Wilhelm Lehmbruck was a brief and troubled one. Lehmbruck was 38 when he committed suicide in Berlin in 1919. The personal motivations for his act are somewhat clouded, but one of the causes seems to have been Lehmbruck's feeling that he had survived the slaughters of World War I to no great purpose. Among the poems he wrote in his last yearshe was a sometime poet as well as a sculptorthere is a particularly eloquent one titled Who Is Still, Here? It opens with the lines, Who stayed behind after these murders/Who survived this bloody sea? and ends on a note almost of anticipation, You who prepared so much death/ death for me?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Television
description: IT ended, not with a whimper but with a bang. Just like thatit was gone. I was in the bedroom knotting my tie when my wife called out the chilling news. There's no Sesame Street, she cried. Naturally, since there's no Sesame Street was tantamount to being told that our rent had been decontrolled, I humored her. You've probably used the wrong tuner, I called back soothingly. We've recently been wired for cable, and the extra tuning box is still confusing.

title: New Novel
description: 263 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95.

title: Attack Near Eilat Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June Al (AP)  Palestinian guerrillas blew up an Israeli army truck today in Eilat on the Gulf of Aqaba, killing the driver and wounding another soldier, a guerrilla communiqu said.

title: Miss Kurth's Nuptials
description: RYE, N.Y., June 10Miss Patricia Ann Kurth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Kurth, was married here this morning to John Michael Pentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale M. Pentz of Broomall, Pa. Msgr. Thomas V. McMahon performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Mrs. Robinson Wed
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 10Mrs. Vanessa Waring Gillespie Robinson of Riverside, was married here this morning to Herbert Meson Jr. of Old Greenwich, in a garden ceremony at the Old Greenwich home of the bride's sister and brotherinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Bonner 3d. The Rev. William Murphy of the Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Franklin Robinson of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. Mrs. Meson, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Waring Gillespie of East Hampton,

title: Repoz Traded to Rochester
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10 Roger Repoz was traded by the California Angels to Rochester of the International League today for Jerry Davenon. The Angels said Davanon, an infielder who batted 213 at Rochester with one home run and 13 runs batted in, would report to the Angel's Pacific Coast League farm club at Salt Lake City.

title: Susan Lord Bride of Kirk Bauer
description: ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 10Miss Susan Bodine Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Galey Lord 2d of Irvington, and Kirk Marston Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell E. Bauer of Livermore, Calif., were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea.

title: Footloose and Footsore, an Author Retraces His Hero's Footsteps
description: THE normal order of things, especially for a first novel, is for the art of the novelist to follow, apprehensively close, his life. And if he needs a rationalization for taking that safe path, he has his choice: from the mundane editing cliche to write about what you know to the admonition of the thoughtful Henry James, who insisted that while a writer could expand a fleeting experience into a fictional world, he could not create credible work entirely from the imagination.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONS  We have reached the point at which it is no service to the idea of the United Nations and no contribution to its future to blink at its limitations... We believe that the time has come for a large dose of realism and candor in United States policy toward the United Nations.

title: Perry Opened Japan, But Not the Japanese
description: VISITING a country for the first time always involves a confrontation between preconceptions and reality. Usually what the traveler sees and feels add up to variations from what ho expected. Once in a while he Is caught entirely off guard, the victim of oversell: Nothing seems to remotely resemble the picture Implanted in the mind and he feels cheated.

title: Rights Panel Urges U.S. Juries Study 4 Deaths in New Mexico
description: SANTA FE, N. M., June 10The New Mexico Committee of the United States Civil Rights Commission recommended today that special Federal grand juries be empaneled to investigate four killings by New Mexico policemen, including the shooting death last year of a handcuffed youth by the Santa Fe police.

title: THIEU LOSES BID FOR NEW POWERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10South Vietnam's lower house today refused to override the Senate and grant President Nguyen Van Thieu authority to rule by decree for six months.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after the Supreme Court ruled in 1967 that suspects were entitled to counsel when they were placed in a police lineup, a Washington lawyer, waiting for his client's lineup to occur, agreed to stand in another lineup to supplement the number of suspects. He was promptly identified as a rapist by an outraged woman who refused to back down until the lawyer was able to prove he was trying a case at the time of the rape.

title: A comical historical pastoral about growing up
description: ... He should be serious and silly, noble and vulgar, tender and cold. In short he should be a perfect mine of contradictions.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Do YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Ryun Victor In 3:57.3
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10Just in time Jim Ryun has regained his kick and, more important, his confidence.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Northport Seniors Bow to Tradition
description: NORTHPORT, L. LGraduating seniors at Northport High School will wear rented caps and gowns at graduation by order of the Board of Education. The order vetoed a student move to dente the rental money to charity.

title: Folk:
description: JAKE AND THE FAMILY JEWELS: The Big Moose Calls His Baby Sweet Lorraine (Polydor, PD 5025). One thing Allan Jacobs, better known simply as Jake, will never be accused of is pretentiousness. Ever since his days as one half of the combination of Bunky and Jake (a group which, to my mind, was about 10 years ahead of its time), he has been singing, playing (guitar) and writing very simple, joyous music.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Few today will recall that it is just seventy years since the ending of the Boer War. What was then the mightiest empire in the world, after two and a half years of effort which had stretched its resources to the utmost, had finally vanquished two small Dutch republics.

title: Colorado River Salt Annoys Mexicans
description: MEXICO CITY, June 10 When Mexicans discuss relations between their country and the United States, they tend to mention first the level of mineral salts in the Colorado River and its effect on agriculture in Mexico's Mexicali Valley.

title: 21YearOld Sets Her Sights on Convention
description: One of Victoria Free's concerns at the moment is that if she is elected as a delegate and goes to the Democratic National Convention with her credentials clasped in her hand, how is she going to convince the sergeantsatarms that she is not an impostor?

title: The Saxophone: New Jazz King?
description: THE first instrument to send the clarion call of jazz out to the world was the trumpet its powerful, brassy persuasiveness a dominant voice from the time of the legendary Buddy Bolden in the 1890's to the twenties solo flights of Louis Armstrong. More recently, the saxophones, of all shapes and sizes, have moved to the cutting edge of the jazz adventure. Lacking a history, lacking a legitimate reference point, lacking, in short, any genuine identification with European music, they are perhaps the perfect instruments for the genuinely personal talents of jazz players, since they can be so readily shaped to the goals

title: 31 Reported Missing In Vietnam Air Crash
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP) A chartered Chinese Nationalist transport plane carrying United States and South Vietnamese soldiers normally engaged in clandestine operations crashed into a mountain in the Central Highlands a week ago.

title: Debra Neuschel Wed To Robert W. Jones
description: ROSLYN, L. I., June 10 Miss Debra Jean Neuschel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Neuschel of Brookville and Palm Beach, was married here this afternoon to Robert Wood Jones of West Chester, Pa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: An old man should be permitted his dreams. (I voted for Cox and Roosevelt in 1920).

title: Community Plans Bring New Hope for Retarded
description: OMAHA, June 10Two years ago, Mike S. was just another severely retarded 6yearold staring vacantly at the drab. walls in one of the jampacked wards at the state home in Beatrice, a farm town about 100 miles southwest of here.

title: Head of Columbia's LamontDoherty Observatory Is Joining University of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 10Dr. Maurice Ewing, one of the world's leading geophysicists, will leave his post as director of Columbia University's LamontDoherty Geological Observatory to join the University of Texas Marine Biomedical Institute in Galveston.

title: M'GOVERN'S RECORD CRITICIZED BY AGNEW
description: OMAHA, June 10 (AP)Vice President Agnew zeroed in today on Senator George McGovern and predicted the voters would become disillusioned with the South Dakota Democrat, now the frontrunner for his party's Presidential nomination.

title: U.S. Olympic Soccer Team Tied by Pennsylvanians, 11
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (UPI)Larry Huston scored goal with 19 minutes left today to give a team of Eastern Pennsylvania allstars a 11 tie with the United States Olmpic soccer team.

title: U.S. BRIDGE ACES LOSE 2 MATCHES
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 10 The world champion Aces, representing the United States in the World Team Olympiad, had an unsuccessful afternoon here today.

title: Women Don't Need Help
description: To THE EDITOR: A story in the June 4 paper said that the male runner who paced the women in the Crazylegs mini marathon in Central Park represented the Staten Island A.C. He is not a member of our club, but a member of the Long Island A.C.

title: SAMUEL N. CAPLOW
description: LONG BEACH, L. I, June 10 Samuel N. Caplow, associate counsel to the New York City Board of Transportation before his retirement in 1957, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 84 years old and lived at 55 Monroe Boulevard.

title: 2,500 BLACKS MEET TO BACK NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)Some 2,500 blacks gathered here today to support President Nixon's reelection in, November and to raise more than $200,000 for the Republican party at a fundraising dinner.

title: Guineans Slowly Taking Steps To Develop the Nation's Wealth
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  Guinea, could be one of the richest, countries in black Africa, according to independent economists. The country has some of the best bauxite deposits in the world as well as vast untapped Ironore resources. The climate is diverse and the soil good.

title: Women Advised on Their Rights and Opportunities
description: PARAMUSAll day long my phone would ring, Dean Lois Marshall, head of community services at Bergen Community College here, recalled last week. People would call and say, I have a problem.

title: Alexandra Gardner Plans Bridal
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 10Mr. and Mrs. George P. Gardner Jr. of Brookline have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Gardner, to Nicholas Frederic Papanicolaou of Athens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sophocles Papanicolaou of Athens and London.

title: McGovern Starts Planning Campaign to Defeat Nixon
Two Who Fought a Good Fight
description: WOW, said a young choreographer drifting back into the Juilliard Theater, she really knew her stuff! She was the late Doris Humphrey; we were watching Juilliard students perform revivals of four Humphrey works, The Shakers (1931), Day on Earth (1947), Lament for Ignacio Sanchez Mejfas (1946), and Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor (1938). Also within the past few weeks, the company of Humphrey's former partner, Charles Weidman, has presented part of her masterwork, New Dance, as well as some of his own important dances. This summer, the American Dance Festival at New London, Connecticut, will offer more Humphreyweidman revials.

title: KISSINGER BEGINS JAPANESE TALKS
description: TOKYO, June 10  Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, began talks with Japanese leaders today that ranged widely over world affairs as they bear on United StatesJapanese relations.

title: Not All MiddleClass America Is in Suburbs
description: Someone must have passed a new Homestead Act five or six years ago and now in Park Slope we have the groovy Brownstone Victorian Renovation. Where late bare ruined window shades hung, masking the loncly, now blackpost lamps cneerily gutter (and leak) gaslight. Well, it shows that not all middleclass America is slinking out to the suburbs.

title: A heroine with a talent for survival
description: Our yearning for meaningful novels, for novels that will truly change us for the better, is so constantly thwarted that when we come upon the work of a contemporary who has written such a work our first reaction is astonishment. It is something we no longer expect. We have lost faith in many of our imaginative writers; we have begun to look elsewhere for the experiences that only the novelwhen it is at its bestcan really give us.

title: Black Woman in Texas Is Governor for a Day
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 10 (UPI)State Senator Barbara Jordan became the nation's first black woman Acting Governor today.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drug Institute Focuses on Plight Of Squares and Dope Fiends
description: The large black woman stood on the steps of 21 West 118th Street, so chilled in her sleeveless blouse that she hugged herself to keep warm. She did riot know it but she was the focus yesterday of a discussion at a daylong drug institute across the street.

title: TOO MUCH TO ASK?
description: TO THE EDITOR: Garrett Epps semirequest for censorship is, to put it mildly, dangerous.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, June 10An 18yearold member of a leftwirrg movement opposed to Israeli occupation of Arab lands will go on trial in military court tomorrow on charges of evading the draft, the Israeli radio said today.

title: Physician Reports Soaring V.D Rate For Young Britons
description: LONDON, June 10 (AP)In any school class of 16yearolds in Britain there is an even chance that someone has venereal disease, a British specialist says.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In Tax Law Favors Homeowner [April 16], Lester O. Sumas presents his hypothetical bank in the dual roles of mortgage lender and residential landlord simplistically using an 8 per cent pretax return on investment criterion for both the mortgage and the residential holding. When the bank's after tax return on investment criterion is realistically substituted, one finds the bank's yield equalizing in the first year, when rental income is lower than mortgage interest income.

title: WATERMETER PLAN APPROVED IN QUEENS
description: The state Public Service Commission has approved the Jamaica Water Supply Company's 10year program for installing meters for the 104,000 customers in southeastern Queens and Nassau County who now pay a flat rate.

title: O'GORMAN'S BOAT OVERALL VICTOR
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 Bevin Koeppel's Congere from the Beach Point Y. O. was first to finish a 21mile course and third in the fleet as Indian Harbor Yacht Club conducted the second of four races i its Whitmore and Endymion Trophy series today on Long Island Sound.

title: RADICAL IDEOLOGY
description: To THE EDITOR: Garrett Epps attack on The French Connection, Straw Dogs and Dirty Harry is an astonishing example of selfcontradictory, radical ideology. Although starting his last paragraph with the statement, It is widely accepted that art should be free to say what it must without political or moral responsibility, he concludes It by asking that we, his readers, place pressure on producers and distributors to stop offering us fascist propaganda and sado masochistic wet dreams.

title: ST. AUGUSTINE AND WOMEN'S LIB
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: BLAST MAY HURT RHODESIA OUTPUT
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 10The loss of more than 400 lives in the mine explosion at Wankie has overshadowed the possible economic consequences of the disaster.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Action has been delayed until next year on Representative Wilbur D. Mills interesting tax reform bill, but out in Los Angeles, Senator George McGovern told representatives of The New York Times that he regarded Mr. Mills Proposals as better than his own tax reform program. Does thereby hang tale?

title: Headliners
description: To many, John Paul Vann was a living symbol of the American involvement in Vietnam. He began his career there as a lieutenant colonel in 1962, just as the American buildup was starting. Soon he was in the thick of controversy. An unorthodox tactician, he challenged conventional military Ideas drawn from World War II and Korea. He vehemently criticized and exposed corruption Vietnamese high places. To make matters worse, he frequently aired his views news correspondents. His constant battles with the military hierarchy forced retirement from the army in 1963, but he was soon back in Vietnam as a State Department civilian adviser. It was in this role, working in the strategic Central Highlands area as the latest North Vietnamese offensive got under way that Mr. Vann found new prominence. And it was there last Friday night that he met deathat the age of 47, in a flaming helicopter crash, while flying from one danger spot to another to check on the action.

title: Little tarts to gobble up
description: Fruit pies and cheesecake are among America's most popular homemade desserts. Combine the two and you come up with fruited cheese pies. And everyone is happy. The fruit can be varied according to the season. Peaches and plums and cherries and all the rest of summer's fruits make any number of seasonal variations possible. wedge of fruited cheese pie makes a delicious ending any meal. And topped with a dollop of ice cream whipped cream, it is a fabulous dessert.

title: Riva Ridge Wins
description: Riva Ridge won the $155,900 Belmont Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park by seven lengths. Ruritania ran second and Cloudy Dawn third as 54,635 spectators watched the 104th running of the race for 3yearold thoroughbreds. Riva Ridge paid $5.20, $4.80 and $3.80 for $2 across the board. Details in Section 5.

title: Aldeburgh's Gentlest and Most Intimate of Festivals
description: A LDEBURGH, EnglandIn the beginning there was Aldeburgh, at the end of one of the least marred stretches of English countryside within 90 miles of London, an uncommunicative Suffolk fishing village whose streets of red brick Victorian houses gave way to Georgian and Regencyfronted mariners cottages along the marshes and the North Sea.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Jewish Group Cites Times
description: The Union of American Hebrew Congregations last night, in a ceremony at the Plaza Hotel, cited The New York Times for its reporting of complex issues. In the first award bestowed on an individual or institution in its 99year history, the organization said that The Times through courageous reporting, helped bring illumination and understanding of incredibly complex issues.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 25 editorial More Loophole Than Law clearly pointed out the senselessness and cruelty of aerial hunting and the loopholes in P.L. 92159. The loophole you mentioned was added specifically to appease stock raisers from Western states like Wyoming and Washington where the stock raisers (and government officials) wanted to be able to continue aerial predator control of coyotes.

title: Art
description: THE four oneseasonold galleries in the handsomely doneup SoHo loft building at 420 West Broadwayto wit, the Castelli, Sonnabend, Weber and Emmerichdo not have a monopoly on all that passes for avantgarde art in New York today. At least three or four other local showrooms (not counting the 420 galleries uptown branches) enjoy something like similar cachet, and perhaps two dozen more can make some claim to uptotheminuteness. But the New York art world has never before seen anything quite like the sheer concentrated hauteur and pizzazz of the 420 quartet.

title: Woman Gets Church Post
description: The Rev. Margaret R. Eddy has been elected moderator of the United Church of Christ's New York Conference. Mrs. Eddy, who has been pastor of the Church of the Resurrection in East Harlem since March, 1971, is the first woman to head the conference, which is the statewide governing body of the twomillionmember denomination.

title: The World
description: PEKINGIf there are any regrets in Peking about President Nixon's visit to the Chinese People's Republic last February, they are not apparent either to the casual observer or to the informed diplomat in this capital. Nor are there any signs that the President's trip to Moscow two weeks ago has caused Peking to reevaluate its position visvis the United States.

title: TITO FLIES HOE FROM SOVIET VISIT
description: MOSCOW, June 10The Soviet leadership sent President Tito of Yugoslavia home today with a warm sendoff and joint proclamation of increasingly friendly relations between the two nations.

title: B52'S RAID NORTH FOR THE FIFTH DAY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 11 United States 1152's flew 12 missions in the southern panhandle of North Vietnam between noon Friday and 6 A.M. today, as the heaviest aerial bombardment missions of the war continued to be directed against North Vietnamese supply caches and depots near Donghoi.

title: Michelin on New York: No    for Restaurants
description: TALLEYRAND spent two years in exile living on what is now West 75th Street. That was some time ago, of course, but isn't that the sort of soothing irrelevance that could give you a whole new perspective on West 75th Street, on the entire Upper West Side?

title: Medicine
description: Four weeks ago an elderly woman arrived at a New York City hospital in a wheelchair. Crippled by arthritis, she was unable to walk or even stand erect. Last week she left for home on her own two legs, aided only by cane.

title: AN INDICTMENT
description: To THE EDITOR: I share Garrett Epps uneasiness over the mindless violence featured in some recent films, but I disagree with him on his treatment of The French Connection. Rather than finding it a celebration of authority, brutality and racism, this viewer saw the film as an indictment of such qualities as embodied in its main character, Popeye Doyle.

title: The Laird Fallacy
description: Secretary of. Defense Laird's insistence in the wake of the missile pacts with Moscow on stepping up the arms race in strategic offensive forcesinstead of stepping it downhas led him into renewed scare statements about Soviet development of a MIRV multiple warhead missile. But the essential factsas now clarified by both the State Department and the Pentagonhave not changed since Mr. Laird's February acknowledgement that the Russians have not yet tested a MIRV warhead, something the United States first did four years ago.

title: Carol Howerton Wed to C. R. Harding
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., June 10Miss Carol Lynn Howerton, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Richard T. Howerton Jr., and Christopher Robert Harding, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Harding of Boca Raton, Fla., formerly of Laurel Hollow, L. I., were married here this evening at the Blacksburg Baptist Church. The bride's father, who is pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Education
description: The bill for Federal aid to higher education, finally passed by Congress last week, has been labeled landmark in the relationship between the nation's colleges and the Federal Government.

title: Selfportrait of a man who won't look at himself
description: Jakov Lind, the once savage chronicler of nightmares who in his early fiction  notably Landscape in Concrete and Soul of Wood provided poignant glimpses of man in the age of the cannibal, has of late been zooming in on himself in what promises to be a longwinded quest for identity. The autobiographical impulse is understandable enough in a man past 40 who feels, with some basis in fact, that the lives he lived were not his own; but it involves large risks, and on the evidence of Numbers it would seem that Lind's rather special gifts leave him peculiarly illequipped for the confrontations involved.

title: Miss Benedict Wed To Basil Mavroleon
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 10  Miss Celeste Janice Benedict was married here this evening to Basil George Mavroleon. The Rev. Leo Daly, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. George Poulos, a Greek Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Benedict of PurchaSe and Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. and Mrs. George M. Mavroleon of Rye are the bridegroom's parents.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor a couple of days it looked as though the biggest tax reform anyone could imagine was in the making. Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, the Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and the man who calls most of the tunes on tax matters, appeared to be paving the way for a massive rewrite of the tax laws. He introduced a bill that would, repeal, over a threeyear period, 54 sections of the tax law that confer special, benefits on certain individuals or corporations or both.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: THERE arrived on my desk a few days ago as surprising a manifestation of the current universal enthusiasm for needlecraft as I have yet seenand I have seen many. It was a copy of a Dictionary of Needlework that was first printed in London 90 years ago (in 1882) and has now been reissued in both hardcover and paperback by Arno Press. It is fat and, in keeping with the fancy work it encompasses, it is fancy. It is 528 doublecolumn pages long, and its illustrations are numbered 1 (Alencon Bar) to 822 (YaklaceImitation) and they are woodcuts of great clarity.

title: Girl, 9, Survives Napalm Burns
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP)Nineyearold Phan Thi KimPhuc is recuperating in a Saigon children's hospital, the unintended victim of a misdirected napalm attack.

title: Abortion Opponents Active
description: EDISON  Last December, months before a Federal court ruled that New Jersey's abortion law was unconstitutionally vague and an invasion of women's right to privacy, the first office of Birthright in the state opened its doors.

title: Swimsuits Give Way To Sweaters Here As Mercury Falls
description: Weather more suitable to October than to June pervaded the metropolitan area's weekend, curtailing a few of summer's pleasures but intensifying others.

title: FirePolicemen, on Patrol, Watch Out for Any Lawbreaker
description: PLAINFIELDNew Jersey firemen are taking on new responsibilities to cope with the times, one of them being that of firepolicemen, a controversial role.

title: Government Says News Media Distort Pentagon Papers Issues
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10The Government, in a motion in Federal District Court here, has charged the news media with distortion of the issues involved in the Pentagon papers case.

title: Sheinkmans Have Child
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Sheinkman on May 29 at the University Hospital. The child has been named Talya Regina.

title: 14 Injured in Fire
description: WALTHAM, Mass., June 10 (AP)A flash fire in a chemical processing building at the sprawling Polaroid Corporation plant here today injured 14 persons, none of them seriously. Thirteen of the injured were admitted to Waltham Hospital. for treatment.

title: I Still Love Artie Shaw
description: THERE was a time, not so long ago, when exbandleader Artie Shaw seemed to be in constant flight from the Swing Era and everything it stood for. To bring up the subject of the glorious big band days was to turn him off. Only two years ago he told a Down Beat writer. I don't care about 1938, and all that crap about the big band sound. That isn't today. Every body's always talking about the good old days... the good old days led to Hitler and war.

title: New Labor Law Expected to Set off Arizona Clash
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 10 The United Farm Workers union and Arizona's produce growers are locked in a classic American labor battle over organization of migrant field workers in the irrigated crop lands of the southwest desert.

title: Arthur Potts jr., Law Student, Marries Alexandra D. Tenney
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 10Miss Alexandra D. Tenney and Arthur G. Potts Jr., were married here today in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee, the rector. A reception was held at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Tenney Jr., in Locust Valley. The bridegroom Is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Potts of Danbury, Conn.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show, expanded to five days for the first time, gets under way Wednesday in Darien, Conn., with most of the leading mounts in the East on hand. The feature of the event will be the Connecticut Classic for jumpers, which is being held for the first time. It's a $3,000 added class with $1,050 going to the winner. The class will be over 16 obstacles, including a water jump, on closing day. The only requirement will be that entries must have shown in two other open jumper classes in the show.

title: Art
description: JUNE WAYNE, founder of Los Angeles famed Tamarind Lithography Workshop, is not at all unhappy about the fact that the workshop's publication of a racilytitled statistical study, Sex Differentials in Art Exhibition Reviews, has opened awell, Pandora's box.

title: TRADE PACTS SIGNED BY CHILE AND CHINA
description: PEKING, June 10 (Agence FrancePresse)The first Chilean ministerial delegation to visit China has obtained an interestfree loan of $65million.

title: OBSERVER
description: Robert Morley, the English comic actor, and a very good one too, fancies himself a worrier. Writing in a British newspaper, The Observer, he catalogues the things. he is capable of worrying about.and, in the process, reveals that as a worrier he is a featherweight. His bank balance and specifically whether he has one at the moment Writing a checkais the sort of thing he worries about Spots in front of his eyes, a mole on his cheek, his children when, they are out in the fog, the possibility of masked desperadoes invading his bedroom. That sort of thing.

title: Davis Rally Site Shifted
description: DETROIT, June 10 (UPI)Sponsors of a victory rally for Angela Davis, the black militant, said today that they would hold the event somewhere in Detroit June 18, but not at University of Detroit. as originally announced. Wendell E. Addington, secretary of the Michigan Committee to. Free Angela Davis and All Political Prisonners, said that the university had reversed a decision to permit the rally.

title: Movies
description: WHAT? You haven't seen The Fantasticks even thrice? Well, somebody must have, in order to have kept it running all these years Off Broadway. If you haven't seen it, perhaps your problem has been some strange prejudice against the delightfully snug Sullivan Street Playhouse in Greenwich Village, where the Tom JonesHarvey Schmidt musical has been pleasing audiences for over 12 years. If so, you're in luck, because The Fantasticks may soon be playing all over townon screen. Negotiations are now under way between Paramount and representatives of the musical, and if all goes as planned, Howard W. Koch should put the movie into production some time next year.

title: 70 Protestant Barricades Block Key Routes in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 10Protestants set up 70, barricades in central Belfast today as a 48hour token protesti against the continued existence in Londonderry of Roman Catholic areas sealed off from security forces.

title: Photography,
description: HONEYWELL has introduced a new compact electronic flash unit which Is that company's first shoemount model that offers builtin automatic exposure control with a choice of aperture openings. Called the Auto/Strobonar 360, the unit computes exposures for subjects located from 2 to 22 feet away, and offers a guide number of 44 with ASA 25 film, with a choice of either manual or automatic operation. With an ASA 25 film, the camera can be set at f/4, f/2.8 or 1/2, which will work at distance ranges of 2 to 11, 3 to 15.5 or 4 to 22 feet respectively. With an ASA 400 film, the choice of settings would be f/16, f/11 or f/8 at the same distance

title: ROSS, OROPEZ REACH STATE TENNIS FINAL
description: Steve Ross of Brooklyn, seekhis third claycourt title, had to struggle to beat Kirk Moritz of Old Westbury, L. I., a Columbia University player, 46, 62, 63, in the semifinals of the New York State men's tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

title: SENATE TAKING UP SPORTS CONTROL
description: Senate hearings will begin Friday on a bill to set up Federal Sports Commission, the most comprehensive proposal advanced so far in the rapidly expanding field of sports legislation.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: HAROLD SCHONBERG is to he commended for amending the misleading impression he originally gave of the N. Y. Philharmonic's programing for the forthcoming season.

title: Portrait of a City in Photos
description: PATERSON The City of Paterson, poetically limned by William Carlos Williams a quarter century ago, has had its picture taken for viewing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Scenic Woodmere Lake To Become a Preserve
description: WOODMLRE, L.I.A tiny, but scenic lake that once was part of historic, 1,000 acre Lord; WOOdS is cxprctcd to be designated as a nature preserve by the Hempstead Town Board.

title: At General Foods, Did Success Breed Failure?; Hamburger Chain, Other Errors Lost Millions
description: Another corporate god has stumbled on its feet of clay. Last January the General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of packaged convenience foods, disclosed that it had lost $83million, mostly on the Burger Chef fastfood chain it had acquired in 1968.

title: The Summer Game
description: The Summer Game provides such finely observed and finely written reportage on majorleague baseball during the past decade that I hope it will triumph over certain of its disadvantages. One is that it is a collection of pieces. Collections don't sell unless they have an obvious gimmick, and I don't see any in sight for Roger Angell's witty but tactful coverage. Still, The Summer Game is a genuine book, unified by its ongoing account of the new developments and distortions of the sport and integrated by Angell's consistent ability to capture the feel of the player, the game, the series, the pennant race, and by his articulate and imaginative defense of the sport itself against its adversaries, beginning with the major league owners.

title: 14Week Nixon Drive Gets $10Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The main Republican campaign treasury for the reelection of President Nixon has received more than $10million in early 1972 gifts from contributors whose identity apparently will never be known, the President's first full Federal election finance statement disclosed today...

title: Miss MacCauley Wed
description: PARAMUS, N.J., June 10Miss Maureen Ellen MacCauley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. MacCauley of Teaneck, was married here this morning to Francis Gerald Racioppi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Racioppi of Orange. Judge S. Harvey Smith of the Bergen County District Court performed the ceremony at J. B. Mario's restaurant. The bride's father is president of the Publication Corporation in New York.

title: Who Bears Responsibility?
description: In the management of a billiondollar corporation such as General Foods, who bears responsibility?

title: Mrs. King Gets Top Prize
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 10 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of the United States was awarded the $2,600 first prize in the women's singles competition after rain had washed out the final of the John Player roundrobin tennis tournament today.

title: A Score Composed of Notes on The Summer Music Festivals of Europe
description: Summer music festivals are a major attraction for tourists traveling abroad, and for many the primary reason for their trip. Increasingly, travel agencies are arranging special musical festival tours complete with tickets to performances. In addition to the larger festivals listed below, small local concerts are very much a part of the European summer experience, from four octogenarians playing light classics in an outdoor cafe in Dubrovnik or a uniformed band playing Verdi and Puccini in a small piazza by a canal in Venice to a full symphonic orchestra playing under the stars.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWith the Democrats generating all the excitement and winning most of the political headlines, the only source of fun on the Republican side of the fence these days is the recurrent speculation that John B. Connally will replace Spiro Agnew on the Republican ticket this fall.

title: Book Wholesalers Form Group To Gain Voice in Their Industry
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Book wholesalers, who regard themselves as stepchildren of the industry, are demanding a voice of their own.

title: If You Go...
description: . to Aldeburgh during the remaining few days of the festival (until June 19) don't expect to get tickets without the intervention of a miracle. But other musical weekends with scheduled operas, recitals and ballet occur nearby in July, August and September at the Maltings. And throughout the summer there are nonmusical attractions that are hardly onenight stands: walks along the scenic marshes; a swim in the sea followed by fresh lobster on the beach; nature walks and tours of local architecture. Then there is the local dining, perhaps at the Maltings, or at the Plough and Sail in Snape. In Aldeburgh the fare is fine at the Wentworth, the town's principal hotel, or the Cross Keys, a 200yearold, oakbeamed pub featuring oysters, smoked salmon sandwiches and beer drawn difrom the cask.

title: Submarine Will Hunt a Spot to Dump Sludge
description: SANDY HOOK A tiny submarine with three scientists aboard will explore the ocean bottom along the length of New Jersey this summer in hopes of finding a spot where millions of tons of sewage sludge from metropolitan New York can be dumped temporarily with minimal harm to the marine environment.

title: CrossOver Republicans Helped Rodino to Win
description: NEWARK  The leaflets handed out by the thousands on the street corners of this city by volunteers for Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. during the brief but volatile 10th Congressional District primary campaign here asserted: This election is not as simple as black and white.

title: Jailed Teachers Still Go to Class
description: HACKENSACKEvery night since June 2, Illona Mellor has packed a bag, picked up her books and papers, hopped into her candyapple red Volkswagen and driven herself off to the Bergen County jail.

title: Miss Valk Wed To L. D. Benton; 6 Attend Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 10Miss Leslie Valk and Lawrence David Benton were married here this afternoon in the Congregational Church by the Rev. Charles Smith. Msgr. Francis Maguire assisted.

title: Fascist Threat in Italy
description: If Italy's democratic forces need a reminder that the election last month gave them only a reprieve and not a solution for a nagging national crisis, the neoFascist Italian Social Movement (M.S.I.) has provided a rude one. On the day President Leone designated Giulio Andreotti Premierelect, the leader.of the M.S.I., Giorgio Almirante, hinted at a Fascist takeover which might get support from elements in the nation's armed forces.

title: Retarded Join Community
description: PATERSONAfter nearly 30 years as an inmate of the Lisbon State School for the Retarded, 41yearold Clarence M. has found home and has become a taxpaying member of the community.

title: Gray MacWhorter Bryan 3d Fiance of Joan Dillon Moseley
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., June 10  Miss Joan Dillon Moseley plans to be married here next spring to Gray MacWhorter Bryan 3d at the home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglas Dillon. Mr. Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, is president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, and was Ambassador to France and Under Secretary of State.

title: Dedication Day Set
description: CLIFTONA dedication of more parts of Botany Village, the 28acre restoration here, will be held next Saturday, starting at noon, and with a Botany Ball at 8:30 P.M. The restoration at Parker and Lakes Avenues, just off Route 46, has buildings, antique cars and cottage industries reflecting the turn of the century.

title: Stamps
description: Illustrated is an artist's conception of the philatelicnumismatic firstday cover planned by the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission. It will be issued July 4, when the block of four Colonial American Craftsmen stamps have their firstday sale at Williamsburg, Va. The cover includes the bicentennial medal, struck by the U.S. Mint and first of a series to commemorate the 1976 bicentennial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If President Nixon's policies on Vietnam are of such overriding importance and so out of step with majority public opinion, we will find out soon enough through the direct democratic procedure of national elections. With that election only five months away, it is both superfluous and arrogant for any group, no matter how well endowed with education, titles or selfrighteousneis, to begin organizing impeachment proceedings against president Nixon.

title: Gardens
description: THE deliciously fragrant blooms of Daphne cneorum fill the early spring air. Then in May and June those of Daphne Somerset are equally fragrant. Both plants flower occasionally throughout the summer and early fall.

title: State PupilTesting Plan May Raise Storm
description: TRENTONWhen they check their mailboxes tomorrow morning, thousands of elementary and secondary public school teachers in the state will find a special document, and some of them may not like it.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Mrs. Oliver Has a Son
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 10A son was born May 28 to Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Oliver in the YaleNew Haven Hospital. Mrs. Oliver is the former Miss Louise Vietor of New Haven. Her husband is a lawyer and a contributor to the National Review. The child, the couple's third, has been named for his father.

title: A Western story that is playing for keeps
description: Summer in southern Alberta is an interval of blistering heat between winter seasons which seem to last most of the year and which, as one of Herbert Harker's characters says, make even Manitoba seem like heaven. Covering three summer months in the lives of half a dozen people, Goldenrod does for southern Alberta what has never quite been done before by a novel. It converts it into a province of the imagination; and it brings to fresh and often comic life some of the traditional materials of the western story.

title: TEXAS NINE RALLIES, TOPS OLE MISS, 98
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 10 (UPI) The Texas Longhorns, trailing by 8.0, after six innings, sent 13 men to the plate in the seventh today, scoring nine runs and edging Mississippi, 98. The loss knocked the Rebels out of the 26th annual College World Series.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: VINCENT CANBY is hopeless! He prefers Francine du Plessix Gray's New Yorker pieces on The Trial of the Catonsville Nine to Daniel Berrigan's text, which the film follows all too faithfully. Father Berrigan's original published text, which Mr. Canby hastens to assure us he has read, was arranged and edited by Father Berrigan and Saul Levitt before the New York production of the play. It is this unpublished text taken entirely from the court transcript which is used in the film. It is literally the trial, wether Mr. Canby likes it or not; shortened but nevertheless the trial presented In the actual words of the defendants, the judge, the attorneys.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drew U. Archeologist Resumes Digging in Israel
description: MADISON  A team of archeologists headed by a New Jersey professor is rapidly discovering that even Caesarea. the ancient Roman capital of Palestine now buried under centuries of Mediterranean sand, cannot go unscathed by the effects of progress.

title: Rutgers Board Approves Undergraduate Tuition Rise
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 10  The Rutgers University board of governors yesterday approved a $1S5increase in undergraduate tuition, effective for the fall term, and ratified increases for graduate students and students attending summer sessions.

title: The Nation
description: By the time the voting in the Senate began last Thursday, the issue was no longer in doubt. Even some Senate Democratic liberals decided to go along on the theory that a President ?? be given every benefit of the doubt when it comes to picking his Cabinet members. And so, by a decisive 64?? 19 vote, Richard G. Kleindienst was approved as the new Attorney General. He will be sworn in by the President tomorrow.

title: Hospital Set to Begin Expansion Program
description: GREENPORT, L. I.  Construction will begin in the fall on a $4million dollar expansion and modernization program at Eastern Long Island Hospital here if the project is approved by the State Regional Board of Health.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Having made five feature films and several hundred television programs, from comedies and musicals to documentaries and thrillers, I've never felt the urge to respond to criticism, good or bad, until The New York Times chose to reprint an uninformed slur from the Harvard Crimson (Does Popeye Doyle Teach Us to Be Fascist?", by Garrett Epps, 72). It's tempting to dismiss it as an overdose of youthful idealism and let it go at that but the accusations it makes and the misconceptions it raises about The French Connection compel a response. Are we living in a time and a place where everyone whose work displeases us is either fascist racist?

title: Buckner Leaves Manhattan
description: Bob Buckner, Manhattan College's freshman and assistant basketball coach of four seasons, has resigned. Buckner, also a teacher at DeWitt Clinton High School, said increased duties at the high school and oilier personal commitments forced him to give up the post.

title: Praschmas Have Child
description: A daughter was born on June 3 to Count and Countess Otto Praschma in Wiesbaden, Germany. Countess Praschma is the former Mary Golfrey Volk of Cambridge, Mass. Her husband is a tax lawyer. The child has been named Anna.

title: POLAND APPROVES NEW 5YEAR PLAN
description: WARSAW, June 10  The Polish Parliament finally got around to approving the current fiveyear economic plan this week, 17 months after it went into operation.

title: East Bay Span Rejected, 3 to 1, By San Francisco Area Voters
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 10The firm rejection of a new San Francisco East Bay freeway bridge by Bay area voters shows that the freeway revolt that began here in 1964 is still alive.

title: Patricia Hillman Is Bride in Jersey
description: GLEN RIDGE, N. J., June 10Miss Patricia Naomi Hillman and George Michael Brookover, graduates of Cornell University, were married here this afternoon by the Rev. William Roeger at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ellen Holly Writes to Anthony Quinn
description: DEAR ANTHONY QUINN: ON MAY 12, on the Dick Cavett Show, you stated your intention to produce a film in Haiti in which you would play the part of the black Haitian emperor, Henry Christophe. A few days later, the May 17th issue of Variety ran an article entitled FILMING IN HAITI: QUINN BLACKS UP, that restated that intention.

title: Wedding Held For Mrs. Cain
description: WESTON, Mass., June 10 Mrs. Ricki Hinrichsen Cain, widow of John E. Cain Jr., was married here this afternoon to Armstrong A. Stambaugh Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., an executive vice president of the Howard Johnson Company. The ceremony was performed in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. David Clark, assisted by the.Rev. Philip Krug.

title: Peking Says 3 Large Provinces Have SelfSufficient Grain Yield
description: HONG HONG, June 10Peking has reported that three of China's most heavily populated northern provinces have become basically selfsufficient in grain production, enabling the authorities to reduce the amount of rice and other crops traditionally shipped from the south to the north.

title: Lynn Matthews Wed To Joseph P. Marrow
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 10 Miss Lynn Marie Matthews and Joseph Patrick Marrow, an assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, were married here today in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. William Delaney.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRIONNE, FranceLike most fishermen I am saddened by the gradual disappearance of the fat trout which used to lie in these lovely Norman streams. The Risle has been intermittently polluted over stretches as have the Charentonne and Andelle. Plastic bottles, indestructible rubbish and increasing chemical poison quotients have replaced the May fly hatch.

title: WOODMAN IS FIRST IN OFF SOUNDINGS
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 10A fleet of 220 yachts completed the second and final day of the 35th spring off Soundings Club race today, riding home to port here on winds of 15 knots early this afternoon.

title: HERBERT SOPER, 60, JERSEY ACCOUNTANT
description: SUMMIT, N. J., June 10Herbert D. Soper, a partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Co., in the Newark office, died yesterday in Stamford, Conn. He was 60 years old and lived at 67A New England Avenue.

title: The Scars at St. John's Are Gone
description: St. John's University last week held a placid. uneventful commencement, ceremony that contrasted sharply with the events that divided the Jamaica, Queens, campus just six springtimes ago.

title: Jordan Gets Bonn Loan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 11 (AP)Jordan has received a $16.8million loan from West Germany to finance the building of a 66mile railroad between Ma'am and the port of Aqaba on the Red Sea, the Government announced today. Ma'am, a small city southeast of Amman, Is linked with the capital by a 125mile railroad.

title: Amy Sandler Married to Charles Levin
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J.. June 11Miss Amy Sandler was married here this afternoon to Charles Levin, son of Mrs. Morris Levin of East Orange and the late Mr. Levin. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis N. Sandler.

title: Business Is Strong In Specialty Steels
description: PITTSBURGH, June 11Producers of specialty steels were enjoying relatively good business last week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your June 1 editorial on the massacre at Tel Aviv airport, you concluded your appropriate condemnation of that act of barbarism with two points which, it is submitted, were less appropriate.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his letter of May 17, Vusumuzi Zulu takes issue with the United Nations, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, the Organization of African Unity, the World Council of Churches, The Times and a legion of African governments. To this incredible number of adversaries one should add the Vatican, which exchanged ambassadors with Sudan after the settlement of the problem of the southern provinces.

title: Forecasters Are Divided On Future of Bond Rates
Heroin Clinics Opposed
description: CHICAGO, June 11 (UPI)Clinics that would give heroin to addicts would add to the drugcrime problem, not solve it, Dr. Vincent P. Dole of Rochester University wrote to1 day in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Dr. Dole, an early supporter of methadonemaintenance clinics, listed as flaws the problems of increased tolerance, black marketeering and lack of rehabilitalion potential.

title: Webster Qualifies in Dash
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11Don Webster, a 27yearold Philadelphia municipal employe, qualified today for the Olympic trials by clocking 21 seconds in the 220yard dash at the Middle Atlantic Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Franklin Field.

title: DR. WILLIAM AGAR, GEOLOGIST, U.N. AIDE
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 11 Dr. William M. Agar, a geologist, educator and author, died yesterday in a nursing home here after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 363 Hill Street.

title: SAMUEL HIBBEN, LIGHTING EXPERT
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 11 Dr. Samuel G. Hibben, a pioneer illuminating engineer and former director of applied lighting of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Bloomfield, died Friday in Mountainside Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 31 Clinton Avenue.

title: INDIA BANGLADESH SIGN NEW ACCORD
description: NEW DELHI, June 11India and Bangladesh have agreed to mesh their economic development programs.

title: Writer Says U.S. Troops Killed Civilians in Delta
description: A Newsweek Magazine correspondent who spent four years covering the Vietnam war has charged that American forces killed thousands of civilians in the Mekong Delta under the guise of pacification.

title: U.S. Cuban Population Rises By 351% From 196070
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) The population of firstand secondgeneration Cubans in the United States increased by 351 per cent between 1960 and 1970, according to the United States Census Bureau.

title: DETECTIVE ACCUSED OF STRIKING WOMAN
description: An offduty detective was arrested last night on charges of felonious assault and menacing in connection with a disturbance that took place early yesterday on the street in front of a Queens nightspot.

title: 3 Die in Ulster Battle
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 11At least three men were killed in a threehour gun battle involving Roman Catholics, Protestants and British soldiers in north Belfast today.

title: Miss Susan Long Burr Bride Of M.R.Clifford, Ornithologist
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 11Miss Susan Long Burr, granddaughter of William H.
