Long Jr., honorary chairman of the hoard and a member of the executive committee of Doremus & Co., advertising and public relations agency, was married here this afternoon to Michael Robin Clifford, an ornithologist.

title: PEARSON TAKES 400; AVERAGE 146.6 M.P.H.
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 11 (AP)  David Pearson fought off stiff challenges from Richard Petty and Bobby Allison midway through the Motor State 400 at Michigan International Speedway today and pulled away in the last 100 miles to capture the $83,000 NASCAR race.

title: Doctors at Seminar Gave Help When Victims of Flood Arrived
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 11 (UPI)On Friday night, about 500 medical doctors, lawyers, and clergymen from various parts of the country were gathered in western South Dakota, here and around Hill City, for a seminar. The subject was Death and the management of the dying patient.

title: KENYATTA'S JAZZ SHOWS OLD BITE
description: Robin Kenyatta, who had become one of the most polished and imaginative of the current jazz saxophonists and flutists before he moved to France two years ago, has returned to the United States with much the same musical outlook he had before he left.

title: Bolshoi's New Karenina Stars Maya Plisetskaya
description: MOSCOW, June 11There were all the earmarks of a major event: a sense of electric anticipation, extra police guards waving away traffic with white gloves, the appearance of much of Moscow's cultural elite, crowds on the sidewalk swarming at the sight of an extra ticket and an exultant shout, Oh, how lucky I am, from young woman who landed one at the last minute.

title: 14 NEW PLAYS TO RUN AT O'NEILL CENTER
description: Fourteen new plays will be presented by the Eugene, O'Neill Theater Center from July 9 to Aug. 6 at the eighth, annual National Playwrights Conference in Waterford, Conn The center, which has been instrumental in the development of new talent, will offer the works of 11 newcomers to the conference as well as those of three playwrights previously represented there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Roger Morris's The Ultimate Betrayal reveals that a man who can handle words well may yet fail to grasp the realities he purports to describe.

title: An Imbalance of Power
description: NEW HAVENPressure is on to persuade the public that, in the absence of a genuine emergency, there is no justification for a legal ban on strikes by municipal employes. The validity of this positionwhich represents the new sophistication in labor relationsdepends on the validity of its underlying premise; namely, that a city, as employer, is no different from a private corporation.

title: Country Singers Join Wallace's Son at Rally
description: LAKELAND, Fla., June 11 (AP)The country and Western stars, Tammy Wynette and Del Reeves joined George C. Wallace Jr. today in stumping for the Alabama Governor before a crowd of 10,000 at Wallace's Woodstock.

title: FASHION TALK
description: All over town, shoppers are muttering over the price tags in clothing departments. Sixty dollars for a blouse? exlaimed one woman to her friend in a Fifth Avenue store. They've got to be crazy.

title: Interest in Acupuncture Rises in U.S.; Doctors Test Old Chinese Technique
description: Some American doctors have quietly begun using acupuncture needles to deaden surgical pain in themselves, their colleagues and a few patients. They have been encouraged by recent favorable reports from highly respected American physicians who have witnessed the new use that Chinese doctors had discovered for the ancient technique of twirling needles that are inserted into the body at specified points.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HOCKENHEIM, Germany, June 11 (AP)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil won the Jochen Rindt Memorial Race today by driving his Lotus Formula II to victory in both 15lap heats as a crowd of 35,000 watched in shivering cold and rain.

title: Police Plan to Blanket Park at Odd Intervals
description: Central Park will be blanketed with policemenon foot, on scooters and in patrol carsat unannounced times every day this summer under an experimental program that begins today.

title: Julie Schneider Bride Of Gregar A. Tausche
description: ITHACA, N.Y., June 11Miss Julie Beth Schneider, a junior at Ithaca College, was married here today to Gregar Alan Tausche, a graduate of Cornell University. The Rev. George Urioste performed the nondenominational ceremony in the garden at the home of James Gardner, family friend.

title: ALBERT PARRENO, 51, A TAX LAWYER, DEAD
description: WESTERLY, R. I., June 11Albert J. Parreno, a member of the New York law firm of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosle and a specialist in tax and corporate law with special ireference to Latin America, died today of a heart attack in the Westerly Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 350 East 57th Street, New York.

title: Father Sees Daughter Sworn In, Dies Next Day
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 11 (UPI)The Rev. Benjamin M. Jordan, father of State Senator Barbara Jordan of Houston, died today in an Austin hospital of a stroke he suffered while watching his daughter sworn in as Governor for a day in Texas. He was admitted to the hospital yesterday.

title: Wedding Is Held For Carol Yahr, John L. Tucker
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 11Miss Carol Yahr and John Lathrop Tucker were married here at noon today. Rabbi Lloyd Tennenbaum performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Melvin D. Yahr.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bonnier, Swede, Is Killed at Le Mans
Ribicoff Urges Tax Credits To Help Nonpublic Schools
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 11 (AP)Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that he would introduce legislation to grant to parents tax credits of up to $475 for each of their children attending nonpublic schools.

title: Venice Biennale Is Optimistic in Spirit
description: VENICE, Italy, June 11The 36th Venice Biennale, which opened today with the customary speeches and ceremonies, is an exhibition remarkably optimistic in spirit but sadly undernourished in substance.

title: Block Parties a Growing Trend in City
description: The residents of South Portland Avenue in Brooklyn took to the street yesterday in what has become a proliferating New York phenomenon: the block party.

title: CARDINAL'S NOTES CAUSE A DISPUTE
description: ROME, June 11Documents left by the late Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, the scholarly French prelate who was a counselor to five Popes, have hecome the object of a dispute between his purported heir and he Vatican.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read Rabbi Meir Kahane's May 26 OpEd article Call for Mass Emigration to Israel and I wish to comment on it.

title: Cabaret: At the Plaza
description: The Plazayes, the good old venerable Plaza Hotel with its Plaza 9 Music Hall is scraping the barrel these nights with a larkish lump of entertainment called They Don't Make Em Like That Anymore. Let's hope nobody cooks up another pancake like thissoon, anyway.

title: DR. ERWIN A. WERNER
description: Dr. Erwin A. Werner, a cardiologist on the staff of New York Hospital for 25 years until his retirement in 1965, died there Friday. He was 68 years old and lived at 11 East 63d Street.

title: Barney's Clothes Picks Scali, McCabe, Sloves
description: Having looked at some 20 agencies, Barney's Clothes has decided that Scali, McCabe, Sloves suits them best. And don't think the agency isn't panting for that money.

title: Nullifying Brown
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in striking down a Federal District Court order to merge the predominantly black school district of Richmond with its two largely white suburbs, has done little to clarify a complex issue. The consolidation order was based primarily on the contention that the state had consistently used its power to preserve segregation and to keep the suburban districts white by locking the blacks into the city. Federal District Judge Robert Merhige Jr. said that both in the pattern of housing and of school construction the state had directly facilitated the maintenance of a segregationist wall which had the effect of perpetuating dual school systems.

title: DRAW OF ROYALS TOPS YANKEES,10
description: KANSAS CITY, June 11 Dick Drago, a fastball pitcher with superb control, outlasted New York's Steve Kline today as the kansas City Royals beat the Yankees, 10. Drago permitted five hits.

title: View From the Canal
description: The small plane takes off from Tel Aviv's local airport, nonchalantly dodges the towering stack of the municipal power plant and skims down the Mediterranean coast past ancient ports and modern pipelines, then along the northern edge of some of the most desolate country on earth, the Sinai Peninsula. Within an easy hour the plane puts down at a desert airstrip marked by a couple of huts, a handful of soldiers and the Israeli flag fluttering over the administered territories of Sinai.

title: Times A re Disappointing In SpeedSailing Trials
description: BELLPORT, L. I., June 18C'mon, wind Go, boat, go! Sheet that jibl Now, go! Stopwatch in one hand, sliderule in the other, Walter (Brad) Bradfield not only timed the boats sailing through his speed trap today on the Bellport Yacht Club but also rooted them on.

title: Illinois Gizz Kids Regain Wheelchair Games Title
description: Susan Sea of Clarendon Hills, Ill., won gold medals in the javelin throw, shotput and discus throw in Class II competition yesterday to help the Illinois Gizz Kids regain their team title in the 16th annual National Wheelchair Games at Bulova Park in East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Democratic Factions in Mississippi Urged to Settle Delegate Fight
Elaine Shiang Becomes Bride
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., June 11 Miss Elaine Shiang, a Wellesley College graduate who will enter Harvard Medical School in the fall, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Frederick Pei Li, a physician with the National Institutes of Health and the Children's Hospital of Boston. The Rev. H. Paul Santmire, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the Wellesley College Arboretum.

title: EDWARD JAMES
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., June 11Edward James, general managergeneration of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a heart attack yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived at 5 Burrington Gorge.

title: Premier Says Libya Aids Revolutionaries in Ulster
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11Premier Muammar elQaddafi of Libya said today that his country was sending arms, money and volunteers to help Irish revolutionaries fighting British forces in Northern Ireland.

title: Frederick F. Lovejoy Jr., 70, Lawyer in Norwalk, Dead
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 11Frederick F. Lovejoy Jr., a lawyer who served three terms as City Corporation Counsel, died here yesterday in a nursing home. His age was 70.

title: Moscow Talks: A Splendid Formulation
description: MOSCOWJune 11, 1942, is now hardly remembered by anyone as a date connected with a historical event. Yet it was a milestone in the history of SovietAmerican relations. On that day an agreement on principles applicable to mutual aid in conducting war against aggression was signed. Of course, a lot of water has flown under the bridges since the war when the Soviet and American peoples cooperated so fruitfully in defeating Fascism. The cold war rust has corroded many agreements of the war years. And still, thirty years after, it is worthwhile recalling all this.

title: Printer and Wife Die in Fire
description: WILLISTON PARK, L.I., June. 11A 58yearold unemployed: linotype operator and his wife: were killed early today in a fire that destroyed their home. The fire, whose origin is under investigation by the Nossau County Fire Marshals, took the lives of Alfred J. Lowe and his wife, Catherine, 57, of 20. Dartmouth Street, Williston Park.

title: Kathy Ahern Triumphs by Six Strokes
Mrs. Fox's Australian Terrier Gains Bestat Connecticut Show
4 Are Killed as Train Derails Near London
description: LONDON, June 11Four persons were killed tonight when a train jumped the rails and crashed near Eltham on the southeastern outskirts of London. Four of the train's eight cars, as well as the locomotive, derailed.

title: Perils Are Many for U.S. Families in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) Mary Jane, tenth grade. Teacher reported her sleeping in class. Taken to the school nurse, she admitted to smoking heroin. Action: Suspended from school and referred to the Fifth Field Hospital for psychiatric help.

title: New Antitrust Chief Thomas Eugene Kauper
description: WASHINGTON, June 11Thomas Eugene Kauper, who was nominated Friday by President Nixon to be chief of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, has been steeped in the law since childhood. I've heard Supreme Court cases at the dinner table since I was 10. he says.

title: East German Flees to West
description: BERLIN, June 11 (AP)An 18yearold East German fled through fire from automatic weapons of border guards today and escaped unhurt to West Berlin, the police report. ed.

title: Fire Officers'
description: The number of firemen seeking medical care after fighting fires rose again yesterday and the president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association warned that the figure could soar to 300 or.500 if there was an outbreak of fires.

title: Chinese Doctors Advise Caution on Acupuncture and Tell of Problems in Use
description: PEKING, June 11  Chinese doctors appear to he cautioning against acceptance of some of the more wildly uncritical reports on acupuncture that have appeared in the West.

title: J. C. Snead's 282 Wins by Shot As Rodriguez Finishes Second
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 11 Jesse Carlyle Snead beat Chi Chi Rodriguez by one stroke today and captured the Philadelphia golf tournament with a 72hole total of 282.

title: Gospel Parley to Open
description: DALLAS, June 11An expected total of 100,000 persons began streaming into Dallas today, for the opening tomorrow of Explo 72, a mammoth Christian training conference.

title: Total Eclipse of Sun to Occur July 10
description: On July 10 the shadow of the moon will drop down and touch the sea near the Soviet island of Sakhalin. It will sweep across Alaska and northern Canada and out over the Atlantic in the only total eclipse of the sun visible to Americans in 1972,

title: Touring Connally Rests On an Argentine Ranch
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 11 (Reuters)John B. Connally, President Nixon's special envoy, relaxed on a cattle ranch near here today after the third stop on his aroundtheworld tour.

title: JUSTICE MINISTER RESIGNS IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, June 11Minister of Justice Yakov Shimshon Shapiro, a pillar of Premier Golda Meir's coalition Cabinet, resigned today under fire in a domestic economic controversy.

title: Homosexuals Hold March
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (UPI)Thousands of homosexuals marched through downtown Philadelphia today in observance of what they said was Gay Liberation Day. The homosexuals, accompanied by smaller group calling itself Straights for Homosexual Freedom, ended their march at Independence Square.

title: 11 Children Killed In a Pickup Truck In Louisiana Crash
description: SHADY NOOK, La., June 11 (UPI)  A tractortrailer truck loaded with wheat struck the rear of a pickup truck today, killing a young woman and 11 children in the smaller truck who had been driving to swimming hole.

title: Flow Rate in Creek Flood Was 10 Times Old Record
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The flow of Rapid Creek reached almost unbelievable rates, hydrologists reporting from flooded South Dakota said today.

title: Gale M. Schneider Wed to L.W. Miller
description: In the Conservative Synagogue of Riverdale, the Bronx, yesterday, Miss Gale Merri Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schneider of Riverdale, was married to L. William Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Miller of the Bronx. Rabbi Chaim Pearl performed the ceremony.

title: 62 STUDENTS CITED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 11 (Reuters)Sixtytwo students were charged today under an antiriot law providing stiff fines or jail terms.

title: Texts of RooseveltChurchill Messages
description: The increasing gravity of the war has led me to feel that the principles of the Atlantic Charter ought not to be construed so as to deny Russia the frontiers she occupied when Germany attacked her. This was the basis on which Russia acceeded to the Charter, and I expect that as everywhere process of liquidating hostile elements in the Baltic states, etc., was employed by the Russians when they took these regions at the beginning of the war.

title: The Ultimate Weapon
description: The military component of foreign aid is again becoming a lightning rod for Congressional discontent with major elements of President Nixon's foreign policy particularly in South and Southeast Asia.

title: White Wins Yonkers Marathon by 350 Yard Margin
Selassie Off to Rabat
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 11 (Agence FrancePressel Emperor Heile Selassie or Ethiopia left here today by plane for Rabat to attend meeting of the Organizations of African Unity tomorrow. He is scheduled to fly to London on a private visit after the meeting, then to Belgrade before returning home.

title: Roundup: Tigers Halt A's and 3 Streaks
description: Three streaks came to an end yesterday at Detroit as Bill Freehan's leadoff home run in the bottom of the ninth inning gave the Tigers a 32 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Shots Miss Official in Aden
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, June 11 (Reuters)Premier Ali Nasser Mohammed escaped an assassination attempt on May 22 when a man forced his way into his office and fired several shots at him, the Ministry of Interior announced.

title: 13 ACCUSED OF FRAUD IN FRANCHISE SCHEME
description: FLINT, Mich., June 11 (AP)Thirteen persons were arraigned in Genesee County Circuit Court today on charge of fraud and conspiracy charges in connection with an alleged pyramid referral scheme headed by Glenn W. Turner, the Florida cosmetics tycoon.

title: Lutz 64, 63 Victor
description: STAMFORD, June 11After a slow start, Bob Lutz defeated Marty Riessen, 64, 63, and took the $10,000 Clark Gum roundrobin tennis tournament today. First prize was $4,000 in the event for contract pros.

title: Convening Prosecutors Hard at Play
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 11The mosquitoes massed over Sackett Lake and the rain clouds were gathering. The hotel loudspeaker shrilled requests for mahjongg players and the beach boys couldn't find the towels. But the district attorneys of New York State, spread out over the playing fields, were oblivious to it all.

title: Taiwan Officials Told to Shun Cabarets and Ribbon Cuttings
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 11Premier Chiang Chingkuo has issued a list of rules for officials designed to improve Government efficiency and raise standards of official conduct.

title: Mitchell Says 90,000 Have Aided Nixon Bid
Judge Dembitz Endorsed
description: Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for a seat on the State Court of Appeals, announced last night that she had been endorsed by Bess Myerson, the city's Consumer Protection Administrator.

title: Patrolman Kills Partygoer Who Reportedly Shot 3
description: A Queens man attempting to flee after he had shot three persons at a house party was shot and killed yesterday by pursuing patrolman the police reported.

title: 7 Gain U.S. Yacht Trials
description: BABYLON, L. I., June 11Seven skippers qualified today at the Babylon Yacht Club to go to the Olympic trials for singlehanded Finn class yachts later this month at Marion, Mass. They were: Pete Conrad of Milford, Conn.; John Eggers of Sparta, N. J.; Tom Patterson of Sea Isle, N. J.; Art Ellis of Marion, Mass.; Robbie Doyle of Marblehead, Mass.; Jim Hahn of Annapolis, Md., and Dan Hurley of Mantoloking, N. J.

title: City Is Studying Productivity Projects for Saving of $5Million
description: Budget Director David A. Grossman said yesterday the city had 150 productivity projects under study, with expectations these would produce at least $5million in savings in the next year.

title: Cynthia Van Allen Is Married To Robert T. Schaffner on L.I
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 11Miss Cynthia Olney Van Allen, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. James Alfred Van Allen of Iowa City and Southampton, was married here this afternoon to Robert Todd Schaffner, son of Mrs. Robert Schaffner of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Schaffner.

title: U.S. TEAM TAKES ONION PATCH LEAD
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 11The 58foot sloop Saga, a member of the Brazilian team, won the first race for the Onion Patch Trophy today, but American yachts took the next two places and helped the United States team take a 2point lead over Argentina in the international competition. The Onion Patch Trophy series is for yachts going in the biennial NewporttoBermuda race.

title: Orantes Captures German Net Title; Miss Tuero Loses
description: HAMBURG, Germany, June 11 (AP)Manuel Orantes of Spain beat Adriano Panatta of Italy, 63, 98, 60, to win the men's single title at the German tennis championships today. The lefthander has also won the Belgian and Italian crowns.

title: Red Smith
description: Lucien Laurin and Edward Sweat led Riva Ridge into the winner's circle, and both the trainer and the groom were breathing harder than the horse. From the clubhouse dining room a man watched through binoculars as they hung a stole of white carnations over the colt's withers. This makes me feel worse than ever about the Preakness, he said.

title: Death in Boston
description: The planned publication next Sunday of the final edition of The Boston HeraldTraveler will mark the death of a New England institutiqn. The 125yearold Herald, which merged with The Traveler after World War II, had been in the past a bible for Bostonians and preeminent throughout the region. Its editorial page had won four Pulitzer Prizes, more than any other in the nation.

title: NEWISSUE BOOM LIFTS EUROBONDS
description: BRUSSELS, June 11 The newissue boom on the Eurobond market is still churning along despite a noticeably weaker trend in the neglected secondary sector.

title: Black Parleys in Capital Hail Nixon and Thurmond
Bridge: Italian Blue Team Seems Slated to Retain Laurels
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 11The first three days play in the World Bridge Team Olympaid here suggests that the Italian Blue Team will retain its title, and that the challenge of the Aces, who have twice won the Bermuda Bowl World Championship in the absence of the Italians, will be unavailing.

title: CITY LOOKS TO U.S. FOR TRANSIT HELP
description: Both the city's Congressional delegation and Mayor Lindsay's administration renewed their calls yesterday for Federal operating subsidies to help the transit system here, following a breakthrough on Federal aid for construction.

title: COSMOS OBTAIN ACE FROM ITALIAN TEAM
description: The New York Cosmos didn't get to play Moscow Dynamo over the weekend, but they did get Cinesinho, an Italianbased Brazilian forward whom the Cosmos had been after since early March.

title: Workers Are Aided
description: Among the most active groups contributing to the United Fund of Greater New York's current appeal are union members. Labor leaders were among the executives who formed the fund's charter in 1968. Today, union officials such as William H. Bowe, Peter J. Brennan, Albert Shanker, Irving Stern and Harry Van Arsdale Jr. play active roles.

title: Redistricting Ax
description: The Republican leadership in the State Legislature teamed up with organization Democrats this year doom at least two of New York City's best Congressmen. By ruthless manipulatiOn of district lines, they contrived to create contests that would almost surely oblige outstanding reformers to run against one another or meekly submit to political extinction.

title: U.N. PARLEY TOLD OF SULFUR RAINS
description: STOCKHOLM, June 11 Sweden has presented to the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment case study of the effects in Sweden of acid rains generated largely by emissions from the industrial belt stretching from the Ruhr to the British Midlands.

title: Wilson Arrives in Rumania
description: VIENNA, June 11 (AP)Former British Prime Minister Harold Wilson arrived in Bucharest today on a visit to Rumania, the Rumanian press agency Agerpres reported. Mr. Wilson was welcomed by Rumanian officials headed by Manea Manescu, secretary of the Rumanian Communist party's Central Committee.

title: North Korea Emphasizes Benefits, Not Cash Salary
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea At the Mangyondae chickenraising factory on the outskirts of Pyongyang, the conversation turned to wages and salaries in this socialist economy.

title: 52 WAR PROTESTERS ARRESTED IN JERSEY
description: MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 11 (AP)Fiftytwo antiwar protesters were arrested today by about 30 Marines after failing to heed orders to end a blockade of railroad tracks leading into the Naval, Ammunition Depot at Earle, according to a spokesman for the military.

title: Books of The Times
description: As a writer of fiction, Joyce Carol Oates has a bold and individual imagination. The apparent ease with which she turns out novels and stories (as well as poetry) is astounding in the light of her consistent skill and literary art. Beneath their relentlessly violent surfaces, her novels grope for transcendent meanings and, at their most ambitious, seek to locate the central mode or attitude of our time.

title: Cambodian Road Still Cut
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 11 (Reuters)The road from Pnompenh to Cambodia's second biggest city, Kompong Chem, remained cut for the fifth day, the military command reported.

title: Beatrice Buys 2 Dairies
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Ontario, June 11 (Canadian Press)The Soo and Model dairies have been sold to the Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago, it was announced this weekend. The price was not disclosed.

title: Smith Leads a Memorial To 430 Rhodesian Miners
description: WANKIE, Rhodesia, June 11 (UPI)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith led a memorial service today for the 430 miners killed last week in a coalmine explosion here.

title: Michel Lettre Weds Lynn Muskin
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 11Miss Lynn Muskin and Michel A. Lettre 1972 graduates of CarnegieMellon University, were married here this afternoon. Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan J. Muskin, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Albert M. Lettre of Pikesville, Md.

title: DEATHS PASS 200 IN DAKOTA FLOOD; SEARCH GOES ON
description: RAPID CITY. S.D., June 11 Officials said today that more than 200 bodies had been recovered after the flash flood that crackled, crumbled and thundered through this city Friday night.

title: L.I. Home Is Torn Up by Agents Hunting $4Million Drug Funds
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., June 11 Federal agents who spent the weekend tearing up a man's home, yard and furniture here in a vain search for $4million in narcotics proceeds abandoned efforts today, and the owner, surveying the debris, declared he would sue the Government for repairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, in her letter published June 6, has made the claim that the ethical issues underlying abortion and birth control have been ignored by the Rockefeller Commission, The NeW York Times and others who have long urged that such matters should be, determined solely by the affected woman.

title: Notes Illuminate RooseveltChurchill Ties
description: The Franklin D. Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park, N. Y., has completed the declassification of the secret wartime correspondence between President Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, providing new insights into one of the great personal and political relationships that fashioned Western history.

title: New Congressional Hearings May Intensify LaborManagement Job Safety Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The Labor Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives are setting the stage for a renewal of the managementlabor struggle that attended passage of the Occupational Safety and Health Act in December, 1970.

title: Representatives Listed as Foes By Antiwar and Ecology Groups
description: WASHINGTON, June 11An antiwar group has named 12 hawkish Congressmen as its deadly dozen, while an ecology group has cited 12 House members as its dirty dozen, and both are organizing to defeat the Representatives on their lists.

title: Phonemen Convention Bound
description: A group of 22 New York Telephone Company technicians left yesterday for Miami Beach to help set up communications for the Democratic National Convention.

title: Russians Advised to Eat 4 Meals a Day
description: MOSCOW, June 11Russians are being told that four or five meals a day keep the doctor away.

title: White Police Chief in Michigan Accuses Judge of Racial Bias
description: FLINT, Mich., June 11Police Chief James W. Rutherford, who is white, has charged that a ruling by Flint District Judge Ollie B. Bivins Jr., who is black, constitutes discrimination against blacks.

title: Tories Think the Unthinkable: A WagePrice Freeze?
description: LONDON, June 11On the eve of the second anniversary of taking office with a promise to free the economy from socialist restraints, the Conservative Government of Britain is seriously considering imposition of a wages and prices freeze.

title: Rescousse Finishes First In $343,000 French Oaks
description: PARIS, June 11Baron de Rede's Rescousse won the 124th running today of the $343,000 Prix de Diane, the French Oaks the world's richest race for 3yearold fillies.

title: Ship Leaking Oil Is Seized
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 11 (UPI)The United States Coast Guard for the first time has invoked Federal law and taken over a vessel to prevent further oil leakage from the firerazed. Liberian tanker Oriental Express. Workmen used chemicals and an oil retention boom today to prevent the oil from reaching beaches. Thus far, their efforts have been successful. Capt. Edgar W. Darr said the Coast Guard exercised its authority under the 1970 Water Quality Control Act to take control of the ship.

title: Caso Tells of Plans for a $115Million Campus
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 11Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso announced plans today for an entirely new, $115million campus for. Nassau Community College, the largest community college in the State University system.

title: Spending and Taxes: a Dilemma for Democratic Platform Makers
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A major dilemma is building for the Democratic party as it prepares for its national convention in Miami Beach July 10how to satisfy the growing demand of its constituents for greatly expanded domestic expenditures while honoring the findings of its own fiscal experts that current programs promise to soak up new revenues as fast as they come in. Public hearings before the Platform Committee of the convention, being held this months in cities across the country, have encountered two concurrent and seemingly contradictory trends:

title: Trevino Practices In Hospital, Plans Open Title Defense
description: EL PASO, Tex., June 11 (UPI) Lee Trevino, the United States Open champion, heartened by new chest Xray reports on his illness, ordered putting rug brought to his hospital room today so that he could practice before going to Pebble Beach, Calif., to defend his title.

title: GLUT OF TEXTILES FOUND IN EUROPE
description: With the exception or sum fabrics as corduroy and denim, which are in short supply throughout the world, European textile markets are itV oversupply, and huge quantifi ties of polyester fibers are readily available, it was pointed) out here over the weekend.

title: Marcy Jaffe Married
description: Miss Marcy Jaffe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Jaffe of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Joel Howard Goot, sales manager of the Plaza, where Rabbi Louis Lederman performed the ceremony. The parents Of the bridegroom are Mr. and Mrs. Max Goot of Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Shipping Strike Clogs Japanese Ports
description: TOKYO, June 11 A twomonth strike of the Japanese seamen's union is having a serious effect on the country's shipping concerns and its export industry.

title: Gottlieb Duo Triumphs
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I, June 11Bill and Steve Gottlieb of Kings Point captured the Eastern fatherandson grass tennis championship for the third time today by downing Leo and John. Hayes of Cos Cob, Conn., 62, 46, 64, in the final at the Meadow Club. The Gottliebs have now won seven tournaments in a row.

title: Diane Dillenberg Wed
description: Miss Diane Lynn Dillenberg of New York and Capt. Fredric Ira Lederer, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Seymour G. Lederer of Oceanside, L. I., and the late Colonel Lederer, U.S.A.R., were married here yesterday evening at the Harmonic Club by Rabbi Bernard Zlotowitz. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs, D. Allan Dillenberg of Sarasota, Fla, Mrs. Lederer is an auditor for the New York Life Insurance Company. Her husband is a member of the Army Judge Advocate General Corps assigned to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

title: BRONX MAN IS SHOT IN ROBBERY ATTEMPT
description: A Bronx man, reportedly armed, was shot four times in the chest yesterday by two plainclothes men of a Transit Authority stakeout squad moments after he allegedly attempted to rob a change booth clerk at the IRT elevated station at 174th Street and Boston Road, the Brqnx.

title: Aftermath of the Flood: Tears and Debris
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., June 11 The damage caused by the weather's turnabout is most visible wherever the creeks and rivers swell out of their banks after the flash flood that swept this city Friday night.

title: McGill Bids Hofstra Class Keep Faith in American Way
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 11 Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, urged graduating students attending outdoor commencement activities at Hofstra University here today to keep faith in the American way of life and in the continuity of its institutions.

title: PHONE COMPANIES IN STATE LIFT NET
description: ALBANY, June 11 (AP)New York State's nine largest telephone companies showed an increase of almost 21 per cent in combined net income during the 12 months ended March 31, compared with the yearearlier period, the Public Service Commission reported today.

title: Kidnapped Venezuelan Is Reported Released
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 (Reuters)The Venezuelan millionaire Carlos Dominguez was freed tonight by kidnappers who grabbed him from his Cadillac limousine 10 days ago, a high police source said.

title: Sandler Handball Victor
description: Steve Sandler won the national Amateur Athletic Union onewall handball crown for the sixth time yesterday as he defeated Ruby Obert of the New York Athletic Club, 2021, 214, 215, in the final at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn. The 32yearold Sandler represented the host club.

title: Although Pay Is Low, It Helps Gauge Status
Battle for Datdo Tests Local Vietnamese Leadership
description: DATDO, South Vietnam. June 11Poking through the bombedout ruins of his home and store today, Cao Van Lien found only a photograph of President Nguyen Van Thieu left undamaged by the twoweek battle for this devasted district town.

title: Corey's Late Goal Earns Bethpage 76 Polo Victory
Young Women Challenging Their 2dClass Status in Judaism
description: A small but increasing number of young women, stimulated by the feminist movement, are questioning their role, and what they describe as their secondclass status, in Conservative and Orthodox Judaism.

title: U.S. Draws Morocco
description: MUNICH, Germany, June 11 (AP)The United States saecer team will meet Morocco on Aug 27 at Augsburg in an openinground Group I game of the 1972 Olympic games, officials announced today.

title: Pike Charges a CoverUp Over General's Dismissal
description: Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of New York, yesterday accused the Air Force of trying to sweep a scandal under the rug by withholding information from Congress on the dismissal three months ago of Gen. John D. Lavelle as commander of the Seventh Air Force in Southeast Asia.

title: Herbert D. Stone, Lawyer; ExHead of S. Klein Here
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., JUne 11Herbert D. Stone, a lawyer who was president of the Real Estate Review Board of Harrison, N. Y., died Friday in White Plains Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived on Westerleigh Road, with homes also in Bar Harbor, Me., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Chinese Doctors'
description: Four American doctors who went to China last fall said they had received a tacit acceptance of an invitation that they extended three weeks ago for a small group of physicians representing broad aspects of Chinese medicine to visit the United States.

title: Dance: City Ballet Flexes Its Muscles
description: If by chance, you can be pregnant with expectation, that was the odd mood of the New York City Ballet yesterday. It was giving its last two performances of general repertory before it races into its final sprint to the Stravinsky Festival, which opens on Sunday.

title: Mrs. Tananbaum Wed
description: Mrs. Rhoda Tananbaum, widow of Alfred Tananbaum, who was chairman of the board of Yonkers Raceway, was married here yesterday afternoon to Alexander Lerner, retired board chairman of Phoenix Clothes, a division of Genesco. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence Schwartz, rabbi of the White Plains Jewish Community Center, performed the ceremony In the State Suite of the Plaza. Mr. Lerner was a widower.

title: Food Stamps for Flood Area
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Residents of flooded areas of South Dakota are eligible for emergency rations of food stamps, the Agriculture Department said today. The stamps will be provided initially for 30 days but the state can request an extension.

title: AbzugRyan Debate: Issue Is Advocacy of Change
description: She referred to him as Bill: he called her my opponent. Representatives Bella S. Abzug and William F. Ryan, who are fighting each other in the June 20 primary for the Democratic nomination from the 20th Congressional District, faced each other across a conference table for an informal debate at The New York Times last Friday.

title: McGovern Gains Delegates in, 2 States; 3 Others Choose Uncommitted Slates
Hamilton Gets New Dean
description: CLINTON, N. Y., June 11 (AP)John W. Chandler, the president of Hamilton College, announced today the appointment of R. Gordon Bingham, assistant to the president of Union College in Schenectady since 1969, as Hamilton's new dean of students.

title: A BIT OF AMERICA IN OXFORDSHIRE
description: MIDDLETON STONEY, EnglandThe barmaid at the Jersey Arms said that no one thought of them as Yanks or foreigners, they were part of the community.

title: Beame Checking the Circumstances Under Which a City Official Received Double Pay
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame is investigating the circumstances under which the city's Director of Tourism, Charles G. Slepian, was certified on the payrolls of two city agencies at the same time.

title: The Lunts, Wed 50 Years, Get First National Artist Award
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 11Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, the American theater's most famous couple, celebrated their golden wedding anniversary tonighttwo weeks late a gala given in their honor by the American National Theatre and Academy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his letter published June 2, Thomas A. Parisi expresses concern about the selection of the 1,200 households in the Nielsen metered sample which produces network television ratings. He concludes, Shouldn't the public know something about the tribunal of 1,200 and how they are selected?

title: Margaret Griggs Wed to Banker
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 11  Miss Margaret Ruth Griggs was married here this afternoon to W. David Anderson, son of State Senator Warren M. Anderson of New York and Mrs. Anderson of Binghamton, N. Y. Mr. and Mrs. Osborne Edington Griggs of Northampton are the parents of the bride. whose father is president of the CocaCola Bottling Company here.

title: KISSINGER ASSURES JAPAN ON CHINESE
description: TOKYO, June 11  Henry A. Kissinger, chief adviser on national security to President Nixon, told Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda today that the United States would not undertake any major negotiations with China without consulting Japan.

title: POLISH CHIEF ASKS MORE U.S. TRADE
description: POZNAN, Poland, June 11Edward Gierek, the Polish party leader,,interrupted a visit to the American pavilion at the Poznan Trade Fair today to stress Poland's desire for increased trade with the United States.

title: Critics Look at Burlington Industries
description: The big one in the American textile industry, Burlington Industries, Inc., is run by two men of such widelydifferent temperaments and talents that there are some who believe that this is why the corporate giant is having some of its problems.

title: HENRY SCHWARTZ
description: Henry Schwartz, manager of Local 40 (Beltmakers) of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park. He was 65 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Lull in the Offensive
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, June 11 As the North Vietnamese offensive has seemed to lose momentum in recent weeks, there have inevitably been assertions that it was costly failure and even that South Vietnam can look with some confidence toward a secure future, Some such assessments come from senior, experienced and gifted military officers. But there are other opinions from men who also merit great respect.

title: Memory Is a Blank for Youth Walking Onto Key West Beach
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 11A curlyhaired blond youth walked out of the Atlantic Ocean onto a deserted beach in Key West one week ago and he does not remember his name, his family, where he is from or how he got here.

title: SOVIET SAID TO JAIL DANCER FOR 2D TIME
description: MOSCOW, June 11 (AP)  A former soloist with Leningrad's Kirov Ballet, who was dismissed after applying to emigrate to Israel last month, has been sentenced for the second time to a jail term on a charge of petty hooliganism, his friends reported today.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 11Several weeks ago in this space there was a report from the North Vietnamese village of Phucloc. It described the damage done when, as the villagers and North Vietnamese officials said, American planes bombed Phucloc at 2:20 on the morning of April 16. They said that of the population of 611, 63 were killed and 61 injured.

title: Wheat Crop Estimated
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  This year's winter wheat crop may total about 1,192,478,000 bushels, 2 per cent above last year's, the Agriculture Department said this weekend.

title: HOSPITAL WORKERS TO DEMONSTRATE
description: Hospital workers are to leave their jobs tomorrow and march to City Hall for a show of strength in a deadlocked contract dispute between the union and the League of Voluntary Hospitals.

title: Hulme Triumphs In CanAm Opener As Top Two Falter
Body of Missing Man Is Found In Wrecked Car in Connecticut
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., June 11 A 52yearold business executive reported missing by his family last Thursday was found dead in his car last night in heavily wooded area off the Merritt Parkway, where the vehicle had crashed into tree.

title: COMMON MARKET CUTS BEEF PRICES
description: PARIS, June 11The Common Market is experimenting with its tariff schedules to reduce the price of beef for the housewife.

title: JOSEPH ROSENZWEIG
description: Joseph Rosenzweig, a founder and president of Classy Leatner Goods Corporation of New York City and Middletown, N. Y., died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 1740 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: GERSHON SALHANICK
description: FALL RIVER, Mass., June 11 Gershon Salhanick, board chairman of the United States Textile Company of this city, died yesterday at his home, 591 Herman Street. He was 57 years old.

title: ITALIAN HERITAGE IS FESTIVAL THEME
description: I'm going to make Antonio Meucci famous, said John Napoleon La Corte, his trim white mustache and goatee moving up and down. As I made Giovanni da Verrazano famous, we are going to make Meucci famous.

title: Connecticut Loses to U.S.C. On Unearned Run, 54, in 11
description: OMAHA, June 11 (AP)Daryl Arenstein's 11thinning single chased in an unearned run tonight that gave Southern California a 54 victory over Connecticut in the National Collegiate baseball tournament tonight.

title: Red Cross Radio Link Opened to Flood Area
description: New Yorkers concerned about friends or relatives in and around Rapid City, S.D., may make use of an emergency radio network set up by the Queens chapter of the American Red Cross.

title: JOHN D. MONTGOMERY
description: John D. Montgomery, legal sales representative of PrenticeHall, Inc., book publishers, in the Wall Street area for the last 25 years, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home on Carman Road in Old Brookville, L. I. He was 59 years old.

title: At Met Pact Talks, No Raised Voices
description: The pace of contract negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera Association and the 14 unions representing its 800 performers and supportive employes is expected to quicken this week.

title: Advertising:
description: D'ArcyMacManus International has fought off a field of hungry competitors and is holding onto the Air Force recruiting account.

title: Harold N. Kaufman Dead; Carpet Concern Officer, 63
description: Harold N. Kaufman, executive vice president of the Kaufman Carpet Company, a major retail chain in the metropolitan area, died yesterday at his home, 210 Central Park South. He was 63 years old.

title: Opera: Rich Rigoletto
description: A strong blow in favor of allstar casts was delivered Saturday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera. The opera was Rigoletto, and it had Joan Sutherland as Gilda, Luciano Pavarotti as the Duke, Sherrill Milnes as Rigoletto and Ruggero Raimondi as Sparafucile (all, incidentally, singing their respective roles for the first time in New York). The heavens above the equator on a calm moonless night could not be starrier.

title: A Parade Here Honors Philippine Independence
description: The Philippine community of the East Coast staged yesterday what organizers said was its first New York City parade in honor of Philippine Independence Day.

title: Great Lakes Dredge Signs A Contract for $60Million
description: CHICAGO, June 12 (AP)The Great Lakes Dredge and Dock Company announced today a $60million contract with Argentina for a dredging project the company described as the largest ever undertaken.

title: New York Races
description: Emanuel Celler, 84 years old and in his 50th year in the House of Representatives, and Elizabeth Holtzman, 30, who is challenging Mr. Celler in the June 20 primary, have at least one point of agreement beyond their desire to represent Brooklyn's 16th District. They both say Mr. Celler's record is the central issue.

title: NOSTALGIA INFUSES BOWDEN DANCE SOLO
description: Sally Bowden's untitled and touching solo at Tears Realty Company Sunday evening might easily have been titled lonelyheart's lament or the wallflower walk. She appeared in a dowdy black print dress and wedgie shoes moving sympathetically and longingly to a baker's dozen of 1930's and 1940's songs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BOSTON, June 12 (UPI)Mount Washington Hotel in New Hampshire's White Mountains will conduct the $25,000 Bretton Woods International Tennis tournament July 5 to 9, Rod Laver said today.

title: Harold Prince Honored
description: Harold Prince received the Actors Fund of America Medal yesterday in recognition of his producing Fiddler on the Roof. The musical will become Broadway's longestrunning show on Saturday with 3,225 performances,

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF BY 0.1% LAST WEEK
Notes on People
description: Emperor Hirohito of Japan received an invitation to the United States from President Nixon through his envoy, Henry A, Kissinger. Mr. Kissinger, ending a threeday visit to Tokyo, did not say when the visit would be, but Japanese officials indicated it would take place after the Presidential election here.

title: Folger Increases Coffee Price; Dow Sets Rise for Chemicals
description: Prices of coffee and chemicals rose yesterday.

title: Oral Roberts College Has Grown in 7 Years
description: TULSA, Okla., June 12The president is a former tent evangelist and faith healer who never finished college. Faculty members are picked for their religious beliefs as well as their academic credentials. The central structure on campus is not a library but a shiny 200foot space needle known as the Prayer Tower,

title: Impact of Connally Trip Seems Limited
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 12The travels of John B. Connally as President Nixon's special envoy to major developing countries have produced exchanges that high officials call useful but they have had almost no public impact in Latin America.

title: EXL.I. PARTY AIDE TELLS OF A BRIBE
description: The former Republican leader of Babylon, L. I., testified yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn that State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst offered him $50,000 in 1968 in exchange for the party's nomination to the bench.

title: Vegetable Plants Given Out
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI) Half a million vegetable plants were distributed free in downtown Washington today by a group seeking to reintroduce the victory garden as a means of fighting inflation. The National Committee to Curb Inflation, which said it was originally formed more than 15 years ago, has been revitalized and is attempting to persuade people to grow their own vegetables, said Gale Johns, a spokesman for the group.

title: Many Fail Draft Test
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)Only 35 of every 100 draftees passed preinduction examinations this, year in Massachusetts, the state's Selective Service Director, Victor C. Bynoe, said yesterday.

title: New OTB Parlor Opens Tomorrow At Penn Station
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation will open a new office in Penn Station tomorrow, replacing two temporary locations that have served betting commuters for more than year.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS SHOW SHARP RISE
I.O.S. Share Auction Brings Penny Apiece
description: GENEVA, June 12 (AP)A total of 18,200 preferred shares of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., parent company of the oncegiant I.O.S. were auctioned here last Friday for $182, or one cent a share.

title: INTEREST CUT IS SET BY CANADIAN BANKS
Wartime RooseveltChurchill Messages
description: Cablegram by Roosevelt to Churchill, Sept. 11, 1939: It is because you and I occupied similar positions in the World War that I want you to know how glad I am that you are back again in the Admiralty. Your problems are, I realize, complicated by new factors but the essential is not very different. What I want you to know is that I shall at all times welcome it if you will keep me in touch personally with anything you want me to know about. You can always send sealed letters through your pouch or my pouch.

title: BadilloRamos Contest Centers On Who Is More Puerto Rican
description: After a decade of solitary eminence as the city's only prominent Puerto Rican politician, Representative Herman Badillo is being challenged for his seat in the 21st Congressional district in the Bronx on the ground that he is not Puerto Rican enough.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
Mitchell, Penn State Back, Signs Multiyear Colts'
description: BALTIMORE, June 12 (AP)Lydell Mitchell, the allAmerica running back from Penn State, was signed today by the Baltimore Colts.

title: Peace Investment
description: A State Department order to United States missions to the United Nations and affiliated agencies to seek hold the line on spending in the world organization for the next several years runs contrary to the recommendations of a Presidential Commission and to the interest of the United States in developing more effective international institutions.

title: 25 Per Cent of Reform Rabbis Back Union With Conservatives
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 12  Nearly 25 per cent of the nation's Reform rabbis favor uniting with their fellowrabbis in the Conservative branch of American Judaism, according to a study released today. And, the study said, another 43 per cent lean strongly toward the more traditional Judaism of the Conservative movement, the study said.a past president of the Central Conference, said in an interview that he could foresee wholehearted agreement on social issues, education and all practical matters, but not on theology. He gave merger no chance at all.

title: Court to Rule on Defense Pleas for Knapp Witness
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh said yesterday that be would decide by tomorrow morning a number of defense requests in the murder trial of William R. Phillips, a suspended patrolman  including a request to introduce into evidence a lie detector test purporting to show Mr. Phillips's innocence.

title: Connally Cast a Ballot In Democratic Primary
Journalism Course Opens
description: An 11week program to train minority group members for careers as reporters for television, radio and newspapers opened for the fifth summer yesterday at Columbia University.

title: Saul Alinsky, 63, Poverty Fighter And Social Organizer, Is Dead
description: CARMEL, Calif., June 12 (UPI)Saul Alinsky, the poverty fighter and social organizer, died of a heart attack today while walking near his small home here. He was 63 years old.

title: A BridgeTurnpike Link To Be Opened in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 12 (AP)The State Transportation Department announced today that a section of Route 95 linking the George Washingon Bridge and the New Jersey Turnpike would be opened to traffic Thursday.

title: Morgan Stanley to Move
description: Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., announced plans yesterday to move its offices uptown from 140 Broadway, effective early next year. The investment banker's new quarters will be five floors at 1251 Avenue of the Americas between 49th and 50th Streets.

title: Survivors of Dakota Flood Vow to Get on With It
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 12The flood waters were still trickling out of Mrs. George Dewey's mobile home at 4 A.M. Saturday when she reached for a dry rag and the furniture polish.

title: To Sighs of Relief, The Chemise Makes Triumphant Return
description: The chemise, which occupied fashion's center stage during most of the nineteensixties, was shoved ingloriously aside towards the end of the decade. Designers said they were tired of it, that there wasn't much they could do to make it look new.

title: Papers to Be Published By the Princeton Press
description: The Princeton University Press announced yesterday that it would publish the complete RooseveltChurchill wartime correspondence in the fall of 1973.

title: McClellan Faces a Battle In Arkansas Runoff Today
She Says It's the Men Who Are Enslaved
description: LONDONEsther Viler was awakened in her hotel room here the other day by an emphatic knock on the door. She opened it to find a group of hatted English matrons in their fifties who quietly but earnestly asked her to leave the country.

title: RAIL APPEAL LOST IN SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Holders of New Haven Railroad bonds lost an appeal in the Supreme Court today in a dispute over the value of two lines turned over by the bankrupt Penn Central to New York and Connecticut transportation authorities.

title: WAGEPRICE UNIT BLOCKS PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The Cost of Living Council suspended temporarily today a District of Columbia order raising the minimum wage for hotel and restaurant employes, asserting that the increase would be unfair to small companies not subject to controls and might drive them out of business.

title: A Local Agitator
description: In an age when the most conspicuous form of radicalism was the proclamation of assorted dogmatic idealisms, Saul David Alinsky represented an older tradition going back to Samuel Adamsthe agitator who arouses a neighborhood or a nation to go after specific objectives.

title: No Signal From Hanol
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 The State Department said today that no signal of any kind had been received from Hanoi to suggest that North Vietnam was ready to resume the Paris talks on what the United States considered serious and constructive basis.

title: Lindsay Asks Ban on New Electric Heating in City
description: Mayor Lindsay urged the State Public Service Commission yesterday to restrain Consolidated Edison from supplying electricity for heating new buildings under construction or about to be constructed.

title: U.S. and Canada Plan Talks On Volume of Midwest Exports
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The growing volume of Middle Western exports moving abroad through Canadian ports will be the subject of highlevel discussions with the Canadian authorities, the chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission said here today.

title: Honduras Treaty Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters)The United States Senate voted today to ratify a treaty recognizing Honduras's sovereignty over the Swan Islands. The 740 vote came without debate. The treaty, signed No vember 22, 1971, provides for cooperative AmericanHonduran operation of a weather station and an air radio navigation beacon on the Swan Islands, rocky keys in the Caribbean 98 miles off the coast of Honduras. cooperative AmericanHonduran operation of a weather station and an air radio navigation beacon on the Swan Islands, rocky keys in the Caribbean 98 miles off the coast of Honduras.

title: Rehearsal of Hamlet Duel Livens Central Park
description: The heavy breathing of perspiring actors and the clash of steel swords broke the country morning quiet of Central Park's Delacorte Theater yesterday, where rehearsals for the free New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Hamlet were just getting under way.

title: Londonderry Guildhall Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 12The Guildhall in Londonderry, a building that serves as a city hall, was severely damaged today by bombs that had been carried into the building in plastic garbage pails by six armed men.

title: Arthur Daley
description: An attempt to postpone the inevitable for another four years began yesterday at the Air Force Academy Colorado. Henry Iba, the coaching magician from Oklahoma State, assembled there some threescore candidates for the basketball squad that will represent the United States in the Olympic Games at Munich in the late summer. It is an assignment that keeps building up, much like an unattended pressure cooker. Eventually the lid will have to blow off. But when? That's what provides extra suspense factor for each set of Olympics. Not only has the United States won every Olympic basketball tournament, but it also has won every game in every tournament. Hence the record in this greatest of international showcases represents total embarrassment of riches, 55 victories and no defeats.

title: Advertising:
description: At the moment the salesmen at newspapers and magazines are pretty much in the dark about lightlight whisky, that is.

title: High Court Decides Clubs Can Reject Negro Guests
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The Supreme Court held 6 to 3 today that it is constitutional for states to grant liquor licenses to private clubs that practice racial discrimination.

title: Secret Sessions Criticized
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)Common Cause, the citizens lobby, criticized the Massachusetts legislature today for conducting much of its business in secret. In a brochure passed out at the State House, Common Cause listed Massachusetts as one of 13 states where much of the business of government was done behind closed doors.

title: Judge to Consider Bid to Review I.T.T. Merger
description: A Federal judge in Hartford said yesterday he would consider a move to reexamine the controversial merger in 1970 of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

title: 2 RELIEF GROUPS AID THE FLOOD VICTIMS
description: Two voluntary relief organizations announced yesterday measures to aid the victims'of Friday night's flood in Rapid City, S.D.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The National Wildlife Federation, one of the leaders in the effort to make it illegal to hunt waterfowl with other than nontoxic, softiron shot, has registered strong disapproval of the Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife's proposal to conduct what the federation calls a series of useless field tests while several million more waterfowl died of lead poisoning.

title: Market Place: Judging Stocks Of Franchisers
description: It wasn't so long agoit seems only yesterday if you're one of those who got burned  that franchise stocks were much in the news.

title: PYRAMID PROMOTER AMONG 30 INDICTED
description: FLINT, Mich., June 12 (UPI) A. Genesee County grand jury has indicted 30 persons, including Glenn W. Turner, a Florida promoter, on charges of fraud in a pyramid scheme called Dare to Be Great.

title: Teachers Urged to Limit Bargaining
description: The United Parents Associations declared yesterday that matters of school security and educational policy should not be part of the contract negotiations between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers.

title: WALDHEIM REPORTS EFFORT ON HIJACKING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12  Secretary General Waldheim has informed the International Federation of Airline Pilot Associations that its request for convening of the Security Council to deal with air, craft hijacking was being given the most serious attention.

title: 5,000 Sifting Debris of Flood As Hunt for Bodies Intensifies
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 12An army of 5,000 National Guardsmen, volunteers and city employes intensified today the search for bodies of victims of the flood that slashed. through this city on the edge of the Black Hills last Friday.

title: CITY GETS GRANTS TO COMBAT CRIME
description: Fourteen projects to improve the criminaljustice system in the city have received $4,114,421 in grants from the State Crime Control Planning Board, Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday.

title: British Rail Dispute Ends
description: LONDON, June 12A ninemonth pay dispute that will result in wage increases equivalent to 13.5 per cent for British railwaymen ended tonight.

title: 3 In Westchester Card 74's to Tie For Amateur Lead
Hospital Work Stoppage Threatened in City Today
description: Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union was enjoined by a State Supreme Court justice yesterday from carrying out a work stoppage scheduled for today at 33 voluntary and 10 municipal hospitals. Leon J. Davis, president of the union said, however, that the demonstration is still on.

title: DistillersSeagrams Lifts Profit by 10% in Quarter
Canadian Exports Up in May
description: OTTAWA, June 12 (Canadian Press)Canada's export shipments to all countries last month rose 21.6 per cent to $1.80billion from $1.56billion in May, 1971. This brought the total of exports for the first five months of 1972 to $7.78billion, up 10.5 per cent from $7.05billion in the comparable period a year ago.

title: London: Jolly Good journey's End
description: LONDONThe evening of Jan. 21, 1929, remains landmark in British theatrical history. Journey's End, World War I drama by an unknown 32yearold insurance clerk, R. C. Sherriff, opened at the old Savoy Theater to 19 curtain calls, rapturous reviews and instant stardom for Laurence Olivier. I was just telling people what it was like, said Mr. Sherriff, who watched most of his brother officers killed in 1916 at Vimy Ridge and the Ypres Salicnt.

title: Peace as the Issue
description: WASHINGTONMore than a year ago, President Nixon told Republicans that the Vietnam war would not be an issue for Democrats in the 1972 campaign. The broad and highly effective progress of Vietnamization and the successful pace of United States troop withdrawals have given every indication of bearing out the President's appraisal. However, after the massive invasion of South Vietnam by twelve North Vietnamese divisions and the actions taken to repel that invasion, some have questioned whether the President's prediction requires reassessment. It does not.

title: Gromyko Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, June 12 (AP)Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, arrived here today for consultations with French Government officials, as part of the regular series of consultations and visits under terms of a treaty between the two Governments.

title: SHERIFF REMOVES 16 L I. JAIL GUARDS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 12The Nassau County sheriff, Michael P. Seniuk, formally suspended today 16 of 24 county jail guards indicted last week after a twoyear investigation, but allowed eight who were charged with misdemeanors to remain on duty.

title: QUARTER SALES RISE AT MANUFACTURERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters)Sales of manufacturing corporations rose slightly in the first quarter of 1972 to $197.63billion from $196.5billion in the last quarter of 1971, the Federal Trade Commission reported to day.

title: Dollar Inconvertibility Is Scored
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 12The Bank for International Settlements warned today that permanent dollar inconvertibility could split the world into restrictive monetary blocs. The bank, a body that central bankers from both East and West use as a forum and as an intergovernment central bank, said dollar convertibility was desirable because it would subject the United States to balanceofpayments discipline.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc. yesterday announced plans to register a secondary offering of its common stock sometime later this year. According to the announcement, the offering would not exceed two million shares. It would, the announcement added, consist of common stock belonging to investors who were shareholders in the stock brokerage firm before it went public last year. The firm's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, was down  at 36 at the close of trading yesterday.

title: JUDGES RESERVE DECISION ON I.O.S
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals reserved decision here today on whether an American executive could refuse to testify before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the ground that anything he said might subject him to criminal prosecution under Swiss secrecy. law.

title: Firehouse Sickbay
description: Sixteen fire companies were out of service for periods ranging from thirty minutes to threeandahalf hours yesterday as a result of the unconscionable sickout initiated by unionized fire officers to force the city to surrender to their parity pay demand. With the Uniformed Fire Officers Association warning that the artificially inflated number of firemen seeking medical care after fighting fires will go still higher, it is plain that the city's safety requires prompt injunctive action.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: OIL RESEARCH GROUP ISSUES A TAX STUDY
description: The oil industry's tax burden is above the average for American industry in general, according to a study released yesterday by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, Inc.

title: TopSeeded Gonzales, 44, Beats Japanese, 22, in British Tennis
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 12 (AP)  Pancho Gonzales, seeded No. 1 here despite his 44 years, whipped Ken Hirai of Japan, 75, 97, In the first round of the Kent tennis tournament today and then laughed at the possibility he would be seeded for the Wimbledon tournament.

title: 40,000 See Corinthias Win
description: ATHENS, June 12 (UPI)Corinthians of Brazil enchanted 40,000 Greek soccer fans by beating Olympiakos of Piraeus, 20, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: Auction of Multimedia Rarities Raises Funds for Peace Work
description: A silent auction throng, fitted comfortably into the small Van Darn Theater at 15 Van Dam Street, passed judgment last nigbt on the pecuniary merits of rarities, and the process helped swell a fund devoted to the pursuit of peaceful solutions to explosive world problems.

title: Buchanan, Duran Exchange Jabs
description: On the movie screen at Les Champs Restaurant yesterday, Roberto Duran was about to knock out Hiroshi Kobayashi of Japan but, even though he never had seen the Panamanian challenger in ring, Ken Buchanan was disinterested. Every so often, the world lightweight champion looked away to butter breadstick.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In marked contrast to the bombing in Teheran and the stoning in Caracas and California, Richard Nixon and the United States of America received, for the second time, a hero's welcome in Poland.

title: Big Board Reports 13 Firms Are Selling Life Insurance
description: About 1,350 registered representatives in 13 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have been licensed to sell life insurance in the two months since such sales have been permitted.

title: Gaffney Jubilant
description: HARTFORD, June 12The Supreme Court decision left the state's election officials confused and many of its politicians in dismay. Some Republicans, especially the leaders, were delighted, however.

title: POTATO FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: The Maine potato futures market, dormant since the nearby May contract went off the market some time ago, came to life yesterday, with prices rising in 817 trades on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Rising Number of Sick Calls by City's Fire Fighters and Officers Forces 16 Companies Out of Service
description: The number of fire fighters and fire officers reporting sick or injured after fires increased sharply yesterday, forcing 16 companies out of service for periods ranging from a half hour to three and a half hours.

title: Merchant Marine Officer Class Finds a Brighter Job Outlook
description: The employment picture for the 211member class of 1972 at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, N. Y., is brighter than it was for the class of 1971.

title: DR. SAMUEL J. NEUMAN
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 12Dr. Samuel J. Neuman, a dentist here and in New York and first violinist in the White Plains Symphony Orchestra for 35 years, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: GENERALTESTIFIES HE MADE 20 RAIDS WITHOUT ORDERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 John D. Lavelle acknowledged today that he was dismissed in March as commander Air Force units in Southeast after ordering his planes make in the neighborhood 20 unauthorized raids on military targets in North Vietnam and reporting them as protectivereaction missions.

title: Ulster Protestants Get British Pledge
description: LONDON, June 12William Whitelaw, Northern Ireland's British administrator, assured Ulster's Protestant majority tonight that the Government in London would not betray them.

title: MEMPHIS LIKELY TO STAY IN A.B.A,
description: The Memphis Pros franchise may be saved, but little hope was held out for the Pittsburgh Condors and the Floridians as the fiveyear old American Basketball Association held the first of two days of meetings yesterday at the Essex House.

title: Revenue and Profit Marks Are Set by Citizens Utilities
description: The Citizens Utilities Company of Stamford, Conn., achieved record revenues and (profits in the first quarter of this year, Richard L. Rosenthal, chairman and chief executive, officer, said yesterday at the, annual meeting in Stamford.

title: Antiwar Canoes Withdrawn
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N. J. June 12 (AP)Antiwar activists ended their attempt to block the seaward approach to the Earle Naval Ammunition Depot here today, but promised to return next weekend. The demonstrators manned 13 canoes that stayed just outside a security channel about 750 yards off the piers used by the Navy to load munitions. Five Coast Guard vessels prevented the canoes from going into the area.

title: OBSERVER
description: If Senator McGovern becomes the Democratic candidate for President, the word radical is in for some heavy use. It is already limp with fatigue from the treatment given it by newspapermen, who roll it out with every mention of the Senator's program, and the Republicans haven't even begun to warm up on it yet.

title: PreOlympic Fireworks
description: At 11:30 A.M. last Friday, one of America's top high jumpers, Gene White, left the Centre County Jail in Bellefonte, Pa., on a onemonth trip that he hopes will lead to an Olympic gold medal in track and field.

title: U.S. Reduces Psychological War Effort
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, June 12American psychologicalwarfare efforts in Vietnam, centralized for the last seven years in a single large agency here, are being rapidly closed out or dispersed, mainly to duce public reminders of United States role in the war. The Joint United States Public Affairs Office has vacated the large building near Saigon's City Hall that has been a downtown symbol of the American presence since the midnineteenfities.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal Government has made $63million available to modernize aging, citybuilt publichousing projects, S. William Green, regional director of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced yesterday.

title: Richmond Soiree At Carnegie Stars Rose and Dichter
description: Every now and then. Frederick W. Richmond decides to give a musical soire, and inasmuch as Mt'. Richmond is a trustee of Carnegie Hall he naturally favors that prestigious location. On Sunday night, he sponsored a concert as a benefit for 14 Brooklyn charitable, religious and civic organizations, and the performing artists were definitely of Carnegie Hall caliber: Leonard Rose and Misha Dichter.

title: 10% of 800 Relief Recipients Called by City for Recertification Fail to Show Up
description: Of the first approximately 800 welfare cases called In by the city for facetoface recertifications, 10 per cent have failed to show up and have been served notices their aid would be cut off unless they appealed and explained why they had not kept their appointments.

title: Roosevelt and Churchill: United but Divided
description: On March 4, 1944, Prime Minister Winston Churchill cabled President Franklin D. Roosevelt:

title: Unit Pricing Grows Fast, But Use by Buyers Lags
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 Unit pricing, designed to help shoppers compare the cost of different sizes and brands of products in supermarkets, is rapidly becoming an established part of the country's merchandising system. But its popularity with the average shopper is falling below expectations.

title: 3FOR2 STOCK SPLIT PROPOSED AT H.F.C.
description: The directors of the Household Finance Corporation proposed yesterday a 3for2 split of the common stock. They also voted to increase the cash dividend on the common stock and to call for redemption of all of the $4.40 cumulative convertible voting preferred stock.

title: Sheriff in Florida Charged in Slaying Of Black Prisoner
description: TAVARES, Fla., June 12 (AP)  The sheriff of the largely rural Lake County was arrested today and charged with kicking a black prisoner to death in a jailhouse attack.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 12A survey of reliable and experienced military sources in Vietnam by Charles Mohr of The New York Times convinced him that only the enormous use of American air power... had prevented a South Vietnamese collapse early in April.

title: Isaksson Beats Nordwig With a Pole Vault of 183
description: HELSINGBORG, Sweden, June 12 (UPI)Kjell Isaksson, Sweden's world polevault recordholder beat the East German European champion, Wolfgang Nordwig, tonight for the second time in his career.

title: BROADWAY CRIME TOPIC OF DEBATE
description: Can Broadway be made safer and more attractive for theatergoers?

title: Advertising:
description: Hire him, He's got great legs says the headline of an ad that is not scehduled for Sports Illustrated.

title: Enough of Mr. Rooney
description: For Democrats of the Fourteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn there is a real choice in this year's primary. If they want the continued services of a conservative oldline regulara man who has for years damaged the country's prestige abroad by approaching all State Department appropriations bills with a butcher's cleaverthey have only to vote again for Representative John J. Rooney. If they want an imaginative Reform Democrat, an articulate exponent of the new politics, their man is former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, the national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action,

title: TV: Added Exposure for Public Access on Cable
description: Few areas of communications are less understood, or even generally less known, than that of public access on cable television. One evening last week, the subject was accorded a rare and helpful hour and a half of its own in the electronic media. Produced by John Reilly, who with Rudi Stern is a codirector of Global Village, the program was shown on Sterling Manhattan's public channels and simultaneously broadcast on WBAIFM.

title: HIGH COURT BARS ANY JAIL SENTENCE WITHOUT COOUNSEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The Supreme Court ruled today that no poor person may be jailed for a petty offense unless he has been furnished free legal counsel or has waived his right to a lawyer.

title: View Over the Jordan
description: The paradox of Israel today is that While Israelis are surely more selfsatisfied and relaxed than probably at any other time in their 25year history, there is neither peace nor the prospect of peace as the dangerous frustrations of the surrounding Arab world grow steadily deeper.

title: BeerMaking Is Only One of Schlitz Arts
description: It is becoming safe and respectable, if not yet widely fashionable, for business to support the arts nationally and locally. The steady increase in Government funding on Federal and state levels has helped to develop a climate favoring such support, and so has the missionary work of the Business Committee for the Arts, which draws its membership from the chief executives of many of America's leading corporations.

title: A BROOKLYN CAVEIN IMPERILS FIREMEN
description: A dozen Brooklyn firemen narrowly escaped serious injury or death early yesterday when the walls of a threestory furniture store and warehouse in the Williamsburg section collapsed during a threealarm fire.

title: U.S. Vietnam Forces Cut 1,800, to 61,900
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12 (AP)  The United States command announced today that American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 1,800 men last week, to 61,900.

title: Ruggiero Testifies $2,500 Was a Fee to Help Carey
