description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 13For a driver suffering through a 37race losing streak, Real (Coon) Cormier went into tonight's harnessracing program at Roosevelt Raceway with a refreshing outlook.

title: W. WENDELL REUSS
description: ATLANTIS, Fla., June 13W. Wendell Reuss, a retired railroad analyst with W. E. Hutton & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here today at his home. He was 69 years old.

title: Jewish Seminary Honors 2
description: Two New York business and Jewish community leaders were honored yesterday before 1,000 guests at a $150aplate dinner at the Aemricana Hotel. The two, Meshulum Riklis, chairman and president of the Rapid American Corporation, and Arthur G Cohen, president of the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, received the Eternal Light Medal of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: Economic Analysis;
description: TOKYO, June 11A Japanese proverb goes, Men and autumn sky are alike. It means that neither is to be trusted. Many conversations here with Japanese businessmen, journalists, Government officials, and academics have left this visitor convinced that trust in American friend ship with Japan has been damaged too seriously to be restored by the visit of Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's envoy, however hard he worked to convey sympathy for Japanese economic and security concernsor even by Mr. Nixon's invitation to the Emperor to visit the United States.

title: House Panel Backs a Rise In Aid to Justices Widows
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)The annual pension for the widows of six Supreme Court Justices would be increased from $5,000 to $10,000 under a bill approved today by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: DR. ALBERT T. YORK JR.
description: Dr. Albert T. York Jr., an ophthalmologist, died early yesterday in a onecar accident near Washington, where he was driving from New York. He was 34 years old and lived at 210 East 75th Street.

title: Airman Says Raid Reports Were Falsified on Orders
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The sergeant whose letter led to the dismissal of the top Air Force general in Vietnam charged that members of an American photoreconnaissance team had been ordered to falsify classified documents concerning air strikes over North Vietnam.

title: Texts of Agreed Interpretations and Unilateral Statements With Arms Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Following as issued today by the White House, are the texts of agreed interpretations between the United States and the Soviet Union on the strategic arms limitation agreement, as well as unilateral statements by the two sides. The arms accords discussed in these documents were printed in The New York Times on May 27.

title: CONSUMER AGENCY BACKED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Legislation to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend consumer interests won the unanimous approval of a Senate subcommittee today.

title: Pinkerton Names President
description: Pinkerton's, Inc:, has named Jerome V. O'Grady as president and chief executive officer effective July 1. He succeeds Edward J. Bednarz, who continues as chairman of the board. Mr. O'Grady is vice president and a member of the board.

title: Dividend Reinvestment Plan
description: The Union Camp Corporation said yesterday that it would begin a program to allow its shareholders to reinvest dividends in additional stock.

title: Hospital Chaos Ahead
description: The decision of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union to defy a court order and call 20,000 workers away from their duties for four hours yesterday was clearly intended as a warning that the city's voluntary hospitals and many of the principal municipal hospitals as wellface the chaos of a fullfledged strike unless the union gets what it wants in higher pay by the end of this month.

title: Major Provisions of Senate Bill on Social Security and Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, June 13Following are the major provisions of a $17.6Killion Social Security and welfare reform bill tentatively approved today by the Senate Finance Committee:

title: Meskill, Tired of Boola, Selects a State Song
description: HARTFORD, June 13 (UPI) Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut, signed an executive order today designating The Hills of My Connecticut as the state's official song. He said he was tired of being introduced at affairs of state to the tune of Boola, Boola, the Yale fight song.

title: Miss Anne Valiquet Gram Bride Of Edward Townsend Shean Jr.
description: Miss Anne Valiquet Gram was married here yesterday evening to Edward Townsend Shean Jr. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: O'Grady Heads Pinkerton's
description: Jerome V. (Jerry) O'Grady has heel; elected president of Pinkerton's Inc., it was announced yesterday by E. J. Bednarz, retiring president and current chairman of the board. Pinkerton's is the world's oldest and largest investigative and security organization, and numbers the New York Racing Association among its clients.

title: Cairo Says It Shot Down 2
description: CAIRO, June 13An Egyptian military spokesman said that eight Egyptian planes intercepted 16 Israeli fighters today and shot down two of them near Ras el Barr. a sandspit about 30 miles northwest of Port Said. He accused Israel of a premeditated violation of Egyptian air space.

title: STATE IS SUED ON AID TO PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: A group of civic organizations, already successful in a series of attacks on state aid to private schools, filed a new suit yesterday in reaction to a state law signed last Thursday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Farmers Pleased in Corn Belt, And That Should Please G.O.P.
description: DALLAS CENTER, IowaAn optimist in the Midwest's corn belt is a timid creature, rarely seen or heard.

title: MITCHELL'S PAY SET AT $60,000 A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell is earning $60,000 a year as director of President Nixon's reelection effort, the campaign committee says.

title: Women's, Children's Wear Seen Rising by 4% in 72
description: Although production has been less than expected in the year so far, output of women's and children's wear during 1972 is expected to exceed the 1971 level by about 4 per cent, the leaders of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union were told yesterday at a meeting of the general executive board in Unity House, Pa.

title: Ship Unions and Owners Press Talks as Contracts Near End
description: The pace of labor negotiations designed to reach new agreements with deck, engineer and radio officers before the deadline at 12:01 A.M. Friday quickened yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 22 editorial Not By Bread Alone reflects a philosophy of education which is basically humanistic. Few would disagree with your position that the goals of education should encompass cultural and ethical as well as pragmatic values. However, the new emphasis given to career education by United States Commissioner Sidney P. Marland Jr. does not restrict academic studies in favor of vocational training.

title: Net Up Sharply at J. Ray McDermott
Nassau Coliseum Names Goodman as Boxing Chief
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., June 13 The Nassau Coliseum today filled a post essential to the workings of a bigtime arena when Murray Goodman, a longtime figure in boxing, was named the new building's boxing promoter.

title: Common Market Complains
description: BRUSSELS, June 13 (Reuters) The Common Market today published its position in its trade disputes with the United States, criticizing in particular the way America's trading partners are being asked to assume responsibility for eliminating the United States balanceofpayments deficit.

title: Wife Wins Latest Round In Battle Over Old Cars
description: MCLEAN, Va., June 13 (UPI) To Robert C. Reynolds, his 128 Studebakers, aged 8 to 45 years, represent a priceless collection. To his neighborsand his wifethey represented a junk yard eyesore.

description: The Queen Elizabeth 2 will dock here tomorrow morning after a transAtlantic trip from Southampton and Cherbourg, and Federal authorities said the bomb hoax involving the liner several weeks ago was still under investigation.

title: A dvertising:
description: Three years ago, Richard M. Earle, a vice president and creative supervisor at Grey, was put in charge of the creation of an antidrug abuse campaign for the National Institute of Mental Health. Last week, he was elected president of the National Coordinating Council on Drug Education, a fouryearold consortium of 130 national organizations interested in the fight.

Goodman, the radio station's general manager, were formal ly cleared yesterday of contempt of court charges stemming from Mr. Goodman's refusal to make available to the Manhattan District Attorney's office tape recordings of interviews made during the 1970 riots at the Manhattan Men's House of Detention.

description: STOCKHOLM, June 13Apart from shipments relating to the Vietnam war, the Soviet Union has become the largest supplier of weapons to third world countries, according to a comprehensive analysis of world armaments issued here today.

title: GEORGE C. SHATTUCK OF HARVARD IS DEAD
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 13Dr. George C. Shattuck, professor emeritus at the Harvard School of Public Health and an authority on tropical medicine, died yesterday at his home here. He was 93 years old.

title: F.B.I. Overseer Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) Senators Fred R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Lee Metcalf, Democrat of Montana, introduced a resolution today to establish a special Congrestional committee to oversee activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 13The system is totally dependent on people being honest, a colonel at the military headquarters here said today in reaction to Gen. John D. Lavelle's testimony in Washington that he ordered unauthorized strikes against North Vietnam last winter. No special measures have been taken, according to command spokesmen here, to prevent a recurrence of what General Lavelle said he did about 20 times between November and March.

title: Unconscious Sent to Stud
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 14 (AP)Unconscious, winner of 10 races and $373,300 in his injuryplagued career, suffered! pulled suspensories in his left, front ankle in a Nvorkout and will he retired at stud, his trainer, john Canty. said today.

title: Notes on People
description: After almost two weeks as the boy without a name and as John Doe, amnesia victim, the teenaged youth who swain ashore in Key West. Fla., was identified as Kim Basil Kadas, 16 years old, of East Chicago, Ind.

title: Cambodians Report Clash
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 14 (UPI)The Cambodian military command reported two Cambodians killed and 17 wounded in a sharp clash today with Communist forces 38 miles southeast of Pnompenh. The fighting occurred near Preyveng, a provincial capital that has been surrounded since soon after the start of the North Vietnamese offensive at the end of March. It was the first sizable battle in the area in more than a month.

title: 6 Black Colleges Aided By Science Foundation
description: The National Science Foundation has made awards totaling almost $2,200,000 to six predominantly black colleges and universities for the improvement of their undergraduate science education program.

title: Crippler of Young Adults
description: The National Multiple Sclerosis Society has been making progress in its research efforts against multiple sclerosis, a disabling disease of the central nervous system that usually strikes be tween the ages of 20 and 40. The cause, prevention and cure of the disease remain unknown, but there is hope that societysponsored research will conquer the great crippler of young adults.

title: Bank Expansion Upstate Is Scrutinized
description: Harry W. Albright Jr., the newly appointed State Superintendent of Banks, is determined to hold expansion upstate by the four largest retail banking concerns in New York City to a measured pace.

title: Dollars Return to U.S.
description: PARIS, June 14Western financial experts established today that money has been flowing back to the United States over the last three months and that this has been the fundamental reason for relative calm in the foreignexchange markets despite gyrations in the price of gold.

title: Democrats Shun Lindsay Endorsements in Primary
description: Ten months after his conversion to the Democratic party and two months after his Presidential candidacy collapsed, Mayor Lindsay is so unpopular, according to Democratic politicians, that candidates in next Tuesday's primary are avoiding mayoral endorsements or identification with Mr. Lindsay.

title: Harvard Names Radiologist
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 (AP)The appointment of Dr. Stanley Baum as professor of radiology was announced today by the Harvard Medical School. Dr. Baum is a former professor of radiology at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. He will serve at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: Budgets and Other School Matters Are Put to the Test in Suburban Balloting
description: Voters In most of the suburban communities that held elections yesterday approved their proposed school budgets. The voting took place in various communities in Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk and Rockland Counties.

title: Death Stalks Refugees On Road From Anloc
TEAR GAS IS USED AT STONES CONCERT
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 14 (AP) The police used tear gas tonight to disperse a crowd of 200 to 300 youths who attempted to crash a concert by the Rolling Stones at the Tucson Community Center.

title: U.S. Bars Paris Talks Now but Leaves Door Open
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 State Department officials said today that they did not believe it would be useful for the United States to resume the Vietnam peace talks In Paris at this time.

title: U.S. Studies Races Here For Possibility of Fixing
description: An investigation into the possibility of fixed races at Aqueduct and/or Belmont Park has been going on ter six months, United States Attorney Robert A. Morse acknowledged yesterday.

title: HUNG JURY ENDS PANTHER 4 TRIAL
description: The sixweek trial of four Black Panthers charged with the arsonmurder of Samuel Napier, a fellow Panther, ended last night with a hung jury.

title: Hard Line on Soviet Press
description: MOSCOW, June 14  President Nikolai V. Podgorny left Moscow by air for Hanoi today, evidently to brief the North Vietnamese leaders on President Nixon's talks here last month.

title: Mohawk Data to Expand
description: Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation announced yesterday a major expansion of its series peripherial equipment for computers. The new devices included processors, key display systems, tape and disk drives, printer, paper tape equipment and the software needed to run the machines. Richard P. Rifenburgh, president of Mohawk, said that the new devices will do an increasing share of the work for the mainframe computer increasing the overall data processing capability of the overall system.

title: Earthwatch Voted to Check Habitability
description: STOCKHOLM, June 14A global program to keep watch over the habitability of the planet was given final approval here today by the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment.

title: CLINTON F. ZERWECK
description: CRANFORD, N. J., June 14Clinton F. Zeereck of 11 Heathermeade Place, retired headmaster of Newark Academy, with which he was associated 48 years, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. His age was 91. He retired in 1953.

title: Armstrong Cork Cuts Prices
description: The Armstrong Cork Company said yesterday it had reduced prices about 23 per cent on its Montina line of vinyl corlon sheet floors.

title: Intelsat 4 Switches Orbit
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 14 (UPI)A new Intelsat 4 communications satellite switched today into its final stationary orbit 22,300 miles high. The satellite, launched yesterday, will reinforce telephone and television links among 17 nations.

title: 'The Burglars'
description: For the first five minutes, about as long as the main title credits last, Henri Verneuil's "The Burglars" suggests a degree of technical competence, of simply knowing what to do next, that is rare enough in movies these days to perhaps make up for any lack of real qualityat least to the level of passable entertainment. But by the second five minutes, technical competence has become technical quirkness, and before a quarter of an hour has passed "The Burglars" reveals itself as yet another international caper filmthis time, set in Greecethat does nothing very well and almost everything in excess.The excesses start early, with the caper, which takes place at the beginning rather than at the end of the movie. It is a jewel theft and it involves opening a safe with the aid of a handy attach case that contains an X-ray vision TV camera, TV screen, tape recorder, three kinds of computers, miniature hand drill, metal-working vise, keys-made-while-you-wait machine such as you find in your local hardware store, and an instruction booklet. Such a machine might excite the envy of James Bond's armorer, or the delight of Rube Goldberg. But what it does for Henri Verneuil is to fill up a great deal of film time with a device rather than with an action, and that is exactly the method by which all of "The Burglars" has been made.The devices extend to an endless (and pointless) car chase, a warehouse full of grotesque toys, an automated harbor-side granary, a spicy nightclub, and a spicy meal in a Greek restaurant  take out 10 minutes to photograph and explain the local cuisine. There are also two murders. The only reason for the first murder is to justify the second, so I suppose they belong in the category of mechanics as well.Under Verneuil's direction, characters resolve themselves into a collection of emphatic mannerisms  the way a cigarette is lit, a nervous habit with the hands  which, together with the wooden English-speaking voices dubbed for most of the cast, tends to make people into things: cleverly automated, but things nevertheless.There is, of course, a plot. The plot pits a good crook against a bad cop and places a million dollars worth of emeralds in the balance. Jean-Paul Belmondo plays the crook, Omar Sharif plays the cop, and Dyan Cannon plays an enigmatic woman attached to both of them. I was especially taken with Miss Cannon's part, which seems not so much a role as a succession of brief guest appearances requiring mainly that she smile and walk and wear clothes."The Burglars" opened yesterday at the Loew's State I and Columbia I theaters.

title: $48.1Million in Mortgages Are Issued by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday it had issued $48.1million in Governmentbacked home mortgage commitments at an average yield of 7.625 per cent.

title: Choreographers Move Into Park ForLunch Hour Dance Salute
description: At Bryant Park Tuesday afternoon still another group of choreographers brought openair dancing to casual strollers. This was the start of a fourday Lunch Hour Dance Salute organized by the Cubiculo Experimental Arts Center, which has long been hospitable to young choreographers.

title: METS WIN, 8 TO 3, AND REGAIN FIRST
Rock n Rhetoric Rally in the Garden Aids McGovern
description: Rock n rhetoric were mixed last night at a giant rally in Madison Square Garden in the cause of Senator George McGovern's quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Shakerism: A Colonial Vision of Communal Living Fades
description: SABBATHDAY LAKE, Me. The longest and most successful American experiment in celibate Christian communal living is fading away in two remote New England communities where yesterday and today merge in living museums.

title: RISING NEED SEEN FOR GAS TANKERS
description: The increasing need for specially designed liquefied natural gas (LNG) tankers was emphasized yesterday.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES IRISH POTATO BAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  A bill to ban Irish potato trading for future delivery on commodity markets was approved by the House Agriculture Committee today.

title: Suit Over Yellow Pages Won
description: DENVER, June 14 (AP).Dr. Robert L. Irish, a dentist whose name was omitted from the Yellow Pages in 1968, should be paid for lost income by the telephone company, the Colorado Court of Appeals ruled yesterday. Dr. Irish said that he lost nearly $18,000 in business while he was left out of the phone book.

title: Man in the News
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 14  Among the modest trophies on the wall of Mayor Donald Vern Barnett's office is a handlettered, framed quotation from an article by Norman Cousins in The Saturday Review in 1971. It reads: Optimism supplies the basic energy of civilizetion... pessimism is a waste of time. Mr. Barnett. at 29 one of the youngest Mayors in the United States, is no waster of time, no pessimist, despite what has happened to his plans and his city.

title: A Bum Parking Rap
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y.Talk about your wet hens. That is what upstate New Yorkers, New Englanders and New Jerseyites get as sore as when small gales of overtime parking summonses blow into their mail boxes from New York City, when they haven't been on the Big Apple since Oklahoma closed.

title: Huntington Pesticide Injunction Lifted
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 14 State Supreme Court Justice George F. X. McInerney today lifted an injunction prohibiting the enforcement of the Town of Huntington's pesticide control law, believed to be the strongest of its type in the country.

title: J. G. Louis Molloy Dead at 69; Investigator in Walker Scandal
description: OXFORD, Conn., June 14. J. G. Louis Molloy, a New York lawyer who was active in the Seabury investigation of municipal corruption and later was legal adviser to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died yesterday at his home, 39 Bowers Hill Road. He was 69 years old.

title: IRVING MARANTZ, 60, PAINTER, SCULPTOR
description: Irving Marantz, painter and sculptor, died at New York University Hosiptal on Tuesday after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 198 Avenue of the Americas.

title: New York Races
description: Frank J. Brasco, a Democrat, who is seeking a fourth term as the 11th Congressional District's Representative, is being challenged in the twocounty district by a businessman and restaurateur who is making his first foray into politics.

title: S.E.C. ASKS POWER ON OIL INVESTING
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Securities and Exchange Commission submitted legislation to Congress today that would bring under regulation the sale of interests in oildrilling programs.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Win, 113, to End Royals Fenway Park Hex
Mrs. Chisholm Pressing For Key Convention Role
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., June 14 When Representative Shirley Chisholm is asked publicly if she is a serious candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency, she bristles and answers:

title: Podgorny Stops Over in India
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 14 (AP)  President Podgorny stopped over in Calcutta today on his way to Hanoi.

title: 3 SHEFFIELD UNITS FILE BANKRUPTCY
description: Three subsidiaries of the Sheffield Watch Corporation filed a petition yesterday for a reorganization under Chapter. XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District.

title: ADM, FELIX STUMP, LED PACIFIC FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  Adm. Felix B. Stump, who was captain of the aircraft carrier Lexington in the Pacific in World War II, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon met with Secretary of State Rogers to discuss the strategic arms limitation agreements and other matters. He announced that Secretary Rogers would attend the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization meeting in Canberra, Australia, June 2728.

title: ... but Who's in Charge?
description: The case of Gen. John D. Lavelle, who was relieved of his command of United States Air Forces in Southeast Asia last March for exceeding his authority in ordering attacks against North Vietnam, raises the most serious questions about the effectiveness of civilian control over the American military.

title: No Talks This Week
description: PARIS, June 14  The United States and South Vietnam refused today to resume the Vietnam peace talks this week, but left the door open for sessions later.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 5 million shares of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. common stock ($10.00 par value) at $24,625 per share was announced yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Incorporated, The First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody & Co. Incorporated. According to the underwriters, the utility will use the net proceeds from the sale for the construction of a utility plant. Con Ed's stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed unchanged yesterday at 24.

title: Doyle and Weir Advance In Eastern Senior Tennis
Geoffrey Bloomingdale Weds Elizabeth Fahr
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 14  The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Fahr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mehard Fahr of Lima, Peru, and Iowa City, to Geoffrey Bloomingdale took place here this afternoon, The bridegroom is a son of Alfred Bloomingdale, cofounder of the Diners Club, and Mrs. Bloomingdale and a greatgrandson of the late Lyman G. Bloomingdale, founder of the New York destore.

title: Rise in Strategic Arms Spending Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The House Armed Services Committee approved today the $1.3billion increase in the strategic weapons program that the Administration said was neces sary to maintain technological superiority over the Soviet Union.

title: Time to Retire
description: Representative Emanuel Celler, seeking renomination in next week's Democratic primary in Brooklyn's 16th Congressional District, faces unusually spirited opposition from Elizabeth Holtzman, an honor graduate of Radcliffe and of Harvard Law School, who has had some experience in city government.

title: Dr. Georg von Bekesy, 73, Dies; 61 Nobel Laureate in Medicine
description: HONOLULU, June 14 (AP)Dr. Georg von Bekesy, winner of the Nobel Prize for medicine and physiology in 1961, died yesterday at the age of 73. He had been professor of sensory sciences at the University of Hawaii since 1966.

title: Monsanto Unit to Expand
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its Monsanto Polymers and Petrochemicals Company unit would expand nylon plastic capacity at its Pensacola, Fla., plant by 150 per cent.

title: Elderly in Bronx Aided By DialARide Service
description: Some 250 elderly and handicapped Bronx residents will be taking taxis today, something most of them could not afford to do yesterday.

title: Kennedy Sees Merger But Not for 197273
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 14 (UPI)Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, conceded today the pro basketball merger was dead as far as next season was concerned but said he still thought it would be approved.

title: SchoolHousing Project Backed With Vigor by Bushwick Area
description: Repeated, fervent endorsements were lavished on a publichousing proposal at City Hall yesterday as residents from the Bu'shwick section of Brooklyn complained that they had been ignored and victimized too long by the city and its pressures.The project is to extend from mile north of the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery.

title: 30 Volkswagens Vandalized
description: The windows and headlights on some 30 Volkswagens were smashed by vandals in a residential section of the northern Bronx early yesterday, the police of the Wakefield station reported. The police placed the time of the vandalism between 2 and 6 A.M. and said that at least two persons had been involved, They had no theory as to why the Volkswagens had been selected for the vandalism.

title: BIG SWINGS MARK TRADING IN COTTON
description: Wide price swings in the nearby July contract featured the trading in cotton futures yesterday. A nearlimit decline of $9.50 a bale in that contract on Tuesday attracted buyers yesterday.

title: Songcan 85 in Dexter Trot Saturday
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 14he postposition draw for Saturday night's $100,000 Detxer Cup trot for 3yearolds was held today at Roosevelt Raceway and it put Songcan in the No. 5 slot in the field of six.

title: MovingtheBall Violations Charged to Janie Blalock
description: ATLANTA, June 14 (UPI)The Ladies Professional Golf Association said today observers hiding in woods and stationed on television towers with binoculars had seen Jane Blalock illegally move her ball during tournament play.

title: India to Deliver 150 P.O.W.'s To Bangladesh to Face Trial
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 14 (Reuters)India has agreed to give 150 Pakistani prisoners of war to Bangladesh for interroga tion and trial on charges of genocide, a Foreign Ministry official said here today.

title: Dr. Jacob Papish, Chemist, Dies; Cornell Professor Emeritus, 85
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 14 Dr. Jacob Papish, professor emeritus of chemistry at Cornell University, died last Thursday at the home of his daughter, Mrs, Dorothy B. Papish, 35 Elk Street. He was 85 years old.

title: 4 Charged in Attempted Theft In Air of $3Million Securities
description: ATLANTA, June 14 (AP)When Eastern Air Lines Flight 393 took off from Greensboro, N.C., at 9 o'clock last night it carried in its cargo hold $3million in securities and a box containing a 39yearold man. The man, says the Federal Bureau of Investigation, planned to steal the securities.

title: Trifecta Pays $20,122
description: CHICAGO, June 14 (UPI)The trifecta on the ninth race at Arlington Park paid $20,122.50 today. There were three winning tickets. Frank N Jesse won, followed by Eternal Prince, an 801 shot, and Goshawk. In the trifecta, the bettor must pick the first three horses in order.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 14 (UPI)Mr. Irvis said today that the nation would witness a black massacre within the next decade unless the Supreme Court took a tougher stand on civil rights.

title: HIGH COURT ASSAILED BY N.A.A.C.P. GROUP
description: The Supreme Court decision on Monday upholding the right of a Harrisburg, Pa., Moose Lodge to deny service to a black State Representative, K. LeRoy Irvis, and still retain its liquor license was described, yesterday by an official of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., as reversing a trend of more than two decades in the law of human rights.

title: Back to the Table...
description: The return to Paris of the American negotiator, Ambassador William Porter, and the prospective return of North Vietnam's delegation chief, Xuan Thuy, suggest the approach of another monsoon negotiating season. Now that a new military equilibrium has emerged on the ground and the weather is too soggy for decisive battles, both sides may be ready for some serious talking about a compromise settlement.

title: Seymour's Position on Inquiry
description: United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. declined to make any substantive comment when he was asked about the investigation of narcotics corruption that his office has been conducting for the last 14 months.

title: Witness in Trial Of a State Justice Held in Contempt
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn held a key Government witness in contempt yesterday in the bribery trial of State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst after the witness refused to authorize examination of his coded Swiss bank accounts.

title: ASIA GROUP LOOKS TO NEW CHINA TIES
Rate Rise Feared If El Paso. Gas Co. Drops Acquisition
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)Congress was told today that the breaking up of the El Paso Natural Gas Company, as ordered by the Supreme Court in 1964, would result in an increase in gas rates throughout the West.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Not even a shout can overcome vicious lie nor do I have any hope that this letter of denial will be enough to overcome the injury done to me in the letter signed by four M.D.'s asserting that my campaign workers are conducting a whispering campaign about William Ryan's health.

title: Trevino Cards 74 in U.S. Open TuneUp on Coast
United Artists Is Joining Reader's Digest in Films
description: United Artists and Reader's Digest will present a series of films designed to appeal to family audiences.

title: Olympic FundRaising Seeks Last $2Million
description: With $8milion already in the kitty, the United States Olympic Committee kicked off on the anchor leg of its national campaign to raise the additional $2million needed to send the United States team to the Summer Olympics in Munich with luncheon yesterday at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

title: U.S. Agency Tells 10 States To Curtail Some Pollutants
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) Overruling state air cleanup plans for the first time, the Environmental Protection Agency today tentatively ordered 10 states to tighten controls on certain industrial pollutants.

title: A 200Point Ecology Plan Gains at U.N. Conference
description: STOCKHOLM, June 14A program of international measures to improve the world's living conditions emerged in, final form today as the United Nations Environmental Conference began the twoday process of ratifying the conclusions of its three committeesofthewhole.

title: Trails, New Work By Linda Tarnay, Danced at Church
description: Linda Tarnay and Tina Croll, two choreographers who have good ideas but seem unable to develop them, each presented two works Tuesday night at the theater of Riverside Church. The concert was presented by Dance Theater Workshop.

title: DR. GAETANO J. MECCA
description: Dr. Gaetano J. Mecca, a urologist and a lifelong resident of Greenwich Village, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had served on the staff for 35 years. He was 80 years old and lived at 83 Charles Street.

title: Thomas H. McGlade, 49, Partner in Shields &
description: Thomas Hugh McGlade, a general partner in the investment firm of Shields & Co., 44 Wall Street, died of a heart attack yesterday in Turnberry, Scotland. Mr. McGlade, who had been on a golfing tour of Scotland, was 49 years old and lived at 21 Hancock Lane, Darien, Corm.

title: Railroad Passes Dividend
description: BALTIMORE, June 14 (AP)The Western Maryland Railway Company's board of directors, citing depressed earnings, decided today not to declare a secondquarter dividend on the preferred cumulative 7 per cent stock, first preferred cumulative 5 per cent stock or corn1 mon stock.

title: IN THE NATION
description: BOSTONJames R. Hoffa apparently got respectful attention when he talked about prison life before a Senate subcommittee. If the Senators were paying as much attention to what he said as they were to his reputation, which is doubtful, they heard him make two of the most Important points about the medieval penal institutions still tolerated in America.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The people of Alaska must begin the battle to save Alaska from the misguided dogooders of the conservation movement (the most recent of the kookattracting causes) and from the United States Government.

title: Women Filmmakers: Doors Opening
description: Working with men in an authority situation is very difficult for a woman like me. I find it very, very hard to assert myself.

title: O.A.U. Chooses Top Official
description: RABAT, Morocco, June 14 (Reuters)Nzo Tkanganti of the Carneroons was elected secretary general of the Organization of African Unity tonight. He succeeds Diallo Telli of Guinea.

title: Duncan Photo Show Is a First at Whitney
description: David Douglas Duncan, in the last 38 years, has photographed three American wars and much of the rest of the world in peace and in agony. Today his work becomes the subject of the first photographic exhibition in the 40year history of the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Mass Busing Is Ordered For Detroit and Suburbs By JERRY M. FLINT
description: DETROIT, June 14  A Federal judge in Detroit issued today the most sweeping school busing order in the nation's history, calling for the integration of 780,000 schoolchildren in Detroit and 53 suburban school districts.,

title: Graebner, Mrs. King Advance
description: BRISTOL, England, June 14 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York defeated Australia's John Cboper, 64, 64, in the first round of the West of England tournament today while Mrs. Billie Jean King advanced to the women's semifinals.

title: News of Dogs
description: Most fanciers are satisfied to have one breed and do well with it. Mrs. Dorothy Burke of Fort Worth is an exception. She has shown six breeds and done well with all of them.

title: JACK'S CONVICTION POSES A QUESTION
description: The big question in the 70th Assembly District in Harlem is: Can the Democratic incumbent, Hulan E. Jack, retain his Assembly seat against a challenge from three opponents in the primary next Tuesday despite his recent conviction and subsequent sentencing to three months in prison on conflictofinterest charges?

title: Factory Output and Personal Income Rise
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Industrial production rose substantially again in May, marking the ninth consecutive month of advance, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: 85 Killed in Crash of Japanese Airliner Near Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, June 34 (Reuters)  A Japan Air Lines DC8 jet crashed in flames as it prepared to land at Palam International Airport near here tonight, killing 83 of the 89 people on board.

title: So. California Tops Texas On Arenstein's Hit in 10th
description: QMAHA, June 14 (AP)Daryl Arenstein's 10thinning single tonight gave Southern California a 4.3 victory over Texas and kept alive the Trojans bid for a third straight National Collegiate world series baseball title. Texas was eliminated.

title: Individual Pennsy Role Sought by John Hancock
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, one of the largest single creditors of the Penn Central Transportation Company, has decided it wants to go it alone in the railroad's bankruptcy proceedings, rather than continuing as part of group of insurance companies appearing in the case.

title: Garber Wins P.S.A.L. Tennis
description: Joe Garber, a 16yearold junior at Abraham Lincoln High School, won the Public Schools Athletic League singles tennis championship by defeating Martin Sturgess of Forest Hills High, 61, 64, at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, Tuesday.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Everybody agrees about the general developments in fall fashionsthe prevalence of pants, the importance of separates and the casual look, the dominance of long dressses for evening. But despite the apparent unanimity, there's no chance of women all looking alike next season. The collections described below give an indication why.

title: KEY ULSTER PARLEY IS SET FOR TODAY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 14Representatives of the main Roman Catholic political party in Northern Ireland, the Social Democratic and Labor party, will meet William Whitelaw, Britain's administrator for Ulster, in London tomorrow. The meeting will end the party's long boycott of the Government here.

title: Legislative Primaries
description: In addition to the primary contests among candidates for Congress, a confused race among committed and uncommitted delegate slates for the Presidential nominating convention and several judicial scraps, the Democrats of New York will confront a host of state legislative primary battles in Tuesday's balloting. The Republicans are not nearly so active. Aside from selecting their state committeemen and making choices in scattering of primary contests, they will have little to do.

title: 10 Americans on Plane
description: TOKYO, Thursday, June 15 (Reuters)Japan Air Lines said today that passengers of at least 11 nationalities were aboard the DC8 that crashed near New Delhi last night.

title: 100 Violations Found by City in Medical Clinic in East Harlem
description: Dr. Joseph A. Cimino, City Health Commissioner, said yesterday that more than 100 health code violations had been found in a private East Harlem medical clinic during inspections conducted in the last three days after community residents complained.

title: Books of The Times
description: There are so many brilliant and moving things in Robert Craft's Stravinsky that one hardly knows where to begin in praising the book. In the last two decades of Stravinsky's life, Mr. Craft functioned as friend, sounding board, musical catalyst and standin conductor under Stravinsky's supervision. Having collaborated on six books with Stravinsky, Mr. Craft is a practiced writer: He is also an extremely good one.

title: Chapel, a Father's Memorial, Honors More Than Vietnam Dead
description: EAGLE NEST, N. M.The little chapel with its curving, gull wings, rising on a hill in northern Mexico, makes some visitors uneasy. They do not seem to know how to behave inside it.

title: Cahill Asks Jersey Legislators To Vote on Income Tax Bill First
description: TRENTON, June 14  Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he had asked New Jersey's legislative leaders to vote on his proposed state income tax first in the special legislative session on tax reform that begins here tomorrow.

title: Diverse Group Formed to Fight Revival of AntiSemitism in Italy
description: ROME, June 14A new group of Roman Catholic priests and laymen, Protestants and intellectuals unaffiliated with churches warned yesterday that antiSemitism was being revived in Italy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is much interest these days in recycling glass and reprocessing metal and paper. Another topic of concern is the rehabilitation of prisoners.

title: Walkout at a Hospital Interrupts Hearing in LeagueUnion Clash
description: Word that hospital workers who took part in Tuesday's Fork stoppage were being suspended caused a brief unauthorized walkout by 250 workers at University Hospital yesterday.

title: Dataon Mars Indicate It's a Dynamic Planet
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 14A clear and often surprising portrait of Mars as a distinctive, dynamic planet is emerging from the pictures and data transmitted back to earth by Mariner 9, the spacecraft that has been circling Mars twice day for the last seven months.

title: A Wedding Cake for $20 and Two Days Work
description: Fathers of the bride, rejoice! There is a way to cut costa on your daughter's June wedding.

title: Safety of 40% of 8.52 Fleet May Be Periled by Defect
description: WASHINGTON, June. 14 The Air Force has discovered a structural defect that may affect up to 40 per cent of its fleet of B52 strategic bombers and curtail their usefulness, according to Congressional testimony released today.

title: Thousands Flee Italian City After 2 Earthquakes Strike
description: ANCONA, Italy, Thursday, June 15 (Reuters)Thousands of panicstricken people fled this Adriatic port city last night after two powerful earthquakes struck in two hours, leaving at least one person dead and causing serious damage.

title: Russo. Seeks Trial Delay In Pentagon Papers Case
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) Attorneys for Anthony J. Russo, codefendant in the Pentagon papers case, filed motion today to stay his trial and sever his case from that of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: GOLD PRICE DROPS; DOLLAR IS WEAKER
description: LONDON, June 14 (AP)The price of gold dropped further today on Europe's bullion markets. The United States dollar weakened.

title: West Germany, Soviet Gain Soccer Cap Final
description: West Germany and the Soviet Union were victorious yesterday in the semifinals for the European Nations Cup in soccer and will meet Sunday in the final.

title: Study Finds That 41% of U.S. Reform Rabbis Marry Jews to NonJews
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 14Fortyone per cent of the nation's Reform rabbis defy tradition and officiate at mixed marriages involving Jews and nonJews, a statistical study indicated today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I would like to comment on The Times editorial [June 2] entitled Hospital Crisis.

title: MALPRACTICE PANEL SETTLES 58 CASES
description: A mediation panel formed to settle medical malpractice cases out of court reported yesterday that in its first seven months it settled nearly onethird of the 201 cases it reviewed.

title: WAGNER SEES LOSS OF FAITH IN CITIES
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner declared yesterday that there was a spreading loss of public confidence in local governments in the state coupled with a growing sense of continuing crisis and imminent catastrophe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I was shocked and dismayed to read that a jury has found physicians not guilty of wrongful death of a patient when they removed his beating heart [news story May 27].

title: Family on the Move: The Wife's Feelings
description: INDIANAPOLISDean and Stella Jones had the blues after two weeks in the new town. It might have been the right town for a lot of families, but it was just the one for the Joneses.

title: Those E.E.R.'s and B.T.U.'s Are Part Of ABC's of Buying AirConditioners
description: For anyone buying an airconditioner this year, the initials E.E.R. should be as important a consideration as B.T.U., according to Consolidated Edison, the Home Appliance Manufacturers Association and the Lindsay administration.

title: Shooting Victim Identifies Phillips at a Pretrial Hearing as His Assailant
description: A man who was wounded in the 1968 Christmas Eve shootings that left a pimp and his girlfriend dead was reported yesterday to have identified William R. Phillips, the star witness at the Knapp Commission hearings, as the man who shot him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN W. SCHNEIDER
description: John W. Schneider, a partner in the accounting firm of Pustorino Puglisi & Co., died of cancer Monday in Bronx Veterans Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 2575 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The number of fire officers and fire fighters reporting III or injured after fires in the 24hour peiod ending at 6 A.M. yesterday went up to 156, compared with 135 in the previous 24hour period, but the number of companies out of service dropped from 16 to eight. Only 38 of those reporting ill or injured were officers, the remainder being the fighters. The Fire Department canceled all time off except for vacations.

title: Munich Called Portal for Mideast Heroin
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 14This booming city of 1.4 million has become Europe's main gateway for hard drugs emanating from Turkey and the Middle.East, according to narcotics experts,, taking the lead as a transfer point from Marseilles in the last year.

title: Horror on French Hill
description: An important element in the unique aesthetic and historical appeal that attracts thousands of pilgrims and other tourists each year to Jerusalem is the rugged, nearly barren landscape of hills that forms a biblical backdrop to the Holy City. That landscape, already marred by insensitive building construction, is currently threatened as never before, ironically by wellmeaning Americanfinanced efforts to build additional accommodations for the booming tourist trade.

title: U.S. Looking Into Heroin Bribery Here; Some Officials A re Said to Be Implicated
description: A Federal investigation into bribery by New York heroin dealers has been under way for 14 months and is expected to lead to the indictment of key police officers and possiblyofficials in other areas of law enforcement, according to sources in the office of the Federal prosecutor and the Police Department.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A,M. on Cyprus question.

title: POPE PAUL WIDENS POWER OF BISHOPS
description: ROME, June 14The Vatican said today that Pope Paul VI, in a meeting with some 20 ranking Cardinals last night. announced broader powers for bishops and episcopal conferences to act independently.

title: Advertising:
description: Despite a disheartening lack of cooperation from its membership, the American Management Association has completed a research report on Truth in Advertising.

title: Anaconda Payment Suspended by Chile Until Tribunal Acts
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 14 (Reuters) The Chilean Government said here today that it would not honor outstanding promissory notes totaling $5.85million to the Anaconda Corporation until the Chilean Copper Tribunal delivers definitive judgment in a suit between the state and Anaconda, the Kennecott Corporation and the Cerro Corporation. The suit arose from national. ization of copper mines last July.

title: Chess: 1490 Manuscript Termed Earliest Text on Openings
2 WORLD PREMIERES AT BALLET THEATER
description: American Ballet Theater will present two world premieres, three company premieres and three revivals during its sixweek season at the State Theater from July 4 through Aug. 13.

title: GONZALES GAINS IN BRITISH TENNIS
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 14 (AP)Pancho Gonzales used his head to save his legs today and the topseeded American moved smoothly into the quarterfinals of the Kent tennis tournament.

title: Lay Teachers Reject Union
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP)Lay teachers in the Philadelphia Roman Catholic Archdiocese's elementary schools voted yesterday against unionization. The State Labor Relations Board, which ordered the election held, said that the vote was 646 to 410. The election had been requested by Local 1776, Association of Catholic Teachers.

title: McKenzie Quits Bruins To Pilot W.H.A. Blazers
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP)John Mckenzie felt the Boston Bruins didn't want him, so he left the National Hockey League today to join the new World Hockey Association as playercoach of the Philadelphia Blazers.

title: REACTIONSTRIKES CALLED COVERUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 A former photointelligence specialist for the Seventh Air Force, in Vietnam said today that in 1970 his topsecret unit planned, a number of bombing strikes into North Vietnam that a few days later were publicly described by the Air Force as protective reaction.

title: Child Labor Policy Under U.S. Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 14In a departure from policy, the Labor Department is now considering a proposal to allow East and Gulf Coast seafood processors to employ children 14 to 16 years old as crabmeat pickers.

title: Mexico's Leader in Capital For Talks With Nixon Today
description: WASHINGTON, Tune 14 (Reuters)President Luis Echeverria of Mexico arrived here tonight and left immediately for Camp David. Md., for an overnight stay before opening talks with President Nixon at the White House tomorrow.

title: Communist Atrocities in Vietnam; If the North takes over the South, what will the bloodbath be?
description: LONDONThe present invasion of South Vietnam and the intense fighting of the last few weeks draw attention once again to the human suffering caused, on an almost unprecedented scale, to the Vietnamese people by the continuing war. I am not here considering the battle casualties which, although on each side they have probably reached 500,000, can at least be regarded as legitimate in war.

title: Yankees Triumph, 30; Stop White Sox Streak
Reinsurer Names Director
description: Richard E. Stewart, former State Superintendent of Insurance and now senior vice president and general counsel of the First National City Bank, was named yesterday as a board member of the General Reinsurance Corporation.

title: Jury Finds Ruggiero Guilty of Perjury
description: Joseph E. Ruggiero, a former Republican party official, was found guilty yesterday of having lied to a Federal grand jury investigating corruption.

title: Phillies Trade McCarver To Montreal for BatemanI
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies and Montreal Expos exchanged catchers today, with the Phils sending Tim McCarver to the Expos for John Bateman.

title: MECOM CUTTING TIES TO ACCUSED GROUPS
description: The National Football League commissioner, Pete Rozelle, revealed yesterday that John Mecom, owner of the New Orleans Saints, was severing connections with an investment program that was under question by the House Select Committee on Organized Crime.

title: Chrysler Moves Up Date For Its Electronic ignition!
description: DETROIT, June 14 (UPI)The Chrysler Cotporation will make its electronic ignition system standard equipment on all its models with eightcylinder engines beginning next week, adding $14 to the manufacturer's suggested retail price. It was to have been made standard equipment on 1973 models.

title: Germans Getting Refund of Surtax Imposed in 197071
description: BONN, June 14Starting tomorrow the Bonn Government will refund West German corporations and wage earners $1.84billion of an antiinflationary tax surcharge imposed for 11 months in 1970 and 1971.

title: Key Rail Line Reported Cut
description: SAIGON, Thursday, June 15 (AP)  The United States command reported yesterday that American air strikes severed the main rail line between Hanoi and Haiphong on Tuesday. This was accomplished, the command said, through the bombing of a rail and highway bridge at Haiduong, midway between the two cities.

title: Willowbrook Chief Is Named Head of Rome State School
description: Dr. Jack Hammond has been named director of the Home State School after serving for eight years as director of its sister institution, the controversial Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded on Staten Island.

title: Tenants Are Ordered To Take Down Sheets
description: Tenants at 210 Central Park South began taking in the sheets from their balconies after a State Supreme Court justice ordered an end to their display of sheets lettered with complaints about the 24story luxury apartment house.

title: BERTRAM M. STONE
description: Bertram M. Stone, president of the Greiner Scientific Corporation, a manufacturer of laboratory instruments, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 181 East 73d Street.

title: Police Department Says Times Story Is Accurate
description: The Police Department issued the following statement shortly before midnight last night, after the exclusive publication of the story on the bribery investigation in The New York Times:

title: Commuters&
description: Now the pink wild roses come to cover the embankments along the commuters railroad tracks, partially hiding the ugly wounds of polluting man. Papers, cans, old grocery carts, even baby buggies lie partially obscured under the lush green leaves of the wild rose vines, the bright blossoms giving elegance and fragrance.

title: DDT BANNED IN U.S. ALMOST TOTALLY, EFFECTIVE DEC. 31
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 William D. Ruckelshaus, admin, istrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, banned today almost all uses of DDT, the longlived toxic pesticide that lodges in the food chain of men, animals, birds and fish.

title: British Boats Dominate Onion Patch Racing
NewCar Sales Climb to a 10Day Peak
description: DETROIT, June 14New card sales for the first 10 days of June were at a record level because of a strong performance by the General Motors Corporation.

title: Three Indicted in Union County On Zoning Kickback Charges
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., June 14 Two former Union County Democratic party officials and a former Clark Township official were indicted today by a special grand jury on charges that they sought kickbacks from a concern attempting to construct a Ramada Inn and an office complex in the suburban community of Clark.

title: Nassau Is Planning to Buy A11 10 Bus Lines in County
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 14County Executive Ralph G. Caso announced today that the entire Nassau bus system, now in the hands of 10 private companies, would be purchased at a total cost of $10million and operated by a public agencyeither the Metropolitan Transportation Authority or an authority set up by Nassau County.

title: 38 Airlines Moving to End Kickbacks
description: Officials of 38 international airlines convened a special meeting here yesterday aimed frankly at making themselves less dishonest.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: ONLY 5 DAYS TO GO BEFORE THE BIRTH OF THE NEW WORLD: A MAGA ZINE ADDRESSED TO THE LIFE OF THE MIND ADVT.

title: CLYDE L. M'PHATTER
description: Clyde L. McPhatter, a rock and soul singer who formed The Drifters in the 1950's, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, while visiting friends in the Bronx. He was 41 years old and lived at 142 Garden Steet, Teaneck, N. J.

title: Copters Ferry More Saigon Troops Into Anloc as Enemy Fire Ebbs
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 15With enemy ground fire greatly reduced, allied helicopters poured more South Vietnamese troops reinforcements yesterday into the besieged and devastated provincial capital of Anloc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Cici Posts 75 to Lead Long Island Golf by 3 Shots
Big Board's Audit Power Is Assailed by Lefkowitz
description: Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Attorney General of New York State, called yesterday on Congress to strip the New York Stock Exchange of much of its selfregulatory power in the area of memberfirm auditing.

title: Bridge: Italy and the US Win Easily In 16th Round of Olumpiad
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 14The United States team pulled up to third position in the qualifying stage of the World Team Olypiad here this afternoon. The Aces won 19 to against Spain and 182 against New Zealand.

title: Tenants vs. the Landlord in The Coop
ADM SHERBROOKE, 71, BRITISH NAVAL HERO
description: LONDON, June 14Rear Adm. Robert St. Vincent Sherbrooke, whose destroyers attacked superior German naval forces to protect a convoy for the Soviet Union and who continued to direct the action although blinded in one eye, died last night. His age was 71.

title: U.S. Survey Indicates Dumping Off Sandy Hook Hurts Sea Life
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The dumping of sewage and sludge from dredging into the New York Bighteast of Sandy Hook  appears to be harming marine life, according to a report by the National Marine Fisheries Service.

title: Waldheim Back From Trip
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 14 (AP)Secretary General Waldheim returned today from a twoweek trip to five nations. He visited Sweden, where he addressed the opening session of the United Nations Conference on Human Environment, and then went to Cyprus, Turkey. Greece and Portugal.

title: Screen: Last Ride for Jesse and Boys
Seeley Will Fight Vasquez On June 26 Garden Card
description: Walter Seeley of Sayville, L. I., will face David Vasquez of the Bronx in a 10round featherweight bout as the semifinal to the Ken BuchananRoberto Durand lightweight title fight at Madison Square Garden on June 26. Seeley and Vasquez are stepping up from the bantamweight division.

title: Life in Uruguay Disrupted By Violence and Inflation
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 2Attacks by the Tupamaro revolutionary guerrilla movement, counterviolence by the right wing and a combination of inflation and stagnation are fraying the durable fabric of Uruguayan democracy.

title: KISSINGER IS GOING TO CHINA 4TH TIME TO TALK WITH CHOU
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Henry A. Kissinger, the President's adviser on national security, will go to China next week for five days of talks with Premier Chou Enlai and other officials on a variety of issues, presumably including Vietnam.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS GATEWAY PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The House Interior Committee today approved the creation of a 26,000acre Gateway National Urban Recreation area at the entrance to New York Harbor after voting to let New York State build housing on part of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

title: SOVIET TESTS DEVICE FOR UNDERSEA STUDY
description: MOSCOW, June 14The SoViet Union reported today the successful test of a new underwater apparatus capable of exploring the ocean floor.

title: Advertising:
description: Grayson F. Lathrop, general manager in New York for the Al Paul Lefton Company, and an executive vice president, has been elected chairman of the board. Mr. Lefton Jr. continues as president and chief executive.

title: RICHARD M. BARR, 64, A FORMER NEWSMAN
description: Richard M. Barr, a newsman, war correspondent and, in recent years, a public relations consultant, died of a heart attack at his home, 140 East 28th Street, on Tuesday evening. He was 64 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: The H. Heinz Company has elected S. Donald Wiley as senior vice president, secretary, general counsel and a director.

title: OBSERVER
description: The honorary degrees which are given away on campuses all over the country each year at this season are something like the Queen's Honors List in England in that they constitute sort of official certification of the recipient's fame, wealth or talent.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CLAREMONT, N.H.  By late afternoon, the heavy clouds were swept away by a strong north wind, the lush, green shores of the Connecticut River gleamed in the bright sun, and twice before dusk we saw Baltimore orioles flicker like orange flames against the tossing trees.

title: Film Center Names Aide
description: James Powers has been named director of publications at the American Film Institute's Center for Advanced; Film Studies in Los Angeles.

title: E.P.A. Aide Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Robert Lewis Sansom of Arlington, Va., to be an assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, succeeding Donald MacMurphy, who resigned.

title: Diplomats in Peking and Hong Kong Weigh Rumors That Mao Is Ill
description: HONG KONG, June 14Diplomats stationed in Peking and Hong Kong have alerted their governments to a new flurry of rumors about the health of Mao Tsetung, with the caution that they should not be entirely discounted.

title: Sugarman Puts Relief Rejections at 27%, and Sees Leveling at 30%
description: Rejection rates on new applications for welfare are running about 27 per cent, up from a low of 20 per cent reached last fall, when clerks first took over decisions from caseworkers throughout the city, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.

title: More Are Accounted For in Rapid City
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 14 The list of persons still missing in this floodstricken city dropped markedly today as duplications were eliminated, new reports of survivors were received and more bodies were recovered.

title: U.S.Mexico Draw Set
description: MEXICO CITY, June 14 (AP) Tom Gorman will meet Mexico's top player, Joaquin Loyo Maye, Friday in the opening singles match of the second round of North American Zone Davis Cup play.

title: Basic Measure Used
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The basic deficit in the nation's balance of international payments worsened in the first quarter of this year but did not reach the record deficit of the summer of 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Up to this point in his career, Richie Allen has fallen snveral degrees short of being the favorite pinup boy of any of the big league managers for whom he has played. He kept wearing out his welcome so fast that he now with his fourth team in four seasons, the Chicago White Sox. When the Phillies finally gave up on him, they unloaded him on the Cardinals, who unloaded him on the Dodgers, who unloaded him right out of the league on the Chisox. Immediately Richie asked that he be called Dick. Did he also change his disposition and habits? Chuck Tanner, his new manager, is so impressed by him that he raves about him without restraint. Allen is not only super ballplayer, he said yesterday, but I've found him to be a super person. In my opinion he's the best ballplayer in the league and the man who makes the wheels go round. I'll say one thing. As far as I'm concerned, this is his last stop. He can play ball for me for the rest of his life and his next stop after leaving the White Sox will be the Hall of Fame Cooperstown.

title: ExRep. Philip J. Philbin Dead; Served Massachusetts 28 Years
description: BOLTON, Mass., June 14Former Representative Philip J. Philbin, a Democrat who served 28 years in Congress before losing in the 1970 primary to Rev. Robert L. Drinan, a Jesuit priest who went on to win the seat on an antiwar platform, died today at his farm here. He was 74 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: Bee Bee Bee Scratched
description: STANTON, Del., June 14 (AP) Bee Bee Bee, winner of last month's Preakness, has been declared out of next Sunday's $50,000added Leonard Richards Stakes at Delaware Park.

title: LEAD STUDY HINTS RACE DIFFERENCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)A 27city survey indicated today that black youngsters might be more susceptible to lead poisoning from paint in old slums than white children.

title: Personal Finance: LandBuying Aid
description: Mrs. C. E. Eckles of Mt. Vernon, N. Y., bought some land for investment purposes a few years ago from the Gulf American Land Corporation.

title: WITCHCRAFT ISSUE IN OUSTER BATTLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 A suit seeking reinstatement has been filed by an Air Force lieutenant who contends she was dismissed after complaining about alleged security violations at the missile tracking site at Laredo, Tex. Her complaints led to an investigation at the base.

title: U.S. Won't Oppose Merger
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)  The Justice Department announced today that it would not oppose the proposed acquisition of The Boston Herald Traveler by The Record American. The antitrust division has been studying the acquisition since early May. Its announcement clears the way for it to take effect as scheduled June 18.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Norman F. Dacey's Letter to the President advertisement, June 6, should not be dismissed as a mere political ad in an election year. The charges made therein are too serious; they require full and frank discussion now from all points of view. Americans demand candor on everything pertaining to Vietnam. Why should there not be equal candor about the U.S. role in the ArabIsraeli problem? Must this be softpedaled until after the November electionsand then on into the indefinite future?

title: Psychiatrist Is Charged With Selling Methadone
description: A psychiatrist who runs a licensed private methadonemaintenance clinic in the Bronx was arrested yesterday and charged with selling methadone to six persons who reportedly said they were not heroin addicts, but wanted the drug for reasons unrelated to maintenance therapy. The six were state undercover agents.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELSWestern Europe is Increasingly concerned about prospects not only that its strategic defenses, as devised in the North Atlantic Alliance, but also its economic stability may be directly threatened by Russian advances in the Mediterranean.

title: KNAPP NOMINATED AS FEDERAL JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15President Nixon today nominated four Federal judges for the Southern District of New York, including Whitman Knapp, who headed the commission that investigated police corruption in New York City last year, and Robert L. Carter, a former general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Americana Closes Wooden Indian Bar After Indian Protest
description: A group of Indians succeeded yesterday in having the Wooden Indian bar in the Americana Hotel closed because the name and decorations were offensive to them.

title: Rubin Quits L. I. U. to Pilot 76ers
description: Roy Rubin, whose 20 seasons of basketball coaching at Columbus High School in the Bronx and Long Island University have been spent building from the bottom, was named yesterday to coach the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association.

title: 5 Gay Candidates Are in State Contests
description: Five selfproclaimed homosexuals are running as delegates or alternates to the Democratic National Convention from New York State  the first time, activists in the homosexual rights movement say, that avowed homosexuals have ever run for public office here.

title: 6YEAR U.N. FUND FOR ECOLOGY SET
description: STOCKHOLM, June 15The United Nations Conference on the Human Environment today approved plans for a fund of at least $100million to be used by the world organization over the next five years to stimulate environmental preservation efforts.

title: WARNINGS URGED ON PESTICIDE USE
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Senator Gaylord Nelson proposed today that the Administration's pesticide bill be amended to require that foreign nations and international agencies be warned of the dangers of pesticides that are bannel in the United States but are still produced in this country for sale abroad.

title: Mrs. Hilda Dannay Dies; Teacher Was Writer's Wife
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 15 Mrs. Hilda Wiesenthal Dannay, the wife of Frederic Dan may, the mysterystory writer, died of cancer today at her home, 29 Byron Lane. She was 55 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times in particular and the American free press in general are to be commended for enabling a man like Norman Dacey to place a message like his (advertisement June 6) before the people of this nation. The message, regrettably, reveals much of the antiIsrael position to be basically rooted in long discredited myths about world Jewish/Zionist conspiracies accompanied by a magnified pereeption of any weakness of Israeli conduct and a total blindness to Arab wrongdoing.

title: High Levels of Asbestos Found In 3 Paints and 2 Talcums Here
description: Three brands of textured ceiling paint and two brands of talcum powder have been named by the city's Environmental Protection Administration as having heavy asbestosfiber levels that might contribute to lung cancer years after a person inhaled their dust.

title: Institute of Justice Urged
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI)Leon Jaworski, president of the American Bar Association, suggested yesterday the establishment of a national institute of justice to quicken reform of the legal system.

title: BOND ISSUES FIND A COOL RECEPTION
Journey for Peace
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.It is ironic that the man who has just completed the longest journey for peace in our nation's history should be blamed for a war which he did not beginand a war which he more than any of his predecessors in the White House has worked so desperately to end.

title: CHURCH TO STAY IN MERGER TALKS
description: MONTREAT, N. C., June 15  The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) voted today to remain in the Consultation on Church Union, which seeks a merger of Protestant denominations.

title: Judge Grants Writ Barring Sick Calls By Fire Officers
description: State Supreme Court Justice Oliver C. Sutton signed a temporary restraining order yesterday enjoining fire officers from concerted action, in the form of sick reports, as a pressure tactic to force the city to accede to their contract demands.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Referring to the advertisement in The Times of May 31, pages 2223, entitled A Resolution to Impeach Richard M. Nixon as President of the United States, I wish to inform you that neither Ronald Young nor I have given permission to use our names in the manner they were used, as members of the National Executive Committee. We had never been approached on that basis. If we had, we would have refused to give permission to use our names that way.

title: S.E.C. Orders Investigation Of a BrokerDealer Here
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Securities and Exchange commission ordered an investigation today to determine if New York brokerdealer violated Federal securities laws.

title: Verner W. Clapp, Librarian For Library of Congress, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Verner W. Clapp, chief assistant librarian of the Library of Congress from 1947 to 1956, when he became the first president of the Council on Library Resources, died today in Alexandria (Va.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: JAPANESE GROUP POSTS GAIN IN NET
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator McGovern is the Great American Dream made flesh: everyone's instant fairy godmother. Are you poor? You shall be poor no longer. Are you unemployed? You shall be employed. Are you old? You will be provided for, in comfort and dignity. Are you opposed to war? There will be universal peace. Are you blackred brown? You shall sit in the seats of power. Arc you young? Grieve no more. The young shall inherit the earth. Are you rich? Weee...Hm.

title: Rollon, RollOff Vessel to Serve Puerto Rico Trade
description: Transamerican Trailer Transport Inc. announced yesterday that it would place its third highspeed rollon, rolloff vessel into service to Puerto Rico before the end of the year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: My attention has been drawn to an advertisement in The Times of Tuesday, June 6, placed by an individual who writes that he will work for the defeat of President Nixon this year because he finds the President's Middle East policy intolerable.

title: Nuptials for Miss Gural
description: WOODMERE, L. I., June 15 At Congregation Sons of Israel here this evening Miss Barbara Ann Gural and Richard Alan Steinwurtzel, 1972 graduates of Russell Sage and Union Colleges, respectively, were married by Rabbi Saul Teplitz.

title: Bunker Says Civilian Toll Runs Higher Than at Tet
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Ellsworth Bunker, the American Ambassador to Saigon, has reported to Washington that South Vietnam's civilian casualties in the current fighting are running far ahead of those in the 1968 Tet offensive.

title: McCormick, Maloney Retire
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 15 (UPI) Mike McCormick and Jim Maloney, both former top pitchers, retired today after they were bypassed by the major leagues before the trading deadline. Both had been pitching this season for the Phoenix Giants of the Pacific Coast League.

title: New York Races
description: The tone was waspish and the heated rhetoric matched the muggy weather yesterday as some of the Democratic Congressional contenders in Tuesday's primary entered the final days of campaigning with a blitz of accusatory press releases.

title: City Property Tax Rate Due to Rise 9%
description: The basic property tax rate here for, the coming fiscal year will rise about 9 per centor 54 cents; for each $100 of assessed valuationit was estimated unofficially yesterday.

title: Pace of Monetary Growth Slowed Markedly in Week
Muskie to Revive Campaign in State
description: Aides announced today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie would try to revive part of his Presidential campaign in New York with a surprise visit to Buffalo Sunday afternoon.

title: Court of Appeals
description: In the Demodatic primary next week, four judges are contending for three seats that are opening up on the New York Court of Appeals, highest court in the state and one of the most respected in the nation. They will replace justices who reach the mandatory retirement age of 70 this year.

title: Jewish Group Here Addressed by Agnew
description: Vice President Agnew, in a speech sprinkled liberally with Biblical allusions, used an Orthodox Jewish gathering last night to defend the concept of law and order as an outgrowth of the teachings of Moses.

title: Red Smith
description: Willi Daume, president of the Olympic Organizing Committee and thus promoterinchief of this summer's muscle dance in Munich, says Bobby Lee Hunter will not be welcome as a member of the United States boxing team because an Olympic athlete should be an example youth. Hunter is a flyweight doing time for killing a man in a knife fight.

title: M'GOVERN VISITS POLICE IN QUEENS
description: Senator George McGovern, a civil libertarian from South Dakota, assured the men of the 112th police precinct in Queens yesterday that they would have a friend in George McGovern if he got to the White House.

title: C. P. MYERS AND WIFE DIE IN PLANE CRASH
description: PITTSBURGH, June 15Carlisle P. Myers of Fox Chapel, a Pittsburgh suburb, a top executive of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, and his wife, Emma, were among 85 persons killed yesterday in the crash of a Japan Air Lines DC8 near New Delhi.

title: FURTHER GAIN SEEN FOR PRICES OF GOLD
description: Gold prices, which recently have reached record levels, may climb still further, two specialists asserted here yesterday.

title: House Puts a Billion More In Health and School Plans
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The House of Representatives passed legislation today that would increase appropriations for Federal health and education programs in the next fiscal lyear $1.3billion above the sum requested in President Nixon's budget.

title: Texas Proves That the New Delegate Guidelines Work
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 15One day late in 1970, when the McGovern Commission was drafting the reform rules under which the party is selecting its Presidential nominee this year Will D. Davis, the most outspoken critic of the proceedings, told his fellow commission members:

title: Scott Panel official Assails City on Hospital Inquiry
description: The general counsel of the state commission investigating New York City's governmental Operations asserted yesterday that the city's Health and Hos pitals Corporation was a finan cial disaster, and he accused city officials of using obstruclionitt tactics to impede the commission's inquiry into the corporation.

title: BRITISH CRITICS LAUD STOKOWSKI
description: LONDON, June 15  British newspaper critics were unanimous today in their belief that Leopold Stokowski, at the age of 90, is still as good as he ever was.

title: 2 GERMANYS BEGIN TALKS AIMED AT TIES
description: BERLIN, June 15East and West Germany today opened new round of talks aimed at normalizing their relations.

title: Kenton, to Offset Losses, Plans To Dispose of Some Properties
description: The Kenton Corporation, the holding company that in the last few years has acquired several of New York's most prestigious retail stores, announced yesterday that it would sell some of its businesses and had set aside a provision for losses incurred through the sale of $5million before taxes.

title: SelfExpression With Patches On Blue Jeans
description: For Arthur Williamson, they are a pallet and a bathing suit. To Freddy Monserratz they tell a tragic story. By wearing them, Shelley Frankel can look back in delicious sadness; her friend, Nancy Miller, thought them just right for her brother's engagement party. They are jeans. Blue jeans. Denim.
