Faded. flared and torn. Plain or decorated. Either way, essential. But more than clothing, more than an inexpensive pair of pants. Linus may not agree, but blue jeans have replaced the security blanket in the hearts of America's youth.

title: Muskie Mends Fences
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 15Seeking to capture a majority of Utah's 19 votes at the Democratic National Convention, Senator Edmund S. Muskie met last night and this morning with the state party leaders, had breakfast with 300 grassroots workers and made a halfdozen television and radio appearances.

title: Executive Changes
description: Sidney F. Wentz has been advanced to the post of executive vice president of Crum & Forster, large insurance holding company.

title: London Prices Drop
description: LONDON, June 15 (AP) The price of gold fell at London and other European bullion markets today as recent speculative buying interest slackened and some shortterm operators took their profits.

title: TRADING IN BLOCKS IS HEAVY ON AMEX
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A grossly irresponsible advertisement recently published in your newspaper has just been brought to my attention. It quotes me as stating that every liberal Senator receives more than half of his campaign contributions from Zionist sources. I suggest that before permitting quotations of this kind to appear, even in your advertising, columns, it would be desirable to check with the person quoted. In this case, at any rate, the, quotation is an invention.

title: Whitelaw Announces Conference Of the Various Factions in Ulster
description: LONDON, June 15William Whitelaw, Britain's administrator in Ulster, announced today that a conference of the people of Northern Ireland would be held in an attempt to restore peace to the anguished province.

title: Bill Seeks to Nullify Gas Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The El Paso Natural Gas Company, one of the largest interstate pipeline utilities, contended today that, if it was forced to sell a company it acquired in 1957, as the courts have ordered, gas consumers in the Pacific Northwest might suffer.

title: Books of The Times
description: Oh, Gawd, yes... the reviewer understands exactly what L. Rust Hills is getting at in How to Do Things Right: The Revelations of a Fussy Man. As a matter of fact, the reviewer found himself in a perfect doingthingsright situation just last week. There he was, standing thighdeep in an absolutely classic trout pool, snaking out long lazy casts and placing his dry fly just so. All his equipment was in tidy place  his flybox full of flies, his aerosol can for drying them off, his leader pouch, spare line and bottle of Old Woodsman insect repellent  each in its special pocket in his fishingjacket. He was a little arsenal of efficiency, making perfect long casts. Of course, he wasn't taking fish  he wasn't even raising a nibblebut everything was so neat and right that it didn't matter. He felt good about the order of it all, and Mr. Hillswho, when he isn't neatening up around the house, is a magazine fiction editor and teacher of creative writinghas explained why. FUSSINESS IS ITS OWN REWARD, reads a sign that Mr. Hills would post in the bathroom, except that his family has already had bit much of his signs. DISORDER IS THE ULTIMATE EVILORDER IS THE INITIAL GOOD, goes the message on a giant blinking neon sign that Mr. Hills would erect on his roof except that the world might think him daft.

title: Old Partnerships Swing at Benefit
description: The benefit show Wednes day night at Madison Sqbare Garden was for Senator George McGovern, but the musical interest centered on the phoenixlike revival of the old partnerships of Simon and Garfunkel and Peter, Paul and Mary. For seasoning, the reunited comedy team of Elaine May and Mike Nichols and the superb singing of Dionne Warwick were added. The result was one of the best shows of the season.

title: LAFAYETTE NINE TAKES TITLE, 112
description: Alex Scala, a 17yearold righthander from the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, took over the pitching with two out in the second inning yesterday and hurled Lafayette to an 112 victory over Fort Hamilton for the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship in Yankee Stadium.

title: Four Infiltrators Are Killed In Golan Heights by Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, June 15Four men, possibly Syrian soldiers, were killed and two Israelis were wounded today in an encounter on the occupied Golan heights of Syria, It was reported here.

title: Turf Charges Held Unfounded
description: Thoroughbred racing's security czar charged yesterday that headlinemaking material provided by cheap hoodlums was giving the sport an undeserved black eye.

title: Justice Officials Called Furious Over Disclosures by Seymour
description: High Justice Department officials were reported yesterday to be furious with Whitney North Seymour Jr., the United States Attorney for the Southern District, for agreeing to share information with the press concerning a major investigation of possible corruption in the city.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA A  Blues ranging from six to 10 pounds continue to attract fishermen on the north end of Barnegat Ridge. Most catches are being made with smelt, bunker back and mackerel. Bottom fishermen in that area are taking some sea bass and ling. In a 10mile stretch of beach between Manasquan and Sea Side Park, fluke are being taken off the beach. Fishing is reported poor near Surf City, with only a few sharks providing the attraction. Deepsea enthusiasts can go out at midnight on Friday and Saturday nights from Bogan's Basin in Brielle. Reservations on the Jamaica, a party boat, can be obtained by calling 2012234929. The boat goes as far out as 100 miles for tile fish (30 to 50 pounds) with catches

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Bridge: Italians Beaten by Taiwanese For First Loss in Olympiad
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 15The stars of the great Italian Blue Team lost their first match in qualifying stage of the World Bridge Team Olympiad here this afternoon, but seem to have a permanent grip on the leading position. They lost to the young Taiwanese team by the slender margin of 2 international match points, or 9 to 11 in victory points.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 8%
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Department of Commerce announced today that departmentstore sales last week totaled an estimated $859million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $782million. Total retail store sales were $8,569,000,000, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $7,948,000,000.

title: Kennedy and the Vicepresidency
description: WASHINGTON, June 15About 10:30 yesterday morning, Senator Edward M. Kennedy's face turned, as one bystander described it, as red as a man's face can get.

title: Where the Cooking Is French and Fine
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: AUSTRALIAN HALTS GONZALEZ IN 3 SETS
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 15 (AP)Bill Lloyd, a 23yearold Australian, defeated 44yearold Pancho Gonzalez of the United States, 46, 61, 75, in the Kent tennis tournament today.

title: Japan's Payments Surplus Fell to $30Million in May
description: TOKYO, June 15 (Reuters)Japan had a balanceofpayments surplus in May of $30millionthe smallest since January, 1971  the Finance Ministry said today.

title: PRIVATE RITES HELD FOR EDMUND WILSON
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., June 15 The ashes of Edmund Wilson were buried here this afternoon as 30 family members and friends attended a 15minute graveside service at the Wellfleet Cemtery.

title: 21 ARE OVERCOME BY SUBWAY SMOKE
description: Twentyone persons, including 16 firemen, were overcome last night when acrid smoke from an electrical fire filled the IRT subway station at 181st Street and St. Nicholas Avenue in Washington Heights.

title: Advertising:
description: Almost all magazines depend on the mails, so they are naturally fighting the postal rate increases.

title: Surgery Hospital Names New Aide
description: The appointment of Dr. Philip D. Wilson Jr. as surgeoninchief at the Hospital for Special Surgery was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Robert Lee Patterson Jr., who has served as surgeoninchief since 1963 and is retiring on July 1.

title: Black Frees Tax Aide After Governor's Visit
description: MEMPHIS, June 15 (AP)A black cleaningstore operator won a private meeting with Gov. Winfield Dunn tonight as a ransom for a hostage tax agent and then was taken into custody by the police. He met for an hour with the Governor to discuss his concern over problems facing Negroes.

title: Sabotage Clues Sought in Crash of Japanese Airliner in New Delhi
description: TOKYO, June 15 (UPI)Japanese officials refused today to rule out the possibility of sabotage in the crash last night of a Japan Air Lines DC8 jet that killed 87 persons, including 16 Americans, only seconds from landing at New Delhi.

title: Mexican Chief Asks Change in Relations With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 15President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico told a joint session of Congress today that his nation wanted a new phase in relations with the United. States.

title: Bridge Officers Ratify Pact
description: Ratification of a 30month contract retroactive to last July I by the Uniformed Bridge and Tunnel Officers, representing 560 employes of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, was announced last night. Anthony M. Mauro, president of the union, said results of a mail ballot showed approval by 407 to 32. The agreement will lift annual pay by $2,200 to a rate of $12,500 as of July 1 next year.

title: The World of Balanchine Still Awhirl in Creativity
description: George Balanchine is creating, which in his case is a highly visible and sometimes even audible thing. Now we go like this, he says, or, Maybe we should do this. Sometimes, however, he just stands and stares at nothing while his dancers stare at him. All right, he says after a while, we will try it this way.

title: AIRMEN SAY RAIDS ON HANOI ARE OFF FOR POKORNY TRIP
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 15  United States Air Force officers here said today that their planes stopped bombing the Hanoi area yesterday, beginning a fourday pause that would last as long as President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union was there.

title: Ill Trevino Uses 32 Putts and 17 Pills for Healthy 74
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 15  Sniffling and coughing, Lee Trevino took 32 putts and 17 pills today.

title: 81 Die in Civilian Jet Crash Over Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15  An airliner that took off from Bangkok today for a flight to Hong Kong crashed in South Vietnam's Central Highlands, apparently killing all 81 persons aboard.

title: Books of The Times
description: Even if you never get to London this summer these books will be a pleasure to read. If you do, you will find it an additional pleasure to see where you have been. They are not all strictly guide books, unless one counts Lost London a guide to the London he can never see. And the Blue Guide to England covers a lot more than London. Nevertheless each volume contributes to sharpening one's perception of street layouts, of building facades, of the arrangement of squares, of large and small monuments, of the sense and weight of history. To have some idea of the development of the area from Regent's Park to St. James's Park and John Nash's contribution to that development makes an ordinary walk an excursion into the past, even though in places we see only a facsimile of the original. Hermione. Hobhouse's stunning book on the treasures that are gone will alert every visitor to the threatened extinction of those not yet destroyed the graceful Albert Bridge, and St. Pancras Station with its ornamented and towered front, others.

title: The Pentagon Reports No Inquiries on Raids
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Defense Department said today that there are no active investigations under way within the military regarding unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam.

title: South Africans Are Asked To Quit U.S. Track Meet
description: SEATTLE, June 15Faced with a possible walkout by top American athletes, three South African track and field competitors were asked to withdraw from the 84th annual National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor championships today.

title: H.E.W. EASES RULES FOR TREATING POOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it was lowering standards in its proposal to require most of the nation's hospitals to provide minimum amounts of free service to the poor for the first time.

title: Martha Pezrow And Artist Wed At the Regency
description: Miss Martha Joyce Pezrow was married here last evening to Arturo DiModica, a sculptor and painter with a studio and foundry in Florence, Italy. State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Dubin performed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: Phillips Loses Bid to Limit Testimony
description: All eight persons who have identified Patrolman William R. Phillips as having some connection with the 1968 murders of a pimp and his teenage girl companion will be allowed to testify against him at his trial, State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh ruled yesterday.

title: HARVARD HONORS PUSEY AND WIFE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 In a sentimental gesture, Harvard University awarded honorary doctorates today to Nathan M. Pusey, who resigned last year after 18 years as president of Harvard, and to his wife, Anne Woodward Pusey.

title: DDay on Welfare..
description: The Senate Finance Committee is finally nearing an end of its dawdling campaign of sabotage on welfare reform, but it intends to keep polishing the wreckage just long enough to insure that the Senate cannot get around to attempts at reconstruction until after the Democratic National Convention in midJuly.

title: Special Police Heroin Unit Cuts Its Personnel by 39%
description: The staff of the Police Department's Special Investigating Unit, a focal point in the current Federal investigation into bribery by heroin dealers here, has been substantially reduced in recent months.

title: Panama Talks Suspended On Boise Cascade Utility
description: PANAMA, June 15  Three representatives of the Boise Cascade Corporation, including its president, checked out of the Executive Hotel here this morning and caught a jet headed in the general direction of Idaho.

title: BENJAMIN SHERMAN, VENDING EXECUTIVE
description: Benjamin Sherman, who founded in 1926 a vendingmachine business that grew into ABC Consolidated Corporation, a nationwide food and refreshment service organization acquired in 1967 by the Ogden Corporation, died yesterday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 150 Central Park South.

title: 9 Die in Mexico City Floods
description: MEXICO CITY, June 15 (Reuters)Nine persoons were killed early today in flash floods caused by torrential rains on thte outskirts of Mexico City.

title: ExAirtnen Tell of 20 Planned Raids a Month in 7071
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Three former members of a photointelligence team assigned to Pacific Air Force headquarters in Hawaii said in an interview today that at least 20 to 25 planned bombing raids later described as protectivereaction strikes were flown each month by Air Force planes over North Vietnam throughout 1970 and 1971. This number would be more than three times the total of protectivereaction raids officially announced by the Pentagon.

title: Kaufman Sort of Collaborates Again
description: George S. Kaufman and Howard Teichmann, the merry collaborators who set off explosions of laughter in the fifties with the Broadway comedy hit The Solid Gold Cadillac, have collaborated again.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A secondary offering of 300,000 shares of Johnson Products Co., Inc., common stock at $35 per share by a selling shareholder was announced yesterday by Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, manager of an underwriting group. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange closed, yesterday at 35, down .

title: UNIT OF WADDELL SUES BIG BOARD
description: A brokerage subsidiary of Waddell & Reed, the big mutualfund complex, charged yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange's rules against institutional membership amounted to an illegal boycott in violation of the Federal antitrust laws.

title: RailFreight Traffic Down
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended June 10 totaled an estimated 15.9 tonmiles, down 0.2 per cent from the corresponding week last year. Rail carloadings totaled 533,183 cars, down 3.7 per cent from last year.

title: KISSINGER IS ON WAY TO 4TH PEKING VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, left by plane tonight on his fourth journey to Peking.

title: Detour on F.D.R. Drive
description: The City Department of Transportation said yesterday that southbound traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive would be diverted into nearby thoroughfares at the 23d Street exit beginning today from 9 P.M. to 5:30 A.M. and lasting for about two weeks. The detour will be for repairs between 14th and Jackson Streets.

title: Mayor Orders Civil Jail Closed Within 60 Days
description: New York City's Civil Jail, a home away from home for the famous, the infamous and the allbutanonymous for more than 70 years, will close its irongrilled doors within the next 60 days.

title: Nicklaus Is Among 6 at 71 in U.S. Open
Judge Tells Local 1199 Chief to Appear on Monday
description: Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union, was ordered yesterday to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Monday to answer contemptofcourt charges stemming from a work stoppage last Tuesday involving 20,000 hospital workers.

title: BIG BOARD TO WEIGH CHANGE IN DISCIPLINE
description: Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to submit to members constitutional amendments that would revamp Big Board disciplinary procedures.

title: Spans Near Port Hit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 16 (AP)The United States command reported today that of the 14 bridges bombed on Wednesday 9 were hit between the port cities. of Vinh and Donghoi.

title: A Religious Woodstock Draws 75,000
description: DALLAS, June 15 The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, says it's a religious Woodstock.

title: Crowe and His Troupe Bring Bluegrass to Max's
description: Bluegrass music at Max's Kansas City, which made its first appearance several weeks ago when the Country Gentlemen appeared there, is making a second stand there this week with the music of J. D. Crowe and the Kentucky Mountain Boys.

title: STATEN ISLAND LINE USING L.I.R.R. CARS
description: Staten Island Rapid Transit commuters, who have been riding in 47yearold cars, yesterday welcomed 17yearold airconditioned coaches on loan from the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Senate Approves Increase In BlueCollar Wage Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Senate overrode Administration opposition today and passed, 56 to 19, a bill to increase the pay scales of the Government's bluecollar workers as much as 12 per cent above those in private industry.

title: Konstanty Resigns Post
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., June 15 (AP)Jim Konstanty, a former major league pitching star, resigned today as athletic director and chairman of the physical education department at Hartwick College.

title: Bridge Traffic Up 3.8%
description: NEW CASTLE, Del., June 15 (AP)Traffic on the Delaware Memorial Bridge, connecting New Jersey with Delaware, increased 3.S per cent in May over the same month last year, bridge authorities report

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In reading your June 12 editorial on the Scheuer Bingham race for Congress, one would think you were about to endorse Representative Jim Scheuer.

title: Officials in Dakota Ask Nation to Give Cash as Flood Aid
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., June 15Gov. Richard F. Kneip and Mayor Donald V. Barnett appealed today for cash donations to aid the victims of last Friday's flash flood, which wiped out major sections of Rapid City.

title: ROSEMARY CASALS GETS REPRIMAND
description: BRISTOL England, June 15 (AP)Rosemary Casals, a leading United States contender for the Wimbledon tennis title later this month, was subjected to a verbal dressing down for her conduct today by officials at the West of England championships, then was beaten by Mrs. Billie Jean King, 36, 26, in a semifinal match.

title: WINDFALL IS SEEN IN HEALTH PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A citizens organization charged today that six giant insurance companies gained windfall profits totaling $96million from group health insurance plans last year, as a result of the Government's wageprice freeze and the tight job market.

title: Messersmith Has Surgery
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 15 (AP)Andy Messersmith, the California Angels pitcher, had successful surgery today, to repair a torn tendon sheath in the middle finger of his right hand. The Angels said they hoped the righthander would be able to pitch again in about six weeks.

title: Terminology in Air War
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The phrase protective reaction was first used on Oct. 9, 1969, by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, but the practice that it represents had been carried on for almost a year before that.

title: Bernard Ruggieri Elected Head of City's Democrats
description: Bernard Ruggieri was elected unanimouslly yesterday the new chairman of the New York City Democratic Committee.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Envisions Power to All the People
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm, the only woman and the only black running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has a vision of American government.

title: BOMB HOAX AIMED AT CUNARD AGAIN
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2 was the object or another bomb hoax as she docked at Pier 84 yesterday morning, prompting a stemtostern search by her harried crew and a small disappointment for a panting police dog named Brandy.

title: Dance: NewFashioned Falco Troupe
description: It is less than five years since Louis Falco, formerly principal dancer with Jose Limon, formed his own dance company. But in those five years the Falco Company has developed into one of the most interesting around, with a style of its own, even an audience of its own.

title: 19 TO RUN FOR SEAT HELD BY GAMBRELL
description: ATLANTA, June 15Sixteen Democrats and three Republicans have qualified to run in Georgia's United States Senate primary to be held Aug. 8.

title: ClosedEnd Investing Unit Is Sponsored by City Bank
description: The First National City Bank, which last year lost a fiveyear battle in the United States Supreme Court to get into the mutual fund business, announced yesterday that it would sponsor a new, closedend investment company.

title: African Group Criticizes Israel and U.S.
description: RABAT, Morocco, June 15Representatives of 40 African nationsincluding 23 heads of stateended 11 days of meetings here today after agreeing to strongly worded resolutions criticizing Israel's role in the MiddleEastern conflict and the United States role in Rhodesia and in Portugal's African territories.

title: Some Safety Checks Cut
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The House voted, 213 to 154, today to end health and safety inspections by Federal agents in businesses with 25 employes or fewer. If the measure is enacted, an estimated 90 per cent of employers and 30 per cent of the employes covered by the 1970 Occupational Safety and Health Act would be affected.

title: Pacific Telephone Austerity
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 The Pacific Telephone & Telegraph Company today announced a drastic austerity program and put the blame for it on a recent court reversal of rate increases granted last year.

title: Printing Walkout Ends
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 15 (AP)Printing and reproduction workers who staged a oneday strike yesterday were back on the job today as union and management officials negotiated a pay dispute. The 300 members of the International Alliance of Stage and Theatrical Employes Local 780 called off picket lines after the McGregor Werner Company agreed to negotiate. The company has a printing and reproduction services contract at the space center.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four members of a Bronx street gang were arrested early yesterday after a shootout with detectives investigating the killing earlier of a rival gang leader.

title: Vincent Tops MacCracken In Senior Tennis, 75, 61
description: Tony Vincent of New York, the topseeded player, defeated Cal MacCracken of Fort Lee, N. J., 75, 61, in a quarterfinal round singles match yesterday in the Eastern senior tennis championships at the New York Tennnis Club in the Bronx.

title: U.S.C. Nine Stays Alive, Beating Arizona State, 31
description: OMAHA, June 15 (AP) Randy Scarberry, sophomore, spaced seven hits tonight and Southern California earned chance for a third straight National Collegiate baseball title with a 31 victory over Arizona State.

title: Judicial Silence
description: No judicial  or other  canon bars judges from speechmaking, agitating or just plain hollering to attain improvements in the quality of the administration of justice

title: Long Road From Memphis
description: BOSTONThere is a bitter process which we see in operation in this nation at the present time. A number of important, solemn, and inexorable wordseach of which in itself has deep and desperate implication, resonance and connotationcan be defined and neutralized and drained of value by those who write and speak of social change or social revolution in terms which do not have a great deal of direct or practical connection with the things they talk about.

title: U. S.O. Acknowledges Corruption in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The United Service Organizations acknowledged today that charges of currency manipulatioon, blackmarket activities, mail order fraud and other corrupt practices by some of its employes at service clubs in South Vietnam had been substantiated.

title: WILLIAM P. TERRY
description: William P. Terry, vice president in charge of custody administration of the Chemical Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 5 Cambridge Drive, Warren, N. J. He was 55 years old.

title: Lone Star Gas Co. Makes Cash Deal For a Supply Unit
description: The Lone Star Gas Company acquired yesterday the Industrial Gas Supply Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Stone & Webster, Inc., for $13,750,000 cash. The acquisition expands Lone Star's natural gas system into the Gulf Coast market, an area comprising Houston. The oil and gas production properties formerly operated by Industrial Gas are not included in the sale, Stone & Webster said, explaining that these will be operated by a new subsidiary, Enterprise Resources, Inc.

title: For Weekend Chef, an Appetizer and a Dessert
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Giants Get Browns'
description: In an attempt to bolster some weaknesses in their defensive unit, the New York Giants yesterday acquired pair of highly rated football players from the Cleveland Browns.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Bid To Televise Is Rejected
description: An application by Roosevelt Raceway to televise races in partnership with the Offtrack Betting Corporation was rejected yesterday by the State Harness Racing Commission.

title: Market Place: Municipal Bonds For Little Guys
description: Most investors figure that the municipal bond story is strictly a tax story. If you're in a high bracket then you're interested. If you're a bluecollar or even a whitecollar worker, you're not.

title: Kennedy Asks Funds for Mass Transit
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy urged yesterday that the Federal Highway Trust Fund no longer be used exclusively to finance highway construction. He said he would soon introduce legislation so that Money that money from the $5billion fund could be used either for roads or! mass transit, as local officials saw fit.

title: Judge in Busing Case Stephen John Roth
description: DETROIT, June 15A few weeks ago a leader of Michigan's Democratic party sat musing over a drink, contemplating the political disaster to come Who would have thought Steve would have done this? the politician asked. Judge Stephen John Roth of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan had warned that he would probably order black and white children bused between city and suburb. That threat was enough to make the politician's nightmare come trueGeorge C. Wallace won the state's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: ...and on Social Security
description: Even though the House of Representatives has voted a 5 per cent increase in Social Security benefits and the Senate Finance Committee proposes a raise twice that big, the strong mood in Congress appears to be not to stop with either figure but to enact a 20 per cent increase in time to get it into the checks of the elderly before Election Day.

title: ROBERT KLOPSTOCK, THORACIC SURGEON
description: Dr. Robert Klopstock, a noted thoracic surgeon, died yesterday at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 60 West 57th Street.

title: YANKS WIN, 8 T0 1; MURCER, CLARKE HIT 3RUN HOMERS
Laurie Nemiroff and Alan Kur Married
description: Miss Laurie Sue Nemiroff and Alan Kur, Monmouth College graduates, were married here yesterday evening. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony in the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: Tropicana Busily Expanding Citrus Domain
description: BRADENTON, Fla., June 15  Tropicana Products, Inc. the giant citrus processor that today reported record ninemonth earnings  is starting a new national advertising campaign and building a new corrugatedbox plant.

title: American Press Institute Gets 3 New Board Members
description: Three new members have been appointed to the advisory board of the American Press Institute and three other members reappointed, trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday.

title: Charlotte Curtis Is Married To Dr. W. E. Hunt, Surgeon
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 15 Charlotte Curtis, family style editor of The New York Times, and Dr. William E. Hunt, neurosurgeon, were married here this afternoon.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 3.6 Million Fowl Killed in Drive To Halt a Deadly Avian Disease
description: Federal and state health officials in California and Arizona have killed 3.6 million domestic fowl and have given 61.5 million immunizations to other birdsmostly chickens and turkeyssince last March in the largest program to combat an avian disease in this country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The usefulness of gun controls is not just doubtful, but actually dangerous. Most criminals today already have their guns illegally, unavailable to respectable citizens.

title: Hail to Sunshine Train
description: The Sunshine Train calls itself a joyous gospel musical and indeed it is. Without being theater in the least, or the least bit theatrical, this is a 90minute concert of rhythmic, soulfelt songs in simple tribute to the Almighty. It may be exactly what Fun City could use at the moment.

title: Samuel Goldman, 88, Dies; Retired School Principal
description: Samuel Goldman, who retired in 1952 as principal of Public School 16 in Brooklyn, died in his sleep Wednesday at his home, 4311 Smart Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 88 years old.

title: PARIS AND MOSCOW REITERATE AMITY;
description: PARIS, June 15  France and the Soviet Union found themselves in broad agreement today on problems in Europe, the Middle East and Southeast Asia after a threeday official visit by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: REFORM RABBI SAYS MORE LOOK TO PAST
description: GROSSINGER, N, Y., June 15A movement to revive within Reform Judaism some longignored Jewish laws and disciplines was started here this week at the annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

title: A.T.&T. EARNINGS REAM A RECORD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday record revenues for the three and 12 months ended May 31, Net income for the May quarter was also at a new high for the period.

title: Deal With Gray Line Ends Avenue Coach Receivership
description: Receivership of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its whollyowned subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., has been terminated as a result of an agreement consummated yesterday with the Gray Line Corporation.

title: Freedom to Advertise
description: On this page today we publish a small selection from the several hundred letters The Times has received in protest against two advertisements that appeared in this newspaper on May 31 and June 6 respectively. The first of these advertisements, signed by a group of citizens calling themselves The National Committee for Impeachment, denounced President Nixon for continuing prosecute the war in Vietnam in alleged violation of law and the Constitution, and demanded his removal from office. The second of the two advertisements consisted an open letter to the President signed by one Norman Dacey, bitterly attacking Mr. Nixon for a Middle East policy in allegedly blind support of Israel.

title: Security Council Extends Cyprus Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15The Security Council voted today to extend for six months the stationing of the United Nations peacekeeping force on Cyprus.

title: J. R. PRENTICE DIES; CATTLE BREEDER, 69
description: CHICAGO, June 15J. Rockefeller Prentice, a retired cattle breeder and a member of prominent Chicago family, died on Tuesday at his home in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 69 years old.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: ONLY 4 DAYS TO GO BEFORE THE BIRTH OF TILE NEW WORLD: A MAGAZINE ADDRESSED TO THE LIFE OF TILE MIND. ADVT.

title: TV: Complexities in Class... and the Classroom
description: Class... and the Classroom, presented Tuesday evening on Channel 13's Dateline 13, was the third and final program in a Group W series called The Search for Quality Education. Filmed in Duluth, Minn., the documentary focused on two segregated elementary schools and two segregated high schools. The segregation in these cases, however, was not by race but by income and social status, and the State Board of Education has suggested desegregation along socioeconomic lines.

title: 6 U.S. Soldiers Killed In Vietnam Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (UPI)Six Americans were killed in combat last week, five fewer than the week before, the United States command reported today.

title: Miss Krintzman Bride Of Richard Birnbaum
description: Miss Linda Sue Krintzman was married here last evening to Richard Scott Birnbaum. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: FOOD CHAINS WARN OF BIG PRICE RISES; U.S WEIGHS MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Major retail food chains and their trade organizations are quietly warning consumer organizations that a sharp rise in food prices is under way and asking that retailers not be blamed.

title: 12 IN CONGRESS SEEK RIGHT TO REPLY ON T.V
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  Led by Senator Harold Hughes, Democrat of Iowa, a dozen members of Congress complained officially yesterday that the three major television networks had refused to sell them time to reply to President Nixon's position on the Vietnam war..

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Perhaps the advertisement entitled A Letter to the President which appeared in The Times on June 6, is not worthy of comment and should be ignored as the bitter and false diatribe that it is.

title: SOVIET CONCEDES SOME OPPOSITION TO SUMMIT TALKS
description: MOSCOW, June 15  Soviet leaders acknowledged today that they had faced opposition in their decision to go ahead with the summit talks with President Nixon after the United States mined North Vietnam's ports last month.

title: Starving Afghan Children Await Death Along Roads
description: CHAKHCHARAN, Afghanistan, June 9The boy's spindly body sank slowly to the dusty gravel road. He lowered his head to the pebbles, resting his sunken cheek on his hand. His dry, cracked lips did not close. He tried to cover his feet, but the torn, dirtencrusted rags he wore were not long enough. He placed an empty tin can, his only possession, near his stomach. And then he started to cry.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Thank you for giving aid and comfort to the enemy by publishing A Resolution to Impeach.

title: LITTON DISPUTED ON SHIP CONTRACT
description: Litton Industries, Inc., disclosed yesterday.that its problemridden new Mississippi shipyard had begun construction of DD963class destroyers six months ahead of the contract schedule.

title: Meadowlands Given GoAhead on Racing
description: TRENTON, June 15The New Jersey Racing Commission today gave the state Sports and Exposition Authority permission to conduct harness and thoroughbred racing meetings in a proposed $33million race track in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: NearAccord on Declaration
description: STOCKHOLM, Friday, June 16 (UPI)The United Nations conference on the Human Environment early today reached partial agreement on its general declaration of principles, but China refused to budge on the issue of nuclear weapons, conference officials said.

title: Newport Base Shifts Chief
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 15 (AP) Capt. Richard E. Rumble, a naval aviator, has been named the new commander of the Newport Naval Base, effective June 30. He will replace Rear Adm. Robert R. Crutchfield, who is retiring.

title: Buffet II Defeats Une de Mai By 5 Lengths in Paris Troi
description: PARIS, June 15  Pierre Alaire leaned miserably against the post in the jockey's room and it wasn't because his Une de Mai had been beaten by five lengths today. Allaire, coowner of the 8yearold mare who has won more money (more than $1.5million) than any other trotter in history, was disconsolate because he had been unable to buy the horse that trounced Une de Mal, a 5 yearold named Buffet II.

title: STUART D. PRESTON, INSURANCE OFFICER
description: Stuart D. Preston, a former banker and insurance company executive, died yesterday at his home, 125 East 72d Street. He was 88 years old.

title: Railroads Press Request For Rise in Freight Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  The nation's railroads pursued today their request for an increase in freight rates before the Interstate Commerce Commission amid strong opposition from their customers.

title: THIS IS THE ARMY 30 YEARS LATER
description: Nostalgia flowed like Niagara Fallsmassively and unabashedly. They came from London, California, Florida, Ohio, Indiana, Baltimore, Minnesota and New York to embrace vigorously, pat one another's backs affectionately and greet each other emotionally.

title: A.I.D. UNIT QUITS; RIGHTS LAG CITED
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Equal Opportunity Advisory Committee of the Agency for International Development has dissolved itself, accusing the agency of failing to adequately hire and promote minorities.

title: Kentucky May Declare
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., June 15 (AP)Gov. Wendell Ford hopes to announce Monday that the overwhelming majority of Kentucky's 37 uncommitted delegates to the Democratic National Convention will vote for Mr. Muskie for President.

title: SENATE BARS AID TO ANTIRED UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Senate voted today to cut off funds for the Subversive Activities Control Board, an agency created by Congress 22 years ago at the height of the antiCommunist movement in government.

title: STOCK MANIPULATOR HELD FOR CONTEMPT
description: Sidney Stein, 46 years ,old, who is fighting a twoyear prison sentence for stock manipulation, was jailed yesterday on a Federal court order for contempt in refusing to file reports of his stock transactions.

title: Mormons Criticized
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 15 (UPI)The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) told the Mormon church today that its 1975 assembly would not be held in Salt Lake City because a spokesman said The Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints denied the priesthood to blacks.

title: NIXON MAKES PLEA FOR ARMS ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 15President Nixon told about 100 key members of Congress today that, despite the two strategic arms limitation agreements, signed in Moscow last month, Soviet leaders had made it absolutely clear that they would go ahead with the development of offensive weapons systems not barred by the accords.

title: PPG Industries Increases Its Prices on Two Solvents
description: PPG Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it was raising market prices for methylene chloride by 1.5 cents a pound, and for orthodichlorobenzene by 1 cent a pound, effective immediately on spot sales, and July 1 on contract sales.

title: PAYSON J. TREAT, 92, STANFORD HISTORIAN
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 15Dr. Payson Jackson Treat, a noted historian who retired in 1945 after more than 40 years of teaching at Stanford University, died today at his home, 750 Dolores Street, on the Stanford campus. He was 92 years old.

title: Senator Griffin in Race
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, announced today his candidacy for reelection. His opponent will be chosen in the Michigan Congressional primary election in August.

title: Mrs. Ruth Krefetz Dead; Writer and Artist Was 49
description: Mrs. Ruth Marossi Krefetz, writer and artist, drowned last Saturday in a boating accident in Moriches Bay, off Long Island. She was 49 years old and lived at 463 West Street.

title: Notes on People
description: Owen Lattimore, a former State Department China expert, found the setting considerably more congenial than two decades ago as ho appeared before a Congressional committee that is studying China.

title: MANPOWER WASTE REPORTED IN AUDIT
description: A state audit has found that extra holidays granted to 9,200 Board of Education administrative employes cost the city $1.4million this year.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Favorable crop growing weather brought futures prices for grains and soybeans down again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Edgar Stern Weds Mrs. Zita Davisson
description: Mrs. Zita Davisson of New York and Edgar Stern of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., were married yesterday at the home of the bride by State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold.

title: Advertising:
description: Wyatt Cooper, who was editor of Status Magazine, a societytype publication, is now editor of The Magazine, which will make its debut (175,000 copies strong) in October. Gloria Kins, who had been New York office editor of Holiday, will be publisher.

title: Lesser Plea in Heroin Case Described
description: A narcotics detective told all a joint legislative committee here yesterday that a man he had arrested for the possession of a sizable quantity of heroin and five illegal weapons was permitted to plead guilty to attempted possession of a dangerous weapon.

title: Senator Omitted From List
description: Because of an error in an announcement by the New York Civil Liberties Union, the name of State Senator Harrison J. Goldin, DemocratLiberal of the Bronx, was omitted from an article on voting records in The New York Times last Sunday. Mr. Goldin should have been listed as one of four State Senators and an Assemblyman who scored perfect 100 per cent ratings in a civil liberties voting index of the 1972 session of the State Legislature published recently by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: U.S. Is Disbanding Major Combat Unit In South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16One of the last two major American combat units here is being deactivated to meet President Nixon's deadline for reducing United States troop strength in South Vietnam to 49,000 by the end of June.

title: Physicist Sues Two Nobel Laureates
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 16 (AP)A nuclear physicist has filed suit against two scientists, alleging that they discovered antimatter and won the 1959 Nobel Prize in physics by using an idea he originated.

title: FOREST OIL REPORTS FIND ON NORTH SLOPE
description: The Forest Oil Corporation said yesterday that it had discovered hydrocarbons in apparent commercial quantities at its No. 1 Kemik wildcat well on the North Slope of Alaska.

title: 350 LaidOff Workers Of G.M. Unit Recalled
description: The Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had recalled 350 more laidoff workers in Dayton, Ohio. and was planning to return 150 more to their jobs during the (next several weeks, increasing the total brought back to work to 3,000 by the end of June.

title: Vann Gets Hero's Burial And Medal of Freedom
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) John Paul Vann, the most renowned United States adviser in the Vietnam war, today was given a hero's burial and the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award.

title: KIRKE L SIMPSON, PULITZER WINNER
description: LOS GATOS, Calif., June 16 (AP)  Kirke L. Simpson, a Pulitzer Prize winner in 1921 for his Associated Press story on the burial of the Unknown Soldier, died here today at the age of 90.

title: Churchill Library Named A National Historic Site
description: ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP)The Winston Churchill Memorial and Library at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., has been declared a National Historic Site by the National Park Service, Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, announced today.

title: Dance: A Stylish Group
description: New York loves originals. The Louis Falco Dance Company, now making its Lincoln Center debut, has a freshness that is all its own. Its second program of its alltoobrief encounter with the Alice Tully Hall emerged Thursday night and showed this stylish young company at its best.

title: PFINGST DISCLAIMS BUYING JUDGESHIP
description: State Supreme Court Justice Joseph P. Pfingst took the stand at his bribery trial yesterday to denounce as lies testimony that he had paid $50,000 for his judicial nomination in 1968.

title: Du Pont Acquires Patents
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had acquired United States and Canadian rights to certain chromiumplating patents, technology and trademarks from the Diamond Shamrock Corporation for an undisclosed consideration. This marks du Pont's entry into the chromeplating field.

title: Revolution in Virginia
description: In a year of political upheavals, no party has undergone a more dramatic shift in control than the Democrats of Virginia. For nearly a half century, the ruling party in the Old Dominion was tightly controlled by the late Senator Harry Flood Byrd Sr. and his personal organization based on the rural courthouses. Poll taxes and other more subtle forms of discrimination and social pressure kept the voting turnout lowamong poor whites and Negroes. Rebels against organization discipline found themselves politically ostracized.

title: Rain Cancels Chisholm Rallies but Her Spirits Are Undampened
Soviet Effort for Vietnam Peace Hinted by Russian
description: MOSCOW, June 16The first suggestions emerged here today that the Soviet leadership might be engaged in a diplomatic effort to persuade North Vietnam to accept President Nixon's proposal for ceasefire in place.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In the 24hour period ended at 6 A.M. yesterday, 176 firemen and officers reported sick or injured after fires as the officers continued to put pressure on the city to conclude a contract with them. And there was a sharp increase in sick and injured reports between 6 A.M. and 3 P.M. yesterday, compared with daily reports earlier in the week.

title: Bracelet That Stands For a Cause
description: During a nationally televised debate last week just before the California primary, Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles pointed to the other candidates for the Democratic party's Presidential nomination and proclaimed that he was the only one on this panel who is wearing a P.O.W. bracelet.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With all the candidates in New York City for various Federal offices making charges and countercharges about many issues before Primary Day, there seems to be an absence of comment or leadership in the housing field. Yet, ironically, Senator John Sparkman of Alabama, who is chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee which has jurisdiction over housing, has the following to say about the situation in New York City:

title: Milk Price Up From Pennies
description: GOODLAND, Kan., June 16 (AP)The price of milk rebounded today in Goodlandto 23 cents a gallon. The low point in a twoweek price war was three cents a gallon. Milk was selling at $1.11 a gallon when one store cut its price to 85 cents, and the price wet began.

title: Federal Rule for Miners
description: The decision of Secretary of Labor Hodgson to appoint monitors to supervise all affairs of the United Mine Workers pending a new courtordered election of union officers was necessary for the protection of membership rights in that abysmally mismanaged union.

title: SECURITY NATIONAL SEES A TAX REFUND
description: The Security National Bank, Huntington, L. I., expects to gain a $1.9million Federal tax refund as a result of a series of transactions taken in connection with its recent merger with the Royal National Bank, the bank said yesterday, in a statement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your May 29 editorial concerning the plight of higher education institutions in New York City called for the Board of Regents to bring together the leadership of all the city's colleges and, under the direction of a small group of independent experts, to set forth realistic choices.

title: Marine Engineers Reach Accord on 3Year Contract
description: The 11,000member Marine Engineers Beneficial Association and the Maritime Service Committee and the Tanker Service Committee, two major; shipowner groups, announced late yesterday that they had reached agreement on a new threeyear contract.

title: JOHNSTON SONGS NOT SO IRISH NOW
description: The Johnstons, a singing trio that was thoroughly Irish when it made its first appearance here last fall, returned to Folk City this week, slightly changed in personnel and not quite as Irish as before.

title: $9,000 Taken at Post Office
description: After locking four postal Service employes in a mail truck at a South Bronx post office, two gunmen escaped yesterday afternoon with mailbags containing more than $9,000 in cash and checks. One employee was struck in the head with a revolver, but no one was seriously hurt in the incident at the post office, at Southern Boulevard and 167th Street.

title: Mets Defeat Reds, 21, in 9th On Triple and Wild Pitch
Susan's Girl to Face 7 Filly Rivals in $110,600 Oaks
description: The Coaching Club American Oaks will have a gross value of $110,600 if all eight start in the 1mile classic at Belmont Park today. The race is the third part of the triple crown for 3yearold fillies, preceded by the Acorn and the Mother Goose.

title: Allende Names New Cabinet Today in Effort to End Crisis
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 16President Salvador Allende Gossens said today that he would name a new Cabinet tomorrow in an attempt to overcome serious divisions within Chile's governing leftwing coalition.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 16Against a backdrop of windbent cypress trees, Julius Boros was swinging his driver easily on the first tee. Nearby, also about start their second rounds of the United States Open golf championship, Jack Nicklaus and Lanny Wadkins peered up the fairway. Behind a yellow rope, two small blondhaired boys in white golf shoes hurried along, like two golden bear cubs who had wandered out of the Del Mont woods.

title: City Ballet Opens Salute To Stravinsky Tomorrow
description: The New York City Ballet will open its weeklong stravinsky festival tomorrow night with a fanfare to be trumpeted from one of the terraces of the promenade of the State Theater.

title: F.D.A. WEIGHS BAN ON A CATTLE FEED
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Food and Drug Administration threatened today to ban chemical widely used to enhance the growth of livestock unless ways can be found to keep it out of food.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A doorway monitor to detect thefts of small quantities of plutonium, the valuable reactor fuel, was patented this week for the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your May 29 editorial Piecemeal Into Disaster clearly makes some points that have hitherto been allowed to remain either unanalyzed or surrounded by secrecy.

title: PROSECUTOR SAID TO FACE CHARGES IN BRIBERY STUDY
DR. OTTO PICKHARDT, LENOX HILL SURGEON
description: DORSET, Vt., June 16  Dr. Otto C. Pickhardt, a member of the Department of Surgery of Lenox Hill Hospital in New York since 1914 and its director from 1945 to 1952, died on Tuesday. He was 84 years old. In recent years he had been a consultant to the hospital.

title: Sato Retiring as Premier; Led Japanese for 7 Years
Dartmouth Gets Grant
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Representative James C. Cleveland, Republican of New Hampshire, said today that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency had granted Dartmouth College $24,815 for a research project involving simulation of urban pressures on the environment of a river basin.

title: Girl Dies in Crash Of a Bus in Jersey On a P.A.L. Outing
description: A teenage girl was killed and several other persons were injured when a bus returning from a Police Athletic League outing in New Jersey went Out of control yesterday evening on a narrow rural road in Somerset County and crashed into a tree.

title: Screen:; What Became of Jack and Jill? Heads Neighborhood Twin Bill
Forest Service Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)Rexford A. Resler, of Portland, Ore., was named today associate chief of the Forest Service. He succeeds John R. McGuire, who became chief of the Forest Service April 30.

title: Harvey Hanover'sTrainer Eyes Upset in Dexter Cup
TOKYO UNIT CLEARED FOR MERRILL LYNCH
description: TOKYO, June 16 (AP)The Foreign Investment Council, an advisory body to the Finance Minister, gave approval today for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc. of the United States, to open a branch office in Tokyo, ministry officials said.

title: IRVING SENTENCED TO 2TERM
description: Clifford Irving, who tried to swindle McGrawHill, Inc., out of more than $750,000 with a bogus autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, the industrialist, was sentenced yesterday to two and a half years in prison, while his wife and researcher received lesser terms.

title: U.N. PARLEY ENDS BY ADOPTING GUIDE TO POLLUTION WAR
description: STOCKHOLM, June 16 The United Nations environ.; mental conference ended tonight with the adoption of a muchdebated declaration of principles to serve as a guide for an international fight on pollution.

title: 178 Are Off to Fast Start In Bermuda Ocean Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 16The start of the ocean race to Bermuda was a brilliant success here today. The fleet of 178 yachts, a recordbreaking entry for this 66yearold event, got away under a spanking 18knot southwest breeze at near their best speed on a close reach.

title: A Pentagon Gimmick
description: WASHINGTONSoon after Presitent Nixon's return from Moscow urgng approval of the most significant armscontrol agreement of our time, its Secretary of Defense went before Congress arguing for increased funds to modernize our offensive strategic armaments. The Pentagon has found a new gimmick to obtain monies for new weaponsarmscontrol 'negotiaions. When Soviet threats lag, when military requirements evaporate and when demands for reprograming of scarce resources to civilian needs besome strident, then is the time that the weaponeers turn to arms control for their sustenance.

title: Rumania Leads Cup Semifinals
description: VIENNA, June 16 (UPI)Rumania took a 10 lead today over Italy in the Opening singles of their semifinal European Zone Davis Cup competition.

title: I.T.T. Trading Halted
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted all trading in International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation stock yesterday pending the filing of Securities and Exchange Commission charges against the company. An exchange spokesman said he presumed the stock would be traded Monday, although there could be a slight delay In the opening.

title: HOUSING STARTS ADVANCED IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Housing starts rose in May after an April dip and generally are maintaining their booming pace, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sales of Vodka Cut Sharply by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 16The Soviet Government ordered a sharp reduction today in the sale of vodka, and expanded the output of soft drinks in an intensified drive against heavy drinking.

title: TERRORIST LEADER SEIZED IN GERMANY
description: BONN, June 16The state police in Hanover today announced the capture of Ulrike Meinhof, a founding member of a leftist terrorist group known popularly as the BaaderMeinhof gang.

title: Cracking Down on Habitual Offenders
description: America historically has been the least restrictive of nations on many issues. But compared with the penalties for convicted drunk drivers in other countries, she may be accused of a fatal permissiveness on the highways, which takes 55,000 lives each year.

title: 3 Presidential Aspirants At Black Caucus Dinner
Public's Faith In Business Has Declined, Survey Finds
description: The public's confidence in business operations has seriously eroded in the last seven years, according to a survey by the Opinion Research Corporation. Its national sampling of 4,059 people reported that 60 per cent disapproved of business, compared with 47 per cent in 1965.

title: 2 Seized Here in Theft
description: Two men were seized by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a midtown hotel yesterday and charged with the unlawful possession of $1million in bank money orders that had been stolen last year from the Federal Savings and Loan Association in Ponce, Puerto Rico. They were identified as Dennis O. Tyers, 27 years old, of Oceanside, L. I., and Aaron M. Finkelstein, 37, of Wantagh, L. I.

title: U.S. Court Orders Mine Union to Hold Supervised Election
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A Federal District Court judge ordered new elections today for the leadership of the United Mine Workers of America and he outlined strict procedures to govern the union's activities until Jan. 1.

title: Japanese Is Indicted In Killings in Israel; Faces Death Penalty
description: TEL AVIV, June 16A Japanese was indicted before a military court today on charges punishable by death in the massacre May 30 at Tel Aviv's airport.

title: Let's Go to the Moon Together
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect of astronauts and cosmonauts chummily tooling around at 167 miles above the earth raised hardly a ripple when it was announced at the Moscow meetings. The same cannot be said for John F. Kennedy's attempt to cooperate in space with the Soviets nine years ago. His failure provides an example of the differing methods of Kennedy the idealist and Nixon the pragmatist.

title: Woman Joins Iowa Guard
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, June 16 (UPI)  An 18yearold girl, maintaining she was not doing anything for the sake of women's liberation, became toaday the first woman member of the Iowa National Guard. Julie Anderson of Webster City was sworn in by Gov. Robert D. Ray at ceremonies in the statehouse. In a week she will start six weeks of basic training at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, Tex.

title: Army Retreats on Beauty
description: DENVER, June 16 (UPI)The Army first said no when two Wacs asked if they could enter the Miss Black Colorado beauty pageant. But when military public affairs experts told the Pentagon that having beauty queens in the ranks could help the Army's effort to modernize its image, the answer became yes. Three generals gave their approval yesterday for specialist 4 Rosetta Phillips, 25 years old, of Paterson, N. J., and Pvt. Alma McClain, 19, of Chicago, to ?? the ??

title: State Inquiry on Drug Prosecutions Angers Gold
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn yesterday angrily challenged a study of the State Joint Legislative Commitfee on Crime that indicated that his office performed comparatively poorly in prosecuting heroin traffickers.

title: Trains Crash in Tunnel In France, Killing 29
description: SOISSONS, France, Saturday, June 17 (UPI)Two passenger trains traveling in opposite directions last night smashed almost simultaneously itno a heap of cement and stone inside a partly collapsed railway tunnel near this town north of Paris.

title: An 1800's Artist at One With Nature
description: The 19thcentury American landscapist and marine painter William Trost Richards was an artist who had clout in his day. He lived comforta,bly through numerous commissions, he was recogniZed as a consequential talent by the academies and his work was hung in the best museums in the country. But the modernist 20thcentury has shunned Richards. and many other artists of his time. It perhaps found his interpretations of the Eastern seaboard and the New York and Rhode island landscapes a little too sentimental and idealized and somewhat anachronistic for an austere technological society.

title: S.E.C. Charges I. T.T. With Stock Deals
description: WASHINGON, June 16The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and two of its top officials were accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission today of illegal dealings in the company's stock at a time when they knewbut the public did notthat an antitrust suit against the company was about to be settled.

title: Suzi Smith Is Bride of Neil Reyer
description: WEST ORANGE. N.J., June 16Miss Suzi Diane Smith was married here this evening to Neil Reyer. The nonsectarian ceremony, which was written by the couple, was performed in the garden at the Manor by the Rev. Dr. Tracey K. Jones Jr., general secretary of the Board of Missions of the United Methodist Church, in New York.

title: Merger News
description: Grand Metropolitan Hotels, Ltd., announced yesterday in London that it had increased its previous $1.04billion bid to acquire Watney Mann, Ltd., the multinational brewing, distilling and pub empire.

title: Opera: Change of Crown
description: Ruggero. Raimondi put on the crown of Philip II, King of Spain, for the second Don Carlo of the Metropolitan Opera's Verdi Festival on Thursday night, replacing Nicolai Ghiaurov. Like so many other star attractions listed in the prefestival publicity, Mr. Ghiaurov is indisposed. The epidemic of cancellations has put a strain on the Met's casting department as well as, perhaps, on the credulity of its patrons.

title: AIRLINE STOPPAGE ORDERED MONDAY
description: The international pilots organization announced yesterday that it had taken irreversible steps to carry out on Monday its threatened 24hour stoppage of airline. traffic throughout the world to dramatize demands for sterner measures against hijacking.

title: Honor for Former Speaker
description: BOSTON, June 16 (AP)On a voice vote, the Massachusetts House has passed and sent to the Senate a bill to name a new state office building in Boston after former United States Representative John W. McCormack, Speaker of the House until he retired two years ago.

title: BRONX ZOO OPENS WORLD OF BIRDS
description: The World of Birds at the Bronx Zoo made its public debut yesterday, and judging from the reactions of the thousands of visitors, the new ornithological wonderland is a spectacular success for young and old and inbetween.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Bloomingdale's may not have planned it that way, but it so happens that a recent collection of imports antique porcelains from China and Japanis balanced by a collection that couldn't be more American: wool rugs handwoven by Navajo Indians. The Chinese imports include vases, bowls, jars and snuff bottles. All of them arc oneofakind and most of them have certificates of antiquity issued by the Hong Kong Art Crafts Merchants Association.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of Erie County and a former professional football quarterback, during his first year and a half in the House has become one of the more aggressive Congressional supporters of President Nixon. This week Mr. Kemp assailed one of his Republican colleagues, Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, who ran against Mr. Nixon in some of the early Republican Presidential primaries.

title: Airbus Photos, at Venice, Show Power
description: VENICE, ItalyWhen the American photographer Diane Arbus died last year at the age of 48, she had already become a legend and an influence among serious photographers of the younger generation. Her fame was just beginning to penetrate the world of critics and collectors who, still uncertain of their attitude toward photography in general, seemed nonetheless ready to make a cult of this particular photographer. Her work had recently been published on the cover of a monthly journal. Artforum; normally devoted to abstract art, and her name was rapidly acquiring the semimythical status our culture confers upon artists who specialize in extreme and unfamiliar experience.

title: FINANCING IS SET BY FORD AND UNIT
description: The Ford Motor Company and a wholly owned subsidiary announced yesterday a $325million financing package to be raised publicly and by placement with the Ford Foundation.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: STOCKHOLM, June 16An observer at the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment said longingly the other day that it needed Thomas Jefferson  someone who could lift the delegates above their parochial concerns and rally them behind a contemporary equivalent of the call for life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

title: Alexander's Shows Loss Of $865,000 for Quarter
description: Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's leading retailers, had net loss of $865,000 in the third fiscal quarter against a net profit of $211,000, or 4 cents a share, in the corresponding 1971 period.

title: Bankruptcy Rise Feared In WagePrice Program
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The wage and price controls program is beginning to create what Administration officials call unforeseen disturbances in the economy that could lead to widespread bankruptcies and other dislocations in the marketplace.

title: F.T.C. and du Pont Agree In Complaint on Antifreeze
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commisson agreed today to settlement of its complaint against E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co. for marketing Zerex antileak antifreeze allegedly with the knowledge that it could damage auto cooling systems.

title: William H. Berry Dead at 63; Headed Insurance Pool Here
description: William H. Berry, executive vice president of the Continental Insurance Companies, 80 Maiden Lane, died yesterday at his home in Summit, N. J. He was 63 years old.

title: Pilot Dies in Plane He Built
description: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill., June 16 (AP)Loren Brightman, 30 years old, of Schaumburg, a United Air Lines pilot, died yesterday in a crash of his homebuilt aircraft in a marsh southwest of the Crystal Lake Airport.

title: Judson Reis Weds Kathryn A. Fortuin
description: Miss Kathryn Ann Fortuin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Floyd Fortuin of Wyckoff, N. J., was married here last evening to Judson Patterson Reis in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Norman D. Stanton. A reception was held at the New York Junior League.

title: Father's Day Shoppers Crowd the Stores
description: Mrs. Peggy Koppel of Caracas, Venezuela, walked through Macy's yesterday with her small daughter and her motherinlaw to find the right Father's Day gift for her husband. She stopped at the toiletries counter of the Herald Square store and purchased an Aramis aftershave and cologne set for $6.96.

title: BRITISH DOCK STRIKE AVERTED
description: LONDON, June 16An unofficial national dock strike was averted today when an appeals court saved three picketling dockers from jail.

title: Market Place: Funds Cramped In Telling Story
description: The radio pitch began by telling the listener how to get rich and it extolled a savings bank and what it could do for the saver over a period of 40 years of regular savings.

title: MUSKIE VOWS FIGHT ON DEFENSE BUDGET
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16Senator Edmund S. Muskie paused during his 10state political tour today to assail President Nixon's defense budget and vowed to lead the fight against it in the Senate.

title: The Oldest of These Gourmet Chefs Is 15
description: The quiche Lorraine came out of the oven, a goldenbrown dream.

title: 4 J.D.L. Members Held in Bombings
description: Four members of the Jewish Defense League were arrested yesterday in the firebombings last Jan. 26 of two Manhattan talent booking agencies that handle Soviet artists.

title: New York Races
description: Five candidates for three vacancies on the State Court of Appeals visited the drab, overcrowded facilities of the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island yesterday to talk with inmates and inspect living conditions.

title: Paine, Webber Discussing A Merger With Shearson
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. and Shearson, Hammill & Co. Inc., two of the nation's largest brokerage houses, disclosed yesterday that they had undertaken a study to determine the feasibility of merging.

title: Asian Parley Ends With Acceptance of Peking on Rise
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 16The Asian and Pacific Council, an organization for economic, social, cultural and technical cooperation among nine East Asian and South Pacific countries, ended its seventh annual ministerial meeting here today with a communique that called for open membership. as Pote Sarasin of Thailand, left, and Kim Yong Shik, Foreign Minister of South Korea, sat looking on. Ninecountry meeting stressed open membership policy.

title: Minister of the Interior Resigns in South Africa
description: CAPETOWN, June 16Theo Gerdener, Minister of the Interior, announced his resignation tonight.

title: U.S. GAINS 2I LEAD IN WIGHTNIAN CUP
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 16  With America's established stars elsewhere, 17yearold Chris Evert stepped into the breach today and won from Virginia Wade in the key match that gave the United States surprising 21 lead over Britain in the opening matches for the Wightman Cup in tennis.

title: POUND IS BACKED BY CENTRAL BANKS
description: PARIS, June 16The pound was supported today by the central banks of West Germany, France and Belgium in what is likely to become the first major test of the Common Market's new monetary unification efforts.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
F.C.C. Sets Open Sky Policy on Satellite Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission voted 4 to 3 today for an open sky policy that would permit all qualified applicants to provide communication satellite service for the transmission of television, telephone, telegraph and computer data signals.

title: ARMS NETWORK SOUGHT IN ROME
description: ROME, June 16The police said today that they were investigating what looked like clandestine network trafficking in arms destined for Middle Eastern countries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am very interested in how your pensioners manage on their retirement pensions in the face of terrific rises in food prices, rents, etc. My husband retired as a metal polisher at age 65 after paying National Health premiums and taxes for fifty years. Having never paid any. myself and being fourteen months older than my husband, I had to wait until he reached 65 before could draw my pension of 3.70. His is 6.30.

title: Talc Warning Is Labeled False
description: The medical researcher who did tests on asbestos in baby powder for the city's Environmental Protection Administration charged yesterday that the agency had misinterpreted his analyses and published false data.

title: President Lines to Move From Jersey to Brooklyn
description: The American President Lines, a Major cotnainership operator that has been doing business on the New Jersey side of the harbor for the last 45 years, has decided to move to the Northeast Terminal project in Brooklyn.

title: WifeHusband Team to Head Bennington
description: Bennington College in Vermont has chosen a 29yearold Harvard professor, Gail Main Parker, as its next president and her husband, Thomas, an administrator at Harvard, as vice president.

title: U.S. Planes Raid MIG Bases in North but Shun Hanoi
description: SAIGON, Soulh Vietnam, Saturday, June 17The United: States command reported yesterday that American planes struck at three MIG air bases and other North Vietnamese: targets Thursday in one of the heaviest days of bombing thus far.

title: Text of the Environmental Principles
description: STOCKHOLM, June 16 (Reuters) Following is the statement of principles from the Declaration on the Human Environment adopted today, by the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment:

title: Red Cross Negotiations in Korea Gain
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 16South and North Korean Red Cross officials surmounted a major obstacle here today in their efforts to agree on ways to permit limited travel between the North and South.

title: Sirhan's Sentence Is Reduced to Life By California Court
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) The California Supreme Court upheld today the firstdegree murder conviction of Sirhan B. Sirhan in the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy but modified his sentence of death in the gas chamber to life imprisonment.

title: Berkey Inquiry Continues; Stock Is Up 2 After Delay
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday afternoon it was continuing its investigation into recent trading in shares of Berkey Photo, Inc.

title: 35 FlagRank Officers Used in Aid Program
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 The four military services have 1,323 flag rank officers, of whom 35 are assigned to the military aid program.

title: U.S. TENNIS TEAM FORGES 20 LEAD
description: MEXICO CITY, June 16 (AP) Topseeded Stan Smith and Tom Gorman needed only three sets each to give the United States a 20 lead over Mexico in today's opening play of the final round of the North American Zone Davis Cup tennis championship.

title: City Foot Patrolmen Walking to Different Beat
description: The brown waters of the Bronx River glinted in the afternoon sun as Patrolman Richard Iskowitz. set his size ?? AAA brogans to pounding his central Bronx beat.

title: Sorry or So Sorry?
description: Despite Henry Kissinger's helpful visit to Japan, relations of confidence and trust between Washington and Tokyo are not likely to be quickly revived.

title: Tropical Storm Off Yucatan First of Hurricane Season
description: MIAMI, June 16 (UPI)  A tropical storm named Agnes, the first storm of the 1972 hurricane season, was strengthening today off Yucatan and expected to move to the east or northeast.

title: HUMPHREY PICKS UP 4.2 VOTES IN DAKOTA
Amritraj Ousts Lloyd
description: BECKENHAM, England, June, 16 (UPI)  Vijay Amritraj of Madras, India, defeated Australian Bill Lloyd today and reached the men's singles final at the Green Shield Kent lawn tennis championships.

title: HEARINGS BEGIN ON CONTROL BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Senate Commerce Committee opened four days of hearings today on a bill that would place professional sports under Federal control with public testimony on such industry practices as television blackouts of local sporting events and the requiring of seasonticket buyers to purchase tickets to preseason games.

title: SHELL EGG PRICES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: Shell egg futures rose 20 to 65 points (hundredths of a cent a dozen) on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday.

title: Commanders Visit Anioe
description: SAIGON, June 16 (AP)Wounded South Vietnamese troops were airlifted from Anloc today and two senior allied commanders who flew into the battered city came under enemy fire as they landed.

title: Airline Merger Approved
description: Stockholders of Northeast Airlines, Inc. yesterday voted approval of a previously announced agreement to be merged with Delta Air Lines, Inc. On Wednesday, directors of Delta approved acceptance of the merger terms. A tentative date of Aug. 1 has been set for consummation of the proposed merger.

title: TrusteeReceiver Clarifies 5th Ave. Coach Agreement
description: S. Hazard Gillespie, trusteereceiver of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., issued a clarification yesterday on consummation of the previously announced agreement with the Gray Line Corporation. The receivership, which began in August, 1968, ended at one !,minute after midnight yesterday. Management of the company's affairs was then vested in a board of directors that was elected by stockholders in 1970.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alan Fischer has been elected chairman, president and chief executive officer of Sherwood Diversified Services, Inc. He replaces Robert D. Esseks, who becomes president of the Oak Leaf Coal Company, a subsidiary.

title: Canadian Power Project Opens
description: CHURCHILL FALLS, Newfoundland, June 16  The world's largest underground powerhouse was formally opened here today.

title: Scott Stays in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 16 (AP)Charlie Scott, the former American Basketball Association scoring champion, will play with the Phoenix Suns of the National Baskethall Association next season, theSuns general manager, Jerry Colangelo ,said today.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Continental Air Lines, Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed public offering of 1.5 million shares of the company's capital stock. The offering will be made by a nationwide investment banking group managed by Lehman Brothers, Inc., in early July.

title: JOHN TUTHILL JR., L.I. PUBLISHER, 78
description: BROOKHAVEN, L. I., June 16John T. Tuthill Jr. the executive editor and publisher of The Long Island Advance in Patchogue, died today at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived on Beaver Dam Road here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a frequent airline passenger, I'm fed up with being taxed to support hijackers, and I have a solution.

title: Jersey Utility Seeks Rise In Gas and Electric Rates
description: NEWARK, June 16 (UPI)Public Service Electric & Gas Company filed a petition with the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners requesting an overall increase of $95million revenues, it was announced today.
