title: The Growing Confidence of the Israelis
description: TEL AVIVIsrael enters its sixth year since the SixDay war with sense of confidence hardly imaginable in the past, which even a terrorist slaughter of arriving tourists could not shake. Solidly entrenched along the ceasefire lines, militarily stronger than ever, Israel has refuted all prophecies of doom.

title: Surgery on Wallace Is Set for Tomorrow
2Year Ban Imposed On Glasgow Rangers
description: BERNE, June 16 (Reuters) The Glasgow Rangers of Scotland, winners of the European Cupwinners Cup in soccer, have been banned from European Football Union competition for the next two seasons because of their supporters misbehavior at the cup final, it was announced today at the union's headquarters.

title: CHURCH REFUSES TO CRITICIZE WAR
description: MONTREAT, N. C., June 16 The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) ended its annual meeting today after rejecting strong statements against American involvement in Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Melvin Laird's statement tying approval of the recent Moscow pact to increased funds for offensive weaponry constitutes a complete repudiation of the seemingly cooperative tone of the Moscow meetings. Unless President Nixon promptly repudiates Mr. Laird's aggressive stance, we, the people of these United States, will be obliged to recognize that we have been once again the victims of a Nixonian hoax.

title: Iraqi Revolutionary Aide Plans Further Oil Meetings
description: PARIS, June 16 (AP)Saddam Hussein Takriti, chairman of the Iraq Revolutionary Command Council, today extended his threeday official visit to France and scheduled new meetings with President Georges Pompidou and Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas for tomorrow.

title: Bridge: Italian Team Is Leading way  Into Semifinal at Olympiad
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 16Several of the leading teams suffered shocks during this afternoon's play at the World Bridge Team Olympiad.

title: 400,000 TENANTS TO GET RENT RISE OF 15% ON JULY 1
description: Owners of more than 400,000 rentcontrolled apartments in the city were authorized yesterday to collect a 15 per cent rent increase from July I to the end of the year.

title: Eight Young Women Bow at Fairfield Ball
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 16  Eight young women were presented at the Fairfield Debutante Ball at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Silliman here tonight. Mrs. Silliman was chairman for the event, proceeds from which will go to the Leukemia Society.

title: FIRST FINES LEVIED IN RHODESIA TRADE
description: A Federal judge levied $131,750 in fines yesterday against two corporations and three men who pleaded guilty to trading with Rhodesia in violation of Department of Commerce regulations and United Nations sanctions.

title: FELICIANO SINGS AT WOLLMAN RINK
description: Summer in New York City is the sound of rhythm and song throbbing congas and melodious steel drums, improvised vocal harmonies and a funky flute echoing through the dangerous early morning hours. In a more formal sense, summer in New York City means the rhythms of the Schaefer Music Festivals at Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park. The seventh happy season began Thursday night with a program that included folkrock pianist Billy Joel and guitaristsinger Jose Feliciano.

title: Laotians Open Attack
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 16 (AP)  An informed source reported today that United States and Laotian Air Force helicopters landed more than three battalions of Government troops yesterday near Khong Sedone, a provincial capital in southern Laos, to retake the town.

title: JONES &
description: PITTSBURGH, June 16 (Reuters)  The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation said today it planned to reduce a substantial portion of its outstanding bank debt in what a spokesman called an amplification of plans announced in its 1971 annual report.

title: MRS. KING WINS IN BRITISH TENNIS
description: BRISTOL, England, June 16 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., won the West of England women's tennis championship today when. she defeated Kerry Melville of Australia, 63, 62, in just 40 minutes.

title: Antiques: Tureen Forms
description: Interest in fruitand vegetableshaped ceramic tureens and boxes has been stimulated by last week's sale at ParkeBernet of a group collected by Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, widow of the Wall Street broker.

title: LINDSAY TO MISS PRIMARY TUESDAY
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he would not vote in Tuesday's Democratic primary.

title: Strike Peril Snarls Travel Plans
description: Faced with the threat of a oneday shutdown of international commercial airline service Monday, hundreds of travelers around the world canceled trips or hurriedly sought alternate means of travel yesterday.

title: Spain Increases Lead
description: AVILES, Spain, June 16 (UPI)  Juan Gisbert beat Bernard Balleret, 61, 62, 60, today to give Spain a 40 lead over Monaco in the GroupB European Zone Davis Cup tennis semifinal.

title: McCloskeys Are Separated
description: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif, June 16 (UPI)Representative Paul N. McCloskey, Republican of California, and his wife of 23 years have separated, his campaign manager said today. Albert R. Schreck of the McCloskey staff said the Representative was very hopeful that there will be a reconciliation.

title: Bath Iron Works Receives Contract to Build Tankers
description: BATH, Maine, June 16 (AP)The Bath Iron Works Corporation reported today that it has received an $80million contract to build five tankers for the Military Sealift Command.

title: Fiddler Is History
description: In the beginning were the words: by Sholom Aleichem, the Yiddish Mark Twain, spinning tales of Tevye the dairyman and his daughters and friends in the old country. Then there was one of those rare Broadway miracles: a blend of story, book, lyrics, music and acting into a classic called Fiddler on the Roof. Some day the cultural historians will explain how come a musical about a Jewish family in Czarist Russia in 1905about poor and unimportant peopleis loved in Finland, Japan, South Africa, Brazil and just about every country but Russia itself. Meanwhile, New Yorkers can take some pride in the fact that it all began here and that, with this evening's performance, Fiddler on the Roof becomes the longestrunning production (passing Life With Father) in Broadway history. Mazel tov.

title: Some Belden Products Due For Price Cutbacks July 1
description: The Belden Corporation announced yesterday that it was rescinding price increases on products manufactured by its transportation and electrical divisions that had been approved by the Price Commission in the course of the year.

title: OFFTRACK TV BAN ANGERS SAMUELS
description: Bumped off stride in his latest effort to hitch offtrack betting to television, Howard J. Samuels claimed foul yesterday against both the State Harness Racing Commission and Governor Rockefeller.

title: RECORDED BOAST OF KILLING HEARD
description: A boastful claim by Patrolman William R. Phillips that he killed three people, blowing 'em away as if they were nothing, will be offered as evidence in Mr. Phillips's forthcoming trial on charges of murdering a pimp and the procurer's girlfriend.

title: SCHOOL UNIT TOED TO CLEAR HIRING:Scribner Bids Local Board Have State Review Policy
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner yesterday ordered the community school board of District 1 on the Lower East Side to clear its controversial new personnel policy, which some critics have charged would impose ethnic hiring quotas, with he State Division of Human Rights.

title: Nine N.B.A. Stars Fined For Playing A.B.A. Five
description: A new confrontation developed yesterday between the National Basketball Players Association and the 17 N.B.A. owners when the players who participated in the May 25 allstar game against the American Basketball Association allstars were fined. The game:, sponsored by each league's players association and televised nationally, was won by the N.B.A., 106104.

title: New Issues of Stock Receive Mixed Reaction From Investors
Books of The Times
description: As in the case of India, Great Britain's stay in Egypt proceeded more by chance than by design. The process by which Great Britain, professing all sorts of things to the contrary, went ahead consolidating its hold on the country defies logic. Yet one step led inevitably to the next, one policy to another, usually more severe, until Egypt could not even breathe without British approval. There were no goals in sight when it began. The goals appeared as the presence of England spread. Not all the Egyptians were supine, and one thing Peter Mansfield's thorough study makes clear is that the nationalist movement in Egypt had a long history. It began, in fact, with the British invasion of Egypt in 1882 and continued with varying degrees of fervor until 1956, when the British left for good, cased out by the colonels who had deposed King Farouk.

title: Mrs. Mildred Greenberg, 50, A Leader in Jewish Studies
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., June.16 Mrs. Mildred Deitch Greenberg, supervisor and teacher of Hebrew studies at Temple Israel in South Orange, died last evening at Beth Israel Hospital, Newark. She was 50 years old and lived at 51 West Cedar Street.

title: Echeverria Reports Gains in Nixon Talk
description: WASHINGTON, June 16President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico announced today that an agreement had been reached with President Nixon on easing a series of disputes that have severely strained United StatesMexican relations.

title: Democratic Aide Resigns After Woman's Complaint
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 16 (AP)  A Democratic National Convention official resigned today after a young woman accused him of making improper advances while interviewing her for a job as a convention hostess.

title: The Right to No Trial
description: Angela Davis is following up her acquittal with nationwide tour intended to drum up pOpular support for the notion that all militants accused of specific acts of Violence must be viewed as victims of repression and freed without trial.

title: Household Sector of Economy Had Net Stock Sales in Quarter
Florida's Plea to Extradite William Bremer Is Granted
description: LITTLE. ROCK, Ark., June 161 (AP)  The office of Gov. Dale Bumpers granted today a request by Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida that William Allen Bremer, 32 years old, of Fort Smith be extradited.

title: Notes on People
description: With traditional drumrolls and a minimum of ceremonial speechmaking, Vice Adm. William P. Mack replaced Vice Adm. James Calvert as Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md.

title: Chou Cites Eisenhower and Korea as Way to End War
description: PEKING, June 16Premier Chou Enlai forcefully reiterated tonight that the United States was involved in a war of aggression in Indochina and cited former President Dwight Eisenhower's conduct in the Korean war as a good example for Washington to follow in ending the Vietnam war.

title: Experts Smuggling Ancient Mexican Art to a Profitable Market
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11A few months ago in Manhattan a welldressed young woman got off a creaking elevator and knocked at a secondfloor gallery overlooking Madison Avenue. After the door was unlocked the visitor was greeted by the person in charge, a middleaged, olivecomplexioned man in a bright colored turtleneck and dark slacks.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Ever since Ossie Davis, the actor, said last year it's not the man but the plan, it's not the rap but the map, blacks have seemingly been stumbling over one another to come up with the plan. signed to provide political solutions to black problems. However, this proliferation of black agendas has posed the seriods threat of undermining potential black strength in this important election year.

title: Campaign Unit to Take Complaints of Public
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 The Fair Campaign Practices Committee announced today that henceforth it would accept complaints from the public as well as from political figures.

title: Man in the
description: KINGS PARK, L.I., June 16 Friends of Detective Robert Leuci say he learned his lessons well when he had selfdefense training at the Police Academy a decade ago. In the years that followed, they say, he came to feel the integrity of the force itself needed defending. So he kept his stance properly flexible and went to work for Federal investigators who were looking into the bribing of policemen by heroin dealers.

title: Manhattan Civil Court
description: In the Civil Court, which is the court of first instance for much litigation in New York County (Manhattan), four seats will be contested in Tuesday's Democratic primary. Three are countywide and the fourth is in the Second Municipal District (Lower East Side). The lower courts should not be overlooked by Manhattan voters.

title: McGovern Ties His Plans To a Lower Jobless Rate
Amex Fines Loewi &
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had levied a fine of $25,000 against Loewi & Co., a member firm, and had suspended its president, William L. Liebman, for 20 days.

title: Busy Reign Starts Rolling for New National Marbles Champion
description: WILDWOOD, N. J., June 16  For Rick Mawhinney of Cumberland, Md., a year on the banquet circuit, a year of free gifts, a year of people asking his advice about things, a year of instructional sports clinics, and a year of being introduced. as the national champion is over.

title: Sybron to Close Plant
description: ROCHESTER, June 16 (UPI) The Sybron Corporation said today it would close its Buffalo plant and cease production of hospital furniture. It said a $3.5million writeoff would be offset by the $20million sale of the Patterson Dental Company in May.

title: Too Many Generals Head Aid Missions, Senator Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Senator William Proxmire said today that American military aid missions abroad had become so topheavy with gen erals and admirals that We are nearing the point where we have all chiefs and no Indians.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On June 14, you mentioned two candidates in the Democratic primary contest for the State Senate in the 23d District, and you repeated this on your editorial page on June 15.

title: The Talk of Raisin City. Calif.
description: RAISIN CITY, Calif., June 16Raisin City is just a glorified crossroads 17 miles from Fresno, a handful of stores, a post office, and Little League field, where mothers in print dresses sit on plastic folding chairs and cheer the players for Rau's Dairy and the Big B. Market.Here, the sandy soil grows the sweet, earlymaturing grapes prized by raisin producers. As summer approaches, the heavy green vines creep toward the roadside. They seem almost asleep in a sun so fierce that some people buy Cokes frozen solid.

title: JOSEPH J. TOOHER SR.
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 Joseph J. Tooher Sr., former acting postmaster of this community and a former chairman of the Democratic City Committee, died Wednesday at Stamford Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 48 Hillside Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The apparent hopelessness of the hijacking mess leads me to suggest workable solution.

title: MISS O'DONOVANROSSA
description: PATERSON, N.J., June 16Isabel O'DonovanRossa, a 1905 graduate of the St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nurses in New York City and its oldest living alumna, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic. She was S9 years old and lived here at the Holy Family Residence.

title: Stage: Baron as Bruce
description: Emotionally and physically Lenny Bruce is a challenging and a harrowing role for an actor. On stage for almost the entire play, he has to portray a superb standup comic as well as a tragic, collapsing human being. In the case of Sandy Baron, who this week assumed the role of Lenny on Broadway, he has to contend with the memory not only of Lenny Bruce but also of Cliff Gorman.

title: Hine Hurt in Car Crash
description: SILVERSTONE, England, June 17 (AP)John Hine, Britain's leader in the European sportscar driving championships, suffered burns and back injuries when he crashed in flames today while driving at, over 100 miles an hour in practice runs for tomorrow's Martini international race.

title: Uncommitted Blacks Could Give McGovern Victory on First Ballot
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Uncommitted black delegates have aquired, as they had long hoped they would, a potentially decisive role in the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Glasgow Appeals Ban
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, June 17 (UPI)The Glasgow Rangers soccer club said today it would appeal the twoyear ban imposed by the Union of European Football Associations as a penalty for Scottish fans boisterous behavior after last month's Ranger victory over Moscow Dynamo in the European Cupwinners Cup final at Barcelona, Spain,

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  A decadelong struggle came to what may prove to be the decisive turning point last week when William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, ordered a ban, effective Dec. 31, on almost all remaining domestic uses of the toxic, virtually nondegradable pesticide DDT.

title: DREA UPSETS DIETZ IN SINGLES SCULLS
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17Sean Drea of Ireland upset Jim Dietz of the New York A. C. today in the elite singles event of the Schuylkill Navy regatta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We know, of course, that President Nixon does not have time to see the papers because he is entirely occupied in arranging for a generation of peace (sometime), in bringing the war in Vietnam to an end with honor (sometime) and in teaching the North Vietnamese respect for the American Presidency (right now, by flattening with bombs and naval shelling everything that moves or functions there). To avoid his being diverted from these tasks, he gets his news from public sources in capsule form prepared by a staff of expert analysts and summarizers.

title: WALL STREET
description: Now that the New York Stock Exchange has nominated its new board of directors, the next big step will be to find a new chairman and chief executive officer to preside over that board.

title: Sezna Retains Golf Title
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y. June 17 Wallace Sezna of Greenville, Del., successfully defended his title Wednesday by winning the 12th annual Eastern Seniors Golf Association championship with a twoday, 36hole score of 149 at Siwanoy Country Club.

title: L.I.R.R. Improving Service on All Lines Under a New Timetable
description: Many Long Island Rail Road passengers will be spared changes at Jamaica, Queens, running times will be shortened in some instances and a consistent service will be instituted for offhour trains under a new timetable that the line will put into effect June 26.

title: Movies
description: WE ALL know that Fiddler on the Roof is now the longest running show in the history of Broadway, but not all of us know that Joseph Stein, who wrote the book for both the stage and film versions of the musical, has been fiddling around with another story about a Jewish family. Actually, he's been more than fiddlinghe has actually completed the screenplay for Call It Sleep, Henry Roth's classic evocation of life in a New York Jewish ghetto during the first part of this century. The focus is on the sensitive son of the family and his relationships with his loving mother and his harried father. It wasn't an easy script to do, says Stein, 'but have hopes that it truly captures Roth's remarkably human documentation of a poor, alien family's struggle to adjust to an extremely hostile world. I feel close to the people in Call It Sleep, much as I did to Sholem Aleichem's Tevye and his family in Fiddler.

title: Showdown Is at Hand on Income Tax
description: TRENTON After an initial, inconclusive skirmish on Thursday, a historic special legislative session on tax reform has begun in New Jersey, with Governor Cahill characteristically leading with his chin.

title: Disputed Cleveland Area Election Board Names Black Director
description: CLEVELAND, June 17The Cuyahoga County Board of Elections, given a courtordered reprieve of the dismissal of all its members, has named the first black in Ohio to be a director of elections.

title: Grant Enables Ecology Agency to Expand to Coast
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the country's leading environmental law firms with offices here and in Washington, will expand its operations by opening a branch in Palo Alto, Calif., this summer, with the aim of becoming a national force in the environmental movement.

title: Photography
description: IT Is a sad truth that while the numerous new galleries in town have increased the amount of photography being exhibited in New York, there has been little commensurate rise in the level of quality, nor much added diversity in the kind of work being shown. Thinking back over the past season, which has seen the opening of over half a dozen new photographic galleries, I am forced to the startling conclusion that the most consistent showcases in this city for the widest range of exciting work by younger photographers have been the Witkin Gallery and Light.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As Martin Garbus pointed out in your Week in Review column (May 28), it is unfortunate that the Supreme Court of the United States determined that under the Federal Constitution person who claims his Fifth Amendment privilege against selfincrimination, and is then given immunity compelling him to testify, is protected only from the use of the compelled testimony in a subsequent criminal proceeding and from the use of evidence derived from that testimony.

title: VIOLATIONS CITED AT FOOD OUTLETS
description: Three prominent New York restaurants are cited for serious violations of the city's health code in the most recent list published by the Health Department.

title: Cambodian Road Opened
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 17 (Reuters)  Cambodian troops reopened the vital road link between Pnompenh and the provincial capital of Kompong Cham today after 11 days of hard fighting, the military command said.

title: Drug Roundup Is Shock to Divided Town
description: LYNDHURSTThis small, industrial town (population 22,729) is a community in shock. Overnight it has: become a town divided against itself. What was a gap threatens to become a chasm between generations.

title: From a novelist waiting for the muse
description: Almost all the biographical data in this study of Lillian Hellman: Playwright comes straight from her memoir, An Unfinished Woman. The interpretations of her plays are equally secondhand: runthroughs, eked out with quotations. In place of criticism, there are surveys of early drafts to show that later ones were improvements, and summaries of contemporary reviews with plaudits appropriated and strictures modified. When no other ground for praise exists, Richard Moody, professor of theater and drama at Indiana University, points to a successful boxoffice.

title: Courage Party in State Wants Wallace on Ballot
description: SYRACUSE, June 17The chairman of the Courage party said today that plans were being made for a petition drive for 20,000 signatures to get the name of Gov. George C. Wallace on the New York State in November.

title: The World
description: It is impossible to understand why the United States does not apply the same boldness and imagination that it applies to solving complex problems with its enemies to the solution of simple problems with its friends.

title: New Plan Offers Data To Cut Peril at Fires
description: The smoke and flames that envelop a burning building are hazards well known to any fireman. But there are also hidden dangers of which the fire fighters are unaware and which can lead to serious injury and death.

title: U.N. RIGHTS GROUP HELD INEFFECTIVE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17The performance of the Human Rights Commission here is being harshly criticized by Western countries.

title: Education
description: WASHINGTONMy kids aren't going, a woman in a bluecollar, virtually allwhite suburb of Detroit said last week.

title: Dr. Nathaniel Saxon, 91, Led Hospital Association
description: WEST FALMOUTH, Mass., June 17  Dr. Nathaniel W. Saxon, a physician and hospital administrator who was president of the American Hospital Association in 1933, died yesterday in Falmouth Hospital. He was 91 years old.

title: The Faces of Spain
description: The landscape of Spain may bear a likeness to Sicily, France, to Austria and, with its windmills, even to the Netherlands. But the character of its inhabitants is something apart; Napoleon put it succinctly when he said, Europe ends at the Pyrenees. And the differences of the people from province to province within Spain are even more pronounced.

title: A Frenchman Says Non
description: BETHPAGE, L. I.While there may be enough Frenchmen to fill up Levittowns around Paris, one Frenchman who tried the local variety moved as fast as he could. It, was not'the homes that did not suit himit was their owners.

title: PHELAN WINS TWICE IN JUNIOR A.A.U. MEET
description: Dennis Phelan, a sophomore from Manhattan College, registered the only double victory in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championships yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: OBSERVER
description: Directions for painting a small rusted castiron container with a shiny coat of rustresistant black paint, in order that two geraniums and some white impatiens may be planted in and the arrangement placed at the edge of a brick patio to give the garden a more pleasant appearance:searching under the sink, note a serious leak in the sink drain. Pray that it will cost no more than $150 in new plumbing.

title: Schwab Sets Hurdles Record In National Scholastic Meet
Concern Increases in Miami Beach Over Possible Disorders at Conventions
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 16There is mounting concern that the two national political conventions to be held here in the next two months will lead to confrontation between the police and political demonstrators that leaders on both sides have worked to avoid since the bloody street battles at the Democratic convention in Chicago in 1968.

title: Missisippi Mud Takes Intermediate Jumping Title at Ox Ridge
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 17Two years ago Melanie Smith didn't think Mississippi Mud would ever jump a fence again following a serious leg injury. She was wrong.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Vietnam war has generated so much dishonesty and moral blindness through three Administrations that the nation now appears to consider these normal. So there is no particular outcry over the disclosures that numerous protective reaction raids on North Vietnam have been staged, to let American fliers bomb what they wanted to bomb, when they wanted to bomb it.

title: Eight Stories; Matthew Looney and The Space Pirates By Jerome Beatty Jr. Illustrated by Gahan Wilson. 159 pp. Scott. $4.95. (Ages 8 to 11)
description: The Moonsters live in peace and quiet until expeditions from Earth raise the fear of invasion. Moonman, Matt Looney (serving his fourth hitch as Mr. Beatty's spacecommander hero), sets out to colonize the planet Freeholy so the Moonsters may move there if the Earthlings take over their satellite. Enroute Matt is ambushed by Hector Hornblower and his space pirates, returns the runaway Princess Annalunkus to her daddy, Great Klunkus of Bolunkus, and is reunited with his crew. It may be some measure of the author's talent for combining frenetic narrative with satire that neither the lack of scientific authenticity nor his comicstrip cast detract from the fun.

title: A Cry of There She Blows Haunts House on Bedlam St.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.This oncebustling whaling port has a museum that accurately captures the hard life howling arctic winds and skills of the sailing men who lived for the cry of There she blows more than a hundred years ago.

title: Deborah Eliason Wed
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June I7In the Red Clay Creek Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss Deborah Jayne Eliason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McIntire Eliason Jr., was married to John Douglas Rollins, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Brooks Rollins Jr. of Shelburne, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl Bogard. The bridegroom's father is academic vice president of the University of Vermont.

title: Bay Dismays Ecology Class
description: A mechanical shovel dropped 30 feet into Jamaica Bay near Kennedy Airport and brought a clump of foulsmelling sewage to the deck of the Atlantic Twin, an oceansupport vessel.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: In 1935 Congress gave legal status and regulation to collective bargaining. A reluctant and apprehensive management was escorted to the Congressional altar and required by the National Labor Relations Act to pledge its unilateral vows to a beaming labor bride.

title: Seeding Reviving Oysters
description: ATLANTIC CITY  One Federal and two state programs are under way along the South Jersey coast to reviva the state's onceprosperous shellfish industry, decimated in recent years by pollution and blight.

title: Millicent McKinley Bride of Thomas Cox
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The marriage of Miss Millicent Ogden McKinley, daughter of Mrs. William S. McKinley and the late Mr. McKinley, to Thomas Storke Cox took place here tonight. The Rev. John R. Anschutz of Christ Episcopal Church, Georgetown, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Mount Vernon College.

title: CARDS TOP GIANTS ON RUN IN 11TH, 43
description: ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP)Lou Brock's 11thinning sacrifice fly scored Dwain Anderson with the winning run today as the St. Louis Cardinals topped the San Francisco Giants, 43.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Relations Between the U.S. and India Still Mired in Suspicion and Distrust
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Six months after their fallingout over the war between India and Pakistan, the United States and India remain in a state of strained relations, mired in mutual suspicion and distrust.

title: Some Husbands Talk About Their Liberated Wives
description: W HAT is the effect of consciousnessraising on the husbands of wives who have had their consciousnesses raised? To answer this, I convened a meeting of the men whose wives are in the same consciousnessraising group as my wife.

title: Cepeda Walks Out on Braves After Dispute With Manager
description: ATLANTA, June 17 (AP)Orlando Cepeda, claiming he is fed up with the situation in Atlanta, left the club prior to the Braves game against the Montreal Expos tonight.

title: Skarin, Mowen 1,2 in Olympic Bicycle Qualifying Race
description: LAKE LUZERNE, N. Y., June 17Speeding down S turns at 60 miles an hour, moving up mountains with a curious fishtail sway, 67 men took off today in what they considered the toughest bicycle race in the United States, a 120mile grind that closed out the qualifying runs to select the Olympic roadracing team.

title: The Nation
description: It is hard to believe that he is gone, the most eminent man of letters of this century.

title: The Chickencoup Chinaman
description: IF John Osborne had been A young ChineseAmerican playwright of mediocre attainments, he might conceivably have written a play very much like The Chickencoop Chinaman, which is the season's final offering at the American Place Theater.

title: Model for Acupuncture
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julian M. Sobin went to the Canton Trade Fair last month to buy chemicals.

title: Zoning Plan Embracing Woodbury Is Opposed
description: WOODBURY, L. I.Civic groups here and in Syosset are forming a coalition to fight against certain aspects of the final master plan for the development of the SyossetWoodbury area, the largest undeveloped acreage in the unincorporated section of the Town of Oyster Bay. They have scheduled a meeting for June 26.

title: 10 CONVICTS OFFER TO BECOME P.O.W.'s
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 17 (AP) Ten convicts who say they want to do something for their country have petitioned President Nixon offering to change places with 10 American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: Bridge The problem with aceasking bids...
description: THE world's most popular bridge convention, devised almost 40 years ago by Easley Blackwood, is deceptively simple. It aims to prevent a partnership from falling into either of two pitfalls: a grand slam in which the opponents win the first trick with an ace; or a small slam in which they win two quick tricks with aces.

title: Blasts Rip Fuel Tanks At U.S. Longbinh Post
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 18 (AP)  A series of explosions ripped through five fuel tanks shortly before dawn today at the United States Army's Vietnam headquarters 12 miles northeast of Saigon. First reports said there were no casualties.

title: Rahway Inmates Ask Now Books
description: RAHWAYInmates at the maximumsecurity Rahway State Prison do not keep a bestseller book list. But if they did, the works of Harold Robbins, Irving Wallace, at al., would never make it.

title: A Welcome Solstice
description: The summer solstice occurs this week, before dawn on Wednesday; and for once it will be fully welcome. Thus far the weeks that should have been warming up the whole outdoors and preparing for July and August have been wet and chilly. Farmers have been bogged their fields. Gardens have been too wet to plant. Hay that should have been cured and stowed two weeks ago is still in the fields. You can't cure hay with rain.

title: Countess de Bravura Wed in Paris
description: The marriage of Countess Catherine Helene Charlotte Anion de Bravura to Stephen John Knerly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Knerly of Waite Hill, Ohio, and Deer Isle, Me., took place in Paris yesterday.

title: ONION STOPS FOE AND RETAINS TITLE
description: COLOMBES, France, June 17 Carlos Monzon of Argentina kept his world middleweight title tonight when JeanClaude Bouttier of France failed to answer the bell for the 13th round of a onesided fight the loser almost won.

title: Summer Guest Captures Filly Oaks by 4 Lengths
ELLSBERG SEEKS EVIDENCE CURB
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17Lawyers for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo, defendants in the Pentagon Papers case, have filed a motion asking the Federal District Court here to suppress evidence that the Government allegedly obtained through surveillance of the accused following their indictment.

title: The World
description: PARISNeither world opinion, as expressed in criticism voiced at the Stockholm conference on the environment, nor the example of the United States and the Soviet Union in trying to limit the arms buildup, seems likely to divert France from going ahead with her latest series of nuclear tests on the Polynesian island of Mururoa.

title: WALL STREET; What's in It For D.L.J.? Insiders' Profit
description: American Express, known worldwide for its credit cards and travelers checks, plans to buy 25 per cent of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the big institutional investment house, and Wall Street is asking what's in it for D.L.J.

title: Miss Orlando Married
description: In St. Theresa of the Little Flower Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, Miss Genevieve Orlando was married yesterday morning to Richard Baccariello by the Rev. Joseph D'Argenio. The parents of the couple are Judge Adolph C. Orlando of the New York State Court of Claims and Mrs. Orlando and Dr. and Mrs. Santo Baccariello. Both families are of the Bronx.

title: Color My World, Or, No News From Cheshire High School
description: CHESHIRE, Conn. ALL high school kids smoke marijuana. They all ride motorcycles and listen to acid rock and go on strike and build bombs during chemistry class, and the only time they're not making trouble is when they're making love.

title: The Guest Word
description: Two recent Last Word columns by John Leonard (Nov. 14, May 14) touched on some important questions about the current state of writing, which has been clouded, as Richard Locke argued, also on this page (May 28), by political considerations. And criticism, which normally might be expected to provide some clarity, has itself been reflecting the general confusion.

title: Long Islander Breaks N.H.L. Ice
description: On the long bus rides back from games in Montreal or Ottawa that would get him home at 6 in the morningjust enough time for him to have breakfast and then go to school  Chris Ahrens would sleep and perhaps dream about playing for a New York team in the National Hockey League.

title: Brooklyn Building Regains Its Prestige
description: The building with the canopy enjoys a prestigious reputation in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. From postman to delivery boy to shop owner, neighbors of the sixstory brick structure at 580 Empire Boulevard speak appreciatively of the building's slow and costly transformation from potential aim to conversation piece.

title: 28 Pro Golfers to Compete In B'nai B'rith Tournament
description: Leading golf professionals of Westchester and Putnam Counties will compete in the first B'nai B'rith golf tournament at Lake Isle Country. Club in Eastchester Wednesday. Twentyeight have signed to compete for some $8,000 in prize money.

title: World News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, June 17Mayor Jean Drapeau has announced that this year's Man and His World exhibition, the annual successor to Montreal's Expo 67, will be reduced substantially both in size and in running time.

title: Mary Bardes Married to Jay Page
description: CINCINNATI, June 17The marriage of Miss Mary Brittain Bardes to Jay Jarvis Page, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Multhrop Page of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, New York, took place here this afternoon.

title: Miss Karen Monaghan Wed To R. R. Walbridge, Teacher
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 17Miss Karen Reynolds Monaghan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Holt Monaghan of Southport, was married here this afternoon to Ryckman Ray Walbridge, son of Mrs. Eugene W. Stetson Jr. of Westport, and George O. Walbridge of Madrid, in Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Francis X. Chenney, rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Mrs. Gail Ann Wald Married To Frederick Coverly Calder
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 17  Mrs. Gail Ann Finkel Wald was married here this afternoon to Frederick Coyerly Calder, headmaster of the Germantown Friends School in Philadelphia. Westchester County Judge George D. Burchell performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Finkel, parents of the bride.

title: One Costly Pipeline?
description: MONTREAL  Canadian and American oil men hope that it will be three, two, one and then go for a pipeline to bring gas from the rich North Slope of Alaska and the promising MacKenzie Delta of the Northwest Territories to the energyhungry cities on both sides of the border in Midcontinent America.

title: In France
description: MESNILST. DENIS, Prance Well, there are differences.

title: 3 Firemen Killed and 6 Missing in Boston Hotel Fire
description: BOSTON, June 17 (AP)Three firemen were killed and at least six others were listed as missing tonight after the collapse of a back corner of the Vendome Hotel during a blaze that struck the upper stories of the centuryold hotel in Boston's Back Bay area.

title: AllDressage Show Listed for July 2
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 17The Ox Ridge Hunt Club will hardly have time to draw a long breath after its big show ends tomorrow because an alldressage event is scheduled for July 2. The club conducted an alldressage event last year for the first time and it went over Americap Horse Shows Association. Americap Horse Shows Association.

title: Travel Notes:
description: Eighty contestants will compete for trophies and $500 in prizes at the 10th annual OldTime Fiddlers Contest July 29 in the village of Craftsbury Common, Vt. Also scheduled as part of the event arc a fiddle auction, a fiddlemaking demonstration and a chicken barbecue... The White Memorial Foundation's Mobile Camp, which is supervised by staff members of the Litchfield (Conn.) Nature Center and Museum, will take boys and girls aged 14 to 16 on a trip through the Northeast between July 24 and Aug. 4. The group will visit the Barn Island Marshes, Cape Cod, Woods Hole and Manonet, Mass.; Paris, Me.; the White Mountains of :New Hampshire and SwiftWater, N. H... By July 15, travelers calling Eastern Air Lines for plane reservations should be able also to book rooms at any of the 228 hotels and motels in the I.T.T. Sheraton Corporation of America chain. The airline says its computers will provide confirmations in a matter of seconds. . The New Orleans Food Festival, now in its fourth year, will be held between June 30 and July 2, leading off with a $30aperson La Fete Creole at the Marriott Hotel. In addition, food tasting and culinary arts displays are scheduled at the Rivergate Exhibition Center.... The Woman's Club of Honesdale, Pa., will hold an antiques and art sale from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. on July 7 and 8 at the Stourbridge School on U.S. 6.... A 33story replica of the Eiffel Tower is the focal point of Kings Island Amusement Park, recently opened on Interstate 71 about 25 miles north of Cincinnati. The park features four theme areas: Oktoberfest, Coney Island, Rivertown and Happy Land of HannaBarbera....The Caribbean island of Bonaire in the Netherlands Antilles has opened a tourist information office at 405 Lexington Avenue, New York (phone: 2126876655).... The second annual Governor's Militia Muster will be held on Aug. 4, 5 and 6 in York, Me. On the final day, Gov. Kenneth Curtis reviews the troops.

title: GENTRY IS VICTIM OF 3 RED HOMERS
description: CINCINNATI, June 17The Mets had fun watching Yogi Berra play third base tonight, but Berra didn't have any fun watching the Mets play anything.

title: The Pollution Lobby
description: STOCKHOLM  At a United States Embassy reception Wednesday night, the head of a big American metals concern wandered, seemingly lost, among the throng of guests involved in the United Nation's Conference on the Human Environment.

title: Pamela H. Murray Married in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, June 17Miss Pamela Holmes Murray, daughter of William Edwards Murray of New York and Atlanta and the late Mrs. Minnie Holmes Murray, was married here this afternoon to DeFord Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip by the Rev. John C. Ball, assisted by the Rev. Frank M. Bulloch Jr.

title: LIGHT AIR SPOILS COW BAY YACHTING
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 17Short courses and al long postponement were they reward for 58 yachts that sailed in tardy and light northwesterly winds off Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today in the Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association competition.

title: Coins
description: LIBERIA, the oldest African democracy, which will mark the 150th anniversary of its founding this year, will issue a sixcoin proof set dated 1972. This will be the fifth year for Liberian proof coinage and the United States Mint again has the contract to turn out the sets. Liberia's monies, from the dollar to the cent, are similar to those of our nation, and have the same exchange rate. Each proof set is made up of 1, 5, 10, 25 and 50 cents, and the dollar piece. All are struck of cupronickel except the cent, which is in bronze.

title: To Fearful Women A Senator's Wife Offers GoodAdvice
description: INDIANAPOLIS (UPI)Marvella Bayh, whose husband, Senator Birch Bayh, the Indiana Democrat, withdrew a presidential contender last fall to remain with her after she underwent surgery for cancer, has become symbol of encouragement to many American women.

title: Dr. Frederick Schwerd Dies; Surgeon at Richmond Hospital
description: Dr. Frederick M. Schwerd, a founder and retired chief surgeon of Richmond Memorial Hospital on Staten Island, died Friday of a stroke. His age was 79. He lived at 133 Finlay Avenue in the borough's Pleasant Plains section.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: While Congress wrestles with the question of establishing an independent consumer protection agency in the Federal Government hierarchy, a number of state and local efforts have been started on their own.

title: 2 Groups Merge to Form Religion and Health Panel
description: The American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry and the Academy of Religion and Mental Health have joined forces.

title: Fear of Israeli Revenge Dominates a Refugee Town
description: EIN EL HILWEH, Lebanon, June 15  In this wretched town in which more than 18,000 Palestinians have lived since 1948, turning it gradually from a camp of tents into a warren of huts made of stucco or of concrete blocks and topped with roofs of corrugated metal, nervousness is palpable and suspicion of the rare outsider flickers from many eyes.

title: A Freshening of Colorado River Pledged in U.S.Mexico Accord
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 17The United States pledged today to undertake a variety of actions to improve the quality of water that flows from the Colorado River into Mexico.

title: Mrs. Anz Married To Richard Daniels
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 17In the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Mrs. Gloria Gordon Anz, widow of John B. Anz of New York, was married to Richard Ross Daniels, a stockbroker with Lombard, Nelson & McKenna, Inc., in New York. The Rev. Lawrence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony. A reception for members of the immediate families was held at the home here of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Daniels.

title: Bromfield Show Farm Will Be Owned by Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 17 (AP)The late Louis Bromfield's stately Malabar Farm near Mansfield, fashioned from the countryside's rolling hills as a showplace for land conservation and organic farming techniques, will soon belong to the State of Ohio.

title: Television; Commercials Instead of Shows? Well...
description: IT'S been suggested that television programing has deteriorated to the point where the commercials are more entertaining than the shows, so why not dump the Bradys and the Ironsides and just run the good stuff in between? The idea has to have come from a nonwatcher, of course. No regular viewersick unto death of pitchmen promising blindingly fast headache relief, transcendentally white wash and Saharadry armpitswould doom himself to an evening of such torment.

title: World News Briefs
description: TOKYO, June 17American and Japanese business leaders ended a threeday session in Tokyo today without finding any solution to the problem of correcting the heavy imbalance in trade between the two countries.

title: The New Anatomy Of Britain
description: Britain in the 1970's is melancholy and uncertain. A secondrate power with a poignantalmost mysticalyearning to be taken seriously, the nation faces her strikes, labor unrest, problems in Northern Ireland and political division over entering the Common Market with a kind of bemused selfdoubt. Americans are seduced by it because the lady in question, if a bit threadbare, is charming, quaint and a little smug about her problems.

title: Guards View Life From Inside Cells
description: BORDENTOWN The cell doors clanked open, and the 20 young men slowly entered the sparsely furnished cells. Then the heavy bars slammed shut and the men were locked in for the night.

title: Law
description: A policeman kills an innocent bystander while chasing a bank robber. A citizen shoots a man attempting to rape his sister. A man's property is burnt to prevent a raging forest fire from speeding into a densely populated community. Seamen mutiny against a captain who has threatened to wreck his ship and kill his men. The speed limit is violated in pursuing a suspected criminal. Shipwrecked survivors kill and eat one of their group to avoid starvation.

title: Gordon L. Parker Jr. Marries Jane Gray
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., June 17  Miss Jane Tilden Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dalton Knight Gray, and Gordon Lancaster Parker Jr. of Providence, R.I., son of Mrs. Gordon L. Parker of Providence and Little Compton, R.I., and the late Mr. Parker, former treasurer of Brown University, were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Haig Nargesian, the rector, performed the ceremony, after which a garden reception was given at the Mayflower Inn.

title: Probation Chief Is Retiring
description: The retirement of Arch E. Sayler as chief probation officer of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York was announced last week by David N. Edelstein, chief judge of the court. Mr. Sayler, whose retirement is effective next Friday, had been a Federal probation officer since 1937. John T. Connally, deputy chief protection officer, will succeed Mr. Sayler.

title: Royals Down Brewers, 63
description: MILWAUKEE, June 17 (AP) John Mayberry hit a threerun home run and Fred Patek delivered a tworun single to lead the surging Kansas City Royals to a 63 victory today over Milwaukee. The loss was the Brewers ninth in a row.

title: Sutherland and Horne Talents Are Beacon on a Rainy Evening
description: One of the foremost musical acts of the century, the Bel Canto Girlsmore formally and properly known, of course, as Joan Sutherland and Marilyn Hornehelped the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra celebrate its 50th anniversary at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel on Friday night. Miss Sutherland and Miss Horne had the former's husband, Richard Bonynge, at the conducting tiller, as usual. As usual, too, they cruised with notable success through the most perilous vocal waters: selections from Rossini's Semiramide and Bellini's Norma.

title: Souffl surprise
description: If you poach four eggs for a briefer time than usual, you can place them gently inside a souffle and bake the whole dish without solidifying the yolks. Don't tell your guests about the hidden eggs, but be sure you mark the souffle dish so that you know where they are, or you'll surprise yourself by bursting one as you serve this tour de force.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tax reform has suddenly become popular issue.

title: REFORM IS URGED FOR CIVIL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The solution to the unmanageable Federal bureaucracy the subject of anguished complaints by presidents and Congressmen alikelies in making its processes visible and accountable to the public, according to a Ralph Nader study of the Civil Service system released today.

title: 2 Bombs Go Off in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 17 (AP)  Two huge bombs went off here today, injuring 25 persons, and Roman Catholic and Protestant youths fought in the streets.

title: Applauseand Voice Lessons Are in Order
description: IT is odd to watch a performer who is utterly out of focus with a play gradually make the play come to focus on him. Or her, I should say, because I am mainly thinking of wench named Carole Shelley who has been brought to Canada from Britain to join the Stratford Festival company for its 20th season. (Who would have thought there were so many seasons upon us since we first ventured into Ontario, to sit under a tent, that short time ago?)

title: Son for the Roffmans
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Eric H. Roffman of Stony Brook, L. I., on May 28 in the Syosset (L. I.) Hospital. Mrs. Roffman is the former Miss Dorothy Ann Kaplan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Kaplan of New York.

title: Miss Miller Wed To Mark C. Riley
description: SMOKE RISE, N. J., June 17Miss Martha DeGraw Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Collins Miller Jr. of Smoke Rise, was married here this afternoon to Mark Christopher Riley, son of Comdr. William P. Riley Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Riley of Christiansted, St. Croix, Virgin Islands. The Rev. Albert T. Woodward, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the Community Church.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe policies and regulations of the Pay Board are putting a brake on new wage increases  or so it seems at the moment.

title: Mary Judith Friedman Bride Of Theodore Albert Kramer
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 17Miss Mary Judith Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Friedman, was married here this evening to Theodore Albert Kramer in Temple Schaarai Zedek by Rabbi David L. Zielonka.

title: Miami Wins Golf Title
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., June 17 (UPI)The University of Miami at Coral Gables, Fla., captured both the team and individual titles today in the National women's intercollegiate golf tournament. Ann Laughlin, with 310 for 72 holes, won the individual title and teamed with Terry Bednarski for a 639, two strokes better than Florida Slate.

title: Mailbox:
description: In reading Arthur Daley's recent column on 1point or 2point conversions in pro football, a thought occurred.

title: Big Refuse Dump May Close
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS A sprawling landfill, transformed from a centuryold pig farm into one of the state's largest refuse dumps, may close by the end of the month and touch off a solidwaste disposal crisis affecting much of northern New Jersey.

title: Music
description: JOHN PRINE is a 24yearold country singer and composer from Maywood. Ill., a onefactory western suburb of Chicago which was destroyed as a community by the racial clashes of past hot summers and is now slowly dying. Visions of suburban ghost towns form when John talks about Maywooda sciencefiction future of boardedup shopping centers and bluecollar despair.

title: Billy Eckstine's Grand Manner Is Fitting Persian Room Finale
description: There was an air of fatigue and surrender around the Persian Room this week. Like so many of the oldstyle supper clubs that once were at the heart and soul of New York City's sophisticated entertainment, the Persian Room will close next week after the engagement by the singer Billy Eckstine.

title: U.S. Ships Hit, Hanoi Says
description: HONG KONG, June 17 (Reuters)The North Vietnam press agency said today that six United States warships were set ablaze by shelling from shore batteries between June 10 and 14.

title: Unions for Doctors Pose New Challenge to A.M.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17Faced with declining membership, a rift within its hierarchy and rising rankandfile discontent, the 150,000member American Medical Association opens its weeklong annual convention here tomorrow confronted with yet another challenge the unionization of doctors.

title: New & Novel Ragland By John Van Orsdell. 314 pp. New York: World Publishing Co. $7.95.
description: Some pretty crazy things happen in this political melodrama though readers may find them pale beside the burgeoning campaign of 1972. Truth is certainly more interesting than the outlandish ideas of President Jeffrey Ragland, who hopes to launch a compassionate foreign policy by kidnapping. (I won't say whom.) In the private sector, Ragland, a divorc, keeps up with his girlfriend, and love and war carry on in parallel play. ('While Page was savoring the anticipation of her evening in the presidential sack, [Defense Secretary] Archer 0. Stiles was reluctantly meeting with the Joint Chiefs at the Pentagon.') And so it goes.

title: Panel to Study Food Value
description: BOSTON, June 17 (AP)The Massachusetts House has voted to create a special committee to investigate nutritional values of foods sold in the state. The committee will assess existing food enrichment laws and study the feasibility of nutritional labeling requirements.

title: 300 Attend EnvironmentalAction Forum Here
description: Some 300 people involved in programs to improve the environment were given practical information yesterday on how to translate concern into political action at a forum sponsored by Consumer Action Now, Inc., a national organization primarily composed of housewives.

title: New & Novel A Portion For Foxes By Jane McIlvaine McClary. 607 pp. New York: Simon &
description: After Zagaran, a mysterious Gatsby type, buys Ballyhoura, things are never the same among the foxhunting set. Ballyhoura is an antebellum Virginia estate so encrusted with tradition that it comes with an ancestral curse. Curse or no, poor Zagaran seems to have rotten luck, despite his pelf and his good intentions toward the Valley Hunt. He rebuilds the rundown steeplechase course, only to be accused of cheating during the race for the historic Shelburn Cup. Things like that. It seems that chauvinism is thicker than good work, although if the truth were known, Zagaran is more closely related to the F.F.V. crowd than he lets on.

title: The World
description: Alcoholism has long been a serious social problem in the Soviet Union. Premier Khrushchev once tried to reduce the national consumption of vodka by permitting restaurants to serve only one small bottle per diner, But that seemed to encourage many to go from restaurant to restaurant and have a bottle in each place. And it did, nothing to discourage the purchase and consumption of vodka outside of restaurants.

title: White Plains Man Accused Of Sending Threat to I.B.M.
description: A 47yearold White Plains man was arraigned in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday on extortion charges in connection with an alleged threat to set off explosives in the offices of the International Business Machines Corporation and five of its customers unless the company paid $350,000.

title: Terlain Leads as 54 Yachts Start SingleHanded Race
description: PLYMOUTH, England, June 17 (Reuter)  a Frenchman, Jean Yves Terlain, in his 128foot schooner, Vendredi 13 was reported leading the Observer singlehanded yacht race today four hours after the 54 entries got under way.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Democratic candidate George McGovern has been called a radical because he proposes that no one be allowed to inherit more than $500,000. Actually this proposal is neither as radical nor as novel as it would at first appear. A similar one was put forward in 1887 by that Republican nonradical, Rutherford B. Hayes.

title: Pegeen Eustis Becomes Bride Of M. P Keating
description: In St. John's Chapel at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist here yesterday afternoon, Miss Peggy Brittin Eustis was married to Marshall Peter Keating, a senior member of the New York law firm of Kirlin, Campbell & Keating. The ceremony, performed by Msgr. George Kelly, was followed by a small reception for relatives and a few close friends at the River Club.

title: Religion
description: Explo 72: Holler For Jesus

title: The Queens Run: An Omnibus of Informal Seminars
description: The Fresh Meadows Express Bus is homeward bound, bucking through the traffic's iron curtain northbound on the Avenue of the Americas, slogging East on 57th Street in the oozing lavalike flow of vehicles converging on the Queenisboro Bridge, with its superb view of the sunsetbordered Manhattan skyline so rarely observed by the passengers. The bus is one of 14 express bus routes linking Queens and Manhattan. It is the senior service, having started on Feb. 26, 1968, and proving successful enough to inspire more of the same for people who live in what are otherwise twofare busandsubway zones. In addition to Queens, there are seven Bronx express bus routes and two each in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Staten Island.

title: F. D. Moore jr. Marries Ann Clifford Boothby
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17Miss Ann Clifford Boothby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Sands Boothby Jr., was married here today in the garden of her home to Francis Daniels Moore Jr. of Brookline, Mass., son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Daniels Moore.

title: Home Improvement
description: ONE of the simplest and least expensive ways to rejuvenate an old ceiling that is badly cracked, stained or peeling is to put up a new ceiling directly over the old oneusing one of the many forms of ceiling tile that are widely available in lumber yards, hardware stores or other dealers who sell building materials and home improvement supplies.

title: $4Million in Gifts Reported By the Harvard College Fund
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 (AP) Harvard has announced that a record of more than $4million in gifts from alumni, parents and friends was reported by the Harvard College Fund for 19711972.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: NOW that the first half of 1972 is virtually completed, many business analysts are again taking stock of the economy and assessing how their yearend predictions for it have panned out far. On both scores, the track record is quite good.

title: BEE BEE BEE, $4, WINS AT LIBERTY
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17 The Preakness winner, Bee Bee Bee, owned by William S. Farish 3d, trained by D. W. (Dal) Carroll and ridden by Eldon Nelson, won the $29,675 fourth running of the Patriot Stakes for 3yearolds by five lengths from Mrs. James O'Bryant and Mary Belt's Hustlin Greek on a good track today at Liberty Bell Race Track.

title: LUTHERANS STUDY PREJUDICE ROOTS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 17Rosearchers who conducted a major study of Lutheranism in the United States say their findings contradict earlier research that found a correlation between Christian orthodoxy and antiSemitism.

title: The World
description: TOKYODuring his mission here last week to soothe the feelings of resentment against Washington that had arisen in Japan in recent months, Henry A. Kissinger said jestingly he had been told that he himself was the chief problem between Japan and the United States. This was a reference to his image in Japaneseand othereyes as the man President Nixon listens to most in formulating the Administration's foreign policies.

title: MUNCEY SEEKING HIS 5TH GOLD CUP
description: Can 13 other unlimited hydroplanes prevent the most successful driver in the sport from capturing his fifth American Power Boat Association Gold Cup victory next Sunday in Detroit? The answer is probably not.

title: Council Hearing Set
description: The City Council's Housing Committee has scheduled public hearing for next Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. at City Hall to discuss the extension of exemptions from some rent increases for elderly citizens who live on limited incomes.

title: Irish Dream Island: No Government at All
description: ROSAPENNA, County Donegal, IrelandApproached by sea, Tory Island seems to be sinking like a giant linerits bow raised, Ls stern nearly submerged. On the lift in by helicopter, the bow becomes the sheer cliffs at its east end, the stern, its beaches and lowlying pastures and town to the west. Either way, Tory is not easily approachable; the seas and tides and winds off the northwestern coast of Ireland, which is where Tory Island is, are among the worst in the North Atlantic.

title: Alison Magee Jersey Bride
description: HOHOKUS, N. J., June 17In St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Alison Weston Magee and Andrew Stewart, 1968 graduates of the Kent (Conn.) School, were married by the Rev. Hayward J. Levy Jr.

title: FundRaising Tour Begins for Provisional I.R.A.
description: IrishAmericans have begun new drive to raise funds for the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Eight Stories; The Secret of The Crazy Quilt By Florence Hightower. Illustrated by Beth and Joe Krush. 232 pp. Houghton Mifflin. $4.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: The quilt isn't crazy in any playful calicoandstripesandpolkadots sense; it's ugly as sin, and its secret is murder. Intriguing? Yesif murder implies that a person who committed it could have been bravely dealt with rather than dismissed; if the story line did not sag; if the characters talked more and specified less; if they could have been brought to life; and if the descriptions were brisker, not so faded. The time is summer, 1926; the place, a seaside town in Massachusetts. Many things happened that summer, none of them dull. But they are dull indeed as recalled 13 years later through a haze of nostalgia by two narrators, Jerusha, who's a teenager at the time, and Aunt Edith, who's beautiful and resentful, on the verge of spinsterhood.

title: Some Old War Stories Were Fought in Grand Hotels, Too
description: THERE is nothing, said Dr. Johnson, which has yet been contrived by man by which so much happiness is produced as by a good tavern or inn.

title: Earl Clifton Reno Will Marry Mrs. June M. Robbins, Writer
description: Mrs. June Mellies Robbins, a freelance magazine writer of Sharon, Conn., will be married July 14 in Cornwall, Corm., to Earl Clifton Reno, a retired political scientist of Marlow, N. H.

title: Top of the World a Risky Perch
description: SEATTLE, June 17Greg Fredericks looks like the boy who used to live next doora polite, modest, softspoken, selfeffacing 22yearold who suddenly finds himself at the top of the world in track and field, but is not about to let success change his life style.

title: FREETEX, 131, POSTS OHIO DERBY VICTORY
description: CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP)Freetex thundered down the stretch today to beat favored True Knight by 1 lengths in the $101,800 Ohio Derby for 3yearolds at Thistledown.

title: As if John Gunther had written Inside Science
description: What makes people do science? What are scientists like? If some realistic answers haven't yet sunk into the nonscientific reading public, it isn't for the want of telling: from passages of autobiography, like G. H. Hardy's austere and beautiful A Mathematician's Apology, down to James D. Watson's considerably less austere The Double Helix, aided by biographers who are either scientists themselves, such as Emilio Segre and Martin Klein, or commentators who are not scientists but have managed to inform themselves, as in the works of Ronald Clark.

title: Miss Ogden Has Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 17  Miss Constance Linda Ogden and James Thomas Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Greenfield, Ind., were married here this afternoon. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schuyler Ogden of New Canaan.

title: Television
description: I HAVE a confession to make about children's programs. As a subject for discussion, they are near the top of my instantrevulsion list. (The top is shared by game shows and sermonettes.) No area is more subject to the dissection of experts who have fashioned careers out of theories that are so nebulous they are unassailable.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: American Steel Ready to Compete
description: The domestic steel industry Insists that it can compete technologically with any foreign steel industry.

title: Morrison Canisius Coach
description: BUFFALO, June 17 (AP)John R. Morrison, 27yearold former basketball star at Canisius College, was named head basketball coach at Canisius coach today.

title: The World
description: The boy's spindly body sank slowly to the dusty gravel road. He lowered his head to the pebbles, resting his sunken cheek on his hand. His dry, cracked lips did not close. He tried to cover his feet, but the torn, dirtencrusted rags he wore were not long enough. He put a tin can, his only possession, near his stomach. And then he started to cry.

title: Travel Notes:
description: DOWN through the ages, eclipses have terrified man, sending him scurrying for the hills to escape the wrath of the gods. But today. eclipses have become tourist attractions, generating a kind of festive atmosphere. At 4:30 P.M. on Monday, July 10, a total eclipse of the sun will occur in Canadait's billed as the allCanadian eclipseand visitors from all over the world will converge on the 100milewide, crosscountry path of totality to get as close as possible to the phenomenon. The path will also traverse the eastern Soviet Union and Alaska. The eclipse will be the last total solar blackout within easy access of the East Coast of the United States for 45 years, although a lessspectacular total eclipse will be visible from Washington State, Canada and Greenland in 1979.

title: Five Novels
description: First Blood is almost all blood and ample proof that David Morrell, whose first novel it is, is all storyteller.

title: Bus Drivers in New Haven Strike in a Layoff Dispute
description: NEW HAVEN, June 17 (AP) New Haven area residents were left without bus service today when drivers of the Connecticut Company walked off the job in a dispute over the layoff of 10 drivers.

title: HARTFORD PARLEY FASHIONS A SLATE
description: HARTFORD, June 17Fighting off challenges from the floor of the state convention here today, Connecticut's Democrats patched together a largely uncommitted delegation to the party's national convention in Miami Beach on July 10.

title: New York Primary
description: It is widely accepted that slates pledged to Senator George McGovern are going to win an overwhelming share of New York's delegates to the Democratic National Convention. A victory of the dimensions now expected will put Senator McGovern within little more than 200 votes of the necessary majority, making his nomination all but certaina tribute to an extraordinary campaign that has already made history.

title: L.I.Boy, 15, Fatally Shoots Brother, 12. in. L. L Accident
description: EASTPORT, L. I., June 17 a 12yearold boy was accidentally shot and killed by his 15yearold brother today at their home here, according to police.

title: PHONE SERVICE GAIN REPORTED BY P.S.C.
description: The first rebates to New York Telephone Company customers for poor service are being mailed out this month, but citywide service trends have all finally turned in a positive direction, according to the state Public Service Commission.

title: A TwoStar Disciple of the Maharishi
description: Gen. Franklin M. Davis, who presides over the war college, is anything but the stereotype of the military leader. He is outgoing and warm and the author of a dozen books11 novels and an excellent history of the occupation of Germany after World War II called They Came as Conquerors. He also is the leader of an effort to persuade the Army to provide centers for transcendental meditation at all of its posts, and he is meditator himself.

title: Kindergarten Plan Loses
description: PITTSFORD, Vt., June 17 (AP) Voters in the Rutland County town of Pittsford have soundly defeated a proposal to establish a kindergarten as part of their school system. Only 96 of the 472 persons voting on the issue Tuesday were in favor of the preschool program.

title: StateCity Commission Hails Federal Funds to Aid Mentally
description: New Federal funding may provide a chance to help thousands of chronic mentally ill persons who have been discharged from or refused admission to state mental hospitals under a four year old state policy, according to city investigators.

title: Despite Issue of Age, Celler Is Confident
description: Representative Emanuel Celler, 84 years old, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee and the dean of Congress with nearly 50 years in office, does not seem to regard himself as the underdog in his Democratic primary fight against two much younger opponents in Brooklyn's 16th Congressional District.

title: Living fashion
description: I'm not a littleblackdress person, although I do own one, says Nancy White, formerly editorinchief of Harper's Bazaar and now Bergdorf Goodman's fashion director. In Manhattan, I'm sort white and beige. In Connecticut, I'm yellow and orange and bright green. In New Hampshire, I'm red and white and navy. In Vermont, I'm beige and red. Coping with four homes is a mere nothing to Miss White, mother of two and grandmother of three, who is married to Ralph D. Paine Jr., the former publisher and editor of Fortune. Besides her new job at Bergdorf's, she works with the National Council of the Arts, The Lighthouse for the Blind and The Fashion Group. And what about the clothes she chooses for her many activities? I always have three or four smashing coats and underneath I wear something comfortable move around quickly in. I don't think I'm the spectacular type, but I do want to look well dressed and attractive.

title: New &
description: It is hard to imagine a more devastating childhood than that of Philip Neros, one of a brood of eight GreekAmericans living in a Connecticut industrial town. Mother a dementia praecox, buried in self loathing and self love. Interludes in the county home and in the lair of a sadistic foster mother, who mistreats the children and feeds them Laddie Boy. And home: a disheveled nightmare awash in rubbish, hovering on the brink of scandal and disaster. But bad childhoods make good novels, and Mr. Mountzoures extracts pure gold from the rough matrix of his hero's experience.

title: The Nation
description: No city has had more painful opportunity than New York to learn that blending the rigidities of Civil Service with the militancy of trade unionism makes an explosive brew. Developments on four fronts last week provided worrisome notice that fresh eruptions might lie immediately ahead.

title: Kline, Stottlemyre, Lyle Pace Yankee Triumphs
3 INJURED IN FIGHT AT CAMPAIGN OFFICE
description: A brawl occurred early yesterday morning in front of a campaign storefront of an aspirant for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in Brooklyn, resulting in minor injuries to three persons.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., June 17Two New York girls, Pat Shoolman of Fairport and Sheila McInerney of Rome, will meet tomorrow in the final of the New Jersey State (girls 18 years and under) singles championship at the Westfield Tennis Club.

title: Task Force Helps Cool Frustration In Queens
description: For what seemed to be the umpteenth time, the Deputy Mayor was explaining to the 75 welldressed, middleaged people that the city just doesn't have the money for more aanitationmen, more policemen, more men to pave the roads.

title: New York Races
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell, who had previously charged his primary challenger, Assemblyman Leonard M. Simon, with violating Federal election law, obtained a court order yesterday forbidding the distribution of some of Mr. Simon's campaign literature, at least until after the primary.

title: William Woodrow Jr. Weds Susan Lopez
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 17Miss Susan Sandra Lopez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Lopez of this city and of Northport, Mc., and Buenos Aires, was married here this afternoon in St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church to William Thomas Woodrow Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow of Belfast, Me.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture
description: THE scaffolding is up at the Old Merchant's House. It is not destruction, but victory of a sort. The roof is about to be repaired and loose bricks are being replaced.

title: The World
description: Expanding SovietAmerican trade was a major topic during President Nixon's summit meeting with Soviet party leader Leonid Brezhnev last month, though a definitive trade pact eluded the leaders. Last week, however, there were further signs that both sides are still greatly interested in the subject.

title: NIXON GAINS FOUND IN A CATHOLIC POLL
description: President Nixon has scored a sharp and sudden gain in popularity among Roman Catholic voters, moving ahead of both his principal 1972 Demoratic opponents in tests with this voting bloc, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Miss Mary Brooke Carmichael Bride of Richard W. Wooster
description: GATES MILLS, Ohio, June 17Miss Mary Brooke Carmichael and Richard Willet Wooster were married here this afternoon in St. Christopher by the River Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William D. Shively.

title: Jerseyan's Symphony Has Its Premiere
description: CINCINNATIThe world premiere of Variations in a Mod Mood by Mario Lombardo, an Elizabeth, N. J., composer, was a highlight of the American Symphony Orchestra League conference here last week.

title: FlightPath Straying Scored in Queens
description: A group of residents of the South Ozone Park section of Queens called on Congress last week to investigate what they called a constant deviation from prescribed flight patterns into and out of Kennedy International Airport.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Matthews Is Soling Victor In Indian Harbor Regatta
Eight Stories; The Witch of Fourth Street By Myron Levoy. Illustrated by Gabriel Lisowski. 110 pp. Harper & Row. $4.95. (Ages 8 to 11)
description: There's the night the El trains stop so that Keplik, the Match Man can finish his masterpiecea matchstick sculpture of the Brooklyn Bridge. Then there's the mysterious pencil lady, hands twisted like roots torn from the earth, who turns out to be the wife of the jolly organ grinderreassuringly, not a witch at all. Eight stories that remember with bright and sincere sentiment growing up on New York's Lower East Side. Set in an unspecified past, they vary in mood  some are humorous, some shadowed with magicbut all share a rambling, nostalgic pace. Muted illustrations capture basic of the stories with delicate simplicity.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor. Garry Wills is such a brilliant writer, decent man, and longtime polemical friend it is hard for me to feel unkindly toward him. His foible (which I've learned to love) is overkill.

title: The Nations Cup Final
description: BRUSSELS, June 17For the good of the world of soccer, one must hope that West Germany will beat the Soviet Union tomorrow in the final of the European Nations Cup and win a second major victory for total football.

title: Water Study Set Upstate
description: ALBANY, June 17 (AP)Portions of the Genesee River, between Mount Morris and Genesee, and parts of the Black Creek between Churchville and the Genesee River, will be dyed red Monday as part of a United States Geological Survey. The study is to determine how long it might take the two bodies of water to dilute waste materials dumped into them.

title: Soviet Poet Gets U.S. Visa
description: VIENNA, June 17 (UPI)The poet losif Brodsky, who left the Soviet Union earlier this month, received an immigration visa to the United States, United States Embassy sources here said today. Mr. Brodsky, a 32yearold Jew from Leningrad, has accepted a lecturer's post at the University of Michigan.

title: News of the Rialto
description: ACLASSIC putdown has it that those who can, do; those who can't, teach. Naturally, there are exceptions who do both, one being Lawrence Cerra. A short, stocky man with hardly a trace of academe about him, Carra teaches directing at Pittsburgh's CarnegieMellon University, better known as Carnegie Tech. Lately he has sent us John Michael Tebelak, who commenced working on what became the phenomenally successful Godspell while one of Carra's graduate students. Mel Shapiro, who recently won a Tony for his staging of Two Gentlemen of Verona, is another Carra trainee. And now Carra is coming to town with his own item, Comedy.

title: 30 Arrested in Michigan In Campus Antiwar Protest
