description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 17 About 30 persons were arrested here today and charged with malicious destruction of property following attempts by a crowd of about 500 to dig symbollic bomb craters in the lawn of the University of Michigan campus.

title: European Track Mark Tied
description: MILAN, Italy, June 17 (UPI)  Pietro Mennea of Italy equaled the European record of 20.2 seconds for the 200meter dash tonight in a fournation meet among Italy. Belgium, the Soviet Union and Rumania.

title: New Mission to Moscow
description: ATLANTA, June 17 (UPI)A local entomologist, Glenn F. Burkhalter, has been dispatched to Moscow to get rid of cockroaches in the United States Embassy. His employer, the Orkin Division of Rollins, Inc., said Tuesday that Mr. Burkhalter was traveling at company expense because we feel we have a responsibility to help bring peace of mind to ourembassy staff members who have been unable to find a way to control the situation.

title: As if John Gunther had written Inside Science
description: It must be a disappointing irony for the Jesuits that Macdonald Hastings, who admires them so much, is such a poor advertisement for their education. Like his father and grandfather, he went to Stonyhurst, the Jesuits English public school. He was taught the tag Stonyhurst is what Eton was, a school for the sons of Catholic gentlemen"; but Stonyhurst, like other Catholic public schools, seems to have succeeded better in making gentlemen than in making Catholics. Stonyhurst boys may have been the first British soldiers to win the Victoria Cross in both the First and the Second World Wars, but many of its most notable old boysincluding Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, Charles Laughton, Lord Devlin and Mr. Hastings himselfhave shown themselves more loyal to England than to the Roman Catholic Church, which is ironic indeed for the successors of St. Edmund Campion who was hanged, drawn and quartered for putting things the other way around.

title: Doctor to the body of the doctor of the mind
description: In wartime Vienna, during the autumn of 1915, Max Schur, not yet 20 and at the beginning of his medical studies, attended Freud's introductory course of lectures on psychoanalysis. It is not clear why he did not, then and there, choose psychoanalysis as his life work. Dr. Schur decided upon a more orthodox career; he specialized in internal medicine. But Freud's medicine had taken, quite internally; for a few years Schur remained a mere admirer, but in 1924 he began the formal part of his conversion experience; he found himself in analysis. Four years later, Schur treated the Princess Marie Bonaparte, among all Freud's disciples the one who carried the highest social prestige. Princess Marie persuaded the ailing and aging Freud, then 72 years old, to appoint the able young internist as his personal physician. During the decade of their relation, professional and personal, Schur was an intimate witness to the slow, painful and unutterably dignified death of Freud's body. This immortal mind was encased in an extraordinary character.

title: Toll Reaches 63 in French Train Wreck
description: VlERZY, France, June 17This village of 300 at the mouth of a milelong railway tunnel about 60 miles north of Paris was preparing to celebrate its annual farmers feast day when the first news came from the tunnel last night.

title: BROOKLYN TOURED BY MRS. CHISHOLM
description: Mrs. Shirley Chisholm brought her campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination home to Brooklyn yesterday.

title: SPEEDUP TESTED BY QUEENS POLICE
description: The Police Department has begun a program in Queens designed to speed booking procedures for criminal suspects and enable the arresting policemen to return to duty sooner.

title: City to Restore Memorial To Prisoners of British
description: Down, rebels, down! was the cry of the British guards as the American prisoners were forced into the hold of the ships at night. In the morning, it was: Rebels, turn out your dead!

title: HARVARD'S EIGHT TOPS YALE AGAIN
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14Harvard's wellcoordinated varsity eight, understroking Yale for the entire fourmile trip down the Thames River, continued the domination over its traditional rival today with a sparkling fivelength victory.

title: 2 Die on Argentine Train
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, June 17 (Reuters)An express passenger train rammed into stopped freight train today, killing at least two persons and injuring several others, the police said.

title: Czechoslovakia Gains 11 Tie
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, June 17 (UPI)Czechoslovakia tied West Germany, 11, today after the second singles match of their semifinal Section B European Zone Davis Cup competition.

title: McGovern Income Plans Ridiculed by a Nixon Aide
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Nixon Administration attacked for the first time in detail today Senator George McGovern's plan for redistributing the nation's income and raising the money through tax reform.

title: Mailbox:
description: Thirtysix years after the most disgraceful Olympics in history, German officials, this time with the seeming consent of Avery Brundage, are once again introducing bigotry, racial prejudice and stupidity into international athletic competition.

title: Whitney Young Center Dedicated in Kentucky
description: SIMPSONVILLE, Ky., June 17 (UPI)Mrs. David Eisenhowever, eulogizing the late Whitney M. Young, Jr. yesterday as a mediator who helped people find understanding, dedicated a new Job Corps center that was named in his honor at his birthplace here.

title: George Roberts Hoguet Weds Marie Montamat in Bay State
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., June 17Miss Marie Isabel Montamat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Montamat of Vineyard Haven and Gay Head on Martha's Vineyard, was married here this morning to George Roberts Hoguet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Hoguet of New York, Syosset, L. I., and Colo.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONIn Detroit, a judge in Misdemeanor Court hired a different lawyer each day last week, paying him $150 to sit all day defending succession of alleged drunks, prostitutes and assorted miscreants. In Seattle, when a drunk court judge requested the public defender to do the same, he refused, saying he would have no part of assembly line justice. In Nashville, a Traffic Court judge surveyed his courtroom, full of lawyerless defendantsand recessed court for a week.Experience has shown that the legal new breed takes to breaking new legal ground for the poor, but that most lawyers quickly feel bogged down in the repetitive business of handling the daytoday legal woes of the poor.

title: Cal Eleven Going South
description: BERKELEY, Calif. (UPI)The University of California football team will hold a twoweek fall practice session at the University of California at Santa Barbara campus.

title: Dance: Bolshoi Troupe on Canada Tour
description: OTTAWA, June 17The ways of cultural exchanges and cultural politics are strange indeed. It is now six years since the full Bolshoi Ballet played in New York, although a troupe of Bolshoi dancers did have a season at the Metropolitan Opera in 1969. Now a similar troupe led by Maya Plisetskaya is on a Canadian tour, but is not moving south of the border to the United States. This is sad.

title: Eight Stories; Up the Pier By Helen Cresswell. Illustrated by Gareth Floyd. 144 pp. Macmillan. $4.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: A fantasy set along a bleak pier in Wales, past shabby, deserted kiosks, under leaden skies, where the gulls screech. Young Carrie chances upon the Pontifexes, an odd lot whom a magic spell has brought forward in time from 1921 to 1971. Is the author's wish to convey the struggle between man's desiderata and harsh reality? Or is her aim to entertain via the antics of Welsh magical tradition in its cheerless modernday degeneracy? She fails in either case; for the ethical crux remains buried under a farrago of contrived characterizations and the plot fizzles out despite its original promise of succulent mysteries.

title: Pop
description: ON Friday night, June 9, an air of shabby carnival hung over Seventh Avenue. The sidewalks around Madison Square Garden teemed with kids and toothless old men hawking Elvis pennants, Elvis posters, albums of Elvis pictures. There were cops on horses and cops on foot, and vendors with brown paper bags containing Elvis Tshirts circulated among the ticketholders. But few ticketholders stopped to buy. They kept moving toward the arena, their excitement so palpable it seemed to cut through the muggy twilight.

title: A School Board Head in Jersey Orders Liberal Books Deleted
description: ROSELLE, N. J., June 17John Everett, president of the Roselle Board of Education, bluepenciled four books this week that were to be placed in the high school library here as part of a new federally funded American studies course.

title: 8 Dead in Hong Kong Rains
description: HONG KONG, June 17 (AP) Eight persons were known dead in floods and landslides today as heavy rain continued to drench the city for the second day. More than a dozen others were reported missing, and at least two of those were believed to have been buried under mud and rock in one of the more than 30 landslides that have crashed down Hong Kong's steep hillsides since yesterday morning. More than 12 inches of rain has been measured in the last two days.

title: CATHOLIC DEFICIT IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17A comprehensive study of the fivecounty. Philadelphia archdiocesean school system, the second. largest Roman Catholic system in the country, has found that mounting deficits and declining enrollment pose a grave threat of collapse.

title: Letters
description: I read with interest the article Scholars Ponder Right to Shelter [May 7] It would appear that New York State law relating to forming cooperative apartments is unconstitutional and a violation of due process when applied to a rentstabilized tenant who votes against cooperative plan.

title: Photography
description: TWOWEEK workshop in photography, open to anyone with basic skills, and sponsored by Columbia College in Chicago, will be conducted on a farm near Woodman, Wisconsin. To run from Aug. 27 to Sept. 10, the course will give students three college credits, and applicants must submit a sample of their work by July 1. The cost will be $240, which includes room and board, darkroom facilities and instruction. Those interested should write the Photography Department, Columbia College, 469 East Ohio Street, Chicago, Ill. 60611.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Regarding the article (June 4) with regard to the longterm consequence for the dollar of the energy shortage: While increasing imports of energy will undoubtedly change our trade pattern (as will those of other short raw materials), I believe your approach is an oversimplification.

title: Candidates in Primary Submit Preliminary Campaign Figures
description: Preliminary campaign spending figures for the state primary election Tuesday show Senator George McGovern spending more than twice as much as Senator Edmund S. Muskie in a contest hardly considered a, race but nevertheless costing at least a million dollars.

title: Loss of Gold Smuggling Hurts Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 17 (AP)The onceflourishing gold smuggling industry here has collapsed, forcing the Government to take drastic action to save what remains of the economy.

title: Popularity Rating Slumped
description: TOKYO, June 17A recent public opinion poll indicated that the popularity rating of the Sato Government had fallen to 24 per cent, the lowest for any Cabinet since World War II.

title: Miss Moffatt Plans Bridal
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 17 The engagement of Miss Camille Ann Moffatt to Henry Lawrence Bertram, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Henry Bertram Jr. of Haworth, N. J., and Amagansett, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James V. Moffatt of the Hill School, Pottstown.

title: Craftsmen Project Expanding
description: LAYTON  The Peters Valley Craftsmen, a New Jersey pilot project to broaden and increase the creative use of national recreational areas, is enlarging program, as well as its p ysical facilities, with a boost from the National Park Service.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An experiment in highintensity lighting, under way for six months along a one mile strip of the Henry Hudson Parkway, has cut down accidents and brought praise from motorists, according to the city's Department of Public Works. The experimental lowpressure sodium lights, which cast an amber glow, were installed along the highway. between 158th and 182d Streets last December.

title: Rutgers Clinic Aids In Key Law Cases
description: NEWARK  What has the Rev.. Philip Berrigan in common with the longhair students involved in a controversy with the New Jersey State Police?

title: SHOP TALK
description: RUTHERFORD  Only eight miles west of Times Square, in the heart of the New JerseyNew York metropolitan area, this surprisingly peaceful borough in Bergen County is home to one university, at least 50 industrial plants and 20,000 people. It is a nice mix.

title: AROUND THE
description: Malothion is a low toxicity, broad spectrum spray that can be used to reduce populations of aphids, leaf chewers and other nibblers.... Resow beans. Be alert for chinch bug damage to lawns, especially on Long Island.... Keep up fruit tree spray schedule... Finish annual plantings for border and terrace displays.

title: Downstate Developing Family Doctors
description: Every Wednesday afternoon, many Brooklyn residents go to the Downstate Medical Center in Flatbush, there to be treated by teams of medical students working in a recently developed concept of patient care.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: I'm starting a Baptist novena for Robert Townsend. His review of In the Name of Profit, a survey by a team of veteran reporters telling us who did what inside the private governments of six monster companies, is the wisest, wittiest, most hopeinspiring call to action I've heard so far in our present climate of despair.

title: Pupils Given Insight on Legal Rights
description: NEWARKThey want to know what to do if a policeman searches their car or their landlord threatens to dispossess them; they want to know about family law, consumer law, draft laws and work laws.

title: Kirsten Fenninger Plans Wedding
description: SPRINGTOWN, Pa., June 17Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Fenninger Jr. of Springtown and South Welifleet, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kirsten Fenninger, to Robert W. Ramage Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ramage of Snyder, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: Eight Stories; Right On, Shane By Matthew Skulicz. 119 pp. Putnam's. $4.75. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: For a time, Shane, a fatherless Harlem teenager may look familiar: the hero as a dropout, aimlessly shuttling between violence and alienation. When a friend is hospitalized after an attack by a rival gang member, Shane retaliates with his knife in the streets. He dallies briefly with an attractive, forthright girl, but drops her when she gets serious. Another buddy gets Shane's 14yearold sister pregnant, and Shane, whose insistence on respect is uncompromising, decides that an illegal abortion financed by a oneman ripoff is the answer. It is in the subsequent tragedy that Shane comes to accept the bitter verdict: respect has to be reciprocal. The story moves at heady pace which indifferent readers, for whom the book is designed, will follow readily.

title: Amei Wallach Wed to Charles Tebo
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 17Miss Amei Wallach and Charles F. Tebo were married here this evening at the home of friends by the Rev. Lewis Davis, a retired Methodist minister. He was assisted by Wendell Wallach, the bride's brother, who attended the Harvard Divinity School. The couple wrote parts of their wedding ceremony.

title: David Hayes to Wed Miss Elizabeth Tracy
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., June 17 The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Simpson Tracy to David Michael Hayes, son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Hayes of Syracuse, N. Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sedgwick Tracy of Hillside and Skaneateles Lake, N. Y. A wedding.. in August is planned.

title: Bethanne L'Hommedieu a Bride on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, LI., June 17Miss Bethanne L'Hommedicu and Richard Duffy of Oyster Bay were married here today in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector. A reception followed at the Swan Club in Glen Head.

title: Historical Seepage
description: The recent complete declassification of the thirtyyearold secret wartime correspondence between Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill by the Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park underscores one of the archival anomalies of the United States: The fact that the papers of the President, the greatest of American public offices, are the private property of the Chief Executive which he is free to dispose of as he wishes when he leaves office. This has been the custom since the administration George Washington, and many are the records that could illuminate a Presidency which have been dispersed, lost, secreted or destroyed as a result of that tradition.

title: New & Novel The Three Sentinels By Geoffrey Household. 220 pp. Boston: AtlanticLittle, Brown &
description: Irony drips from this sophisticated thriller, an intricate moral confrontation characteristic of Geoffrey Household. Item: a hasbeen mining engineer as imperturbable as El Exigente, hired to settle a workers boycott in a bleak South American oilfield. Item: an idealistic workers leader with the psyche of a mad priest, who differs with both the Britishowned company and his own union. Stalemate ensues, accompanied by sniper fire, gelignite and the death of some of the oilfield workers wives in a confused encounter.

title: Eight Stories; The Windmill Summer By Hila Fell. Illustrated by Fred Brenner. 128 pp. Harper & Row. $4.95. (Ages 8 to 12)
description: Over the years authors have manipulated their young characters into everything from a boxcar to the Metropolitan Museum in order to get them in a place that's different, where life is inventive, independent and endlessly interesting. In this story 11yearold Arabella, discontented with her life in a houseful of elderly relatives, moves into Greatgrandfather Horace's windmill which is built in the shape of a ship complete with spiral staircase and galley. Arabella befriends and cooks for numerous animals (salmon mousse for a raccoon, bass with mayonnaise collee for herself). The animals are supposedly drawn from those near the author's salt marsh home, but it's the people back at the big house who bring the book to life. Light and pleasant reading and an intriguing backtonature experience.

title: Letters:;UNSUITABLE ESCORT
description: To THE EDITOR: Peter Andrews seems to have fared better than Judy Klemesrud in the Miami rentadate department, on which they wrote paired articles headed Leasing People for Fun and Profit (Travel section, June 4). Whatever prompted the RentaGent agency to send Miss Klemesrud a man wearing a bright orange suit? I would have promptly sent him away as being an unsuitable escort for anything more advanced than a trained wallaby (no slight to wallabies intended). But, Miami being what it is, maybe no one noticed.

title: Stamps
description: STAMPS of the People's Republic of China, never entered in general stamp catalogues published in the United States, are to get recognition in forthcoming 1973 editions of the Minkus World Wide Stamp Catalog and the Scott Standard Stamp Catalogue.

title: Traditional Golf Events Pose Conflict for Women in Area
description: Two traditional golf events are scheduled this week. One is the 69th annual Women's, Metropolitan Golf Association matchplay championship and the other is the 66th annual Women's Eastern 54hole medalplay tournament.

title: TaftHartley at 25How It's Worked
description: With the end of World War II and of the nonstrike pledge given by organized labor to assure full production in the arsenal of democracy came an unparalleled wave of strikes. Virtually every major industry was shut down for some period in 1946, bringing the volume of strike losses on an economywide basis to one day out of every 60 of scheduled work time, a record never approached before or since.

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONAt one time, Binhlong province north of Saigon was a prosperous region heavily planted with neat rows of rubber trees and with flourishing towns strung out along its one real road.

title: Mittlers Have Child
description: A daughter was born June 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Mittler of New York at the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Mittler is the former Miss Janet Schlesinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Schlesinger.

title: Artists at Westbeth Fight Plan For a 17 Per Cent Increase
description: The families of 250 artists living at Westbeth, the artists colony on West Street in Lower Manhattan, have organized to fight a demand for a 17 per cent increase.

title: Miss Susan Whittington Affianced
description: ARLINGTON, Va., June 17 Banning E. Whittington, press officer of the United States Supreme Court, and Mrs. Whittington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Luella Whittington, to Lieut. Peter Christopher Woolston, U. S. N., son of Mrs. Evelyn D. Woolston of Washington's Georgetown section, and Capt. John Woolston, U. S. N., commander of the Charleston (S. C.) Naval Shipyard.

title: OLD CHINESE CITY IS THRIVING ANEW
description: SIAN, China, June 15Fifteen hundred years ago this was probably the world's greatest cityChangan, capital of China's Tang Dynasty and boasting a population estimated at 2,000,000.

title: Blind Darkroom Technician at Hospital Sees Film With Hands
description: The radrorogicar department of Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens, is small and crowded. The patients wait silently to be Xrayed and, with the anesthesia room also on the seventh floor, that particular hospital smell is more apparent than usual.

title: Stokes Game Set for Aug. 15
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 17 (AP)The annual Maurice Stokes Memorial benefit basketeball game will be played Aug. 15 at Kutsher's Country Club here. The game is named for the former Cincinnati Royals star, who died in 1970.

title: Television; Got a Problem? Call Christopher Jones
description: IT'S a typical Monday in Megalopolis  that crazyquilt community of 20 million people who live in New York City, the suburbs, and neighboring parts of Connecticut and New Jersey. This morning, a 74yearold man in Rego Park, whose Medicare check is three months late, will be disappointed again as the mail brings only a chanceofalifetime giveaway and coupons worth 10 cents on cat food; in Secaucus, a woman whose home is within inhaling distance of a smoldering refuse dump will lock the windows, tell the kids they have to play indoors, and take two Valium; in the back seat of a limousine, a distinguished captain of industry from Bedford Hills will review his unanswered letters to a fashionable men's clothing store demanding a refund on a damaged $325 overcoat, and feel a strange sinksensation.

title: 5 Charged With Burglary at Democratic Quarters
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Five men, said to have been carrying cameras, electronic surveillance equipment and burglary tools, were arrested shortly after 2 A.M. today after a floorbyfloor search that led to the executive quarters of the National Democratic Committee here. The suspects were charged with seconddegree burglary.

title: As if John Gunther had written Inside Science
description: A little more than 10 years ago Goronwy Rees, formerly principal of University College of Wales in Aberystwyth, journalist, and columnist for Encounter, wrote an autobiographical study, A Bundle of Sensations. Elegiac in style and drawing in a quite arbitrary way upon a handful of significant incidents in his life, it ended with his recuperation from a serious automobile accident he had suffered in the 1950's.

title: Legislative Notes: A 2d Term for Education Chief
description: TRENTON  Dr. Carl L. Marburger had been in office for only 11 weeks as New Jersey Commissioner of Education in September, 1967, when he stunned a convention of school superintendents by suggesting that the best way to integrate schools would be to change district lines.

title: A School for Auto Racers on the Island
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I. Classes start at 9 A.M. at Fred Opert's Motor Racing School at Bridgehampton Raceway, but Jonathan Farkas, in a tan RollsRoyce Silver Cloud, arrived an hour early for his first class.

title: From a novelist waiting for the muse
Girl, 15, Stabbed to Death in Home
description: A 15yearold girl was stabbed to death early yesterday by an intruder who climbed through a groundfloor window into her bedroom in the Jamaica section of Queens.

title: Movies
description: VINCENT CANBY says the voluntary film rating system is all wrong. Canby recommends that the entire rating system be scrapped and the movie industry use its funds to fight nuisance suits against the industry. In other words, abandon ratings and then fight local censoring or legal classification authorities.

title: Staten Island Cricket Victor
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club side defeated Brooklyn C. C. by 77 runs yesterday at Red Hook Stadium, Brooklyn. The totals were Staten Island 138, Brooklyn 59.

title: IRT Clerk Robbed and Shot
description: Holdup men shot and slightly wounded a subway changebooth clerk in Brooklyn early this morning after robbing him of $70 at the Van Siclen Avenue Station of the MT. the Transit Police said. The clerk, whose name was not released, was treated for a stomach wound and released from Brookdale Hospital, according to the Transit Police.

title: Philippe Disqualified in 800
description: The threeday meet has been marked by a number of controversies. A dispute in a semifinal of the 800meter run cost Marcel Philippe of Fordham a spot in the final.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: As an anthropologist and as an American, I must object to Confessions of a Tomb Robber by Robert J. Dunphy (Travel section, June 4). The article [the writer described how he brought home from Mexico a ceramic bowl for which he paid $3 and which the vender claimed was a Mayan artifact] concluded that the worst that could happen was that the bowl would have to be returned to Mexico. That is not the worst thing that can happen: Your writer may find that on his next visit to Mexico he faces a jail sentence as a receiver of stolen goods. That the item is of small value and that other travelers are equally guilty is no excuse before the law.

title: 2 Years in Making
description: WASHINGTON, June 17When President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev signed the four copiestwo in English and two in Russianof the arms limitation agreements at 11 P.M. on May 26, they kept a little secret from the hundreds of newsmen covering the event in Moscow.

title: Miss Stephanie von Hirschberg Married to Joseph V. Del Gatto
description: Miss Stephanie Mary von Hirschberg, daughter of Carl F. G. von Hirschberg, permanent representative of the Republic of South Africa to the United Nations, and Mrs. von Hirschberg of New York and Pretoria, South Africa, and Joseph Vincent Del Gatto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Del Gatto of Manchester, N. Y., were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELSPerhaps nothing better symbolizes the cockeyed conditions of our present world than the following juxtaposition of known facts. The Soviet Union sincerely desires a European security conference to be followed by a formal EastWest agreement: It is prepared to pay for the latter ratification of Europe's existing borders by some kind of separate mutual balanced force reduction (the famous M.B.F.R.) of the NATO and Warsaw Pact armies.

title: Harriman Concludes Campaign
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y. June 17 After more than a month of intensive campaigning for a place on the New York State I delegation to the Democratic National Convention, W. Averell Harriman settled down today to his more familiar role of elder statesman, advising the party in planning its platform on peace, defense and the economy.

title: Housing For Aged In Brooklyn Advances
description: Progress was reported last week on plans to create residences for Bay Ridge's population of 18,000 elderly persons.

title: The Nation
description: Locked in bitter Democratic primary struggles in districts with large Jewish populations; New York City's Congressional candidates often sound like they're running for the Knesset.

title: FORD TO RECEIVE FOOTBALL AWARD
description: Gerald R. (Jerry) Ford, Representative for 24 years from Michigan and a member of the University of Michigan's undefeated teams of 1932 and 1933, was named yesterday as the 16th recipient of the National Football Foundation's Gold Medal Award.

title: Hotels and Motels Have a Lot of Room for Improvement
description: THERE'S a clean traveling salesman story currently going the rounds among businessmentravelers, who make up twothirds of all hotel guests, that has a lot more truth than fancy to it. The joke has the salesman handing the hotel manager a bouquet of flowers. It's for the switchboard operator, he says. Thank you, sir, the manager replies, I'm sure she will appreciate the compliment for her fine service. Service? roars the salesman. I thought she was dead.

title: ALGERIAN PRESIDENT REDISTRIBUTES LAND
description: ALGIERS, June 17President Houari Boumediene started his plan of redistributing land to the peasants today in the middie of a wheat field at the little village of Khemisklkhethna, about 15 miles east of Algiers.

title: Carol Elizabeth Burr Married in Jersey
description: TEANECK, N. J., June 17Miss Carol Elizabeth Burr, an associate professor of English literature at Chico (Calif.) State College, was married this afternoon to Stephen Louis Francone, an engineer with the Matson Steamship Company in San Francisco. The Rev. Eric Kullberg performed the ceremony in the Teaneck United Methodist Church.

title: Movies
description: IM not personally offended by sex and violence, says the inflatedlooking man with the short legs, the flushed face and the pouting lips. But I always take great care in my own films to use the best possible taste.

title: Stamps,
description: Belgica 72, the international stamp show, opens in Brussels, Belgium on June 24. As reported here May 21, the United States Postal Service will release a souvenir card at the show on its opening day utilizing vignettes of three United States stamps linked to Belgium.

title: SOL YAGED PLAYS JAZZ FOR DANCING
description: For years and years, memories of the swing era and, in particular the sound and style of Benny Goodman, have been kept alive in New York by Sol Yaged. He is a clarinetist who has made the Goodman manner completely his own and whose groups have been patterned on the Goodman combos of the 30's and 40's.

title: Scholars Starting to Advise McGovern
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 It may be too early to call it a brain trust, but small cadres of scholars have begun to coalesce to provide Senator George McGovern with policy advice on foreign affairs, science and economics.

title: Marion RobinsonDuff Is Bride Of Patrick Oliver Filley on L.I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 17Miss Marion RobinsonDuff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay RobinsonDuff Jr. of Oyster Bay, was married here this afternoon to Patrick Oliver Filley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Dwight Filley Jr. of Far Hills, N. J.

title: The World
description: PEKINGPremier Chou Enlai has simple advice for the United States on how to end the Vietnam war: Bite the bullet.

title: Art
description: AS a sculptor, Jacques Lipchilz has never been exactly lighthanded. His earliest worksthe historically important sculptures, influenced by Cubist painting, which he began executing around 1914 and 1915were apt to be stolid and sober in their translations of Cubist pictorial devices into threedimensional form. Much of his sculpture has been characterized by a certain weightinessa kind of peasantlike stolidityeven when it has been most poetic. That is, even when, as Lipchitz admits of his later sculptures, the work has been prompted more by mythical or poetic considerations than by strictly formal concerns.

title: Can the Main St. Hotel Survive?
description: WHEN travelers talk about hotels, their grandeur, their growth and the creature comforts they provide, they are usually thinking in terms of the big places, those monuments to jet and superhighway travel that are operated by the hotel chains. But there is another kind of hotel that is grand not in its total of square feet or number of rooms but in its relation to the community in which it stands and the affection in which is held by the townspeople as well as its guests.

title: Letters; TV ADS (MALE VIEW)
description: To THE EDITOR: NOW's attack on TV commercials (NOW Says: TV Commercials Insult Women, by Judith Adler Hennessee and Joan Nicholson, May 28) is way off target. While feminists are trying to change society advertisers are trying to appeal to people as they really are.

title: Story Wins Yale Award
description: NEW HAVENWilliam Lawrence (Larry) Story Jr., a standout lacrosse and football player at Yale for the last three years, has been named to receive the university's highest athletic recognition, the William Neely Mallory Award.

title: STATE BOXING TITLE IS TAKEN BY LEWIS
Should the Public Play a Role in Antitrust Settlements?; Two Rulings Suggest Idea Gains Acceptance
description: WASHINGTON  Just as war is too important to be handled exclusively by the military generals, big antitrust settlements are too important to be handled exclusively by the attorneys generalof either party.

title: the traveler's world
description: TROMSO, NorwayThere has been no night here in northern Norway well above the Arctic Circle for the past several days and on Wednesday, Midsummer's Day, the sun will shine brightly 24 hours around the clock on a kind of atavistic solar bacchanalia that will rock this Land of the Midnight Sun with joy. Tourism officials of Scandinavia have embraced this natural phenomenon caused by the earth's orbiting of the sun, and anyone who has not held for some time a confirmed airplane seat and a confirmed hotel reservation throughout the northern reaches of Norway, Sweden and Finland will have trouble getting a close view of a genuine 24hourdaylight day.

title: Foyt Joins Chorus of Criticism Aimed at Geriatric Set at Indy
description: No less an authority than A.J. Foyt, threetime winner of the Indianapolis 500, has joined the chorus criticizing the neardisaster in the 500 on May 27, when the chief steward, Harlan Fengler, abruptly started the race one lap earlier than the drivers had been signaled to expect. Most of the blame is concentrated on the incident in which the pace car, to get off the track, had to cut in front of Bobby Unser's poleposition car. Foyt noted another nearaccidentHis car, stalled at the start, was ready to roll from the end of pit row after the single pace lap. If, in the confusion of the contradictory yellowthengreen lights, Foyt had joined the racing pack, you would have seen the damndest wreck you've ever seen. Foyt also saw overkill in the penalties imposed on Jerry Grant and Jim Hurtubise.

title: Music
description: IT seems as if most instrumentalists, young and old, student and professional, take to the countryside about the time of the summer solstice. They don't change their habits muchthey spend most of their time on practice, ensemble rehearsals and performance but at least the environment is different. Some them manage to get further afield than the United States and Canada; they go to Europe. And if their schedule is still centered around the business or pleasure of making music, they can enjoy the perquisites of sightseeing, sampling a foreign culture, learning another language.

title: World News Briefs
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 17The Pakistani Government tonight announced a budget for the coming fiscal year in which a record amount will be spent on national defense.

title: 5 Killed as 2 Planes Collide Over Airport in San Diego
description: SAN DIEGO, June 17 (UPI)Two light planes collided in the air and crashed today, killing five persons. One of the planes was apparently in trouble and trying to land, and the other was taking off.

title: Susan Hunter, Smith Alumna, Is Bride of M. Peter Thomson
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 17Miss Susan Hunter was married here this noon to M. Peter Thomson. They have been friends since she was a student at the Emma Willard School and he was at Deerfield Academy. And when the bridegroom was attending Dartmouth College, the bride, a student then at Smith College, spent her junior year at Dartmouth as an exchange student.

title: BRITAIN BOWS, 52
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 17The socalled secondrate United States women's tennis team, headed by the teenage prodigy, Chris Evert, and four players ranked midway in the first 20, won the Wightman Cup today, 52.

title: Letters
description: The article headlined MobileHome Plan Thwarted [May 28] is rather disappointing in its implications. Having been concerned with the design and production of prefabricated houses for four decades, I have always felt that largescale prefabrication in the small house field can be accomplished only by the manufacture of houses of the type that we no longer call trailers, but mobile homes. For the fact of the matter is that pretab houses can be produced in quantity, at low cost, with a wide variety of sizes, shapes and plans only by the mobilehome industry.

title: Strike Ended in Pakistan After Inquiry Is Ordered
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 17 Thousands of workers who had tied up hundreds of industrial plants in this city for the past 10 days called off their strike today and decided to resume work Monday.

title: The Nation
description: What this country needs, of course, is a safer bullet. And last week the New York City Police Department announced that it had found one and put it into service. The new projectile is simply flattipped rather than round and is safer because:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I was pleased to learn in the article Use Highway Fund Money for Highways that the trucking industry allowed itself to be taxed for highways; the rest of us are taxed whether we like it or not.

title: On Long Island
description: LEVITTOWN, L. I.When Mrs. Ella DeGregorio first saw Levittown, its name, at least to her, was mudplain, unadulterated mud. Now, in Levittown's 25th anniversary year, three generations of DeGregorios'. call it home.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PARISAt a recent art show here the cloakroom attendant insisted on taking the briefcase of Dr. Milton Gilbert. I've got all the economic secrets of the world in there, said the economic adviser to the Bank for International Settlements. But he finally yielded.

title: WINESBURG, OHIO SUBJECT OF DANCE
description: Dance Theater Workshop has put together one of its strongest programs at the Riverside Church this weekend in what is billed as the New York debut of the organization's touring unit, the DTW Company.

title: Royal Visit to Olympics
description: LONDON, June 17 (Reuters) Queen Elizabeth will pay a private visit to Germany to attend part of the Olympic Games, Buckingham Palace announced today. The Queen, accompanied by Princess Anne, will stay with the Duke of Bavaria in Munich from Aug. 29 to Sept. 1.

title: For Anloc Civilians, Weeks of Terror
description: PHUCUONG, South Vietnam, June 15 One afternoon during the North Vietnamese siege of Anloc an artillery shell killed eight people in the house to the left of where Vu Van Nam and his family were staying. The next morning another shell killed 12 people in the house on the right.

title: Japanese Accused in Israel Reportedly Shuns Lawyer
description: TEL AVIV, June 17 (AP)The Israeli lawyer picked to defend Kozo Okamoto, the Japanese accused in connection with the killing of 24 persons at the international airport here on May 30, said today he had dropped the case because Okamoto refused to accept Ms services.

title: Press Curb Feared As Chile Restricts A Paper Company
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 17The economic strangulation through Government restrictions of Chile's only private producer of newsprint is being denounced by the anti Marxist Opposition as a threat to freedom of the press.

title: Eight Stories; The Year of the ThreeLegged Deer By Eth Clifford. Illustrated by Richard Cuffari. 164 pp. Houghton Mifflin. $3.95. (Ages 9 to 12)
description: The bone of this tragic story is the terrible dilemma of the frontier: Jesse Benton, his Indian wife and their children, 14yearold Takawsu and 10yearold Chilili (who speaks to animals and nurses a savagelymauled fawn), must, this year of 1819, choose a colori.e., in the future they must call themselves either red or white. This novel tells of their last year together: moonlit deer hunts, a renegade Indian's ambush, a black man's kidnap by slave hunters, a historic trial in which white men are sentenced to hang for massacring Indians. Yet despite the richness of the history on which the book is carefully based, the story itself is disastrously told. Flashbacks interrupt events constantly. Details jumble, people jerk back into the present suddenly, and the villains speak frontier colloquialisms while all the heroes speak pure English.

title: Carolyn Strahan Zoephel Bride Of Lieut. James B. Lockhart 3d
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., June 17Miss Carolyn Strahan Zoephel and Lieut. (jg.) James Bicknell Lockhart 3d U.S.N.R. were married here this afternoon in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Albert Wickens.

title: HOUSE UNIT CRITICAL OF AID TO CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)A House committee accused the Nixon Administration today of suppressing the record on United States aid to Cambodia.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The Secretary of Agriculture spoke impatiently of restless cheap food advocates.

title: Ch. Acadia's Xaari, a Standard Poodle, Is Chosen Best in Show at Bryn Mawr
LOCAL HANOI RADIO HINTS AT TROUBLES
description: HONG KONG, June 17North Vietnam projects abroad an image of a selfless, dedicated people and a valiant, unbeatable army, but in broadcasts intended only for home consumption there are hints of problems and pressures among the civilian population and the members of the armed forces.

title: Suits on Gettysburg Tower Plan Scheduled in Court This Week
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 17 Two more skirmishes in the latest battle of Gettysburg will take place next week when a Court of Common Pleas judge hears two cases involving planned construction of a 307foot commercial observation tower overlooking the Civil War battlefield here.

title: Mary Shea Wed To Daniel Helt, Indiana Lawyer
description: WESTON, Mass., June 17Miss Mary Linda Shea, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Francis Shea of Weston, was married here this afternoon to Daniel White Helt. He is the son of Mrs. Allen Heber Helt of Dana, Ind., and the late Mr. Helt.

title: Kennedy and Mills Urge Health Plan For 1972 Platform
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Two influential Democrats urged their party today to adopt compulsory national health insurance as a plank of its 1972 platform.

title: Mexico's Happy Plant
description: HOSPITALITY In Mexico begins with a tequila cocktail. Since preColumbian times, this alcoholic beverage is brewed from the maguey or agave plant which is native to the American tropics. Misnamed the Century Plant', for it falsely had been thought to bloom once in hundred years, the agave is truly a miracle of nature in providing man's basic needs.

title: The Nation
description: TRENTONRaising taxes anywhere involves enormous political risksbut nowhere are they more perilous than in New Jersey, the only large industrial state in the country that has no state income tax. Last week, however, the state felt the initial shock from what promises to be the greatest tax battle in its history as the Legislature convened in special session to consider  an income tax.

title: Girl Jockey Wins Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., June 17 (AP)Melmitch, a 10yearold bay gelding, won the $2,000 feature at Finger Lakes Race Track today by threequarters of a length over Deltas Gem. Violet Smith rode the winning horse over the mile in 1:40 35. Melmitch paid $4.40, $3.20 and $2.80.

title: Puerto Rico: Island in Search of Itself
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto RicoWill the real Puerto, Rico please stand up?

title: Nets Rookie Training Camp: A St. John's Reunion
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 17 Although he was bedridden with a virus, Lou Carnesecca, the Nets coach, did not forget this week that he once coached basketball at St. John's University.

title: Five Novels
description: The author of the following reviews has written Greased Samba and Other Stories, One Morning, for Pleasure and the forthcoming nonfiction book, Rancho Paradise.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The biggest Italian mistake, to my viewpoint: the hardsell approach, the old attitude that all Americans have plenty of money. Just one minor instance: On a jaunt to Pompeii, our bus made an unannounced stop at a cameo factory's showroom. Although there was no mention of this visit in our tour booklet, there was an insistence on our buying jewelry, once inside. It was waste of precious time that could have been better spent at the excavations. Bad manners and bad tempers are not confined to either side of the Atlantic, and aggravations can arise. However, did not encounter any of the carping about ItalianAmericans that was evident in the article on the interviews in Rome. Most Italians were pleasant, courteous and quick to lavish praise on of the language, no matter how limited.

title: News Guild Loses Vote
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. June 17 (UPI)Employes of the editorial staff of The Kansas Star and Times voted last night not to join the Newspaper Guild. The vote was 80 in favor and 153 against the Guild. Four votes were challenged. A simple majority was needed.

title: 2 BRIDGE SERIES LED BY ITALIANS
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 17The final week of the World Bridge Team Olympiad began here today with Italy apparently headed for a double victory.

title: Songcan, $3, Wins In Dexter Cup Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 17Songcan, a $5,000 bargainbuy as a yearling, tonight captured the $100,000 Dexter Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, took half the purse and boosted his careerearnings to $151,221. The Florican colt, clearly the best of the six 3yearolds going postward before 29,000 fans, also made certain by winning that there would be no Big Five nor Triple Crown trotting king this season.

title: Heavy Rains Pose New Flood Threat In Rapid City, S.D.
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., June 17 (AP)A second cloudburst in eight days struck this Black Hills area today, posing the threat of another flash flood similar., to one that took at least 216 lives a week ago. Mayoronald Barnett declared martial law.

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  The longing for some sort of peace in Vietnam has grown so strong, both in and out of the Nixon Administration, that the slightest hint of progress toward the evanescent goal instantly spurs eager speculation that a settlement may yet be within reach.

title: Joan Baez:I Was in a State of Guilt
description: PUT it this wayI had a choice of whether I wanted to be a millionairess or not, and I decided against it. I live well, don't kid yourself about that: I do not live the way the farm workers live. But I think it's pointless to have stored up Xmillion amounts of dollars when they could be put to use somewhere. Joan Baez, in town for a few daysto muster support for her latest nonviolent project, was getting a bit impatient. I had been pressing her about contradictions, about how she reconciled the image of the enormously successful folk singer with that of the St. Joan of the benefits, charities and peace marches.

title: CHARLES STURZER
description: Charles Sturzer former chief auditor of the Board of Education, died yesterday in Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived at 60 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

title: A Dummy Fights Cigarettes
description: PARAMUS  Sam, a familiar sight to Bergen County youngsters, has been around since 1968 and has been seen by more than 25,000 students.

title: PELHAM REBUFFS EDUCATION BOARD
description: PELHAM, N.Y., June 17A controversial Board of Education was thrown out of power here this week when, by margins of 2 and 3 to 1, voters rejected all five candidates sup ported by the incumbent board majority and elected those backed by the Citizens Nominating Committee, a nonpartisan townwide group.

title: Call Paid on Waldheim.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 17President Echevarria arrived here from Florida today and paid a brief visit to Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: $112,000 Arlington Feature Captured by Kings Bishop
description: CHICAGO, June 17 (AP)King's Bishop scored a 1 length victory today in the $112,000 Pontiac Grand Prix at Arlington Park as heavily favored Hold Your Peace finished a disappointing fifth.

title: Feathered Find a Friend in Suffolk
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I.There was no mistaking the sounds coming from the top of the stove. The noises escaping from boxes set in pans surrounding the pilot light were faint, but distinct.

title: Celebrities Add Glamourto PrePrimary Parties
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, suited in gray and deeply tanned, stood before the fireplace in Jean Stein vanden Heuvel's drawing room, jammed a hand into a pants pocket and looked out at the welldressed bodies on the velvet sofas, the chairs and the floor.

title: HUMPHREY AIDES EXPECT NEW HELP
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's most faithful financial backers are confident they can supply $150,000 more to take the Senator's debtridden campaign through the Democratic National Convention next month,

title: Every Little Crook and Nanny
description: To the Editor. In 1964, Martin Levin reviewed my novel Buddwing.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S Music
description: Sines last October, a small group of specialistsa jazz musician, a film makerphotographer and a graphics designerhave been talking their way toward a jazz exhibit that will be held during July, August and September at MUSE. This BedfordStuyvesant neighborhood museum, which is situated at 1530 Bedford Avenue, is operated by the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

title: Law
description: A thirsty traveler who arrives in Philadelphia late at night and seeks refreshment does not find it easy to buy a drink. State and local licensing laws in Pennsylvania contain many severe restrictions on the hours during which hotels and restaurants can sell liquor. On Sunday nights after 10 P.M., there is a statewide ban except for speciallylicensed private clubs, such as Elks Clubs or Moose Lodges.

title: An Army Post That Offers More Than Military Tradition
description: CARLISLE, Pa.We are a nation of poll takers; no matter what the question, someone will eventually come along to solicit our answers, and count them. In one poll taken recently on the corner of Lexington Avenue and 53d Street in New York City, 10 pedestrians were asked if they had any idea what the United States Army War College is. A perfect poll: zero for 10.

title: Prima Sidelined by Virus
description: Louis Prima's engagement at the Rainbow Grill has been interrupted because of illnesshe has a virus. His show is being replaced from tomorrow through Saturday by Sarah Vaughan.

title: M'GOVERN VICTORY EXPECTED IN VOTE IN STATE TUESDAY
description: Senator George McGovern, whose opposition is scattered and disorganized, is favored to win at least 200 of the 248 delegates to the Democratic National Convention to be elected in the state Democratic primary Tuesday.

title: Orioles Register Ninth Consecutive Victory by Turning Back Twins, 4 to 1
description: BLOOMINGTON. Minn,, June 17 (AP)Pat Dobson pitched the Baltimore Orioles to their ninth straight victory today, beating the Minnesota Twins, 41.

title: You Americans do not understand Vietnam! they kept telling me... Journal of a correspondent in North Vietnam
description: Two 14yearold boys: I met the first in Hanoi, at the house used by the mission of the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam. (Years ago, I discovered later, the house was the American ConsulateGeneral.) There I was introduced to three heroic liberation fighters from the Southa girl 22, a boy 17, and the 14yearold.

title: Bermuda Ocean Racers Perform in an Exclusive World
description: The ocean racing fleet to Bermuda, 1,200 yachtsmen and a score of yachtswomen, is at sea today, its 178 vessels strung out for about 100 miles on or near the rhumb line. The what line? It's one of those phrases that give the ocean racer an exclusive vocabulary.

title: MATCH RACE WON BY CONVENIENCE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 17 Leonard Lavin's Convenience won the richest match race in the United States thoroughbred annals by a head today over Fletcher Jones's favored Typecast in a $250,000 Hollywood Park spectacular.

title: WHITE HOUSE WARNS OF ACTION ON PRICES
description: KEY BISCAYNE, June 17The White House warned today that the Administration might be forced to take new steps to deeal with rising food prices if they continued to move out of hand.

title: OSCAR B. SCHIER 2D, ENGINEER, 65, DIES
description: Oscar B. Schier 2d, a national leader in mechanical engineering, died Friday evening in Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Woodbury, L.I.

title: LINDSAY MEETS M'GOVERN IN CITY
description: After an hourlong private meeting in Gracie Mansion yesterday, Mayor Lindsay exchanged good wishes and sympathies with Senator George McGovern but did not endorse him for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Rumania Leads Italy, 20
description: VIENNA, June 17 (UPI)Rumania led Italy, 20, today after the opening two singles of their semifinal European Zone Davis Cup series in Bucharest.

title: Caribbean Storm Becomes First Hurricane of Year
description: MIAMI, June 17 (AP) Agnes, the first major storm of the 1972 season, swirled to hurricane strength today and forecasters posted a hurricane watch for the Florida Keys.

title: Cynthia Browne Is Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Miss Cynthia Browne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Britton Browne Jr. of Washington and Watch Hill, R. I., was married here this afternoon to George Paull Torrence Sargent 2d, son of Mrs. Randall H. Hagner Jr. of Washington and the late Christopher Smith Sargent. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square here.

title: Diane Williams Has Bridal on L. I.
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 17Miss Diane Helene Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Williams of Mill Neck and Boca Raton, Fla., was married here this afternoon to William Patrick Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Murphy of West Simsbury, Conn. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William Spilman, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Donlan.

title: A.K.C. Weighing Voice for Women
description: With so many women active in both clubwork and in showing dogs, the American Kennel Club is. moving once again to consider giving women a voice in its legislative body.

title: Myra Martin Wed in South
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. C., June 17  Miss Myra K. Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Hunter Martin Jr., and Randall Duncan MacCuaig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Laurier MacCuaig of Fairfield, Conn., were married here this afternoon at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shephard by the pastor, the Rev. Cyrus F. Frazier.

title: Lord of East Hampton Manor
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. I'm the only man alive who grows my own laurel to crown my own brow, remarked Evan Manning Frankel on a walking tour of Brigadoon, his 15acre estate here. How's that for a quote? I'm the supreme egotist!

title: Phoenix House Donation
description: The Kiwanis Club of Coney Island has donated a Ford station wagon to Phoenix House, the drug rehabilitation center staffed almost entirely by exaddicts. The wagon will he used es a transportation bus and to pick up supplies.

title: City Toughens Demands in VoluntaryHospital Pacts
description: The city is beginning to take a more aggressive bargaining position in its negotiations with the private, nonprofit voluntary hospitals that spend onequarter of the municipal health budget of almost $1billion.

title: Bremer's Brother Accused
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 17 (AP)William A. Bremer, 32 years old, of Fort Smith, brother of the alleged assailant of Gov. George C. Wallace Of Alabama, was extradited, to Florida yesterday: to face charges of stopping payment of a check with, intent to defraud. Mr. Bremer is the brother of Arthur H. Bremer of Milwaukee, who is charged with shooting Mr. Wallace in Maryland May 15.

title: The Nation
description: The rain came in torrents in the Black Hills of South Dakota. Rapid Creek could not contain the water; it poured over the banks and raged down stream in a flash flood, sweeping away everything in its path. The flood crashed through Rapid City in a fourblockwide swathe and burst a darn in a city park. Caught in the path of the raging flood were homes and people.

title: Dean Gets Newark Post
description: UNION, N. J., June 17 (AP)David Dean, basketball coach at Long Branch High School, was appointed assistant athletic director and soccer coach at Newark State College today.

title: Poznan Fair: For Trade or Show?; Poland Aims At More Emphasis On Business
description: POZNAN, PolandFor several years the managers of the Poznan Trade Fair and officials of the American pavilion, one of the largest at the show, have been faced with a single dilemma: Should the emphasis be on trade or fair?

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The TaftHartley Act, passed over President Truman's veto 25 years ago, cannot be evaluated in isolation, for it was a revision of the Wagner Act (1935), designed to alter both the broad policies and the detailed rules established by that statute, and it must be judged in that context.

title: Riding in Southern Comfort
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Southern Railway Company faced a decision 14 months ago on whether to get out of the passengerhauling business  the dream of most American railroaders for at least a decade  its president, W. Graham Claytor Jr., surprised some observers. He decided to keep on hauling people.

title: Religion
description: Reform Jews are concerned about unityboth with the Conservative branch of Judaism and among themselves. This was evident last week in two studies made public at the annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis (Reform) held in Grossinger, N.Y.

title: Bigger Machines for Bigger Farms
description: CHICAGOA farm tractor with an isolated cab that is air conditioned and heated, an enormously complicated machine that has, among its other gagdets, power steering, four wheel drive, an adjustable seat, a padded instrument panel as well as a tinted windshield, a stereo tape deck, an AMFM radio and can pull a disc plow and planter over 12 rows at the same time?

title: AIRLINES APPEAL JUDGE'S REFUSAL 10 BAR WALKOUT
description: Preparations for a 24hour international strike by airline pilots tomorrow, to demand sterner treatment of hijackers moved ahead yesterday after 2S United States scheduled airlines failed to win an immediate court order banning participation by American pilots.

title: Music
description: IF SOME philanthropist ever decides to establish a Hall of Fame for American composers, there should be one niche reserved for Silas Gamaliel Pratt. Although his career chiefly produced such ephemera as the opera Zenobia and tone poems bearing names like Paul Revere's Ride, Pratt's fame rests on something more secure: his pathbreaking in the field of selfpromotion. By all contemporary accounts, Pratt's selfesteem was monumental and sincere, and he is best known, perhaps, for the tribute he is said to have paid a fellow composer during a visit to Bayreuth: Herr Wagner, he proclaimed, you are the Silas G. Pratt of Europe.

title: Bus Line Seeking New Service Cuts
description: NEWARK  Thousands of daily bus riders in the state will be forced to find alternate means of travel in the next few months if Transport of New Jersey, which has 120 routes in 405 municipalities. succeeds in a bid to end some runs or reduce service.

title: Burns Wins Twice, Gains Final in L. I. Amateur Golf
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., June 17 George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills eliminated Bob Murphy of Garden City Country Club, 2 and 1, in the quarterfinals and John Humm of Rockville, 2 and I. today to reach the final of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the St. George Golf and Country Club.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, June 17  The Greek Government showed willingness today to end its fourmonthold feud with the President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, and to work with him to solve the island republic's complex problems.

title: Still the Greatest Dictator
description: H AD I known of the actual horrors of the German concentration camps, Charlie Chaplin writes in his autobiography, I could not have made The Great Dictator.

title: Brooklyn Melting Pot for American Indian, Too
description: Sixtyfifth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in Brookyn, is a wide, commercial street at the crossroads of the Staten Island and Gowanus Expressways. Lined with warehouses, service stations and small industrial plants, it is busy in the daytime, bleak at night.

title: AIRFIELDS ARE NIT AS HEAVY STRIKES CONTINUE IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Sunday, June 19American planes continued heavy bombing of North Vietnam yesterday, and the United States command announced that it had begun deactivating the last major American combat unit in South Vietnam.

title: MAJOR HANOI AIDE ARRIVES IN PEKING
description: TOKYO, June 17 (AP)Le Duc Tho, the chief adviser for North Vietnam's delegation to the Paris peace talks, arrived in Peking today on his way to Hanoi, Hsinhua, the Chinese news agency, reported.

title: Recordings
description: THE common livingroom phonograph  what a fantastic timemachine it is. Despite all flaws and dangers, including its power to tempt us into passivity or even stoned inertness, the record player is Everyman's electronically powered Celestial Omnibus. It can bring us closer to genuine timetraveling mobility than any other legally obtainable mind expander. Used properly, as a device to stimulate active understanding of music rather than as a tranquilizer, the turntable is in every sense revolutionary.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: TULSA, Okla., June 17 (UPI)Joe Gibson really got a good deal on a used car.

title: Kirby of Padres. Subdues Pirates, 40, With Colbert Driving In All the Runs
description: PITTSBURGH, June 17 (AP) Nate Colbert drove in four rill's with a homer, double and sacrifice fly, and Clay Kirby hurled a ninehitter tonight, giving the San Diego Padres 40 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Russian Research Center Renamed for a Bulgarian
description: MOSCOW, June 17The Soviet Union has renamed one of its nuclearresearch center for Georgi Dimitrov, a Bulgarian Communist revolutionary.

title: Art
description: THE news from Venice is that, contrary to all rumor and expectation, the Biennale is still alive and functioning. After the protests and demonstrations and boycotts of recent years, there certainly was reason to wonder if this venerable international showcase of contemporary art would survive. For the moment, at least, it has.

title: Five Novels
description: Zane Kotker's name might throw the reader but her first novel, Bodies in Motion, leaves no doubt that she is a woman. It is a persuasive portrait of a talented, independent young photographer who becomes wife and a mother at the cost of her independence and places her talent in jeopardy. Blame traditions, or the talented and ambitious young husband who believes in them, or time, or biology.

title: Top Golf Pros to Play At Wykagyl Tomorrow
description: Some of the New York area's best professional golfers will gather at Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle tomorrow to participate in the fourth annual Tanqueray tournament for club managers, professionals and metropolitan golf writers.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When you get a character in a mystery novel who says such things as here's villainy afoot, or who describes a situation as a nefarious enterprise, or who mutters there's devilment in it, the reader can legitimately wonder in which century the book was written. The main character in Ben Healey's THE VESPUCCI PAPERS (Lippincott, $4.95) talks like that, and his book was published only last month.

title: Cordero Rides Copter From Belmont to Take $41,700 Handicap at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 17 Angel Cordero Jr. risked the cost of a hedicopter ride from Belmont Park to Monmouth Park and returned with the investment paid off when his mount won the $41,700 Longfellow Handicap at the New Jersey track with Darby Dan's Good Counsel.

title: ROSS PACES ADVANCE IN JERSEY SINGLES
description: KEARNY, N. J., June 17Top seeded Steve Ross of Brooklyn led the field into the semifinals tonight in the New Jersey State men's singles championship at the Arlington Players Club.

title: Russians Score Sweep In Kent Grass Tennis
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 17 (AP)  Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union beat Jill Cooper of Britain, 64, 61, to win the women's title in the Kent grass tennis tournament today.

title: The Hotels of Africa Rate High Despite Some Idiosyncrasies
description: ONE can learn little about any continent from the inside of a hotel, except, of course, for the sort of person whose alleged firsthand impressions are In fact the warmedover fantasies of room waiters and bartenders. But at the same time, the traveler has to sleep somewhere, and at the end of any journey, like one made to 14 black countries accompanied by my wife and two sons, then aged 7 and 9, the places he stays are prominent in his recollections, even when he doesn't stay In the grandest hotel in town.

title: Rustic Museum Reflects Nature
description: BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N.YWe're metamorphosing, but we're not sure what the butterfly will look like, George Bowditch, acting director of the Adirondack Museum here, said the other day as he sat in his comfortable office.

title: Doyle in Senior Final
description: Al Doyle, the secondseeded player, defeated Tony Franco. 61, 61, and reached the final of the Eastern senior tennis championship yesterday at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx. Paul Lynner beat Stan Weil, 57, 61, 62, in a quarterfinal match.

title: Giants Pick Sept. 4toOct. 4 As Upsala Training Period
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J.The New York Giants will be working out at Upsala College from Sept. 4 to Oct. 4. The Giants and the college arrived at final agreement for the use of Upsala's facilities over last weekend.

title: Irvine Named President Of ChrisCraft Division
description: ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., has announced ne appointment of George Marshall Irvine Jr. to succeed Clifford M. Fellows as president of its boat division.

title: Burlington Gains in Growth By Exodus From Philadelphia
description: The white exodus from Philadelphia and into suburban areas near and far during the 1960's had a major effect on the growth spurt in New Jersey's nearby Burlington County.

title: RED SOX WIN, 108 AFTER A 54 LOSS
description: BOSTON, June 17 (AP) Duane Josephson tripled home tying run in the eighth inning and then scored on Phil Gagliano's bloop single as the Boston Red Sox rallied for three runs tonight and beat the, Chicago White Sox, 108, for split of a daynight double header.

title: Russians Hail Pacts
description: YAROSLAVL, U.S.S.R., June 15I saw your President on TV, a burly collective farmer said as he stood waistdeep in a murky, motionless pond beside his modest peasant home. He looks like a Russian. It is good that he came.

title: Fiddler, 3,225 Performances Old, Tops LongRun List
description: Fiddler on the Roof danced and sang its way into theatrical history in the Broadway Theater last night, playing for the 3,225th time here, making it Broadway's longestrunning show.

title: NITRATES PERILING WATER OF GALILEE
description: TEL, AVIV, June 17Israeli scientists say they have found a way of undoing ecological damage to the Sea of Galilee caused by the drainage of the Hula Lake and swamp some 15 years ago.

title: Dave Anderson
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 17Behind him, the tide slid up the sand with the gentle speed of a 20foot putt. Sea gulls floated in the wind. Arnold Palmer was marching toward the 18th green of the Pebble Beach Golf Links today after having lofted a nineiron shot to within 10 feet of the cup.

title: Political Differences Split Quebec Labor
description: MONTREAL, June 17Quebec's labor movement, which has become more politically militant in recent years, was sharply split this week in a dispute that goes to the very heart of trade union philosophy.

title: Great Swamp Has Too Many Deer
description: BASKING RIDGE  Something new is being added to the Bambilike fawns of whitetailed deer hereear tags.

title: Hospital in Brooklyn Adding 7Story Wing
description: Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn has begun its $26million expansion program by breaking ground for a sevenstory wing. This marks the first phase of the multimilliondollar modernization project, which will create an expanded medical center designed to serve the communities of Ridgewood, Middle Village, Maspeth and Glendale.

title: School Budgets Still Unsettled in Score of Districts
description: TRENTONWith the new fiscal year about to dawn on them, more than 20 of the state's 602 boards of education still have no firm budget on which to run their public schools starting September.

title: Collegians Help Disturbed
description: This is Nathaniel. He's 10 years old and learning how to look after himself.

title: BQLI Family/Style
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L. I. There were bookends and mirrors, there were paintings, sculptures and mobiles, there were elegant gowns and mink boas, there were coffee tables, candlesticks and artificial floral pieces, and there were lamps, umbrella stands, clocks and magazine racks. There were more such dustcatchers than you might be able to count In three hours, but Julius Patiky couldand did.

title: VICTORIA SONG TAKES QUEEN'S PLATE RACE
description: TORONTO, June 17 (Canadian Press)Victoria Song, owned by Mrs. William Seitz of Toronto, scored a twolength victory today over J. Louis Levesque's Barachois to take the $56,143 first prize in the 113th running of the Queen's Plate at Woodbine Race Track.

title: Born Free in Cheshire
description: Cheshire doesn't look like a town of 20,000, maybe because it hasn't been one for very long. As recently as 1954 the community was too small to need a high school of its own; now there are 1,600 students in grades 9 to 12 alone. Cheshire still has a smalltown looklots of trees, cows by the side of the road and a view of mountains. That must be what appealed to the young executives who began flocking here 15 years ago, from Ohio and New York and California and a lot of other places, to build splitlevels and settle down. They've been coming, and going, ever since.

title: Kissinger Rests in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, June 17 (UPI)Henry A. Kissinger rested at an oceanside hotel today and conferred with his aides. He will leave tomorrow for China.

title: 5 New Plays at Yale to Join 3 Older Ones at Repertory
description: Eight plays have been selected for the seventh season of the Yale University Repertory Theater, it was announced by Robert Brustein, artistic director.

title: FULMER VICTOR AT WATKINS GLEN
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 17Calmly making up for the time lost in replacing a damaged tire, George Follmer, the runaway leader of the current TransAmerican championship, won for the third time today in the four races run this season.

title: Cornelia Ray Wed to James Thompson
description: Miss Cornelia Claiborne Ray and James Robert Thompson, both of Brooklyn, were married here yesterday morning. The double ring ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Morris in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: If she were a patient person, Juliette May Moran might today be with the Atomic Energy Commission, but since she is not she has to be content with being a senior vice president of the GAF Corporation.

title: The World
description: LONDON  Three masked Protestants drove to Stormont Castle in East Belfast last Tuesday and, once inside, took off their disguises to spend 90 minutes with William Whitelaw, Britain's administrator for Northern Ireland.

title: Spassky's Training Is a Secret As He Prepares to Play Fischer
description: MOSCOW, June 17Boris Spassky, the world chess champion, declined to reveal yesterday how he was training for his match against Bobby Fischer of the United States, which begins July 2 in England.

title: Unpredictable Court
description: It is already clear that the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Burger has an orientation quite different from the Court under Chief Justice Warren. But the Court retains a rugged quality of unpredictability that defies efforts to put it In any rigid ideological mold. This quality has just been reflected in the Court's ruling that no person may be jailed for a petty offense without the right to free counsel.

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON  Dear Senator Hughes, the letter began, I and other members of wing intelligence... have been falsifying classified reports for missions into North Vietnam. That is, we have been reporting that our planes have received hostile reactions such as AA [antiaircraft fire] and SAM [missile] firings whether they have or not.

title: Ryun Sets His Sights on an Olympic Track Double at 800 and 1,500 Meters
description: SEATTLE, June 17For the second time in his storied track and field career, Jim Ryun will attempt to qualify for the Olympics in two eventsthe 800 and 1,500meter runs.

title: Dance
description: THEY say the first seven years are the worst, and Flemming Flindt at the ripe old age of 36 is just completing his seventh season as head of the Royal Danish Ballet. He accepted the jeb with considerable reluctance, but he has proved startlingly successful. It seems that whomever you talk to In Copenhagenwriters, people in the theater or in films, even scientists and other civiliansthere is little but praise for the Danish ballet. Flindt has made it virtually the most popular of the Danish performing arts, as well as internationally the best known.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Whistles
description: CROYDON, N.H.  More than a month ago, when asked if I knew how to fashion a willow whistle, I replied that I was a skilled whistlemaker, as was every former country boy of my vintage.

title: Meg E. Lloyd to Marry on July 29
description: DOTHAN, Ala., June 17Miss Meg Ellen Lloyd and Edward Hoyt Dominick plan to be married in the Episcopal Church of the Nativity here on July 29.

title: For Queens Housing, Roaring Sixties Were a Time to Recall
description: During the favorable construction climate of the nineteensixties. new housing units popped up like dandelions along the main thoroughfares of northwest Queens. This was especially true along the Long Island Expressway, Queens Boulevard and sections of Metropolitan Avenue and Northern Boulevard.

title: ROBERTS VAULTS 18 AT SEATTLE Howe Captures 1.500 Run in 3:38.2 and Evans Wins 400 in National A.A.U. Finals
description: SEATTLE, June 17  Dave Roberts cleared 18 feet in the pole vault, Jerome Howe became the fourth fastest American in the 1,500 and Lee Evans showed his old form in the 400meter dash today on the final day of the 84th annual National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor track and field championships.

title: Education
description: Much like a family that has become used to a period of prosperity and, with harder times upon it, persists in a style it can no longer afford, the nation's colleges and universities were told last week that they must slash their spending. What gave the warning special force is that it came not from caviling critics but from a good friend, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education.

title: Dorothy Clift Is Bride of Vaughn P. Keith
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Miss Dorothy Ann Clift, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Clift of Washington, was married here this afternoon to Vaughn Phillips Montaigne Keith, son of Col. Quentin Keith of the Army Reserve and Mrs. Keith of Red Bank, N. J.

title: A Southern Textile RecoveryImport Curbs Helped
description: INMAN, S. C.The fine mist floating off the poplar trees and remnants of the flowering dogwood may contribute to the contentment that pervades this small textile community. But primarily it is the full working schedules in the mills and almost full employment that have created a feeling of wellbeing.

title: Five Novels
description: The first section of Conventional Wisdom is entitled Memories of a Marriage. It begins immediately after the wedding, with the couple returning home to make love. The language is imageladen, save for dialogue, and as usual human anatomy does not yield new comparisons. Breasts once again are pale white rising like mountains, soft as fresh bread, or like bunches of sweet grapes. (One longs for nonsense: breasts like beanstalks, like the Grand Canyon.) In brief scenes Will and Sarah, the couple, suffer the gradual disenchantments and dull spots. He is unwilling to have a child because he is uncertain about himself. They lave one another lovingly, swim and make more love, but the adumbrations are bad. Finally, she comes to wash his dishes. He asks about the kids. The kids are fine. Joseph's fine. Joseph is probably the

title: The World
description: COLOMBOThe lush Indian Ocean island of Ceylon, or Sri Lanka as is now offfeially known, a little more than a year ago was rent by an insurrection that left thousands dead and threatened to overthrow the Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike.

title: Dilemma in the new 20th Congressional District
Famed Jumping Rider Pilots Last Race Today
description: PARIS, June 17One of the finest jockeys in steeplechase and hurdle racing, Stan Mellor of England, will make his farewell ride in the E95,000 Grand Steeplechase de Paris at Auteuil tomorrow.

title: Mailbox:
description: Are not the reasoning powers of mankind a sight to behold? He can forgive an entire nation for slaughtering 6 million defenseless Jews and conduct an Olympic Games in that nation.
