Yet he cannot forgive a single man (Bobby Lee Hunter) for destroying a single man in a personal combat or a petty forger (Gene White) his forgery regardless of his serving out his term.

title: Insurgents Pressing Drives for Democratic Leadership
description: TRENTONPolitical shockwaves generated by this month's party primary elections continued to keep the Democratic party in ferment last week, as the victorious McGovern reform forces in the state began flexing their brandnew political muscle, and as both parties held their postelection selections of county leaders.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: As William S. Odlin Jr. appropriately points out in Use Highway Fund Money for Highways (June 11), the cost of moving goods in this nation is paid, in the end, by the consumer.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: One level of the retail business that the public rarely sees has been there for decades, closely reflecting all the ripples that have altered the fortunes of thousands of retail stores over the years.

title: Granberg's Zip II Wins In Star Class Sailing
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., June 17John Granberg's Zip II snapped Alan and Bill Burtis's Guacharo streak at four straight today to capture Star Class honors in the Hempstead Harbor sailing conducted by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club.

title: College TV Course No Snap
description: In the control room of Television Studio B, a technician starts the countdown: 10, 9 ('Ready to fade in camera 7, calls the director)... 3 ('Fade in music, 2, 1 ('Air).

title: State Teachers Approve Merger With Group in City
description: SYRACUSE, June 17 (AP)The House of Delegates of the New York State Teachers Association today overwhelmingly approved a merger with the United Teachers of New York,

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ALBANY, June 17  A highly unusual consultant's report advising against the construction of a major north south expressway in central New York State has been made public by the State Department of Transportation.

title: Chess: Entertainment, Not Age, Called Tourney Criterion
Swords to Ploughshares
description: The Senate hammered some swords into ploughshares the other day when it voted to ban military aid to Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and other South Asian nations, at the same time restoring the full $100 million requested by the Administration for economic aid to Bangladesh.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17Once upon a time in the early days of filmmaking, the villains tied silent movie star Pearl White to a railroad trestle in the path of an onrushing steam locomotive.

title: Environment
description: STOCKHOLMThe charges, countercharges and debates were familiar to those who frequent such meetings, but there is new hope that the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment may mark a historic turning point.

title: Child to Wassermans
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Wasserman of 230 East 71st Street on May 25 in Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Wasserman is the former Miss Susan Harris of Brooklyn. The child has been named Sheryl Elisabeth. Mr. Wasserman is a manager with the Commercial Information Corporation.

title: Casper, Insulted, Says He'll Skip Westchester
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 17  Billy Casper said today he would not compete in the $250,000 Westchester Classic at Harrison, N. Y., because of insults. The former United States Open titleholder said, In past years, my wife, my family and I have been insulted by those associated with the Westchester Country Club, not necessarily by those officials conducting the tourney. He declined to elaborate.

title: She Had the Idea For Father's Day
description: SPOKANE. Wash.I liked everything you said about motherhood, Mrs. John Bruce Dodd told the minister after a Mother's Day church service, but don't you think fathers deserve a place in the sun, too?

title: Podgorny Still in Hanoi
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 17 (AP)  President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union has prolonged by a day his visit to North Vietnam.

title: Sense of Accomplishment Buoys Delegates Leaving Ecology Talks
description: STOCKHOLM, June 17This was the first day of what representatives of many countries see as a new era of international collaboration to improve the globe's deteriorating quality of life.

title: Environment
description: For 50 years the osprey or sea eagle seemed extinct in Britain but under the most elaborate protective measures it now is slowly reestablishing itself in Scotland. Some years ago, a single pair reappeared; by last week eight pairs were nesting.

title: Art
description: DEAR Mr. Apateonas: Somehow I just can't rest easy until I'm sure you know that I know that the little gold Eros pendant I bought in your shop a few weeks ago is not a work of the 4th century B.C. as you claimed, but circa 1972 A.D. When my wife and I came into the shop and asked if you had any antique jewelry, we had in mind the kind of 19thcentury thing that is easy to find in Greece and, of course, can be sold and exported legally without permits. Which reminds me that I must explain why I'm addressing you as Mr. Apateonas rather than by your real name.

title: Eleanor Trevor Married to Broker
description: Miss Eleanor Fisher Trevor was married here yesterday afternoon to Charles Steele von Stade Jr. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Dr. Burton J. Thomas. A reception was held at the Colony Club, where the bride made her debut in 1966.

title: A SelfAnalysis: Hotelmen Set Out to Solve Their Problems
description: EVERY night of the year hundreds of thousands of people stay at hotels and motels all over the United States with pleasure and without complaint  either because they have no complaints or simply don't voice them. But the industry's leaders are hardly sanguine; not only do they concede their problems but they have undertaken a serious selfexamination to solve them.

title: Sex in back seats and front parlors
description: Probably yob will judge Dan Greenburg's chronicle of his youthful sexual misadventures according to whoor whatyou are.

title: Carol J. Levinson Is Wed to Mark Baskir
description: Miss Carol Jane Levinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Levinson of Woodbury, L. I., was married here last night to Mark A. Baskir, son of Philip Baskir of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Baskir. Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin performed the ceremony at the Americana.

title: ALLENDE REVISES CHILEAN CABINET He Replaces Six Ministers, Including Economic Chief as Inflation Stirs Crisis
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 17President Salvador Allende Gossens today dropped six Cabinet members, including the Minister of Economy, Pedro Vuskovic, in a shakeup intended to respond to growing political opposition and an economic crisis.

title: Man of Letters
description: For more than fifty years, Edmund Wilson was vigorous presence in this nation's intellectual life, bringing to bear on books and public affairs a penetrating intelligence, a keen curiosity, a humane concern. At his death he was America's foremost man of letters.

title: Nudity Curb Voted
description: SACREMENTO, Calif., June 17 (AP)A measure bannnig most nudity and fourletter words in material sold to minors has been approved by the State Senate, 22 to 19. Senator John Harmer said during floor debate Tuesday that his bill would forbid direct sale of Playboy magazine to youths under 18.

title: WENDELL KILMER
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 17Wendell Kilmer, a photographer for Hofstra University and an amateur meteorologist, died Thursday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola. He was 67 years old and lived at 199 Atlantic Avenue.

title: We are what we drive
description: At the risk of sentimental commonplace and pedestrian naturalism Theodore Weesner in his first novel The Car Thief has written a story so modestly precise and so movingly inevitable that before I knew what was happening to me I felt in the grip of some kind of thriller. But it's not quite the thriller you might think from the title.

title: JURY IS DEADLOCKED IN SUFFOLK SLAYING
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 17A Suffolk County Court jury was dismissed this afternoon when it was hopelessly deadlocked in the fiveweekold murder and conspiracy trial of John O. Hughes, a suspended Smithtown lawyer.

title: Eight Stories; Small Wolf By Nathaniel Benchley. Illustrated by Joan Sandin. 63 pp. Harper & Row. $2.50. (Ages 6 to 8)
description: What happens to an Indian boy on Manhattan Island after the Dutch arrive. The details of Indian daily life are interesting and informative but the story line bogs down in homily as Small Wolf encounters the white devils and is forced to move from land that was rightfully his. This I Can Read book shoulders heavy burden of social consciousness to the point of virtually becoming an antiwhite tract. There was a time when antiIndian sentiments dominated American children's literature. That sin is overcorrected here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The black panelists at the Chicago conference pronounced it an obligation for the black artist to use his art as a mass revolutionary tool (news story May 29). What they say coincides with the mandates of Hitler and Mussolini and with what the Russians still are saying; the art of those countries was bastardized under the yoke of officialdom.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Sam Huff is returning to the Giant scene after too long an absence. But he comes back only as a disembodied voice, the new resident expert of the radio broadcasting team. He won't help the football forces a doggone bit and that's a pity. What the Giants need so desperately these days are players with the extraordinary, skills of their former middle linebacker. Not only did he make The Violent World of Sam Huff a superior television documentary, but he also reflected the tone, tempo and charac ter of an organization that once was generally regarded as the best in professional football.

title: West Point Baseball Team Picks Newsom as Captain
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June 17 Five team captains have been selected for the 1973 spring season at the United States Military Academy.

title: U.S. Beats Mexico in Doubles to Clinch Davis Cup Series
description: MEXICO CITY, June 17 (AP) The United States team of Stan Smith and Eric Van Dillen won a marathon first set today and went on to beat Mexico's Joaquin Loyo Mayo and Vincente Zarazua, 2119, 63, 64, and clinch the Davis Cup North American Zone championship series.

title: Linda Rockey Married
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 17Miss Linda Rockey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rockey, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Henry A. Maccaro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Maccaro of Merrick, L. I. The Rev. Michael Servinsky performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church. Dr. Maccaro graduated last month from the Temple University School of Dentistry, where his bride was also a student. His father is a former president of the Nassau Lawyers Association.

title: Old Swamp In Flushing Has a Touch Of Coney
description: If you're looking for adventure with a capital A and can afford it, you'll find it midway between Shea Stadium and the BronxWhitestone Bridge in some reclaimed swamp in historic Flushing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: As Defeat Indians, 32
description: OAKLAND, June 17 (AP)Dave Hamilton, a rookie lefthander, won his fourth consecutive game today, combining with Darold Knowles to pitch the Oakland A's to a 32 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: OLMEDO IS BEATEN BY HEWITT IN FINAL
description: BRISTOL, England, June 17 (AP)  Bob Hewitt won the men's final in the West of England grass tennis championships today, hobbling to victory over Alex Olmedo, who was also handicapped by an injury.

title: Strange Peaches By Edwin Shrake. 375 pp. New York: Harper's Magazine Press. $7.95.
description: Jack Ruby has a speaking part in Strange Peaches. President Kennedy's assassination is filmed by John Lee Wallace, narrator and principal figure. Some Texans of our time are suggested by characters: Billy Bob Teagarden, influence peddler in trouble; Big Earl, the senile billionaire who composes amazing hymns and ballads; Little Earl, his son, who owns a professional football team.

title: BALLOT DECISION TO BE APPEALED
description: With primary elections scheduled for Tuesday, the city's Board of Elections is going to the Appellate Division tomorrow to appeal from a State Supreme Court ruling that some of its lists of candidates violate Chapter 146 of the state's Election Law, passed last March.

title: Larchmont Sail Becalmed
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 17 The Larchmont Yacht Club's annual spring regatta, which also was the 10th event of the Yacht Racing Association championship season on Long Island Sound, was canceled today. A lack of wind, with nearly 100 yachts waiting, was the reason.

title: And a red telephone
description: Picture a studiopeeling paint, cracking plaster, stained plumbing, a rancid stove. What did the new tenant, a bachelor businessman in his late 30's want from this chaos? Digs fit for James Bond, complete with a red telephone that would be sleekly elegant and yet easy to care for. Designer John Saladino stripped through the wreckage and totally redesigned the 14by23foot room. He raised the floor level one step from the entrance hall to the main living area and recessed stainless steel panels within the wall planes for reflected drama. Furnishings were reduced to essentials, the bedcumsofa rests in platformed niche, facing a cabinet with concealed TV. Placing the bed on the diagonal reduced its visual bulk and changed the orientation of the long narrow room to a more interesting shape with the feeling of alcoves beyond. Other touches of pure Bond are the central control for lights, stereo and air conditioning flicked on by a floor switch at the door and, of course, that bright red phone.

title: Valerie J. Nickerson, James Grosfeld Wed
description: Miss Valerie Jane Nickerson, a London fashion model, was married here last evening to James J. Grosfeld of New York, copartner in Amherst Associates and Amherst Europe, both hedge funds. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the Harmonic Club.

title: Miss Taylor Is. Wed
description: LEWISBORO, N. Y., June 17Miss Katherine Duncan Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dale E. Taylor of Darien, Conn., was married here this noon to Stephen Hueffner Daley, son of Mrs. Debbie Daley and Eugene G. Daley, both of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Hotel Managers Also Have Problems: Men, Women, Dogs
description: AYOUNG woman registered at Bermuda's luxurious Elbow Beach Hotel. She was shown to her room overlooking the ocean. Exhausted from the plane trip, she undressed, lay down on the bed and fell asleep.

title: Patricia L. Cox Bride of Officer
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 17  Miss Patricia L. Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Cox, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Harry R. Polychron Jr., U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Polychron. The ceremony was performed in Grace Methodist Church by the. Rev. Arnold Miller.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Amtrak will soon get another infusion of Federal support, but as yet it is unclear whether it will be $170million, $325million or an amount in between.

title: The Nation
description: The New York Presidential primary on Tuesday is supposed to be a cakewalk for Senator George McGovern. Even the South Dakotan stepped out of his normally subdued character in Buffalo last week to predict that he will pick up at least 200 of the state's 278 delegates. Anything less than that would be a setback of sorts, the Senafor said.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The venerable jeep, which came home from war 27 years ago to become part of the postwar dream for thousands of Americans, will not be part of the postwar scene when the troops come back from Vietnam.

title: U.S. Wrestlers Are Banking on Luck
description: The United States will send its strongest freestyle wrestling team ever to the Summer Olympic Games, but whether it will win any gold medals depends more on luck than athletic prowess.

title: 76 Firemen Report in Sick Over a Period of 24 Hours
description: The number of firemen calling in sick or injured after fires declined again over the weekend.

title: Miss Gonnerman Wins
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 18Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., the defending champion who headed the draw, retained the Eastern women's claycourt championship today by defeating Sheila McInerney, an unseeded 14yearold from Rome, N.Y., 62, 62. in the final at the Orienta Beach Club.

title: 9TH FIREMAN'S BODY IS FOUND IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, June 18 (UPI)The body of the last of nine firemen killed yesterday when a flaming hotel collapsed on them was recovered today. Mayor Kevin H. White proclaimed a day of mourning for the worst firefighting disaster in Boston's history.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: No Breakthrough Foreseen
description: PEKING, June 18An atmosphere of expectancy prevailed in diplomatic circles in Peking today on the eve of Mr. Kissinger's arrival, but diplomats generally played down the idea of any dramatic breakthrough on Vietnam and other difficult issues.

title: Heart Suit Begins Today
description: HOUSTON, June 18 (UPI)A $4.5million suit filed by the widow of Haskell Karp against Dr. Denton A. Cooley and another doctor for alleged gross negligence in the world's first artificial heart transplant goes to court tomorrow. Mr. Karp, 47 year old, of Skokie, Ill., received the artificial heart April 4, 1969, and used it 65 hours before it was replaced with a human heart. He died four days later.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYORS UNIT DROPS BUSING RESOLUTION
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 18 (AP)  A committee of the United States Conference of Mayors, in a surprise move today, voted to sidestep discussion of busing to promote racial integration of the schools.

title: ISRAEL BARS ENTRY OF TOKYO LAWYER
description: TEL AVIV, June 18A Tokyo lawyer who flew here to defend Kozo Okamoto, the only survivor of the three gunmen who killed 24 people in the Tel Aviv airport on May 30, was refused entry tonight.

title: 2 OTHERS ELUDED QUEENS PROWLER
description: The police disclosed yesterday that an assailant had tried to kill two other young women last week in the Jamaica, Queens, neighborhood where 15yearold girl was stabbed to death early Saturday.

title: Kissinger Leaves Honolulu
description: HONOLULU, June 18 (UPI)Mr. Kissinger left here today for Peking after a threeday stopover in which he conferrea with Adm. John S. McCain Jr., commander in chief of United States forces in the Pacific.

title: Hospital Aides Who May Strike See Their Duties as Essential
description: Walter Smith, one of the 20,000 hospital workers who took part in a demonstraiion near City Hall last week, believes that the kind of work he does as a medical attendant is the backbone of a hospital.

title: KING COLE'S BROTHER DISPLAYS OWN STYLE
description: When a singer and pianist happens to be the younger brother of Nat (King) Cole, it is inevitable that he'll be expected to sound like him. Freddie Cole, the youngestafter Eddie, Ike and Natof four pianoplaying Coles boys (the final s in the family name was dropped by Nat to enable him to be known as King Cole)is walking an interesting musical tightrope between following and not following the style of his older brother during his performances at Joe's Pier 52, on West 52nd Street, just east of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Miss Black Colorado Picked
description: DENVER, June 18 (AP) Celine Edwards, a 23yearold stewardess for Continental Airlines, was selected last night as Miss Black Colorado for 1972.

title: Gilbert Cards Four 77's
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June 18 (UPI)  Gibby Gilbert finished today as the most. consistent golfer in the Open., His scores were 77, 77, 77, 77 for a 308. Only two others in the event's history, Frank Stranahan with 75's in 1953, and George Smith with 77's in 1929, ever carded four identical rounds.

title: LOSS OF POOL STIRS FIGHT IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 18 Angry Stamford legislators, residents and high school students gathered today at Sterling Farms, a municipal golf course on the city's north side, where a community swimming pool has been quietly filled in with dirt to make more room for golf carts.

title: City Ballet Triumphs in Stravinsky Fete
Echeverria Urges Chicanos Not to Yield Mexican Identity
description: CHICAGO, June 18 (Reuters)  President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico today urged MexicanAmericans not to change their nationality and to return to their homeland if theY felt it possible.

title: Gas Used in Prison Strife
description: HOUSTON, June 18 (AP) Prisoners at the Harris County Rehabilitation Center were subdued by nausea gas early today in the second straight night of disorders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: STOCKHOLMA Chinese official was talking with a Japanese ecologist. In Peking, he said, there are 1.5million bicycles. From your experience in Tokyo, do you think it would be advantageous to change to motor transport?

title: Podgorny's Forecast on Talks Arouses U.S. Interest
description: WASHINGTON, June 18United States officials expressed considerable interest today in the Soviet President's forecast of an early resumption of the Paris talks on Vietnam,, but advised against any undue optimism in the absence of firm signs that Hanoi had changed its negotiating stance.

title: CHURCH UNION PLAN CRITICIZED BY BOARD
description: ST. LOUIS, June 18 The general board of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) reaffirmed last week the denomi nation's commitment to the Consultation on Church Union, the 10yearold forum seeking merger of nine American Protestant denominations.

title: Gas Explodes on Ohio Farm
description: CHARDON, Ohio, June 18 (UPI)A pocket of shale gas, sparked by hot drilling equipment 526 feet below ground, exploded and shot flames 200 feet into the air today on farm in nearby Montville township. There were no injuries reported, but firemen said that unless explosives were used to stifle the flames, the gas would burn for at least two days.

title: Ellen Lee Erpf Bride of Jeffrey A. Miller
description: Miss Ellen Lee Erpf, a senior at Trinity College in Hartford, was married here yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Allan Miller, who was graduated from Trinity this year and elected to Phi Beta Kappa there. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Carlton House.

title: Rich Flying Scot Winner
description: ISLAND PARK, LI., June 18 Robert Rich won the Greater New York District Flying Scot Class yachting championship today at Hempstead Harbor Yacht Club. Rich triumphed with 8 points in the threeday, fiverace regatta. Rich had two firstplace finishes, including a victory today in the wind up race.

title: 4 Pakistani Prisoners Slain
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, June 18 (Reuters)Four prisoners were killed and 12 were wounded when police opened fire during a riot at Rajanpur Jail, southwest of here last night, an official statement said today. According to reports, the trouble started when prisoners protested about the food.

title: A Day for McGovern: Harlem and Brooklyn
description: Senator George McGovern, nearing the end of his primary campaign, spent yesterday on the classical New York City political pilgrimagegoing from a Harlem church to meetings with Hassidic rabbis in Brooklyn.

title: A TENTATIVE PACT ON LATIN OIL SET
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The United States and Venezuela are entering the homestretch on delicate, hitherto unreported negotiations that involve tariffs on virtually all United States imports of oil.

title: Miss Niederhoffer Wed
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 18Miss Diane Fern Niederhoffer, an administrative assistant at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University of New York, and Francis Charles Klein, educational director of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center there, were married here today at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Niederhoffer. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. David Jonas and Frank Klein, both of New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom of Temple Emanuel here performed the ceremony.

title: Greenwich Group Opposes Offices on Hotel Site
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 18Local businessmen have formed a foundation, drawn up an advertising campaign, hired a lawyer and are seeking help from more than 60 civic groups to block construction of office buildings on the site of the demolished Pickwick Arms Hotel.

title: Study Finds TV Campaign Fails To Increase Use of Seat Belts
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 Motorists who do not use their seat belts are unlikely to heed television commercials urging them to buckle up for safety's sake according to a research report.

title: MRS. NIXON ATTENDS RITES IN RAPID CITY
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., June 181 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon stopped briefly in Rapid City today to attend a memorial service for the 215 persons known to have been killed nine days ago when a flash flood devastated the Black Hills resort town.

title: YANKS LOSE BAT DAY IN STADIUM RAINOUT
description: The Yankees had expected a Bat Day crowd of 55,000 at the Stadium yesterday. But the persistent morning downpour held the paid crowd to 34,40 and forced the game against the Texas Rangers to be postponed.

title: U.S. Expects a Decrease in American and Soviet Influence by 1980
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The State Department has predicted that by the end of the decade the power and dominance of the United States and the Soviet Union in world affairs will decline while those of Western Europe, Japan and China will rise.

title: Presidential News Conferences Quietly Dying of Nixon Disuse
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Presidential news conference is dying, without ceremony or explanation, and reporters who moan about it are being put down by the Nixon staff as selfserving whiners who merely miss the chance to kick the President around or to bask in his g ry in public. The reporters are not much more generous in speculating about Mr. Nixon's motives. so there is a lot of ugly talk about a subject that might just be worth some serious discussion, especially in an election year.

title: It's Racing at Big A Today
description: Thoroughbred racing shifts from Belmont to Aqueduct today for a 36day summer meeting. For the bartenders, waiters and other Mondayoffers who will swell the crowd at BagdadontheSubway, a $27,500 stakes race brightens the card.

title: XAARI VOTED BEST IN JERSEY SHOW
description: FORT DIX, N. J., June 18Ch. Acadia's Xaari, a black standard poodle, who yesterday was named best in show at Bryn Mawr under bright skies, today proved she is an equally good trouper in the rain when she took the top honors at the Burlington County fixture on sodden Doughboy Field.

title: Two New South African Trains Offer Wine Racks, Tinted Glass
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 18 (UPI)It's the hottest thing on wheels, a South African Railways official said as one of the new 16car Blue Trains rolled into Johannesburg station for its first public viewing.

title: Panamanians to Vote in August For First Time Since 68 Coup
description: PANAMA, June 16Panamanian newspapers are carrying little notices these days reminding people that Aug. is election day and assuring them that their votes will be counted. honestly.

title: ROSS AGAIN TAKES N. J. TENNIS CROWN
description: CLIFTON, N.J., June 18Steve Ross of Brooklyn won the New Jersey State men's singles championship for the third straight year today by beating Andy Finn of White Plains, 61, 62, at the Clifton Indoor Tennis Club.

title: Fitz Gibbon Net Victor
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., June 131 (AP)Herb FitzGibbon of New York beat topseeded Mike BelH kin of Canada, 63, 76, to win the Southeastern tennis championship today. Belkin was bidding for his fourth straight title and had been unbeaten in 17 tournament matches.

title: DIGIUSEPPE SECURE ASTRAVIATA TENOR
description: In the two and a half years since he made his Metropolitan Opera debut, Enrico DiGiuseppe has made steady progress through a number of major tenor roles with the company, and Saturday night he added yet another.

title: Smith, Solomon Top Mexicans for a Rout In Davis Cup, 5 to 0
description: MEXICO CITY, June 18 (Reuters)  Stan Smith beat Joaquin LoyoMayo, 60, 63, 26, 64, and Harold Solomon beat Octavio Martinez, 64, 61, 62, today to give the United States a 50 sweep over Mexico in the Davis Cup North American Zone final.

title: U.S. Return to Talks Is Urged
description: PEKING, June 18 (Agence mance Presse)  The North Vietnamese Ambassador, Ngo Thuyen, said here today that if President Nixon had any new ideas on Vietnam, they could be presented at the Paris peace talks.

title: Sociologist Named to Board Of Equitable Life Assurance
description: Dr Eleanor Bernert Sheldon, Science Research Council, has oven elected a member of the ooard of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the U.S.A. sociologist and executive associate of the Russell Sage Foundation in New York since 1961, Dr. Sheldon is the first woman to be elected to Equitable's board.

title: Nicklaus Wins U.S. Open by 3 Strokes
Spook Asserts Third Party Intends to Press Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI)  Peace activists and other liberals intend to continue organizing a third party, despite Senator George McGovern's strong drive toward the Democratic Presidential nomination and hope to be on the ballot in more than half the states in November, Dr. Ben. jamin Spock said today.

title: Jaycees to Hear Agnew
description: ATLANTA, June 18 (AP)Vice President Agnew will speak to the United States Jaycees gathering here tomorrow for the start of their 52d nationla! convention.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Word comes from California that Gov. Garry Schumacher, scholar, raconteur and bon vivant, is retiring as the San Francisco Giants public relations administrator. This is the right season for it. During his years of service on two coasts, Garry knew the glory that was Mays and the grandeur that was Marichal. Now Willie wears the doubleknit regimentals of the Mets, Marichal's wonlost record stands at 210 and Candlestick Park is the home of baseball's most accomplished losers. If there could be a fitting time for the Governor to pack it in, this is it.

title: Racing: It's Tough to Keep the Faith
description: Before he lost his faith in horse trainers and jockeys, Bobby Byrne used to think about The Dream Race a lot.

title: MOZART CONCERT PLAYED OUTDOORS
description: KATONAH, N.Y., June 18There is no more glorious place for enjoying outdoor music than the garden surrounded Venetian Theater at Caramoor, and there is hardly a composer whose works harmonize more graciously with nature than Mozart.

title: AIDE IN MIAMI BEACH WILL ASSURE MEDIA
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 18City Manager Clifford W. O'Key will advise the nontelevision news media this week that they will not have to remove their equipment from the Convention center between the two national political conventions.

title: 6 States and Puerto Rico Choose Delegates
description: Senator George McGovern of South Dakota picked up sizable blocs of delegates at Democratic conventions in four mountain states and in Connecticut, North Dakota and Puerto Rico this weekend.

title: Delegates in Pennsylavnia Face Challenges by 2 Units
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP)  Political groups representing young people and women will move tomorrow and Tuesday to unseat a share of Pennsylvania's 182 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: POSTCARD HISTORY SHOWN AT MUSEUM
description: CANAAN, Conn., June 18When the picture postcard was first introduced in the late 19thcentury, it revolutionized the international postal system.

title: Our Election in German Eyes
description: COLOGNE, West GermanyLook ing from abroad at the American Presidential election I get the impression that there is quite a bit of hazard involved. It seems that it will be just accidental or unavoidable that Richard Nixon will obtain another term.

title: Elder Drives 1972 Dodge To Golden State 400 Victory
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 18 (UPI)Ray Elder of Caruthers. Calif., took the lead on the 110th lap today and captured the $70,000 Golden State 400 at Riverside International Raceway for his first Grand National victory of 1972.

title: Bullet Removed From Wallace's Spine, With No Immediate Effect on Paralysis
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 18A team of neurosurgeons removed a bullet today from Gov. George C. Wallace's spinal column.

title: Unauthorized Raids Attributed To Eased White House Control
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A number of former Government defense specialists believe that the recent disclosure that Gen. John D. Lavelle conducted a series of unauthorized bombings of North Vietnam reflects an even larger problem  the Nixon Administration's relaxation of command and control over the air war in Southeast Asia.

title: Liver Ailment Patient Dies
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., June 18 (AP) A California woman whose blood was routed around her liver and through that taken from a baboon died today. The authorities at Talmadge Memorial Hospital said that Mrs.! Linda D. Greenaway, 32 years old, of Buena Park, who was suffering from a serious liver ailment, had died of respiratory arrest.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Relations with Host Country3:30 P.M.

title: COSMOS GAIN LEAD AFTER 21 VICTORY
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 18  Splashing and sliding but kicking the ball accurately on rainsoaked Hofstra Field, the New York Cosmos climbed to first place in the Northern Division of the North American Soccer League today by edging the Toronto Metros, 21.

title: Global Pilots'
description: The man at the head of the international pilots stoppage is a stolid Finn whose ordinary discourse resembles messages between the control tower and an approaching jetcareful, brief, firm.actions carefully, said friend the other day whileCaptain Forsberg was meeting at. the United Nations with Secretary General Waldheim. But once convinced he does not hesitate.

title: Rumania Tops Italy, 41
description: BUCHAREST, June 18 (AP)  Rumania split the last two singles matches today in the European Zone's Group A Davis Cup tennis tournament against Italy to score a 41 victory and advance to the group final against the Soviet Union in Moscow.

title: Guard Charged With Trying To Murder His Daughter
description: A 31yearold private security guard was charged with attempted murder yesterday after he allegedly shot his 12yearold daughter in the neck during an argument at their home in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: HONG KONG RAINS TAKE MANY LIVES
description: HONG KONG, Monday, June 19More than 100 people were feared dead and thousands were homeless in Hong Kong today following three days of torrential rain that sent hundreds of tons of earth and rock sliding down the steep hillsides on which much of this British colony is built.

title: Lebanese Security Official Says Commando Activity Is Off Sharply
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18A highranking Lebanese security official says that Palestinian guerrilla operations against Israel from Lebanese territory are at their lowest point In years.

title: Hug Wins Gymnastics, Heads Olympic Squad
description: DES PLAINES, Ill., June 18 (AP)Steve Hug, the National Collegiate gymnastic champion from Stanford, outperformed Makoto Sakamoto, a six time Amateur Athletic Union winner, by less than a point today and took first place in the qualification for the United States Olympic gymnast team.

title: Carolina Air Crash Linked To Faulty Traffic Control
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) The collision of a jet airliner and a light plane in North Carolina last Dec. 4 was the result of inadequate airtraffic control, the National Transportation Safety Board reported today.

title: Czechoslovakia Trumphs
description: DUSSELDORF, Germany, June 18 (AP)  Czechoslovakia defeated West Germany, 32, Sunday in the semifinals of the European Group B Davis Cup tournament today.

title: A Tragedy With an Aftermath of Guilt
description: Wordsworth's We are Seven is one poem that Mrs. Judith Choate can recite by heart, and often does. Early one morning in 1965, the willowy, former fashion model tiptoed into the nursery of her West Side apartment and found her 5monthold son, Robert, dead in his crib.

title: DUAL ARMS PLANS BEFORE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The Administration, under the modernization program it contends is essential to maintaintechnological superiority over the Soviet Union, plans tospend $11billion over the next five years developing a supersonic strategic bomber.

title: A.E.C. STUDY BACKS SHOREHAM, PLANT
description: SHOREHAM, LI., June 18A key Atomic Energy Commission division has issued a firm recommendation that the Long Island Lighting Company be allowed to build a nuclear power generating reactor here. The recommendation was contained in a 370page Draft

title: Sports News in Brief
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 18 (AP)The South African Amateur Athletic Union plans to invite American athletes, including blacks, to compete in the South African Games next year, an athletic official said today.

title: JOHN STACK, EXPERT ON WIND TUNNELS, 65
description: YORKTOWN, Va., June 18 (AP)John Stack, an engineer who helped develop the first highspeed wind tunnel in the 1930's, died today at the age of 65. He had fallen from horse on his farm in nearby York County.

title: West Germany Takes Soccer Cup, 30
description: BRUSSELS, June 18 West Germany expectedly and impressively won today's final of the European Nations Cup overwhelming the Soviet Union by 30.

title: American Air Directors To Elect New President
description: When directors of American Airlines, Inc., meet here on Wednesday, it is expected by industry observers that they will promote the system's 50yearold general manager and executive vice president, George A. Warde, to the post of president and chief operating officer.

title: Wendy Wexler, B. R. Berkowitz Wed in Jersey
description: TENAFLY, N. J., June 18In Temple Sinai here this afternoon, Miss Wendy Marla Wexler was married to Barry Richard Berkowitz by Rabbi Irwin Blank. A reception was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Wexler, father and stepmother of the bride. Mrs. Wexler, the former Jacqueline Grennan, is president of Hunter College. Her husband is president of the Cape Music Company in New York.

title: Nicklaus Wins Open
description: Jack Nicklaus won the United States Open golf championship for the third time yesterday with a finalround 74 for 290, beating Bruce Crampton of Australia by three strokes. It was Nicklaus's 13th major title, tying the record of Bobby Jones. Details on Page 43.

title: Explo 72 Bus Wrecked
description: ODESSA, Texas, June 18 (UPI)A chartered bus transporting 40 to 50 young people from Explo 72 in Dallas to their homes in Fresno, Calif., skidded on rainslick Interstate 20 and flipped over on its side just west of here before dawn today. There were no injuries.

title: Bridge : Leaders in Olympiad Widen Margins Over Challengers
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 18The leading teams moved further ahead of their challengers in this afternoon's play in the World Team Olympiad. The United States and Taiwan both scored maximum points, gaining a little on Italy, which was able to beat only Argentina, 12 to 8.

title: All 118 Killed in Worst British Air Crash
description: LONDON, June 18A British European Airways jet plunged into a field minutes after taking off from Heathrow airport today, killing all 118 aboard. It was Britain's worst air disaster.

title: Dr. O. Frederick Nolde Dead; Active in World Peace Effort
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18The Rev. Dr. O. Frederick Nolde, a Lutheran clergyman and a spokesman on international affairs for Protestant churches since World War II, died yesterday at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: MR. SPINDLETOP WINS AT DARIEN
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 18Mr. Spindletop, a 6yearold chestnut gelding who obviously likes rain, mud and fog, won the first annual Connecticut Classic for jumpers today at the closing session of the fiveday Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse Show.

title: Italian City Is Fearful Of a Quake
description: ANCONA, Italy, June 18This ancient Adriatic seaport, which has been rocked by 2,500 earth tremors since January and brutally shaken by two earthquakes during the last few days, Is living in fear.

title: Books of The Times
description: In April of 1898, Nadezhda Konstantinovna Krupskaya set out from St. Petersburg for the Siberian village of Shushenskoe, 4,000 miles away. She was 29 and about to begin a threeyear sentence forrevolutionary activities. The court had originally ordered her to Ufa, in European Russia; but by claiming to be the fiance of V. I. Lenin, the young Marxist theoretician who was serving a similar sentence in Shushenskoe, she had her place of exile changed. It was all right with Lenin. Czarists authorities, for all their harshness to radicals, accommodated lovers. In St. Petersburg or Moscow almost anyone of appropriate age and sex could visit a political prisoner. As a result, engage ments were arranged and rearranged so that news could be smuggled in, orders to comrades and clandestinely written tracts smuggled out. One such prisoner was visited simultaneously by three fiances, and the warder gave him his pick. Krupskaya and Lenin had worked together for several weeks in a small Marxist group, even gone to the theater together; but there is no evidence that they were lovers.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A century plant has started to make one of its rare bloomings at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, hut horticulturists hasten to say it really happens about every 25 years or so, not every 100 years, as the plant's name implies.

title: Macy's Names Chief Officer For MissouriKansas Unit
description: Joseph C. Kresse, president of the Macy's MissouriKansas division of R.H. Macy & Co., Inc., has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of the division, effective Aug. 1.

title: ARTHUR HOMER, 76, STEEL EXECUTIVE
description: OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., June 18Arthur B. Homer, chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation from 1957 to his retirement in 11964, died today in Hartford Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Otter Cove here.

title: DENTISTS TO TEST FOR HYPERTENSION
description: Health workers are starting a pilot program in Bergen County, N. J., that if successful could make dentists an important factor in reducing the number of deaths caused by high blood pressure and heart disease.

title: Pat Shoolman Victor
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., June 18Pat Shoolman of Fairport, N.Y., won the New Jersey State girls 18 years and under singles championship today with a 60, 61 victory over Sheila McInerney of Rome, N.Y., at the Westfield Indoor Tennis Club.

title: Anne H. Meissner Bride Of Alexander W. White
description: WEST FALMOUTH, Mass., June 18The Friends Meeting House was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Hyde Meissner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Niemeyer Meissner of Wellesley Farms, to Alexander Weld White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tredway White Jr. of New Canaan, Corm. Both families have summer homes on Chapoquoit Island here.

title: French Begin a New Series Of Nuclear Tests in Pacific
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, June 19 (Reuters)The French civil aviation authorities in Tahiti said today that a new series of French nuclearweapon tests will begin in the Pacific at midnight tonight.

title: Multinational Companies Shift Course
description: There is only one way to keep a business going in a foreign country. It must provide benefits for them and for us. You might be able to buy the government for a while, but that kind of arrangement won't last. You'll be out in the end.

title: Nora Sharkey Bride Of Michael G. Murphy
description: Miss Nora Clare Sharkey, associate editor of The Catholic News, was married yesterday afternoon to Michael G. Murphy, editor of the weekly newspaper.

title: Simon Reports an End Of Curb on Campaign
description: Assemblyman Leonard M. Simon said yesterday that he had secured revocation of a temporary restraining order, obtained Saturday by his opponent for the Democratic Congressional nomination, forbidding the distribution of some of Mr. Simon's campaign literature until after the primary tomorrow.

title: Trudeau's Big Problem: What to Do About the American Elephant Next Door
description: OTTAWA, June 18The failure of the fouryearold Government to find a satisfying way for Canadians to live with the elephant next door, the United States, blights what many regard as a record of notable advances in Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's search for new foreign policy. Since Mr. Trudeau and and his liberals won election overwhelmingly, Canada has established her identity in many parts of the world. She recognized China, and many Canadians feel this smoothed the way for President Nixon's visit to Peking. Also, Mr. Trudeau, through an exchange of visits with Premier Aleksi N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, shored Canada's relations with her neighbor over the Arctic.

title: SinoSoviet Influence on Hanoi
description: WASHINGTONPresident Podgorny's visit to Hanoi and Henry Kissinger's trip to Peking may have been coincidental, rather than prearranged to virtually coincide, but both may contribute to a new effort to negotiate peace In Vietnam. The return to Hanoi of North Vietnam's chief Paris negotiator, Le Duc Tho, suggests that new decisions are being taken there.

title: Global Environment
description: The United Nations Conference on the Human Environment has weathered the political squalls that repeatedly threatened to swamp it. In the light of its modest objectives and its formidable obstacles, it must be counted a success. Economic, social and political problems were confronted, if not solved; consensus was reached on more than a hundred recommendations ranging from a moratorium on the taking of whales to the promotion of family planning; and, above all, machinery was agreed upon to enable the U.N. to make itself useful in the improvement of the world's environment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Delegations Silent
description: PARIS, June 18The four delegations to the peace talks here declined comment on the statement made by President Podgorny in Calcutta today.

title: Conference to Study Urban Arts Centers As Links to Schools
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18The first national conference on community arts will open here tomorrow, bringing together more than 200 educators and representatives from museums, foundations and state arts councils.

title: Two SingleHanded Sailors Turn Back in Heavy Sea, Wind
description: PLYMOUTH, England, June 18 (Reuters)Yachtsmen from 11 nations were fighting their way today through heavy Atlantic seas and fierce winds on the second day of the Observer Single Handed Trans Atlantic Race.

title: City U. Union Demands Action to Cut Dropout Rate
description: Improving instruction to reduce the dropout rate and the hiring of more black, Hispania and women teachers are among the major items In the contract demands to be presented today by the Professional Staff Congress to officials of the City University of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICEMEN PELTED IN EAST SIDE MELEE
description: About 150 irate residents of a Lower East Side neighborhood yesterday rained debris on policemen attempting to arrest a man on a traffic violation, the police said.

title: Giantism on the Farm
description: Three decades before Cesar Chavez began his uphill struggle to bring unionism to farm workers, the National Sharecroppers Fund launched a lowkeyed but neverrelaxed effort to alert the nation to the needs this most exploited segment of America's labor force.

title: Personal Finance
description: Diplomas and debt go handinhand for most college students, and the combination is becoming an increasing worry for banks that make loans for education. This Is because most such loans are not repayable until some months after graduation or the end of studies.

title: O.P.E.C. Output Steady
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18 (UPI)  The world's major petroleumexporting countries have decided not to raise their output, of crude oil to replace petroleum taken off the international market when Iraq nationalized the Westernowned, Iraq Petroleum Company, the official Iraqi news agency said today.

title: AllStar Ticket Sale Set
description: ATLANTA, June 18 (UPI) Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has given the Atlanta Braves permission to start selling tickets by mail on Thursday to the 1972 AllStar game at Atlanta Stadium July 25.

title: Next Stop on Way to Slam Is Lost Tree Village, Fla.
Dr. Ludwig von Bertalanffy, A Behavioral Scientist, 71
description: BUFFALO, June 18Dr. Ludwig von Bertalanffy, a professor of social sciences and administration and natural sciences and mathematics at the State of University of New York, died here on June 12. He was 71 years old.

title: CAMPAIGNING CUT BY MRS. CHISHOLM
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm slipped her underdog campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination into low gear yesterday, braving the rain to make campaign appearances only twice.

title: Mitchell Gets HoleinOne
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., June. 17Bobby Mitchell, who had: defeated Jack Nicklaus in the playoff at the Tournament of Champions, today scored the second holeinone in the UnitedStates Open in two days.

title: Memorial to de Gaulle Dedicated by Pompidou
description: COLOMBEY LES DEUXEGLISES, France, June 13(AP)With an emotional speech pledging continued faith to Gaullist principles, President Pompidou today dedicated a huge granite Cross of Lorraine overlooking the home and the grave of Charles de Gaulle.

title: Levine to Heid Book Group
description: George L. Levine, sales and production manager of the United Synagogue Book Service, has been elected president of the Association of Jewish Book Publishers. He succeeds Ralph Davis, director of publications of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. The association, founded 10 years ago, encourages the use of Jewish books by the public.

title: Sex Called Problem in Half of Marriages
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18Dr. and Mrs. William H. Masters, the noted sex researchers, told tile American Medical Association today that half of all the marriages in the country are troubled by some form of sexual problem in which one partner has a clinically significant degree of sexual dysfunction.

title: Parley Concerned Over Increased Use of Strip Mining
description: MIDDLEBORO, Ky., June 18 A woman rancher from Montana,, a Navajo from New Mexico and a Senator from Oklahoma were among a diverse group that gathered yesterday at the historic Cumberland Gap to remind one another that the surface mining of coal was spreading to their sections of the country and was rapidly approaching underground mining as a source of coal.

title: Bank Account for Aged
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company has established a special bank account for the aged under the prodding of the Gray Panthers, an activist group of elderly persons. The special account was sought to enable elderly personsoften the target of muggersto carry less cash.

title: Muskie Offering Himself As McGovern Alternative
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 18Senator Edmund S. Muskie is telling politicians that he, and not Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, is the logical alternative should Senator George McGovern falter in his drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Threat of Controls Fades For Eurocurrency Sector
description: The threat of significant new controls over the Eurocurrency marketwhich might be imposed as part of the general reform of the international monetary system currently under discussion among the major financial powers  appears to hive receded markedly in recent weeks.

title: Missile Numbers Game
description: President Nixon was right to urge the Congress speed approval of the missile curb pacts with Moscow. There was no winnerloser outcome in the SALT I negotiations; as the President emphasized, Both sides won and the whole world won. Moreover, the central argument being made by critics of the agreements has now been refuted in a study made by former Pentagon officials.

title: 2 Service Shooters Gain Spots on Olympic Team
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 18 (AP)  Two service shooters from California and Pennsylvania won spots on the trap contingent of the United States Olympic shooting team today.

title: Elizabeth Litt Is Bride
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y. June 18Miss Elizabeth Litt was married here this afternoon to Lawrence Gordon Gill 3d. State Supreme Court Justice Morrie Slifkin performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Litt, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gill Jr. of Scottsdale, Ariz. The bride was graduated last week from Yale College,

title: Bridal Is Held for Eileen Shapiro
description: Miss Eileen Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Shapiro of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married at noon yesterday to Charles Mantell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Mantell of Cedarburst, L. I. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, assisted by Cantor Bernard Dienstag, performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Ontario, Tightening Rules, Backs Canadian Directors
description: TORONTO, June 18  Onhas announced that all companies incorporated in Ontario must have Canadian directors by Oct 1, 1973 and hold most of their board meetings in Canada with Canadian directors in the majority at every meeting.

title: Caren Jane Altchek Wed to Lawyer
description: In a small 18th century chapel at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue here yesterday afternoon, Miss Caren Jane Altchek, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Salem Altchek of New York, became the bride of Roger Andrew Pauley of Arlington, Va. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Pauley of New York.

title: 10 Die in Japanese Floods
description: TOKYO, June 18 (UPI)Heavy rains which ended today caused flooding and landslides and resulted in the deaths of 10 persons in southern Japan. Weather officials said 13.6 inches of rain fell on Kyushu, Japan's southern island, during the weekend. In the city of Sendai, six persons were buried in landslides and under collapsed buildings. Four other persons died of various causes, including drowning.

title: Offensive Failed, Thieu Says
description: SAIGON, Monday June 19 (Reuters)  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today the North Vietnamese offensive had been defeated and pledged that all territory lost to the Communists would be regained within three months.

title: Miss Devlin Urges a CeaseFire in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 18 (AP)Bernadette Devlin, the civil rights leader, appealed today to militants of the Irish Republican Army to call a sevenday halt to violence in Northern Ireland.

title: 500 Catholics Urge A Purge of Bishops In U.S. Conference
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 18A group of conservative Roman Catholics today asked the nation's Bishops to prune the staff of the Bishops secretariat, the United States Catholic Conference, of revolutionary elements.

title: FourWay Stop
description: After the bus had inched its way through the rushhour congestion to the corner of a major intersection, the light finally turned green. But the goahead was merely symbolic. Traffic remained stalled in all directions because trucks and cars had failed to clear the passage made narrower by the usual digin of ole of the public utilities. The resulting bedlam of horns and curses was not specifically indicative of urban life gone mad; it was merely evidence of the way New Yorkers now normally live.

title: CITY SEEKS U.S. HELP ON UTILITIES PRICING
description: Mayor Lindsay's administra Lion has appealed to the Federal Price Commission to re quire the state's Public Service Commission to be more ??sponsive to Federal pricecontrol philosophy on utilityrate increases.

title: 17 Foreign Carriers Cancel Flights Here
description: At least 17 foreign airlines Kennedy International Airport reported yesterday that they were canceling today's scheduled flights because of the international pilots strike. This would halt 114 of the daily average of 1,000 takeoffs and landings at the airport.

title: Arabs by the Tens of Thousands Visiting IsraeliOccupied Areas
description: JERUSALEM, June 18With official and public attention focused on the wellbeing of thousands of foreign tourists arriving daily at Israel's international airport, another flow of more unusual tourists is pouring into the country with little notice and little tension.

title: Memo to the Campuses
description: The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education will not win any popularity contests in academia for urging the colleges and universities to increase their productivity and trim their budgets. The latest study, More Effective Use of Resources: an Imperative for Higher Education, estimates that in order to carry out their responsibilities at a cost that the country and the consumer can afford, the universities must cut about $10 billion by 1980 from their then projected annual expenditures.

title: They Brave Storm Even in the Galley
description: Cooking for a crew of eight or more men over 635 miles of unpredictable ocean in a pocketsized galley on a yacht that more often than not is heeled over at a sharpangle isn't most women's idea of bliss.

title: Sacking and Saving Italy
description: ROMEIn Italy, nature and history are so closely related that it would be impossible to separate the two. Land in its natural state is practically nonexistent in Italy; throughout the country, nature has been remodeled or at least marked by works of man over the ages. The farmlands in Italy have prevalent characteristics and structures which vary from region to region, while the villages are nestled in hills and the monasteries, churches and castles punctuate plains, mountains and coasts. All of these landmarks form an organic wholea chain of naturalarchitectural events which until a few'decades ago unfolded practically unaltered from the Alpine peaks the sea.

title: WILLIAM J. PRICE 3D
description: BALTIMORE, June 18William J. Price 3d, a limited partner in the investment banking firm of Alex. Brown & Sons, died yesterday. at his home in Ruxton. He was 72 years old.

title: Mrs, Mary Gallatin Hoppin, Fund Raiser for Lighthouse
description: Mrs. Mary Gallatin Hoppin, founder of Amateur Needlework of Today, which conducted many national exhibitions to raise funds for The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, died Saturday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 88 years old and lived at 6L0 Park Avenue.

title: Javelin Star Bears. Life of Boomerangs
description: SEATTLE, June 18Bill Skinner looks the picture of power and confidence with his muscular 6foot6inch, 235pound frame, a reddish handlebar mustache and giant hands that can grip a javelin, a welder's torch or his daughter's hand with equal intensity and feeling.

title: M'Rae, New Zealand, Wins Watkins Glen Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 18Graham Cassius McRae of New Zealand won his second Continental 5000 championship race of the season today over the 3.377mile road course of Watkins Glen Grand Prix circuit. He drove an Englishbuilt LedaChevrolet of his own design which he intends to discard soon.

title: BIG BOARD REQUESTS VIEWS ON NEW PLAN
description: The New York Stock Exchange has asked the various regional stock exchanges for comment on the Big Board's recent proposal for developing a consolidated stock trade reporting system;

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine Is Voting Today on a Challenge to Mrs. Smith
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 18Issues of job security, taxes and the state's economy are creating a surprising threat to the reelection prospects of Margaret Chase Smith, the United States Senate's only woman and a political institution in the State of Maine.

title: Advertising:
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the country's fourth largest agency, confirmed Friday that it has taken the preliminary steps toward going public.

title: John Erickson, Transposed Lone Ranger Theme Song
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 18John E. Erickson, the songwriter and composer who transposed the William Tell Overture for the theme song of the Lone Ranger, died Friday in the New Rochelle Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 10 Davenport Avenue.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., June 18George Burns 3d of Wheatley Hills, who had eliminated the defender, Bob Murphy of the Garden City Country Club, in an early round, beat Richard Stanley of Mill River, 1 up today in the final of the 49th annual Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the St. George Golf and Country Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Body Recovered Off Battery
description: The police yesterday recovered the body of a man who fell overboard from a Circle Line boat late Saturday night off the Battery. He was identified as Patrick J. Thelan, 28 years old of 15 Elm Street, West Orange, N.J. The police said the boat had been chartered for a moonlight cruise by, the Elks Club's Crippled Children and Veterans Committee of the North Central District of New Jersey.

title: Connecticut Starts Plan to Aid Students by Purchasing Loans
description: HARTFORD, June 18Connecticut has started an unusual program of buying student loans from banks, with an eye to helping students, banks and the state government as well.

title: Peter Knopp Weds Patricia La Farge
description: KILLINGWORTH, Conn., June 18Miss Patricia La Farge, a greatgranddaughter of John La Farge, the artist, was married here this afternoon to Peter Francis Knopp. Justice of the Peace Robert Frank performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hooper La Farge, parents of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mrs. Charles Levy of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late George Knopp, a New York lawyer.

title: SHOP TALK
description: People keep asking me if we're a resale place, said Vicki Cooper, glancing around the long, skinny shop called Ulla at 886 Madison Avenue, near 72d Street. They can't believe the prices. Prices run to $50 for a blazer, $15 for pullon pants, $18 for a shirt.

title: MRS. ARTHUR C. FORD
description: Mrs. Lydia Bowser Ford, wife of Arthur C. Ford, a civil enginer and former City Commissioner of Water Supply, died Saturday in a Forest Hills nursing home. She was go years old and lived at17305 Croyden Road, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Taylor Caldwell Married
description: BUFFALO, June 18 (AP)In a brief ceremony held in her home yesterday, Taylor Caldwell, the author, was married to William Everett Stancell, a retired Florida real, estate developer. Miss Caldwell, 71 years old, and Mr. Stancell, 72, met on a roundtheworld cruise in January. Justice Sherwood L. Bestry of suburban Amherst performed the ceremony.

title: 2 Air Force Pilots Killed As Jet Explodes in Florida
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., June 18 (AP),Two pilots from Nellis Air Force Base, Nev., died today when their F111 jet fighter exploded after takeoff and plunged into Choctawhatchee Bay near this north Florida base.

title: Police Urge Social Security Numbers on Valuables
description: New Yorkers will be encouraged to engrave their Social Security numbers on their valuables and register them with the police to facilitate recovery in the event of theft, under a program scheduled to begin in the next few days.

title: Jane Dubrowin Married in Suburb
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 18Miss Jane Ellen Dubrowin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Dubrowin of White Plains, was married here this afternoon to Melvyn Bernard Marks. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Marks of Middletown, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: A Partnership Forged on Navy Yard Plan
description: After months of dissension and bitterness over the slow development of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard into an urban industrial park, a partnership has finally been forged between community leaders and the city government that takes politics out of management, ac City Hall Notes cording to Economic Development Administrator Ken Pat ton. Because of the earlier bick ering, at least three companiesa ship builder, a glass company and a light manufacturing plant  have held up their planned relocation in the yard. With the restructuring of management, Mr. Patton said, these companies would be ready to move in.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STANTON, Del., June 18Mill River Stable's 11 to 1 shot, Floor Show, stole the show today at Delaware Park when he captured the $62,265 Leonard Richards (turf) stakes. John M. Schiff's heavily backed Dubassoff could only finish third after being repeatedly blocked during the mileanda16th event for 3yearolds.

title: L. M. Finder Marries Victoria Hoxter
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 18Miss Victoria AnnHoxter and Leslie M. Finder were married here this afternoon. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Curtis J. Hoxter.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Soldiers
description: BELFAST, June 18 (Reuters) Two British soldiers were killed and three others seriously injured when a boobytrap bomb exploded near Lurgan, about 15 miles from here.

title: Advertising:
description: If you want to reach 2.6 million households containing a lot of upscale suburbanites who believe in doing good and dress up at least once a week, then Arthur W. Van Dyke has a buy for you.

title: 2 Boys Drown Upstate
description: MINETTO, N. Y., June 18 (AP)Two youths drowned today while swimming in the Oswego River under the Minetto Bridge according to the state police. The body of Charles David Eastridge, 15 years old, was recovered shortly after the drowning. The body of the second boy, who was 14, had not been found when the search was called off at nightfall. The police withheld his name.

title: Gaza Arabs Get Life Terms
description: GAZA. June 18 (AP)Two Gaza Arabs, one a 16yearold, were sentenced to life in prison by Israel today on charges of murdering 13 Arabs they believed were cooperating with the Israelis.

title: Seaver Heats Reds, 24; Mets in First, Staub Hurt
Children'sBook Writer Is Slain In Landmark House in Village
description: Irma Simonton Black, a writer and editor of children's books, was found stabbed to death yesterday in the Greenwich Village landmark.house she had lived in for more than 30 years.

title: Survivors Are Still Sought In Wreck of French Trains
description: SOISSONS, France, June 18 (UPI)Faint groans from persons still trapped In smashed railroad cars today spurred rescue workers seeking survivors of the train crash two days ago deep inside the milelong Vierzy tunnel.

title: Personalities: Swift Recovery?
description: Chi Cheng of Taiwan, the world's fastest woman sprinter, who underwent surgery in April for the removal of a muscle where she sits, has entered the 100and 200meter dashes in the Olympic Games in Munich. She had been considered out of the games because of the operation. It's still doubtful that she can compete... Monica Pflug, West Germany's goldmedal winner in the 1,000meter speed skating event at the Winter Olmpic Games in Sapporo, Japan, escaped serious injury in an automobile accident in Bayerischzell, Germany. A family spokesman said that Miss Pflug received her driver's license less than three weeks

title: DEMOCRATIC RAID TIED TO REALTOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The, apparent leader of five men arrested yesterday for breaking into the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee here was identified today asi an affluent Miami real estate man with important Republican party links in Florida.

title: Speaks in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, June 18Senator Muskie told an overflow crowdof about 700 persons here today, I am still a candidate for President. I came to Buffalo to make that clear.

title: Stage Institute Names Head
description: Larry Arrick has been appointed the new director of the National Theater Institute, founded in 1970 and maintained at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

title: Mao's Old Stronghold Awaits a Tourist Army
description: YENAN, China, June 14To the American visitor Ye ian in many ways seems like a city of ghosts but not, it should be emphasized, like a ghost town.

title: Miss Vasquez Bride Of Allan F. Hewitt Jr.
description: Miss Vivienne Marie Vasquez, daughter of Mrs. Colliston Rainford of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Allan Fitzroy Hewitt, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hewitt of Port of Spain, Trinidad in St. Francis of Assissi Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. John L. Kiernan performed the ceremony.

title: RangelWingate Debate: Powell, Bosses and Credibility
description: They were alternately acerbic, freewheeling. heated and humorous as each explained why he should be the Congressman from the city's 19th District, symbol of black power whose center is Harlem.

title: LAURENCE MISCALL, THORACIC SURGEON
description: Dr. Laurence Miscall, a thoracid surgeon, died of cancer Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 5 Russel Place, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: FRANK E, BAKER
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) Frank Eugene Baker of Bryn Mawr, a former president of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, died today at the age of 82.

title: Dorchester's Tenants Debate How to Tip Staff
description: It was swelteringly hot other night as members of Dorchester Towers Tenants Council debated what to about Christmas tips for building employes at 155 West Street.

title: STAPLE SINGERS ADD RHYTHM TO HARMONY
description: The Staple Singers were at Philharmonic Hall Saturday night for their first concert here since their hit single, I'll Take You There, was released.

title: Blue Wins First
description: Vida Blue, the Athletics lefthander, who was the American League's most valuable player last year, registered his first victory of the season yesterday as he stopped the Cleveland Indians, 90, on a fourhitter at Oakland. It was his first complete game. Blue missed the first six weeks of the season because of a salary dispute. Last year at this time his wonlost record was 142. This year's record is 13.

title: 5 Groups of the Disabled Plan Citywide Alliance
description: Representatives of groups formed to press the rights of the physically handicapped held a modest pilot meeting in Queens yesterday to discuss the organization of a citywide alliance.

title: U. of Michigan Triumphs In Shields National Sail
description: NEWPORT HARBOR, Calif., June 18  The University of, Michigan won the Cornelius Shields national sailing championship that finished yesterday after five days of competition.

title: Wedding Couple Arrested
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 18 (Reuters)Uruguayan armed forces raided a wedding reception here and arrested the bride and bridegroom after finding a Tupamaro printing press in the house, the Government announced today. Ten members of the leftwing urban guerrilla movement, including six married couples, have been captured in the past few days. another official communique said. Hundreds of Tupamaros have been arrested since the Government declared an internal war in midApril.

title: GLOBAL STOPPAGE SNARLS AIRLINES; U.S. PILOTS CURBED
description: A 24hour global work stoppage called for today by pilots and maintenance men to press for more stringent measures against hijacking has disrupted major portions of airline operations.

title: STEEL SHIPMENTS UP SHARPLY IN MAY
description: PITTSBURGH, June 18 Steel shipments rose sharply in May.

title: MORGEX CAPTURES RICH PARIS RACE
description: PARIS, June 18Mrs. Michel Marie's 8yearold gelding, Morgex, won the $193,000 Grand Steeplechase de Paris run today over four miles and 110 yards and 28 fences at Auteuil, France.

title: Miss Gorfinkle Wed to Michael Baker
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 18Miss Geraldine Susan Gorfinkle and Michael Erskine Baker, graduates of Northwestern University, were married here at noon today by Rabbi David Greenberg in the garden terrace of the Beach Point Yacht Club.

title: Hurricane Perils Florida; Some Urged to Evacuate
description: MIAMI, June 18 (AP)Residents of a lowlying area along the Florida panhandle were urged to evacuate today as a hurricane named Agnes headed toward them with winds of up to 100 miles an hour. Tornadoes spawned by the storm killed one person and injured at least 35.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ROME, June 18 (UPI)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the favorite, led from start to finish today in his John Player Special to win the Grand Prix of the Republic, the first race for Formula 1 cars staged in Rome in 18 years.

title: 3 DIE AS PLANE SKIDS OFF JERSEY RUNWAY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 18 (UPI)  Three persons were killed today when their singleengine plane skidded off the end of a rainsoaked runway here and fell into the Intracoastal Waterway.

title: Roundup: Tigers Sweep Angels to Reach the Top
description: The Detroit Tigers didn't get many hits in the threegame series that ended with Mickey Lelich's 20 victory over the California Angels yesterday in Anaheim, Calif. But they came out with three victories and undisputed possession of first place in the American League Division.

title: South Vietnamese Troops Raid 2 EnemyHeld Areas
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 19South Vietnamese troops have raided two areas occupied by North Vietnamese forces, according to military spokesmen.

title: JOHNSON'S KETCH IN BERMUDA LEAD
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18Mark Johnson's Windward Passage, the 73foot ketch from Grand Bahama Island and one of the world's fastest oceangoing yachts, was leading the race to Bermuda today with a shot at breaking the record for the 66yearold event.

title: So What Is a Multinational?
description: Multinational corporation is a relatively new corporate catchphrase to describe a form of business that is as old as...

title: Newbury Crash Kills One
description: NEWBURY, England, June 18 (AP)A light plane crashed near a race track here today, killing the pilot and injuring four other persons, including Joe Mercer, one of Britain's top jockeys.

title: Broker Tells of In Aims
description: A constant fascination about Wall Street is the variety of investment methods used by stock brokers Marshall M. Weinberg, 42, describes himself essentially as a lowmultiple or assetdiscount buyer. He is a partner and a substantial producer at Herzfeld & Stern, which he joined in 1954. Mr. Weinberg deals with the practialities of the market in a way that reflects his college education in philosophy prior to obtaining a Master of Business Administration degree at Columbia. Last week, he outlined his investing philosophy in a discussion with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Portions of the interview follow:ANSWER: My philosophic training before I switched to business was highly empirical and semanticoriented. It made me focus on the fundamentals and eliminate the gibberish in Wall Street.

title: Auto Workers Are Given a Voice on Assembly Line
description: DETROIT, June 18Since Henry Ford and his engineersput together the first car assembly line in 1914, the auto industry has been fitting the man to the line.

title: Major Democratic Races Enliven Primary Here
description: Eight major contests for Congressional nominations, the first primary for the State Court of Appeals and scores of legislative contests highlight the statewide Democratic primary tomorrow.

title: Payments for Paperback Rights Soar
description: A spate of enormous payments to authors for paperback and movie rights is changing the profile of the book business as well as testifying to its financial health.

title: FRANCE ASSURED OF OIL FROM IRAQ
description: PARIS, June 18 Iraq has guaranteed that France can continue to take oil from the nationalized Kirkuk Fields for 10 years under conditions that prevailed before the takeover on June 1, a joint communique said tonight.

title: WHITE HOUSE'S ROLE IN AIR WAR DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Daniel Z. Henkin, the Pentagon's chief spokesman, has criticized those former Government officials who hide behind the cloak of anonymity while criticizing the Nixon Administration's conduct of the air war in Vietnam.

title: MURPHY REVIEWS BRIBERY CHARGES
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that the most significant aspect of the current Federal investigation of birbery by heroin dealers was that it went beyond the police and involved judges, prosecutors, lawyers and bondsmen.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The Treasury Department began an investigation today to determine if the manufacture of Korean tennis shoes was being illegally subsidized by the Korean Government. The Treasury's investigation could result in additional duties being imposed on imports of Korean tennis shoes if the subsidies are found to exist.

title: Cards Help to Guide New York Voters
Rodgers, Nebraska Star, To Appeal Jail Sentence
description: LINCOLN, Neb., June 19 (AP) Nebraska's football star, Johnny Rodgers, filed notice today that he intended to appeal conviction and subsequent 30lay jail sentence he received for driving with a suspended license.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It seemed an ironic circumstance that your excellent May 23 editorial The Backs of the Poor should have been followed by the poignant one The Broken Pieta. The children of the deprived and poor are all too often the frustrated grownups who take out their slow anger on whatever will hurt most  perhaps memorable works of art or wouldbe political leaders.

title: Timber Purchase Set
description: Willamette Industries, Inc., said yesterday it had exercised an option to buy 19,500 acres of Douglas fir timberlands in Oregon's Alsea River basin for $40million.

title: Primary Day
description: There are glaring inadequacies in New York State's primary election laws. For example, hundreds of thousands of this state's young voters, recently enfranchised by court decree and an amendment to the Federal Constitution, are nonetheless ineligible to participate in today's balloting. Eligibility in this case depends on the date that a prospective voter turned eighteen years of age. State law requires that anyone eligible to register and enroll in a party prior to a general election must have. done so in order to be eligible to participate in a subsequent primary.
