Thus, those who were eighteen before last Election Day must have registered and enrolled then order to vote now. The purpose of the law is to prevent crossover voting but the integrity of a party's primary could be amply protected by requiring registration and enrollment thirty days prior to any balloting.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)Howard Cosell, the sports broadcaster, said he supported legislation to establish a Federal commission to bring some order into the affairs of professional sports.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF 5TH WEEK IN ROW
description: The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday the fifth consecutive week of lower production. Meanwhile, the Aluminum Association said that April shipments of sheet and plate were down 6.1 per cent from the yearago level.

title: M.T.A. Signs Pact For 50 New Cars For HudsonHarlem
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority signed a $15,604,000 contract yesterday for 50 more Metropolitan electric commuter cars for the Hudson and Harlem Divisions of the Penn Central.

title: Rates Seen on Increase For ShortTerm Loans
description: Treasury Under Secretary Charls E. Walker hinted yesterday that he believed the cost of shortterm business borrowing would increase, while longterm borrowing costs may already have peaked.

title: Local Vietcong More Active in Areas Near Saigon
description: RACHKIEN, South Vietnam, June 16Taking advantage of the major North Vietnamese attacks elsewhere local Communist units have been quietly reasserting control this spring over many of their oncepowerful bases in the provinces around Saigon. They are posing what officers on the scene consider a serious threat both to the vital pacification program and to the capital itself.

title: Notes on People
description: Wearing flared bluejeans, a brown blouse and highheeled sandals, Mrs. Clifford Irving, surrendered at the United States Court House in Manhattan, ready to serve the twomonth sentence she received for her part in the hoaxautobiography of Howard it Hughes, the billionaire.

title: COMPLAINT FILED ON ANTINIXON AD
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Common Cause, the citizens lobby, filed formal complaints today against The New York Times and the Committee to Impeach the President over an advertisement published May 31 in The Times.

title: Stravinsky: A Composer Never Far From Ballet
description: It has been said of Tchaikovsky, who composed three fulllength ballets, that in all of his music he had classic ballet percolating in his subconscious. There are dance movements in his symphonies, and the feeling of dance permeates many of his other absolute pieces of music.

title: As Hell's Kitchen Changes, So Does McManus
description: Like two of his great uncles and his father before him, James McManus will lead the Democrats of Hell's Kitchen to the polls in today's primary.

title: Penguins Sign Top Scorer
description: PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP)  Jean Pronovost, right wing and scoring leader for the Pittsburgh Penguins, signed oneyear contract today.

title: Texas Air Crash Fatal to 5 Is Called a MurderSuicide
description: GONZALES, Tex., June 19 (AP)The authorities said today that the pilot in a plane crash that killed five persons yesterday was the victim of murdersuicide.

title: One Man Killed, 2d Is Shot In $4,000 Harlem Stickup
description: One man was killed and another was wounded by gunmen who stole $4.000 from them and forced them to undress outside an East Harlem bottle club early yesterday, the police said. A woman who was with the two was beaten.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: QUARRY WILL ALTER STYLE TO AVOID CUTS
description: Jerry Quarry said yesterday he planned to alter his style for his fight against Muhammad Ali next Tuesday night. In a 14city telephone hookup interview with the newsmen throughout the country, Quarry said his main objective in altering his style would be to avoid being cut by the former heavyweight champion.

title: Bridge: Lebanon and Morocco Forfeit Matches to Israel in Olympiad
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 14Political problems became a factor in the closing stages of the World Bridge Team Olympiad qualifying contest here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (Reuters)Longterm mortgage loans totaled $9.2billion during March, the latest month for which figures are available, the Department Housing and Urban Development said today. This was 33 per cent higher than in February and about 46 per cent higher than in March, 1971, but the department noted that credit agencies of state and local governments were included in the figures for the first time.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES EXTRA JOBLESS AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPi)The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today an Administration proposal that would extend an emergency jobless benefits program for six months beyond its June 30 expiration date and increase an employer tax to pay for it.

title: Burglar, 16, Helped Gather Data That Led to 9 Arrests in Bronx
description: A 16yearold burglar who was caught stealing from a public school in the Bronx turned undercover agent and helped gather evidence that has led to the arrest and indictment of nine Bronx merchants on charges of receiving about $10,000 worth of goods that the youth stole from four schools in the area.

title: Rodon Is First to Finish NewporttoBermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 19Robon, a 61foot sloop from Newport Beach, Calif., was the first yacht to finish the Bermuda ocean race tonight.

title: Prince Visits Aircraft Plant
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19 (UPI)  Prince Sulta Ibn Abd al'Aziz, defense minister of Saudi Arabia, visited the faciltes of the Northrop Corporaton today. He was shown mockups of the new aircraft being produced by the company, including a new light attack bomber.

title: Tool and Die Makers to Equip 5 Plants for $55Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 An association of mainly small United States manufacturers of tools and dies announced today a $55million deal with the Soviet Union to equip five new factories for producing table flatware and holloware such as teapots, which have been in scarce supply there.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Rent Commissioner, Nathan Leventhal, was ordered yesterday to defend in state Supreme Court next Monday the plan to authorize retroactive rent increases for nearly 400,000 tenants In controlled apartments beginning July 1. A showcause order was issued in a suit challenging the legality of the increases retroactive to last Jan. 1, which was filed yesterday by Representative Bella S. Abzug.

title: SMITHSONIAN SET TO SELL U.S BOOKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19lhe Smithsonian Institition has just put 10,000 more items on display, but this time its millions of visitors can take the exhibits home with them.

title: Moderate Shift in Chile
description: President Allende has moved to resolve a severe crisis within his Popular Unity coalition in Chile by rejecting the radical counsel of his own Socialist party and adopting the more moderate and conciliatory approach urged by the Communists. In thus shifting back toward the center of Chile's political spectrum, Dr. Allende has reduced the danger of largescale civil strife and given his revamped Government its best chance to revive sagging economy.

title: Death Penalty Is Upheld
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 19 (AP)The Mississippi Supreme Court refused today to outlaw the death penalty as cruel and unusual. Chief Justice Robert Gillespie handed down the decision in an appeal by Fred Peterson, who was sentenced to death for a Stone County murder.

title: Judge Blocks Hearings
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP)A city judge blocked the Democratic National Committee today from holding hearings on charges of impropriety in the selection of national convention delegates pledged to Senators Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: Rev. James Munro, 72, Led Presbyterians in Canada
description: TORONTO, June 19 (Canadian Press)The Rev. James Alan Munro, a former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, was found dead today at his home in Weston. He was 72 years old.

title: Chess: Despite Petrosian's Record, He Is Only a Fischer Victim
Front Page 2  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: DANIEL CORY DIES; WRITER, EDITOR,67
description: Daniel Cory, literary executor of the late George Santayana, the philosopher and poet, died Sunday at his summer apartment in the Brunnenberg, a castle near Merano, Italy. He was 67 years old and lived also in Rome.

title: Striking Pilot Explains: I Had to Do Something
description: The airline pilots seemed to strike more in sorrow than in anger yesterday. Indeed, the angriest pilot of all, who carried a sign saying, The Next One Killed by an Air Pirate May Be You, was full of regret.

title: Kissinger, Arriving in Peking, Is Greeted by Foreign Minister
description: PEKING, June 19 (Reuters)Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, arrived in Peking tonight and was driven almost immediately to the Great Hall of the People, apparently for meeting with Premier Chou Enlai.

title: Slain Queens Girl's Family Seeks to Bar Visitors
description: The family of a 15yearold girl who had been stabbed to death strove yesterday to stem the tide of total strangers visiting a funeral home in Jamaica, Queens, as police offiClEilS moved extra homicide personnel into an area where 10 assaults of a pattern have occurred in less than two years.

title: Senators Indicate Support At ArmsAccords Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Senate Foreign Relations Committee began formal hearings today on the new strategic arms limitation agreements with Moscow and all the Senators who attended expressed various degrees of support for the agreements.

title: ALIOTO ACQUITTAL ORDERED BY JUDGE
description: TACOMA, Wash., June 19A Federal judge announced today a directed order of acquittal for Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco and two former officials of this state on charges of bribery, conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is a serious imbalance between Presidential and Congressional controls over warmalting and foreign policy: The Senate appears impotent in the face of executive domination; the House is essentially an instrument of Presidential will.

title: Floods Snarl Traffic in Metropolitan Area
description: An overnight torrent of rain, exceeding 10 inches in 24 hours in some areas, thoroughly soaked much of the metropolitan area yesterday and produced the most severe flooding in 17 years in parts of Westchester County and southern Connecticut.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision on wiretapping today, delivered by Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr.

title: A.M.A. CHIEFS ASK EASED DRUG LAWS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 (UPI)The American Medical Association leadership has proposed that the nation abolish criminal penalties for possession of marijuana for private use.

title: Agnew Warns Elitists Of Election ShakeUp
description: ATLANTA, June 19 (AP)Vice President Agnew warned today that the elitists of the new left and their renegade followers are due for a shakeup in the November election.

title: $10,000 Safety Fine Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) The Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission, in the largest fine to date, said today that it has upheld a $10,000 penalty against an Ohio ship building company In connection with a fire in which four workers died. The American Ship Building Company of Lorain was accused of five violations of Federal job safety standards in the fire, which occurred June 24, 1971, on board the merchant ship Roger Blough, being constructed in the company's shipyard in Lorain.

title: 12 U.S. Journalists Chosen by Harvard As Nieman Fellows
Democratic Congressional Races Highlight Primaries Here Today
description: Charges of lowroad appeals for the Jewish vote in the Bronx and promises by two feuding Congressional contenders in Brooklyn to bring further lawsuits against each other dominated the waning hours of the primary campaign yesterday as sporadic rains forced the cancellation of numerous handshaking tours.

title: State Moves to Reorganize Its Welfare Setup
description: Another major reorganization of the state's Department of Social Services was announced yesterday, proposing businesstype management and an ongoing audit of program and welfare spending.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, June 19 (Reuters)David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, urged Japan today to liberalize her trade substantially and increase direct investments in the United States to counteract protectionist sentiment and pressure for another revaluation the yen. The No. 1 international concern of the United States is its $3billion trade deficit with Japan, he said at a luncheon of the AmericaJapan Society.

title: Impoverished Pupils Lose U.S. Aid, Bergtraum Says
description: A Board of Education official charged yesterday that 11,000 impoverished pupils in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond were Ling denied a share of Federal Title I funds because of rigidities in Federal guidelines.

title: Japanese WhiteCollar Couple Complain of Rising Prices and Tell How They Try to Make Ends Meet
description: TOKYO, June 10Now that the days are hot, Masataka Hataye stops off on the way home from work for a beer and a chat with friends.

title: Theater:
description: The Rev. Al Carmines is an urban optimist. He sees the despair and the degradetion. and he chases them away with gentle mockery and graceful music.

title: Proposed Commuter Rate Rises Scored
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 19Elected officials and commuters last night assailed a proposal to raise fares on the Harlem and Hudson lines of the Penn Central an average of 23 per cent.

title: Business Briefs
description: William B. Camp, the United States Controller of the Currency, has recommended that the Federal Reserve Board approve an application by the Citizens Bancorp, bank holding company in southern New Jersey, to acquire the First National Bank of Marlton, N..7., in part because of the Marlton bank's inadequate capital and its deteriorating loan portfolio.

title: 43 Summer Explorers From U.S. Schools Setting Out on World Missions
description: A valley in Kenya, a sunken city in Greece and an archeological excavation in Israel are some of the international sites that are to become classrooms this summer for talented, young Americans.

title: RESERVE TO CHECK ON REALTY TRUSTS
description: The Federal Reserve Board is planning a broadscale investigation of conflicts of interest in the management of real estate investment trusts by commercial banks.

title: Castro at East Berlin Rally
description: BERLIN, Tune 19 (Reuters)Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba wound up the official part of his eightday visit to East Germany today at a rally in East Berlin. He goes to Czechoslovakia Wednesday and then to the Soviet Union.

title: PROFIT SETS PEAK AT LEVI STRAUSS
description: Levi Strauss & Co., producer of jeans and slacks, showed record sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended May 28, it reported yesterday from San Francisco headquarters.

title: DEMOCRATIC PANEL GETS MAYORS'
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 19 (AP)The Democratic platform committee heard 10 Mayors say today that the future of the nation depends on the future of the cities.

title: Kansas Governor in Race
description: TOPEKA, Kan., June 19 (UPI) Gov. Robert B. Docking today formally filed for the Democratic nomination for a fourth term. Three Republicans are running for their party's gubernatorial nomination. They are Lieut. Gov. Reynolds Schultz, former Gov. John Anderson Jr. and Ray Frisbie, a former Kansas Farm Bureau director.

title: MSGR. CHARLES J. REILLY
description: Msgr. Charles J. Reilly, pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Most Blessed Sacrament, in Bayside, Queens, died yesterday in Mary Immaculate Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Judge Bars Hanrahan Plea And Slates Trial for July 5
description: CHICAGO, June 19State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan, the Democratic nominee for second term in a politically sensitive office, lost today his last chance to avoid a trial on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in his handling of a 1969 raid on a Black Panther headquarters.

title: OBSERVER
description: A number of persons have written to ask why the money is constantly becoming less. Here are some of the more important reasons:

title: COURT'S DECISION PRAISED BY KUHN
description: The United States Supreme Court decision on the Curt Flood case yesterday was hailed as constructive by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, who also called for renewed collective bargaining on the reserve system after the 1972 season.

title: 24 KILLED IN INDIA IN RELIGIOUS RIOTS
description: NEW DELHI, June 19 (UPI) Religious riots in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh have resulted in 24 deaths in the last three days, officials at the state capital, Lucknow, reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his June 11 column, To Reach for Other Stars, C. L. Sulzberger illustrates the kernel of ecological truth in the sentence Surely we cannot let ecological qualms halt dreams of fertilizing the Sahara or warming up Antarctica with nuclear power, thus rendering habitable millions of new acres.

title: Advertising:
description: Just a couple of days apart the mails brought in an invitation to the party for the launching of Ms. magazine, and the announcement that New Woman magazine suspending publication. That's publishing for you.

title: Connecticut District Plea Fails
description: HARTFORD, June 19  A threejudge Federal court here refused today a request by the state Republican party to order nominations and elections for the Connecticut General Assembly under a reapportionment plan the same three judges had declared unconstitutional.

title: CHINA'S ECONOMY SHOWS BRISK GAIN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19Official Chinese statistics, the first available more than a decade, showed brisk rate of growth in mainland China's farms and factories.

title: Laborite Sees Devaluation; Tories Denounce Diatribe
description: LONDON, June 19As the pound drifted downward another 20 points in the foreign exchange markets today, Denis Healey, the Labor party spokesman on finance, predicted in an address that sterling would be devalued by July or August.

title: The Restraint of Law
description: The Supreme Court has delivered a sharp rebuke to those ideologues of the executive branch who consider the President's inherent powers superior to the Constitution. In an 8to0 decision the Court has, rejected the assertion that the Government has the right, without court orders, to tap the wires of dangerous radical groups. Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., who wrote the opinion, said: The price of lawful public dissent must not be a dread of subjection to an unchecked surveillance power.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: JOAN. Mr MATE. FOR WHOM EVERY DAY HAS MEANING. THIS DAY, HAPPY BIRTHDAY. LOVE, BEN D.Adv.

title: Executive Changes
description: Richard P. Strubel has been appointed chairman of the board and president of the Buckingham Corporation, sole United States distributor of Cutty Sark Whisky. He succeeds J. U. KaiNielsen, who has resigned from the subsidiary of Northeast Industries, Inc.

title: Samuel Goldstein, 92, Lawyer In 150 Murder Cases, Is Dead
description: Samuel Goldstein, dean of Bronx criminal lawyers at his retirement in 1943, died Sunday at his home, 25 Sutton race South. He was 92 years old.

title: U.S. WILL RESUME AID TO PAKISTAN
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 19The United States tonight announced a full resumption of foreign aid to Pakistan except military aid. The aid was stopped in March, 1971, before the IndianPakistani war.

title: Coast Guard Calls 1971 Worst Year For Boating Deaths
description: The Coast Guard has just set down 1971 as the worst year in United States pleasure boating history.

title: Storm Fading in Florida After Killing 12
description: APALACHICOLA, Fla., June 19 (AP)Hurricane winds of 80 miles an hour, accompanied by heavy rain, struck the Florida Panhandle today, but the storm's intensity began to subside as it churned inland.inland, and in several spots stalks were bent almost parallel with the ground.

title: Lima's Poor Build a Suburb Overnight
description: LIMA, PeruOn a given day they gather at dusk in the courtyards of dozens of former palatial mansions and elegant business houses that today barely hide Lima's decaying downtown slums.

title: U. S. Claims Record Strike At Foe's Antiaircraft Guns
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 20The United States command reported yesterday that its planes destroyed more of North Vietnam's antiaircraft defenses during the previous 24 hours than in any period since Hanoi's offensive began March 30.

title: French Warnings Suggest Pacific Atom Test Is Near
description: PARIS, June 19France has issued warnings to aircraft and ships to steer clear of her Pacific atomic testing center starting at midnight tonight, Greenwich mean time (7 P.M. Monday, New York time).

title: Personalities:Mazeroski Retiring
description: Bill Mazeroski, who is playing his 17th season with the Pittsburgh Pirates, intends to retire at the end of this season. This year is it, the 35yearold second baseman says. I think the time has come. He announced his re?? at the end of last season, but Manager Bill Virdon convinced him to try one more year... Muhammad Ali, undaunted by the news that Jerry Quarry will alter his boxing style against Ali in their fight next week, offered his opponent some dubious advice when Quarry stopped by to watch All train. The only way to beat me, Ali told Quarry, is to knock me coldand that's impossible.

title: Protest Empties Airports From Tel Aviv to Maine
description: In Madrid, New Delhi, Tel Aviv, Frankfurt and Buenos Aires, airports were silent and nearly empty. In Rome, Amsterdarn, Zurich and Belgrade, harried travelers vied for tickets on crowded trains. In Panama City, a pilot lay down in front of a jetliner to make sure it could not take off.

title: TITO VISITS WARSAW; RISE IN TRADE IS SEEN
description: WARSAW, June 19President Tito arrived today for four days of talks with Polish leaders that are expected to lead to expansion of their already vigorous industrial trade.

title: HONG KONG RECOVERS FROM FLOOD SLOWLY
description: HONG KONG, June 19Hong Kong was recovering slowly today from the paralyzing effects of what the Governor, Sir Murray Maclehose, described as the worst rainstorm of the century.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 19Meadow Stable's Riva Ridge, winner of the Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes, is the first horse invited to the $100,000 Monmouth, handicap race to be run Saturday, Aug. 5, at Monmouth Park.

title: SENATE HOLDS UP MONEY FOR BASES
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Senate, in an assertion of its foreign policy prerogatives, voted today to cut off funds for recently concluded military base agreements with Portugal and Bahrain unless the agreements are submitted to the Senate as treaties.

title: Hill Joins San Diego St.
description: SAN DIEGO, June 19 (AP)Dick Hill, who coached several worldclass athletes at Florida A. and M. and in recent years It Southern University, was named track coach today at San Diego State. He succeeds Dick Wells.

title: Young Designers on the Way Up in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON  A small group of young black designers has begun to make its mark in the capital.

title: A Hijacking Suspect Pleads Not Guilty to Three Counts
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 19 (UPI)  Frederick W. Hahneman today pleaded not guilty to air piracy, kidnapping and assault charges in an Eastern Airlines hijacking that netted $303,000 ransom.

title: Ziegler Names Press Aide
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. June 19 (UPI)Tom Decair; 27 years old, formerly a reporter for The Kalamazoo (Mich.) Gazette, has joined the staff of the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, as staff assistant.

title: Macy's Shifts Merchandising Posts
description: Macy's New York has promoted Miss Mary McMahon to senior vice president for merchandising. She will head merchandising of these product classes: children's, boys cosmetics, drugs, stationery, greeting cards, notions, toys, intimate apparel and fashion fabrics. She will also be a director and member of the executive committee.

title: QUALIFIERS PACED BY MRS. GUSHING
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 19Mrs. Justine Cushing of Meadow Brook won the qualifying medal in the 69th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: 8 Quit Olympic Trials
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., June 19 (AP)Eight players have dropped out of trials for the Olympic basketball team, leaving 59 for the second week of drills. Those who left because of injuries or for personal reasons were: Ken Morgan, George Adams, Jim Baker, Steve Downing, John Aing, Richard Morsden, Tom Peck and Charles Edge.

title: 4 CONVICTED HERE IN COCAINE DEALING
description: Vincent Pacelli Jr., who was linked to an investigation into the murder of a former Manhattan model, was convicted yesterday for the second time this year of Federal narcotics charges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again Mayor Lindsay and his administration are asking city taxpayers and city workers to pay the price for mismanagement. Only Mr. Lindsay could think of laying off highway workers at a time When the city's streets are becoming virtually impassable.

title: World Aviation Group Spurs Bid For Sanctions in Air Hijackings
description: MONTREAL, June 19The council of the International Civil Aviation Organization adopted today a strongly worded resolution that could lead to joint sanctions against countries that give refuge to air pirates.

title: Pilots Halt Flights Abroad, But Strike Falters in U.S.
description: An uneven oneday work stoppage by airline pilots caused wholesale grounding of overseas flights yesterday but halted only about 10 per cent of operations by United States carriers.

title: Tahiti Yachts Battle Calm
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19 (UPI) The fleet of seven sailboats, competing in the 3,571mile transPacific Tahiti yacht race, had to contend with no wind for their sails today and, because of a heavy blanket of clouds, there were no stars or sun to make sightings from. On the fifth day, Greybeard led the fleet, with Pen Duick III first on handicap.

title: Japanese Brokerage Office
description: New Japan Securities International, a Japanese brokerage concern, announced the opening yesterday of a New York office at 80 Pine Street. The opening represented the first move of a Japanese securities house into the New York market since 1959.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Harvard Netman Is AllStar
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 (UPI)  Harris Masterson of Harvard was named today to the singles allstar team by the Eastern Intercollegiate Tennis Association. Also named were John Adams of Pennsylvania, Bill Colson of Princeton, Craig Dawson of Navy, Dirk Dugan of Cornell and Rick Fagel of Columbia.

title: M'GOVERN LOOKS TO VICTORY TODAY IN STATE'S VOTING
description: On the eve of an expected major victory in the New York Presidential primary, Senator George McGovern declared yesterday that he would not shift his political philosophy despite charges that he was too liberal for many Democrats.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX STAGE A RETREAT
description: Stock prices opened higher on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and then enough selling entered to push them down slightly below Friday's level. The index closed at 27.48, off 0.02. In the overthecounter market, the NASDAQ index was down 0.76 to 140.11.

title: PENNSY AND BANK SET ACCORD ON RAIL SALE
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company trustees announced yesterday they have reached agreement with the New England Merchants National Bank to distribute proceeds of the proposed sale of about 10 miles of the former Boston & Albany Railroad mainline and part of a branch line to the State of Massachusetts for $3million. The bank is trustee of a Boston & Albany mortgage.

title: Stabbing Victim Saved By Brooklyn Patrolmen
description: Two Brooklyn patrolmen were credited with saving the life of a stabbing victim last night when they stopped the flow of blood from his severed jugular vein and rushed him to a hospital half a mile away in their radio car.

title: 1,400 Gas Stations Will Be Eliminated Because of Unprofitable Experience
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it would cease marketing branded gasoline and other automotive products in most of the Northeastern United States over the next 15 months.

title: More Coal Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 19A State Department official who attended the recent oil congress of Arab states reported today that these producers seem to be unwilling to increase output to keep pace with the United States growing appetite for foreign oil.

title: ROCHESTER SHUTS ITS HIGH SCHOOLS
description: All 10 secondary schools in Rochester were ordered closed yesterday for the summer vacation three days ahead of schedule after gangs of black and white students clashed at two schools and at least 29 of them were hurt.

title: American Electric Power Files for Disposition Plan
description: The American Electric Power Company filed yesterday an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval of a disposition plan for gas properties it acquired in 1967. The plan calls for transfer of gas properties of the former Michigan Gas and Electric Company, now the Michigan Power Company, to a new subsidiary to be formed by American Electric Power.

title: $1.75 Wage Floor Is Voted in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 19  A measure that would raise New Jerseys minimum wage from $1.50 to $1.75 an hour received final, overwhelming approval today in the State Assembly.

title: CHALLENGES REDUCE PRIMARY CONTESTS
description: Successful challenges to the validity of petitions filed by some candidates and the withdrawal of other candidates have reduced the number of contests for party nominations in today's primary election.

title: GRAEBNER VICTOR IN LONDON TENNIS
description: LONDON, June 19  With Stan Smith and the rest of the United States Davis Cup team en route from Mexico City, secondseeded Clark Graebner led four Americans into the second round of the London Grass Court championships today by drubbing switchhitter Jean Claude Barclay of France.

title: Prof. Thomas McMahon, Writer on Hemingway, 49
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 19Prof. Thomas McMahon, who joined the English department at the University of Tam in 1970 after serving for several years as department chairman and honors program director at the University of Puerto Rico, died today in St. David's Hospital. He was 49 years old.

title: The Right to Speak Up on War
description: Whatever the sentence of the court, it certainly is not the intent of this court to deter any peaceloving people [from] pressing forward in getting message to the American people, because in our system, it is most important that the issues of the day, whatever they are, are freely discussed and that all sides are given opportunity to be heard.

title: TV: Perpetual People Puzzle an A.B.C. Potpourri
description: In the beginning, a little over a year ago, there was public broadcasting's The Great American Dream Machine. As a TV magazine in search of a weekly theme, it captured the critics votes with its perky, wacky, sometimes penetrating, sometimes controversial material. But Dream Machine ran into publicTV politics and money troubles, and before finishing its regular run last season the contraption was quite noticeably losing steam.

title: FIDELITY CORP. PLANS HENTZ&CO.PURCHASE
description: RICHMOND, June 19 (AP)The Fidelity Corporation has announced plans to acquire H. Hentz & Co., a major New York Stock Exchange brokerage house, in a move that would open Big Board membership to financial institutions.

title: Court Here Rules The Mad Bomber Is Still Incompetent
description: George P. Metesky, the eccentric mechanic once known as The Mad Bomber, lost legal effort yesterday to have himself declared mentally cornpetent.

title: Moscow Rebuffs Iran
description: BEIRUT, June 19 (AP)The Soviet Union has rejected demands by Iran for an increase in the price of its natural gas, industry, sources reported today.

title: HIGH COURT CURBS U.S. WIRETAPPING AIMED. AT RADICALS
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today the Federal Government's pratice of wiretapping, without first obtaining court approval, domestic radicals considered dangerous to the national security.

title: Agricultural Research Accused Of Favoring Big Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The nation's agricultural research establishment, including the big landgrant universities, was accused by some of its own representatives today of favoring big corporations while neglecting consumers, small farmers and the rural poor.

title: Irish Mixed Marriage  It's Lonely
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandEach afternoon Bessie Mulgrew steps out her red brickhouse on Theodore Street, in the bleak Roman Catholic quarter, and walks alone towards the Protestant Shankill Road.

title: Chou Enlai at 74: Realistic Leader Is Wistful for the Past and Fascinated With America
description: PEKING, June 19Premier Chou Enlai does not believe that at my advanced age he should look forward to visiting the United States but he has lost none of the interest in Americans and things Americans that has marked his long career.

title: The Judge in Wiretapping Case Damon Jerome Keith
description: DETROIT, June 19When Federal. Judge Damon J. Keith was a law student at Howard University from 1946 to 1949, Thurgood Marshall and other men would say to him, It's there. It may take time. It may take struggle. But the remedies are there. The men, prominent black lawyers who often gathered at the university to rehearse cases before arguing them in the Supreme Court, were referring to the Constitution and the Federal court system, through which they believed blacks would eventually win their freedom and equality.

title: Treasury Bills Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Advertising:
description: Life magazine, with the help of the Louis Harris organization, has returned to the marketplace to feel the pulse of the consumer.

title: Drug Detective Says Gold Fails to Prosecute Pushers
description: A narcotics detective charged yesterday that Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold failed to prosecute narcotics pushers in the borough's schools and that one of Mr. Gold's assistants had tried to bribe him not to press a case.

title: HOUSE UNIT STAYS TOCKS IS. PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The HOuse Appropriations Committee today held up more than $7million in construction funds for the controversial Tocks Island dam and reservoir in the Delaware River Valley and directed that the money be used instead to speed land acquisition until environmental questions about the project were resolved.

title: MinorityGroup Students Here Learn Hospital Administration
description: As part of a national program to interest minoritygroup college students in the field of hospital administration, 20 New York City youths yesterday began a 12week interneship in municipal and voluntary hospitals.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Johnny Bench of Cincinnati replaced Manny Sanguillen of Pittsburgh in the race for the No. 1 catching spot, and Willie Mays of the New York Mets climbed to third place among outfielders in the second week of voting for the National League AllStar team. Bench had 130,823 votes to 88,688 for Sanguillen, according to figures released by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Now Class, Today We're Going to Learn Something About TobaccoSpitting.
description: RALEIGH, MissIs longdistance tobaccospitting a manifestation of rural culture worthy of indepth presentation by the Mississippi Authority for Educational Television? Or would it spatter the image of the Magnolia State?

title: Bantam Will Issue American Review In Publishing Shift
description: New American Review, the avantgarde quarterly that introduced Philip Roth's Portnoy's Complaint and Kate Millett's Sexual Politics, will he issued by Bantam Books beginning in January under a new title, The American Review.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Ball Corporation, Muncie, Ind., manufacturers of glass containers, yesterday disclosed plans to sell 1,002,284 sharesits initial public sale of stock. The offering, to be comanaged by Morgan Stanley & Co. and Collttt & Co., is scheduled in midJuly. Of the total number of shares, 300,000 will be sold by the company itself and 702,284 by certain stockholders.

title: Vendome Fire Inquiry
description: BOSTON, June 19 (UPI)Mayor Kevin H. White said today that the city had hired national consulting concern. Charles T. Main Company, to determine the cause of the Vendome Hotel fire and collapse that killed nine Boston firemen Saturday.

title: Arthur Daley
description: When Paul Richards was running the Baltimore Orioles during their formative stages many years ago, he swung a massive deal with the then reigning Yankees. He yielded Bob Turley and others for nine players. But the key the transaction was Turley and disgruntled Yankeehaters of that era accused Richards of coilbloodedly handing the Bronx Bombers another pennant. I don't give a damn about the Yankees, snapped back Richards. l'm interested in what I got from them for my ball club, and they gave me four or tive guys who will be Baltimore regulars.

title: Mrs. Smith Easily Defeats Rivalin Maine G.O.P. Race
Walter E. Heller to Finance 3 American Airline DC10's
description: Walter E. Heller & Co. announced yesterday it was the successful bidder for the financing of three new McDonnell Douglas DC10's to be leased on a longterm basis to American Airlines, Inc. The three jets, which cost a total of $51million, will be delivered to the airline during the final quarter of 1972.

title: Texan Sees Nixon Victory
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 19 (UPI) Former Mayor Erik Jonsson of Dallas predicted today that Republicans and conservative Democrats in Texas would unite to give President Nixon a solid victory over his Democratic challenger next November. Mr. Jonsson, a threeterm Mayor who relied heavily on bipartisan support to win that post, was officially named today as head of Mr. Nixon's reelection campaign in Texas.

title: LLOYD HARBOR RACE CAPTURED BY TROON
Firemen's Sick Calls Drop To 65 in a Day From 183
description: A Fire Department spokesman said that 65 fire officers and fire fighters reported sick or injured after fires in the 24hour period that ended at 6 A.M. yesterday. Only one fire company was forced out of service because of a lack of manpower in that period, he said.

title: Police Say Slayer of Author Used 3 Weapons
description: Irma Simonton Black, the murdered author, was stabbed with a scissors and a large knife as well as with a carving fork, police officials reported yesterday as they pressed a widescale but so far fruitless investigation through the streets of Greenwich Village.

title: HIGH COURT BARS STORM KING PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Supreme Court rejected by an 8to1 vote today appeals by conservation groups and the City of New York to block construction of the world's largest pumped water storage plant at Storm King Mountain on the Hudson River.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CROYDON, N. H.  June was October when Vic Pomiecko of Claremont, N. H. and I launched our canoe on Long Pond in Croydon  a northwest wind was gusting to 40 miles an hour, the temperature was in the high 40s, and whitecaps churned under dark skies.

title: Sniper Kills Soldier in Ulster; Prisoners Granted Concessions
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 19The fourth British soldier to be killed in Ulster in 24 hours fell to a sniper's bullet today.

title: Business Briefs;RockwellStandard's Appeal Fails
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)The RockwellStandard Corporation failed today in the Supreme Court to win an appeal for a new trial of charges that it induced the Scaife Company to buy its Tiken Silent Automatic Division with misrepresentation. A jury in Allegheny County, Pa., awarded Scaife a $1.2million damage judgment, but the trial judge found the verdict excessive and took steps for a new trial. Last December, however, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court allowed the judgment to stand.

title: HANOI AND SOVIET BID U.S. END RAIDS
description: MOSCOW, June 19The Soviet Union and North Vietnam today published a joint demand that the United States end the mining of North Vietnamese harbors and air raids against Hanoi's territory and resume constructive negotiations toward peace in Vietnam.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: McGovern and Youth
Michigan Aide Asks Judge To Drop Plan for Schools
description: DETROIT, June 19 (UPI)Attorney General Frank J. Kelley of Michigan asked Federal District Judge Stephen Roth today to suspend the order he issued last week for the development of a desegregation plan for the public schools in the Detroit area.

title: SHOP TALK
description: A famous European candymaker, which introduced its chocolates into this country a couple of years ago, soon had so many outlets for its wares that not enough imports could be brought in to fill the demand. Result: The chocolates are now being made here.

title: Counterfeit Ring's Plan For Convention Upset
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While I agree with John IL Yadvish's condemnation of the air bag to promote auto safety [letter June 9], I feel that his counterproposal (a governor to limit auto speed to 60 m.p.h.) is not only drastic but possibly counterproductive. His basic tenet, that most vehicle fatalities occur at high speeds, is erroneous to say the least.

title: Ruling Is Seen Raising Prospect of Baseball Strike Next Spring
description: A massive strike in baseball next spring became a possibility yesterday as a result of the Supreme Court's refusal to redefine the reserve clause.

title: PERCY WEST
description: Percy West, a retired vice president of the First National City Bank, died yesterday in Claremont Care Center in Point Pleasant, N. J. He was 78 years old and lived at 301 Brooklyn Boulevard, Sea Girt, N. J.

title: TABLOID NEWSPAPER IS LOST BY BOSTON
description: BOSTON, June 19 (AP)The Boston Herald Traveler ceased publication yesterday, and today the tabloid format of the takeover newspaper, the RecordAmerican, disappeared from newsstands.

title: BROOKLYN MAN SLAIN IN DEMOCRATIC CLUB
description: A 60yearold Brooklyn man said by investigators to have been involved in narcotics was shot to death last night as he watched televison in a local club.

title: Bang the Bell, jack, I'm on the Bus
description: GLASGOW, ScotlandAlienation is the precise and correctly applied word for describing the major social problem in Britain today. People feel alienated by society. In some intellectual cirdles it is treated almost as a new phenomenon. It has, however, been with us for years. What I believe is true is that today it is more widespread, more pervasive than ever before. Let me right at the outset define what I mean by alienation. It is the cry of men who feel themselves the victims of blind economic forces beyond their control.

title: Urban Lifeline
description: The clearest message from the voters in this year's primary elections is that government is too unresponsive to the immediate needs and concerns of the people. One way to start correcting that deficiency is to strengthen the governments closest to the peoplerthe states and localitiesthrough increased Federal aid.

title: EDWARD BUNN, 76, LED GEORGETOWN
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 The Rev. Edward B. Bunn, chancellor of Georgetown University, died last night in his room at the university. He was 76 years old and had been president of the Jesuit institution from 1952 until 1964, giving him the longest tenure of any president in the school's history.

title: Cost Deters France
description: PARIS, June 19French sources, who declined to be identified, said today that although France's 35 per cent stateowned Compagnie Francaise des Paroles had just won assurances over future supplies of Iraqi oil from the nationalized Kirkuk Fields, the company would not, in the foreseeable future, buy Kirkuk oil.

title: BEAMON RETIRES AS LONG JUMPER
description: SAN DIEGO, June 19 (AP)Bob Beaman, who four years ago electrified the sports world with a record long jump of 29 feet 24 inches, said today he was retiring from track and field and would not try to make the United States Olympic team.

title: In Italy, Largest Show of Moore's Art
description: FLORENCE, ItalyIn one of the most beautiful openair settings in the worldthe Forte di Belvedere, in the hills overlooking the city of Florencethe sculpture of Henry Moore is on display this summer in one of the most extraordinary exhibitions any modern artist has ever had in this venerable arthaunted city. A selection of major works in stone and bronze from the last quartercentury is installed on the spacious, multileveled terraces of what was once a fortress (commisioned by Giovanni de Medici) and is now a public park, while the four floors of the principal building house a comprehensive retrospective of small sculpture, drawings and prints.

title: Beame Charges Irregularities in Neighborhood Aid
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that officials and employes of Mayor Lindsay's Neighborhood Action program had raided the agency's $5.000 revolving pettycash fund for interestfree loans, per. sonal expenses, wining and dining, and office parties.

title: ExG.O.P. Aide Linked to Political Raids
description: WASHINGTON, June 19A former consultant to a high White House official was reported tonight to have met in Miami about two weeks ago with the apparent leader of the group that has been charged with attempting last Saturday to install secret listening devices at the offices of the Democratic National Committee here.

title: Market Place: Customer Urged To Test Broker
description: The small investor has been told about brokers who follow the philosophy, Don't call us, we'll call you. And it's probably fair to say that most brokers would rather do it themselves.

title: Air Strike
description: The attempt to shut down the world's airlines by pilots harassed and frustrated beyond endurance by the hijacking menace cannot be condonedbut it certainly can evoke public sympathy as a desperate response the obstruction and indifference of selfserving commercial and national interests that have blocked international efforts to control aerial piracy.

title: Dr. William Antopol, 69, Dies; A Pathologist and Researcher
description: Dr. William Antopol, a leading pathologist and director of laboratories and research at Beth Israel Medical Center, died in San Francisco early yesterday of a heart attack while attending the meeting of the American Medical Association. He was 69 years old and lived at 350 First Avenue.

title: Wallace Reported Suffering Normal Post Surgery Pain
description: SILVER SPRING, Md. June 19 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was reported suffering normal postoperative pain today but recovering satisfactorily from surgery that removed a bullet lodged near his spine.

title: RESERVE SOUGHT CUT IN GROWTH OF MONEY
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its March meeting to step up the growth rate in its new bank reserve target of operations, but with the aim of actually slowing somewhat the growth in the nation's money supply, it was disclosed today.

title: Marriott to Build Abroad
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (AP)Marriott Hotels, Inc., announced today plans for constructing the chain's first European hotel, a 400room, 12story unit in Amsterdam. Construction is expected to begin shortly, and the opening is scheduled for early 1975, a Marriott spokesman said.

title: IN THE NATION
description: PINIKHAM NOTCH, N. H., June 19Some writers say there are really only three storiesman against man, man against nature, man against himself. After three days of backpacking on the Mount Washington range, at least the last two can begin to seem like one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since Senator Byrd sets such great store by the facts concerning Congressional action in breaching the chrome trade embargo against Rhodesia (letter June 13), I thought he might be interested in one basic fact he thoroughly distorted.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (Reuters)Two Senators began a bid to get Bobby Lee Hunter, who is serving an 18year prison term for manslaughter, into the Olympic Games as a boxer.

title: Technological Gains by Soviet Reported by Silver Institute
description: The Soviet Union has contributed more to technical literature on silver than any other country in the last 12 months, according to the Silver Institute.

title: The Prospects for Vietnam Talks: Nixon Telling Hanoi Time Is Now
description: WASHINGTON, June 19The briefcase that Henry A. Kissinger took on his Peking visit today is bulging with position papers on everything from the suitability of basketball for diploatic Ping Pong to the cashandcarry possibilities of some big ChineseAmerican trade deals. But there is not much mystery about his overriding interest: Vietnam. Mr. kissinger's continuing purpose in Peking, like much of President Nixon's purpose there and in Moscow earlier this year, has been defined on many occasions by Mr. Kissinger and the few other informed Administration officials. It has been to enlist the Russians and the Chinese in an elaborate exercise, :both diplomatic and military, to persuade the North Vietnamese that the summer of 1972meaning the weeks between now and Labor Dayis the optimum time for negotiating an end, of the war.

title: Italy Signs Accord
description: ROME, June 19 (UPI)Italy and Iraq agreed today to broaden cooperation on oil matters following the recent nationalization of the Iraq Petroleum Company.

title: LEVITZ OFFERING OFF FOR PRESENT
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporationwhich has been a highflying stock on the New York Stock Exchangedisclosed yesterday that it would not proceed with its proposed public offering of 600,000 shares.

title: Flett Returns to N.H.L. After Jump to W.H.A.
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP)Bill Flett, who jumped to the World Hockey Association last month, returned to the National League today, signing a threeyear contract with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: WIDER POWER URGED FOR CUSTOMS GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)  The House Appropriations Committee ordered the Customs Bureau today to halt the preclearance of travelers hound for the United States at all foreign points.

title: NEWSLETTER TO DROP DISPUTED AD CLAIMS
description: Moneysworth, a consumer newsletter published by Ralph Ginzburg, has agreed to discontinue advertising claims that were described as fraudulent by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Pan American to Lay Off 400 of Service Personnel
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would lay off 400 mechanics, aircraft cleaning specialists, and other service personnel effective July 10. The cutbacks will affect 300 employes here and 100 in Miami.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you stop and think about it, Samuel Eliot Morison seems most unfashionable

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the eyes of the peace movement and many segments of the press, it is an article of faith that President Thieu is a corrupt dictator and that Vietnamization is a delusion. But a recent headline in The Cleveland Plain Dealer Thieu Denied Rule by Decreetells us in a nutshell what Vietnamization is all about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:May I be allowed a belated comment on your may 22 editorialNot by Bread Alone The editorial implied that career education is an attampt by the Office of Education to undermine the academic preparation of students, from kindergarten on up, in an effort to equip them for the world of work. Noithing could be further from the truth.

title: ExPolice Officer Draws Five Years On Larceny Count
description: A former police lieutenant who refused to testify before a grand jury investigating the murder of a man he allegedly tried to kill was sentenced to five years in prison in a separate case yesterday.

title: Barriers Remain
description: Although the Court removed a major barrier to construction of the Storm King plant, there are still some hurdles ahead for the controversial facility.

title: Lenny Closes Saturday
description: Lenny, the Julian Barry play based on the life and material of Lenny Bruce, will end its run at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Saturday night after 455 performances. Sandy Baron replaced Cliff Gorman in the title role a week ago today.

title: FMC in $21Million Deal
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Wayne Manufacturing Company of Pomona, Calif., a major manufacturer of mechanized municipal and industrial sweeper equipment, for stock valued.at $21million. The terms of the agreement call for FMC to exchange 0.7778 of a share of its common stock for each Wayne share outstanding. On June 16, Wayne had 1,004,062 shares outstanding.

title: I.O.S., Ltd., Still Troubled 1971 Annual Report Shows
description: GENEVA, June 19I.O.S., Ltd., the mutual fund complex, is still in serious financial trouble, its 1971 annual report shows.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company will increase its tire prices by a range of 1.5 to 2.5 per cent, beginning July 1.

title: Court Move on Daley Slate Perils Democrats'
description: WASHINGTON, June 19A Federal district judge ruled today that the Democratic party could not compel states that elected their convention delegates to balance the delegations on the basis of race, age or sex.

title: I.T.T. Denies S.E.C. Charges; Stock Trades Again, Drops 3
description: International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation stock dropped yesterday to its previous low price of the year on the New York Stock Exchange before recovering slightly to close at 53, 3 lower than its Thursday level.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: British Jet Crash Attributed to a Stall After LiftOff Device Retracted
Baseball's Exempt Status Upheld by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Baseball, and only baseball,remains exempt from the antitrust laws, the Supreme Court ruled today by a 53 margin. But the Court again urged Congress to resolve the problem.

title: A Shift of Workers In Hospitals Union To City Nears End
description: The city Health and HospitalsCorporationsaid yesterday itwould complete plans this week to transfer 1,500 privatehospital workers to the city payrolls.

title: CURB IS SOUGHT ON BOND OFFERS
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt moved yesterday to make it more difficult for public authorities in New York to sell bonds without putting them up for competitive bidding.

title: Soviet Underground Urges Strikes to Raise Standards
description: MOSCOW, June 19  An underground appeal circulating in Moscow calls on Russians to strike and to demonstrate for better living conditions, as the Poles successfully did in 1970.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Heavy selling of newcrop soybeans sent futures prices down sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: A Review of Realty Trusts Is Confirmed by Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A spokesman for the Federal Reserve Board confirmed today that the issue of bank management of real estate investment trusts was one of very many under review by the board's staff in connection with interpretation of the Bank Holding Company Act, but added that the issue was not currently before the board.

title: MEMENTOS OF TRIP TO CHINA ON EXHIBIT
description: Mementos of President Nixon's trip to China, presented as a formal exhibition by the State Department, will be open to the public today through Sunday, at the East River Savings Bank.

title: Howard Johnson., 75, Founder Of the Restaurant Chain, Dead
description: Howard Johnson, who gave the country 28 flavors of ice cream and a chain of restaurants to buy them from, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospitall. He was 75 years old and lived at 812 Fifth Avenue, He also had homes in Wollaston, Mass., the company's headquarters, and in Miami Beach.

title: OVERSEER NAMED FOR U.N.W VOTING
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Department of Labor today named Ronald T. Weakley, a former trade union official employed by the department, to supervise the affairs of the United Mine Workers of America until the union holds courtordered election.

title: 2 Draw 20Year Sentences As Narcotics Conspirators
description: A chase through uptown streets Jan. 26 led yesterday to 20year prison sentences for two men. The defendants were convicted May 2 in Federal court and sentenced today.

title: Bridge: U.S. Loses, but Italians Keep Rolling in Olympiad
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 20With the qualifying stage of the World Team Olympiad drawing to a close here, teams representing Italy, the United States, Canada and Taiwan seemed well on the road today to the semifinal stage, which starts Thursday.

title: BROKER SEES NO NEED FOR TRADING FLOORS
description: The head of a leading brokerage house said yesterday that no need existed for stockexchange trading floors and that markups in securities prices might take the place of commissions paid by investors.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the last 13 years JeanLuc Godard has directed more than 25 movies and become the most celebrated, reviled, exasperating and influential filmmaker of his generation. He began with Breathless in 1959 as one of the new wave directors, a friend and colleague of Truffaut, Chabrol, Eric Rohmer and other young critics on the important French film magazine Cahiers du Cinema; but as the others careers waxed and waned, Godard steadily turned out one brilliant film after another. (His best, for me, remains My Life to Live, his fourth, made in 1962, but there are so many that one can argue about for hours.) After the French political crisis of May, 1968, Godard devoted himself to a series of increasingly abrasive, didactic filmed political tracts 4 is Chinoise. Though badly injured in a motorcycle accident last year, he has just released new film in Paris, starring Yves Montand and Jane Fonda, entitled (one hopes prophetically) Tout Va Bien.

title: Many in Quangtri Die in Daylong Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 21 (AP)North Vietnamese backed by tanks counterattacked South Vietnamese marines north of Hue yesterday, triggering dawntodust battle that left 268 men dead, military spokesman reported today.

title: Research Park Planned
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Government announced today that the site for the nation's first environmental research park, 200,000 acres of pine forests and swamplands, would be the area surrounding the hydrogen bomb materials production facility near Aiken, S. C. The site is designed to provide a protected outdoor laboratory where longterm projects can be set up to answer questions about man's impact on the natural environment, the Atomic Energy Coinmission said.

title: Iraq and Syria Get an OilBloc Loan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20Arabian oil countries decided today to lend Iraq and Syria $169million to help them meet foreign exchange shortages arising from the nationalization of the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company.

title: JOHN J. KENNEDY.
description: John J. Kennedy, who was publication manager of the old New York Mirror from 1924 to 1963, died yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived in. the Bronx.

title: Mrs. Bye, With 75, Leads By Stroke in Eastern Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., June 20 (UPI)Mrs. Alice Bye shot a threeoverpar 75 today to take the openinground lead in the 66th annual women's Eastern Golf Association amateur championship.

title: Crash in Spain Kills Woman
description: VERIN, Spain, June 20 (Reuters)A passenger train and a freight collided headon in a tunnel near this northwestern town today, killing a woman and injuring 17 other persons, one of them seriously, officials said.

title: VergariEaston
description: In Westchester County's 24th District, which takes in the central and southeastern sections of the county, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari was an easy victor in the Republican primary over Glenn H. Easton, a Port Chester businessman, and Andrew C. Risoli, a Mount Vernon lawyer.

title: Dressy, Festiveand Short
description: Beaches and tennis courts aside, it's been a poor year for leg watchers, what with women wearing pants all day and long skirts at night.

title: Famine Relief in Afghanistan Hindered by Inertia and Corruption
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 11 The old man rested his shovel and pulled a bulbous root from his pocket.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)Senator Philip A. Hart said today that collective action by PhiladelphiaBaltimoreWashington Stock Exchange members to remove institutional members might violate the antitrust laws. The Michigan Democrat, who is the chairman of the Senate antitrust subcommittee, said he had so advised Thomas W. L. Cameron, chairman of the exchange's board of governors, in a letter.

title: Personalities: Monroe in Surgery
description: Earl Monroe, obtained by the Knicks last November from the Baltimore Bullets but unable to match his past scoring skills because of bone spurs, underwent surgery at Roosevelt Hospital. Dr. Andrew H. Patterson, the team doctor, removed two spurs from his left foot. Monroe, who averaged 11.4 points last season, less than half his 23.7 career average, will remain in the hospital until Friday and then will wear a cast for 10 days... The Phoenix Suns apparently will send Paul Silas, the 6foot7inch forward, to the Celtics in payment for Boston's having given up its draft rights to Charlie Scott. Scott led the American Basketball Association in scoring last season before he jumped from the Squires to the Suns in the closing weeks. Phoenix and Virginia reached an outofcourt settlement last week on the Squires claim to the guard.

title: Executive Changes
description: William K. Eastham has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Johnson Wax Company, succeeding Samuel C. Johnson, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Raymond F. Farley has been elected executive vice presidentU.S. operations.

title: Disney on Parade Due
description: A new edition of the musical extravaganza Disney on Parade will be presented from Aug. 1 through Aug. 27 at Madison Square Garden. As in the previous two versions, the musical will use live performers in the guises of Donald Duck, Mickey Mouse and Winnie the Pooh in a variety of sketches and songs,

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD REALIGNS DIVISIONS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday the formation of three new toplevel organizational groups and the election of three senior vice presidents and six corporate vice presidents.

title: Cambodia Reports Attacks
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 20 (AP)The Cambodian command reported a series of enemy attacks today on the village of Taten, 15 miles southeast of Pnompenh. It said North Vietnamese troops overwhelmed the town on the east bank of the Bassac River and that burning houses were seen by reconnaissance planes.

title: Ballet: Blanchine Gem
description: Not all Stravinsky is equal, and not all Stravinsky ballets are memorable. This must be remembered when we assess the New York City Ballet's fecund and fantastic Stravinsky Festival at the New York State Theater. This flight to ballet history must of necessity have its ups and downs. Last night we collected a few downs.

title: FRANK MMASTER OF L.I. PRESS. DIES
description: Frank MacMaster, a retired reporter for The Long Island Press who spent half a century covering City. Hall, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 14940 Beech Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Pilots Strike: Possible Key Point in Hijacking Fight
description: I Monday will not go down in history as the day the airliners stopped. There were too many places where the shutdown called by the world pilots organization did not materialize, including most of this country and all of the Communist world except Yugoslavia. But it may prove a day to remember, nevertheless. It may mark a turning point, many knowledgeable observers believe, in the efforts of the international aviation community to gain control of the menace of ar piracy.

title: Advertising:
description: The Singer Company confirmed the rumors yesterday by announcing that it is switching most of its domestic consumer advertising from J. Walter Thompson to Grey Advertising. The company puts the billings at between $12million and $13million.

title: LAIRD WOULD KILL PACTS IF CONGRESS BARRED ARMS FUND
description: WASHINGTON. June 20Secretary of Defense Melvin R Laird said today that he would recommend the scrapping of the strategic arms limitation agreements if Congress failed to support the Administration's proposals to modernize the offensive strategic forces of the United States.

title: BrascoJacobs
description: In the twocounty 11th Congressional District, Frank J. Brasco, the Democratic incumbent seeking a fourth term, easily won over Gerald Jacobs, a 52yearold businessman and restaurateur. With moro. than half of the returns in, he led by almost a 3to1 margin.

title: ABRAMS IS NAMED AS CHIEF OF STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 President Nixon today named Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of United States forces in Vietnam, as the Army Chief of Staff.

title: Roundup: Lonborg and Scott Combine Pitching and Batting to Beat White Sox
Business Briefs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 (AP) Donald Rumsfeld, director of the Cost of Living Council, said today that dividends would increase less than 4 per cent this year in line with a voluntary ceiling set by the Nixon Administration.

title: Theater: Antony and Cleopatra, a Roman Candle
Perverting UNRWA
description: When a Times reporter tried to visit United Nationsfinanced camps for Palestinian refugees in Lebanon recently as a means of making contact with ordinary Palestinians, permission was denied by commando organizations which exercise de facto control over these camps. Later, when the correspondent did manage visit a camp under U.N. auspices, his movements were strictly confined to the school, clinic, soup kitchen and welfare center. The camp leader, whose office was decorated with commando posters, refused access the rest of the camp, although all of it was built With and depends upon U.N. funding.

title: NET REDEMPTIONS OF FUNDS PERSIST
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 Net redemptions of mutual fund shares continued in May, though at a somewhat lesser rate than in April,.the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: SMITH IS VICTOR TWICE IN TENNIS
description: LONDON, June 20  Stan Smith celebrated his top seeding for next week's Wimbledon tennis championships by winning two matches to reach the final 16 at the Rothman's London grass championships today. But the rest of the United States Davis Cup team, groggy after a 24hour trip from Mexico, was knocked out of the tournament.

title: State Bankers Tell of Unloading Bad Brooklyn Loans on F.H.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 Three bankers told a Senate subcommittee here today that they had rid themselves of delinquent conventional mortgages on deteriorating houses in Brooklyn by exchanging them for mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: DETROIT BANK HEAD OFFERS RESIGNATION
description: John E. Thompson, president of Detroit's troubled Bank of the Commonwealth, resigned yesterdaY effeetive, with the appointment of his successor, which is, expected in about 60 days.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Arguing Curt Flood's suit before the Supreme Court, former Justice Arthur J. Goldberg reviewed the long and seamy history of buckpassing between the Court and Congress, both of whom have stalled for half a century over baseball's privileged position with regard to antitrust law. Borrowing from Harry S Truman, he told the justices: The buck stops here,

title: HoltzmanCeller
description: In a race almost no one expected to be close, Representative Celler, the 84yearold dean of the House, was defeated in the unofficial. returns whose count was completed at 2:35 A.M. today. He had run neck and neck through the night with Miss Holtzman, a 30yearold lawyer who had campaigned on the theme that the elderly Congressman was out of touch with his constituents.

title: PodellSimon
description: Representative Bertram L. Podell's landslide victory over Assemblyman Leonard M. Simon leaves Mr. Simon on the November ballot as the Liberal party's nominee, but only halfheartedly.

title: French Clamp Secrecy on Nuclear Tests
description: PARIS, June 20 (Reuters)Extreme secrecy today surrounded the start of the latest series of French nuclear tests in the Pacific as protests grew in countries bordering the blast area.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 20Senator Margaret Chase Smith, having crushed the first effort in 18 years to deny her the Republican party nomination, is preparing to face a major Democratic effort to defeat her in November.

title: Stravinsky Fete: A Jggling Act, Too
description: The New York City Ballet's Stravinsky festival this week is something no other company could do, in the naturally biased opinion of George Balanchine, the company's artistic mentor.

title: Allison Retiring as Coach
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 20 (UPI) Wilmer Allison, former national champion, said today he would retire Sept. 1 as tennis coach at the University of Texas. He has been coach for 15 years. His teams won four Southwest Conference titles.

title: F.D.A. Would Put Amount of Seafood On Cocktail Labels
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 The Food and Drug Administration, initiating a new food labeling program, moved today to require disclosure of the percentage of seafood in seafood cocktails.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 20 (UPI)Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., and Australia's Evonne Goolagong have been topseeded for the Wimbledon lawn tennis championships, which begin Monday.

title: MRS. TRACY UPSET IN WOMEN'S GOLF
Treasure Diver Finds Buyers Market Here
description: Rex Cowan, a British lawyer who tired of his trade and now dives for sunken treasure, saved some of his best pieces of eight to exchange for American money. Yesterday he saw a couple of the ancient coins auctioned for $1,200 each at Sotheby, ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: Noryema, British Sloop, Is Victor in NewporttoBermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20A British yacht won the Bermuda ocean race today. But the owner, because of the. press of his construction business in the United Kingdom, failed to make the passage, which in the world of yachting would be equivalent of failing to attend one's birth.

title: Mercer Rides Ascot Winner, Then Collapses After Race
description: ASCOT, England, June 20 (AP)Brigadier Gerard, the 12 favorite, won the $20,000 Prince of Wales Stakes today in record time under Joe Mercer, who collapsed after the race at Royal Ascot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In attempting to portray George McGovern as a reasonable alternative to Richard Nixon as President, James Reston [column June 7] was very careless in his choice of words. He speaks of President Nixon as extending the Lyndon Johnson years of political expediency"a very difficult charge to substantiate in view of Mr. Nixon's international achievements and domestic proposals.

title: U.S. and Soviet Optimistic as Disarmament Conference Resumes in Geneva
description: GENEVA, June 20  The United States and the Soviet Union said today that the agreements concluded at the May summit meeting in Moscow to limit strategic nuclear missiles should spur the conclusion of other arms accords.

title: Reserve Reports Increase For ShortTerm Interest
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve reported today that shortterm interest rates on noninstallment loans of $10,000 to $25,000 increased slightly in May.

title: At Royal Ascot: Tradition, Hats and All
description: ASCOT, England, June 20 The wind tugged at widebrimmed hats, the Queen wore green, the wellheeled and the highborn looked the part, the gulls eggs arrived on time and the prime social event of the sporting season was under way.

title: Bruns, Nordeman Sues I.T.T. on Data System
description: Bruns, Nordeman & Co., brokers, filed a $15million lawsuit here yesterday against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, alleging breach of contract because of an allegedly defective computer data transmission system.

title: Market Place:
description: Some years back Wall Street was In love with the conglomerator, the man who said he could put together a number of pieces of a jigsaw puzzle and make the whole equal more than the sum of its parts.

title: HOUSE UNIT PUTS OFF TAX REFORM HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)Proponents of the immediate closing of some tax loopholes lost another round in the House today as the Ways and Means Committee promised full reform hearings early next year.

title: Sinatra, Sought by Panel, Is Reported in Monte Carlo
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 20 (UPI)Frank Sinatra, sought for questioning by House of Representatives select committee on crime, is registered in a hotel here, a notel official said today.

title: Aerial Hijacking Scored By U.N. Security Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20The Security Council today in a strongly worded consensus agreement condemned aerial hijacking and called upon all states to take all appropriate measures within their jurisdiction to deter and prevent such acts and to take effective measures to deal with those who commit such acts.

title: Rye Digs Out After Heavy Rains
description: RYE, N. Y., June 20They went fishing for boats in the marina here today.

title: Service Is Normal
description: Airline service returned to normal yesterday after a 24hour international pilots protest strike that crippled air travel in western Europe, Latin America, and much of the rest of the world, but had only limited impact in the United States.

title: AMOS TOP NETS AND GO INTO LEAD
description: HOUSTON, June 20Normally, Yogi Berra makes out the Mets lineup several hours before the game, even before the players arrive at the park. Tonight, though, the befuddled Berra had to wait until about an hour before game time before completing the lineup.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The United States Auto Club's Championship Trail returns this weekend to this area with qualifying on Saturday and Sunday for the Schaefer 500 at Pocono ternational Raceway in Pennsylvania. The obvious man to beat is Bobby Unser, who has won two of the four races thus farPhoenix and Milwaukeeand who has started from the pole in all four events. For the Indiananp olis 500 Bobby qualified his Olsonite EagleOffenhauser at 195.940 miles an hour to break the previous record by 17.244 m.p.h.

title: 165 Persons Still Missing After Hong Kong Mudslide
description: HONG KONG, June 20 (AP) Authorities said 87 bodies had been found but 105 persons were still missing today after four days of record downpours, mudslides and building collapses in this British colony.

title: Players Charge N. F. L. Owners Refuse to Bargain on 2 Issues
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 (AP) Edward R. Garvey, director of the National Football League Players Association charged today that the N.F.L. Management Council had violated its contract with the players by refusing to bargain on the issues of synthetic turf and players fines.

title: NIXON PENSION BILL HAILED BY HODGSON
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson urged today Congressional approval of a bill that would guarantee a worker's retierment benefits when the combination of his age and years of employment equaled 50.

title: Lufthansa Lists Loss for 71
description: BONN, June 20 (AP)  Lufthansa, the West German national airline, showed a loss last year for the first time since 1963, the carrier's annual report showed today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)The Senate Banking Committee said today the Treasury should make available for inspection its records on the controversial $250million Governmentguaranteed loan to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. Congress approved the guarantees last year so Lockheed could continue work on the L,1011 Tristar commercial jet plane. After private financial institutions refused to extend Lockheed any more credit, it had said it would go bankrupt without a Governmentguaranteed loan.

title: A Cosmic Particle With Peak Energy Detected by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 20The Soviet Union disclosed today that a cosmicray satelite orbiting the earth last April recorded a particle from the deep recess of space with the highest energy yet detected in the vicinity of the earth.

title: Nixon Plans Statement Before July 1 on Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, June 20President Nixon will make a new announcement before July 1 concerning the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam, the White House said today.

title: Jobless Rate Dipped To 6.1% for May, Lowest in 5 Months
description: The unemployment rate in the state for May dropped from 6.3 per cent to 6.1 per cent, the lowest in the first five months of this year, but well above the average rate for the last seven years. Total unemployment in the state for May was 505,000, the State Labor Department announced yesterday.

title: British Use Electronic Gear to Fight I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 14  This sniffer is better than any dog God ever made, said the lance corporal, but it's hell for weight.

title: Gastronomic Tourist Has New Place to Go
