description: A record increase of 54.8 cents in the city's basic property tax rate was approved yesterday by the City Council after an attempt at tax revolt that proved to be little more than a pro forma skirmish.

title: Muncey Denied Hydro Speed Record
description: DETROIT, June 22When is a world record not a world record? When it is a historic performance, according to officials of the American Power Boat Association, who disputed today Bill Muncey's fastestever speed in an unlimited hydroplane during a qualification run yesterday for Sunday's Gold Cup rage.

title: Just Who Is Crazy?
description: PRINCETON, N. J."The whole world is crazy! exclaims my 87yearold greatgrandmother whenever my brother and I talk with her. That line always makes its way into any conversation with her; it is her view of the world and her explanation of its ills.

title: ASTROS TOP REDS, REGAIN LEAD, 95
description: CINCINNATI, June 22 (AP)Cesar Cedeno cracked lour straight hits, including a homer, and Doug Rader keyed a sixrun third inning with a threerun homer tonight as the Houston Astros whipped Cincinnati, 95, and regained first place in the National League Western Division from the Reds.

title: Harassment In Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 22 (Agence FrancePresse) Communist forces have stepped up artillery harassment of nearly all Government positions along Route 1, leading from Pnompenh to Saigon, the militaryspokesman said today.

title: 2 Artistic Visions Join in Pulcinella
description: Choreography is usually the expression of one man's artistic vision. But Pulcinella, a ballet that bows tonight as part of the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival, will have the benefit of two visions, those of George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

title: Rayon Staple to Be Raised
description: The American Viscose division of the FMC Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase prices on rayon staple and tow beginning Sept. 1. The price of rayon staple will be raised from 31 cents a pound to 32, while rayon tow will be moved up by 1.5 cents, to 43.5 cents a pound. In addition, the price of solution dyed staple will go up by one cent a pound.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 22 (Reuters)A mediumpace bowler, Bob Massie, made a memorable test debut for Australia today at Lord's when he broke the back of England's batting on the opening day of the second cricket test.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Dr. Leonard A. Maynard Dead; Led Cornell School of Nutrition
description: ITHACA, N. Y., June 22Dr. Leonard A. Maynard, emeritus professor of biochemistry and nutrition at Cornell University, died last evening at the Tompkins County Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: After 23Year Effort, a Dakota Town Plugs In and Gets Telephone Service
description: SQUAW GAP, ND.There's a strange clicking sound in Squaw Gap these days, coming from within the new, pink cementblock building over by the crumbling community hall. Every so often a workman visits the windowless structure, but the clicking continues. And that's just fine with everyone here. For that sound, about the only unnatural one heard for scores of miles in this rugged, rolling corner of North Dakota, symbolizes the end of isolation for the few people of Squaw Gap and the beginning of a new way of life.

title: Amex Accepts Listing Of Plc n Pay Common
description: Pic n Pay, Inc., a shoe store chain, announced yesterday that approval for the listing of its common stock on the American Stock Exchange had been given by the exchange's board of governors.

title: Electoral Muddle
description: To vote at all in last Tuesday's primaries in this city reflected a triumph of citizen determination over official bungling and pettifoggery. The ballots were unnecessarily confusing. Machines jammed. Polling places were hard to find. Once found, they were often inadequately staffed. Voters at some of the worst precincts had to wait in line until midnight to register their preferences.

title: DR. JOHN MOORE, 54, AMHERST CLASSICIST
description: AMHERST, Mass. June 22Dr. John A. Moore, chairman of the department of classics at Amherst College, was found dead of a cerebral hemorrhage today in his home, 227 South Pleasant Street. His age was 54.

title: Brazil Bus Plunge Kills 20
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, June 22 (Reuters)Twenty persons were reported killed and many injured when a bus plunged off a viaduct near here today, Radio reports, quoting a highway patrol spokesman, said the bus fell on to high tension wires over a railway track.

title: Villanova Names Rosenberg
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., June 22 (AP)John Rosenberg, a former Penn State assistant, was named defensive coordinator today for head football coach Lou Ferry at Villanova University.

title: Notes on People
description: The newest White Lion, First Class, is Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, who received the Czechoslovak Government honor in Prague, where he continued his tour of Eastern Europe. The honor was given by Gustav Husak, Communist party leader, instead of President Ludvik Svoboda, who was said to be slightly ilL

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last week at an estimated 15.9 billion tonmiles, 3.5 per cent above the corresponding week last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., said intercity truck tonnage last week was 4.8 per cent above last year.

title: Cypriot Ambassador and Wife Are Held Up in Central Park
description: Zenon G. Rossides, Cyprus's delegate to the United Nations and chairman of the United Nations committee that deals with the safety of diplomats here, was mugged and robbed as he strolled in Central Park early Wednesday evening, the police reported yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: An Alien Creature
description: WASHINGTONOnce again the Administration has come before the Congress with a requestthis year for almost threefourths of a million dollarsand the plea that the moribund Subversive Activities Control Board be allowed to survive yet another year. Again there is a flurry of activity before June 30 to distract the Congress from the board's 22year history of inactivity, at a price thus far of almost $7 million.

title: AntiAbortion Bill Voted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. June 22 (AP)The House voted today 157 to 34, in favor of a bill outlawing abortions except where there was reasonable medical certainty that the woman would die without the operation.

title: Thousands Attend Rites For 9 Boston Firemen
description: BOSTON, June 22 (AP)As thousands of firefighters from throughout the country lined the rainslicked streets outside, Archbishop Humberto S. Medeiros of Boston celebrated a funeral mass today at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross for nine firemen killed. last Saturday in the Hotel Vendome fire.

title: Senate, 821, Votes To Fund Public TV For 2 More Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The Senate passed today and sent to the White House legislation that would guarantee Federal financing of noncommercial radio and television for two more years.

title: World Body Formed By Union Leaders In Rubber Plants
description: GENEVA, June 22  Trade union leaders who assert they represent about 90 per cent of the nearly 200,000 workers employed around the world by the giant DunlopPirelli rubber combine said here today they would demand a hearing by the group's top international management.

title: N.L.R.B. Aide Refuses to Hear Testimony of Vikings'
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 22 (AP)  National Labor Relations Board examiner Melvin Welles refused to hear testimony today from the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings during the hearing on a complaint filed against the National Football League owners.

title: Martha Mitchell Would Like Her Husband to Quit Politics
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) Martha Mitchell said tonight that she had given her husband an ultimatum to get out of politics or she would leave him.

title: Securities Legislation Is Seen Advancing
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, predicted here today that his Senate banking subcommittee would report favorably next Tuesday to the full Banking Committee legislation dealing with operational problems of the securities industry.

title: Oppose Majority Ruling on Ground It Is Move for Racial Balance
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The longstanding unanimity of the Supreme Court on the Issue of school desegregation ended today as President Nixon's four nominees dissented against what they characterized as an effort to require racial balance rather than desegregation.

title: Miss Amy Fabrikant Married to Rene Rofe
description: Miss Amy Fabrikant was married last evening to Rene Rofe by Rabbis Sion Maslaton and Hanania Elbaz at the Utopia Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: Alice Ann Rosenfeld Bride of C. D. Uniman
description: MILLBURN, N. J., June 22 Miss Alice Ann Rosenfeld and Charles David Uniman were married here this evening at the Chanticler by Rabbi Harvey Fields.

title: Restaurant That's Satisfying and Disappointing
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Advertising:
description: A fellow came in to Ralph P. Davidson's office the other morning and dropped a copy of the June 26 Time on his desk. He'll be saving it a long timeyou can bet on that. It's the first to carry the signature of Ralph P. Davidson on A Letter From the Publisher.

title: Manuguerra in Rigoletto
description: Matteo Manuguerra, a Tunisianborn baritone, sang the title role of Rigoletto at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, replacing Sherrill Milnes, and received warm applause for his solo arias. Mr. Manuguerra stepped into the role Monday night when Mr. Milnes became ill during the performance. Appearing in the cast with Mr. Manuguerra were Joan Sutherland and Luociano Pavarotti.

title: HOUSE APPROVES REVENUE SHARING IN 274122 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The House of Representatives passed a revenuesharing bill today by a vote of 274 to 122.

title: U.S. Gunship Downed; 12 Men Are Missing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, June 24 (AP) North Vietnamese troops shot down one of the United States largest computerized gunships on South Vietnam's northern front last Sunday night and 12 crewmen are missing, the American com mand announced today. Three crewmen were rescued.

title: Pound Off to $2.53 in Trading Here
description: The pound's value dropped sharply yesterday in the for eignexchange market in New York in what was described as wild, very erratic, thin trad ing.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Yul Brynner, who made the bald pate fashionable may today be setting another fashion by wearing the gold necklaces designed by his cousin, Irena Brynner, whose work is on exhibition through June 30 at the Lee Nordness Gallery on the Upper East Side.

title: Schaefer Concert Reslated
description: The Schaefer Music Festival concert, canceled last night by rain, will be held tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. The performers are Seatrain, Loggins & Messina, Chi Coltraine. Tonight's concert by Benny Goodman at the Waterloo Village Music Festival in Stanhope, N. J., has been canceled because of rain. No new date has been set.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I. T. T. Taking First Step For Canteen Divestiture
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday took the first step in divesting itself of the Can teen Corporation, as required by an antitrust settlement that allowed the conglomerate to keep the Hartford Fire Insur ance Company.

title: Hydroplane Racing: Ego Trip That Appeases Male Vanity
description: DETROIT, June 23Illustrating the im minent danger drivers face when their tender craft take on quixotic waters, the unlimited hydroplane Miss Madison was torn apart today and sank in the Detroit River. Charlie Dunn, her rookie driver, es caped serious injury in his unsuccessful attempt to qualify for Sunday's Gold Cup. The Gold Cup is the race of races for one of the world's most dangerous sports. Ironically, Dunn was the only racer who tempted the froth, whipped up yesterday by 20knot winds.

title: TOURISTS IN LONDON FIND VARYING RATES
description: LONDON, June 23 (AP) American tourists in London were able to change their dol lar travelers checks freely to day but rates varied widely.

title: S. Howard Young, Art Dealer, Friend of Eisenhower, Is Dead
description: S. Howard Young, one of the world's wealthiest art dealers, died yesterday in his galleries in the Pierre Hotel after a brief illness. He was 94 years old on May 22.

title: BANKERS FILE SUIT ON SECRECY RULING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP)The California Bankers Association, representing all major banks in the state, has filed suit, asserting that new parts of the Bank Secrecy Act are unconstitutional because they allow the Government to pry into anyone's private bank account.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 23A Federal District judge refused late tonight to order the seat ing of Florida delegates on Democratic National Conven tion committees.

title: Security Council Meets
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23Israel criticized the United Nations as ineffectivetonight at an emergency meet ing of the Security Council.

title: Little New Flooding Is Reported in Metropolitan Area
description: While remnants of Hurricane Agnes were visiting a fury of destruction yesterday on some parts of the East, the metro politan region contended with relatively minor flooding dur ing the 1th day of rain in the last 12.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Police Academy graduated two new groups of specialists yesterday14 policewomen who will for the first time be assigned to neighborhood police teams, and 30 policemen who will serve as moderators in a recently instituted workshop program in ethical awareness.

title: KISSINGER RETURNS FROM CHINA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on national se curity affairs, returned to Washington this afternoon aft er four days of talks in Peking with Premier Chou Enlai and other Chinese officials.

title: Avis and MCI Stocks Gain In Active NewIssue Week
description: Eighteen new issues com menced public trading this week, a larger number of such entries than in the last two weeks, with several of the more familiar newcomers advancing above their issue prices by the close of trading yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DENVER, June 23 (AP)Alvin Jackson, a 17yearold from Classical High School in Providence, R.I., set a na tional high school hammer throw record of 191 feet 11 inches tonight in the National Junior track and field championships.

title: Celanese Corp. to Lay Off 1,300
description: The Celanese Corporation, a diversified producer of syn thetic fibers chemicals and plastics, announcea yesterday that it was terminating the employment of about 1,300, mostly whitecolor workers.

title: Westinghouse Is Accused On Purchasing Practices
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Justice Department ac cused the Westinghouse Elec tric Corporation today of hav ing used illegal purchasing ar rangements with customers and suppliers. Walker B. Comegys, acting assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, said the proposed judgment would be in effect for 10 years. He said it would prohibit Westinghouse from the follow ing:

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 23 (UPI)Claude Lelouch, a French film director, appealed to international shipping today to keep alert for any radio messages from his yacht Ven dredi 13, the largest yacht in the singlehanded trans Atlantic race. JeanYves Terlain, the skipper of the 128 foot Vendredi 13, has not been heard from since midday Sunday. He is supposed to radio her position twice a day.

title: HIJACKED PLANE RAMMED BY AUTO
description: ST. LOUIS, Saturday, June 24An unidentified man, in an apparent attempt to thwart the departure early this morn ing of a hijacked American Airlines jet, drove his car through two steel fences near the airport terminal here, out onto the runway, and smashed headon into the Boeing 727 as it was about to take off.

title: Lynch Asks Britain to Help Achieve a United Ireland
description: John M. Lynch, Prime Minis ter of Ireland, has proposed a union of the Republic of Ire land and Northern Ireland, by agreement with Britain, as the, only solution for the island's division and strife.

title: OCONEE VICTOR IN TWO CLASSES
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 23 Christine Platten, a Bennett College freshman rode Oconee to victory in two classes and took a place ribbon in another today to move into a command ing lead for the Division A ama teurowned working hunter championship at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

title: METS RAINED OUT; PLAY 2 TOMORROW
description: Faced with an advance ticket sale of 35,000 and reschedul ing problems, the Mets tried to play last night's game with St. Louis, but the rain came out ahead.

title: 3 JUDGES TO SCORE ALI, FOSTER FIGHTS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 23 The referee will not do any scoring in either the Muham mad AllJerry Quarry fight or the world lightheavyweight ti tle bout between Bob Foster, the champion, and Mike Quarry at the Convention Center Tues day night.

title: Umbrella Sales Increase as Rains Persist
description: Retailers who are prone to gripe about the adverse effect on their business of pro longed rainy spells are happy this week about at least one department. More umbrellas have been sold in New York stores since last Monday's few drops turned into a near torrent than in any compa rable week this year.

title: Oak Ridge Pact Approved
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 23 A new threeyear contract for 4,250 union workers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the Y12 plant was ap proved last night. The vote was 2,482 to 691. Under the new contract, hourly wage scales of laborers were raised from $3.29 to $3.49, operators from $4.27 to $4.53 and skilled craftsmen from $4.62 to $4.90.

title: MISS BAUGH TOPS TWO FOES IN GOLF
description: HUNSTANTON, England June 23 (AP)Laura Baugh of Long Beach, Calif., was the only American advancing to the semifinals of the British women's amateur golf cham pionship today. Three other Americans were beaten in the quarterfinal round.

title: Pope Says EastWest Contacts Are Spurring Hopes for Peace
description: ROME, June 23Pope Paul VI said in an address to the College of Cardinals today that President Nixon's talks in Pe king and Moscow and other EastWest contacts had en couraged hope for peace in the Middle East and Vietnam.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Platform Committee of the Democratic National Conven tion began today to draft the party's stand on issues, with all signs indicliting that its docu ment will reflect the liberal views of Senator George Mc Govern of South Dakota.

title: Echlin Manufacturing Increases Earnings by 29.2% for Quarter
description: The Echlin Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of re placement parts for motor driven vehicles and engines, achieved a 27 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 38 per cent in the nine months ended May 31, the report dis closed yesterday. For the third fiscal quarter the increases were 29.2 and 25.5, re spectively.

title: The Talk of Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 19  This city, whose recent political alignment with the East rather than the West is apparent in the scarcity of cars of more recent date than the late nineteenfifties, is jammed with the newest American and West German models these days. They belong to the oil barons of Saudi Arabia, Iraq and the Persian Gulf sheikdoms, who are overnighting on their way to the moun tains of Lebanon. There they summer in coolness, either in their palatial houses or in the many hotels that have sprung up in the last two decades.

title: Mexico's Example
description: Mexico's recent decision to launch a major national family planning program represents a policy switch that could have significant repercussions throughout Latin America. It offers a timely boost to the expanding population efforts of the United Nations, to which the Mexicans are expected to turn for supplementary assistance.

title: At Their Farm Home, A Haven for Children
description: WALDEN, N. Y.One might think that Clement Bar tolemy would have had enough of other people's children by this time of year. But no. After winding up the academic years as director of athletics at the Lycee Fran cais in New York, he and his wife, who have a son and two daughters of their own, are taking in boys and girls from 6 to 12 years of age at their farm.

title: Arab Boat Reported Sunk
description: TEL AVIV, Saturday, June 24 (Reuters)An Israeli Navy force patrolling near Tyre in Lebanon last night encountered an armed boat manned by Arab guerrillas and sank it, a military spokes man announced here today.

title: Civil Service Aide Sworn In
description: Mayor Lindsay swore in David Stadtmauer yesterday as a $31,000ayear member of the New York City Civil Service Commission. Mr. Stadtmauer, a lawyer, succeeds Frank C. Ar ricale 2d, who resigned. He will serve for six years.

title: Issues Raised by Primary System
description: News Analysis

title: Merger News
description: The City Investing Company, which owns approximately 55 per cent of Guerdon Industries, Inc., a large mobilehome manu facturer, announced yesterday it intends to acquire the rest of Guerdon's outstanding common shares through merger.

title: WESTINGHOUSE TIES ILLEGAL, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Justice Department ac cused the Westinghouse Elec tric Corporation today of using illegal purchasing arrange ments with customers and sup pliers.

title: Detroit Utility Company Defends Record on Blacks
description: DETROIT, Juno 23 (AP) Responding to Federal charges of discrimination against blacks, the Detroit Edison Company said today that it had aggressively been seeking black employes and had a number in skilled or semiskilled positions.

title: Thursday Night Fight
description: Los AngelesTuri Pineda, 130 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Speedy Naldo. 127, the Philip pines, 2 rounds.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Three prominent black mem bers of Congress will deliver a possibly decisive bloc of black delegate votes to Senator, George McGovern on Monday.

title: Five States Named Disaster Areas
description: Tropical storm Agnes widened its destruction yesterday as cresting rivers spilled over their banks, broke through dikes and inundated cities from upstate New York to southern Virginia in what was termed the worst flooding in the history of the United States.

title: Juries in Jeopardy
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y.The recent acquittals of Angela Davis and the remaining Soledad Brothers in Cali fornia, along with the hung juries in the Berrigan & Company, Bobby Seale, Huey Newton and Harlem Four cases, have focused public attention on the jury system. For many the inability of the prosecutors to convince any or even mostof their respective panels that the defendants were guilty of the crimes with which they were charged has been regarded as a stun ning vindication of our legal system. For others, including myself, these re sults only indicate that just verdicts are, under certain conditions, obtain able, but in all of the cited cases, as Ms. Davis has already put it, the only fair trial would have been no trial at all.

title: Sports Control Bill Gets Varied Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The commissioners of three major professional sports expressed opposition today to a proposed Federal Sports Commission, and so did Senator Sam J. Ervin, Democrat of North Carolina from a different point of view.

title: Meteorologists Explain Growth of Storm
description: Weather forecasters knew there was a chance of rain storm problems for the East ern Seaboard when they no ticed a tropical disturbance de veloping a week ago yesterday off Cozumel Island, between Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and Cuba.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 23 (Reuters)Bob Massie, who took a record eight wickets for 84 runs, and Greg Chappell helped Australia grasp the initiative from England today in the second cricket test at Lord's.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The trouble with baseball, the theorists say, is that the players don't have any fun any more. They read The Wall Street Journal instead of The Sporting News. They worry about their pension instead of their curveball. They'd rather have a union meeting than extra batting practice. Maybe so in some cases, but Scipio Spinks provides hope. For baseball, and maybe for us all. Because this lean 24yearold righthanded pitcher with a hard fastball and a soft manner has succeeded in putting on his little cornerof the world. Joe's here, he said in his Essex House hotel room. He's been wait ing for you.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL EXPLAINS ITS POSITION ON POOR
description: Officials of Beth Israel Medi cal Center said yesterday that it had been forced to refuse clinic service to poor people not covered by Medicare to avoid being plunged into debt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: The American Cyanamid Company will construct new manufacturing facilities at a cost of more than $20million at its organic chemicals division complex in Bound Brook, N. J. The new units will produce Beta naphthol, powdered Schaeffer's salt and powdered Rsalt, materials widely used by the dye, pigment and rubber industries.

title: Zen, Universal Style
description: OLD WESTBURY, N. Y.  On this page there recently appeared a piece entitled Zen, American Style. Its derisive and critical tone and the ac companying caricature of a Zen mas ter with a Frankenstein face over whom there hovered an imaginary zoomorphic creature, seemed to me to call for some more balanced presenta tion of an ancient and honorable way of life, currently of interest to many intelligent Americans.

title: News Analysis
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 23Quick, how much is two plus two?

title: Nastase Walks Off Court With Foe at Match Point
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 23 (AP)  Die Nastase of Ru mania smilingly walked off the court today when within one point of defeat by Andres Gimono.

title: Film: In 'Ben,' a Boy Befriends a Rat
description: In Phil Karlson's "Ben," the rats that were supposed to be so terrifying in last year's immensely popular, exceedingly dumb horror film, "Willard," come very close to shutting down all of Los Angeles with the connivance of a lonely little boy with heart trouble.Danny Garrison is old before his time (which I'd estimate to be about 10), coddled by his mother and sister, and constantly aware of the possibility of death. Apparently because he feels himself a misfit, Danny befriends Ben, the leader of the pack of rats trained by the late Willard (who was murdered, none too soon, at the end of the first film).Danny seems to reason that fate has given them both raw deals, equating his own infirmity with Ben's rotten luck to have been born a rat.After Ben and his friends have been out ravaging the city, chewing up citizens for food and sport, running amok among the Cheerios in The Best of Everything supermarket, Ben can always return to Danny for the affection denied him elsewhere. Rats, says "Ben," need love.The way in which you respond to "Ben" will depend on a number of variables, including how you feel about the possibility of Los Angeles shutting down, trick photography, dreadful acting by a dreadful cast, the decline and fall of Phil Karlson ("The Phenix City Story") as a director and a screenplay that never has the courage to acknowledge its comic impulses.At least, I assume that there's a comic impulse at work somewhere when Danny sits down at the piano and, while idly tickling the ivories, composes a song for his friend."Ben . . ." sings Danny, looking off into the creative artist's middle distance, "The two of us need look no more/Ben/We've both found what we've been looking for. . . ."It doesn't scan too well, but "Ben" idiotically aspires to a certain realism. A 10-year-old, smart-mouth kid, who has a bad ticker and intimations of his mortality, isn't likely to compose "Rhapsody in Blue."

title: Incentive Pay Eliminated
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 23 (AP)  By a 72vote margin, production workers at the Gen eral Electric Company plant here accepted yesterday a planeliminating incentive pay rates. Directly affected by the vote are 2,300 workers who will transfer to straight hourly pay, costing them an average of $25 a week over a 61week period.

title: MAYE KICKED MAN, WITNESS TESTIFIES
description: A city official testified yes terday in Manhattan Criminal Court that he saw Michael Maye, president of the Uni formed Firefighters Association, stomp a member of the Gay Activists Alliance when the homosexual group demonstrat ed at the New York Hilton Hotel in April.

title: Charles P. Coleman Jr. Marries Miss Conway
description: In St. Vincent Ferrer Church here this afternoon, Miss Catharine Laming Con way, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Conway of New York and Palm Beach, Fla, and the late Dr. Conway, was married to Charles Payson Coleman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Payson Coleman of Lawrence, L. I., and Winhall, Vt. TheRev. Eugene F. O'Neill, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony.

title: Notes on People
description: Andrei A. Voznesensky, one of the Soviet Union's most talented poets, received a cer tificate of honorary member ship in the American Acad emy of Arts and Letters. At a ceremony in Moscow, the presentation was attended by the American Ambassador, Jacob D. Beam, and the poets Bella Akhamadulina and Mikhail Lukonin. Mr. Voznesensky recently com pleted a tour of the United States.

title: MOST REV. JAN SMIT.
description: ROME, June 23The Most Rev. Jan Smit, dean of the Vatican's Chapter of Canons, died here this morning. He was 89 years old and would have celebrated his 50th anniversary as a bishop next Thursday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jet Collision Kills Navy Flier
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 23 (AP)Two Navy jets on separate missions collided over the Atlantic Ocean off St. Au gustine, Fla., today and one pilot was killed, the Navy re ported. The other pilot flew his damaged A4 Skyhawk over Cecil Field Naval Air Station here, ejected himself and was picked up, apparently unin jured. The names of both pilots were withheld pending notifi cation of relatives.

title: Green Money or Green Earth?
description: GEORGETOWN, Conn.A contest is clearly gathering between the parti sans of the gross national product and of the quality of life; between the money men and the green earth men.

title: Pound Has Fluctuated Widely in Last Year
description: LONDON, June 23 (AP) The pound sterling has had a number of fluctuations over the last year.

title: Sally Dayton Wed to Cleric
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 23 Miss Sally Bradley Dayton and the Rev. Stephen Merreli Clement 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clement 2d of Buffalo and East Aurora, N. Y., were married here this afternoon, The bride's grandfather, the Rev. Dr. Arnold Hilmar Lowe, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Westmin ster Presbyterian Church.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 23 (UPI)Qualifying sessions for the Schaefer 500, the second leg of the United States Auto Club's triple crown series, have been post poned because of severe flooding in the area.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Weddings

title: Market Place: Merging Stocks With Insurance
description: Investors have all heard about the idea of merging the life insurance concept with stock purchases, and in dustry observers say that this is inevitable, althotigh United States laws do not permit it at present.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Rise at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose sharply in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Pennsylvania Toll
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 23 Rampaging flood waters left 31 persons dead in Pennsyl vania today and caused prop erty damage estimated at $1billion.

title: Text of Barber's Speech
description: LONDON, June 23Fol lowing is the text of a state ment delivered today in the House of Commons by An thony Barber, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on the float ing of the pound.

title: COMPROMISE BILL REACHED ON RAILS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Senate Commerce Commit tee today reported out by voice vote a compromise bill, break ing a long impass on how to correct the serious national freightcar shortage. The bill now goes to floor, where ap proval is expected by midsum mer. Similar legislation remains in subcommittee in the House where the outlook for action is unclear.

title: Judge Orders Nets' Barry to Honor 5Year Warriors' Pact He Signed in 1969
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP)A Federal judge ruled valid today Rick Barry's con tract with the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association.

title: Court Aide Slain in Bronx
description: An assistant Bronx Criminal Court clerk was fatally shot Thursday afternoon, apparently by two gunmen who followed him from a bank, the police said. Detectives said the man, Arthur Lundstrom, 51 years old, of 1139 Simpson Street, the Bronx, was shot in the head and chest about 3 P.M. in front of the building where he lived with his mother.

title: A Tribute to Shawn at Jacob's
description: LEE, Mass., Juno 23  A highly unusual program of 19 Denishawn dances per formed by some highly un usual people, who included the outstanding modern dancer Carolyn Brown; her mother, Marion Rice; Barton Mumaw and an impressive contingent of the Rice fam ily, opened the 40th season of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Reserves Up in May; Devaluation Is Reflected
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  United States international monetary reserves reflecting the technical effect of devaluation of the dollar, rose by $1,060, 000,000 in May, the Treasury reported today.

title: Music: Experimenting With Cymbals
description: The outer ear is easily tickled, the inner one decid edly harder to reach. And yet the idea that discovering a new sound will lead some how to a new music con tinues to haunt the psyches of many composers.

title: Personalities: Snead Breaks Par
description: Slamming Sammy Snead, who some devotees of the divot jokingly maintain has been birddogging the small, white ball since the turn of the century, came up with a complaint the other day that was more familiar to duffers than to top tournament golf ers.

title: GRADUATES FIND MORE JOBS OPEN
description: For the first time in three years, job openings for college graduates increased this year, the College Placement Council reported today after a major survey.

title: TitoGierek Talks End With 2 Pacts and Policy Differences
description: WARSAW, June 23Presi dent Tito of Yugoslavia ended a fourday visit today, closer economically to Poland but ap parently just as distant politi cally.

title: Shahid Minto Marries Miss Sabhia Jalal Here
description: Miss Sabhia Jalal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamid Jalal, was married here yesterday afternoon to Shahid Minto at the home of her parents. Dr. Soliman Dania, director of the Islamic Center of New York, performed the cere mony. The bridegroom is the son, of Mr. and Mrs. Mahmood Ahmed Minto of Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

title: L. I. Expressway Nears End of 32Year Construction
description: Before the July 4 weekend sends tens of thousands of cars toward Long Island's beaches, what began as a dream in the mind of Robert Moses and has since become perhaps the most congested and most maligned roadway in the worldthe Long Is land Expresswaywill be finished.

title: Tokyo Market to Close
description: TOKYO, Saturday, June 24 The Finance Ministry an nounced that the Tokyo foreign exchange market would be closed today and Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstate Hit Hard
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., June 23 Three days of furious rain sent rivers in western New York over their banks today, flood ing several cities and causing at least two deaths.

title: S.E.C. Levitz Hearing Is Postponed to July 5
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission postponed yester day for the second time a hear ing into charges brought against the Levitz Furniture Corpora tion. The hearing had been scheduled for Monday but will be held instead on July 5. It had originally been set for June 12.

title: French Unions Demonstrate
description: PARIS, June 23 (Reuters) About 30,000 people marched through Paris today and work ers throughout the country staged token strike's to support demands for a higher minimum wage, a lower retirement age and trade union unity.

title: SCHOLARLY BOOKS FACE NEW PERILS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 23 The opening session of this year's Association of American University Presses meeting to day heard a pointed warning that costconscious university administrators may cripple the essential purpose of academic publishingproducing books of scholarly excellence.

title: DOW INDEX DROPS BY 6.02 TO 944.69
description: A dispirited stock market drifted steadily lower yesterday as worryladen investors pon dered the twin developments of higher prime rates at home and the decision by Britain to let the pound float in value.

title: Antiques: In the Country
description: Be prepared to find early 19thcentury country furni ture hidden by a mass of late (or recent) examples when you go antiquing on Long Is land or in Connecticut on summer, weekends.

title: Proxmire Threatens Fight On Nomination of Abrams
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Senator William Proxmire, Dem ocrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would oppose the nomi nation of Gen. Creighton W. Abrams as Army Chief of Staff unless the general gives a complete and thoroughly satis factory explanation of the more than 20 unauthorized air strikes by the Seventh Air Force while Abrams commanded our forces in Vietnam.

title: Hong Kong Toll Reduced
description: HONG KONG. June 23 (AP) Eightythree persons listed as missing in landslides last week end turned up today when the Government began distributing relief money. This reduced the total missing to 69. At least 100 persons died in landslides and floods caused by three days of heavy rains last weekend.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH LET POUND FLOAT IN VALUE IN WORLD MARKET
description: LONDON, June 23The Brit ish Treasury announced today that it would let the pound float in value for an indefinite period.

title: Executive Changes
description: John B. Santamarla has been named senior vice president and director of administration of Levitt & Sons, Inc.

title: Gonzales Disqualified in Tennis
description: LONDON, June 23That old warrior, Pancho Gonzales, created consternation at the staid Queens Club today by storming at a line judge and eventually walking off the court. He was disqualified in his semifinal match with John Paish of Britain.

title: Wider Wage Floor
description: The Federal floor under wages has some conspicuous chinks that need sealing in the interest of equity. The House of Representatives missed a chance to start this repair project last month when it voted to raise the basic minimum of $1.60 an hour but simultaneously killed proposals for bringing millions of excluded workers under protection of the wagehour law.

title: Duran Ends Fight Drills
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 23 (AP)Robgrto Duran of Pan ama, the challenger for Ken Buchanan's world lightweight title, broke camp today, while the champion sparred two rounds in a private workout at Grossingers, a nearby resort. The two will meet Monday night in New York's Madison Square Garden.

title: Swiss Flyweight Keeps Title
description: BERNE, Switzerland, June 23 (AP)Fritz Chervet of Switzer land retained his European fly weight boxing championship tonight with a 15round deci sion over Anders Romero of Spain. Chervet floored the challenger twice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Days of Delicate Talks Brought I.R.A. Pledge
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 23Secret talks with local officials, fist fights, angry debate and relentless pressure from Roman Catholic housewives led the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army to grudgingly propose a ceasefire starting at midnight on Monday.

title: Jamieson, at 135, Leads WesternGolf by 2 Shots
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill., June 23 (AP)Jimmy Jamieson, sud denly thrust into the role of gallery favorite, responded with, a fourunderpar 67 today and established a twostroke lead after the second round of the $150,000 Western open golf tournament.

title: U.S. Says Britain's Move Need Not Disturb Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Treasury said today that both it and monetary author ties of other countries shared the view that the floating of the British pound need not disturb the basic exchange rate relationships established by the Smithsonian agreement.

title: LARKINS WEAVES KEYBOARD MOODS
description: Ellis Larkins, a brilliant but unusually elusive jazz pianist who was last heard in New York 11 years ago, not only has reappeared here but also has settled down into what is turning into a much longer en gagement than he had planned.

title: War Foes See No Evidence Of Deliberate Dike Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  A number of well informed critics of the Vietnam war, including some men still serving in the Government, said in interviews today that there was no evi dence to support repeated as sertions by Hanoi that the United States had been delib erately bombing dikes and dams in Ncirth Vietnam.

title: Nuptials for Nancy Cunningham and W. D. Clark 3d
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 23Miss Nancy Kathryn Cunningham was married to night to W. Dearborn Clark 3d. The Rev. T. Guthrie Spears Jr. performed the ceremony in the First Pres byterian Church of New Canaan. A reception was held at the Woodway CountryClub in Darien.

title: Sports Fan Sues on Smoking
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23 (UPI)A sports fan who said he had suffered burning eyes, coughing, choking and an over all feeling of discomfort filed suit yesterday to bar smoking during public events at Pauley Pavilion of the University of California at Los Angeles, on the ground that smokers were assaulting his health.

title: I. M. F. Picks Committee of 20 To Work Out Currency Reform
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (Reuters)Executive directors of the International Monetary Fund agreed today on the com position of a committee of 20 to work out a world currency reform, a Fund spokesman said here.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES U.S. HEALTH PLANS
description: The nation's Medicare and Medicaid programs have been challenged as unconstitutional in Federal court here because they specifically exclude the one million Americans who are treated each year in public institutions for the mentally disabled.

title: High Level Fixes?
description: The rampant flow of illegal drugs throughout the city of New York convinced many community leaders long ago that there could also be rampant corruption through out the criminal justice system. Now, within the last few days, accumulating evidence from several official sources suggests that this may unfortunately be so.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: COMMACK, L. I., June 23The Long Island Ducks of the Eastern Hockey League are all set to become high flyers.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 23A professor at Stanford Univer sity and one of his former students were granted a pat ent this week for a method of transporting Arctic and sub Arctic oil through a pipeline at sub freezing tempera tures to avoid en vironmental dam age. Sullivan S. Marsden Jr. of the depart ment of petroleum engineer ing at Stanford and Stephen C. Rose, who is now with the Atlantic Richfield Company at Midland, Tex., received Patent 3,670,752.

title: Builders and Unions Continue to Bargain As Deadline Nears
description: Negotiations between con tractors and major building trades unions here have been moving slowly, with some in dustry officials becoming in creasingly fearful of strikes at the end of next week, when most contracts expire.

title: PACIFIC TEST FOES PLAN AIRBORNE DROP
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 23 (AP)Australian opponents of French nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific are planning to drop rubber rafts and six parachutists into international waters off the testing grounds at Mururoa atoll.

title: A Man's Head Is Found In Trash Can on Fifth Avs.
description: The head of a mustachioed man was found yesterday in a trash barrel at Fifth Avenue and Ninth Street by a rag picker.

title: FARM PRICES ROSE 0.4% DURING MAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Department of Agriculture reported today that the retail price of farmproduced foods rose by a sharp fourtenths of 1 per cent from April to May.

title: The Floating Pound
description: Nobel laureate Prof. Paul Samuelson has expressed the hope that he will live to see the day when a shift in the exchange rate of a major currency does not make Page One of The New York Times.

title: MRS. HART WINS, GAINS GOLF FINAL
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 23Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol and Mrs. Austin Straub of the Huntington Coun try Club will meet in the 36 hole final of the 69th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf As sociation championship tomor row.

title: Montana Generating Units Are Planned by 2 Utilities
description: The Montana Power Com pany and the Puget Sound Power and Light Company an nounced yesterday that they planned to build a coalfired electric generating complex at Colstrip, Mont., 100 miles west of Billings, to supply 700,000 kilowatts of electric power to Montana and the Puget Sound area of western Washington, beginning in 1975.

title: Mrs. Robert Flaherty, Widow Of Documentary Filmmaker
description: Mrs. Frances Hubbard Fla herty, widow of the documen tory filmmaker Robert J. Fla herty, died Thursday at her home in Dummerston, Vt.

title: Bridge: U.S. Olympiad Team Set Back By OverOptimistic Bidding
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 23 The Italian Blue Team head ed confidently for its third straight World Team Olym piad title here this afternoon, aided by overoptimistic bid ding by the Aces, its Ameri can opponents.

title: Harlem Tourney: Straddling Room Only
description: The Harlem Professionals, Inc., basketball league, better known as the Rucker tourna ment, had every expectation that its eighth season would be bigger and better this year. So far, in the first cou ple of weeks it has been literally bursting at the seams.

title: $369Million Mistake
description: In an action that is almost without precedent, the House Appropriations Committee has voted to cut off funds for a major riverwrecking project of the Army Corps of Engineers. If, as expected, the House sustains the committee decision Monday, it will have begun to transform a multimilliondollar mistake into an enduring benefit for millions of East Coast urban dwellers.

title: W. E. Delaney Jr. Weds Mary Dolan
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Miss Mary Anne Dolan and William Everett Delaney Jr., staff writers for The Wash ington Star, were married here this evening at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church by Bishop Paul F. Tanner of the Diocese of St. Augustine, Fla.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS SCHOOL AID BILL; SCORES CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 President Nixon signed today a bill making major innova tions in Federal aid to higher education but sharply criticized Congress for not having pro vided strict and uniform limits on school busing.

title: An Anxious Europe Expects More Curbs of Dollar Flows
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 23The pound crisis be came the dollar crisis on the Continent of Europe today, with immediate prospects for more controls of dollar flows.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that, starting Aug. 1, Federal savings and loan associations would be authorized to make loans for modernization and equipping without the require ment of security. The board's chairman, Preston Martin, said mortgage money was still plentiful at savings and loan associations and, thus, the new authorization for modern ization loans would not cut back on the supply of funds for mortgages.

title: Pacific Search Called Off
description: HONOLULU, June 23 (AP) The nineday search for 20 Japanese fishermen missing at sea since June 9 has been called off, the Coast Guard said yes terday. The Coast Guard cutter Jarvis remained temporarily in the search area about 500 miles southwest of here to sink the burnedout hulk of the Kaigata Maru No. 10.

title: SPEEDY CROWN 52 IN TROT TONIGHT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 23  The trotters and pacers were back at Roosevelt Race way tonight, but harness racing fans, irked by what they termed management's hasti ness in cancelling last night's card, continued today to be critical over the action. As it turned out, last night's pro gram could have been held, since the storm did not hit this area nearly as hard as had been anticipated.

title: BOMBING SUSPECT IS ACQUITTED HERE
description: A Puerto Rican nationalist accused by the police two years ago of having participated in 35 bombingsand who was subsequently indicted on charges relating only to two attempted bombingshas been acquitted of one of those attempts.

title: GABLE, TAYLOR WIN IN U.S. MAT TRIALS
description: ANOKA, Minn., June 23 (AP) Dan Gable of Waterloo, Iowa, won his fourth straight match tonight, defeating Larry Ow ings of the University of Wash ington, 71, in the 149 pound division at the United States Olympic wrestling trials.

title: Favorites as Fickle as Weather at Aqueduct
description: Things took a decided up ward turn at Aqueduct yester day, in the matter of attend ance. The turnout for the thoroughbred activity was 17, 371, a heartening increase of more than 40 per cent over the previous day, when an all time local low of 12,003 passed through the turnstiles.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Except for some handshakes in the cloakroom, a smatter ing of applause when ?? sentative William F. Ryan walked onto the House floor and a speech by Represent ative Bertram L. Podell, it was hard to tell here that the New York primaryelection on Tuesday had changed things very much.

title: Storm Delays Distance Swim
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 (AP) Walter Poenisch, 58 years old, has postponed his attempt to swim from Cuban coastal waters to Fort Lauder dale, Fla., until Tuesday be cause of Hurricane Agnes. The retired Grove City cooky maker said that the storm had churned up the water too much between Cuba and Florida for an at tempt this week. He seeks to establish an ocean distance swimming record.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE AIR CAGE. by Per Wstberg Translated from the Swedish by Thomas Teal. 377 pages. Delacorte. $6.95.

title: Suspect in Raid on Democrats Drew $89,000 From Bank, Hearing Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Bernard L. Barker, one of the five men arrested in the raid on the Democratic headquarters last Saturday, withdrew $89, 000 from a Miami bank on May 8, an Assistant United States Attorney, Earl J. Silbert, said today. The money included $10,000 in $100 bills.

title: Administration Loses in Senate Aid Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Senate today accepted the Administration's suggestion that military aid to Israel be increased, but it still cut $374 million from the military aid package for other nations.

title: VIRGINIA SUFFERS $160MILLON LOSS
description: RICHMOND, June 23Rains from Hurricane Agnes fell on Virginia for the third consecu tive day today, adding to the damage already caused by one of the worst storms to hit the East Coast in manv years.

title: Lawrence E. Gerosa Dies at 77; City Controller Under Wagner
description: Lawrence E. Gerosa, the New York City Controller for eight years until he left the post to run unsuccessfully for Mayor in 1961, died early today of lung cancer at Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Newport Jazz Festival. Expanded for New York
description: Newport never saw a jazz festival like the Newport Jazz Festival that will open here next Saturday. The festival, founded in 1954 and held every July since then in the Rhode Island resort city, has been moved to New York after be ing closed down last year by Newport officials following an invasion of the festival by a group of youths.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: STOCKHOLMAt 73, Gunnar Myr dal looks like the film version of a shaggy, rambling professor wise with age. He maintains the interests that made him an international scholarly figure: Economic development of the poor countries, for example, and the race relations problems that he ex plored in his 1944 classic, An Amer ican Dilemma.

title: JAPAN REDUCES INTEREST RATES
description: TOKYO, June 23Govern ment and private financial in stitutions reduced interest rates today in another move in Ja pan's plan to cope with a do mestic recession and reduce the massive payments surplus in economic dealings abroad.

title: Pioneer Navy Facility Leads Drive to Treat Alcoholism
description: LITTLE CREEK, Va.Be neath a poster that pro claimed, in blurred and wavy lines, Alcohol is a drug, a young chief petty officer told of three suicide attempts in the last two years.

title: Art: Bradley's Prints, Tice's Photos
description: Summer exhibitions can often turn out to be hohum rehashes of past shows, lack luster group endeavors or uninspired afterthoughts that might prove embarrassing during the winter season. But they can also turn out to be an unexpected delight or, oc casionally, a most satisfying discovery.

title: REGENTS DECIDE TO RETAIN TESTS
description: ALBANY, June 23  The State Board of Regents gave the 107yearold Regents examination program a new lease on life today, pending the development of a new and comprehensive system for as sessing school and student per formance that might or might not include the Regents tests.

title: Roundup: Reds, Astros Play LeapFrog
description: The Houston Astros' lead over Cincinnati in the Na tional League's Western Divi sion was shortlived. Last night the Reds walloped the Astros, 71, in Riverfront Stadium to regain the top spot by half a game.

title: ROCKETS' HAYES SENT TO BULLETS
description: HOUSTON, June 23 (UPI) Elvin Hayes, the leading scorer in the history of the Houston Rockets and one of the top players in the National Basket ball Association, was traded to the Baltimore Bullets tonight for Jack Marin, a forward, and undisclosed future considera tions.

title: General Instrument Corp. Reports Rise in Earnings
description: The General Instrument Cor poration believes it is in the early stages of a turnaround, Moses Shapiro, chairman, said yesterday at the company's an nual meeting of shareholders. He reported a profit of $1.7 million, or 20 cents a share, for the first fiscal quarter, end ed May 31, up from the year earlier $1.2million, or 12 cents a share. Sales and service in come rose to $70million from $65.4million.

title: 6 Major Banks to Increase Prime Rates
description: Six of the nation's largest banks yesterday announced that beginning Monday they would charge their best corpo rate customers more to borrow money.

title: Israel Hits Lebanon Again; Many Are Reported Killed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23  Israeli warplanes and ar tillery attacked reported Pal estinian guerrilla concentra tions inside Lebanon today for the second time in three days.

title: U.S. Wins in Softball
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, June 23 (AP)  The United States scored five runs in the third inning on its way to a 100 triumph tonight over Italy and the championship of a five nation softball tournament.

title: SUSPECT IS CHARGED IN JERSEY SLAYINGS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., June 23Edwin J. Grace was for mally charged today with mur dering six men and wounding another six in Cherry Hill on Wednesday afternoon.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH OVER INDIANS, 41, FOR SIXTH IN ROW
description: CLEVELAND, June 23Con sidering that they have lost three more games than they have won after 55 games of the American League schedule, the New York Yankees cannot real istically claim to be enjoying a strong season.

title: 3 British Soldiers And a Youth Slain In Ulster Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, June 24 (AP)Three British soldiers and a 17year old Roman Catholic youth were killed during the night in one of Northern Ireland's most vio lent outbursts in recent weeks.

title: DALEY SUPPORTERS DISRUPT OPPONENTS
description: CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) Led by city aldermen and ward committeemen, hundreds of screaming supporters of Mayor Richard J. Daley disrupted last night all but one of eight meet ings called by challengers to Mr. Daley's delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, June 23 (AP) Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed today a bill maintaining the nineweek extension to the regular 30week unemployment benefits, which Massachusetts loses July 1 under Federal law. The bill provides for a state takeover of financing the ex tension through the state's unemployment compensation fund on a temporary basis.

title: Saigon's Pilots Shun Dangers of Anloc
description: LAIKHE, South Vietnam, June 23Although the enemy pres sure on Anloc has eased some what, American helicopters are still flying nearly all of the highly dangerous support and troopcarrying missions into the town while large numbers of South Vietnamese helicopters sit idle on their pads, their crews lounging and sleeping.

title: MIDJUNE SALES OF CARS ROSE 16%
description: DETROIT, June 23The four major United States auto makers reported today that midJune retail sales were up 16 per cent over the same period last year. Deliveries were put at 255,720 units against 221, 188 deliveries for June 1120 a year ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 23Mayor Lindsay will be pro posed as one of three uncom mitted delegates to the Demo cratic National Convention by the state Democratic chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, at a meeting of the State Democratic Com mittee here this weekend.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX DRIFT DOWNWARD
description: News pending is often the terse reason the American Stock Exchange gives when it halts trading in a company's shares. Yesterday at 1:22 P.M. shares of Binney & Smith crossed the tape at 65, up 1, and that was the last trade permitted.

title: Cooking at the Figaro
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, CanadaIn the evening, I used to walk through the summer streets of Greenwich Village to the corner of Bleecker and Mac Dougal, where the Caf Figaro stood, tables and chairs in the windows occu pied by tourists and artists, loafers and lunatics, sitting around, keeping watch through the night.

title: Auto Dealer and His Wife Slain In Central Park West Robbery
description: A 58yearold foreigncar dealer and his wife were stabbed and strangled in their apartment in Park West Vil lage on the West Side early yesterday morning in what the police believe was a well planned robbery.

title: SPITZ, HALL, JOB SET SWIM MARKS
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 23 (AP)Mark Spitz won the 100metre freestyle event in a meet record 52.4 seconds today to claim his 14th victory in the sixyearold Santa Clara inter national swimming and diving meet.

title: Saigon Reports New Attacks on Troops Defending Hue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, June 24North Viet namese forces reportedly struck again yesterday against the Government's northern defense line after having been repulsed the day before, and there was growing apprehension here that they were opening a new south ward drive.

title: 250 Strikes on North
description: SAIGON, Saturday, June 24 (AP)The United States com mand reported yesterday that American fighterbombers flew more than 250 strikes over North Vietnam Thursday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 23 The Miami Beach City Coun cil voted today against pro viding campsites in the city to nondelegates expected here for the two national po litical conventions.

title: STRIKES SHAKING ITALY'S ECONOMY
description: ROME, June 23Nationwide strikes began in Italy today as 1.7 million farmhands and sharecroppers were ordered by their unions to stay away from work for 48 hours in a con flict over contract, renewals.

title: Dance: Balanchine and Robbins Take to the Stage
description: For dance this has been a week of miracles, miracles sometimes of aspiration and sometimes of achievement. It is probably the most im aginative week in dance his tory since the Diaghilev Ballet stormed Paris more than 60 years ago.

title: ErieLackawanna Plans To Add Commuter Trains
description: The ErieLackawanna Rail way, which serves 35,000 com muters in New Jersey and New York will add trains and make major changes in its commuter train schedule beginning to morrow.

title: Israelis Report Raids
description: TEL AVIV, June 23Israeli gunners were said to have fired into southern Lebanon early today for an hour following the rocket attack on Qiryat Shem ona, an immigrants' town.

title: Bernstein, Language Authority, Retiring From The Times July 1
description: Theodore M. Bernstein, sec ond in command of the news operations of The New York Times for 21 years as assistant managing editor from 1948 to 1969, will retire on July 1. ExAssistant Managing Editor Strove for Clearer Writing Joined Paper in 1925

title: Boston Dog Curb Is Vetoed
description: BOSTON, June 23 (AP)Dog owners here will not have to leash their pets, at least for a while, because Mayor Kevin H. White vetoed yesterday the city's first dogleash ordinance, passed June 5 by the City Council. The measure would have become effective July 1. Mr. White said that the city would be unable to enforce the law or deal with a large num ber of impounded dogs.

title: Farrington Daniels, a Physical Chemist
description: MADISON, Wis., June 23 (AP)Farrington Daniels, an internationally known physical chemist and professor emeritus of chemistry at the University of Wisconsin, died today. He was 83 years old.

title: 2 Women Guards Join Columbia Security Unit
description: For the first time in Colum bia University's 218year his tory, its security force has women guardstwo of them. They are Miss Pat Vickery, a student in Columbia's School of General Studies, and Mrs. Joyce Forbes, the mother of three, the grandmother of two and formerly a cleaning maid at the university.

title: Smith Class of '37 They Preferred Marriage to Jobs
description: Smith College, class of '37: They came to the groves of academe in the depth of the Depression and graduated as the world edged toward another war, and in between they kept their noses pretty much to the grindstone for it was a serious time to be in school.

title: Stone, a Research Aide Of N.B.C., Wed to David White
description: Miss Mary CliffJones Stone, daughter of Mrs. Chauncey Ives of New York and Bromley S. Stone of New York and Locust Valley, L. I., was married to David Elliott White, son of Mrs: Elliott White of Darien, Conn., and Frederick Kingsbury White of New York, yesterday in St. James' Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Alms M. Thorp jr., A reception followed at the Junior League clubhouse.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)Interest rates on home loans are going up again, the Government announced to day. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board disclosed that interest rates on convention almortgage loans climbed slightly in May after six months of decline.

title: Transplant Patient Fair
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 23 (AP)  Sidney Keough, a 53 yearold truck driver who got a new heart Wednesday, re mained in fair condition today, a spokesman for Stanford Uni versity Hospital said.

title: Europe's Bank Chiefs Fail To Agree on British Step
description: PARIS, June 24The Com mon Market's Central Bank Governors sought today to pre vent the disintegration of their embryonic monetary union in the face of Britain's decision to float the pound.

title: AUBREY GOULD SR.
description: HANCOCK, N.H. June 24  Aubrey Van Wyck Gould Sr., a retired New York investment counselor and adviser, died to day in Peterboro, N.H., Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTONEvery day in Portland, Ore., more than 100 convicted drunken driv ers visit a local drugstore and to comply with a court order swallow a special cock tail. It consists of orange juice and a drug that makes them seriously ill if they drink alcohol that day.

title: Imperialist Plot Charged
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi, June 24 (Agence FrancePresse) Burundi's Attorney General has charged that the civil conflict resulted from an imperialist plan to turn Burundi into a strategic base against neighbor ing Tanzania and Zaire.

title: DUMPING COSTS UP IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 24 Westchester County officials say they will have to spend millions to run the county dump at Croton Point the way a Federal Court ordered them to earlier this month.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: BRITAIN announced she would let the pound float in value for an indefinite period, thereby instituting a de facto devaluation that will allow free market forces to set a new international price for sterling.The Bank of Japan cut its discount rate to 4.25 per cent from 4.75 per cent, marking the sixth reduction since Japanese monetary authorities ended a period of tight money in October, 1970.  A group of major banks will raise their prime lending rate to 5 per cent tomorrow.

title: EAST STARS WIN FROM WEST, 4220
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., June 24 (UPI)The East allstars con verted a blocked punt, a fumble and a pass interception into three touchdowns and upset the West, 4220, tonight in the Coaches' allAmerica game, the first football contest of the season.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The late James Thurber once wrote: We live in a time when in the mothproof closet dwells the moth.

title: Christine McKeveny Is Bride on L. I.
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., June 24 Miss Christine Patricia McKeveny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerard Mc Keveny of Woodmere, was married here this afternoon to Claude Byron Holden in St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Martin Rushford, who concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Joseph D'Angelo.

title: Mystified Mayors
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 24The na tion's Mayors have completed their fiveday annual meeting as baffled as a generally sophisticated group of men and women can get.

title: Eugenie La Branche Is Married
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 24  Miss Eugenie La Branche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Michel Lucien La Branche 3d, was married here late this afternoon to Derek Vandergaer Dinkier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carling Dinkier Jr. of Miami.

title: Nets Face Long Battle in Bid to Keep Barry
description: Rick Barry, the New York Nets' top scorer and No. 1 gate attraction, is considering his next step after a court ruling that ordered him to return to the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Asso ciation.

title: Of Killing and Kissing
description: IATTENDED studentmat inee previews of both Julius Caesar and An tony and Cleopatra, which are now running in tandem at the American Shakespeare Festival Thea ter in Connecticut, and I confess I was a bit sur prised when, before the lights could come up on an Egypt costumed in bold and handsome rusts and blues, the Antony of the two plays (Paul Hecht) appeared at the rim of the raked stage with word of caution.

title: Kaat of Twins Wins No. 9
description: KANSAS, CITY, June 24 (AP) Jim Kaat of the Minnesota Twins earned his ninth victory of the American League season today by beating the Kansas City Royals, 4.1.

title: Arma virumque cano
description: No one ever wrote a poem on first looking into a translation of Virgil. Perhaps because everyone was busy trying his own hand at it. In fact, the very poet inspired to sing his admiration for Chapman's Homer had himself attempted a version of the Aeneid. But John Keats aban doned this youthful effort, possibly realizing, as have poets before and since, that the essence of Virgil is no more easily grasped than Aeneas's father in the Elysian Fields: recog nizable and vivid but intangible and unembraceable. Many a titan tried, but even Victor Hugohulascon ceded defeat.

title: Penn Central: A Trustee's View
description: Two years ago last Wednes day, the country's largest railroad system  the Penn Central Transportation Com panywent into bankruptcy. There is some quesiton whether it can ever operate as a viable system under pri vate ownership and some of its major creditors have al ready asked that the super vising Federal Court con cede this now. Jervis Lang don Jr., the Penn Central's senior trustee, discussed the railroad and its prospects in an interview last week with Robert E. Bedingfield of The New York Times. Excerpts from the interview follow:

title: Memory of a Wintry Trip to Sing Sing
description: IT was the first real night of winter. The radio in the car told us that the temp erature was down to five degrees. Driving from Man hattan, we blew into Brook lyn somehow and parked near the St. George Hotel. As we entered the hotel ball room, frozen to the marrow, trembling and afraid of the whip/wind, Eddie Palmieri, Puerto Rican pianist and bandleader, was on his way out, sweating through his suit, the sweat/vapor rising from his head, his smile broad and warm, coat over his arm, two brown goddesses holding on to this biceps and tens of admirers trailing him out.

title: BRITISH GOLF WON BY MISS WALKER
description: HUNSTANTON, England, June 24 (AP)  Michelle (Mickey) Walker retained the British women's amateur golf cham pionship today with a 2up victory over Claudine Rubin of France in the final round.

title: For Blacks, Corporate Door Is Ajar, But Is It Closing?
description: The frantic search by American corporations in the late nineteensixties for black professionals and executives floundered in the recession and mutual disenchantment set in. Many blacks felt they had been used as tokens for corporate windowdressing, and more than one senior management team found budgetary excuses for relax ing the pursuit of minorities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: U.S. IS CRITICIZED ON EQUALITY DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Government's program to as sure minorities and women equal opportunity in Federal employment is thwarted by ad ministrative delays and an em phasis on image rather than substance, a Ralph Nader study group charged today.

title: The World
description: When Henry A. Kissinger, the White House adviser on national security affairs, went to China early last week there was speculation that something was brewing on Vietnam. The speculation was heightened when Soviet President Nikolai Podgorny, en route home from Hanoi, predicted that the Paris peace talks would resume soon.

title: Movies
description: IN his latest film, Ray Mil land is savaged by toads. (The film, opening here July 5, is titled Frogs, but most of the frog roles are played by toads because you can't keep a frog out of water long enough to make a movie star out of him.) In his next film, Milland plays an extra head attached to Rosey Grier's body. That one is appropriately titled The Thing With Two Heads. Then there's the one called Embassy, in which he will appear as an American am bassador in the Middle East and another film he can't even remember the name of which he's about to begin shooting in Capetown, South Africa.

title: Lieut. Comdr. T. C. Failmezger Weds Miss Susan Woodward
description: Miss Susan Woodward and Lieut. Comdr. Theodore Charles Failmezger, U.S.N.R., Medical Corps, both of New York, were married here yes terday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner) by The Rev. Norman Catir. He was assisted by the Rev. James L. Rhinesmith, a Methodist minister and an uncle of the bridegroom. The lesson was read by Michael Dunn, the actor, who is a friend of the couple.

title: The Storm's Devastation
description: PENNSYLVANIAAt least 40 dead, 13 missing, 250, 000 homeless. Damage estimated at more than $1billion. Damage most severe in Harrisburg, WilkesBarre, Blooms burg along flooded Susquehanna. Flooding Monongahela and Allegheny join to form Ohio at Golden Triangle of Pittsburgh.

title: Child for the Dooskins
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., June 24 A daughter was born on June 3 to Mr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Dooskin at the Highland Park Hospital. The child has been named Hillary Anne. Mrs. Dooskin, the former Miss Ruth Doren bush of New York, is known professionally as Dr. Ruth Dooskin.

title: MATTESON IS LEADER IN MORICHES SAILING
description: MORICHES, L. L, June 24 Bob Matteson of the Moriches Yacht Club had three second place finishes today to take the lead in the roundrobin series to determine the men's championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Asso ciation.

title: Party Delegates Are New Breed
description: TRENTON  When New Jersey's delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion met for the first time, they were called to order by the party's state chairman, Salvator A. Bontempo.

title: MILLET SOUFFLE
description: cup millet 1 cup water

title: Rescuing Local Rule
description: The overwhelming vote in the House of Representa tives for a fiveyear program of revenue sharing marks the first step toward a fundamental advance in the American governmental structureone in which the Federal Government acts as centralized tax collector for the states and localities.

title: Community Puts Itself on TV
description: CAPE MAY  Last week in this southern New Jer sey resort city an idea be came a corporation.

title: Miss Gile Wed To C. E. Pfeifer In the Bay State
description: CHATHAM, Mass., June 24 Miss Shelley Hill Gile was married here this afternoon to Charles Frank Pfeifer at Riptide, the summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clement Dexter Gile of Rye, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Charles Pfeifer of New Canaan, Conn., and New York and the late Mrs. Charlene Church Pfeifer.

title: Burundi Reported Continuing Executions And Reprisals Against Ethnic Majority
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Diplomatic cablegrams reach ing Washington report that widespread repression and po litical executions are continu ing throughout the central Af rican country of Burundi.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE mounting concern over rising prices for meat and other foods in the United States and the sudden, dramatic action of Britain in floating the pound sterling last week diverted the atten tion of the business and economic community from the domestic economy and the securities markets.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The sorrows of young Werther, Brooklynstyle
description: According to J. B. S. Haldane you cannot drown newborn mice; their lungs somehow extract oxygen from water. This grotesque though per haps reassuring bit of esoterica comes to mind because Richard El man, in his hybrid autofiction about coming of age in Jewish Brooklyn, seems from a tender age to have been the captive animal in a series of parental humiliations (intended to make him sink, or swim, out of sight), and yet seems to have sur vived by breathing water.

title: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 4 No Title

title: Madagascar to Cancel Pacts
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, June 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Malagasy Government will review its policy of dialogue with South Africa and will cancel joint development contracts signed in November, 1970, it was announced here yesterday. The contracts are for for the tourist development of NossiB island, off the north west coast of Malagasy, in particular for construction of a hotel complex.

title: 27 SEEKING SPOTS ON OLYMPIC CREW
description: HANOVER, N. H., June 24 Harry Parker, the United States Olympic crew coach, announced today that 22 oars men and five coxswains had been invited to compete for the berths of 14 oarsmen and two coxswains to represent the United States in the eight oared and fourwithcoxswain competition at the Olympic Games in Munich, Germany.

title: Democratic Rules Panel Backs Sweeping Changes
description: WASHINGTON, June. 24 Sweeping changes in Demo cratic party structure were approved today by the party's convention Rules Committee, firmly controlled by proMc Govern forces.

title: The Nation
description: It was one of the worst storms in half a century  and the most wide spread flood disaster in the nation's history. The toll: 18 dead in Florida  more than 95 dead in the North  scores missing  thousands of homes and offices evacuated in Vir gian, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, West chester and the southern tier of New York  damage in the billions.

title: 2 Groups Moving To Open Beaches
description: SANDY HOOKThe long standing New Jersey tradi tion of closed, private beaches, a sore spot for hun dreds of thousands of resi dents barred from the ocean, is coming under organized attack.

title: Dean Is Named Conductor
description: HACKENSACK From a wealth of 162. applicants, the Bergen Philharmonic Orches tra has chosen a 40yearold college dean and former Ox ford scholar as its new con ductor. He is Prof. Michael Hammond, the head of the Music School at New York State University's new Col lege at Purchase. Members of the orchestra voted over whelmingly for the appoint ment following two days of auditions for 10 finalists.

title: Mailbox: The Great Jones
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Mailbag
description: ON RECORD

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Improved L.I.R.R. Schedules to Begin Tomorrow
description: New schedules on the Long Island Rail Road, the product of several years' work, go into effect tomorrow on every divi sion of the commuter line.

title: MiniSchool Test Ends First Year
description: Last September Haaren High School, at 59th Street and 10th Avenue, attempted to take it self apart and put itself back together in the form of 14 semi autonomous minischools of about 150 students each.

title: Foreign Students Face A Cost Squeeze in U. S.
description: Abdul M.
