Rahmani of Af ghanistan, a 28yearold me chanical engineer with dark eyes and a fierce mustache, came to the United States as a college freshman seven years ago and expects to return home soonwith a Ph.D. and a wor risome feeling about the effects that mounting financial pres sures are having on foreign students in the United States.

title: The World
description: HONG KONG  Disaster is no stranger to the 400,000 squatters of Hong Kong, who live in jerrybuilt shantytowns erected on vacant flatlands or hillsides where nobody else will build. Periodically, typhoons sweeping in from the South China Sea flatten the makeshift homes, fires started by overturned kero sene lamps or stoves spread swiftly through the encamp ments, and floods caused by the torrential rains of the summer monsoons take a heavy toll in death and de struction.

title: Harrison Williams 3d Weds Miss Dodge
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., June 24Miss Priscilla Lee Dodge and Harrison Williams 3d of Leesburg, Va., and Denville were married here this after noon in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, Canon Robert H. Booker.

title: Expos Down Phils, 54
description: MONTREAL, June 24 (AP) Ron Woods and Ken Singleton hit home runs and Clyde Mashoe drove in two runs with two sacrifice flies as the Mont real Expos scored a 54 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, extending Woodie Fry man's personal losing streak to seven straight games.

title: Pirates' 2Run 8th Topples Cubs, 31
description: CHICAGO, June 24Manny Sanguillen drove in two runs with a basesloaded single to break a 11 tie in the eighth inning today and help the Pitts burgh Pirates to a 31 victory over the Chicago Cubs:

title: Policemen Accept Raise
description: LOWELL, Mass., June 23 (AP)  Lowell policemen have ratified a threeyear contract calling for a $37aweek in crease in top salaries to $216 a week and for a shorter work week.

title: Miss Drapeau Wed
description: PELHAM, N. Y., June 24 In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church here at noon today, Miss Suzanne Marie Drapeau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Drapeau Jr., was married to Michael Edward Hobbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Franklin Hobbs Jr. of Griffin, Ga., by the Rev. Arthur R. McGratty. The bride made her debut at the 1968 Westchester Cotillion and was graduated from Marymount College in Arling ton, Va. Mr. Hobbs, who was graduated June 6 from the University of Georgia, will enter the Emory University Law School.

title: Art
description: THE day I arrived in Florence for the Henry Moore exhibition, I read the news of the death of Edmund Wilson. A few days earlier, in Venice, I had a glimpse of the ancient Ezra Pound sit ting in the audience at the Teatro La Fenice, where he had come to hear the Verdi Requiem conducted by Thomas Schippers  Ezra Pound, whose writings on sculpture were so crucial an influence on the young Hen ry Moore and whose audac ious literary labors had played, even earlier, so im portant a role in the careers of Eliot, Yeats and Joyce, the writers Wilson had so brilliantly elucidated in Ax el's Castle.

title: PROFESSORS WEIGH BLACK STUDY ROLE
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 The leaders of black studies programs at 15 major colleges have attempted to define what legitimately belongs in such programs. They concluded there was room both for serious scholarship and for social ac tivism.

title: ITALIANS CAPTURE TITLE IN BRIDGE
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 24 Italy won a convincing victory here today in the World Bridge Olympics. The celebrated Blue Team, which captured 12 world titles in the fifties and sixties, emerged from a twoyear retire ment to beat the Aces, who won the world title for the United States in 1970 annd 1971, by 65 inernational match points.

title: I don't think I will sing any more
description: Delusions, Etc. was already in proof when John Berryman jumped off a bridge in Minneapolis onto the frozen Mississippi last January. So there is no question of its being a ragbag of uncollected work hastily gathered up as a memorial. The book is as he wanted it, the order of its poems and the emotional emphasis all his. Which seems to point to the fact that, up to the end, he was fighting against the way of dying he finally chose. For the emphasis is on the faith he had regained after 43 years away from the Roman Catholic Church. So Delusions begins and ends on a religious note, as though to defend himself against his own depression.

title: Capt. Bassham Gains Lead In Free Rifle Competition
description: PHOENIX, June 24 (AP) Army Capt. Lanny Bassham of Ft. Worth, Tex., moved into the top spot today during the second round of the free rifle competition in the United States international shooting championships.

title: Ceylon Head Goes to Peking
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 24 Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the Prime Minister, left for Peking today for a sevenday visit in search of economic as sistance.

title: How Senator McGovern Thanked Some Special Contributors
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Senator George McGovern invited some of his favorite people the VIC's, for Very Important Contributors to a royal round of entertain ment in the capital yester day, in exchange for a $5,000 per couple donation. Twenty one stanch supporters took him up on It.

title: Mrs. Pratt Has Son
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 24  A son was born May 30 to Mr. and Mrs. John Lowell Pratt in the Green wich Hospital. Mrs. Pratt is the former Miss Susan Marie Smith of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia. Her husband is a realtor. The child, the couple's third son, has been named Derek Wyniard.

title: 12Man U.S. Team Picked For Volleyball in Olympics
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 24 (AP)The 12member United States men's Olympic volley ball team was chosen today.

title: BUCHANAN RISKS TITLE TOMORROW
description: Ken Buchanan, a master boxer from Scotland, and Ro berto Duran, a slugger from Panama, will meet in a 15 round fight for Buchanan's world lightweight championship tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Renata Scotto Has Son
description: A son was born Wednes day to Dr. and Mrs. Lorenzo Anseimi in Lugano, Switzer land. Mrs. Ansehni is Renata Scotto, the Metropolitan Opera soprano. Her husband is former concert master of the La Scala Opera Orchestra in Milan, Italy. The child, the couple's second, has been named Filippo.

title: MEAT PRICES HERE RISE 4 TO 10 CENTS
description: Meat prices rose 4 to 10 cents a pound last week in the New York City and Hartford areasthe only ones where government price reporters maintain a weekbyweek price watchand the New York and Connecticut State Agriculture Departments warned consumers that still higher prices were likely.

title: We Are Playing A Dangerous Game With Japan
description: ALTHOUGH a year ago Americans would have thought the idea preposterous, some strangely prescient Japanese have long been haunted by the fear that the United States might sometime arrange a rap prochement with China without their intermediation or even their knowl edge, leaving them isolated. Last July 15 they saw that nightmare beginning to come true.

title: Students Playing A Business Game
description: A young executive squared off against an elderly board member at a corporation meeting.

title: Art: Flowers Are in Bloom
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.The lull and lethargy of summer have settled on the New York art world. Museums have drastically decreased their schedules, and those galleries that have not closed their doors yet are satisfied to assemble group shows from their stable of artists.

title: NEW SYSTEM TRIED FOR MEDICAL SUITS
description: In an experimental program to settle lawsuits involving medical malpractice, nearly one third are being resolved by threeman mediation panels composed of a judge, a physi cian and a lawyerthus avoid ing protracted and expensive trials.

title: India to Build Oil Refinery
description: NEW DELHI, June 24 (AP) The Government announced to day that it would build a $215 million oil refinery, the nation's largest, at Mathura, 85 miles south of New Delhi.

title: Mrs. Kurtz Has Daughter
description: A daughter was born June 11 to Mr. and Mrs. Donald Kurtz of New York at the New York Hospital. Mrs. Kurtz is the former Mara Stoller of New York, where her husband is president of Kurtz Kambanis & Symon, an advertising agency. The child has been named Sasha.

title: Northport Zoning Row Flares
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.An old hotel, the Holiday Lodge, is now a huge pile of rubble, while a battle to develop its prime waterfront site begins anewlike a film rewound to the start.

title: ITALIANS CAPTURE TITLE IN BRIDGE
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 24 Italy won a convincing victory here today in the World Bridge Olympics. The celebrated Blue Team, which captured 12 world titles in the fifties and sixties, emerged from a twoyear retire ment to beat the Aces, who won the world title for the United States in 1970 annd 1971, by 65 inernational match points.

title: DRIVER'S PROBLEM IN POLAND: PARTS
description: WARSAW, June. 24  The police raided the nation's best supplied and most efficient au tomotive parts store a few weeks ago and confirmed a widelyheld Polish belief: If something works well, there must be a catch.

title: RUSSIAN IS IN U.S. FOR CHINA STUDIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 24A distinguished Soviet scholar is spending nine months touring United States universities to study the foreign policy of China.

title: Music: Balaban And His 5 Cats
description: EAST RUTHERFORD  Ono week after Joe Dressel and Chip Taylor opened their Town House Inn in February, 1969, they sent out a despera tion call for a banjo player who Could lead singalongs, because the leader of the quartet that had played for them the week before could not make It.

title: This Little Dead End Kid Made Good
description: THIS softspoken, gentle guy, a serious actor, a serious student of Zen  could this be Gabriel Dell, one of the original Dead End kids? I remember all the longago Saturday after noons at the movies when we kids in Chicago gorged on Cracker Jacks and wriggled through the deliciously scary thrills of living out our most secret delinquent fantasies with that rat pack of little street punks. They talked English so funny and they got away with tough stuff we'd never dare dream of try ing.

title: Education
description: In recent years many an Amer ican college has changed its ways in response to student demands for more direct voice in their educa tion. One of the more drastic overhauls has occurred at Hobart and William Smith, two coordinate colleges in central New York.

title: Body Shortage Curbs Medical Study
description: A serious shortage of cadavers is hampering the teaching of anatomy to the growing number of students who are learning to become doctors and allied health workers. The shortage affects medical schools throughout the country, with few ex ceptions.

title: RABBIS ARE UPSET BY ASSIMILATION
description: FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 24 The Rabbinical Council of America, the largest of the country's Orthodox rabbinic groups, has voted to establish a National Commission on Jew ish Survival to resist what its president termed the frighten ing increase in intermarriage and missionary activity among Jews.

title: Bell Wins Pole Position
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, June 24 (AP)Britain's Derek Bell, driv ing a new Gulf Mirage of the John Wyer team, registered the fastest trial time today and se cured the pole position for to morrow's 1,000kilometer race on the Oesterreichring. Bell's time for the 5,9kilometer course was 1 minue 40.60 sec onds.

title: Miss Salzman, Thomas Jerige Marry in Forest
description: RIVERTON, Conn., June 24Miss Shelley Ann Salz man and Thomas Michael Jerige of Riverton, were mar ried here this afternoon in the Peoples' Forest, a state preserve.

title: Dr. Brian Catlin Fiance Of Rosalie Hornblower
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 24Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Horn blower Jr. have announced the engagement of Mr. Horn blower's daughter, Miss Rosa lie Hornblower, to Dr. Brian Catlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Catlin of New York and Greenwich.

title: Manpower and Ecology
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Senator Robert P. Griffin, Re publican of Michigan, said to day that he would introduce legislation to permit volunters in such programs as VISTA to devote their efforts to protect ing the environment. Senator Griffin said the proposal would bring to bear on the environ mental protection problem a whole new pool of generally untapped manpower.

title: Litton to Run Cancer Research Lab
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The National Cancer Institute named a contractor yesterday to operate its newly acquired facilities at Fort Detrick, Md., and predicted that, by fall, the former biological warfare lab oratories would be fully at work toward the conquest of cancer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: The leaflets were widely distributed through the mail and posted promi nently in a number of subway cars around New York. Bearing the symbol of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the name of the New York Transit Authority, they told rid ers what to do if they happened to be mugged on one of the system's new R44 subway cars, the doors of which are automatically locked while the train is moving.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Stewart R. Mott 3d made a list the other day of the money he had contributed, pledged and lent to politicians or their causes so far in 1972. It stag gered him.

title: Waterborne Concerts Have Two Goals
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. On July 24, a huge self propelled vessel resembling a giant kettledrum, which serves as a waterborne con cert stage for the American Waterways Wind Symphony, will drop anchor here for a diversified program of music.

title: Furniture Centers Started The Trend
description: Maybe the Levitz Furniture Corporation didn't exactly invent the furniture ware houseshowroom, but it cer taily put this method of distribution on the map.

title: Ballet Group Dancing With Tears in Their Eyes
description: MINEOLA, L.I. Ballet 4, until last October known as the Recreation Ballet Com pany and operating, under the auspices of the Nassau Coun ty Department of Parks and Recreation, is now at the crossroads. Having lost the support of the county, which reorganized its entire per forming arts program at the end of last summer, the com pany is now very much in need of funds and rehearsal space.

title: Italy Ending Monday Papers
description: ROME, June 24 (Reuters) Italy's newspaper proprietors announced yesterday that they will stop publishing Monday edi tions of their newspapers, be ginning next week, because of the prohibitive cost of Sunday labor.

title: Hijacker Jumps With $502,500 Ransom
description: ST. LOUIS, June 24 More than 150 law enforcement offi cers in helicopters, light planes, boats and on foot patrolled a wooded area of northcentral Indiana today, searching for a swarthy hijacker who para chuted, clutching a canvas bag containing a $502,500 ransom, from an American Airlines jet early this morning.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN an electric doorbell, buzzer or chime fails to ring, repairs are usually quite simple for the doit yourselfer to make and, since these devices always work on low voltage, there is no danger of shock or need to worry about creating a fire hazard. However, as in any electrical repair job, it is es sential that one be reason ably familiar with how the system works and with how the various parts (bell, but ton, power supply) are wired.

title: A Letter From Detroit Leaves Car Owners Petrified
description: George Rosenberg looked away from the Vega with its hood up in the service de partment of his Bronx Chev rolet dealership and said, The chances of an accident to the average car is very, very small. But when people get that letter, they're scared.

title: Phone Company Gets Warning On Institutional Advertisements
description: New York City may be a wonderful town, but the State Public Service Commission warned yesterday that saying so might have to come out of a utility's profits  not, for example, out of the bills of telephone csutomers.

title: Jane E. Tuohy Sets Marriage
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24Mr. and Mrs. John J. Tuohy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Tuohy, to Leo Augustus Whelan Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Whelan of Belmont, Mass. The wedding will take place here in October.

title: A. S. Melcher Weds Cynthia Gould
description: POTTERSVILLE, N.J., June 24 Miss Cynthia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyttleton B. P. Gould Jr., was married here this after noon to A. Stephen Melcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Melcher Jr., of Lexington, Mass. The couple plan to serve with the Peace Corps in South Korea.

title: Camden: An Exodus of Whites
description: Talk about the white exo dus from the cities usually evokes visions of massive departures from such metrop olises as New York and Philadelphia.

title: Russians Are Warned On Drunken Swimming
description: MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) The newspaper Trud, alarmed by 50 drownings in the Mos cow area so far this summer, has warned Russians that those who drink like fish often cannot swim like them.

title: Bridge
description: APLAYER should be happy in slam bidding if his trump suit is substantial, and sad if his trumps are feeble. At a low level the strength of the trump suit is a minor con sideration. The combined pointcount and the existence of an eightcard trump fit are the vital matters, for if there are losers in the trump suit there will be compensating winners elsewhere. But in a slam it is a dif ferent matter: 15 tricks in the side suits will not compensate for two trump losers.

title: Barclay Blayman Marries Joanne Edson
description: Miss Joanne Newell Edson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John N. Edson of Brooklyn Heights, was married yester day afternoon to Barclay Blayman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Blayman of Tenafly, N. J. The ceremony was per formed in the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims (Con gregational) in Brooklyn Heights by the Rev. Harry Kruener.

title: Cambodia Reports Setback
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 24 (UPI)The Cambodian high command said today that Gov ernment troops had apparently lost two positions to the Com munist forces on Route 1, about 35 miles southeast of Pnom penh.

title: Cancer Grant in Boston
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Representative Louise Day Hicks, Democrat of Massachu setts, has announced that the Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare approved $6million construction grant to the Children's Cancer Research Foundation in Boston. The funds will be used for the con struction of Charles A. Dana Cancer Center Clinical Investi gation and Research Facilities, Mrs. Hicks said she was told by a foundation official.

title: Aquarium Complex For Suffolk Gains
description: RIVERHEAD, L. LSuffolk County decided last week to support the third and final feasibility study of a com bination aquarium, museum and vocational center in Greenport.

title: Cowboys Sign 2d Draft Pick
description: DALLAS, June 24 (UPI) Robert Newhouse, a No. 2 draft choice whose 1,757 yards rush ing last fall for the University of Houston was the second highest season total in col legiate history, has signed a threeyear contract with the Dallas Cowboys, general man ager Tex Schramm announced today. The terms of Newhouse's contract were not announced, but it was understood to be for more than $100,000 over the threeyear period.

title: Tigers Triumph in 12th, 21, After Bowing to Orioles' Homers in Opener, 31
description: BALTIMORE, June 24 (AP) Eddie Brinkman hit a sacrifice fly with the bases loaded in the 12th inning to score Norm Cash and give the Detroit Tigers a 21 victory and a split of their doubleheader with the Balti more Orioles tonight.

title: Miss Biddle Betrothed To Thomas G. Reeves
description: Mrs. Richard G. Blaine of New York and Oliver C. Biddle of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Chris tine Mortimer Biddle, to Thomas George Reeves, son of Mrs. Guy G. Manuel and Louis Milford Reeves, both of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

title: SYKES'S DIXIE FIRST IN SHIELDS REGATTA
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 24 James W. Sykes Dixie into a 1point lead for the Long Is land Sound District champion ship of the Shields Class today by placing second in both races held off Larchmont Yacht Club in a 10to12 knot westofsouth breeze. One race tomorrow will complete the regatta.

title: The First Ten in Jeopardy
description: The American dollar is not the only bill that has been shrinking in value over the past few years. The American Bill of Rights, our most precious na tional resource, is also in the process of being significantly devalued. The civil liberties of all Americans  the right to be free from unwarranted Government intrusion, to speak criti cally of those in power, to be treated fairly and with due process  have been seriously curtailed over the past few years. As the chief counsel to the Senate subcommittee on constitutional rights recently put it: The only part of the Bill of Rights that the Adminis tration hasn't either rewritten or vio lated is the only one it should have the right to bear arms.

title: Italians Triumph in Soccer
description: ROME, June 24 (Reuters) Rome of Italy won the Anglo Italian soccer tournament to day by beating Blackpool of England, 31, in the final. The teams were scoreless at half time.

title: New de Gaulle, in Father's Image, Emerges
description: PARIS, June 24  Another de Gaulle has come into the limelight, showing the same stiff pride and imperiousness of the late President.

title: The Bonus
description: One of the few bonuses of this year's cold, wet spring has been the lush leafage and remarkable abundance of blossoms on the trees and the bushes. The woodlands seem to have more leaves than ever before, perhaps to catch the comeandgo sunlight, and blossoms have been a constant display in every brushy pasture margin in every woodland and scrap of timberland.

title: Harness Writers Slate Hall of Fame Ceremony
description: The installation of Ralph Baldwin and John Simpson Sr. in the United States Har ness Writers' Association Living Hall of Fame at Gosh en, N. Y., is scheduled for July 2 along with special ceremonies dedicating a new building for the Hall of Fame of the Trotter.

title: Era of U.F.O.'s Is 25 Years Old
description: TUSCON, Ariz.  Twenty five years ago at 3 P.M. on June 24, 1947, Kenneth Ar nold a Yakima, Wash., busi nessman, ushered in the era of the flying saucer.

title: Policemen Accept Raise
description: LOWELL, Mass., June 23 (AP)  Lowell policemen have ?? a threeyear contract calling for a $37aweek in crease in top salaries to $216 a week and for a shorter work week.

title: TENTAM IS SECOND
description: Racing in the lead spot most of the way, the Locust Hill Farm's Icecapade was first across the line in the $57,150 Saranac at Aqueduct yesterday. Guided by Eddie Maple, Ice capade had the margin of a neck over the Cragwood Sta ble's Tentam at the finish of the onemile event.

title: FEW ARE COVERED BY FLOOD POLICIES
description: Homeowners and business men have lost at least $1billion to the flood waters of tropical storm Agnes and most of them will have to search long and hard to find anyone who has flood insurance to help meet the cost of rebuilding, a check by The New York Times dis closed yesterday.

title: Child for Kittenplans
description: A daughter was born June 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Kittenplan of New York in the New York Hospital. Mrs. Kittenplan is the former Miss Gail Waldman.

title: Have Daughter, Will Travel
description: ROBERT Altman, who is now shooting Ray mond Chandler's The Long Goodbye with Elliott Gould and a nifty newcomer named Nina Van Pallandt, has just said hello to another movie proj ect. He has bought the rights to Long Division, a novel by Anne Richardson Roiphe which will be published in October by Simon & Schus ter. Altman will both Pro duce and direct the film, starting next summer  at which time Mrs. Roiphe will have finished the screenplay.

title: WALL STREET
description: Warnings of dire conse quences have greeted vir tually every effort to elim inate the New York Stock Exchange's system of fixed commission charges.

title: Speedy Crown Captures $92,505 Realization Trot, With Lightning Larry 2D
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 24  On nearly any other occasion, tonight's spotlight at Roosevelt Raceway would have belonged to Adios Bob, a 5yearold New Yorkbred who posted the sea son's first subtwominute mile at the track. However, the brown son of Tar Boy and Adios Time had to take a sub sidiary role for his 1:59 3/5 clocking in the fourth race be cause of the easedup victory of Speedy Crown in the 11th Real ization Trot.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The good news is that President Nixon has signed the Higher Education Bill, with its aid for colleges and universities and its mild restraints on pupil bus ing. The bad news is that he is still threatening to campaign in the fall for a constitutional amendment prohibit ing busing.

title: M.T.A. APPROVES COMMUTER FARES
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority announced yesterday that it had approved monthly commuter fare in creases of about 23 per cent that had been proposed by the Penn Central for the Harlem and Hudson lines.

title: Violence Shaking Ulster As Truce Deadline Nears
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 24  Bombings, killings and sniper attacks engulfed Northern Ireland today, 72 hours before the promised truce by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Mets' Wounds of Past Turn Into Today's Grins
description: From out of an often tor tured past they streamed into Shea Stadium yesterday, ex Mets like Dick Stuart (I'm just trying to keep my head above water these days), or Al Jackson (How do I ex plain to my kids what losing was like?), or Frank Thomas (I walked the streets for 3 months after I was finished with baseball).

title: The World
description: In November of 1969, Pal estinian guerrilla forces based in southeastern Lebanon reached a rather curious agreement with the Lebanese Government. The accord for bade the guerrillas to fire across the border into Israel but permitted them to cross the border for commando op erations inside Israel. The Government apparently rea soned that since no shots would be fired from Lebanese soil, the country would be safer from Israeli reprisals.

title: Delaware Slate Chosen
description: DOVER, Del., June 24Sena tor McGovern won nine of Delaware's 20 delegates to the Democratic National Conven tion at the state convention here last night. The nine have a total of 5.85 votes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKEES, INDIANS ARE RAINED OUT
description: CLEVELAND, June 24The rain and cold weather that forced today's game between the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Indians to be post poned seemed an apt back ground this afternoon at Muni cipal Stadium for an assessment of the current gloomy plight of the Indians by Ken Aspro monte, the Cleveland manager.

title: Security Council Adjourns After Hearing Lebanese Call for Strong Condemnation of Israeli Forays
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24The Security Council concluded a protracted and at times acrimonious debate to night as Lebanon sought a very strong condemnation of Israel for persistent acts of aggression.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: Airline and government of ficials expect the worst on theground traffic jams ever for air travelers at and near Kennedy International Air port this summer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A speedup in state guarantees of loans to set up nonprofit daycare centersfor which 87 applications are pending in New York Citywas promised yesterday by the State Department of Social Services. The department said it would get legal, accounting, architectural, appraisal and project engineering services to help it process the and project engineering services from the staff of the state Health and Mental Hygiene Facilities Improvement Corpo ration to help it process the loans.

title: Registered Motor Vehicles Up 4.5 Million During 1971
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The Federal Highway Admin istration has announced that 112,922,354 motor vehicles were registered in the United States during 1971, an increase of more than 4.5 million during the year.

title: Bill on Retired Is Rescued
description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP)Rep resentative Francis W. Hatch, Republican of Beverly, the House minority leader, has res cued from a study package a bill allowing retired public em ployes to work in public serv ice for up to 90 clays a year. The bill was referred Wednes day to the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Nassau Collection Agency Fined for Wording of Duns
description: The New York City Depart ment of Consumer Affairs has fined a Nassau County collec tion agency for what the de partment considered undue threats to its debtors. Com missioner Bess Myerson an nounced yesterday.

title: Floating the Pound
description: LONDON  At 2 minutes after 8 Friday morning, the vice president in charge of an American bank here was called from his shaving mir ror to take a call from a friend, the vice president of another Londonbased Amer ican bank. The caller report ed that the Treasury had just announced that the pound was going to float.

title: Speakers at Commencements Put New Emphasis on Old Values
description: Senator Margaret Chase Smith chose a piece of doggerel to conclude the advice she gave recently to the graduating sen iors at St. Joseph's College in Maine:

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Regional economics, a sub ject of increasing interest at the Federal, state and local government levels, is attract ing the attention of profes sionals and some eager ama teurs outside the select con fines of the 12 district Fed eral Reserve Banks and scat tered university campuses.

title: Garelik Scores the Rehiring Of a Former City Official
description: Council President Sanford D. Garelik charged Mayor Lind say's administration, yesterday with arrogance and contempt for the true principles of honest and efficient government for hiring as a consultant an offi cial held to have violated the city's Code of Ethics.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: The recent financial fail ure of Lennen & Newell, Inc., has renewed the advertising industry's interest in who is responsible for the debts in curred by a defunct agency on behalf of its advertiser clients.

title: Fort Wadsworth Is Site Today Of 32d Staten Island K.C. Show
description: News of Dogs

title: 60 Bicyclists to Start Olympic Trials Today
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 24 (UPI)  Sixty top bicycle racers begin the weeklong United States Olympic cy cling trials at the Santa Clara County Velodrome to morrow.

title: Chris Evert, 17, And Connors, 19, Win Net Crowns
description: LONDON, June 24 (UPI) Poncho Gonzales will be re ported to the British. Lawn Tennis Association following disqualification from the Lon don grass court champion ships, but is in no danger of missing Wimbledon, an offi cial said today.

title: Stokes Memorial Game Is Scheduled for Aug. 15
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 24  The Maurice Stokes Memorial basketball game will be played Tuesday eve ning, Aug. 15, at Kutsher's Country Club, Monticello, N. Y. The game is played as a memorial to the Cincinnati Royals star who died in 1970 after a 12year struggle against brain damage.

title: Rising Soviet Tensions
description: For much of the past decade Pyotr I. Yakir has been the most courageously outspoken representative of the tolerated Soviet domestic opposition. His ability to remain a free man while others who felt as he did were sent to jail or insane asylums derived from at least two factors: he sedulously obeyed the letter of Soviet law, and he enjoyed international fame as the son of a famous Soviet general who was framed and executed by Stalin in 1937.

title: Jamaica Bay Pollution System Weathers a Test
description: The rains spawned by the tropical storm Agnes have caused a sharp increase in pol lution levels in areas bordering Long Island Sound, but a new experimental pollution control system on Jamaica Bay passed its first major test with flying colors officials said.

title: LURE TAKES HONORS IN RESOLUTE CLASS
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 24James B. Moore Jr.'s Lure was back in the Resolute Class winners' circle today as 55 boats sailed with the Port Washington Yacht Club in the Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition.

title: AROUND THE
description: Until the ground dries out following last week's deluge, read a book, paint a picture or take a welldeserved cat nap or two.

title: GOVERNOR'S AIDE RESIGNING SEPT. 1
description: Governor Rockefeller's office announced yesterday the resig nation, effective Sept. 1, of Robert R. Douglass, as secre tary to the Governor.

title: Television
description: IT'S documentary time, so this must be black week. In television, ob viously, that has nothing to do with matters racial. It's only the label given to a week in which Nielsen doesn't take any ratings. The networks can re lax and put on some of those news, public affairs or cultural specials that win citations for responsibility but usu ally do not win the massaudience sweepstakes.

title: Son to Mrs. Melvin Kraft
description: A son was born May 31 to Mr. and Mrs. Melvin D. Kraft of New York in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Kraft is the former Miss Katherine Kane of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Her husband is a trial lawyer. The child was named David Kane.

title: Poems Good and Otherwise
description: Since children write very good poetry for themselvessee the Opies and, latterly, the work of Kenneth Koch's students  why do adults persist in writing it for them? Setting aside the motive of avarice, though not actually asking it to leave the room, I suspect that most mature writers write children's verse in hopes of (1) instructing, (2) delighting, or (3) identifying with their young readers, if any. All of these are, or can be, legitimate and praiseworthy motiva tions, as the work of Carroll, Lear, Gilbert, White, McCord, and Updike will show. But all of them can be perverted into solemn, nagging preachments, into bathetic whimsies, into infantile, regressive, wishful filling dreams of a lost childhood.

title: Floating Pound Brings Changes for the British
description: LONDON, June 24Britons awoke this morning to find many of the familiar land marks of their lives changed as a result of the floating of the pound proclaimed yes terday.

title: Mr. Laird's Nonsense
description: President Nixon has wisely parted company with Defense Secretary Laird on the SovietAmerican missile curb agreements, which Mr. Laird wants to hold hostage for a $25billion program of new strategic offensive weapons. The President has called on the Congress to approve the strategic arms limitation (SALTI) agreement first, as urged by arms control advocates, and only then to debate the defense budget items, which he hopes will be approved as well.

title: The Nation
description: How big a problem is unemploy ment? The official figures show that the jobless rate has been frozen for more than a year at around 6 per cent, half again as much as the old 4 per cent standard for full employment.

title: Stamps
description: THEODORE STEINWAY, the distinguished Amer ican stamp collector who also manufactured pianos, will be honored by Liechtenstein on Sept. 7 when his portrait appears on a 1.30franc dark blueultra marine stamp in the prin cipality's third series of Pi oneers of Philately stamps. Sharing the postal tribute with Mr. Steinway (1883 1957) will be Emilio Diena (18601941) of Italy and An dre de Cock (18801964) of Belgium.

title: The Lady Was an Umpire
description: Sports of The Times

title: U.S. TOLD FRANCE TO SETTLE WITH HO
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (Reuters)The United States told France 25 years ago that she should be most generous in her attempts to settle the war against Ho Chi Minh and the Vietminh forces in Indochina or she might play into the hands of the Communists in Southeast Asia, according to State Department documents released this week.

title: 2 Hospitals in Suffolk To Merge Birth Units
description: GREENPORT, L. I.  The maternity service at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Green port will be merged into that of Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead. The consolidation is said to be owing to the prohibitive cost of maintain ing the service at the hospital here and the low occupancy.

title: Nassau Gold Coast to Bare Gems
description: SANDS POINT, L. I. There was a time here on the North Shore when the way of life resembled the castled splendor reserved for story books. Shielded from the on slaught of society and tech nology by high metal gates, the tides and the plush moat of deep woods, this lifestyle thrived on fine art, classic literature, superb cuisine and an abundant appreciation of elegance.

title: Jeannine Byers Rhinelander Is Bride
description: Miss Jeannine Byers Rhine lander, daughter of T. J. Oakley Rhinelander of New York and Newport, R. I., and the late Mrs. JeanneMarie Schley Rhinelander of Far Hills, N. J., and Grasse, France, was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter A. V. Schoeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred O. Schoeffer of New York.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Henry Kissinger is so sure he's been wiretapped he wisecracks that he won't have to write his memoirs  he'll just pub lish the F.B.I.'s transcript of his tele phone calls. Richard Kleindienst, when he was Deputy Attorney General, once had his office swept for listening devices. William P. Rogers, the Sec retary of State, has been known to tell friends he can't discuss foreign policy over the telephone.

title: Illinois, Stunned by Racing Scandal, Cracks Whip on Gimmick Betting
description: The Big Q. died last. Thursday night at Sportsman's Park, killed by an Illinois Racing Board that blames gimmick wagering for the hankypanky it says has been going on at race tracks.

title: 4 Chicago Policemen Questioned on Murders of 6 Black Men in'71
description: CHICAGO, June 24Chicago Police Superintendent James B. Conlisk conceded yesterday that the police department was questioning four policemen about their roles in an execu tion ring believed responsible for the murders of six black men during the last year.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Demons of Paranoia
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer is both an oldfashioned storyteller and a mod ern psychological writer. His large chronicle novelssuch as The Fam ily Moskat, The Manor and The Estateare thick with plot and characters and draw us into the rich and complex life of the Eastern Eu ropean Jewish communities. Singer's short stories, especially those in Short Friday and The Spinoza of Market Street, often take us into another worldthat of dybbuks and demons. Fables built upon man's most perverse yet common weakness es and longings, these demon stories are less realistic than the epic novels, but their intensity is sustained by a weird and driving psychological force.

title: Man Shoots Wife and Kills Self When Police Arrive
description: TEANECK, N.J., June 24  A 44yearold man shot and wounded his wife and, after the police arrived and ordered him to give up, shot and killed himself here tonight, the po lice here said. The incident took place at the couple's residence at 61 VanBuskirk Road.

title: Portnoy Should Complain
description: ERNEST LEHMAN should sue. Seven weeks ago the Movie Mailbag published a letter by Mr. Lehman defending Dr. Aaron Stern, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America's rating board, against charges that Dr. Stern had interfered with Mr. Leh man's adaptation of Philip Roth's Portnoy's Com plaint.

title: DOROTHY S. PHILLIPS, SHORT STORY WRITER
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., June 24 Mrs. Dorothy Phillips Hunt ington, a shortstory writer who wrote under her maiden name, Dorothy Sanburn Phillips, died in a nursing home here yester day. She was 79 years old.

title: Margaret G. Chapman Married In Jersey to John W. Herbert Jr.
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 24Miss Margaret Gorham Chapman was married here this afternoon to John W. Herbert Jr. The Rev. S. Hughes Garvin performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Epis copal Church.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Accountants are supposed to be thin introverts who are concerned with debits and credits and such dry fare and who make you think of ledgers and Bob Cratchit. But John Campbell Burton, the 39yearold educator who last week became the Secur ities and Exchange Commis sion's new chief accountant, is an outgoing 235pound GiantsMetsRangers fan and an activist.

title: Miss Doris jami Bride of Richard Licht
description: At the Forest Hills (Queens) Jewish Center last night, Miss Doris Jami, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Jami of New York, was married to Richard Licht, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Licht of Providence, R. I. Rabbi Ben Zion Bokser per formed the ceremony, as sisted by Rabbi Barton Lee.

title: May the Dick Caveat Show Continue
description: TV Mailbag

title: New York
description: New York

title: Phase 2: Lilco's Headache
description: The Wage Board and Price Commission have created a headache for the Long Is land Lighting Company, but so far the pain has been minor.

title: Willowbrook Boy Injured; Woman Aide Is Suspended
description: A unidentified woman attend ant has been suspended at Wil lowbrook State School on Staten Island after a 10year old retarded boy was found with welts on his back.

title: A playwright's biography, a playwright's memoir
description: From 1918 until 1955 George S. Kaufman was one of the most im portant figures in the American thea ter, as playwright, director, critic, once or twice even a performer, and of course, always as one of Broad way's resident wits. In 37 years he had a hand in writing 45 produc tions. Twentyseven of these were hits, and 18 were failures. It is an impressive record, and it must also be remembered that he worked on many other plays that for some rea son or another never saw the light of night.

title: Capt. Martha Stuart, Army Nurse, Wed
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Capt. Martha Jean Stuart, Nursing Corps, U.S.A. was married here this afternoon to Charles Wood Jewett Jr., who is completing require ments for a master's degree in African studies at Ohio University. The Rev, Donald C. Stuart, grandfather of the bride performed the Epis copal ceremony in the Walter Reed Memorial Chapel at the Walter Reed General Hos pital, where the bride is sta tioned with the medical in tensive care unit.

title: Lon Nol to Take Oath
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 24 (AP)President Lon Nol will take the civil oath of office as Cambodia's first President on July 3. A more elaborate and traditional religious ceremony will be held July 4.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Miss Julie C. Geisler Is Wed To William Howard in St. Paul
description: ST. PAUL, June 24Sena tor Hubert H. Humphrey has interrupted his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination for a weekend of socializing in his home state.

title: Aid for Victims of Flood
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) if anyone wants to help vic tims of the flood at Rapid City, S. D., send bedding of any kind but no clothing, please, the Government has requested. The Office of Emergency Prepared ness, helping to coordinate aid to the stricken area.

title: SandlerWeber Duo Wins In SingleWall Handball
description: Steve Sandler and Don Weber, the No. 1seeded team, advanced yesterday in the Na tional A.A.U. singlewall men's doubles handball championships at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

title: New Book Recounts Mrs. Roosevelt's Criticisms of American Policy Concerning Palestine Early in 1948
description: Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was so upset about what she considered to be growing mili tary influence on foreign policy during the first months of the Truman Administration that she threatened to make her dis agreement public and resign from the United States dele gation to the United Nations.

title: Mrs. Straub Subdues Mrs. Hart by 5 and 3 for the Metropolitan Golf Title
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 24Mrs. Austin Straub of the Huntington Country Club won the 69th annual Women's Met ropolitan Golf Association championship today by defeat ing Mrs. A. S. Hart of Baltru sol, 5 and 3, in the 36hole final round over the 5,822yard, par72 Creek Club course.

title: Patricia Haystead Wed in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, June 24In the Chapel at the St. Xavier School here this evening Miss Patricia Hollister Potts Hay stead, daughter of Mrs. Ladd Haystead of Rutherford, N. J., and the late John Hollister Potts of New York, was married to Frederick Gerald Cloppert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cloppert of Norwood. The Rev. William Creed per formed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Joelle Jons, Actress, Is Bride Of Julian Kheel, Home Builder
description: Miss Mary Jane Grubach, an actress known profession ally as Joelle Jons, was mar ried in Our Saviour Roman Catholic Church here yester day afternoon to Julian Kheel, president of Kheel Homes, Inc., and past president of the Rochester Home Builders Association. The Rev. Joseph M. Gleeson performed the ecumenical ceremony, which incorporated Old Testament readiags and portions of the Hebrew marriage rite into the nuptial mass.

title: Bibby of U.C.L.A. Signs Contract With Knicks
description: The New York Knicks, hoping to pick up backcourt strength, signed a guard, Henry Bibby of U.C.L.A. yesterday.

title: Varsity Status Has Few Seekers
description: College Sports Notes

title: DON'T START WINS TITLE IN JUMPING
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 Don't Start finished second in the stake, the last of six classes in the division, and won the amateurowner jumper championship today at the closing session of the 49th an nual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

title: Saint Joan? Lord, Lord!
description: JOAN of Arc and I go back a long way together. When I was valedicto rian of Joan of Arc Ju nior High School, some time around 1953, our school song went like this:

title: Eligibility Problems Becloud Olympic Track Trials
description: With possible political storms still brewing before the last hurdle, Ameri can track and field athletes will pack four years of training into 10 days of trials for berths on the United States Olympic team starting Thursday in Eugene, Ore.

title: Astronauts to Conduct Isolation Experiment
description: HOUSTON, June 24 (AP) In a dress rehearsal for the Skylab space missions planned for next year, three astronauts will spend up to 56 days in a 20squarefoot altitude test chamber at the Manned Spacecraft Center here starting July 19.

title: Wendy J. Thorsen Bride Of Russell MacMullan Jr.
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 24Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Wendy Josephine Thorsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Thorsen, to Russell Jamison MacMul lan Jr., son of Mr. MacMul lan of Washington and Mrs. Henry Snowden Rigby of Media, Pa., and Beach Haven, N. J. The Rev. Mark S. Sisk performed the ceremony.

title: Sarah Watson Hartford Bride
description: HARTFORD, June 24Miss Sarah Ann Watson and Sperry Andrews DeCew were married here this afternoon in the Asylum Hill Congrega tional Chapel. The Rev. Dr. Robert A. Preston of Lexing ton, Ky., uncle of the bride and a minister of the Chris tian Church (Disciples of Christ), performed the cere mony. He was assisted by the Rev. Bernard T. Drew of the Asylum Hill chapel.

title: U.S. RECORD SET BY PREFONTAINE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 24 (UPI)Steve Prefontaine ran to an American record in the 3,000 meters today, beating his near est competitor by 100 yards in a highlight of the Rose Festival track meet on a cold, drizzly afternoon.

title: PHONERATE REFUND WILL NOT BE MADE
description: ALBANY, June 24An order directing the New York Tele phone Company to refund about $18million of a rate in crease was rescinded Friday by the State Public Service Com mission.

title: The Nation
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn thought the Supreme Court decision last Monday was constructive. Every baseball executive agreed with him. Not so, the playersand the conflict ing views raised the possibility of a called strike in baseball's future. The Court, by a 5to3 vote, had ruled that unlike other sports or other industries, baseball is exempt from antitrust statutes.

title: Coins
description: YOUTH had a big day in the nation's capi tal recently when a special ceremony was staged at the White House to mark the introduction of the United States Mint's newest publication titled Our American Coins. Tricia Nixon Cox was on hand to greet the many young guests and she was recipient of the first copy of the 24page magazine, which was presented by Mrs. Mary T. Brooks, Director of the Mint.

title: The World
description: The longexpected signal came last Monday. As of midnight that day, the French Government said, all ships and planes should stay clear of the French nuclear testing grounds on Mururoa Island in the Pacific. That meant that France's new test series preparations for which had been under way for weeks was about to begin, with the principal purpose of devel oping a miniaturized nuclear warhead for the French sub marine fleet.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MITCHELL, S. D., June 24 Somehow the impression seems to have gotten around the country that Senator George McGovern is not a politiciannot in the good old American sense of the word, at least.

title: U.S. Open and Mrs. PungReturn to Winged Foot
description: Fifteen years ago, when the women's United States Open championship ended at the Winged Foot Golf Club in Ma maroneck, Mrs. Jackie Pung was in tears. The robust Ha waiian, the apparent champion, learned that she had inadver tently signed an iitcorrect score card and thereby lost the title by disqualification. Club mem bers rushed about soliciting funds from spectators and $3, 000 was raised for the de pressed golfer.

title: Miss Sandra E. Leonard Bride Of H. T. Starr, a Film Producer
description: OAKLAND, N. J., June 24 Miss Sandra Elizabeth Leonard and Harrison Truitt Starr, a film producer, were married here this afternoon.

title: Samuel Schwartz, 91, Dies; A Jersey Realtor 60 Years
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 24 Samuel Schwartz, a real es tate developer in this area for 60 years, died here yesterday at the age of 91. He lived at 735 Park Avenue.

title: LAW FIRM FACES SEXBIAS HEARING
description: The City Commission on Human Rights charged yester day that the law firm of Royall, Koegel & Wells, 200 Park Avenue, had practiced sex discrimination in the re cruitment, hiring, promotion and treatment of women law yers.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN

title: Pop
description: MUCH against his will and, I suspect, his better judgment, Randy Newman is becoming a force to reckon with in popular music. Since the sixties are not the seven ties, he is not likely to have the kind of impact Bob Dylan did, but in his own quiet, de ceptively unobtrusive fashion, Newman is carving out an area of expression for the popular song that hasn't been rivaled for lyric sophis tication and musical com plexity since the salad days of Cole Porter.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON In Chicago in 1968, the riots were outside the con vention hall, one Democratic leader observed last week. In Miami in 1972, they're going to be inside, and the reformers are responsible for the change of scene.

title: AFGHAN IS NAMED RHINEBECK'S BEST
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y., June 24 Eight weeks ago, a silverblue Afghan bitch, Ch. Caravan's Blue Passion, won her first group at the Central New York Show and there was a big cele bration in the Alexander (San dy) Schwartz household at Tux edo Park, N.Y.

title: The World
description: ANCONA, Italy  During the day, the old Adriatic seaport of Ancona struggles to stay alive. The post of fice operates out of a truck, a drugstore out of a mini bus. Some work goes on.

title: Soviet Party to Weed Out Passive Communists
description: MOSCOW, June 24The Soviet Union today published plans for a nationwide review of the Communist party's rank and file with the aim of purging those not worthy of the high calling of Communist.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Deirdre Ayres Married to Banker
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 24Mrs. Deirdre Jones Ayres, granddaughter of Hubert Hartigan, trainer to the Aga Khan, was married here at noon today to Edward Patter son, grandson of the late Justice Edward Patterson, who was Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, New York.

title: Greenwich Seeks Court Order To Halt Power Plant Emissions
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 Irate town officials and resi dents are seeking a court in junction to stop a defective Penn Central power plant in Cos Cob from showering boats, automobiles, houses and swim ming pools with coal dust.

title: Possible Health Crises Resulting From Deficits Are Seen by Hospital Official
description: A deficit of at least $75 million confronts the major voluntary hospitals in New York City, according to T. Gor don Young, president of the Greater New York Hospital As sociation.

title: Schumacher Likely to Give Muncey Run for Gold Cup on the Detroit Today
description: DETROIT, June 24  This course is the roughest and toughest challenge in hydro plane racing, asserted Bill Schumacher on the eve of to morrow's $44,000 Gold Cup race.

title: Miss Julie D. S. Ripley Married To R. S. Ridgely, Duke Student
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 24Miss Julie Dillon Storm Ripley was married here at noon to Robert Stirling Ridgely by the Rev. David F. Gunniak in St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sign Language Used on TV To Give Storm Data to Deaf
description: WASHINGTON, June 24A Washington television station employed a sign language ex pert this week to try to get weather and flood warnings to the deaf during its broadcasts about conditions during the re cent storm.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Administration's symphony began to reach crescendo proportions last week on the issue of Government spend ing, with the instruments working perfectly together.

title: Student Weds Miss Kaplan
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 Miss Susanna Ruth Kaplan, a senior at the University of Chicago, and Louis George Lenzi, who is completing work for a master's degree there, were married at noon today in the Unitarian Church in Westport.

title: OTTINGER TO RUN AS FOE OF CRIME
description: YONKERS, June 24 Richard L. Ottinger, the for mer Westchester County Rep resentative, announced this week that the issue of crime control would play a major part in his campaign for re election to the House.

title: Horse Show News
description: The American Horse Shows Association has given owners and trainers until next Saturday to comply with its ban on abnormal amounts of Vitamin B1 (thiamine hydrocloride).

title: Friends Say Goodby to A linsky: Kaddish, Drinks, a Few Laughs
description: CHICAGOThey said the Kaddishthe Hebrew prayer for the deadfor Saul David Alinsky, and then his friends went to the back room of a bar named the Boul Mich and told stories and laughed, which was what he would have wanted.

title: Nassau County Adds to Cultural Life
description: GARDEN CITY, L. LThe appetite was there and we gave them something to chew on, said John W. Maerhofer, director of the Nassau County Office of Cul tural Development, in assess ing the operations of his of fice, which is just a year old.

title: Astros Turn Back Reds, 41, and Regain First Place in National League West
description: CINCINNATI, June 24 (UPI) Cesar Cedeno drove in two runs with a single and a dou ble and Lee May added a home run as the Houston Astros de feated the Cincinnati Reds, 41, behind Larry Dierker's seven hit pitching to regain first place in the National League West tonight.

title: The Short, Unhappy Life Of Black Presidential Politics, 1972
description: LAST Christmas Eve, a political aeon ago, John V. Lindsay in vited Shirley Chisholm to Gracie Mansion. Over a dram of Yuletide cheer, the Mayor of New York urged the Congresswoman from Bedford Stuyvesant to abandon her quixotic quest for the Presidency so that he could more successfully pursue his. But Fighting Shirley Chisholm, as she likes to call herself, wasn't hav ing any of it. She remembers that the conversation went like this:

title: If Europe Floats Currencies, Japanese May Follow
description: TOKYO, June 24 (Reuters) A Japanese monetary offi cial said today that Japan might allow the yen to float if West European nations de cide to float their currencies against the United States dollar.

title: TOWNSEND, CURTIS WIN ELITE PAIRS
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 24Crews bucked 30milean hour headwinds but the waters of the Orchard Beach Lagoon remained comparatively calm today for the 104th annual New York Athletic Club's open re gatta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 23 SewageTreatment Plants Urged Along Shore
description: TOMS RIVERThe state and the Federal Government have scheduled a fourday conference here this week at which they will present a joint implementation plan for ending pollution along the Jersey shore by the end of 1976.

title: BANKER TO AID HUNT FOR THE PEKING MAN
description: CHICAGO, June 24 (AP)A Chicago investment banker who has returned from a trip to China says that he made a close relationship with the Communist Chinese by pledg ing support and a $5,000 re ward in a hunt for the prehis toric Peking man, missing since Pearl Harbor was attacked by the Japanese on Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Hawaii Awaits a Dock Strike Tomorrow
description: HONOLULU, June 24Ha waiians braced today for their first major waterfront strike in 23 years, while the state gov ernment pondered whether to invoke a dockseizure law to keep vital cargo moving.

title: I. B. Singer, Storyteller
description: You don't have to know Yiddish to translate Isaac Bashevis Singer. In fact, better not to. Singer isn't always tolerant of other Yiddishists; his remarks on his contemporaries, not to say his peers, are often se vere. I've helped Isaac Singer put some of his stories, essays and a play into English in recent years, by which I mean that he read his Yiddish manuscript aloud, translat ing freely into English as he went along, and I copied it down, doing my best to preserve the author's art while helping shape the best Eng lishlanguage expression of it. Often this led to debate over a word, a phrase, a sentiment. Sometimes the conversation moved into philosophy of life as well as art.

title: SEAVER IS CHASED
description: The New York Mets saluted their checkered past Yesterday before 45,334 fans in their an nual OldTimers' observance, but they overdid it.

title: MORE BLACK FANS SOUGHT BY HAWKS
description: ATLANTA, June 24  The subject was basketball, or more specifically, how to get more blacks to attend Atlanta Hawks' games.

title: Marko to Drive Ferrari Today
description: MODENA, Italy, June 24 (UPI)Helmut Marko of Aus tria will replace Clay Regaz zoni of Switzerland tomorrow as codriver of the Ferrari's No. 1 car for the 1,000 kilom eters of Zeltweg auto race. Re gazzoni broke a wrist playing soccer with other drivers yes terday.

title: Britain's Gypsies Face New Curbs on Traveling Life
description: LONDON, June 24On a flat asphalt field in East Lon don, Mrs. Charity Eastwood steps out of her battered trailer each morning to heat up a pot of coffee. The open fire flickers. She pauses, then stares at the cars streaming toward the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Captain Named
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 23 Peter H. Korsan has been named captain of Princeton University's 197273 baseball team, succeeding Bill Binder. The Wallinford, Pa., native batted fourth last season and compiled a 292 batting average. He plays center field.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONTo obtain his nu clear armslimitation agreement in Moscow last month, President Nixon had to strike a hard bargain with the Russians. In the past two weeks it has become evident that he also had to strike a bargain with Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird and the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: William Yerkes Weds Elizabeth B. Lassiter
description: Miss Elizabeth Burr Las siter was married here yester day afternoon to William Henry Joyce Yerkes, state house correspondent in Tren ton for The New Tribune of Woodbridge, N. J. The Rev. James Leo performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine (New York Cathe dral).

title: 33 Teachers at West Point Leave Army in 18 Months
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 24  The United States Military Academy has been stung by a series of resignations by many of its most successful and brightest young officers assign ed to teach and train cadets.

title: The Nation
description: It's a kind of Catch22 situation, said Liz Robbins of New York City's Agency for Child Development last week. The catch: Under programs fostered by the United States De partment of Health, Education and Welfare, the city is obligated to in crease sharply the number of children enrolled in preschool programs, from 35,000 this year to an expected 50,000 next year; but under rules enforced by the Department of Agriculture, the money to feed these 15,000 new chil dren is not being increased. Thus the new entrants will have to go without the traditional breakfastthough they will still get lunchwhile those al ready enrolled will get that first meal.

title: 5 Feet of Rain in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, June 24 (AP) Nearly five feet of rain poured on Hong Kong in the last eight weeks, the Royal Observatory said today. Fiftyseven inches, more than twice the normal precipitation for this time of year, was officially measured at the observatory on the main land. A rainstorm last week caused landslides with a toll of 100 dead.

title: Gardens
description: NEARLY 20 years ago, I sighted a frail nest of rose breasted gros breaks in an old apple tree in Inwood Hill Park on the northernmost tip of Man hattan. It was the birds that engaged my interest then, not the tree. The male grosbeak, especially, was an esthetic delight. As I sat in the high spring grass, leaning com fortably against the trunk of a fallen oak, this predomi nantly black bird with the rosy breast and pure white abdomen sang his sweetrobin song from an arching branch of that fallen oak.

title: U.S. FUNDS SOUGHT FOR ART CENTERS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24 The first National Conference on Community Arts ended here yesterday with the decision to lobby in Washington, through the Community Arts League, for direct Government funding of local cultural centers.

title: Republicans' Parley Renominates Brooke
description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP) The Republican State Con vention today nominated Senator Edward W. Brooke by acclamation for a second term.

title: Son to Stuart Davises
description: NEW HAVEN, June 24A son was born June 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Hill Davis in the YaleNew Haven Hospi tal. Mrs. Davis is the former Miss Elaine Buschhoff of New York. Her husband is a re search assistant at the Yale Medical School. The child has been named Christopher Stuart.

title: Press
description: One year after their historic confrontation in the Pentagon Papers case, The New York Times and the Justice De partment  more particular ly the United States Attor ney for the Southern District of New York, Whitney North Seymour Jr.  were involved in another serious dispute. On Wednesday, Mr. Seymour accused The Times and The New York Daily News of doing a great disservice to the people of the city by publishing details of an un dercover investigation into corruption among high law enforcement officials in the city. The investigations would have to be brought to an abrupt halt, said Mr. Seymour, since they de pended on secrecy for suc cess and the newspapers had disclosed those direct ly involved in corrupt prac tices  who might have been utilized in undercover investigative work. Suffi cient evidence had not been developed to bring indict ments, Mr. Seymour said, and now, because of the pre mature disclosures, none was likely to be brought.

title: U.S. TITLE FENCING STARTS SATURDAY
description: The United States national fencing championships, which will largely determine the makeup of this summer's American Olympic fencing team, open Saturday at Bent ley College in Waltham, Mass.

title: JOB SHIFT URGED ON YOUNG JEWS
description: Jewish young men and women face relatively great er jobhunting difficulties in the nineteenseventies and should give more considera tion to nonprofessional jobs than they have in the past, according to a new Federal analysis.

title: Typecast Captures Coast Turf Stakes
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 24 The mare Typecast upset Cougar II and eight other male rivals in a photo finish today in capturing the $125,000 Invi tational Turf Handicap at Hol lywood Park.

title: Sandra V. Williams Has Nuptials on L.I.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., June 24Miss Sandra Virginia Wil liams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Barnwell Wil liams of Manhasset, was married at noon today to Douglas George Ferguson. He is the son of Mrs. Harold Ferguson of Port Washington and the late Mr. Ferguson.

title: MRS. PERCY BRIDGMAN
description: ACTON, Mass., June 24Mrs. Olive Ware Bridgman, widow of Prof. Percy W. Bridgman, 1946 Nobel laureate in physics, died last evening. She was 90 years old and lived in Cambridge and in Randolph, N. H.

title: DONDE TAKES RACE IN Y.R.A.'S REGATTA
description: RYE, N.Y., June 24William E. John Jr. won with his Inter national Class sloop, Donde, by six seconds and one length on Long Island Sound today and Robert F. Shattuck sailed Sera fina to a 1minute12second, 10length Etchells22 Class vic tory in the 12th Yacht Racing Association championship re gatta of the season.

title: MRS. JOHN CONNELLY Jr.
description: Mrs. Troy Stix Connelly, a clothes designer in the 1930's and 1940's, and wife of John E. Connelly Jr., retired partner in the firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donneil & Weyher, lawyers at 299 Park Avenue, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Lindner Triumphs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 24Ken Lindner of Brook lyn, a Harvard player, defeated Bob Greene of New York, City College coach, 63, 26, 61, to win the Eastern men's clay court tennis championship to day at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Mary Heston Bride of Jonathan Sands
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 24  Miss Mary Henderson Heston and Jonathan Bader Sands were married here this afternoon in the garden of the 100yearold home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William May Heston. The Heston residence is one of the original 40 houses built by Alexander T. Stewart, developer of Garden City. New York State Supreme Court Justice Steven Derou nian performed the ceremony.

title: Chinese Are Harnessing Perilous Yellow River
description: CHENGCHOW, China  Ma Yinting is an engineer, by all accounts one of the best men in his field. But more than that, he is that rare thing, an engineer who talks the layman's language.

title: Thai Company Quits Seoul, Ending Role in U.N. Force
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 24 A company of Thai soldiers bid farewell to South Korea in a ceremony here this week, marking the end of Thailand's troop contribution to the Ameri canled United Nations com mand in Korea.

title: Midgets Seek to Beat Weather In Auto Races at Trenton Today
description: About Motor Sports

title: HELEN ROWAN, 45, EDUCATION EDITOR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 Helen Rowan, a writer, editor and member of the staff of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, died of cancer yesterday at her home here. She was 45 years old.

title: State Health Unit Gets Grant
description: The State Health Department reported yesterday a $16,200 Federal grant for its Burns Care Institute to study injuries linked with flammable clothing, up holstery, bedding or similar household fabrics. The oneyear grant from the Food and Drug Administration's bureau of product safety will cover 150 detailed investigations.

title: Kissinger, Often Seen, Is Finally Heard on TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Henry A. Kissinger's brief ing on his China trip today marked the first time since he joined the Nixon Adminis tration that television crews have been allowed by the White House to record his voice as well as his image on film.

title: The 10,000,000year swim and African corporate styles
description: It is, and has been for too long, open season for silly books about hu man nature and human evolution. Books like The Naked Ape, Afri can Genesis, and On Aggression might he forgiven if they did not make a mockery of man's serious ef forts to understand himself, and if they did not commit the offense in the name of science and objectivity. Invariably, they inform us that it is high time to clear the decks and get down to earth for an honest un cluttered view of man as he is, not as he has been pictured to us by peo ple who have been studying him. Let the reader beware. This nononsense approach is as suspect as conversa tions which start with To be frank or Let's face it. It is producing some of the greatest nonsense ever published in the history of pseudo science.

title: Curbing Meat Prices
description: President Nixon's hint that he will lift quotas on meat imports as a means of checking the present uptrend in meat prices is welcome in intent but not likely to be of real help in holding down prices. A worldwide excess of de mand over supply makes it improbable that a temporary suspension of quotas will bring any large increase in meat shipments from Australia or anywhere else.

title: Miss Hall Wed To B. K. Alford.
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 24 Miss Susanne Stuart Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Hall of Plainfield and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Bryant Kittinger Alford, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Edwin Alford of Buffalo, N. Y. The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Mead performed the ceremony at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn.,Cotton, once dethroned as the king of fibers, is enjoying a renewed favor in the world of tex tiles.

title: The World
description: BELFAST  Shortly after 2 P.M. last Thursday the telephones rang in Dublin newspaper offices and a state ment was quickly read: The Irish Republican Army will suspend offensive operations from midnight, Monday, June 26, 1972, provided that a public reciprocal response is forthcoming from the armed forces of the British Crown.

title: Don't Fence Them In
description: The move of the football Giants to New Jersey got considerable attention last week in the Senate Com merce Committee considering the creation of a Federal sports commission.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: KISSINGER DETECTS NO CHANGE ON WAR AFTER CHINA VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Henry A. Kissinger said today that he had discussed the Viet nam war at length with Chi nese leaders but reported no clear signs of a break in the present diplomatic impasse.

title: Wedding Plan Reported For Hussein's Daughter
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24  Sultan Qabus BinSaid of Oman, who arrived in Amman today on a state visit to Jordan, is to marry King Hus sein's eldest daughter, Prin cess Alia, according to in formed diplomatic sources here.

title: Woman Umpire Quits In Tears After Debut
description: GENEVA, N.Y., June 24 The first woman umpire in organized baseball, Mrs. Ber nice Gera, resigned in tears tonight after having worked her first game.

title: Politicians Dealt Blow In Nassau And Suffolk
description: YAPHANK, L.I. Dominic 3, Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic chair man, walked casually into the Board of Elections head quarters early last Wednes day morning and surveyed the damage done to his party organization in the primary.

title: The Nation
description: One day several months ago, Edwin James Grace, 33, appeared at the of fices of Key Personnel, Inc., in subur ban Cherry Hills, N. J. He had pre viously worked as a guard for the Pinkerton Detective Agency and was looking for a job in his line of work, security. Key had nothing for him, and last April Grace went back to work for Pinkerton. But, authorities in Cherry Hill theorized last week, he must have brooded about Key's fail ure to find him a job.

title: Headliners
description: Joan Baez, the folksinger, became a marcher for the civil rights movement from the beginning, and when the United States became deeply involved in Vietnam, she took up the antiwar cry. Now, at 31, she is regarded as a sort of professional protester and her involvement in as she puts itradical, nonviolent action is familiar. Last week Miss Baez was at it again. After weeks of or ganizing work in Washington, she led more than 2,000 women and children who linked hands in a ring around the Capitol to protest the continued Congressional funding of the war. More than $4.5billion will go next year into blowing up Indochina, the singer declared. We're saying, keep that money at home.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Three obstacles loom in the path of Senator George Mc Govern's campaign as it rushes toward the Democratic Con vention in Miami Beach.

title: Bremer Attorneys Assert Publicity Bars a Fair Trial
description: BALTIMORE, June 24 (AP) Attorneys for Arthur H. Brem er have charged that adverse publicity surrounding the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has denied the suspect the right of a fair trial.

title: A Russian, Weary of Waiting in Lines, Suggests BillPaying by Withholding
description: MOSCOW, June 24You're a Russian and you've a bill to pay. It has been strictly on a cash basis so far in a country where personal checks are un known and, anyway, smack of bourgeois wealth and money in the bank.

title: A playwright's biography, a playwright's memoir
description: At the age of 77, S. N. Behrman, author of five books and 20 plays, has extracted a memoir from the 60 volumes of a diary he has kept since 1915. It is, to begin with, a delightful and endearing collection of anecdotes involving such people as George and Ira Gershwin, Ina Claire, Garbo, Ernst Lubitsch, the Lunts and many eminent literary figures.

title: Pamela Dixon Married to Banker
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 24In a candlelight cere mony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this evening, Miss Pamela Lynn Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl N. B. Dixon of River side, was married to W. Gib son Harris 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Rich mond, Va., and Delray Beach, Fla., by the Rev. James E. Annad.

title: Nixon to Fight Democrats on Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, June 24At the risk of a partisan battle on a politically popular issue, the White House was reported prepared today to fight a Dem ocratic attempt to rush a 20 per cent increase in Social Se curity benefits through Con gress next week.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: GARDINERS ISLAND TOUR IV See page 32. Sect. 2 todayAdvt.

title: MORE BLACK FANS SOUGHT BY HAWKS
description: ATLANTA, June 24  The subject was basketball, or more specifically, how to get more blacks to attend Atlanta Hawks' games.

title: A Treasure in Old Posters
description: MAPLEWOOD  In these days of troubled financial times in education, with schools searching in all di rections for funds, Columbia High here suddenly found it self sitting on a veritable treasure  more than 700 World War I posters stored on a high, outofreach shelf in the school vault.

title: Israel Gives Warning
description: TEL AVIV, June 24 (Reuters) Israel warned today that she was ready to strike hard in re ply to any attempt by guerrilla forces from Lebanon to con tinue attacks against Israeli citizens and settlements.

title: World News Briefs
description: BONN, June 24Chancellor Willy Brandt and Foreign Min ister Walter Scheel declared in Berlin today that they would seek federal elections in No vember to end the tievote situ ation that has stymied the Parliament since April.

title: Backyard Is an Art Gallery
description: ENGLEWOOD A pleas ant, slightly overgrown back yard in a middleclass black neighborhood here will make its annual transformation into an art gallery this after noon for a oneman show by A. C. Hollingsworth.

title: A Program for Aged Has Growing Pains
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I,More than seven years ago, a vol unteer program was started here to help meet the needs of elderly people. It expanded dramaticaly and now, its or ganizers say, a major prob lem has risen out of its popularity.

title: The Nation
description: Women got the vote in 1920 but they have got little in politics since. They have been the gofers, the stamp smashers and the matronly party co leaders or vicechairmen who were strictly window dressing to be intro duced at party functions as the real boss with appropriate snickers from the real boss and the audience.

title: Photography
description: ONE wonders how our own Civil War would have ended if Matthew Brady and his photog raphers had been able to take instantaneous photo graphs of wounded soldiers dying in agony. There was in the North a peace party quite as vociferous as the peace party in the United States today. There were riots against the war far bloodier and more violent than any peace demonstra tion today, and on several occasions Northern oppo nents of the war hampered its conduct so seriously that President Lincoln saw fit to suspend the right of habeas corpus and imprison them by the thousands without trial.

title: Catalogue Operations Simplify Shopping
description: The bulky merchandise cat alogue, long a mainstay in shopping by mail, has also simplified shopping in the store.

title: STRANDED MOTORIST SHOT ON VAN WYCK
description: A motorist was shot and slightly wounded shortly before 9 P.M. yesterday after his car became disabled and he had to stop on the Liberty Avenue exit ramp of the Van Wyck Express way in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Discovered Footprint May Be of Stone Age
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)Discovery of what may be the oldest human foot print known  conceivably from a Stone Age childhas been announced by the Na tional Geographic Society.

title: Southampton Prevails As Haven for Shoppers
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.For more than a century, this 332yearold village, the first English settlement in the state, has been a popular and wealthy summer resort. In the winter months, the residents number 5,000, but come Memorial Day week end, when the season begins and summer residents arrive, the number swells to 15, 000 in the 6squaremile area.

title: N. R. Nichols Marries Jan Hudgins
