description: Miss Jan Agnesta Hudgins, daughter of William Ran dolph Hudgins, former pres ident of the Freedom Na tional Bank, and Mrs. Hud gins of New York, was mar ried here yesterday morning to Nathan Richard Nichols, son of Bishop Roy C. Nichols, head of the United Methodist Church in Western Pennsyl vania, and Mrs. Nichols of Pittsburgh.

title: Adelphi Biology Unit Seeking Boats
description: OAKDALE, L. I.The In stitute of Marine Biology of Adelphi University is seeking unusual donations: It wants any old boats it can get.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe city of Balti more would get $19.4million this year as much money as it would realize from an acrosstheboard property tax increase that would raise the taxes on a $25,000 house from $787 to $882.

title: Miss Gilliams Wed to David W. Eden
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 24  Miss Elizabeth Leslie Gilliams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Flem ing Gilliams Jr. of North port, was married today to David Ward Eden, son of Bronston B. T. Eden of Mill Neck and of Mrs. Dorothy Ward Eden of Locust Valley.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Depletion Allowances For Bodies Are Barred
description: SAN FRANSICO, June 24 (UPI)An appellate court has ruled against a lawyer who had attempted to claim depletion allowances on his and his wife's bodies.

title: TWO TEXAS GOLFERS SHARE N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: CAPE CORAL, Fla., June 24 (UPI)Tom Rite of the Uni versity of Texas fired a four underpar 68 and a teammate, Ben Crenshaw, struggled to a 72 today to tie for the National Collegiate individual golf title and lead Texas to its second straight championship.

title: Young and Foolish and Groton Miss Win Divisions of PostDeb at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT N. J., June 24 The PostDeb Stakes at Mon mouth Park today was a study in contrasts.

title: Amsterdam Court Decides Hippies May Sleep in Park
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, June 24 (UPI)The Am sterdam Court has confirmed a ruling of the lower district court that Dutch and foreign hippies may sleep in a part of the down town Vondel Park.

title: OSSIE DAVIS GETS POST IN FESTIVAL
description: CHICAGO, June 24Ossie Davis, the actor and producer, was selected yesterday as chair man of the American commit tee of the Second World Black Festival of Arts and Culture to be held in 1974 in Lagos, Nigeria.

title: Beirut Is Firm on Pact
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 Premier Saeb Salam said em phatically today that Lebanon would not clamp down on the Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Connors and Miss Evert Win at London
description: LONDON, June 24In the first American double here for 25 years, those brilliant teenagers, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert, took the titles today at the London grass court tennis champion ships, dress rehearsal for the Wimbledon fortnight.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drying Process Begins In Metropolitan Region
description: The metropolitan area began drying out yesterday after two weeks of sporadic rain that caused flooding in some places and disrupted commuter train and highway traffic.

title: WIDER ROLE ASKED FOR LAY CATHOLICS
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 More than 200 heads of Ro man Catholic religious orders this week urged the fullest possible patricipation of lay men in the church's decisions, including the selection of bishops, and called for more simplicity in the life style of the church.

title: What America wants to bea selfdestructive, beautiful boy
description: As the men and events of the past 40 years begin to gain the Kan sas flatness of perspective, only Howard Hughes still looms above the horizon, head and shoulders in the clouds. More than Roosevelt, more than MacArthur, more than Kennedy, even more than (either) Hoover, Howard Hughes is of mythic dimen sions. A combination of Mad Ahab and the White Whale, Howard Hughes is that which will never be known, not to himself even, not to a curious world certainly. He is above all else a huge and continuous demon stration of immaculate power, by which I mean power removed from the considerations which motivate the sons of men. Power in the hands of Howard Hughes is used as a child uses electricity, in the disin terestedness of play. He exercises that power from a remote vantage point, inaccessible, unapproachable, at once transcendent and immanent, yet ultimately whimsical. If there is a God, He must very much resemble Howard Hughes, even to the per sistent rumors concerning His death.

title: Ali 5 to 1 Over Jerry Quarry on Tuesday
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 24 (UPI)Muhammad Ali, a one man happening, steals the spot light wherever he goes and that's the way it is for Tues day night, when he faces Jerry Quarry in a 12round bout leading the way to a crack at Joe Frazier and the heavy weight title Ali once held.

title: SEA SAGA, $6.40, TAKES HANDICAP
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24  Because Jim Moseley can take orders from a woman and fol low them to the letter, the meet's leading jockey rode Sea Saga, the better half of Buck land Farm's entry, to a 1 length victory over Bright View Farm's Rosemont Bow today in the $28,875 Whitemarsh Han dicap at Liberty Bell race track where a crowd of 12,840 wa gered $1,343,757.

title: Retiring Patrolman Honored
description: Patrolman Walter Renkwitz, who has been walking a beat along Mott Street for the last 10 years, was honored on his retirement from the Police De partment yesterday at a China town community testimonial affair. A party for him was held at Transfiguration Audi torium, 29 Mott Street.

title: A Busy Executive Who Didn't Want to Sit Around on Weekends
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.Why should a busy New York executive spend his weekends lugging furniture around and riding herd on painters and gardeners?

title: Humphrey Warns Democrats of Control by the Elite
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey warned the Platform Commit tee of the Democratic National Convention today that if the party falls into the hands of any narrow, ideological elite it will lose the November elec tion to the forces of reaction, racism and privilege.

title: COSTA RICA KEEPS FIRM DEMOCRACY
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 19More than 40 years ago, long before he entered politics, President Jos Figueres Ferrer had a try at the hemp business. He called his enterprise the Struggle Without End.

title: Jon E. Stanat Weds Ruth Ellen Corrigan
description: Miss Ruth Ellen Corrigan and Jon Edmond Randolph Stanat, both of New York, were married here this after noon at Holy Trinity Luther an Church by the Rev. Robert D. Hershey. A reception was given at the Hotel St. Moritz.

title: MISS WALKER WINS BRITISH GOLF TITLE
description: HUNSTANTON, England, June 24 (AP)  Michelle (Mickey) Walker retained the British women's amateur golf cham pionship today with a 2up victory over Claudine Rubin of France in the final round.

title: Deborah Simpkins Bride of David Mazza
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 24Miss Deborah Lee Simpkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Lee Simpkins, was married here this after noon to David Lawrence Mazza, son of Mrs. Domenick Lawrence Mazza of Darien and the late Mr. Mazza.

title: JORDAN STRESSES PRAGMATIC VIEW
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 22 Pragmatism is a word that recurs frequently in conversa tions with Jordanian officials as well as diplomats observing King Hussein's policies toward his Israeli enemy, his Arab friends and his Western sup pliers of military and develop ment assistance, principally the United States.

title: Nassau to Expand. Prisoner Job Plan
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  A pro gram to send prisoners off to paying jobs in the outside world by day and return them to jail each night has proved so successful that Nassau County is about to widen its scope sevenfold.

title: Dean Anson 2d Marries Betty C. Robie
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 24The marriage of Miss Betty Carroll Robie to Dean Taylor Anson 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Anson of Bound Brook, N. J., took place this afternoon at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Robie, parents of the bride.

title: New York
description: The situation today is fine. We are reasonably confident that the likeli hood of a recurrence of a major power failure would be reasonably slim. Arthur Hauspurg, vice president of Consolidated Edison Company, July 22, 1969.

title: The Nation
description: The bill on the President's desk last Friday was one of the most farreach ing educational measures ever passed by the Congress. It established three principles of Federal aid that could have a major impact on the nation's colleges and universities: (1) Nearly every institution of higher learning will get Federal money to use as it wishes; (2) it will be national policy to see that every student who cannot af ford a college education will get some financial help from the Federal Gov ernment; (3) Federal assistance will be denied any graduate school or public undergraduate college that discrim inates against women in its admis sions policies.

title: Dance
description: OH to be in Canada now the Bolshoi's there. Well, perhaps not really, but it does seem a trifle odd that the Bolshoi Ballet can visit Can ada and, earlier this year, France, and yet not come to the United States. But there are questions that perhaps only Henry Kissinger knows the answer to, and probably Henry Kissinger has forgot ten. It is a pity that the Bolshodat least the full company  has not visited New York since 1966. We are the poorer, but then so also is the Bolshoi.

title: GALBRAITH TELLS OF LEAKING DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24 John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, has told the Federal District Court that is hearing the Pentagon papers case that he routinely leaked classified Government documents to the press when he was Ambassa dor to India and when he held other official positions.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 24 President Nixon, after viewing what Gov. Milton J. Shapp called the worst flood in the history of Pennsylvania, an nounced the establishment of a Federal office here today to work with the state authorities on a recovery program. The Governor estimated damage from the state's rainswollen rivers at more than $1billion.

description: The following information about today's television pro grams was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: MAURICE TUMARKIN, LED BAKER CLOTHES
description: Maurice Tumarkin, who re tired two years ago after 40 years as president of Baker Clothes, Inc., of New York and Philadelphia, men's clothing manufacturers, died Friday at the Harkness Pavilion. He was 72 years old and lived at 35 East 84th Street.

title: Music
description: READERS who are interested in musical mystery stories (there will be a short pause while all others drop out) are now directed to The Case of Schumann's Finger. If there is one detail of the composer's life known to every person who has ever skimmed a program note or a record an notation, it is that around 1830, when he was 20 years old, Robert Schumann attempted to speed up his progress toward piano, virtuosity by using a fin gerstretching apparatus, thereby crip pling a finger or fingers on his right hand and cutting his performing career short.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOP TALK
description: MONTVILLE  What hap pens to a lovely little rural town, with a population of 4,000, when 41 industrial concerns and 7,000 residents are added? If the growth was anticipated, and planned for, in 20 years it becomes a lovely big town, like Mont ville.

title: Zomoro of Mexico Wins In Olympic Boxing Meet
description: ELYRIA, Ohio, June 24 (AP) Alfonso Zomoro of Mexico was the only nonUnited States victor in the Olympic Western championship today.

title: A STATE IN INDIA ANGERS FARMERS
description: VELLANDIPALAYAM, India June 17Palanichamy Goun der, a wizened 60yearold farmer of this village, is sad and bitter.

title: But is it not strange that even elephants will yield and that The Prophet is still popular?
description: THEY are the Campus Cordials: hard on the outside, liquid sweetness within. Their attire is Undergraduate Militant: cool, neutral flares, army jacket emblazoned with the legend, If You Are Not Part of the Solution You Are Part of the Problem. Their backchat is peppered with references to confrontation tactics, neighborhood control, third world rage. But break off a piece of the exterior and look within. There, on the bottom of the backpack is the giveaway: The Prophet, adorned with a soulful, doleful portrait by the author, Kahlil Gibran.

title: Art Notes
description: DON POTTS'S First Car (now on view at the Whitney Museum) took him roughly six years to build, and one might call It a labor of loveor, at least, as someone put it, auto eroticism. It's not the usual breed of car, if you think in terms of GM, Chysler, Ferar ri, or even a hot rod. In fact, the four curious structures it consists ofbodyless, bi cyclewheeled and lowslung suggest nothing so much as futuristic proposals for cars that Leonardo might have done for his drawing books.

title: Photography
description: TWO new compact 35mm cameras have been in troduced by Konica Camera Corporation, 2520 BrooklynQueens Ex pressway West, Woodside, N.Y. 11377, as part of a new generation of the Konica C35.

title: Aides in Pentagon Predict A New Offensive by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Senior officers in the Pentagon expect the North Vietnamese to renew their offensive, using conventional tactics and weap ons, in the northern part of South Vietnam and in the Kon tum area of the Central High lands in the near future.

title: JAMIESON'S 202 LEADS GOLF BY 8
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill., June 24 Jim Jamieson, playing su perbly while his challengers faded, moved to the brink of his first victory as a pro golfer today with a round of 67 that gave him an eightstroke lead after the third round of the Western open tournament.

title: BRIDEGROOMTOBE SLAIN BY A MUGGER
description: Lawrence Weinstock, a 27 yearold maintenance worker at the Port Authority Bus Termi nal at 41st Street and Eighth Avenue, was to have been mar ried today. Instead he will be buried, the victim of a mugger who stabbed him.

title: Auto Recalls: Caveat Vendor
description: DETROITEarly this April in upstate New York the owner of a 1972 Plymouth began jacking up his car to change a tireand thus trig gered a chain of events that led to last Friday's recall of 56,000 cars.

title: Gold Beats Birbach
description: In one of the Democratic legislative contests that drew wide attention in Queens, Stage Senator Emanuel Gold won renomination by defeat ing Jerry Birbach, the leader of the opposition to the low income housing project in Forest Hills. The vote was 12,851 to 9,848.

title: Opera: Belated Debut for Maskarade
description: ST. PAUL, June 24Sym phonic works by Carl Niel sen, the Danish composer, have been performed with increasing frequency in this country during the last dec ade. Until now, however, his Maskarade, a comic opera, has never been produced in America.

title: Pele May Play Last Game Here Today
description: Fourteen years and a few million dollars later, Pel's be havior still has not changed much. As in 1958, when he was still an unknown outside of Brazil, he talks and smiles to everyone who addresses him; he neither smokes nor drinks, and he accepts criticism from jour nalists without bitterness.

title: Where It's Wet, Shady and Poorly Drained
description: THE problem of wet, shady areas plagues many gardeners. Some try to cope by ignor ing the situation and plant ing as if there were full sun and good drainage.

description: While curious adults smiled from behind the rail ings, third through sixth graders from five neighbor hood schools hoed, raked, chopped and planted a gar den on the lawn in front of the State Supreme Court Building in Brooklyn.

title: Miss Anne Daignault Is Bride Of Edward Winslow Campion
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., June 24  Miss Anne Daignault was married here this after noon to Edward Winslow Campion. The Rev. Barry G. Wood performed the cere mony in St. Bamabas Me morial Episcopal Church.

title: Conglomerate, Italian Style
description: ROME  MontecatiniEdi son S.p.A.the giant Italian concern with 180,000 work ers in everything from min ing and chemicals to elec tronics and retailingis dis covering, as have many of its American counterparts, that life as a conglomerate can be difficult.

title: For $3Million, Will Hull Leap?
description: Ben Hatskin, the Winnipeg corrugated box tycoon, expects to entice Bobby Hull to jump from the National Hockey League on Tuesday for a $3million, 10year package.

title: Love Is Hell, Warren
description: ASTRANGE man gave me a pair of hun dred dollar tickets to the McGovern rally produced by Warren Beatty at Madison Square Garden. That's what happened. The man didn't know I would tell the story of my love affair with Warren Beatty to The New York Times. He didn't even know I was having a love affair with Warren Beatty. Neither did Warren Beatty, if you want to nitpick about it. (I've been inspired by that French lady who wrote of her passion for Henry Kissinger despite his fat sausage fingers.)

description: A tropical storm that killed at least 100 persons and made more than half a million home less in the most devastating Eastern Seaboard floods of the century finally subsided yester day, and thousands of volun teers stepped up rescue and re habilitation work.

description: MILWAUKEE, June 24 (AP) John Briggs homered and Bob Heise stroked a tworun double today as the Milwaukee Brew ers beat Boston, 52. Eddie Kasko, the Red Sox manager, and two of his players were tossed out of the game.

title: Miss Trina Robinson Married in Ohio
description: PERRYSBURG, Ohio, June 24Miss Christine Lawrence Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson Davis Robinson 3d, and James Jay Secor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Secor Jr., were married here this evening in St. Timothy's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Edward Noyes Burdick of St. Luke's Epis copal Church in Granville, Ohio, assisted by Canon Lau rence Hall of St. Timothy's.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 24 (AP)  Aides to Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama insisted today that he was still planning to at tend the Democratic National Convention starting July 10 in Miami Beach.

title: Vital Supplies Are Airlifted Upstate To Thousands Afflicted by Flooding
description: CORNING, N. Y. June 24 An emergency airlift of vital supplies to several devasted communities began today as re ceding floodwaters left thous ands across western New York without food, water, lights or shelter.

title: School With Can Do Attitude
description: ALBERTSON, L. I.  Ten students will be graduated from the Human Resources School here on Tuesday. What makes this commence ment, among the hundreds being held throughout the Island this month, news worthy is that all 10 gradu ates are physically handi capped to the point that, were it not for the school, they, would be homebound that is, restricted to being taught at home.

title: Foe Apparently Repulsed In New Thrusts Near Hue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 25North Viet namese tanks and infantry made a series of daylong at tacks on Government defense lines north of Hue yesterday in an apparently unsuccessful effort to breakthrough toward the city, the Saigon command reported.

title: Jets Appoint Biles As Coach in Charge Of Defensive Backs
description: Ed Biles has joined the coaching staff of the New York Jets after spending a year as a scout for the team, Head Coach and General Manager Weeb Ewbank announced yesterday. Biles will be in charge of the defensive backfield when the Jets head for training camp on July 11. Walt Michaels, previ ously charged with defensive backs and linebackers, will concentrate on the linebackers exclusively.

title: TOWN NEAR HANOI IS FOUND IN RUINS
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, June 24This correspondent and a fel other members of the foreign press visited the town of Nam dinh, a textile center about 60 miles south of Hanoi, today.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISAmerican Presidential cam paigns sometimes cast long shadows overseas and this particularly appears to be the case in 1972. Already one foreign ambassador has been re proached for hints of intervention and, far more important, many capitals appear to be taking exceptional in terest in the projected contest.

description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 24 (AP)The Ladies Professional Golf Association Heritage Vil lage open tourney was delayed another day today and reduced to a 36hole tournament be cause of wet playing condi tions. The event was resched uled to end Monday.

description: The first nonprofit pro fessional resident theater east of Manhattan will open Sept. 27 in Flushing Meadows  Corona Park in Queens. For Joseph S. Kutrzeba, its founder and producer, the opening of the Queens Playhouse will be the climax of what he called a sevenyear, long uphill pull.

title: Winifred Dwyer Married on L. I.
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., June 24 Miss Winifred Dwyer, daugh ter of Mrs. John Charles Mc Carthy of Lawrence and Thomas Dwyer of Anchorage, Alaska, was married here this afternoon to William Nicho las Post. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Post of Torrington, Conn.

title: Music
description: IN the spring of 1971, Maurice Peress had an engagement in Regensburg, Germany. He went through Vienna, where Leonard Bernstein was con ducting Richard Strauss's Der Rosen kavalier at the opera. Peress had been associated with productions of Bern stein's Candide and West Side Story In the past, and he was sched uled to conduct a new version of Can aide. But it was the composer's Mass, then in work, that became the subject of discussions during their meeting in Vienna. Peress got his first glimpse of the music for what has become one of the more controversial theater pieces of our time, and, he says, It took Len nie three hours to tell me what he was trying to do, to describe its form, struc ture and flow. Would Peress take over the conducting of the work when it opened the new Kennedy Center in the fall? Bernstein thought of conducting the first few performances, but even that he relinquished in time.

title: What Is Wrong With Society?
description: PARIS  What's wrong with industrial society? What are the remedies?

title: Stamps
description: A VIEW of Venice as it appeared in 1581, spread over a block of four 50  lire stamps, featured a series of six stamps from the Vatican that were issued earlier this month. On the two additional stamps, a 25lire depicted a mosaic of the 12th13th cen tury in the Basilica of St. Mark in Venice; and a 180 lire stamp reproduced a painting, by Emidio Vangelli, of a front view of the Basilica under a stylized sun.

title: Homer Davison, 73, Led American Meat Institute
description: CADILLAC, Mich., June 24 (UPI)  Homer Rees Davison, a former president of the Amer ican Meat Institute, died last night at his home here. He was 73 years old.

description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 24Miss Janet Ruth Henning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henning of Sy osset, was married here this afternoon to Edward Murphy Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Norris Miller of Oyster Bay.

title: Annual Strawberry Festival May Not Be Long for Suffolk
description: MATTITUCK, L. I.In something vaguely akin to the salmon's upstream swim at spawning time or the re turn of the Capistrano swal lows, 5,000 people con verged on this rural hamlet last weekend to pay homage to that most delicate, delec table and succulent of beau ties, the Long Island straw berry.

title: The Nation
description: The plaintiffs are John Legion, a 30  year  old patient at the Brooklyn State Hospital for the mentally ill, and Lillian Hosts, a 10yearold mentally retarded girl at the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island. Their suit: To halt the nation's Medicare and Medicaid programs until they include the one million Americans who are treated each year in public institutions for the mentally disabled.

title: WilkesBarre Business Area Flooded
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., June 24 The entire downtown busi ness district in this city was under 9 to 12 feet of water today after a 36yearold earth en dike gave way.

title: DUMPING COSTS UP IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 24 Westchester County officials say they will have to spend millions to run the county dump at Croton Point the way a Federal Court ordered them to earlier this month.

title: A Soldier Looks Back
description: WASHINGTONI will put away my uniform on the first of July, 36 years after pinning on the bars of a second lieutenant. This leads me to reflect, not without some nostalgia, upon the Army I have known and served. In so doing, I find certain con stants  truths and principles which have determined the character of the United States Army throughout its proud history. I also find marked evi dence of change as the Army re sponded over the years to the changes in our society and the challenges to our national security. Both  the im mutable character, and the change and growth  have opened the way to far greater opportunities for young men entering the Army today than were open to me long ago.

title: DOUBLE SLAYERS SOUGHT BY POLICE
description: Fifty homicide detectives were working on the West Side yesterday in a hunt for the slayers of a welltodo Central Park West couple.

title: Bhutto Picks Up The Pieces of Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI.

title: The 10,000,000year swim and African corporate styles
description: Since the heyday of the muckrak ers it has been fashionable to speak of the modern business and financial world as a jungle, and of business men as following tribal rituals. Until recently those terms were usu ally allowed to remain metaphors; but now we are seeing a parade of books seeking to convince us that there are actual and fairly close parallels between the behavior of businessmen and that of tribal chiefs, between the customs of modern busi ness life and those of primitive tribal lifeto convince us that, in fact, modern businessmen for better or worse really follow tribal rituals.

title: Blue Loses to Angels
description: OAKLAND, June 24 (AP)  Clyde Wright, a left  hander, hurled a four  hitter today as the California Angels defeated the Oakland A's and Vida Blue, 3.1.

description: WATERBURY, Conn., June 24Miss Daryl Hopkins Goss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Middlebrook Goss Jr. of Middlebury, was married here this afternoon to Christopher John Bond. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Edward Bond of Swampscott, Mass. The Rev. Michael S. Kendall performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church and Msgr. John Carroll assisted.

title: Art
description: AMONG people I have ir ritated recently with out meaning to is Gene Baro, of the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, D.C. As acting director, Mr. Baro was vexed by the inaccuracy of my comment that the Cor coran had dropped its once famous Annual of American Painting, and as a nonNew Yorker he resented the pro vincialism of one given reason because the Whitney An nual, being in New York, lessened its importance. Museums outside New York City don't necessarily feel disadvantaged, Mr. Baro wrote in a letter to boss.

description: Lawrence E. Gerosa, the City Controller for eight years un der Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died early yesterday of lung cancer at the Albert Einstein Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived at 615 West 252d Street, the Bronx.

She indirectly accused the United States of hampering peace ef forts.

description: CHICAGO  The Administration's wageprice stabilization program is about to face its greatest challenge: a sharp increase in costs for the table meat, specificallyin the next few months. At a time when the Presi dential election campaign will be at its height.

description: AMITYVILLE, L.I.Jimmy the Judge has bred pigeons for more than 45 years, ever since he was a boy in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

description: The Police Department will curtail its controversial practice of keeping dossiers on juveniles and then passing along unsub stantiated information to other authorities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE DEMOCRATS HEAD OFF SPLIT; LINDSAY GETSPOST
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 24  In an uncharacteristic display of harmony, the Demo cratic State Committee speedily elected its first black national committeeman today and com pleted naming a 278member delegation to the national con vention that will include Mayor Lindsay of New York.

title: Summer standouts
description: For summer dressing, there's nothing like black and white. The bold combination is for women who don't mind standing out in a crowd. The clothes shown here are available in the stores right now and they can be worn all through the summer into the fall and beyond. The layers of sweaters can mix just as smoothly with wool pants or skirts, as with light summer ones, and the dresses slip comfortably under winter coats.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Earlier this month, repre sentatives of 12 of the 15 nations that are members of the International Commission for Northwest Atlantic Fish eries (I.C.N.A.F.) voted in favor of a complete ban on high seas fishing for the endangered Atlantic salmon by 1976.

title: Social Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: POLL SHOWS NIXON RETAINING APPROVAL
description: Public approval of President Nixon following his summit meeting in the Soviet Union appears to be remaining high, the Gallup Poll reported yester day.

title: Art
description: DURING the past season, the Museum of Modern Art has conducted an exhibition series called Projects devoted to work by young, avant garde artists. Though a fine, bold under taking, the series has failed to generate much excitement. Indeed, the frailty and confusion of nearly all the Projects shows mounted so far have come to seem virtual leitmotifs, like insistent whispers to the effect of something like This is what's happening, alas! It is widely conceded that the avantgarde is not very robust these days, and one might almost conclude that the Modern wished to dramatize its plight.

title: Money
description: LONDONWe are back where we were last November with all the un certainty that means for trade, invest ment and employment in the Western world. That was the reaction of an influential German banker to the sudden announcement Friday by the British Government that it was cutting the pound sterling loose from official parities and letting it float to a new level determined by supply and demand.

title: 20 Food Concerns Cited for Violations Of City Health Code
description: The Health Department yes terday cited 20 city, food estab lishments where inspectors have found serious violations of the Health Code. The list was re leased by the Health Services Administrator, Gordon Chase.

title: Music
description: PUTTING on a festi val, said George Wein, the short, spherical, soft  spo ken man from Boston who has been producing the New port Jazz Festival since 1954, takes a person with tremen dous strength to hold a tre mendous number of slightly crazy people together. They're all individualists.

title: The World
description: Panamanian pilots shut down the Panama City Airport by driving their cars onto runways. One pilot lay down in front of an airliner to make doubly sure  Airport lounges in most of Western Europe were strangely deserted except for a scattering of travelers bedded down on benches to await the return of normalcy  A del egation of Pan American World Air ways pilots in West Berlin apologized to European counterparts for the fact that most domestic United States flights were operating.

title: And Now Man of La Mafia
description: IF the crowds have kept you from going to see The Godfather, don't despair. One of our informers re ports that before long you will be able to see an all singing, alldancing, allshooting musical version on Broadway. Yes, folkshere comes Corleone! or, Guns and Dons, and our informer has even managed to swipe a scenario:

title: Family Awarded $250,000
description: CHICAGO, June 24 (AP)A Circuit Court jury has ordered the Tishman Construction Com pany to pay $250,000 to the family of a construction worker killed during construction of the John Hancock Center. The award to Mrs. Marguerite Green wood, 36 years old, and her two children, came Wednesday after a twoday trial before Judge Irving R. Norman.

title: Recordings
description: WHEN the New York City Opera first mounted its lus trous Giulio Ce sare to mark its move to the New York State Theater, hopes ran high in some quarters that this was but the first stage in a fullscale Handel opera revival. Inter estingly, in spite of the City Opera hit, which proved that baroque opera, if treated to the right kind of stylization, has the power to charm and delight, this has not materi alized. New York has heard several operas by the Ger man  English master in concert performances, thanks mostly to the enterprising Stephen Simon, and the Ken nedy Center was treated briefly to a Beverly Sills dominated Ariodante, but as far as the general opera going public is concerned, Giulio Cesare reigns with out issue.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Legislative Notes: NoFault Coverage Begins at End of Year
description: TRENTONBeginning Jan. 1, any New Jersey motor ist injured in an automobile accident will be guaranteed unlimited reimbursement for medical expenses no matter who caused the accident.

title: Chess: Brilliancy Prize Is Rewarding To Winner but Salt to Loser
description: Lutz Espig of East Germany is becoming a familiar figure on the European chess circuit. He has not yet won the title of international master, but there is no doubt that he is stronger than many who have and he is surely no soft touch for anyone.

title: Flammable Nightwear Held Peril to Children
description: BOSTON, June 24 (UPI) A lawyer has called on parents to have their children sleep nude until the clothing industry uses flameproof fab rics.

title: Old Airport In Flushing Still Plays Vital Role
description: The Dick Abramses of Rochester were in town last weekend with their neigh bors, the Alan Calderons. The Abramses had been in Boston the weekend before, and got there the same way they got here. They have their own plane.

title: Chemical Drums Pose Peril As They Float From Plants
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP)About 1,000 drums con taining toxic, and in some cases explosive, materials have es caped from flooded plants along the Schuylkill River, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Indians Thwart Yanks by 43 and 51
description: CLEVELAND, June 25The New York Yankees' sixgame winning streak turned sudden ly into a twogame losing string at Municipal Stadium as the Cleveland Indians swept a doubleheader, 43 and 51, today.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 25 (UPI) Des Renford swam from the Sydney Harbor Bridge to Manly and back today in final preparation for his third attempt at breaking the record for a twoway swim across the English Channel.

title: Canadian Youths Take to Road With Government's Blessing
description: FLEURIMONT, Que., June 21Robert Morgan, an ani mated 15yearold, hitchhiked from his home in Toronto two weeks ago, bound for a vacation on the West Coast.

title: SHOP TALK
description: For women who can't wait until next fall to start collecting cashmere sweaters, Altman's has a supply on hand right now. They're by Valerie Louthan, a lively, red haired designer who used to work for Braemar and re cently formed her own company in Scotland, where the best cashmeres are made. Hers are for young people who never knew how nice cash mere feels, said the de signer, who firmly believes cashmere is addictive. Once you feel it next to your skin, you never want to wear anything else, she insisted.

title: Searchers in Bangladesh Find Arms, Stolen Goods
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 25 Police and paramilitary forces today recovered large quanti ties of arms and stolen goods in house  to  house searches here. They also evicted per sons who they said were ille gally occupying houses aban doned by nonBengalis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: ENEMIES, A LOVE STORY. By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Translated From the Yiddish by Aliza Shevrin and Elizabeth Shub. 280 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.

title: PRO TENNIS PLAYERS PLANNING TO UNITE
description: The first serious guidelines for a unified professional play ers' association in tennis will be presented tomorrow at si multaneous meetings in St. Louis and London.

title: State's Democrats Mount an Offensive
description: Eager to shuck off the minority role they have played in the Senate and the Assem bly during the last four years, state Democrats are mounting a fall election offensive in which they hope to gain con trol of at least one house of the Legislature.

title: Young Voices From the Ghetto
description: Walking across 106th Street toward the Second Avenue bus line, a Harlem high school boy told me we were in, for a violent summer. Words aren't going to save this city, he said. We have guns and we're going to use them.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, June 25The most talkedabout man in Britain these days is a 51 yearold judge. Sir John Donaldson, a doItyourself enthusiast who is being ac cused of doing too much himself.

title: Church Members Robbed
description: PONTIAC, Mich., June 25 (AP)Two armed youths ent ered the Christ in Christian Union Church here today, held the pastor at gunpoint and rob bed the congregation and col lection basket of about $400, the police said.

title: Woman Umpire Returns to Plates at Home
description: With the female preroga tive of changing her mind, Mrs. Bernice Gera again is a housewife instead of a minor league umpire.

title: City Hall Notes
description: The Lindsay administra tion has granted more than $25,000 in raises, retroactive to Jan. 1, to 37 staff mein hers of the City Council, and has created two new Council staff positions calling for salaries totaling $31,000.

title: Quirks in Brazilian Stocks Stir Bizarre Explanations
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 25 The language is Portuguese and June 21 marks the start of a cold, windy and damp winter in southern Brazil. But lan guage and weather aside, mar ket analysts here arejust as quick with explanations of er ratic behavior of stock prices as their New York cousins.

title: ISRAELIS SETTLE ON GULF OF AQABA
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Israeli ?? Sinai  Israelis are fastening their hold on the strategic Gulf of Aqaba coast of occupied Sinai.

title: McGovern Shy 130 Votes As Delegate Choice Ends
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Democratic party com pleted today, five months after it began, the complicated process of choosing the dele gates who will cast 3,016 votes at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach to nominate the party's candidate for President.

title: Personal Finance
description: Ordering by mail from cat alogues or from enticing ad vertisements in magazines seems easy and pleasant. The customer can sit at a desk, fill out a form, write a check, paste a stamp on the envel ope and walk to a mailbox and then wait.

title: CURRENCY CRISIS JOLTS EUROBONDS
description: BRUSSELS, June 25Euro bonds dealers are breaking out their monetary crisis survival kits for the umpteenth time, with the market mood turning philosophical under the latest barrage of currency unrest.

title: Welfare Clients Tend Oklahoma Vineyard
description: ATOKA, Okla.'I been praying that God would send a worm to eat the vines, said the Rev. Billy Joe How ard of the First Baptist Church of Kenefick.

title: MUNCEY CAPTURES HIS 5TH GOLD CUP
description: DETROIT, June 25Proving an invincible man in his flying machine, Bill Muncey won his fifth Gold Cup race today. Muncey averaged 103.547 miles an hour in his Atlas Van Lines unlimited hydroplane, beating his nearest rival by more than a mile in the final heat.

title: In a Pennsylvania Dutch Market, Homemade Goodies Galore
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  At 6:30 A.M. on a recent Tuesday, Mrs. Jacob Hess, a pleasantfaced, comfortably propor tioned woman, wearing the traditional Mennonite prayer veiling cap, was eating some of the profits. She was nibbling on Sandies, a cookie of choc olate morsels rolled in pecan crumbs. Price: 40 cents a dozen.

title: Unacceptable Risk
description: Ten years after Rachel Carson sounded the alarm against the threat of DDT to animal and human life, a slowmoving Federal bureaucracy has finally banned the persistent pesticide for nearly all domestic uses.

title: Daniel Cleveland Look Weds Anne Carol O'Neil, Classmate
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 25 The marriage of Miss Anne Carol O'Neil, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. O'Neil of Easton, to Daniel Cleve land Look took place here this afternoon. The bride groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen M. Look of West Tisbury, Mass., and a grand son of the late Dr. Hugh Auchincloss, the New York surgeon.

title: Ecology Center Planned at Jersey Stadium Site
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 25In an effort to head off opposition by environmen tal groups to the proposed de velopment of a sports complex on 750 acres in the Hacken sack Meadowlands, the New Jersey Sports Authority has made plans to set aside 130 acres of the site as an en vironmental education center.

title: PETTY TRIUMPHS IN LONE STAR 500
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex. (UPI)Richard Petty, overcom ing track temperatures of 140 degrees, pulled away from Bob by Allison and Bobby Isaac to day and posted an easy victory in the $91,395 Lone Star 500 Nascar race at Texas World Speedway.

title: For James Baldwin, a Rap on Baldwin
description: With the recent publication of a collection of essays, No Name in the Street, James Baldwin hopes a long drought is over.

title: Judith Brown Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Miss Judith Brown, daughter of Mrs. Sophie Feuermann Brown and F. Harry Brown, both of New York, was mar ried here this afternoon to Barry Stewart Greif, sort of Mr. and Mrs. Jonas Greif, also of New York.

title: Rains End in Flooded Regions. Upstate
description: The sun came out over west ern New York yesterday after noon, ending seven days of tor rential downpours that claimed 23 lives and destroyed or dam aged more than 17,000 homes.

title: Flooded Areas Rally as Waters Recede
description: The swollen, rampaging riv ers of the Northeast began dropping below their crests yesterday, leaving scores of towns and cities struggling in the receding waters to recover from one of the region's worst floods.

title: Connecticut Citizen Group Calls Navy's Housing Project Illegal
description: GROTON, Conn., June 25 The Connecticut Citizen Action Groupa Ralph Naderaffiliat ed organizationcharged today that the United States Navy is violating Federal environmen tal laws by constructing a 300 family housing project for per sonnel from its submarine base here.

title: The Welfare Swamp
description: President Nixon has made no contribution toward enactment of welfare reform by undercutting the efforts of a Senate coalition headed by Senator Ribicoff to cor rect defects in the bill already passed by the House.

title: Bidge:Italian Blue Team Forces Aces to Accept No. 2 Role
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 25 The victory of the Italian Blue Team in the world championships that ended here yesterday was far from unexpected. The magnificent sextet of Pietro Forquet, Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Bel ladonna, Walter Avarelli, Massimo D'Alelio and Camillo Pabis Ticci has been unbeaten on any major occasion in the last decade, and Italy has now won 13 world titles since 1957.

title: Ferraris Score Again
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, June 25 (AP)Ferraris swept to victory today in the 1,000kilometer race at the Austria ring near here with Jackie Ickx of Bel gium and Brian Redman of Britain winning. The race is a part of the world manufac turers championship series, which has been clinched by Ferrari.

title: Black Broker Finds Action in Wall Street
description: Irvin W. Hanks was work ing at a summer job with the First National Bank of Chicago a couple of years ago when he came to the conclusion that the action in banking wasn't fast enough for him.

title: Woman Picked by Church
description: TORONTO, June 25 (AP)  The United Church of Canada announced today that for the first time in its 47year history a woman had been nominated for moderator, or presiding of ficer. She is the Rev. K. Harriet Christie of Toronto, one of five nominees.

title: LABOR PACT REACHED AT ROME COKE PLANT
description: ROME, June 25,  A nine month labormanagement dis pute set off by the shutdown of the CocaCola plant here last October appears to have been resolved by an agreement be tween Italy's three major labor federations and officials of the CocaCola Export Corporation.

title: L.I.R.R. '71 Loss $54.7Million, Rise of 45% From Previous Year
description: The Long Island Rail Road lost $54.7million in 1971, near ly $17million more than the $37.8million lost in 1970, an increase of almost 45 per cent, according to an audit released yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: EXGOV. HUXMAN, 85, OF KANSAS IS DEAD
description: TOPEKA, Kan., June 25 (AP) Walter A. Huxman, who swept into office as Governor of Kansas in the 1936 landslide victory of Franklin D. Roose velt, died today in a hospital here. He was 85 years old.

title: Military Evaders Amnesty Is Termed Insult by Byrd
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., June 25 (AP)A general amnesty for draft evaders and deserters would be an insult to Vietnam veterans, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Vir ginia and the Senate majority whip, told the West Virginia Veterans of Foreign Wars state meeting here today.

title: British Businessman, 87, Reported Freed by China
description: HONG KONG, Monday, June 26 (UPI)David Edmunds, an 87yearold British business man held by the Ohinese au thorities during the Cultural Revolution in 1967, was re leased and will cross the border into Hong Kong today, a Gov ernment spokesman said.

title: Smart Bombs and Dumb Bombs
description: To one who has bombed and been bombed, recent Pentagon propaganda about our new smart bombs is dumb and repetitious (not to say, indecent). That's the kind of surekill language we were using twentyeight years ago, when I was a bombardier navigator with the 15th Air Force in Italy. Then it was the Norden bombsight that was supposed to give us pinpoint precision bombing. Now they're saying the same thing about laser and TVguided bombs we have begun dropping on the people we use as live dummies for target practice in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Watching Hanoi's Policy Review
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Nixon Administration be lieves that the current policy review in Hanoi should provide a firm indication within the next two weeks whether a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war is feasible before the United States Presidential election in November.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Yogi Berra came out of the dugout in the fifth inning. Tom Seaver left the mound and met the manager near the foul line. Young Mr. Supermet was ready for his shower. In four innings the Cardinals had jolted him loose from four runs and the three men now on base would soon score, making a total of seven runs earned against him. It is a measure of Tom Seaver's excellence as a pitcher that in almost 200 ball games over five and one third seasons in a major league, he had never before been flogged for so many earned runs.

title: MARCH IS STAGED BY HOMOSEXUALS
description: Chanting, Out of the closet and into the streets!, thou sands of exuberant homosexual men and women and their sup porters staged a crowdcollect ing march through the center of the city yesterday in what has become an annual and in creasingly assertive demonstra tion for acceptance by straight society.

title: JAMES R. BRAWLEY
description: BOSTON, June 25 (AP) James R, Brawley, retired art director of The Record Ameri can and Sunday Advertiser, died Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ja maica Plain. He was 72 years old.

title: Nat Fleischer Dies at 84
description: Nat Fleischer, considered one of the world's foremost boxing authorities, died yes terday at New York Univer sity Hospital after a long illness. The 84yearold Fleischer was publisher and editor of Ring magazine, which he founded more than 50 years ago. An obituary appears on Page 36.

title: STABILITY SOUGHT IN STEEL DEMAND
description: PITTSBURGH, June 25In ventories are seen holding the key to future steel demand.

title: 200 in Prison Disturbance
description: LAGRANGE, Ky., June 25 (AP)About 200 prisoners at the LaGrange State Reforma tory participated in a brief dis turbance today, Warden Harold Black said.

title: William R. Tow Weds Miss Judith R. Feder
description: Miss Judith R. Feder and William R. Tow, an Associat ed Press reporter assigned to Kennedy International Air port, were married here yes terday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Hortense Gabel per formed the ceremony at the Regency.

title: WETLANDS ON L.I. CALLED IMPERILED
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I. June 25 More than 4,400 acres of wet lands have disappeared from Long Island in the last eight years, according to a report prepared by scientists of the Marine Sciences Research Cen ter of the State. University of New York at Stony Brook.

title: Space Unit Names Manager
description: Dr. William F. Hall of Buf falo, the former president and chief executive officer of the Western New York Nuclear Re search Center, has been ap pointd program manager of the State Atomic and Space De velopment Authority, it was an nounced yesterday by the au thority. He will supervise the authority's nuclear power siting program and coordinate its energy and environment re search programs.

title: Corruption Attributed By Some to Low Pay
description: William J. Glinsman, presi dent of the Allied Building Inspectors Union, acknowl edges the existence of cor ruption among his members, but stresses that there are also many honest inspectors.

title: Sunrise Over Ulster?
description: It will be a tragedy of immeasurable dimensions of terrorists of either side are able to wreck the ceasefire in Northern Ireland promised for midnight tonight by the Irish Republican Army's Provisional wing. The cease fire and the positive response from British officials have opened up the best prospects in many months for re storing peace to Ulster.

title: Pele Excels as Santos Routs Catanzaro, 71
description: JERSEY CITY, June 25The roving ambassadors of Brazil; Pel and his team, Santos, put on a brilliant soccer perform ance at Roosevelt Stadium to day as the Brazilians routed Catanzaro of Italy, 71, before 15,343 delighted fans.

title: At Least 50 Reported Dead From Floods in Bangladesh
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, June 25 (AP)At least 50 persons died and many are missing after floods destroyed hundreds of homes in the Syihet district of Bangladesh, according to re ports reaching Dacca today.

title: Army Plans Withdrawal Of 800 G.I.'s From Phubai
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 (UPI)The Army said today that it would withdraw about 800 infantrymen from Phubai, the United States' northernmost South Vietna mese outpost, near Hue.

title: Airport Funds Raised
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Federal Aviation Admin istration said today that it had approved $3.3million in addi tional airport improvement al locations under its airport de velopment aid program.

title: Michele Hodnett Bride
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 25Miss Michele Anne Hod nett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jerome Hodnett Jr., was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Ed ward Daly Jr. in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. David Van Horn per formed the ceremony. The hridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Daly of Crestwood.

title: Miss Babashoff and Hall Break Santa Clara Swim Meet Marks
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 25 (UPI)Shirley Babashoff and Gary Hall of the Hunting ton Beach (Calif.) Aquatic Club set meet records today as the threeday Santa Clara interna tional swimming and diving meet ended.

title: Pirates Kill 5, Manila Says
description: MANILA, June 25 (AP) Armed pirates attacked a mo torized boat with seven persons aboard at sea yesterday off the southern Phillipines province of Sulu, killing five persons and wounding two others, the Phil ippine Constabulary reported today. The police said the pi rates took all the victims' per sonal belongings and money.

title: Air Passenger Search Urged
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (AP)  Representative Roman C. Pucin ski, Democrat of Illinois, said today that he would ask the Federal courts to order com mercial airlines to search all passengers and luggage before departure.

title: Small Business
description: There's virtually no argu ment on the point: manage ment is the key to success in any business venture. But many an otherwise shrewd and talented entrepreneurhas failed early in the game be cause he wasn't manager enough to understand the critical role ofcapital nor enough of a plan ner to get the banks to lend him capital.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Moves by the Secret Service to tighten security around the President and Presidential can didates in reaction to assassi nation fears are creating fric tion between the Secret Service and the Washington press corps.

title: Dunas Turns Radio Into an Accompanist To His Solo Dance
description: William Dunas contrasted the import and impact of words and movement with quiet in tensity in his unhurried solo The Time of Your Life Sat urday afternoon at Westbeth. This short work, one of a series of solo pieces created by Mr. Dunas in the last two years, further elaborates his examina tion of action and symbol.

title: Miss Martha Goell Bride of John Lubell
description: WATER MILL, L. I., June 25  Miss Martha Goell, daughter of Mrs. Milton J. Goell of Hartsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Goell, was mar ried here today to John Lu bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict I. Lubell of Tulsa, Okla. Rabbi Ira Eisenstein performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Brandt, uncle and aunt of the bride.

title: RESEARCH GOES ON AT BOHR INSTITUTE
description: COPENHAGENThirtythree years ago the enormous re lease of energy through split ting of the atom was first demonstrated in a small insti tute here. Consequences for the world were historic.

title: SHAH ASSURES WEST ON IRAN'S OIL SUPPLY
description: LONDON, June 25  The Shah of Iran, before leaving London today, gave a clear declaration of Iran's determina tion to continue a steady supply for many years of Iran ian oil to world markets  and therefore primarily to Western markets at fair world prices.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 25  The Tonkin plain of North Vietnam is hemmed in by mountains to the north and west, the sea to the southeast. In the rainy season every summer vast amounts of water pour out of the mountains and down the rivers that lace the plain. The principal river gives its name to the area: the Red River Delta.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PLYMOUTH, England, June 25 (Reuters)  Weather prospects improved today for the 49 yachtsmen at sea in the singlehanded transAtlantic race to Newport, now in its eighth day.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE ON UNITY PLANKS, BUT FIGHT LOOMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Displaying surprising harmony, a Democratic platform drafting group completed three planks today that reflect the liberal thrust of Senator George Mc Govern's candidacy but are so general they were termed ac ceptable by representatives of Senators Hubert H. Humphrey, Edmund S. Muskie and Henry M. Jackson.

title: GUNMAN KILLS FOUR IN MONTREAL STORE
description: MONTREAL, June 25 (UPI) A gunman walked into a Mon treal delicatessen early today, ordered four employes into a walkin freezer, shot them to death and then covered their bodies with produce. He also wounded a security guard.

title: Fair Play Group Discerns Shift in Campaign Charges
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Political campaigns are as dirty as ever, although the type of abuse is changing, Samuel J. Archibald, executive director of the Fair Campaign Practices Committee, said today.

title: 150 Searchers Find No Trace of Hijacker in Indiana
description: PERU, Ind., June 25 A search party of 150 persons, including 100 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, failed today to find an armed sky jacker, his body or the money he took when he leaped out of an airliner near here yesterday.

title: A Yoruba Rite Weds 2 Families
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 An Africanstyle wedding simply looks different from most American weddings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HONG KONG PLANS NEW DRUGS DRIVE
description: HONG KONG, June 25  Hong Kong is expected to establish a Government post with extensive powers to deal with the serious drug problem in this British crown colony.

title: Man in Newswomen's Unit
description: SEATTLE, June 25 (UPI)A Seattle photographer has be come the first man to join the National Federation of Press Women. Phil Webber, a pho tographer for the Seattle Post Intelligencer, became the fed eration's first enrolled male yesterday when it opened its membership to men. He was the first of five men to join the Washington state chapter, which changed its bylaws to accept men before the National Federation approved a similar amendment.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, June 25 (AP)Har yard University's lightweight eight was seeded first today for the Thames Challenge Cup in the Henley Royal Regatta beginning Wednesday. The Crimson crew, defending the trophy the school won last year, was favored over 19 opponents.

title: Saigon Fears Discord By Veterans After War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25Remote as the prospects of peace now seem to most South Vietnamese, at least a few high officials here have begun to worry about the stag gering social and economic problems that peace and de mobilization will bring.

title: News Analysis
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 21 The new NorthSouth agree ment on an agenda for talks about travel and other con tacts between family members separated in North and South Korea is only a small begin ning but it has raised hopes that NorthSouth antagonismcan in time be ad justed peacefully. The agenda agree ment was reached last Friday be tween the RedCross organization of Seoul and Pyongyang after nine months of difficult negotiations.

title: University Presses Are Struggling to Overcome Financial Crisis
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 25  The country's academic presses, purveyors of special ized books in the sciences and humanities essential to the scholarly community, are strug gling to overcome a financial crisis.

title: Price Panel Declines Comment on a Sunday Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Price Commission met in special session today to dis cuss the issue of soaring food prices but concealed its delib erations under an uncharacter istic cloak of secrecy.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, June 25 (Reu ters)More than 20 people have been killed in monsoon flooding in northeastern India during the last four days, the Press Trust of India reported tonight

title: BUCHANAN RISKS CROWN TONIGHT
description: With obvious scorn for his young challenger, Ken Bu chanan of Scotland will defend the world lightweight boxing title tonight at Madison Square Garden against Roberto Duran of Panama.

title: JAVITS BACKS NIXON AT STRATEGY TALKS
description: ALBANY, June 25 Senator Jacob K. Javits, overlooking what he termed the differ ences between himself and President Nixon, Conducted a twohour strategy session here today on behalf of the Presi dent's reelection effort.

title: Cincinnati Welcomes a Grand New Home for Opera
description: CINCINNATI, June 25A new era began in this city last night when the Cincin nati Summer Opera moved into the newly renovated Mu sic Hall and ended its 52 year tradition of outdoor per formances at the Cincinnati Zoo, sometimes in competi tion with lions and ducks and other vocal creatures in residence there.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: General Physicians Decline Here

title: Motive Is Big Mystery In Raid on Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Moving through the basement after midnight, the guard found strips of tape across the latches of two doors leading to the underground garage.

title: Bear Kills Man in Wyoming
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., June 25 (UPI) An overnight campOut in an offlimits area near the Old Faithful geyser ended in death early today for a 25yearold man, who was attacked by bear apparently raiding a food cache. The names of the dead man and of a companion who escaped were withheld until their families were notified. Four persons have been killed by bears in the 100year history of the nation's first national park.

title: Credit Markets
description: Longterm interest rates re main delicately balanced be tween competing forces that for months now have produced a relative standoff.

title: New Affluence on Kipling's Road
description: NEW DELHI, June 25A few years ago, the scenes along the storied Grand Trunk Road; the setting of tales by Rudyard Kipling, had changed little since the Mogul emperors' caravans traveled that strategic high way from the Khyber Pass to Calcutta.

title: 50 March to Protest War
description: MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 25 (AP)About 50 members of the People's Block ade, an antiwar group, staged a milelong march to the main gate the Earle Naval Ammuni tion Depot here today. The walk was peaceful and there were no arrests. The protests was part of a continuing demonstration at the depot against the war.

title: Zaire Is Promoting Nature Reserves; Plans to Protect 15% of Her Territory
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 25 We cannot show our visitors old cathedrals or ancient monu ments, but we have no com plexes. Our monuments, our cathedrals are our rivers, for ests, insects, animals, lakes, volcanoes, mountains and plains.

title: Study Finds $25Million Yearly in Bribes Is Paid by City's Construction Industry
description: New York City's vast, multi billiondollar construction in dustry pays at least $25million a year in bribes to city building inspectors, highway officials, policemen, state safety inspec tors, agents of the Federal Housing Administration, clerks in various city agencies, union representatives and certain powerful bluecollar workers.

title: ARMY AND GUNMEN BATTLE IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, June 25Troops and terrorists fought a gun bat tle in Belfast today as the peo ple of Northern Ireland waited to see the effect of the truce called by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army for midnight tomorrow.

title: Capitol Extension Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of upstate New York, urged his colleagues today to block a proposed $70 million extension of the his horic west front of the United States Capitol, saying it was unnecessary and too costly. Mr. Stratton called for support for a Senatepassed measure that would prohibit spending Fed eral funds for such construc tion without the approval of the Senate as well as the House of Representatives.

title: EUROPEANS SCAN MONETARY WOES
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 25A dozen monetary seizures in 63 months and another just be ginningthis was the record as the Common Market prepared once again to try to deal with the consequences of too many dollars in the world.

title: California Voters to Weigh Restoring the Death Penalty
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. June 25 (UPI)Voters in the state will decide in November wheth er to reinstate the death pen alty, which was struck down earlier this year by the State Supreme Court.

title: Fischer Cancels Flight To Site of Title Chess
description: Bobby Fischer, the unpre dictable challenger for the world chess championship, abruptly cancelled last night his flight to Reykjavik, Ice land, where he is to begin his match next Sunday with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: Mets Lose Two to Cards, Fall 3 Behind
description: One of the St. Louis players put Scipio Spinks's stuffed gorilla in the clubhouse drier before yesterday's double header, then the Cardinals put the Mets through the wringer.

title: Crash Victim in Semicoma
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25 (UPI) David John Hanley, the young businessman who added a bi zarre extra to Friday's hijack ing by ramming his car into the plane, was reported in a semicoma today from injuries suffered in the crash.

title: 12 PLAYERS PICKED FOR OLYMPIC FIVE
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 25 (AP)Hank Iba, the head coach, announced today the 12 man United States Olympic basketball squad. Six members of the team are 6 feet 9 inches or taller. It also includes the secondstring center of the na tional championship team of last season, the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Pagels Triumphs Again
description: MORICHES, L.I., June 25 Bill Pagels of the Wet Pants Association, Sayville, who ar rived too late to compete in the first event of the sixrace round robin series yesterday, captured his third straight Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association men's sailing cham pionship today. His score in cluded four firsts and a fourth.

title: 9 Are Killed in Plane Crash After TakeOff in Winnipeg
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 25 (Canadian Press)Nine per sons, seven of them Indian high school students, were killed yesterday when a twinengined plane crashed and burned on a residential street shortly after taking off from Winnipeg air port.

title: Tel Aviv Toll Reaches 28
description: TEL AVIV, June 25 (AP) The death toll in the Tel Aviv airport of May 30 has risen to 28 with the death yesterday of another Israeli, Zvi Gutman, 51 years old, hospital authorities announced today. Others killed when three Japanese gunmen fired into a crowd at the ter minal included 16 Puerto Rican tourists, a Canadian woman, nine Israelis and two of the gunmen.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Credentials Committee of the 1972 Democratic National Convention met for the first time tonight to decide the fate of 1,281 delegates whose right to go to Miami Beach has been challenged as a violation of new party reform rules.

title: Fines and Jail for Graffiti Will Be Asked by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay will submit a bill to the City Council tomor row that will seek to halt the scrawling of graffiti in public places by fining and jailing any one caught with an open paint spray can in any public build ing or facility.

title: SYKES, WITH DIXIE, WINS SHIELDS SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 25 James W. Sykes, the skipper of Dixie, won the Long Island Sound district championship of the Shields Class by 1 point at Larchmont Yacht Club today when no one finished the third and final race in the twoday series within the time limit.

title: BUTTING RULE STIRS ANGER IN ALI CAMP
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 25 (UPI)The Nevada State Ath letic Commission refused today to waive an accidental butting rule, despite a strong protest from Angelo Dundee, trainer manager of Muhammad Ali.

title: Sanders Wins S.I. Race
description: Norbert Sanders of the Mill rose Athletic Association won the second annual Staten Is land A.C.'s 20kilometer road race in Clove Lake Park on Staten Island yesterday, finish ing the 12.42mile course in 1 hour 8 minutes 50 seconds. A field of 84 runners started the event over muddy terrain and in a steady drizzle and 77 finished.

title: Disaster Areas Listed For StormDamage Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  The Office of Emer gency Preparedness released today a list of nearly 100 counties and cities in five states that have been offi cially designated as disaster areas in the wake of tropical storm Agnes.

title: Vignettes of Tragedy  and Quiet Courage
description: While Government offi cials toured flood areas yes terday, assessing losses in terms of millions and even billions of dollars, individual victims computed the cost of their private tragedies in more tangible terms dead and missing friends and neighbors, shattered homes; drowned pets, overturned cars, stores with inventories destroyed, no gas to cook with, no electricity, no tele phones.

title: Cheaters Beat the New Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 25 The oldtime gambler, manager of a casino in this city where $2.5million in cash and chips are on the table every night, said, All over the world people lie awake nights to figure ways to beat the tables here.

title: Okinawans Vote
description: NAHA, Okinawa, June 25 With about 15 per cent of the more than 500,000 eligible votes in the prefecture of Okin awa in, Acting Gov. Chobyo Yara, who advocates greater autonomy and removal of mili tary bases, showed a lead of more than 8,500 over his op ponent, Seisaku Ohta. It is the first election here since the United States returned the Ryukyu Islands to Japanese control on May 15.

title: Neighbors Defend ExNazi Guard U.S. Seeks to Deport
description: A small boy leaned against one of the curbside maples, hands over eyes, counting shrilly, while his friends scampered through the back yards of private homes in a game of hideandseek. At the base of the sloping street, teen agers played stickball, confi dent that motorists would slow down for them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Imposes Controls On SterlingArea Investing
description: LONDON, June 25 (AP)The British Government imposed controls today on the invest ment in countries of the over seas sterling area by residents of Britain.

title: To Save the Land
description: At the White House Conference on Natural Beauty in 1965, a delegate from Wisconsin showed a series of maps depicting that state from many points of viewits historic sites; its lakes, rivers and wetlands; its utility grid; its transportation network, and its farmlands, sub urbs and industrial growth areas.

title: Advertising:
description: J. Walter Thompson, which has lost a couple of its Ford Dealer accounts, has restruc tured its operation to handle the remaining 32 in the Ford Dealer Advertising Fund.

title: 3 of 8 at Party Slain As One Starts Shooting
description: DALTON, Ga., June 25 (AP) As eight young persons lis tened to music at a party early today, one of them suddenly began shooting the others with a .45caliber pistol, the police said. Three were killed and two wounded.

title: Shanker and His U.F.T. Poised For a New Showdown With City
description: When Albert Shanker's big ambition in life was to earn a doctorate in philosophy at Columbia University, he chose as the subject of his thesis the speculations in ethics of an obscure Ameri can academician named Eli jah Jordan, who held that an individual's private feelings and intentions had no ethical signifieance.

title: Economic Analysis
description: There is a sense of dj vu in the scenario that confronts the world's financial markets this morning.

title: UNIONISTS FORM ANTIWAR GROUP
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25Rank andfile union members attend ing an antiwar meeting split with their leadership during the weekend over whether a new labor peace organization should press for a national strike to protest the war in Vietnam.

title: Stravinsky Revels End, but He Won't
description: Our revels will never quite be ended but, admittedly, with the onstage vodka toast to Stravinsky, the final night of the New York City Ballet's first Stravinsky Festival got under way at the State Thea ter last night. It had opened with a new Balanchine, in cluded a new Robbins and closed with the orchestra playing the Symphony of Psalms, before filing out for its own vodka offering.

title: Cahill's Corollary
description: In a politically courageous move, Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey has proposed fundamental reform of his state's totally inadequate and regressive tax structure. Local governments have had to shoulder an inordinate responsibility for delivering services while relying on local property taxes, which, as a result, are higher in New Jersey than anywhere else in the nation.

title: G.E. Chooses President; Chairman to Retire at 62
description: The General Electric Com pany announced yesterday that Reginald H. Jones, born the son of an English steel mill foreman, had been elected president, effective immedi ately.

title: Nixon Telephones Head Of Cancer Delegation
description: THURMONT, Md., June 25 (AP)President Nixon tele phoned a Moscowbound sci entist Sunday to express a personal interest in planned AmericanSoviet cooperation in fighting cancer.

title: 5 ROCKLAND INMATES FLEE
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., June 25 Five prisoners escaped from the Rockland County Jail here today after joining a volunteer bucket brigade when water pipes burst on the second floor.

title: Park Rangers to Get Guns
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP)  California's state park rangers will begin carrying guns this week for the first time. Jack Smyre, the park system's new police chief, said that side arms were being issued starting July 1 as a precautionary measure against urban crimes of violence spreading to the outdoors.

title: JAMES R. CLARKE
description: RED BANK, N.J., June 25 James Rae Clarke, president of Dominion Securities Corpora tion of Toronto and New York, until his retirement in 1967, died here yesterday in River view Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived on Navesink River Road in Locust.

title: Miss Ostrin Wed to Dr. P. J. Epstein
description: Miss Abigail Sarah Ostrin was married yesterday after noon to Dr. Peter Jonathan Epstein. Rabbi William A. Orentlicher performed the ceremony in the Bayside (Queens) Jewish Center.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Is Said to Plan Separation Because of Politics,
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Martha Mitchell, the wife of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, was reported to have said today that she was leaving her husband until he decides to leave his job as President Nixon's campaign manager.

title: WELFARE INSPECTOR CITES UPSTATE FRAUD
description: State Welfare Inspector Gen eral George F. Berlinger dis closed yesterday that 181 nearly 19 per centof the 974 cases of, relief fraud or abuse that his office has investigated and referred to local welfare commissioners came from up state areas.

title: Music: Symphony of the New World
description: The Symphony of the New World put together one of its most thoroughly success ful concerts in recent seasons at Philharmonic Hall yester day afternoon, guided by George Byrd's baton and given an enormous lift by the graceful singing of Ve ronica Tyler. The integrated orchestra, which has been pulled in several directions this season by an internal dispute over its leadership and goals, has reconstituted its board of directors as a result of a city arbitrator's decision. Coleridge  Taylor Perkinson, one of the or chestra's founders, has been appointed by the board as acting music director and assiciate conductor.

title: City Ballet May Dance in the Kremlin
description: The Stravinsky Festival ended at the State Theater last night the same way it had begun: with emotion, ap plause and an announcement of things to come.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: Phils Win, 1 0, as Punches Fly
description: Gene Mauch's baseball career has been tempestuous. He has slammed his share of clubhouse doors and kicked over many a dugout water cooler. Some people might say that he even had his reasons.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 25 (AP)  Doctors reported today that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was showing signs of recovery from the effects of bullet damage to his spinal cord and now had some feeling in his thighs.

title: Court to Hear Arguments on Challenge to the War
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (UPI)A threeJudge Federal panel will hear arguments to morrow in a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Vietnam war.

title: MRS. ANDREW HOPKINS
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., June 25 Mrs. Gwendolyn Stephens Hop kins, who had been with Comp ton Advertising, Inc., for the last 15 years, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday evening in the Nyack General Hospital. She was 46 years old and lived on Heritage Drive.

title: Aponte Named to Labor Post
description: Edward William Aponte has been appointed regional man power administrator in the New York City regional offices of the United States Department of Labor, it was annouced yes terday. Mr. Aponte will be re sponsible for the department's employment, work  experience and training programs in Re gion II, made up of New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands. He succeeds Clayton J. Cottrell, who is now region al director.

title: A Bribery Turnabout Reported by a Painter
description: Frank Bona, a member of the painters' union, told of encountering an unusual twist about 10 days ago: an in spector offered to pay a bribe.

title: Teachers' Union Planning Puerto Rican Culture Guide
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, announced yesterday that his union would publish this fall the first teachers' guide on Puerto Rican history and culture.

title: Black Press, Now Courted by White Establishment, Hails Its Recent Gains
description: MIAMI, Fla., June 25A ma jor group of black newspaper publishers worked and played here for four days last week, were courted assiduously by local and national representa tives of the white establish ment and then sailed off on a cruise to Nassau.

title: GREAT PYRENEES TAKES TOP PRIZE
description: A big, white shaggy dog, Ch. Karolaska Glacier, found the heavy, rainsoaked turf of the parade grounds at Fort Wads worth to his liking yesterday. The Great Pyrenees lumbered to bestinshow honors at the 32d annual fixture of the Staten Is land Kennel Club which drew 1,570 dogs.

title: 15 Killed in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 25 (Reuters)Fifteen persons were killed and seven injured when a bus hit a rock and caught fire near the Dieng plateau in central Java, the police reported today.

title: Wellsville, N.Y., United In Fight Against Floods
description: WELLSVILLE, N.Y. June 25Like wellplaced punches, two floods struck this village of 6,000 inhabitants this week, pouring cascades of water, mud and debris onto a third of its homes and stores, destroying three bridges, wrecking part of its hospital, carrying away perhaps 100 automobiles, cut ting off its electricity and tele phones to the outside world and polluting its water supply.

title: Leslie Dansker Wed
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 25Miss Leslie Joy Dankser and Steven Jay Toepfer were married at the Hampshire Country Club here this evening. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Raphael Dansker and Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Toepfer.
