description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 27On the tense first day of the truce called by the Irish Republican Army's militant Provisional wing in agreement with the British, William Whitelaw, Northern Ireland's administrator, began a delicate effort today to reconcile the hostile Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

title: Rusk Message to U.S. Envoy In Moscow on 65 Hanoi Contact
description: Message from Secretary of State Dean Rusk to Foy D. Kohler, Ambassador to Moscow, May 11, 1965.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PIERRE, S. D., June 27The Republicans have chosen their candidate to run for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota.

title: U.S. Intelligence Unit to Sift Soviet Arms Pact Compliance
description: WASHINGTON, June 27Urrited States intelligence officials have established a committee to keep track of Soviet observance of the terms of the strategic arms limitation treaty signed in Moscow May 26.

title: Bus Terminal Is Called Safer Despite Shootout
description: When Barry M. Mayer, manager of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, uses the word opportunist, it covers a multitude of sinnersthe addicts, pickpockets, keyswitch artists, hustlers, handbag boosters, car thieves, prostitutes and soliciting homosexuals who gravitate to one of the world's busiest depots in search of a fast buck.

title: Market Place:
description: Investors who had a piece of the ErieLackawanna Railroad, the freight and commuter line that went under yesterday, may be about to go through one of the least painful reorganizations in corporate history.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: A suit against Jim McDaniels, who broke a $1.5million contract with the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Association to play for the Seattle Supersonics, was filed yesterday in New York State Supreme Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS DISPUTE BOMBING MISHAP
description: JERUSALEM, June 27Deputy Premier Yigal Allon defended himself today against criticism for his admission that Israeli attack bombers had accidentally hit civilian targets in a raid against Lebanon last Wednesday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Senator George McGovern's total of committed delegate votes sagged today as it became clear that he had won substantially fewer black votes than announced yesterday by black leaders who endorsed him.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 TIGERS HOMERS BEAT YANKEES, 52
description: DETROIT, June 27Aided by consecutive homers in the first inning by Aurelio Rodriguez, Al Kaline and Willie Horton, Mickey Lolich coasted to his 12th victory of the season tonight at Tiger Stadium as the Detroit Tigers raised their Eastern Division lead to two games with a 52 victory over the New York Yankees.

title: Loews Has Record Net
description: Operations of the Loews Corporation in the quarter and nine months ended May 31 resulted in the highest revenues and earnings in the history of the company, it reported yesterday.

title: Wedding Held For Mrs. Smith And John Knox
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 27 Mrs. Susan Black Smith of Fairfield and John R. Knox of New Canaan were married here this afternoon in the Hobart Chapel of the First Church Congregational by the Rev. Richard L. Rush.

title: HYGRADE IS SOUGHT BY WESTERN PACIFIC
description: Western Pacific Industries, Inc. the holding company that controls the Western Pacific Railroad, in an effort to diversify, is holding preliminary talks with the Hygrade Food Products Corporation, among other companies, for possible acquisitions, financial sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Phone Deposit and Cancellation Policies Are Scored at Hearing
description: Peter J. Mack of Far Rockaway, Queens, is 67 years old and has chronic high blood pressure. Last November, he told a hearing yesterday, New York Telephone Company billed him for several calls to California he never made. After he refused to pay the bill pending an investigation, his phone service was cut off.

title: Floating Prime Rate Is Set by Mellon Bank
description: The dollar and the pound rallied yesterday in the New York foreign exchange market. But dealers cautioned that the recovery was largely the result of trading among market professionals, and did not necessarily indicate that the international money crisis had passed.

title: The Danger Of Complacency
description: WASHINGTONThe Strategic Arms Limitations Talks have concluded in the ABM treaty and fiveyear interim agreement on offensive systems signed in Moscow May 26, 1972. I have supported the SALT negotiations because I believe we should reduce the dangers of nuclear confrontation.

title: Bill Giving Thieu Wide Defense and Economic Powers Rushed Through South Vietnam's Legislature
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27In an extraordinary session of the South Vietnamese Senate tonight, proGovernment senators pushed through a bill giving President Nguyen Van Thieu authority to rule by decree on matters of defense and economics for six months. The vote was 26 to 0.

title: Nixon Plans to Disclose New Troop Cut Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)Administration officials disclosed today that President Nixon plans to announce another troop withdrawal from Vietnam. They said that Mr. Nixon was preparing to disclose tomorrow the size of a new reduction beyond the level of the 49,000 men that was his goal for the end of this month.

title: Pollution Bond Posted
description: ALBANY, June 27 (AP)Stauffer Chemical Company has posted a $25,000 bond to assure that it will stop discharging toxic acid into Skaneateles Creek in Onondaga County, the Department of Environmental Conservation announced today. The department directed the company to cleanse the effluents of its plant in Skaneateles Falls by Jan. 31, 1973. The company must also provide facilities for recycling.

title: F. H. A. Barring All Mortgages In Sections of Brooklyn and L. I
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 27 The Federal Housing Admin istration has blacklisted at least six areas in Brooklyn and one on Long Island, prohibiting all further F.H.A.insured loans in these areas.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISEurope was startled by a minicrisis this month when French President Pompidou unexpectedly threatened to call off an October summit meeting of the six Common Market members and the four who hoped to joinunless it was agreed to move that expanded organization's political secretariat from Brussels to Paris.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)  Three candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination sketched for the National Association of Counties today the efforts they believe must be made to strengthen the nation.

title: Access to the Law
description: On June 12 the United States Supreme Court gave American lawyers several million new clients. It ruled that an impoverished criminal defendent cannot be jailed unless he has been offered free counsel. This decision further Increases the need for lawyers to represent Americans who have rarely benefited from legal advice and access to courts.

title: McGovern, in the South, Lays Racist Tactics to Nixon
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27 Asserting that President Nixon had been playing to racist emotions, Senator George McGovern traveled across the South today, appealing to Populist sentiments.

title: Tokyo to Tighten Curbs
description: TOKYO, June 27 (Reuters)The Tokyo foreign exchange market will reopen Thursday with some tightening of exchange controls, the Japanese Finance Ministry announced today.

title: MATTHEWS TAKES HIPKINS REGATTA
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 27 Dean W. Matthews of Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club won the men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound by 1 points today by finishing first in the final race of the 21st annual Hipkins Trophy Regatta at Larchmont Y. C.

title: New Venezuelan Air Routes
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) President Nixon approved three new routes today for the Venezuelan airline, Venezolana Internacional de Aviacn, or VIASA. They are to New York by way of San Juan, Puerto Rico; to Washington and New York by way of the Netherlands Antilles and Dominican Republic, and to Frankfurt and Hamburg, Germany, by way of San Juan, Madrid, Paris and Amsterdam.

title: OwensIllinois Sets Major Revamping Of Its Organization
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., one of the world's leading manufacturers of packaging products, announced yesterday a major reorganization of its corporate structure. The company said the changes were designed to prepare it for future growth and the retirement in the next three years of several corporate officers.

title: Further Testing Due Today on Continent
description: LONDON, June 27In the first trading on the foreign exchange market here since the pound was set free to float last Friday, it fell to $2.50 today, 4 per cent below its former official parity of $2.6057.

title: 2 MODERATES WIN MISSISSIPPI RUNOFFS
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 27Two political moderates won Democratic Congressional nominations in runoff primaries today in bids to succeed retiring conservative House members.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN 4PART HEART STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) United States and Soviet doctors will begin joint research into four types of heart disease in September, the White House announced today.

title: I.R.S. Eases Its Stand On Finance Charges
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service in a ruling today declared for the first time that all the finance charges on revolving charge accounts are deductible as interest on incometax returns.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 27 (UPI)Tony Oliva of the Minnesota Twins will probably undergo surgery this week on his ailing right knee, a Twins' spokesman said today.

title: S. & H. Names Directors
description: Dr. Mary I. Bunting, president of Radcliffe College, and James R. Houghton, vice chairman of the Corning Glass Works, have been elected directors of the Sperry and Hutchinson Company.

title: Anderson Alleges Surveillance of Many Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, June 27Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, turned over to the Congressional Black Caucus today a list, which he said came from the Secret Service, containing 5,500 names and aliases of black people on whom he said dossiers are maintained.

title: Dr. William Hannig, 85, Dies; Screened City School Personnel
description: Dr. William A. Hannig, who as a member of the Board of Examiners helped set personnel standards for teachers and administrators in the city's public schools from 1921 to 1953, died Sunday at his home. He was 85 years old and lived at Park Drive North at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

title: Leftist Front Formed in France
description: PARIS, June 27The French Communist and Socialist parties formed a new Popular Front today, their first agreement on a common policy since 1946.

title: Ad Hoc Unit Urges Olympic Approval For Two Convicts
description: The chairman of the New York City Board of Correction, William vanden Heuvel, announced yesterday the formation of a citizens committee to urge Olympic officials to permit two imprisoned American athletes to compete in the Games in August at Munich; West Germany.

title: Aide to Queens Prosecutor Accused of Fix in Gun Case
description: A narcotics agent who for the last 14 months has been part of an intensive Federal investigation of corruption among policemen, prosecutors and lawyers in New York has sworn that a highly respected assistant district attorney in Queens received about $12,000 to fix two cases.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Stock prices on the Amex moved up early in the day but then gave up the struggle to maintain the rise and ended down 0.03 at 27.24, as measured by the index. Meanwhile, the overthecounter market was not following this lead. The NASDAQ industrial index gained 0.52 to end at 139.80.

title: Citizens Group Predicts 50 Million Will Not Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)The Youth Citizenship Fund group predicted today that at least 50 million eligible voters would not vote in November, largely because of registration obstructions.

title: Rapid City Toll Up to 230
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., June 27 (AP)The death toll from the Rapid City flood June 9 rose to 230 yesterday with the recovery of the body of James Toutges, about 30, of Lead.

title: Italian Trade Deficit in May Narrowed From Year Ago
description: ROME, June 27 (Reuters)Italy recorded a trade deficit of 51 billion lire in May against a deficit of 89billion in the same 1971 month and a deficit of 13.5  billion in April this year, provisional figures from the Central Statistical Institute showed today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Whatever put Ken Buchanan on the floor Monday nighta punch below the equator, some witnesses thought; a not especially suppliant knee, according to Gil Clancy, who worked in the Scot's corner; a legal shot to the giblets in the judgment of Johnny LoBianco, the refereewhatever it was, that wasn't what cost him the lightweight championship of the world. The trouble with Kenneth was that Roberto Duran leaped upon him and struck him repeated blows. Duran struck him in the first round and was still striking him after the bell signaled the end of the 13th, whereupon this champion became one with Joe Gans, Benny Leonard, Nineveh and Tyre.

title: Roche Upsets Laver
description: ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) Rod Laver was a threeset victim of a fellowAustralian, Tony Roche, in the first round of the $50,000 Holton Classic tonight. The No. 1 seeded Layer lost. 64, 46, 75.

title: Bernstein Alters Mass for Opening Here Tonight
description: Leonard Bernstein's Mass was in rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera, where it will open tonight for the first time in New York. Maurice Peress was conducting, Gordon Davidson was directing and Mr. Bernstein, who conceived and composed it, was somewhere on the other side of town.

title: Zapata Confirms That S.E.C. Has Begun Informal Inquiry
description: The Zapata Corporation confirmed yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened an informal inquiry into the trading in its stock in connection with a proposed merger with the Granby Mining Company and Granisle Copper, Ltd.

title: FRAUD IS CHARGED AT CADMAN COOP
description: A corporate housing sponsor and its attorney were indicted on fraud charges by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday in connection with the sale of apartments in the Cadman Towers cooperative in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Towing Operators Admit They Steal to Survive
description: The head of an association representing 700 towing companies told a City Council committee hearing yesterday that every member of the association had been breaking the law constantly by overcharging.

title: SENATE APPROVES H.E.W.LABOR FUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Senate voted today to increase appropriations for Federal health and education programs more than $2billion above what President Nixon requested in his budget for the next fiscal year. The vote was 72 to 11.

title: Senate Unit Backs A Bill to Help Solve BackOffice Snags
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate Securities subcommittee approved a bill today that its chairman, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., called a major step toward solving Wall Street's backoffice problems.

title: Vorster Lays Inequalities To Earlier Governments
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa, June 27 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Vorster spoke out last night against students who participate in demonstrations against unequal opportunities for blacks and whites.

title: Israel Reports Guerrilla Killed
description: TEL AVIV, June 27 (AP)A Government military spokesman said today that an Israeli Army patrol killed an Arab guerrilla last night on the Lebanese border near the settlement of Dan.

title: Nixon Asks $100Million in Flood Relief
description: President Nixon asked Congress yesterday to approve an immediate $100million in Federal emergency relief for five states hit hardest by last week's floods.

title: Police Seize Bronx Man After BreakIn at Bank
description: A 27yearold Bronx man was arrested early this morning after he allegedly broke into a branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 749 East Tremont Avenue.

title: Kissinger Note to Bo
description: Message from Professor Kissinger read to Mr. Bo by Mr. Marcovich on Sept. 25, 1967.

title: Business Briefs
description: ROME, June 27 (AP)World production of beef, veal, pork and poultry is expected to increase by 4 to 6 per cent this year, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today. But prices probably will remain high, it added.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CAR THIEF. By Theodore Weesner. 370 pages. Random House. $6.95.

title: At Bombay, Where Drainpipe Can Be Home, Twin City Will Replace Slums
description: BOMBAY, India, June 17 Among the million or more homeless people of Bombay, the thousands who live in the wide drainpipes stored on vacant lots are considered the aristocrats of the squalid slums that disfigure one of India's leading cities.

title: 2 Queens School Boards Reject Scribner's Request Not to Stipulate Behavior on Diplomas
description: At least two of the city's 31 decentralized local school districts have rejected a suggestion by School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and decided to continue to award traditional junior high school diplomas stipulating that the graduates have achieved satisfactory records in behavior and citizenship as well as scholarship.

title: Ali Knocks Out Jerry Quarry in Seventh
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 27Muhammad Ali returned with his glamour and his gloves tonight and scored a technical knockout over Jerry Quarry 19 seconds into the seventh round of their scheduled 12round heavyweight fight.

title: Free Trade Pacts Set
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 27 (Reuters) The six Common Market members today agreed to sign a series of industrial free trade agreements next month with those European Free Trade Association countries remaining outside the European economic community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Panel Asks Curtailment Of Some Rights of Defendants
description: LONDON, June 27  Drastic changes in criminal law procedure that would remove some of a defendant's builtin advantages were recommended today in an official report by a committee of judges and jurists.

title: Music Sleuth Traces America's Past
description: Vera Brodsky Lawrence, a pianist who once concertized extensively in the United States and Europe, is now a headlong, and headstrong, explorer of musical Americana, In her view, To hear the many musics that were heard since our beginnings as a nation is, in a sense, to hear history happen again.

title: GATT Study to Survey World Trade in Textiles
description: GENEVA, June 27An international study of world trade in textiles is to be undertaken for the first time in an effort to find the facts underlying highlycharged economic and social issues that often embitter relations between importing and exporting countries.

title: Further Message From Kissinger To Bo on Oct. 8, 1967
description: Written message and oral points from Mr. Kissinger to Mr. Bo delivered by Mr. Marcovich and Mr. Aubrac on Oct. 8. 1967.

title: All Accused of Shaking Down Bronx Builder of DayCare Center
description: Five City Buildings Department inspectors were arrested yesterday after they allegedly took bribes from a builder at virtually every phase of his construction of a daycare center in the Bronx.

title: EMERGENCY STEPS ADOPTED BY SWISS
description: GENEVA, June 27The Swiss Government took two series of emergency measures today to prevent a flood of foreign capital from upsetting Switzerland's monetary stability by taking refuge in the Swiss franc.

title: S.E.C. Order Stops Levitz Offering
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today to stop indefinitely a planned offering of additional stock by the Levitz Furniture Company.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., June 27 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace's doctor reported today that the Alabama Governor was gaining weight and standing with the aid of braces.

title: Senate Unit Asks I.T.T. Case Review
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to ask the Justice Department to review the, committee's investigation of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation antitrust cases for possible perjury prosecution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PAY BOARD BACKS CITY WAGE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Pay Board today approved firstyear raises in the contracts of about 118,000 employes of New York City and the Transit Authority, but reduced secondyear Increases for most nonuniformed city workers.

title: STATE WARNS CITY ON RENT CUT PLAN
description: The state warned New York City yesterday that a recent change in the city's rent control program was illegal and could not go into effect without approval of the State Commissioner of Housing and Communiy Renewal.

title: EXARMY LAW CHIEF IS GRANTED PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)  The Government granted parole today to Maj. Gen. Carl C. Turner once the army's top law enforcement officer and later chief of United States marshals, who was convicted last year of firearms law violations.

title: London's dips take pride in their work
description: LONDONAnna Dolan stopped in Piccadilly Circus to buy an afternoon paper. She took out her change purse and left her shoulder bag open while the news vendor sorted out three new pence from the coins in her outstretched palm. Having arrived from New York that morning on her first visit to London, she was not yet familiar with the money. When she replaced the purse in her bag, she noticed her billfold had gorie. One copy of The Eyening Standard had cost her about $70.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: If you live in the New York area, were watching TV last night and were paying attention to the commercials, you already know that Joe's back.

title: Jersey Inspections Scored
description: TRENTON, June 27 (AP)A combination of corruption and inefficiency in Newark's Divi sion of Inspection is ruining a statewide program aimed at assuring safe and decent housing, the Center for Analysis of Public Issues asserted today.

title: SCRIBNER IN CLASH AT HOUSE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, June 27A Congressional hearing on the problems of drug abuse in the New York City schools erupted into an angry clash today, with the Chancellor of the city schools and a Brooklyn Representative questioning each other's honesty.

title: Philippine Typhoon Toll Of at Least 100 Is Feared
description: MANILA, June 27 (UPI)A typhoon that struck the Philippines this weekend caused $5million in damage, left at least 25,700 families homeless and took a toll of lives that may pass 100, officials said today.

title: Dr. Sankey Vaughan Williams Marries Constance B. Hess
description: DEAL, N. J., June 27Miss Constance Beth Hess was married here at noon today to Dr. Sankey Vaughan Williams. Municipal Court Judge Lawrence A. Carton 3d of Locust performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Hess of New York and Deal.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, June 27Mayor Daley denounced today the findings of Cecil Poole, the Democratic National Committee's hearing examiner, saying Mr. Poole overlooked the fact that these delegates were elected by 900,000 people.

title: PAKISTANIS LEARN EXTENT OF DEFEAT
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 27 In a frankness the people of Pakistan have not heard, President Zulfikar All Bhutto tonight admitted that Pakistan suffered a crushing defeat in the December war with India and that nearly, a million people were homeless because of Indian occupation of West Pakistani territory.

title: ESB, Inc., Shifts Officers
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) Edward J. Dwyer stepped down today as chief executive officer of ESB, Inc., the world's largest manufacturer of batteries. He will continue as chairman of the board. Frederick J. Port, who was president and chief operations officer of ESB, was elected president and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. Reports Air Strikes Close to Center of Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 28  American planes flew more than 320 strikes against North Vietnam Monday and attacked targets within the city limits of Hanoi and Haiphong.

title: Message From President Johnson To Taylor, Envoy in Saigon
description: Personal message, cabled with flash priority, from President Lyndon B. Johnson to Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, May 10, 1965. U. Alexis Johnson was deputy ambassador to Saigon and the Premier was Phan Huy Quat.

title: City Creates a Design for Fashion Capital of World
description: Plans for the first annual Fall Fashion Festival as part of a program to establish New York as the fashion capital of the world were outlined yestetrday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Bobby Hull Shifts Hockey Leagues for $2.5Million
description: In a deal of such magnitude that it had to be consummated in two countries, Bobby Hull jumped from the National Hockey League to the World Hockey Association yesterday for a package worth at least $2.5million.

title: Stunting Plane Thief Killed
description: REDDING, Calif., June 27 (AP)Robert D. Lively, 25 years old, formerly of Redding, stole a small plane and performed dive and loop stunts for almost four hours today before he nosedived to his death after ignoring warnings that he was running out of gas, sheriff's deputies said.

title: House Backs Extension of $450Billion Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The House of Representatives passed the debtceiling bill today and sent it to the Senate, where Democrats are expected to attempt, over the Administration's objections, to add an amendment increasing Social Security benefits. The vote was 211 to 168.

title: ERNEST J. MARCOULIER
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., June 27Ernest J. Marcoulier, a retired camera inventor and manufacturer, died yesterday in Bradley Memorial Hospital, Southington. He was 93 years old and lived at 416 Beacon Hill Drive.

title: Democrats Assured Of a Platform Fight
description: WASHINGTON, June 27A platform acceptable to Senator George McGovern and his two chief rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senators Hubert H. Humphrey and Edmund S. Muskie, was completed today for presentation to the party's national convention July 10.

title: Eva Beatrice Meinberg Is Bride in Israel of Yakov Aviad
description: Miss Eva Beatrice Meinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Meinberg of PortauPrince, Haiti, was married yesterday to Yakov Aviad, deputy Israeli consul general in New York.

title: Province Chief in Binhdinh, Where Foe Gains, Is Ousted
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 (Reuters)The chief of the central coastal province of Binhdinh, one of the country's most populous and politically troubled areas, has been dismissed by Saigon, the official news agency reported today.

title: Hanoi Reply to U.S. Message
description: Reply from North Vietnamese message, handed to Mr. Marcovich by Mr. Bo on Sept. 11, 1967.

title: Italy to Resume Trading
description: ROME, June 27The Bank of Italy late tonight ordered the reopening tomorrow of normal foreign exchange operations but issued measures to prevent a further weakening of the lira through speculative capital movements.

title: Further Note to Bo
description: Message from United States Government to Mr. Bo, dated Sept. 13, 1967, and delivered Sept. 26.

title: Peron Gets Right to Run
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 27 (Reuters)The exiled dictator Juan D. Peron was authorized today to run for election and to vote, in general elections next March by Federal, Judge Leopoldo Insaurralde, a court spokesman said.

title: Quarry Family Loses Outside the Ring, Too
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 27 (UPI)  The two Quarry brothers did their fighting in the ring tonight, but a fight outside the ring sent their brotherinlaw to jail.

title: Pentagon Volumes on Diplomacy Show Neither U.S. Nor Hanoi Would Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Pentagon papers volumes on the secret diplomacy of the Johnson Administration show that Hanoi and Washington could not reach a peace settlement because they could not compromise their basic disagreement over who would hold power in South Vietnam.

title: KELLOGG IS VICTIM OF FEUD IN JERSEY
description: A New Jersey State Senator has blocked the reappointment of James C. Kellogg 3d as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority.

title: Bridge: Law of Game Do Not Deal With Conduct of Kibitzers
description: The laws of the game have little to say about the proper behavior of kibitzers, and nothing about the proper procedure if a kibitzer does influence the action directly or indirectly. A year or two ago the appeals committee at a national tournament nearly had the embarrassing task of ruling on the penalty for a revoke that had been pointed out by the fiance of one of the players revoked against.

title: Miss Davis, Balking Over Balance Plan, Is Off Cavett Show
description: The scheduled appearance of Angela Davis on the Dick Cavett television show this week will not take place because of a dispute over whether a balancing guest should appear on the same program.

title: Bronx Arm of Triborough Is Closed 12 Hours by Fire
description: The Bronx portion of the Triborough Bridge was closed for almost 12 hours yesterday because of a fire beneath the section, and massive traffic jams developed in arteries to and from the Bronx.

title: 2 Vast Mail Facilities in Jersey Offer Hope for Improved Service
description: KEARNY, N.J., June 27 The world's biggest, most complex mail distribution plant11 miles of conveyor belts monitored with 171 closed  circuit television camerashas begun to process. North Jersey's bulk mail in a 23acre building here in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: Economic Analysis
description: None of Senator George McGovern's economic proposals has stirred up more controversy and confusion than his earlier plan to grant $1,000 to every man, woman and child. In Oklahoma City this week, Senator McGovern disclosed that he was preparing a substitute welfare reform plan that would be somewhat less costly by providing grants or tax credits of $3,700 rather than $4,000 to a family of four, would benefit all families except those with incomes over $20,000, and would provide higher credits for adults than for young children.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has received a $47.7million addition to a previously awarded Army contract for the development of the Stinger missile, an improved version of the Redeye heatseeking weapon, it was announced yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (Reuters)The Federal National Mortgage Association issued $76.6million in commitments on Governmentbacked home mortgages at an average yield of 7.626 per cent, it announced today.

title: TV: Frequently It's Those Little Things That Count
description: Often, especially while watching television, it's the little things that count.

title: 65 Note on Resumed Bombing
description: Message from Secretary of State Rusk to United States Ambassador in Saigon, London and Ottawa, May 17, 1965.

title: Uncommitted Delegate in the Spotlight
description: RIVERTON, Wyo., June 25 Anita Portwood has received so many calls lately that sometimes she picks up the telephone and says, Mrs. Portwood is out on the range and won't be back until July 5.

title: Anaconda Sells Zinc Unit
description: The Anaconda Company reported yesterday the sale of its zinc fuming plant at East Helena, Mont., to the American Smelting and Refining Company, effective July 1. The sale was made in line with Anaconda's decision earlier in the year to shut down zinc operations at Great Falls and Anaconda, Mont.

title: Bombs for Peace?
description: The United States is a fourtime loser in the bombing of North Vietnam's only steel plant. The fifth bombing last weekend again has halted production there, but it is unlikely that it will hamper North Vietnam's war effort any more significantly than did the other four. Nor is there any substantial military purpose to be achieved in the steppedup aerial attacks this week in the HanoiHaiphong area, which undoubtedly are taking a heavy civilian toll.

title: LIBRARY DEFENDED ON RIGHTS RECORD
description: CHICAGO, June 27  The deputy director of the Library of Congress made a graphic and comprehensive defense today of the institution's employment record at the annual convention of the American Library Association. As a result, critics withdrew a motion of censure, alleging discrimination against blacks and other minorities.

title: 65 Reports on Outlook for War By U.S. Intelligence Community
description: Section of Pentagon papers dealing with reports on outlook for Communists activities, April 22, 1965. First section is attributed to leading personalities of the United States intelligence community. Sections in italics are the Pentagon analysts explanation, which later introduces comments by Adm. William F. Raborn Jr., then Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Socialists at Parley Hail Their Golda
description: VIENNA, June 27The Socialist International which is holding its 12th congress here, has the flavor of a class reunion: It's Willy and Harold, Francois and Pietro, Bruno and Olof, as government chiefs greet leading politicians.

title: BRAZIL COURT TOLD OF INDIAN MASSACRE
description: CUIABA, Brazil, June 27 (Reuters)  A criminal court here heard testimony today that confirmed accounts of murder raid by Brazilian adventurers on an Indian jungle village nine years ago.

title: GARMENT UNION AIDS VICTIMS OF FLOODS
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced yesterday that its general executive board had allocated $1million for immediate relief to victims of the floods, especially in Pennsylvania but also in western New York and other areas.

title: Liberal Party for McGovern; Tactics of His Foes Denounced
description: The Liberal party yesterday endorsed the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota and berated the stopMcGovern forces, saying they had to rely on delegates pledged to Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Aluminum Company of America has exercised an option to purchase a large Wyoming deposit of anorthosite, one of several alternates for bauxite as a source of alumina, the ore from which aluminum is smelted.

title: 444POUND TAYLOR SWEEPS MAT TRIALS
description: ANOKA, Minn., June 27 (AP)  Chris Taylor won his second United States Olympic trials wrestling title tonight in four days.

title: A.B.C., in a Shift, Plans Series Of Serious Dramatic Specials
description: The American Broadcasting Company yesterday announced plans to upgrade the quality of drama specials on its television network, including presentation of the National Theater Company of Great Britain's recent highly praised production of Long Day's Journey Into Night, starring Laurence Olivier.

title: Edward Derrell Stone Firm To Design Yugoslav Hotel
description: The architectural firm of Edward Durell Stone and Associates announced yesterday that it had been named prime architect for a $50million hotel resort project to be built near the Adriatic Coast City of Dubrovnik, Yugoslavia. Financing for the project is being provided by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Privedna Banka of Zagreb. Construction of the resort, which will accommodate 5,000 persons, is scheduled to start next year.

title: Middle East Myopia
description: For the sixth time in less than four years the United Nations Security Council has condemned Israel for retaliatory raids against Lebanon without seriously addressing the root of the problemdeadly Palestinian guerrilla attacks against Israel from Lebanese soil. This myopic, partisan approach to incidents in the Middle East can only serve further to exacerbate tensions, to undermine the U.N.'s efforts to promote an ArabIsraeli settlement and to erode whatever confidence still exists in Security Council resolutions.

title: Senate Panel Votes Ban On Most Short Handguns
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Senate Judiciary Committee voted, 12 to 2, today to ban the manufacture and sale of most snubnosed handguns.

title: Notes on People
description: Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader, supped in the Chinese capital with Kuo Mojo, vice chairman of the standing committee of the National People's Congress; Chang Hsijo, president of the Chinese People's Institute for Foreign Affairs, and other officials.

title: BIG A RIDERS HAIL DURAN'S TRIUMPH
description: While the main order of business for the jockeys at Aqueduct yesterday was the workaday chore of riding, the main topic of conversation among the sturdy little athletes was the resounding victory registered by Roberto Duran in wresting the world lightweight boxing championship from Ken Buchanan on Monday night.

title: Credit Markets
description: New York State decided yesterday to postpone selling $151million of bonds because of poor conditions in the market for taxexempt securities. Because the issue was to have been put up for bids this morning, the move had the immediate effect of relieving the upward pressure on interest rates. Three new offerings marketed yesterday attracted strong demand from investors. Otherwise, the irregular but persistent climb in rates continued during the day with corporate issues showing a sharp price decline late in the session and some money rates extending recent rises.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Meeting Of Sperry Rand Holders
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27 AP)A class action suit filed here tonight asks the United States District Court to block the annual meeting of the Sperry Rand Corporation, and alleges that the company had not sent a lawful proxy statement to shareholders.

title: Advertising:
description: Almost at the beginning of its second decade in business, Carl Ally, Inc., filed a preliminary prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission to go public. It's a nice way to celebrate.

title: BOYLE SENTENCED TO A 5YEAR TERM; IS FINED $130,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 27W. A. Boyle, the 70yearold president of the United Mine Workers of America, was sentenced to five years in prison today and fined $130,000 for making illegal political contributions with union funds.

title: DR. PETER FRANK, G.E. SCIENTIST, 39
description: Dr. Peter J. Frank, a scientific representative of the General Electric Company's research and development center in Europe, died yesterday afternoon in a Zurich hospital of a massive coronary attack. He was 39 years old.

title: Lesson of the Flood
description: Now that the torrential rains have ended over the vast area devastated by floods resulting from Tropical Storm Agnes, the enormous job of cleaning up, assessing and repairing the great damage, and trying to help the numerous victims has finally begun. The nation has been told by its chief meteorologist, Dr. Robert S. White, that this last week's flooding is the most extensive in the country's history. In Richmond, Harrisburg, WilkesBarre, Elmira, Corning and hundreds of other badly hit communities there will be no disposition to quarrel with this evaluation. The numbor of dead is well over 100 and damage estimates moulit toward the $2billion mark.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: ATTACK CHARGES DENIED BY MAYE
description: Far from kicking, or stomping anyone during disturbances at the New York Hilton Hotel three months ago, Michael Maye, president of the Uniformed Fire Fighters Association, testified yesterday, he never touched anyone except one unidentified goldenhaired homosexual who grabbed his groin and tore his pants.

title: Personalities: Sinatra to Testify
description: Frank Sinatra has agreed to appear voluntarily before the House Select Committee on Crime when it continues hearings on the relations between organized crime and sports July 18. The entertainer's attorney in Los Angeles, Milton A. Rudin, said Sinatra would talk about his 1962 investment in Berkshire Downs, a Massachusetts race track. The committee, led by Representative Claude Pepper, Florida Democrat, issued a subpoena for Sinatra after he failed to appear earlier as scheduled. Sinatra was reported to have been in England at that time. A spokesman for the committee said yesterday that he thought Sinatra was still in Europe, but that the voluntary agreement to appear meant Sinatra could return to the United States without fear of being served with the subpoena.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 27Eleven top American track and field athletes, including such potential medalists as Lee Evans, Jay Silvester, George Woods and Norman Tate, have been cleared to compete in the Olympic Games this year.

title: 2 French Envoys Meeting With Hanoi Premier in July, 1967
description: Reports on conversations with Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam held in Hanoi in July, 1967, by Raymond Aubrac and Herbert Marcovich, French scientists who are friends of Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Britain Moves to Topple VacantBuilding Empire
description: LONDON, June 27 (AP)For eight years Harry Hyams made millions by doing nothing.

title: Report by U.S. Envoy in Moscow On Talk With High Soviet Aide
description: Report by Ambassador Kohler on a conversation in May, 1965 with Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister. The paragraph in italics is the Pentagon history's commentary.

title: FUEL CELLS LIGHT 3 BUILDINGS HERE
description: A technological development that could put gas companies into competition with electric companies was demonstrated yesterday by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

title: MOLLY S. LEVY DIES; COATSUIT DESIGNER
description: Mrs. Molly Sarnoff Levy, a designer of coats and suits for Jack Sarnoff, Inc., and a partner in the family firm until her retirement last year, died yesterday at her home, 875 Fifth Avenue. She was 67 years old.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS TURN STEADIER
description: Stock prices turned steadier yesterday, recovering from the effects of the floating of the British pound abroad and from the flooding caused by tropical storm Agnes at home.

title: Annual SEATO Meeting Opens With U.S. and the Philippines Differing on Future Role of the Alliance
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 27  The Philippines and the United States differed today on the future of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization as the alliance opened its annual meeting in Canberra.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1 No Title

title: Pentagon Papers Tell Of Soviet Peace Role
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Newly disclosed sections of the Pentagon papers show that the Soviet Union, after first rebuffing American requests in 1965 to serve as a Middleman in ending the Vietnam war, became progressively more interested in acting as a diplomatic channel between Washington and Hanoi. But, the papers add, Moscow always seemed unwilling to put pressure on North Vietnam to give up its struggle.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ralph R. Stafford, formerly director of eastern relations for the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, has been named president of the Satra Industrial Corporation.

title: Nashville Appeals on Busing
description: NASHVILLE, June 27 (AP)The Nashville School Board directed its attorney today to appeal to the Supreme Court a Federal District Court order for desegregation by busing. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld Nashville's busing order earlier this month.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Jackie Stewart is more than just a racing driver who won the world championship in 1969 and 1977, JackieofallTrades is a salesman and public relations expert; he runs discotheques and auto shows, he endorses products and he makes TV commercials for tea and British railways; he models racing clothes and he may yet take up acting. Business takes more of his time than racing and his income is in the neighborhood of $700,000 a year. He lives in Switzerland, a refuge from British taxes, and he carries a full briefcase on the 450,000 miles he travels each year. Currently Jackie is wearing the ultimate badge of the tycoon: An ulcer has temporarily sidelined him from racing these last few weeks.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Democratic National Convention's Credentials Committee, rejecting protests by reformers, voted today to seat three challenged state delegations despite charges that they had been chosen in violation of the party's new guidelines.

title: WESTERN PLANS ON OIL REJECTED
description: VIENNA, June 27 (Reuters) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today cut short its summer conference here and issued a statement rejecting Western oil company proposals for compensation on future oil revenue losses.

title: Hess's Cuts Dividend
description: Hess's, Inc., an Allentown, Pa., department store chain, said yesterday that it has cut its quarterly dividend, to 5 cents a share from 15 cents a share, to conserve capital for expansion purposes. The dividend is payable Aug. 21 to shareholders of record July 27.

title: Mrs. Dorothy Pitkin Dead; Author of Books for Girls
description: AMHERST, Mass., June 27Mrs. Dorothy Horton Pitkin, author of several books for girls, died yesterday in a nursing home here. She was 73 years old and was the widow of Donald S. Pitkin, a Boston real estate broker.

title: BERNARD F. ULRICH
description: Bernard F. Ulrich, president of Metro Education, Inc., of New Rochelle, N. Y., died of a heart attack an Sunday. He was 58 years old and lived at 105 Hartland Avenue, Emerson, N. J.

title: Opera
description: A man once described the Cincinnati Summer Opera at the Zoo as The place where you can't hear Vissi d'arte for the ducks. Well, the Cincinnati forces have just moved into the city's grand old Music Hall, leaving the ducks to compete only with the airplanes overhead.

title: Political Gifts Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) Ralph Nader asked the Internal Revenue Service today to determine whether big political contributors were paying gift taxes. The consumer advocate and an affiliate, Public Citizen, Inc., also asked the I.R.S. to disclose documentation relating to a weekold ruling by the tax agency that eases gift tax avoidance by campaign donors.

title: Business Briefs
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, June 27 (AP)The West German trade balance in May and in the first five months of the year was higher than in comparable periods in 1971, the Federal statistics office reported today. The balance for May was $407million, compared with $381million in May, 1971, The April, 1972, balance was $420million.

title: METS WIN, 7 TO 4, AS FREGOSI STARS
description: Jim Fregosi went to the movies yesterday and then drove in five runs with a single and a homer as the Mets continued their thrust back toward first place with a 74 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Tortoise Tax in Jersey
description: The fundamental reform of New Jersey's inadequate and regressive tax structure has been so long overdue, and so slow in the coming, that the chances for success at the current session of the State Legislature must not be frivolously lost. There is an immediate need for Gov. William T. Cahill, who champions reform, and leaders of the Democratic opposition to work out reasonable compromises.

title: SMITH ADVANCES IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27  Stan Smith moved another shaky step toward the Wimbledon tennis title that he was seeded to win, but the match of the day was abandoned in rain with fourthseeded Andres Gimeno and Onny Parun knotted, 3all, in the fifth set.

title: Lindsay Warns of a Full Attack on Corruption in Construction
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was serving notice on every member of government, and on those in private business and labor who may be tempted to offer a bribe, that this administration is fully committed to an effort against corruption in the construction industry.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon met with members of the Senate Finance Committee to discuss welfare reform and other matters. He saw Dr. John Millis, chairman of the President's Panel on Heart Disease; Dr. Ted Cooper, director of the National Heart and Lung Institute, and Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. The President and Mrs. Nixon were hosts to a reception for about 200 radio and television newsmen and their wives attending background briefings at the White House.

title: Antiabortion Forces Demonstrate a Growing Influence in State Legislatures Across the Country
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Forces fighting the trend toward more liberal abortion laws, which some states began implementing about five years ago, are demonstrating a growing influence on state legislatures across the country.

title: Summer Prospects for City Power Supply Improve
description: State, city and utility officials reported brightened prospects yesterday for electricity here this summer, with 748,000 kilowatts of added capacity already installed ahead of schedule or due to be installed by midJuly and with firmpurchase contracts for up to 1,015,000 kilowatts.

title: Beirut Says Civilian Died
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 (Reuters)A Lebanese civilian was killed when Israeli troops set an ambush inside Lebanese territory last night, a military spokesman said here today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Short covering and a strong demand sent soybean futures prices higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Beans, oil and meal all shared in the advance.

title: Troy Easily Elected to 2d Term As Queens Democratic Leader
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr. scored an easy victory last night as he was reelected chairman of the Queens County Democratic Executive Committee for a second oneyear term.

title: U.S. Message to Hanoi Official On Bombing Pause and 67 Talks
description: Message from United States to Mai Van Bo, North Vietnamese representative in Europe, dated Aug. 25, 1967.

title: Charles Tazewell, Who Wrote The Littlest Angel, Dies at 72
description: CHESTERFIELD, N. H., June 27 (UPI)  Charles Tazewell, author of the Christmas story, The Littlest Angel, died last evening at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: Cooper Plans Price Rise
description: The Cooper Tire & Rubber Company said yesterday at Findlay, Ohio, that it planned to raise prices of its highway passenger tires, truck tires and tubes by 1 to 2 per cent, effective July 1. The company said this was in line with moves made previously by other manufacturers.

title: HOUSE VOTES RISE IN ARMS SPENDING AS ASKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 27President Nixon's request for increased spending authority to improve the nation's arsenal of strategic weapons in the wake of the recent arms control agreements with the Soviet Union was overwhelmingly endorsed today by the House of Representatives.

title: For Political Wives, It's a Difficult Life
description: WASHINGTONMrs. Hubert H. Humphrey just traveled 25,000 miles by car, campaigning strenuously for her husband. She rode in parades, spoke to students in clubs, visited hospitals, handed out literature on the street. She called it all a wonderful experience.

title: CARL RICH, 73, DEAD; EXCINCINNATI MAYOR
description: CINCINNATI, June 27Carl W. Rich, former Republican member of Congress and twice Mayor of Cincinnati, died last night in his apartment at the Cincinnati Club. He was 73 years old.

title: From Art of Others, She Makes Her Own
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I.The Williamsburgstyle house, with its dark brown shingles and white shutters, is one of the more pleasant of the many homes bordering the harbor and golf course here. It was built only about 20 years ago but it manages to convey an unpretentious effect of belonging.

title: Florida Fans Get Unruly As Screen Is Blacked Out
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 27 (AP)The police were summoned to Marine Stadium tonight to calm an unruly crowd of 9,400 that booed and hooted when a closedcircuit television screen went black in the middle of the Bob Foster  Mike Quarry boxing match. Patrons had paid $6 and $8 to see the fight program.

title: Wallace to Appear on TV With 5 Other Candidates
description: Gov. George C. Wallace, partially paralyzed since being felled by an assassin's bullet, will appear with five other Democratic Presidential hopefuls on a special twohour Meet the Press on July 9, the day before the Democratic National Convention.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
REFORMERS SEIZE PARTY IN HUDSON
description: JERSEY CITY, June 27A reform coalition headed by Mayor Paul T. Jordan seized control of the regular Hudson County Democratic organization here tonight, electing Mayor Francis G. Fitzpatrick of Bayonne as the new Democratic County chairman.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 20.

title: TAX RISE OPPOSED BY BUDGET CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 President Nixon's budget chief told Congress today that an increase in taxes is exactly the wrong answer to what he called the ominous trend toward a rise in government spending more rapid than the rise in receipts.

title: Marijuana on Coast Ballot
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 27 (AP)An initiative to legalize the private use of marijuana has qualified for the November ballot, the Secretary of State's office said today.

title: Screen: Mud People Go Home Again:'Savages,' Film by Ivory, Views Civilization
description: The Mud People, a primitive jungle tribe with strict protocols and lax morals, stand ready for the ritual execution of last year's consort to their high priestess. Suddenly, arching over the trees, they see a high-flying croquet ballseemingly possessed of magic properties to lead them, so they cannot choose but follow. They approach the grounds of a deserted country estate, timidly enter the great house, discover stairs, paintings, toy trains, books, speech and clothes. By mid-afternoon they have become rich exurbanites, semi-civilized, much like the rest of usexcept that their style of dress is elegant 1930's, not all of them wear shoes and they worship a croquet ball.This is the situation of James Ivory's "Savages," which opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater and which treats the rise and fall of a civilization, no special civilization, in 24 hours. By evening the savages are exchanging gossip and manipulating great affairs of state and commerce over dinner; near midnight the sacrificial consort drowns himself in the swimming pool; later there are wild orgies in the basement; before dawn the people have rediscovered mud, and the first daylight finds them running back into the forest, following croquet balls they have hit with their own mallets.Nothing is changed, but much has been touched, for "Savages" is the work of a sensibilityor several sensibilitiesrefined almost to the point of invisibility. And each time you think how clever such a movie might be, the movie becomes that clever, or a bit cleverer. Two minor examples: the wonderful Art-Deco title cards to accompany the savages' early silencewith meaningless titles like "Tribal elders are often distinguished by pebbles in their teeth, though such is not the case here"; and the untranslated German voice-over narration, perhaps to bring scholarly authority to the savages' superior powers of adaptation.But in less minor matters the film is not so satisfying. Both its idea of savagery and its idea of civilization are fairly precious conceits, and they lead in the long run to a piling of artifice upon artificea method of satire, but in this case, without a satirist's passion or even his point of view. Almost every moment in "Savages" seems like part of a superb movie that has not been quite put together. And I think that the lack has more to do with the strength or range of very basic concepts, rather than with technique or local insights, which are often marvelous.But whatever is missing from "Savages," we are left with a good dealfrom the almost lyrical direction, to the always intelligent screen writing, to the lush and delicate photography. The cast is large, drawn mostly from the New York stage and, for what it has to do, very nearly faultless. I especially like Anne Francine's distinguished hostess, Thayer David's overbearing capitalist, Sam Waterston's and Lewis Stadlen's decent young men, Ultra Violet's indecent young woman, Paulita Sedgwick's sensitive girl, and Kathleen Widdoes in top hat and tails dancing a number called "Stomping on a Spaniel."

title: Chairman of Pan Am Expresses Guarded Optimism
description: The situation is improving but there is still a long difficult road ahead, William T. Seawell, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways, told security analysts yesterday.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, June 27For many if not most of the attorneys at the time it could easily have been an open and shut case. A suspect in the robbery of a downtown Washington pie shop 30 days earlier had been arrested and identified by the victimized clerk. But in the mind of Charles Robert Richey, the defendant's courtappointed attorney, there were more questions raised than answered. So in a style that was to characterize his mode of operation in coming years, Mr. Richey sought and gained the suspect's acquittal by showing that the clerk could not even identify a bondsman who had spent 45 minutes talking to her earlier during the trial.

title: Philadelphia Aide Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Maurige Osser, chairman of the Philadelphia Election Com mission, was indicted today for evading taxes, mail fraud, ob struction of a criminal investi gation, filing false tax returns and conspiracy. Mr. Osser, 62 years old, has been a member of the commission since 1951.

title: Miss Evert Wins in Struggle, Graebner, Gonzales Ousted
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28Little Chris Evert survived her first appearance in the Wimbledon spotlight, but it took all her legendary coolness in the crises to outlast Valerie Ziegenfuss in a threeset match that had its moments of magic today.

title: Panacon Merger Approved
description: Stockholders of the Panacon Corporation approved yester day its merger into the Celotex Corporation, a subsidiary of the Jim Walter Corporation. Last April, Jim Walter purchased an 89 per cent interest in Panacon from the Glen Alden Corpora tion for $62million. Purchase of the remaining shares brings the total cost of the Panacon acquisition to $73million.

title: Jobson, With 7 Firsts, Captures College Regatta
description: SAN DIEGO, June 28 (AP) A 22yearold New Jerseyan breezed to the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's singlehanded championship yesterday.

title: On Coast, A Trend To Nudity
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. Since the court ruling, I do feel a lot easier about this, said the bearded sun bather, who was on his sec ond trip to the beach this season.

title: Oldenburg Will Head Modern Museum
description: Richard E. Oldenburg, act ing director of the Museum of Modern Art, has been appointed its director, it was announced yesterday by David Rockefeller, board chairman, and William S. Paley, president. The appoint ment is effective immediately.

title: Research Unit Asks Reform of Laws
description: WASHINGTON, June 28A corporate research organization called today for the systematic reform of law enforcement, including the legalization of gambling and marijuana and the outlawing of handguns.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT Ms. IN BIZ WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: Variable MortgageLoan Rates Weighed
description: Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced yesterday that his agency expected to propose, a variablerate mort gage plan for savings and loan associations by the end of the year. If implemented, the plan would represent a major inno vation in homefinancing tech nique.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CANBERRA, Australia, June 28 (UPI) Secret service men today found a homemade bomb at a Canberra hotel where 44 delegates attending the South east Asia Treaty Organization meeting were staying. Security men disposed of the bomb.

title: Company Will Pay $5 For Detaching Phones
description: A telephone subscriber who moves to a new address will receive a $5 credit fee from the New York Telephone Company if he snips off the telephone wire at his former residence and turns the tele phone over to a company serviceman at his new ad dress.

title: Tear Gas Used to Disperse Demonstrators in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 28 (Reuters)The Police used tear gas to disperse 500 antiGov ernment demonstrators here to day, the sixth anniversary of the seizure of political power by the Armed Fores.

title: Dissent and Confusion
description: In ruling that the small, predominantly white Virginia town of Emporia could not withdraw from the predom inantly black county school system, the Supreme Court last week found itself for the first time sharply divided over a school desegregation issue. The four justices appointed by President Nixon dissented from the majority opinion  not, they said, with any intent to retreat from desegregation but in order to register their opposi tion to the view that desegregation must entail creation of a racial balance in school enrollment.

title: Corning Glass Profit Is Up; Flood Damage Assessed
Pennsylvania Lottery Off
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 28 (AP)State lottery officials to day canceled next week's drawing and said the lottery would be out of business for several weeks following the July 12 drawing. Flood waters left stocks of lottery supplies and equipment under nine feet of water, according to Henry H. Kaplan, executive director.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 28 Chuck Hall, the silverhaired Mayor, points out an original John Lennon drawing hanging in his office and exchanges the radical movement's special handshake with gay activists, underground journalists and anyone else young and hairy within reach.

title: Issue of Legal Marijuana To Go on California Ballot
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 28 (UPI)  California voters were assured today of the op portunity to decide this Novem ber whether the private use of marijuana should be legalized in the state.

title: View From Storm King
description: The proposed pumpedwater storage plant on Storm King Mountain is still a long way from realization, de spite refusal of the Supreme Court to review the Fed eral Power Commission's approval of this huge Consoli dated Edison project on the Hudson River. The Supreme Court's action is a blow to conservationists, but it is by no means the last word on the subject.

title: Seaver Captures 10th
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 With four of their best hitters sidelined because of a variety of ailments, the New York Mets relied upon the good right arm of Tom (Terrific) Seaver to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 32, tonight.

title: Laura Rosen Is Bride of Howard Reiter
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 28Miss Laura S. Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rosen of Brooklyn, N.Y., was married here this afternoon to Howard L. Rei ter, vice president of the Ripon Society and a candi date for a doctorate in po litical science at Harvard University as a National Sci ence Foundation fellow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A group of policemen yesterday aided a Pennsylvania couple who had come here as flood victims and then found their car had been towed away for illegal parking.

title: CON ED IS BUILDING TEST PLANT ON S.I.
description: The Consolidated Edison Company broke ground yester day for a $4million pilot plant on Staten Island along the Arthur Kill to find out if there is a cheaper way than the present use of expensive low sulphur fuel preventing noxious sulphur dioxide from getting into the city's air.

title: Townie Tyke Wins $28,050 Nassau County Handicap at Aqueduct
description: That horse ran real good, didn't he, said Sid Wafters at Aqueduct yesterday, just af ter Towzie Tyke of the Hick ory Tree Stable had won the $28,050 Nassau County Handi cap. He beat a lot of good horses. He did, too, and paid $16.40 for $2.

title: Business Briefs
description: E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co., Inc., will form a new subsidiary in Luxembourg to build and operate a plant to manufacture Typar spunbonded polypropylene, used pri marily as a carpet backing in tufted carpets, and in bed ding, furniture, automotive and packaging applications. The plant will be built at ConternHesperange, near Luxembourg, and will employ about 175 people. When completed in 1974, the venture will represent an investment of approximately $40million.

title: CHOATE HEADMASTER TO RETIRE NEXT YEAR
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., June 28 (AP)The Rev. Seymour St. John, headmaster of The Choate School since 1947, has resigned, effective the end of the next academic year, the school an nounced yesterday.

title: Falcey Is Named
description: TRENTON, June 28 (UPI) Robert M. Falcey, currently assistant secretary of state, will serve in Mr. Sherwin's place until the charges brought against the secretary of state have been disposed of, the gov ernor's office announced today.

title: Approval of Retroactive Wage Rises For 118,000 Will Cost City $60Million
description: Pay Board approval of first year wage increases for 118,000 city and Transit Authority em ployes has cleared the way for payment of an estimated total of $60million in retroactive ob ligations.

title: Phone Deposit Policy Called Extortion
description: The New York Telephone Company was accused yester day of extorting high de posits from customers it wants to punish and from those who make repeated complaints.

title: After All These Years, N.H.L. Thinks It Has Found a Way to Stop Bobby Hull
description: Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, indicated yester day that Bobby Hull could well be the highest paid nonplaying hockey star when the season starts in October.

title: ICI AMERICA NAMES 3 HIGH EXECUTIVES
description: Organizational shifts at the top level were announced yes terday by ICI America, Inc., the surviving company of the recent merger of the American subsidiary of Imperial Chemi cal Industries Ltd., of England, and Atlas Chemical Industries, of Wilmington, Del.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MEMPHIS, June 28 (UPI)The Memphis Pros are soon to be only a memory. Charles O. Finley, the new owner of the American Basketball Association team, has announced a contest to rename the club.

title: A Mixed Trend Is Shown By Credit Market Rates
description: Uncertainties about monetary conditions abroad and inflation at home continued to weigh heavily on the money and capi tal markets yesterday. The ef fect on interest rates, however, was unevenly felt.

title: City Council Panel Votes Tough Controls on Noise
description: Noisecontrol legislation de scribed as the most compre hensive in the country was ap proved unanimously yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection.

title: Reform of Environment Long Goal of Maverick
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, the multimedia thinker who for 45 years has been a promin ent maverick in almost every field from philosophy to en gineering, is ending his days as a dogged individualist and turning over his life work of reforming the en vironment of man to a new, nonprofit corporation, the Design Science Institute.

title: Jackie Robinson Says F.B.I. Denies He's on Security List
description: Jackie Robinson, cited by the columnist Jack Anderson on Tuesday as being on a Secret Service list of potential threats to the President, said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Depart ment of Justice had assured him that the report was untrue.

title: PACIFIC ATOM TEST REPORTED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, June 28 (UPI)  France has resumed nuclear atmospheric testing in the South Pacific despite vigorous rirotests that the blasts might endanger the environment, Agence FrancePresse reported today.

title: Navy's New F14 Jet Passes A Landing Test on Carrier
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 28 (AP) The Navy's new F14 Tomcat jet has made its first successful arrested landing aboard an air craft carrier off the Virginia coast, Atlantic Fleet headquar ters announced today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Rare Guide
description: SACO, Me.  There is probably only one striped bass fishing guide on the East Coast who guarantees his clients that they will take fish every time out, and his name is Bob Bollard.

title: MRS. IRVING ASSERTS SWISS BREAK PLEDGE
description: Mrs. Clifford Irving's lawyer charged in Federal Court yes terday that the Swiss Govern ment had reneged on a promise not to seek to extradite her if she faced charges in the How ard Hughes autobiography swin dle in New York.

title: METCALF CRITICIZES COMPANY ELECTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) Senator Lee Metcalf, Demo crat of Montana, charged today that corporate elections in the United States are as rigged as elections in the Soviet Union.

title: Stone Family Selling 2 Million Combined Insurance Co. Shares
description: W. Clement Stone, one of the country's richest men and a major contributor to President Nixon's campaign in 1963, is selling part of a $49million block of Combined Insurance Company of America common stock that was marketed yes terday by a Smith, Barney & Co. underwriting network.

title: BEIRUT PACT CUTS RAIDING ON ISRAEL
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28 Lebanon and the Palestinian guerrillas say they have reach ed an accord on reducing the presence of the commandos here and freezing their opera tions against Israel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Celanese Unit Is Expanding
description: The Celanese Chemical Com pany, a division of the Celanese Corporation, said yesterday that it would build a new acrylate ester plant at Clear Lake, Tex., that would increase the company's annual capacity to more than 300 million pounds. Acrylates, after poly merization with other mono mers, are used by the paint, industrial coatings, paper, tex tile, rubber and other industries.

title: Blacks Rebuff Shanker at N. E. A. Parley
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 28 Albert Shanker was rebuffed tonight when dozens of black delegates to the National Edu cation Association's annual con vention walked out from a meeting at which he was speak ing.

title: Sierra Clubs Slate Talks
description: TOPEKA, Kan., June 28 (AP) Sierra Club representatives from nine Middle Western, Southwestern and Mountain States will meet with national officers of the conservation or ganization in Denver July 15 and 16 to study the states' air quality statutes, Ron Baxter, the Kansas Sierra Club chair man, said today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 One of Senator George Mc Govern's top campaign aides met separately today with the leaders of contending factions in the potentially explosive Illinois credentials fight.

title: MARITIME COLLEGE ACCEPTS 1ST WOMAN
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union announced today that it was dropping a suit against the State University of New York because the New York State Maritime College had agreed to accept the first woman in its 98year history.

title: SPORTS BILL STIRS MORE OPPOSITION
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 More opposition to a proposed Federal sports commission was expressed today as hearings on the bill before the Senate Commerce Committee were ad journed indefinitely.

title: First Execution in 35 Years In British Virgin Islands
description: ROADTOWN, British Virgin Islands, June 28 (AP)A 23 yearold convicted murderer was hanged today. It was the first execution in this Caribbean colony in 35 years.

title: Nixon's News Session On TV at 9 P.M. Today
description: President Nixon's news conference at 9 o'clock to night will be carried live from the White House by the television networks of the American Broadcasting Com pany (Channel 7 in New York), the Columbia Broad casting System (Channel 2) and the National Broadcast ing Company (Channel 4).

title: 150 Pupils From the South Bronx Enjoy a Day Touring Washington
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 About 150 youngsters and 20 adult chaperones flew here early this morning to visit their nation's capital. They toured the White House, viewed a session of the House of Representatives, watched the changing of the guard at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldierin short, they did everything that most tourists do when they come here.

title: Cosmos Suspend Player
description: Cinesino, a former World Cup soccer player for Brazil, was suspended by the New York Cosmos yesterday for having left the team without permission.

title: Decision Is Welcomed
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  PierrePaul Schweitzer, manag ing director of the International Monetary Fund, welcomed to day the decision of a number of major industrial countries, including the members of the European Economic Commu nity, to defend the pattern of currency exchange rates es tablished last December in the Smithsonian agreement.

title: Defense Department Subsidy to Saigon Is Charged
description: WASHINGTON, June 28A staff report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee asserted today that the De fense Department pumped an additional total of $155million into the South Vietnamese economy last year by devising a system of separate exchange rates for private and official transactions.

title: TWO HELD BY SAIGON IN POLITICAL KILLING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28  The South Vietnam ese Government announced to day that it had apprehended two men who had confessed to the asassination of the head of a proGovernment political movement last Nov. 10. It said the men had acted under in structions from Vietnamese Communists.

title: Upstate Youth, 19, Wins School Post After Court Order
description: ALBANY, June 28 (AP)The Watervliet school board was ordered today to seat 19year old Edward Reinfurt Jr. for the fiveyear term as a school com missioner.

title: F.T.C TO IMPOSE LABELING RULES
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Federal Trade Commission an nounced today that a rule for labeling wearing apparel would go into effect next week despite a court decision that the com mission lacked rulemaking au thority.

title: Advertising: TV Will End a Ban
description: The ban on advertising of sanitary napkin, tampon and douche products on televi sion stations that subscribe to the Television Code will be lifted on Nov. 1.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 28 (UPI)The Schaefer 500 auto race, scheduled for Sunday, was postponed tonight because of flooding in northeastern Pennsylvania.

title: Personal Finance
description: Many states raise money from lotteries these days, and one result has been a grow ing number of winners wealthy overnight. Some lot teries pay $50.000 a year for life.

title: ELECTIONS BOARD TO DETAIL SNARLS
description: The Board of Elections said yesterday that it would comply with Mayor Lindsay's request for an indepth report as soon as possible on the June 20 primary election, including a detailed description and anal ysis of delays to the polls and machine breakdowns.

title: News of Dogs
description: Decrying the grim fancier who complains bitterly when his dog loses, Vance Evans looks back to his shbwing days with real pleasure.

title: Cahill's Top Aide Indicted In Alleged Kickback Plot
description: NEWARK, June 28Federal and state grand juries today simultaneously indicted Paul J. Sherwin, the New Jersey Secre tary of State and the second most powerful official in the Republican administration of Gov. William T. Cahill, on ex tortion and bribery charges.

title: So Far, Drive in Jersey Has Indicted 131
description: TRENTON, June 28Secre tary of State Paul J. Sherwin today became the 131st public official indicted in New Jersey since Federal and state law enforcement officials began the crackdown on public corruption three years ago.

title: McGovern Encounters Conservatism And Skepticism in Tour of the South
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 28  Moments before Senator George McGovern was to ad dress this state's legislature to day, one of its most powerful leaders took the floor and ex plained why he was leaving.

title: MRS. WILBUR G. DOWNS
description: Mrs. Helen Hartley Geer Downs, wife of Dr. Wilbur G. Downs, the recently retired director of the virus program of the Rockefeller Foundation and professor of epidemiology at Yale Medical School, died at her home Tuesday. She was 51 years old and lived at 10 Hal stead Lane, Branford, Conn.

title: Sponsors of Battery Park City Seek To Cut Number of LowIncome Units
description: Sponsors of Battery Park City, the milelong waterfront project being built on the Low er West Side, have requested permission to cut the number of planned lowincome apart ments by more than 50 per cent in an effort to make the project more marketable.

title: House Rejects Fund Bill For Enlarging the Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Jun 28 (AP) The House overrode its lead ers today and refused to appro priate funds for enlarging the Capitol to provide more office space.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Curbs Films
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 28 Foreign films are to be im ported only by the Government to halt the showing of ob scene and objectionable movies, Maulana Kausar Niazi, Minister of Information, an nounced in Lahore today.

title: Man in the News
description: Are you a screwball?

title: Vote in Ulster on Union With Ireland Planned for Fall
description: BELFAST, June 28A plebi kite is to be held in Northern Ireland within the next few months to give the people their first chance to vote for or against union with the Irish Republic.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, June 28 (UPI)A New Jersey businessman, Robert Schmertz, became the third owner of the Boston Celtics in the last three months today and asked the National Basketball Association's Board of Governors to approve his purchase of the club.

title: U.S. CONCESSIONS ON ARMS CHARGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Senator Henry M. Jackson ar gued today that the Nixon Ad ministration's past armscontrol proposals demonstrated that the United States had made numerous lastminute conces sions to the Soviet Union to reach the two accords last month on limiting some nuclear weapons.
