title: Arturo DiFilippi, 78, Founder Of Greater Miami Opera Guild
description: MIAMI, June 28 (AP)Ar turo DeFillipi, who founded the Opera Guild of Greater Miami and was its impresario for 31 years, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  When 150 diverse Americans assembled here last Friday to write the Democratic platform, almost everyone was fearful of what they might dothe com mittee staff, the outnumbered Humphrey and Muskie mem bers, even the McGovern work ers, who were never quite sure what their dele gates were up to Too many of these people are crazies, said a longtime liberal activist as a gay liberation caucus held forth down the hall. The crazies attach themselves to humanitarian liberals like McGovern, and there is a real danger they will drag him down.

title: OffDuty Patrolman Slain in IRT Station Gun Battle
description: An offduty Transit Authority patrolman died last night, four hours after being shot in a gun battle in a Bronx subway sta tion. The police said the patrol man had stopped a man who had a gun protruding from his belt.

title: NURSES WILL END NONNURSING DUTY
description: The New York State Nurses Association served notice yes terday that its 5,500 members who work in the city's 18 muni cipal hospitals and other pub lic health facilities would no longer perform nonnursing duties.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dennis Reardon's 'Happiness Cage' Is Better Suited to Stage
description: Dennis Reardon's play, "The Happiness Cage," belongs on stage, not before a camera, with its moralistic concern, its theatrics and its stomach-turning plot all colliding uneasily and starkly magnified. Pulled in close as a movie, with the small cast now clumping around the rooms and corridors of huge Veterans Hospital in Frankfurt, it seems a brilliant contrivance but a contrivance nevertheless.With an expansive prelude and the huge, half-empty premises added, Mr. Reardon's work is still essentially the same as his original play, justly acclaimed Off Broadway. What right has anybody, even the United States Armythe playwright is askingto fiddle around with a human brain?The goal in this hypothetical drama is better soldiers, better, happier men. The patientsor victimsare three veterans, virtually imprisoned and awaiting their turn in the operation clinic. An electric wire bored into the skullwe get it in grisly detailwill produce a well-adjusted, well-controlled human robot.Now seen at mercilessly close range, the action seems far-fetched and bizarre, for all of Mr. Reardon's ferocious indignation and sincerity. The scenarist, Ron Whyte, and the director, Bernard Girard, have not betrayed the playwright. The pros and cons of the experiment are grippingly argued by Christopher Walken, as the brightest of the patients; Joss Ackland, as a conscience-bent surgeon and Ralph Meeker, as an ice-cold major (in the play, a general).The story and that plot resolution simply don't hold up, as X-rayed by the camera. What does sustain is the freezing horror of the hospital atmosphere, conveyed by the dialogue and two piercing, brilliant performances. We weren't sold on the plastic shrewdness of the young hero, voiced by Mr. Walken. But Ronny Cox as a stricken Texan and Bette Henritze as a very surprised hospital aideboth from the original playare wonderfully effective. And the play's the thing.

title: Excerpts From Proposed Democratic Platform Adopted by Convention Committee
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Following are excerpts from the Dem ocratic platform as adopted by the Democratic National Convention's Platform, Committee. The italicized Matter represents a summary of changes proposed in minority reports but not yet put in final written form.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 23 (AP)The United States and the Soviet Union, which met in indoor track for the first time here earlier this year, will clash again in Richmond next year, it was announced today. Olian Cassell, execu tive director of the Amateur Athletic Union, said the meet had been scheduled for March 16, 1973.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: Jersey Festival's Modern Taming of Shrew
description: MADISON, N. J., June 28  Paul Barry founded the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in 1963, and for seven summer seasons in Cape May it offered plays by Shakespeare and other writ ers. Last summer, after fi nancial crises and the loss of two successive theaters, the festival was homeless. For tunately for all residents of Madison and surrounding areas, as well as for outof towners who would like a pleasant day in the country and an evening of lively classical theater, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival is once again in residence on the greenlawned, tree lined campus of Drew Uni versity.

title: Aussie Hurdles to Record
description: WARSAW, June 28 (UPI) Pamela Kilburn of Australia equaled the women's world record of 12.5 seconds in the 100meter hurdles today.

title: Snake in the Tunnel
description: The British pound continues to bob up and down on the world's currency markets as it floats downstream, but all the other major currencies remain tied to their moorings.

title: Sterling Declines Here
description: The British pound slipped yes terday in busy foreignexchange trading in New York while the dollar turned weaker against major Continental currencies.

title: Fall From Boat Kills Girl
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 28A 14yearold girl was killed today when she fell from a boat in Manhasset Bay and was run over by it. The girl, Diana Zwirlein, was riding in the 22foot boat owned by her father, Lewis D. Zwirlein, of 25 Prospect Avenue, Port Wash ington, when it hit the wake of another boat and caused the accident, the police said.

title: 10 Proposed Solutions For Improving World
description: National boundaries, centuries of tradition and the pragmatics of the socalled real world all fade from the view of R. Buckminister Fuller as his mind soars in search of what he sees as the most logical, most efficient ways of making the earth a good place to live for everyone. The intellect, vision and courage of Mahatma Gandhi conceived of passive resist ance with which bloodless revolution he broke the hold on India of history's most powerful sovereignty. Passive resistance will not amplify the production of life support.

title: PLATINUM PRICES REGISTER A GAIN
description: In moderately heavy sales, platinum futures prices gained yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after hav ing dropped the day before. There was, however, no parti cularly bullish news.

title: Harold Brailey, Engineer With Manhattan Project
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 28  Harold E. Brailey, a former vice president and di rector of the Stone & Webster Engineering Corporation, died today in a Montclair nursing home. He was 78 years old and lived at 510 Park Street.

title: Pope Names Bible Panel
description: ROME, June 28The Vatican announced today Pope Paul's appointment of 20 leading scholars as members of a new Pontifical Biblical Commision.

title: Pope Names Polish Bishops for Areas That Were Formerly German
description: ROME, June 28The Vati can in effect recognized Po land's western frontiers today by appointing Polish bishops to territories that once belonged to Germany, and by other changes in the Roman Catholic Church administration.

title: NIXON RULES OUT DUTY IN VIETNAM FOR NEW DRAFTEES
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Nixon ordered today that from now on, no draftees be sent to Vietnam unless they volunteer for duty there.

title: U.S. Aides Believe Saigon Can Withstand Foe's Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28After nearly three months of some of the fiercest fighting of the war, the lead ing American officials in Vietnam say they are optimistic about South Vietnam's short run chances for withstanding the North Vietnamese offen sive, even with major battles north of the city of Hue ex pected soon.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Slow summer trading may have begun earlier this year than usual. Volume on the American Stock Exchange slowed to just over 3 million shares yesterday from 3.4 mil lion the previous day, and the slowest since the day after last Thanksgiving, when 2.5 million shares changed hands.

title: MRS. EDWARD SAVETH
description: Mrs. Betty Norr Saveth, who was an associate professor of geography at Rockland Com munity College and a former city high school teacher, died of cancer yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 57 years old and lived at 110 Riverside Drive and in Fredonia.

title: Chess: Lasker's New Book Produced With Aid of Teaching Machine
description: International Master Ed ward Lasker is 86 years old and, we are happy to report, in excellent physical and mental health. Although he retired from tooechelon com petition in the early fifties, he remains active locally, and both his enthusiasm and the continuing quality of his play are the wonder of New York chess circles.

title: U.S. Agency Cites The Times Over Election Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The General Accounting Office charged The New York Times today with an apparent viola tion of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, a law designed to regulate and limit spending in political campaigns.

title: At the End of the Quest Was Great Ice Cream
description: PHILADELPHIAWhile rivers were still cresting and a storm lowered over head, five intrepid New Yorkers headed south to verify a frequently heard report that the nation's best ice cream was sold in Philadelphia, in the Reading Terminal Market, at L. D. Bassett, Inc.

title: City Sets Meeting With Leaders In Construction to Discuss Graft
description: In a renewed effort to gain the business community's coop eration in fighting graft, city officials said yesterday that they had scheduled a meeting next week with the Building Construction Advisory Council, whose members include promi nent builders, architects, en gineers and union officials.

title: South Vietnamese Launch Push to Retake Quangtri
description: HUE, South Vietnam, Thurs day, June 29A force of about 10,000 South Vietnamese ma rines and paratroopers pushed above the country's northern most defense line yesterday, starting a drive to retake Quangtri Province, which fell to the North Vietnamese nearly two months ago.

title: TV: The 51st State Investigates a Narcotics Case
description: The 51st State on WNET/13 came to a tem porary halt last week at least for the summer, but at 8 tonight it will be making a special appearance with a twohour investigative report revolving around the nar cotics business in New York. The report, written and pro duced by Hal Levinson, with Isabella Dane as a reporter and associate producer, was planned as a segment for the halfhour 51st State but, over a period of three months, it kept expanding.

title: Personalities: Umpire Liberated
description: Members of the National Organization for Women sur rounded their only recruit from organized baseball, Mrs. Bernice Gera, yesterday as the the Queens housewife told why, after fighting six years in court to become the first woman umpire, She quit after one game. Mrs. Gera said her career as an umpire started and ended in a Class A New YorkPenn League game Sat urday night because base ball fought me from the be ginning and was going to fight me to the end. Mrs. Gera said, I never was a member of a Women's Lib group before but I have joined the NOW organization to see this never happens to a woman again. In a release prepared by NOW, Mrs. Gera expressed a desire to get or ganized baseball out of the hands of the sexist opera tors who control it. She said the struggle cost her thou sands of dollars although court costs were paid for by the Human Rights Commis sion. Mrs. Gera plans to write a book about her six years in court and seven in nings the diamond.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mao Greets Leader Of Ceylon in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, June 29  Mao Tsetung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party, met with Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Ceylon, at his Peking residence last night.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (UPI) The Soviet Union said to day the Vietnam plank in the Democratic party platform represented a full revision of the party's former policy, but cautioned that it was clearly a preelection pos ture.

title: P. A, L DEDICATES CENTER IN HARLEM
description: In a ceremony marked by short speeches, energetic music and a rooftop buffet luncheon, city officials and community leaders dedicated the first Police Athletic League center in Har lem yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 28A payment of $47,905,195 to the United States Treasury on Friday by the Tennessee Valley Authority will bring the total amount paid into the Treasury through the years to more than a billion dollars. The sevenstate regional agency said today the latest pay ment was part of nearly $76million in payments that T.V.A. is making from power revenues in the current fiscal year, as required under 1959 T.V.A. powerfinancing legis lation. These payments into the Treasury from power rev enues amount to about $9million more than this year's Federal appropriation to T.V.A. for other resource develop ment activities such as water resources, agriculture, and forestry programs. This week's payment includes a $20 million annual repayment of past appropriations invested in T.V.A. power facilities, plus the second half of the year $55.8million dividend on the remaining appropriation in vestment. The first half dividend payment was made in December.

title: The Latest Fashion: Kids
description: Take a look at the windows of any uptodate depart ment store and you'll find out plenty about the mood of the country. Last April it was China not just sum mit meetings with Chou Enlai, but stuffed pandas at Schwarz and (Mrs. Mao Tsetung would be amused) newly stylish workers' pajamas just like the ones they wear in China. Pregnancysimulating pillows (worn under smocks) were surely some kind of reaction to ZPG and abortion. First midiskirts, then hotpants told us some thing about the ups and downs of mood and daring; and now, well, now it's children's clothes.

title: War Against the U. N.
description: It is the function of international institutions, such as the International Court of Justice, and of national insti tutions, such as the American Society of International Law, to develop and honor international law. Tragically, international law is not honored by the Congress when it adopts chrome plated or Rooneyated violations of our solemn treaty obligations. Nor is it honored by those who are con temptuous of the United Nations and its Charter and, in disregard of our true national interests, use stupid, use less and inhuman measures in South east Asia.

title: Talks in Bonn to Continue
description: BONN, Thursday, June 29 (Reuters)  The West German Cabinet will continue its discus sions on the international mon etary situation today, the Gov ernment announced.

title: Business Briefs
description: The General Services Administration, the Government's housekeeping agency, said yesterday it would resume the sale of mercury out of surplus stocks, with bids accepted monthly, starting on July 11. The G.S.A., which stopped selling mercury in August, 1970, plans to offer a total of 7,710 flasks weighing 76 pounds each at the rate of no more than 500 flasks a month. Buyers must guarantee that the mercury will not be exported and that it will be used in domestic plants.

title: Rusk Bids Congress Keep Defenses Firm
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Dean Rusk returned to Capitol Hill today and lectured Con gress, as he did when he was Secretary of State, on the need for a firm defense posture and the futility of negotiating with the North Vietnamese.

title: Price Rise for Baby Food
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Price Commission an nounced today that it had ap proved an average 3.72 per cent price increase for baby foods sold by the Squibb Corpora tion's BeechNut, Inc. The com pany had requested a 9.4 per cent increase, but the commis sion trimmed it to eliminate unallowable costs.

title: Black Performers Set for 2Week Fete
description: For the first time in its 10 year history, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will pre sent a twoweek program cele brating black theater, dance, poetry and music starting July 23 and ending Aug. 5.

title: Drug Center Here Reports Rise in Addict Treatment
description: The city's Addiction Service Agency announced that 37,097 persons were receiving treat ment for drug abuse in publicly funded programs during the month of May. Commissioner Graham S. Finney noted that the figure was more than dou ble the 18,072 in treatment dur ing the first citywide census last August.

title: Storied Indian Hill City Shines Anew As the Site of an Historic Conference
description: SIMLA, India, June 28 Shades of past glories hang like mountain mist over the rugged, pineclad site of the peace conference this week between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan.

title: Lawyer to Head Committee To Save School at N.Y.U.
description: An emergency committee to save the New York University Graduate School of Social Work will be headed by David Sher, a lawyer and chairman of the board of the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: Ali Is Still Same Old Ali: Back in Form but Better
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 28  Muhammad Ali, never one to duck superlatives, said today, I'm back like I used to be, but I'm better.

title: Cyprus Crisis Is Abating Again, But Disputes Are Far From Over
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 24  The new Cabinet took office more than a week ago, and the longinterrupted talks between leaders of the hostile Greek and Turkish Cypriote communities are scheduled to resume on July 3. Another Cyprus crisis appears to have been over come.

title: Business Briefs
description: The American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that production of rayon filament yarns will be discontinued by its IRC Fibers Company subsidiary in Painesville, Ohio, around Dec. 1. The step will affect 950 of the plant's 1,700 employes. Instead of making rayon for tires and industrial applications, IRC will concentrate its production, research and marketing efforts in the growing polyester tire and industrial yarn markets.

title: Screen: Prime Cut, Uneven Gangster Melodrama
description: Because Michael Ritchie's The Candidate, which opens here tomorrow, is a good film, one might con ceivably want to see his Prime Cut, which opened yesterday and demonstrates what a seemingly intelligent director can do with a bad script. Not much except cast it with responsible actors and decorate it with spectacularly foolish effects.

title: Harlem 4 to Stand Trial Fourth Time On Murder Charge
description: Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Martinis ruled yesterday that the young men known as the Harlem Four, who spent eight years in jail awaiting dis position of their case, must stand trial a fourth time on a murder charge.

title: Power Called Issue in Teacher Demands
description: The Public Education Associ ation charged yesterday that control and power, not high er salaries, were the gut is sues of the city teachers' cur rent contract demands.

title: L.I. Union Official Acquitted On Charges of Embezzling
description: A Federal jury yesterday acquitted Ralph Limmer, an of ficial of a warehouse workers union, on charges of embez zling union funds and making false statements in annual re ports.

title: Market Place: Cautious View Of Blue Chips
description: Bluechip glamour stocks may be headed for their own minibear market. That's the way Robert H. Stovall, chair man of the investment policy committee of Reynolds Se curities, Inc., is reading the market these days.

title: Truman Falls in His Home; XRays Reported Negative
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 28 (AP)Former President Harry S. Truman, 88 years old, was examined by doctors at a hos pital here today after he slipped at his home in nearby Inde pendence, last night, a hospital spokesman said.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DUBLIN, June 28 (AP)Roberto, winner of the English Derby, was made the favorite today for Saturday's Irish Sweeps Derby. Irish Sweepstakes ticketholders will be closely following the race, since a ticket on the winning horse will be worth $125,000.

title: Panel Approves DebtCeiling Bill; Senate to Act Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The Senate Finance Committee, after a halfday hearing, ap proved the debt ceiling bill today under a special pro cedure that will permit the Senate to take it up tomorrow.

title: Orioles Win on 5Hitter, 40
description: The New York Yankees lost their fifth straight game last night when they deserted Fritz Peterson with their gloves as well as their bats and staked the Baltimore Orioles to a 40 victory at Yankee Stadium.

title: Collector Goes Big Time
description: With a single purchase, Robert K. Brown, a book and graphics dealer, became a major collector of the arts style that spawned art.

title: H.E.W. Scored on Medicaid Children
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare has inten tionally refused to provide chil dren of Medicaid families the medical treatment that is due them under the terms of a five yearold Federal law, a spokes man for the National Welfare Rights Organization said today.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Aerospace Corporation, a research organization in El Segundo, Calif., received a $71 million Air Force contract for scientific, engineering and tech nical support of the Space and Missile Systems organization, it was announced yesterday.

title: Court Stays $660Million Allocation Of School Funds to 31 Local Districts
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice issued a temporary stay yesterday that bars the Board of Education from allocating over $660million in city and state funds to the city's 31 local school districts.

title: The Night WilkesBarre's Dikes Failed
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., June 28Roz Smulowitz went to bed last Thursday night with little more than a vague con cern about the rising Susque hanna River that swept along behind flood dikes only feet from her newly redecorated, twostory home.

title: Appeal to Pompidou
description: GENEVA, June 28The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, gen eral secretary of the World Council of Churches, appealed today to President Pompidou on behalf of all humanity to halt the French nuclear tests.

title: Beirut's Airport Will Install BombExploding Chamber
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28 (AP)Lebanon has decided to use antihijacking devices, in cluding metal detectors and a bombexploding chamber at Beirut International Airport, of ficial ?? said today.

title: Poland Welcomes Decision
description: WARSAW, June 28 (Reuters) The Polish Government today welcomed Pope Paul's action in appointing Polish bishops for dioceses in western Poland. A Government spokesman, Wlodi mierz Janiurek, said the step showed that the Vatican had fi nally accepted the reality of Poland's present borders.

title: POLICE OFFICIALS ASK PISTOL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy of New York City, the Sheriff of Los Angeles County and the Cincinnati Chief of Police urged a House judiciary subcommittee today to pass strong controls on pistols, in some cases with tougher re strictions than the guncontrol bill approved yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Opposition in Saigon Accuses ProThieu Senators of Trickery on Special Bill
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 Members of the politi cal opposition are angry over what they consider trickery in the way the Senate rammed through a bill giving special decree powers to President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: AMEX IS REVIEWING DISCIPLINARY RULES
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it was reviewing its pro cedures in disciplinary actions involving member firms, their officers and employes with a view toward a basic revision.

title: Politicians Felt That Sherwin Was Man Who Had Cahill's Ear
description: TRENTON, June 28  Let me put it this way. People who want something are reluctant to call the. Governor, so they call me. Say, a businessman doesn't like a tax program, or a legislator opposes a bill. They'll call me to see if the Governor can do something about it.

title: Stage: Savoring Shaw
description: STRATFORD, Conn Even one of my worst ?? would not call me a ?? yet I must admit that I had rather a good time at the American Shakespeare Festi val Theater's critic's preview of Bernard Shaw's Major Barbara. In the first place it is one of Shaw's best plays, and in the second, the Shake speare Festival's production is stylish and assured.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, June 28 (UPI)Ken Buchanan, who lost his world lightweight title to Roberto Duran of Panama Monday night, arrived home today and said his first appointment was with his local doctor. The Scot said he was still suffering pain in the groin from the blow that ended the fight.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the dazzling splendor of the Olympic Games comes dancing across the television screens late this sum mer, many an athlete will be watching with misty eyes and heavy heart. Thousands of miles away from the action, he will be in an emotional turmoil because he had failed to become a part of it. Perhaps he even would have been good enough to win. But the recipe for an Olympic gold medal begins not too unlike the recipe for rabbit pie, which demands: first catch the rabbit. The gold medal formula starts with: first gain a qualifying berth on the Olympic team.

title: Measles Kills 40 in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 28, (Reuters)  Forty children have died in eastern Bolivia in a measles epidemic raging through the department of Santa Cruz, 550 miles east of here, local authorities said today.

title: Merger News
description: International Computers, Ltd., the only major nonAmerican based company competing in the world dataprocessing mar ket, is being courted by the Burroughs Corporation of De troit, both companies confirmed yesterday.

title: Janie Blalock Is Elated
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 28Janie Blalock was having luncheon on the terrace of the Winged Foot Golf Club today when she received word that her injunction against the L.P.G.A. would be continued. She dropped a fork and ran into the clubhouse.

title: M'GOVERN'S BLOC WINS EARLY TEST OVER DELEGATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Backers of Senator George Mc Govern won a skirmish today in the competition for seating delegates to the Democratic National Convention, but their show of strength appeared in sufficient to win the major bat tle that faces them tomorrow over California's 271 delegates.

title: 5 Marines, Killed 30 Years Ago, Buried in Common Grave at Arlington
description: ARLINGTON, Va., June 28 (UPI)Taps and a 21gun salute echoed along the wooded slopes of Arlington National Cemetery today as five marines who lay buried where they fell for nearly three decades were interred in a solemn ceremony.

title: DIETZ, KLECATSKY SCULLING VICTORS
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, June 28 (AP)  Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club led three American entries into the quarterfinals of the press tigious Diamond Challenge sculls at the Royal Henley Re gatta today.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and his wife, Martha, slipped out of a serv ice entrance of the Westches ter Country Club in Rye, N. Y., where Mrs. Mitchell had spent three days after being quoted last weekend as saying she would leave her husband unless he left poli tics.

title: Books of The Times
description: Here's a mystery one runs up against with surprising regularity in fictiona rea sonably wellwritten, even entertaining novel, which leaves you wondering when you've finished it: Now why did the author want to write that? Alain Robbe Grillet remarked that he writes novels to find out why he wanted to write them. In other words, he hopes or expects to clarify an impulse, to render conscious ideas and feelings that are unconscious, to discover something about himself and/or his world.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BISMARCK, N. D., June 28 (UPI)  Governors of middle Western States formally op posed today President Nixon's lifting of the meat import quo ta and asked for a meeting with the President to convey their grave concern.

title: BENJAMIN MILLER 3D, LAWYER, 56, IS DEAD
description: Benjamin C. Miller 3d, a partner in the law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett since 1950, died yesterday at his home, 66 Barkers Point Road, Sands Point, Port Wash ington, L.I. He was 56 years old.

title: Finder of $500,000 Bars $10,000 Gift; He Wants $25,000
description: PERU, Ind., June 28 (AP) A farmer who found and turned in $500,000 dropped by a plane hijacker refused a $10,00 gift from American Airlines today. He indicated he thought the reward should be larger.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: KEENE, Calif., June 28 (UPI) Cesar Chavez, head of the United Farm Workers Union, praised the Democratic Plat form Committee yesterday for supporting a union lettuce boy cott, saying that it was the first time a national party has taken a position so responsive to the needs of farm workers. The union has endorsed Senator George McGovern's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation.

title: Parties Accompany Mass Performances
description: By the time Leonard Bern stein's celebrated Mass reached New York this week, nearly everybody who is any body had seen it. The real ex citement was in Washington last fall. But in its own way, New York managed to get it self into something of an end of  the  social  season dither, too.

title: Bridge: Italian Experts Demonstrate Twisting of Basic Principles
description: One of the basic principles of bidding that a beginner learns is that a partnership planning to play game should play in a major suit in which eight or more cards are avail able in the combined hands.

title: Introducing the Ginkelvan, MiniBus for Midtown
description: The Ginkelvan, a 20 passenger minibus (or maxi taxi) that is no longer than a Cadillac limousine and was designed for crowded city cen ters, was shown here for the first time yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, June 28 (Reuters)Sir Francis Chichester, competing in the transAtlantic singlehanded yacht race, signaled tonight that he had been illand race organizers said it was evident he was returning home.

title: GuyanaPeking Ties Set
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, June 28  Guyana and China have agreed to establish diplo matic relations and embassies, it was announced last night.

title: Rate of Growth Was Down Slightly From Preceding Months
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Government's composite index of leading Indicators of the economy rose only slightly in May following more than a year of strong growth, the Com merce Department reported today.

title: PENSION RISE GAINS FOR COURT WIDOWS
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The Senate Judiciary Commit tee unanimously approved to day a bill to increase the pen sions of diwods of Supreme Court Justices from $5,000 to $10,000 a year.

title: Music: Bernstein's Mass Opens Engagement at Met
description: Leonard Bernstein's Mass is one of those rare theatri cal works that attempt to sum up their own time like it or not, and that is never a simple or useless thing to do. Mass, which officially opened the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington last Sep tember has arrived in the full ness of time at the Metro politan Opera House, where it is scheduled to play through July 22.

title: Confronted With New Testimony, Stennis Orders Full Hearing on Lavelle
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Senator John C. Stennis, con fronted with new testimony linking Gen. Creighton W. Abrams to the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam, an nounced today that the Armed Forces Committee would hold full hearings into the pending retirement of Gen. John D. Lavelle.

title: FILIBUSTER MARK BROKEN BY TEXAN
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 28 (UPI) Mike McKool, a 5foot4inch tall state Senator who is known as Little Hercules, talked for 42 hours 33 minutes trying to convince the Texas Senate to spend more money for mental health services, then sat down at his desk today, ending the world's longest filibuster.

title: Herbert P. Barnett, Painter, Cincinnati Art School Dean
description: CINCINNATI, June 28  Her bert P. Barnett, dean of the Art Academy of Cincinnati since 1951 and a painter represented in many collections, died here Sunday. He was 61 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, sought today to block what he de scribed as an appalling increase in postal rates for newspapers and magazines. He introduced legislation to freeze second class rates for publications at their current level for the first 250,000 copies and require that additional charges for ex tra copies be imposed over a five to 10year period.

title: COURT BARS SALE OF 800 ROTHKOS
description: The Manhattan Surrogate Court yesterday barred the sale of paintings by the late ab stract expressionist Mark Roth ko, pending a final disposition of lawsuits opposing the sales by the painter's daughter and the New York State Attorney General.

title: Executive Changes
description: Harold H. Hammer has been elected a senior vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: BOMBING CRITICIZED BY SWEDISH ENVOY
description: STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 (Reuters)Sweden's Ambas sador to Hanoi today accused the United States of pursuing a policy or annihilation in its bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Ransom Returned
description: ALGIERS, June 28The vice president of Western Airlines, Robert O. Kinsey, was handed back today the $500,000 ran som two American hijackers ex torted June 3 by Ait Messa qudene, an official of the Al gerian airline AirAlgerie.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City and State Still Split on Aid Cases
description: Three weeks of statecity talks on welfare ineligibility wound up yesterday with dis agreement on threefourths of the cases involved, with the State Welfare Inspector Gener al insisting that the city grant ed relief to 33 ineligible cases and the city contending that the cases were eligible.

title: GIRLS' GOLF WON BY PHILADELPHIA
description: DEDHAM, Mass., June 28 In an exciting series that wasn't decided until the last group had reported, Philadel phia was awarded the Mrs. Frank Enos Trophy today for winning the Junior Girls' Inter city Team Match.

title: 22 Are Killed in Explosion On Oil Tanker at Bombay
description: BOMBAY, India, June 28 (Reuters)At least 22 persons were killed and 30 injured when an explosion rocked a 17,103 ton Greekowned oil tanker at a Bombay repair dock today.

title: Building Contracts Soar to a Record $9.09Billion
description: New construction soared to a record $9billion in May, F. W. Dodge reported yester day.

title: AGNEW APPALLED BY FLOOD DAMAGE
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., June 28 (UPI)Vice President Agnew assessed storm damage in his home state today and termed it appalling.

title: Deep Regret in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 28 (AP)A wave of protests swept Japan today and the Foreign Ministry expressed deep regret over the French nuclear test.

title: BedfordStuyvesant Group To Build $6Million Center
description: Plans for the construction of a $6million commercial center in the BedfordStuyvesant sec tion of Brooklyn, the latest in a growing series of projects undertaken by an organization founded by the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, were dis closed yesterday by Franklin A. Thomas, president of the Bed ford  Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: Bitter End Treated To OneNight Stand By Randy Newman
description: Randy Newman decides to make one of his casual public ap pearances, it's an event that shouldn't be missed. On Tues day he sang his whimsical tales at Paul Colby's Bitter End for a single evening's engagement, and the place was jammed.

title: Alan Steinharter Weds Miss Ballon.
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 28Miss Martha Elaine Balton, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Sidney Ballon of West Hempstead, was married here this afternoon to Alan Jay Steinharter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolf B. Steinharter of Hempstead.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Madison Avenue Mall Is It Only Memory Lane?
description: Every once in a while I arrive on Madison Avenue early enough to walk down it without the intrusion of cars, trucks and buses. When I do, my mind wanders, thinking of how great it would be to walk down the avenue at the height of the day with other pedestrians, to have the street to ourselves, sharing it only with trees, flowers, sidewalk cafes and busy shops.

title: Labor Attacks Congress Over Safety Exemptions
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Organized labor challenged to day the right of Congress to deny workers for small com panies the standards of health and safety now required of large and small employers alike under the Occupational Safety and Health Act.

title: Dr. Manfred Stern Dead; Otolaryngologist Was 75
description: Dr. Manfred Stern, an otol aryngologist who had been a consultant on deaf children to the city's Health Department, died Tuesday in the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 771 West End End Avenue.

title: F.P.C. AUTHORIZES GAS FROM ALGERIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The Federal Power Commission today authorized imports of liquefied natural gas from Algeria over a 25year period to ease growing energy short ages in the United States, but it imposed conditions that might threaten a prompt launching of the $1.6billion project.

title: U.S. PAYMENTS GAP SEEN AT $4BILLION
description: PARIS, June 28 (Reuters)  The United States balanceof payments deficit is expected to be about $4billion this year, but the rate could be reduced by almost half next year, interna tional economists forecast here today.

title: Dr. Gilbert Stanton, Dentist, Biochemistry Professor, 54
description: Dr. Gilbert Stanton, a mem ber of the State Board of Den tistry and an assistant professor of biochemistry at the New York University School of Den tistry, died of a coronary attack Tuesday in the South Nassau Community Hospital He was 54 years old and lived at 119 Malverne Avenue, Mal verne, L.I.

title: Price Changes
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced late yester day that it was lowering prices today on certain galvanized steel sheets with what was de scribed as light commercial coating. The grade is used in automobiles and appliances. No reason was given for the action but spokesmen for several other steelmakers said they thought the move represented more of a change in specifications than in actual prices.

title: July 4 Resolution Voted
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Senate passed today and sent to the House the annual Independence Day resolution calling for a reaffirmation of patriotism to mark the sign ing of the Declaration of Inde pendence July 4, 1776.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, June 28 (UPI)European court action will start July 13 against a United States can manufacturer accused of abusively dominating the European Common Market packing scene, E.E.C. officials said today. The pro cedure in the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg against the Continental Can Company of New York will be the first application of Article 86 of the market treaty forbidding abusive exploitation of a dominant position.

title: Pay Board Reduces Raise For Clerks in Philadelphia
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Pay Board upheld today a recommendation to reduce a 19 per cent pay raise for 13,000 retail clerks in the Philadelphia area to 5.5 per cent.

title: CHINA CRITICIZES U.S. ON USE OF THAI BASES
description: PEKING, June 28 (Reuters) China today criticized the in creased United States use of air bases in Thailand to strike at targets in North Vietnam. She said that American planes had carried out savage bombing of Hanoi and other places.

title: Janie Blalock Is Allowed to Compete
description: ATLANTA, June 28 (AP) The Ladies Professional Golf Association was ordered by a Federal judge today to allow Janie Blalock to compete in tournaments pending settle ment for her $5million anti trust suit against the L.P.G.A.

title: Bayern Wins Soccer Title
description: MUNICH, Germany, June 28 (UPI) Bayern Munich beat Schalke 04 by 51 tonight to win the West German First Division soccer championship. The title is Bayern's third.

title: I.R.A. Issues Unity Plan
description: DUBLIN, June 28 (Reuters) Leaders of the Irish Republican Army issued a plan here today for an allIreland federation that would include the northern province now ruled by Britain.

title: Trial Begins for Phillips In Brothel Murder Case
description: Patrolman William R. Phil lips, the star witness at last fall's Knapp Commission hear ings on police corruption, went on trial here yesterday on charges of murdering a pimp and a prostitute and trying to murder one of the prostitute's customers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wallace's Course
description: WASHINGTONEven while, he sits in a hospital bed, Governor Wallace remains a pivotal figure in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: New Zealand Outcry
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Thursday, June 29 Reports that the French had exploded a nuclear device have brought an intensified outcry of com plaint in New Zealand.

title: Advertising: President of PR Society Resigns
description: After 18 months as the first fulltime president of the Public Relations Society of America, Dr. Robert O. Carlson is resigning.

title: 14 NATIONS DEBATE WHALEHUNT CURB
description: LONDON, June 28With con servationists picketing outside, representatives of 14 nations met in secrecy today to discuss the fate of the whale.

title: NEED OF FLEXIBILITY STRESSED BY SEATO
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 28 The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's Council of Min isters ended its annual meeting in Canberra today with a com muniqu stressing the need for the alliance to be flexible and responsive to changing world conditions.

title: U.S. Defends Antidumping Steps
description: A high Treasury official as serted yesterday that the Ad ministration's tougher en forcement of the antidumping act was in reality a liberal trade measure designed to as sure fair competition for all importers and domestic pro ducers.

title: Slain Grizzly Called Killer
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., June 28 (UPI) A 400pound female grizzly that was shot and killed by Yellowstone National Park rangers was the one that mauled a camper to death over the weekend, park spokesmen said yesterday. They said tests made on the animal by the Montana game and fish labora tory at Bozeman showed traces of human hair on the claws of the huge animal.

title: GandhiBhutto Parleys Open Hopefully
description: SIMLA, India, June 28Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan began their peace conference today with mutual promises, in the same words, to seek a new begin ning in the troubled relations between their countries.

title: POUND AND DOLLAR OFF ON CONTINENT
description: LONDON, June 28  The pound and the dollar weakened further as official foreignex change trading resumed on the Continent today. But there was no rout, and speculators held back to wait for a clear trend.

title: IN THE NATION
description: George McGovern's plan for a $1,000 income grant per American citizen suffers from sloppy arithmetic, grandi ose goals and overstatement, but it nevertheless takes aim at the right targetthe gross maldistribution of in come and wealth that may well be the fundamental American social problem.

title: BIG BOARD DRIFTS TO LOWER GROUND
description: The stock market, still sad dled with worries, drifted lower yesterday in one of the slowest trading sessions of 1972.

title: Roundup: White Sox Blast Three Homers Off Blue in 64 Victory
description: At this time last year, Vida Blue, the winner of the Amer ler League's Cy Young Award, had a 163 wonlost record and was well on his way to 24 victories as a cookie. His sophomore season has been something else.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Democratic members of the House of Representatives re pudiated proposed party re forms today, calling instead for further investigation and study.

title: House Backs an Extension For Unemployed Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Reuters)The House of Rep resentatives voted today to ex tend for another six months the extra 13week period of un employment benefits for long time jobless workers. It also voted to raise employer payroll taxes by $220million to pay the program.

title: Leader of Local 1199 Granted 2d Stay
description: A contemptofcourt action against Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199, Drug and Hos pital Union, was postponed for a second time yesterday to allow for continued mediation of a contract dispute between the union and the League, of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes.

title: RAMOS OUTPOINTS CARRASCO FOR TITLE
description: MADRID, June 28 (UPI) Mando Ramos of Los Angeles sent Pedro Carrasco to the canvas twice in the first two rounds, then withstood a strong comeback by the Spaniard to win the World Boxing Council lightweight title on a 15round decision at the Sports Palace tonight.

title: Domestic Disarmament
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has delivered an encouraging rebuff to the oncepowerful gun lobby with its 12to2 vote to report a bill banning the manufacture and sale of most snubnosed handguns.

title: PUTNAM'S, HARCOURT AGREE ON A MERGER
description: An agreement in principle under which the 134year old bookpublishing company, G.P. Putnam's Sons, will become wholly owned subsidiary of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., was announced yesterday.

title: City U. Center Names Head
description: Dr. Harold M. Proshansky, an environmental psychologist, has been named acting president and provost of the City Univer sity's Graduate SchoolUniver sity Center, effective Sept. 1. Dr. Proshansky is now dean of graduate studies at the center and codirector of the univer sity's environmental psychol ogy doctoral program.

title: WAIVER GRANTED TO WQXR FOR FM
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday renewed the broadcast license of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, and granted the station a special waiver that will allaw it to broadcast simultaneously on AM and FM.

title: Indian Quits Campaign
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 29 (AP)Philip Cassadore with drew today as the Apache In dian candidate for President. Mr. Cassadore, a 45yearold tribal representative from the San Carlos Reservation near Globe, Ariz., said that he was withdrawing because he be lieved he could he more valu able to Indians through other efforts. He had campaigned lightly in several states.

title: PHILLIES 17 HITS CRUSH METS, 94
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29 The Phillies caught up to the New York Mets tonight in no uncertain terms. After losing all seven of their previous con tests to New York this season, the Phillies unleashed a 17hit attack that carried them and Steve Carlton to a sound 94 triumph before 14,457 fans in Veterans Stadium.

title: Gen. Rafael GarciaValino, Franco Commander iii War
description: MADRID, June 29 (Reuters)  Lieut. Gen. Rafael Garcia Valino, a commander in Gen eralissimo Francisco Franco's nationalist forces in the 1936 39 Spanish Civil War, died in a hospital here early today. He was 73 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lowenstein Gets a Court Order Challenging City on Primary
description: Allard K. Lowenstein, who lost his primary bid for a Dem ocratic Congressional nomina tion, obtained a court order yesterday requiring the city's Board of Elections and his pri mary opponents to show why he should not be declared the winner or a new election be held.

title: Ford Recalls 4 Million Vehicles To Fix Shoulder Belt Defect
description: DETROIT, June 29The Ford Motor Company said today that it would recall 4,370,000 of its 1970 and 1971 carspractically the entire model runsto cor rect a safety defect in the shoulder harnesses.

title: PENSION RISE PLAN DELAYED BY G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A Senate move to increase Social Security benefits by 20 per cent hit a snag late today, with Re publican leaders threatening to block action in the House.

title: SPOFFORD TEACHERS TESTIFY OF BEATING
description: Two teachers from the Spof ford Detention Center for Boys in the Bronx told a City Coun cil committee yesterday that one of them was slammed against a wall and beaten un conscious by a 300pound youth at the center.

title: Credit Markets
description: An afternoon rally more than wiped out early declines in the market for corporate and tax exempt bonds and knocked in terest rates down a peg yes terday.

title: Agnew Pays Visit To Southern Tier; Pledges Flood Aid
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., June 29 Vice President Agnew visited the floodtorn Southern Tier this morning on an inspection trip for President Nixon and told community leaders that he would put top priority on their request to have Federal laws amended to give home owners and small businesses bigger flood rehabilitation grants.

title: Roosevelt Superfectta Returns $16,283 for $2
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 The combination of 5684 returned the secondlargest superfecta payoff in the his tory of Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Halston has been described by an admirer as dressing very rich women in such a way that they look as if they didn't spend much money on clothes. The formula was dis covered by Chanel 50 years ago. It's working for Halston too.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 29 (UPI)A small band of Yip pies staged today the first demonstration here linked to the Democratic National Con vention. It was a hike over sweltering streets to protest the city's ban on camping out by demonstrators during the convention, which opens July 10.

title: A Reservist Wins Right to Wear Wig Over His Long Hair
description: A 28yearold Army reservist won a court decision yesterday giving him the right to wear his hair long under a wig.

title: DIETZ ADVANCES IN HENLEY ROWING
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, June 29 (AP)Jim Dietz, United States heavyweight row ing champion, smashed his way into the semifinals of the Dia mond Challenge Sculls at the Henley Royal Regatta today.

description: Sports of The Times

description: Fishing Report

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Treasury announced today it was withholding customs appraisement of Northern bleached hardwood craft pulp from Canada on suspicion sales in the United States market at dumping prices.

title: Media Oppose Limits On ChessMatch News
description: An attempt to limit news transmissions from the world chess championship in Ice land has met strong resist ance from the news media, including The Associated Press, United Press Inter national and The New York Times.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: GRAFITTI SCORES IN AQUEDUCT RACE
description: Grafitti easily wrote off the opposition in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4 yearold filly, owned by Louisa Carpenter, scored by three lengths over Alfred Vander bilt's Cold Comfort in the sevenfurlong sprint for older fillies, with the Cragwood Sta ble's Tanagra trailing the win ner by more than six lengths.

title: FARE RISE OPPOSED ON THE NEWHAVEN
description: New York City sided yester day with some of the Connecti cut and Westchester County residents who commute here in opposing a recent 20 per cent fare increase on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central railroad.

title: Excerpts From Court Opinions in News Case
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Following are excerpts from the majority opinion, concur ring opinion and dissents by the Supreme Court today in the cases of three, newsmen Paul M. Branzburg of The Louisville Courier  Journal, Paul Pappas of television sta tion. WTEV, New Bedford, Mass., and Earl Caldwell of The New York Times:

title: Store Sales Rise in Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $789million, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $746million. Total retail store sales were about $8,392,000,000, up 5 per cent from the year earlier $7,955,000,000.

title: Black Backed for N.A.A.C.P.
description: BOSTON, June 29 (UPI) Jack E. Robinson, the president of the Boston branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today his chapter would attempt to introduce a resolution at next week's con vention in Detroit to have a black man elected president of the organization for the first time.

title: Personalities: Barry Bellicose on Warriors
description: Rick Barry, who raised such a fuss about playing for the Virginia Squires that he finally was dealt to the New York Nets, is hoping the tactic again works. The courts recently decided the basket ball star had signed a valid contract in 1969 with the San Francisco Warriors of the National Basketball As sociation and is their proper ty for the upcoming season. There's no way I'm going to play for the Warriors, Barry said during a golf tourna ment in Reno, Nev. Barry made it big with the Nets of the American Association, and was also a parttime sports announcer here. Dur ing pro career, he has played for the Warriors, the Oakland Oaks (after sitting out a year) Who became the Washington Capitols, and the Nets.

title: 'Come Back Charleston Blue,' Sequel to 'Cotton' in Harlem
description: A good deal of frenzy, if not conviction, is constantly generated by "Come Back Charleston Blue," which crashed into the De Mille Theater and the 72d Street Playhouse yesterday with all the energy of a block party run amok. As the successor to "Cotton Comes to Harlem," which introduced us two years ago to the cool exploits of the novelist Chester Himes's ultra hip black detectives, Coffin Ed Johnson and Grave Digger Jones, the film presents new adventures that are only occasionally funny or incisive.Since it was filmed in Harlem with Mark Warren, a black TV director, making his movie debut, and with a largely black cast headed by Godfrey Cambridge and Raymond St. Jacques, repeating their roles as those slick sleuths, a viewer might expect a lucid, intimate view of the black man's experience, seamy or otherwise. But a convoluted plot and dialogue that is often too "in" for the uninitiated serve to make only some parts of "Charleston" better than the whole, frenetic business.One finally gets the idea that Peter De Anda, seemingly a fashion photographer, is out to wrest Harlem's dope operations from Maxwell Glanville, who plays the black, Harlem representative of a white gang chief, portrayed by Leonardo Cimino. It's clear, however, that Coffin Ed and Grave Digger are cynically aware and will set things straight, their way, man, even if it means bucking their black captain, Percy Rodrigues, and the other local cats.Intense is the word for the performances of the principals, who don't have much of an opportunity for deep portrayals. Raymond St. Jacques again is a man with a low boiling point. Godfrey Cambridge again is happier with his lot, but just as fast with a gun or a quickly tossed quip.Jonelle Allen, of Broadway's "Two Gentlemen of Verona" and "Cotton," gets her face rubbed with a grapefruit in James Cagney style as De Anda's girlfriend, and the rest of the cast is in and out of the action with perplexing speed. Who's Charleston Blue? A rough razortoter apparently rubbed out in 1932, who's still adored by Minnie Gentry, as a genial dowager hipped on the numbers game.Auto chases, gunfights, explosions, dope pushers and users operating in shocking and comic fashion are the essence of this caper. But random vignettes such as a bang-up, bloody debutante ball, someone dressed as a nun riding a motorcycle, or a junkie floating in ecstasy along Harlem's streets stick closer in memory than the over-all farcically sociological picture presented by "Come Back Charleston Blue."

title: Drop in Domestic Wiretaps Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 A Justice Department official told Congress today that wire tapping of domestic groups was continuing despite last week's Supreme Court ruling, but has been markedly reduced. The 8 to0 ruling held that wiretap ping of domestic groups with out prior court approval was unconstitutional.

title: Korvettes Fined by State
description: Penalties of $12,500 were levied on five E. J. Korvettes storesfour in the New York metropolitan area and one in Albanyfor sales of detergents with more than twice the legal limit of phosphates. The State Environmental Conserva tion Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, said that $10,000 of the penalty would be suspend ed, provided the stores were not found guilty of further vio talons of the law. The illegal sales were of Spring Detergent, with a labeled content of 18 per cent phosphate.

title: 'Candidate,' a Comedy About the State of Politics, Opens:Robert Redford Plays Senatorial Hopeful Chronicle of a Doomed Campaign Is at Sutton
description: There is something perverse and puritanical in the way many liberal Americans regard the political system. If a candidate wants to win, he must be suspect. Ambition in itself is bad. Like athlete's foot, it's not a sin, but it is unseemly. We put great store by the kind of modesty that insures defeat and that, only then, is revealed to be a form of arrogance. The best man should lose, or he isn't the best man. This is the Catch-22 of American politics.We all know that men who run for public office hoping only to improve the tone of the campaign, to raise the real issues, usually fail  and look terrible on television, which may be even worse. We suspect that only winning counts, yet we also fondly believesince we've seen it demonstrated often enoughthat the system is so corrupt that no good man can win without either being hopelessly corrupted or turned into a bewildered cipher.That pretty well describes what happens to Bill McKay (Robert Redford), the liberal young California Democrat who campaigns for the United States Senate in "The Candidate," one of the few good, truly funny American political comedies ever made. The film, which opened yesterday at the Sutton, was directed by Michael Ritchie ("Downhill Racer") and written by Jeremy Larner, the young novelist ("Drive, He Said") who was a speech-writer for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy during McCarthy's campaign for the 1968 Democratic Presidential nomination."The Candidate" is a loaded movie. It simplifies political processes. It turns McKay's Republican opponent, the long-time incumbent who looks as trustworthy as Warren G. Harding and is named, meaningfully, Crocker Jarman (Don Porter), into an idiot. It is also, at heart, extremely glib and gloomy but no more glib and gloomy, I think, than it has an inalienable right to be under the current circumstances.As McKay, in a self-mocking mood, says toward the end of his campaign, when the slogans, catchwords and clichs are becoming thoroughly muddled in his exhausted head: "It's the basic indifference that made this country great."The film, beautifully photographed by V. J. Kemper and John Korty, himself a talented young director ("Crazy Quilt," "Funnyman"), looks smashing. It's as nervous and frenetic as the campaign it records through disasters and triumphs, at awful fund-raising dinners with jokey masters of ceremonies (one such dinner is attended by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey), and on dismal handshaking tours when the candidate gets slugged, is asked to autograph a bra and is accosted by a wildly sarcastic ghetto black who wants to know what McKay is going to do for his dog."The Candidate" is serious, but its tone is coldly comic, as if it had been put together by people who had given up hope. This is especially apparent in the progression of McKay (Redford's best performance to date), who begins as a politically uncommitted, liberal lawyer, fighting local battles for civil rights, ecology and such, and in the course of the campaign becomes, not corrupted, but rather neutralized, defused."What do we do now?" he asks when it's all over. It's a funny line that includes just a hint of doom, nothing as specific and immediate as a diagnosis of terminal cancer. The doom is farther off yet it will be no less fatal. The character suggests a young Kennedy or a Tunney, and he actually does have the sort of appeal that turns conservative old women into instant activists. However, in the course of the film the character takes on its own fictional life, and that is practically unheard of in movies of this sort, which usually rely on real-life identification.Almost as good as Redford are the members of the supporting cast, including Peter Boyle as McKay's campaign manager, Don Porter as the beautiful old incumbent, Allen Garfield as an ad-agency genius and Melvyn Douglas as McKay's father. A crucial and sad moment in the film is the television debate between the candidates, when McKay belatedly tries to talk about "issues" and simply flounders around. "I wonder if anyone knew what I was trying to say," he asks his father. Answers Douglas with pride: "Don't worry. It doesn't make any difference."

C.I am a doctor, deeply concerned with the dangers in herent in accidental poisoning of chil dren, and for the last 35 years I have been urging manufacturers not to tell small children that medication is just like candy. The con sequence is that the United States has too many dollars which it doesn't want to keep at home.

description: As the Fleischmann Commis sion enters the final stages of its massive study of education in New York State, a new and perhaps dominant doctrine is emerging from its deliberations: Do not let ultimate decisions about what happens to children in classrooms be made by any one but the teachers, principals, parents and students immedi ately involved.

description: Paul M. Branzburg, who was with The Louisville CourierJournal when he was called before local grand juries in Kentucky, was no stranger to legal processes even then. He had already graduated from Harvard Law School.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 29 (UPI)State Assembly man Vincent Thomas of San Pedro said today that he might propose tax legislation to help lure the Joe Frazier Muhammad Ali heavyweight title rematch to California.

title: JAMES M. STUART, REYNOLDS OFFICER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 29 James M. Stuart, a vice president of the Reynolds Metals Company in New York City, died of a heart attack at his home last evening. He was 51 years old.

title: NORTHWEST PILOTS SET STRIKE TODAY
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 29 (AP)  The 1,600 pilots of North west Airlines decided late to night to go ahead with their, strike against the nation's sev enth largest carrier tomorrow despite a plea by Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson that they continue operations for at least 10 days.

title: Make Place:
description: The stock market has been rather tentative of late, and a number of investment ad visors have been cautioning about the risks of a possible bear market in the months ahead.

title: Transcript of President Nixon's News Conference Emphasizing Foreign Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's televised news confer ence last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Truman Has Sore Back; No Bones Broken in Fall
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., June 29 (UPI)Harry S. Truman, who fell in his home earlier this week was resting with a sore back but no broken bones today.

title: REV. JOHN STOCK
description: CHESTERFIELD TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 29 (AP) The most Rev. John Stock, an auxiliary bishop of the Byzantinerite Ukrainian Catholic Archepar chy of Philadelphia, was killed early today when his car hit a disabled tractor on the New Jersey Turnpike, the police said.

title: Chess? It's Two Armies on the March
description: To a man unfamiliar with chess, except that it seemed vaguely to suggest checkers gone berserk, the approach ing world championship se ries, scheduled to begin in Iceland on Sunday, was rich with the promise of an ad venture in total noncompre hen sion.

title: Two Jewish Leaders Score Minority Job Quotas
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29 The executive heads of two national Jewish organizations condemned today use of the preferential quota to equalize employment and educational opportunities for racial and ethnic minorities, calling it a distortion of antidiscriminaton policies.

title: 95,000 Datsun Light Trucks To Be Recalled by Autumn
description: TOKYO, June 29 (Reuters) The Nissan Motor Company to day announced that it had be gun recalling 95,362 small Dat sun 1300 trucks to replace de ective parts.

title: Corn Pudding and Almond Cake for the Weekend
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an aster isk are followed by a recipe.

title: VIETNAM REPORTING IS TERMED SLANTED
description: A freelance journalist who is executive director of the National Committee for Re sponsible Patriotism said yes terday that much of the news reporting on the North Viet namese invasion of South Viet nam had been slanted, as were accounts of his own factfind ing visit to Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: THE STRANGER IN SHAKESPEARE. By Leslie A. Fiedler. 263 pages. Stein & Day. $7.95.

title: 'Conquest of Planet of Apes' Opens
description: By all rights, the series squeezed from that grand sci-fi thriller, "Planet of the Apes," should he shedding hair all over the place by now. Number Four, "Conquest of the Planet of the Apes," arrived yesterday. It's not bad, as apes and 20th Century-Fox go, at least hand in hand.There's the plot, with a talking chimpanzee befriended by a circus owner and finally leading a swarm of enslaved hairy-clad pals in revolt in a futuristic world of icy-veined humans. The series' writer, Paul Dehn, nimbly continues the story from the predecessor, weaving in just enough crisp philosophizing on both sides to command attention.Furthermore, J. Lee Thompson's direction furiously propels the action in a compact chromium-and-glass settingand wait till you see that last battle royal. Don Murray, Hari Rhodes and Ricardo Montalban do well on the erring human side. But yesterday's audience at the New Embassy cheered the perservering apes and so did I. At 'em, boys!Can an ape look foxy? Roddy McDowall, who steals the picture as their articulate leader, certainly does, with those piercing eyes blinking through a shaggy hide. Anyway, yesterday the apes conquered the planet. Now let's have a sequel called "Take It Back."

title: LATE STOCK RALLY TRIMS EARLY LOSS
description: The stock market continued to slide yesterday, but it added something new on the way down. Some Wall Street an alysts called it the McGovern rally.

title: Family Life When the Father Has to Try Being a Mother, Too
description: WESTPORT, Conn.The ad points to the manwidowed, divorced, separated who is raising his children alone. Even in today's society of changing life styles he is a singular figure, for nationwide statistics show that mothers still pre dominate as single heads of families.

title: Soviet Said to Counsel Arabs to Caution
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 Soviet military experts have re portedly told their Government that the Egyptian and Syrian armies combined cannot yet de feat the Israeli Army, and that if another ArabIsraeli war breaks out there is no guar antee that the Arab disaster of June, 1967, will not be re peated.

title: PRICES OF GRAINS SHOW ADVANCES
description: The imposition of price con trols on certain agricultural commodities sent prices of grains and soybean futures prices up yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade. The con trols affect unprocessed farm products and fish after the first sale.

title: GOLDMAN BEGINS CONCERT SEASON
description: When Florence Schaefer was 8 years old, her father took her to a Goldman Band concert alongside the Butler Library at Columbia University. The year was 1918. If you wanted to sit on a chair, you brought your own, and the mosquitoes were out in full force.

title: President Said to Err On French Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  President Nixon told his news conference tonight that continued bombing would give Hanoi an incentive to return American prisoners of war, rather than not ac count for them, as was the case when the French got out of Vietnam in 1954 and 15,000 French were never accounted for after that.

title: OTB PRAISES SHOP RUN BY EXADDICTS
description: The Offtrack Betting Corpo ration, reviewing its six months of experience with a betting shop run entirely by former drug addicts, decided yesterday to open another such shop, this one entirely for Vietnam veter ans trying to rid themselves of the drug habit.

title: JURY INQUIRY DUE ON SLAYING IN IRT
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts yesterday or dered a grand jury investigation into the fatal shooting of an offduty transit patrolman late Wednesday at the Hunts Point station of the IRT.

title: Threats to Ulster Peace
description: Two things are clear about the fragile peace that has settled over Northern Ireland with the ceasefire by the Irish Republican Army's Provisionals: it cannot endure if Protestant militants set up their own barricaded areas; but the Protestants cannot be deterred from carrying out this threat if the Provos should insist on maintaining their nogo fiefdoms in Belfast and Londonderry.

title: COOLEY AND AIDE CLEARED IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, June 28 (UPI) A United States District Judge exonerated Dr. Denton A. Cooley and his former associ ate, Dr. Domingo Liotta, to night of any negligence in per forming the world's first arti ficial heart transplant.

title: Building Industry Faced With Strikes; 100,000 in 20 Unions May Be Affected
description: The building industry here, with an estimated total of $2 billion in construction projects under way, is faced with the possiblity of serious strikes in the days immediately ahead.

title: PLEA OF MARXIST FOR VISA DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Supreme Court upheld to day the decision of the Attor ney General to exclude a Bel gian Marxist from the United States.

title: Most Correction Officers End Boycott at Prisons
description: Most of the 2,800 members of the Correction Officers Be nevolent Association ended their boycott of prison dining facilities yesterday after an agreement to improve sanitary conditions had been reached by the association and city of ficials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: French Tell of Warhead
description: PARIS, June 24 (UPI)  France said today that she would put, into service in 1976 a hydrogen warhead that would be invulnerable to radiation from antimissile weapons.

title: 4 Rikers Inmates Get 5Year Terms For Actions in Riot
description: Four inmates convicted of tying sheets around the necks of three guards and threaten ing to hang them during the rioting at the Adolescent Re mand Shelter on Rikers Island last Feb. 27 have been sen tenced to five years imprison ment.

title: National City and Fuji Bank Join in Hong Kong Venture
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it had opened a new international merchant bank in Hong Kong, in partnership with the Fuji Bank, Ltd., of Tokyo. The new venture, to be called the Asia Pacific Capital Corporation, Ltd., will specialize in conver tible currency financing in Asia, corporate financial counseling and expects to develop under writing, investment advisory and other securitiesoriented services.

title: Howard S. Cullman, 80, Of Port Authority, Dies
description: Howard S. Cullman, the phi lanthropist, businessman, and Broadway angel who served for 42 years as a commissioner of the Port of New York Au thority and for a decade as its board chairman, died yesterday at his home, 480 Park Avenue. Mr. Cullman, who had been in ill health for some years, was 80 years old.

title: Reducing Gun Charge Is Called Proper
description: The action for which an assistant Queens district at torney was reported to have received a $2,000 bribereduc ing a gun charge from a felony to a misdemeanorappears to have been proper under state law, according to several law enforcement officials.

title: Plans to Ask F.P.C. to Reconsider
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company said yesterday it planned to ask the Federal Power Commission to re consider its approval for the importation of one billion cubic feet of Algerian liquefied nat ural gas (L.N.G.) over the next 25 years.

title: Disappearance of Papers Hampering Levitz Inquiry
description: The disappearance of about 10 important documents and letters involving trading in the common stock of the Levitz Furniture Corporation was re ported yesterday to be im peding one of several investi gations.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A rift between disaffected regulars in the Democratic par ty and members of the state campaign organization of Sen ator George McGovern widened, yesterday when Anthony Scot to, the Brooklyn longshore men's leader, withdrew as a delegateatlarge to the Demo cratic National Convention.

title: Hurting Trees Is Unlawful
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) Two men were arrested re cently on charges of causing injury to trees. The police said the two men were seen throw ing knives at trees in Yale Park near the University of New Mexico campus. The men vio lated a city ordinance.

title: Jersey's No Fault
description: While the lawyerdominated New York State Legisla ture was again rejecting proposals for nofault automo bile insuranceproposals which the New York State Department of Insurance helped to pioneerlawmakers across the Hudson in New Jersey were quietly enacting this fundamental reform calculated to speed recoveries and reduce costs. The theory is that those who sustain injuries in auto accidents have a right to recover their losses regardless of contributory negligence on their part. It places automobile insurance on the same footing other forms of coverage such as health insurance.

title: Miss Cynthia Kinsley Twining Bride of Martin L. Kreiswirth
description: OLDLYME, Conn., July 29  Miss Cynthia Kinsley Twining was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kinsley Twining of River bank, on the Lieutenant River, Old Lyme, to Martin Lewis Kreiswirth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Kreiswirth of Elizabeth, N. J.

title: Executive Changes
description: Herbert V. Kohler Jr., grandson of the founder of the Kohler Company, has been elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Wisconsin based furniture company. Ho replaces Lyman C. Conger, who is retiring.

description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Following are excerpts from the opinions of the nine Su preme Court Justices in the 5to4 decision today outlaw ing the death penalty:

title: Bill to Extend Compensation For Jobless Goes to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate sent to President Nixon today a bill to extend for six months, to Dec. 31, a program of extra unemploy ment compensation benefits to jobless persons in states with high unemployment rates.

title: Mobutu and Cardinal in an Uneasy Truce, but ChurchState Tensions Persist
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  An un easy truce has been called be tween the authoritarian Pres ident of Zaire, Lieut. Gen. Mobutu Sese Seko, and the outspoken Archbishop of Kin shasa, Joseph Cardinal Malula.
